Origin: This kanji is intended to be a pictograph of the sun. Recalling what we said in the previous frame about round forms, it is easy to detect the circle and the big smile that characterize our simplest drawings of the sun - like those yellow badges with the words, "Have a nice day!"
SubOrigin: Used as a primitive, this kanji can mean sun or day or a tongue wagging in the mouth. This latter meaning, incidentally, derives from an old character outside the standard list meaning something like "sayeth" and written almost exactly the same, except that the stroke in the middle does not touch the right side (Frame 620).
Mnemonic1: Open the window, new day.
Mnemonic2: Picture two halves of a 24-hr period: Day & Night.
Compo: 日: day; sun
Ex3English: Japan and the soviet union, japanese-soviet

Origin: In Chinese characters, the number one is laid on its side, unlike the Roman numeral I which stands upright. As you would expect, it is written from left to right.
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, the key-word meaning is discarded, and the single horizontal stroke takes on the meaning of floor or ceiling, depending on its position: if it stands above another primitive, it means ceiling; if below, floor.
Mnemonic1: One down, 2041 to go. ;).
Mnemonic2: To learn this one kanji, I recommend (#2000) this story : Bambi is in a cave, eating a side-dish of salad when trying to learn the kanjis. As he succeed to learn the kanji for "one", you get jealous and decide to shoot him with a slingshot. At this moment you hear the police coming, so you hurriedly burn all the proofs into a fire (so you remove the key-words Bambi, slingshot and fire from recommend). So that when the police arrives, the only remaining clue is a single horizontal bar.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)

Origin: Like the Roman numeral II, which reduplicates the numeral I, the kanji for two is a simple reduplication of the horizontal stroke that means one. The order of writing goes from above to below, with the first stroke slightly shorter.
Mnemonic1: Two lines.
Mnemonic2: Roman numeral II, written on its side.
Compo: 二: two

Origin: And like the Roman numeral III, which triples the numeral I, the kanji for three simply triples the single horizontal stroke. In writing it, think of "1 + 2 = 3" (一 + 二 = 三) in order to keep the middle stroke shorter.
Mnemonic1: One + two = three.
Mnemonic2: THREE measurements define the female shape: BUST, WAIST, and HIPS. Waist is the smallest, and for most women the HIPS are wider than the chest.
Compo: 三: three
Kunyomi: み, み.つ, みっ.つ

Origin: Turn this character 45 degrees either way and you have the x used for the Roman numeral ten.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character sometimes keeps its meaning of ten and sometimes signifies needle, this latter derived from the kanji for needle (Frame 292). Since the primitive is used in the kanji itself, there is no need to worry about confusing the two. In fact, we shall be following this procedure regularly.
Mnemonic1: Two needles crossing marks the spot, or you can use the Roman character for ten (rotated 45 degrees).
Mnemonic2: I scared away ten vampires with a single cross!
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: This character is composed of two primitive elements, mouth and human legs, both of which we will meet in the coming lessons. Assuming that you already knew how to write this kanji, we will pass over the "story" connected with it until later. Note how the second stroke is written left-to-right and then top-to-bottom. This is consistent with what we have already seen in the first three numbers and leads us to a general principle that will be helpful when we come to more complicated kanji later on: write north-to-south, west-to-east, northwest-to-southeast.
Mnemonic1: FOUR year-olds often put their FOOT (human legs) in their MOUTH - but they are too young to realize.
Mnemonic2: I imagine a giant devouring a human in four bites. First the giant bites off the person´s head, then he bites the torso, then from the waist to the knees, and finally the giant plucks up the remaining portion of the human legs into his mouth. See the fourth bite falling in there?
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　儿: human legs
Kunyomi: よ, よ.つ, よっ.つ, よん

Origin: As with four, we shall postpone learning the primitive elements that make up this character. Note how the general principle we just learned in the preceding frame applies to the writing of the character for five.
Mnemonic1: 三 + two vertical lines = 5.
Mnemonic2: This Kanji looks like a "3" Kanji with two added vertical lines. 3+2= 5.
Compo: 五: five

Origin: The primitives here are top hat and animal legs. Once again, we glide over them until later.
Mnemonic1: Indicating 6 parts of the human body: head, body, 2 arms, 2 legs.
Mnemonic2: Six-Six-SIX ((666)) Mark of the Beast!! Imagine that dapper old beastly fellow summoning his top hat to himself. See it scamper over to him on a little pair of beastly legs.
Compo: 六: six
Kunyomi: む, む.つ, むっ.つ, むい

Origin: Note that the first stroke "cuts" through the second. This distinguishes seven from the character for spoon (Frame 476), in which the horizontal stroke stops short.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this form takes on the meaning of diced, i.e., "cut" into little pieces, consistent both with the way the character is written and with its association with the kanji for cut to be learned in a later lesson (Frame 89).
Mnemonic1: This kanji is our good old seven, turned upside down.
Mnemonic2: I wrote it upside down so I crossed it out.
Compo: 七: seven
Kunyomi: なな, なな.つ, なの
Ex1English: The lucky numbers (7-5-3); festival for children of three, five, and seven

Origin: Just as the Arabic numeral "8" is composed of a small circle followed by a larger one, so the kanji for eight is composed of a short line followed by a longer line, slanting towards it but not touching it. And just as the "lazy 8" is the mathematical symbol for "infinity," so the expanse opened up below these two strokes is associated by the Japanese with the sense of an infinite expanse or something "all-encompassing."
Mnemonic1: Hachi (eight) begins with the sound of the katakana "ha", and it´s approximately the same character.
Mnemonic2: The valcano hasn´t erupted for 8 years.
Compo: 八: eight; go in (RTK)
Kunyomi: や, や.つ, やっ.つ, よう

Origin: If you take care to remember the stroke order of this kanji, you will not have trouble later keeping it distinct from the kanji for power (Frame 922).
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall use this kanji to mean baseball team or simply baseball. The meaning, of course, is derived from the nine players who make up a team.
Mnemonic1: Kinda of looks like the kanji of 1 一 with the kanji of 8 八added. So think of it as 一＋八＝九.
Mnemonic2: Warning - naughty reminder A woman in the doggie style position, waiting for my NINE inches.
Compo: 九: nine; baseball (RTK)

Origin: We speak of "round numbers," or "rounding a number off," meaning to add an insignificant amount to bring it to the nearest 10. For instance, if you add just a wee bit, the tiniest drop, to nine, you end up with a round number.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this element takes the meaning of a fat man. Think of a grotesquely fat man whose paunch so covers the plate that he is always getting hit by the pitch. Hence a round baseball player becomes a fat man.
Mnemonic1: Nine plus a drop rounds it off to ten!
Mnemonic2: Watch out for plump (#120). Here Heisig could have added a "t" and we would have had a much better keyword : rotund. Rotund is more specific than "round" which begs for confusion with circle (#1811). A dictionary search on "fat" or "round" doesn´t yield this kanji, but "rotund" does! Primitive suggestion: the Laughing Buddha is often depicted as a rotund, smiling bald man in robes with a largely exposed pot belly stomach (symbolizing plenitude).
Compo: 九: nine; baseball (RTK)　丶: dot; drop
Kunyomi: まる, まる.い, まる.める

Origin: This kanji, also used for Yen, is one you are not likely to need to study formally, since you can hardly get around in Japan without it. The connection is that the yennies, like pennies, are circular in shape. In any case, the elements are: glass canopy . . . walking stick . . . one.
Mnemonic1: The shape of a Yen coin.
Mnemonic2: A poor old man is almost killing himself trying to lift a huge glass hood with his cane (using it as a lever), to get to just one yen coin. Note : the kanji refers to a circular, round object, but also to the Japanese currency (pronounced "en").
Compo: 円: circle; yen

Origin: The character for enter (Frame 842) showed someone walking inwards (in terms of the direction of writing), the one for person, shown here, represents someone walking outwards.
SubOrigin:
As a primitive, it can keep its kanji form except when it appears to the left (its normal position), where it is made to stand up in the form ⺅ (Similar to イ).
The primitive meaning is another matter. The abstract notion of person so often has a relation to the meaning of the kanji that confusion readily sets in. So many of the previous stories have included people in them that simply to use person for a primitive meaning would be risky. We need to be more specific, to focus on one particular person. Try to choose someone who has not figured in the stories so far, perhaps a colorful member of the family or a friend whom you have known for a long time. That individual will appear again and again, so be sure to choose someone who excites your imagination.
Mnemonic1: Behold Mister T (of "A-Team" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he´s sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he´s both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”.
Mnemonic2: (I appreciate some people´s occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.].
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)

Origin: The Japanese refer to a person's 99th birthday as a "white year" because white is the kanji you are left with if you subtract one from a hundred.
Mnemonic1: 100 turned sideways. {sort of the same as what ashoksaraf said}.
Mnemonic2: That dirty ceiling was painted WHITE a hundred times!
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　白: white
Ex2Kana: さんびゃくろくじゅうごにち

Origin: This kanji is almost too simple to pull apart, but for the sake of practice, have a look at the drop above and the ten below. Now put the elements together by thinking of squeezing two more zeros out of an eyedropper alongside the number ten to make it a thousand.
Mnemonic1: It takes many drops of ten to get to a thousand.
Mnemonic2: One T = one thousand.
Compo: 千: thousand

Origin: Japanese counts higher numbers in units of ten thousand, unlike the West, which advances according to units of one thousand. (Thus, for instance, 40,000 would be read "four ten-thousands" by a Japanese.) Given that the comma is used in larger numbers to bind up a numerical unit of one thousand, the elements for one and bound up naturally come to form ten thousand. The order of strokes here needs special attention, both because it falls outside the general principles we have learned already, and because it involves writing the element for bound up in an order opposite to the one we learned. If it is any consolation, this exception is consistent every time these three strokes come together.
Mnemonic1: I bound ten thousand dollars together and hid it under the floor.
Mnemonic2: We have "one" at the top and if you turn the kanji 90 degrees you will see arabic 4 shich means it has four zeros in front of it!
Compo: 万: ten thousand

Origin: Like several of the first characters we shall learn, the kanji for mouth is a clear pictograph. Since there are no circular shapes in the kanji, the square must be used to depict the circle.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this form also means mouth. Any of the range of possible images that the word suggests - an opening or entrance to a cave, a river, a bottle, or even the largest hole in your head - can be used for the primitive meaning.
Mnemonic1: Looks like a huge open mouth.
Mnemonic2: Momma used to say: "Keep your trap shut!" This thing is shaped like a trap door.
Compo: 口: mouth

Origin: Another pictograph, this kanji looks like a bird's-eye view of a rice field divided into four plots. Be careful when writing this character to get the order of the strokes correct. You will find that it follows perfectly the principle stated in frame 4.
SubOrigin: When used as a primitive element, the meaning of rice field is most common, but now and again it will take the meaning of brains from the fact that it looks a bit like that tangle of gray matter nestled under our skulls.
Mnemonic1: A rice field divided into four parts.
Mnemonic2: Ten people use their mouths to eat the yield of the rice fields.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)

Origin: Here again, if we round out the corners of this kanji and curve the middle strokes upwards and downwards respectively, we get something resembling an eye.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the kanji keeps its sense of eye, or more specifically, an eyeball. When placed in the surroundings of a complex kanji, the primitive will sometimes be turned on its side.
Mnemonic1: There are 3 sections. Imagine the outer two being the whites of your eye. The middle is the pupil. Fill it in with imaginary color.
Mnemonic2: 目_目.
Compo: 目: eye

Origin: We have taken the image of a river stream over into English to describe things that fall down in straight lines, or ripple along in lines. All of this is more than evident in the kanji given here, a pictograph of a stream.
SubOrigin:
As a primitive, this character adds to the meaning of stream the more vivid image of a flood. Note, however, that there are certain small changes in the writing of the element, depending on where it appears relative to other elements:
on the left, it is written the same.
on the top, it is written with the three strokes more like less-then signs
on the bottom, it is written with the third stroke similar to a fishhook
Mnemonic1: So as not to confuse this with river (#146) think of streamers falling down.
Mnemonic2: There are three default I/O Streams in UNIX, stdin, stdout, and stderr.
Compo: 巛: river (川); flood (RTK)

Origin: This character is actually a picture of the moon, with the two horizontal lines representing the left eye and mouth of the mythical "man in the moon." (Actually, the Japanese see a hare in the moon, but it is a little farfetched to find one in the kanji.) And one month, of course, is one cycle of the moon.
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, this character can take on the sense of moon, flesh, or part of the body. The reasons for the latter two meanings will be explained in a later chapter.
Mnemonic1: A month is longer than a day.
Mnemonic2: Am I the only one who sees this as someone sticking their ass in the air "mooning" someone (two cheeks of the butt and the legs coming off of it)? The Moon meaning connects well to the meaning of month, considering that months were traditionally measured by the phases of the moon. Also, the mooning "ass" part of it connects well to Hesig´s seemingly unconnected "flesh" or "part of the body" meaning (when used in primitive form).
Compo: 月: moon; month

Origin: Among nature's bright lights, there are two that the biblical myth has God set in the sky: the sun to rule over the day and the moon to rule the night. Each of them has come to represent one of the common connotations of this key word: the sun, the bright insight of the clear thinker, and the moon, the bright intuition of the poet and the seer (see frame 13).
Mnemonic1: The sun makes the moon bright.
Mnemonic2: The sun and the moon are brightest objects in the day and night, respectively.
Compo: 日: day; sun　月: moon; month
Kunyomi: あ.かり, あか.るい, あか.るむ, あか.らむ, あき.らか, あ.ける, -あ.け, あ.く, あ.くる, あ.かす
Ex2English: Bright moon, full moon; harvest moon

Origin: Day . . . feathers . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: weekday (FRAME 576) , laundry (#577), leap (#1285), outstanding (#2272), twinkle (#2534), shimmering (#2880). Story: On weekdays you hang your futon out in the sun.
Mnemonic2: The poor farmer spends every weekday while the sun shines, plucking turkey feathers.
Compo: 日: day; sun　羽: feathers; wings　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Just as sitting before a fire enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames, this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of fire you want to see. It no longer makes a good pictograph, but I invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form - first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there - to see what you can come up with. Everything from matchbooks to cigarette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here. No doubt you, too, will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes.
SubOrigin: To avoid confusion later on, it is best to keep to the meaning of a fireplace (or hearth) or a raging conflagration like a forest fire for this kanji's primitive meaning. Another primitive element for fire, based on this one, is written as 4 small drops and will mean flames, cauldron, cooking fire, or an oven fire.
Mnemonic1: For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!
Mnemonic2: A tepee getting shot at by fire arrows.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)

Origin: This character, which looks a bit like a snowflake, is actually a pictograph of water - not any particular body of water or movement of water, but simply the generic name for water. Should you have any difficulty remembering it, simply think of a walking stick being dropped vertically into the water, sending droplets out in all four directions. Then all you need to learn is how to write it in proper order.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character can keep its form, or it can be written with three drops to the left of another primitive. This latter, as we will see, is far more common.
Mnemonic1: The kanji for water is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes; constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig´s story doesn´t do this).
Mnemonic2: For those having issues with this* "A 7K foot pool of water" Notice it looks like a 7, and a K. Might have to practice writing it a few times.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Here we see a pictograph of a tree, showing the main trunk in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke. The final two strokes sweep down in both directions to indicate the roots. Although it may look similar at first sight to the kanji for water (Frame 137), the order in which it is written is completely different and this affects its final appearance.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji can be used to mean tree or wood. In those cases where the last two strokes are detached from the trunk, we shall change its meaning to pole, or wooden pole.
Mnemonic1: If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.
Mnemonic2: Pictograph of a tree.
Compo: 木: tree; wood

Origin: If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write, I would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows. Anyway, we want to depict bars of gold bullion with an umbrella overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the scepters of the kingdom, drop by drop, and shaping them into bars.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, it means not only gold but any metal at all.
Mnemonic1: The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn´t fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.
Mnemonic2: Under the umbrella´s shade, the king sang, " Drop it to the left, drop it to the right, give me all the GOLD in sight!".
Compo: 金: gold; metal

Origin: I don't like it any more than you do, but this kanji is not the pictograph it is trumped up to be: a mound of soil piled on the ground. All I can recommend is that you memorize it as it is. Anyway, it will be occurring with such frequency that you have almost no chance of forgetting it, even if you try.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the sense of soil is extended to that of ground because of its connection with the kanji for the same (Frame 554). From there it also takes the added meanings of dirt and land.
Mnemonic1: Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground.
Mnemonic2: King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened soil to claim his place as king.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Recalling that books are made of paper, and paper made of trees, one might think of a book as a slice of a tree. Can you seethe "cross-cut" in the trunk of the tree? Picture it as a chainsaw cutting you out a few books with which to start your own private library.
Mnemonic1: The origin of a book is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many books.
Mnemonic2: An axe cutting a tree to make books.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)
Ex2English: The person himself, the said person

Origin: As a "Western" language, English identifies the east with the rising sun. In more fanciful terms, we see the sun piercing through a tree as it rises in the east.
SubOrigin: Both the direction east and the part of the world called "the East" are primitive meanings of this character.
Mnemonic1: Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.
Mnemonic2: The sun pierces through the trees as it rises in the east…
Compo: 木: tree; wood　日: day; sun

Origin: Here we have a simple pictograph of a person, taking up the space of an entire character and giving it the sense of large. It should not be too hard to locate the two legs and outstretched arms.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we need a different meaning, since the element representing the human person will come up later. Therefore, this shape will become a large dog or, if you prefer, a St. Bernard dog. In frame 253 we will explain why this choice was made.
Mnemonic1: A person stretching their arms and legs to look large and scare a bear away.
Mnemonic2: Think of a large St. Bernard dog with his paws all stretched out.
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)
Kunyomi: おお-, おお.きい, おお.いに

Origin: The sense of little that this character represents is not the same as "a little bit." That meaning comes in the next frame. Here little means "small" or "tiny." The image is one of three little drops, the first of which (the one in the middle) is written larger so that the kanji has some shape to it. The point of writing it three times is to rub the point in: little, little, nothing but little.
SubOrigin: The primitive of the same shape keeps the same meaning. Written above a horizontal line, its form is slightly altered, the last two strokes turning inwards.
Mnemonic1: A little penguin with its wings at its side.
Mnemonic2: A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he´s too little to ride the roller coaster.
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)
Kunyomi: ちい.さい, こ-, お-

Origin: The elements here are a walking stick and a mouth. Remember the trouble your mother had getting medicine in your mouth? Chances are it crossed her mind more than once to grab something handy, like your grandfather's walking stick, to pry open your jaws while she performed her duty. Keep the image of getting something in from the outside, and the otherwise abstract sense of this key word should be a lot easier than trying to spoon castor oil into a baby's mouth.
Mnemonic1: Pocky goes in the mouth.
Mnemonic2: My GF lets me come in her mouth (pictogram).
Compo: 口: mouth　丨: line; stick
Ex1English: In; in the middle of; between, among

English: Life, Grow, Be Born, Give Birth To, Student
Origin: A single drop added to the element for grow up gives us the character for life.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we may think of a microscopic cell, that miraculous unit that grows up to become a living being.
Mnemonic1: This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire LIFE, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism.
Mnemonic2: Growing Up is just a Drop of our LIFE.
Compo: 生: life; cell (RTK)
Kunyomi: い.きる, い.かす, い.ける, う.まれる, う.まれ, うまれ, う.む, お.う, は.える, は.やす, き, なま, なま-
Ex2English: Student of the university of tokyo

Origin: Note the clearer outline of a triangular mountain here.
Mnemonic1: Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a mountain often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the mountain (see FRAME 775 for an example).
Mnemonic2: YOU CAN´T POSSIBLY NEED A MNEMONIC FOR THIS!!!!
Compo: 山: mountain

Origin: The kanji for exit pictures a series of mountain peaks coming out of the earth. Learn it together with the following frame.
Mnemonic1: Suddenly, a cactus comes out of the ground with a sign that reads: exit. Now you can leave the desert! (Note: giving this primitive the meaning ´cactus´ can be useful later).
Mnemonic2: The exit lays between these two mountains.
Compo: 山: mountain　山: mountain

Origin: This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking leftwards, putting one leg forward in order to enter someplace. Since the "in" side of a character is the left, it should be easy to remember the writing of this character.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the meaning of the key word is expanded to include: to go in, to put in, to come in, and the like. It generally appears atop its relative primitive, where, unlike the element for umbrella, the two strokes do not touch each other, making it virtually the same as the kanji for eight. When it appears in any other position, however, it retains its original form.
Mnemonic1: Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”.
Mnemonic2: Person enters stage left…
Compo: 入: enter; insert
Kunyomi: い.る, -い.る, -い.り, い.れる, -い.れ, はい.る

Origin: Here we see our famous miraculous magic wand hanging, all on its own, below the ceiling, as you probably already guessed would happen. In addition to giving us two new kanji, the two shapes given in this and the preceding frame also serve to fix the use of the primitives for ceiling and floor, by drawing our attention successively to the line standing above and below the primitive element to which it is related.
Mnemonic1: Roots are below the ground.
Mnemonic2: A magic wand hanging below the ceiling.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)
Kunyomi: した, しも, もと, さ.げる, さ.がる, くだ.る, くだ.り, くだ.す, -くだ.す, くだ.さる, お.ろす, お.りる

Origin: The two directions, above and below, are usually pointed at with the finger. But the characters do not follow that custom, so we have to choose something else, easily remembered. The primitives show a magic wand standing above a floor - "magically," you might say. Anyway, go right on to the next frame, since the two belong together and are best remembered as a unit, just as the words above and below suggest each other.
Mnemonic1: A magic wand standing on above the floor.
Mnemonic2: Above all else, be grounded if you are going to practice augury (#2103)卜. You could turn yourself into a トoad...
Compo: 卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)
Kunyomi: うえ, -うえ, うわ-, かみ, あ.げる, -あ.げる, あ.がる, -あ.がる, あ.がり, -あ.がり, のぼ.る, のぼ.り, のぼ.せる, のぼ.す ・
Ex2English: High and low; rise and fall; first and second (volumes)
Ex3English: One's superiors, one's seniors; one's elders

Origin: The character for stop is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot.
SubOrigin: Although the meaning of stop will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of footprint.
Mnemonic1: If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it´s some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.
Mnemonic2: If you don´t remember this one from the 10,000,000 STOP signs on roads all over Japan, you´re beyyond help!
Compo: 止: stop; footprint (RTK)
Kunyomi: と.まる, -ど.まり, と.める, -と.める, -ど.め, や.める*, や.む*

Origin: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, says the Chinese proverb. Here we see one footprint, complementing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not made correctly, the whole point of the journey will be forfeited. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in correcting their students, and parents in correcting their children.
Mnemonic1: If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.
Mnemonic2: The correct way of learning Japanese? First, stop everything you´re doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig´s book and work from there.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　止: stop; footprint (RTK)
Kunyomi: ただ.しい, ただ.す, まさ, まさ.に

Origin: Mouth . . . mending. Note that the last stroke of mouth and the first of mending overlap.
SubOrigin: As a primitive on the left, it is amended to something similar to correct in place of mending. Its meaning remains leg, but should be thought of as a wooden leg in order to avoid confusion with other similar elements, namely human legs, animal legs, and walking legs.
Mnemonic1: Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale´s mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.
Mnemonic2: I´ll use my mouth to mend your leg, I´ll kiss it all better :).
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)
Kunyomi: あし, た.りる, た.る, た.す
Ex1English: At (under] one's feet; gait, pace, step

Origin: Determination, in the sense of settling on a certain course of action, is likened here to mending one's house.
Mnemonic1: In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher´s HOUSE in various ways.
Mnemonic2: People who decide to renovate (ooh, that´s a fancy word, let´s say "mend") their houses must be very determined DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see DEtermine).
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)
Kunyomi: さだ.める, さだ.まる, さだ.か

English: Hand, Arm; Labor; Skill, Performer Of An Action, -Er
Origin: Any way you count them, there are either too many or too few fingers to see a good pictograph of a hand in this character. But that it is, and so you must.
SubOrigin: Keep to the etymology when using this kanji as a primitive: a single hand all by itself.
Mnemonic1: This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a hand with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.
Mnemonic2: A hand is useful for 千一(1001) things.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)

English: Employ, Use, Things To Do, Business
Origin: Meat . . . walking stick. Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for use (Frame 1065). The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given.
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, we shall substitute the image of a screwdriver, perhaps the most utilized of all tools around the house.
Mnemonic1: To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!
Mnemonic2: I´ll confuse this with use (#990), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, "utilize" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only utilize "utilize" when you´re trying to puff up what you´re saying and sound important. So: "BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, utilizing the our latest FleshGrip(tm) technology!" I´m seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of flesh, a short shaft, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.
Compo: 用: to use; screwdriver (RTK)

Origin: This character is the Japanese character for the supreme philosophical principle of much Oriental thought: nothingness. Make use of the oaken tub from the previous frame, and add to that the oven fire at the bottom.
Mnemonic1: When I enter the wooden tub heated by flames in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into nothingness.
Mnemonic2: In a hot tub you can relax and have your stress vanish into nothingness.
Compo: 無: nothingness

Origin: You may play with the primitives of this kanji as you wish (ceiling . . . person . . . a drop of), but you will probably find that its simplicity, and its frequency, make it easy to remember just as it is.
Mnemonic1: (Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer´s face, he says "Negative".
Mnemonic2: One below zero is a negative number.
Compo: 不: not

Origin: The suffix "-times" refers to a number of repetitions. Its elements: a mouth . . . pent in. Hint: you may find it more helpful to forget the primitives and think of one circle revovling inside of another.
Mnemonic1: Write mouth two -times.
Mnemonic2: Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　口: mouth
Kunyomi: まわ.る, -まわ.る, -まわ.り, まわ.す, -まわ.す, まわ.し-, -まわ.し

Origin: Of all the things we can do with our mouths, speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the kanji for say has four little sound-waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement.
SubOrigin: This kanji, which appears often as a primitive, can mean saying, speech, or words, depending on which is most useful.
Mnemonic1: A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.
Mnemonic2: This is simple a pictogram of a mouth SAYing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.
Compo: 言: word; say

Origin: The primitive for mouth and the character for thousand naturally form the idea of tongue if one thinks of a thousand mouths able to speak the same language, or as we say, "sharing a common tongue." It is easy to see the connection between the idiom and the kanji if you take its image literally: a single tongue being passed around from mouth to mouth.
Mnemonic1: What is in a mouth that permits it to speak a thousand things? Yes, a tongue.
Mnemonic2: Kissing a thousand mouths eventually gets you some tongue.
Compo: 千: thousand　口: mouth

Origin: That the words of the tongue should come to mean a tale is clear from the etymology: a tale is something "talked," not something read from a book.
Mnemonic1: Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen.
Mnemonic2: Tales are spoken words, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a thousand mouths.
Compo: 言: word; say　舌: tongue

Origin: When we speak of a lively personality or a lively party, we immediately think of a lot of chatter. This kanji depicts the idea of lively by having tongues babble and splash around like flowing water.
Mnemonic1: Conversations can become more lively after everyone has had a few drinks. It´s because "watery tongues" loosen lips!
Mnemonic2: I´m sure I can get her pretty lively and wet using my tongue.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　舌: tongue

English: Go, Proceed, Act, Perform, Line (Of Print)
Origin: By joining the top four strokes, you should get a picture of the front current of a river, the stream trailing behind. Hence the character for going.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character has two forms. Reduced to the left side only, it can mean a column, going, or a line of something or other. When the middle is opened up to make room for other elements, it means a boulevard.
Mnemonic1: I use The Flash for for this primitive; a superhero who is always going very fast.
Mnemonic2: To me, this looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　丁: street; nail (RTK)
Onyomi: コウ, ギョウ, アン
Kunyomi: い.く, ゆ.く, -ゆ.き, -ゆき, -い.き, -いき, おこな.う

Origin: This character, a pictographic representation of the heart, is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet.
SubOrigin:
As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings.
In its kanji-form, it appears BENEATH or to the RIGHT of its relative primitive and means th physical organ of the heart.　
To the LEFT, it is abbreviated to three strokes, ⺖, and means a wildly emotional state of mind.
And finally, at the very BOTTOM, it can take the form ⺗, in which case we give it the meaning of a valentine.
Mnemonic1: The four chambers in the heart. In the West, we point to our head when asked about the mind. In the East, they point to the heart. So then, the radical for "state of mind"…
Mnemonic2: Heart needs three drops of blood to work.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Ex2English: One's true mind, one's real intention; one's conscience

Origin: The pictograph for the ear looks much like that for eye, but note how the stroke order gives it a different look.
Mnemonic1: Your ear is like the eye on the side of your head for seeing things, but there is hair around it that creates jagged lines.
Mnemonic2: Pictograph, see book. * The primitive meaning can easily be extended to ear plugs.
Compo: 耳: ear

English: Again; Also, Or, In Other Words
Origin: Like the several abbreviations in Roman script to indicate "and" (+, &, etc.), this short two-stroke kanji is used for the similar meaning of or again.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, it will mean crotch, as in the crotch of the arm. Or whatever.
Mnemonic1: After her boyfriend´s crotch has been satisfied, a woman might suggest they cuddle. The boyfriend, on the other hand, might say, "Or again, we could fool around . . . ".
Mnemonic2: This keyword should really be "again" not "or again" Here is some context: think of the phrase "Jya mata" "じゃ又" which is a farewell similar to "then again". Also "Mata ne" "又ね" and mata ashita (again tomorrow) "又明日"。 Note this kanji is rarely used, most of the time JP people spell it out "mata" except for in the last example: 又明日.
Compo: 又: again; crotch (RTK)
Kunyomi: また, また-, また.の-

Origin: Ear . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: You put your ear next to a womans crotch...and somehow, from it, you hear the words "Take me....".
Mnemonic2: Fuaburisu´s with a twist: You know that classic trick where someone pretends to take something out of an someone else´s ear (such as a coin). Instead of a cigarette or a pen he pulls the person’s crotch out of their ear. Very painful!
Compo: 耳: ear　又: again; crotch (RTK)
Kunyomi: と.る, と.り, と.り-とり-, -ど.り
Ex3English: Take (pick] up; confiscate; deliver a baby; accept, listen to; adopt (a proposal)

Origin: The key word somebody was chosen to convey the double meaning of this kanji: body and person. Its composition is based on the nose (which, you will recall, is also the kanji for oneself). The extension of the bottom and far right strokes of that element, together with the unusual diagonal stroke, forms the pictograph of somebody with a prominent paunch.
Mnemonic1: Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than someone (#1256) is that the story is full of body descriptions.
Mnemonic2: Somebody was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.
Compo: 身: body
Ex4English: (one's) body; one's person, oneself; one's position

Origin: Person . . . tree. Be sure not to confuse with relax (Frame 202).
Mnemonic1: Mr T resting by a tree.
Mnemonic2: Chuck norris rests againsts the tree, but wait, no... the tree rests and stands against him.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: やす.む, やす.まる, やす.める

Origin: Person . . . book.
Mnemonic1: Mister T works out his body (body-building), using two piles of books (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push-ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps).
Mnemonic2: Mr. T works out his body then rips a book apart to test is body. His favorite to destroy is Dianetics.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　本: book

Origin: Person . . . words.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T has faith in the Word of God. (Image: Mr. T kneeling and prayering in front of a bible. "Pity me, fool.").
Mnemonic2: Faith is believing that a person will be true to his word.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　言: word; say

English: Attach, Be Attached To, Hand Over
Origin: Person . . . glue. The few cases in which this character serves as a primitive should include some connotation of "adhering to" that distinguishes it from "glued to." Two examples follow.
Mnemonic1: 賀 TO EVERYONE WHO MADE IT TO 千 kanji!! Remember, after this, you´ll be 読ing japanese novels, the news, and the internet like a native. 吉 to ALL of you in your amazing japanese 往. :).
Mnemonic2: If a PERSON ADHERES to something, they stick to it like GLUE.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)
Kunyomi: つ.ける, -つ.ける, -ず.ける, つ.け, つ.け-, -つ.け, -ず.け, -ずけ, つ.く, -ず.く, つ.き, -つ.き, -つき, -ず.き, -ずき
Ex2English: Attach, fasten; put (one thing on another)

Origin: Birdhouse . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: The bird house is the brothel (someone else said so) and of course everyone is welcome - thay accept any crotch.
Mnemonic2: A birdhouse is a whorehouse that will accept any crotch even those with STDs. (Image: a birdhouse whorehouse with every kind of bird coming and going. Some old madam at the front hole accepts everyone, even the nasty old crows).
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　冖: crown 　又: again; crotch (RTK)
Kunyomi: う.ける, -う.け, う.かる
Ex2English: Reception (of radio waves); receipt of a message

English: To The … Of, By Means Of
Origin: Picture a person dragging a plow behind, and the drop of sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living "by means of the sweat of their brows."
Mnemonic1: A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age "ard" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox.
Mnemonic2: Mr T now makes a living by means of a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it.
Compo: 以: by means of
Ex1English: Not more than, under; the following
Ex2English: Not less than; beyond; the above-mentioned; now that; that's all

Origin: This picture of a vase standing up has its meaning extended to represent the general posture of anything standing up.
SubOrigin: Used as a primitive, it can also mean vase. Using its kanji meaning, think of something standing up that is normally lying down, or something standing up in an unusual way.
Mnemonic1: A vase that can´t stand up won´t be a vase for long.
Mnemonic2: He was a stand up guy: he´d lend you the top hat he wears everyday if you asked, and he will turn everything upside down to help you find your tools.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)
Kunyomi: た.つ, -た.つ, た.ち-, た.てる, -た.てる, た.て-, たて-, -た.て, -だ.て, -だ.てる
Ex3English: Stand up, rise to one's feet

Origin: Muzzle . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: Within the city walls, this section of town was so noisy that we had to muzzle them up.
Mnemonic2: The section within the city walls where dogs must be muzzled by law...
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　口: mouth　邑: village; city walls (阝)
Ex1English: Part, portion, section; a copy (of printed matter)

Origin: Person . . . muzzle. Do not confuse with the kanji for duplicate (Frame 504).
Mnemonic1: Mr. T keeps his double muzzled ... he wants all the glory.
Mnemonic2: Mr T, like many holywood stars, has a butt double who is used only for scenes where T´s buttocks are exposed (he has issues with bearing his behind). The butt double has no speaking parts - he is muzzled. Of course T himself isn´t he´s rambling on about pity and foo.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Let the phrase "turn into" suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the parade marching down main street turns into a dagger-throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change.
Mnemonic1: It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath.
Mnemonic2: The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.
Compo: 戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)
Ex2English: Become, form, consist of; be accomplished
Ex4English: Come into existence; be formed, be organized

English: Replace, Substitute, Generation, Age, Charge, Fare
Origin: Person . . . arrow.
Mnemonic1: Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It´s best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to "mediator" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T shot the substitute teacher with an arrow.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　弋: ceremony; arrow (RTK)
Kunyomi: か.わる, か.わり, -が.わり, か.える, よ, しろ

Origin: See what you can do to come up with a pictograph of a king's scepter here that suits your own idea of what it should look like. You might even begin with the basic element for I beam and then try to fit the remaining third stroke in.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this can mean either king or scepter, but it will usually be taken to mean ball, as an abbreviation of the character in the next frame.
Mnemonic1: To be king you have to be a real crafty one !
Mnemonic2: The king unites heaven and earth. (imagine heaven being the top line over the soil).
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: Note the drop here in the king's scepter, which is exactly what you would expect it to be: a precious jewel handed down from of old as a symbol of his wealth and power.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we can use this to mean either jewel or ball. When it appears anywhere other than on the left side of a kanji, it takes the same shape as here. On the left, it will be lacking the final stroke, making it the same as the character in the previous frame.
Mnemonic1: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...
Mnemonic2: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the "drop").
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Every house has its treasure, as every thief knows only too well. While the things we treasure most are usually of sentimental value, we take the original sense of the term treasure here and make it refer to jewels kept in one's house.
Mnemonic1: On treasure island is a single house - where all the jewels are stored.
Mnemonic2: Put a "roof" (lid) on your jewels and voila! You´ve got a treasure chest.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　玉: jewel; ball

Origin: Jewels . . . pent in.
Mnemonic1: In my country (England) the crown jewels are kept pent-in in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also pent-in (probably for trying to steal those jewels).
Mnemonic2: Just think of Japan, a country which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　玉: jewel; ball

Origin: The color white is a mixture of all the primary colors, both for pigments and for light, as we see when a prism breaks up the rays of the sun. Hence, a single drop of sun spells white.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character can either retain its meaning of white or take the more graphic meaning of a white bird or dove. This latter stems from the fact that it appears at the top of the kanji for bird, which we shall get to later (Frame 2091).
Mnemonic1: A white ray is a drop of sun.
Mnemonic2: Even a small drop (´) of the sun (日) would make you see nothing but white.
Compo: 日: day; sun　丶: dot; drop
Kunyomi: しろ, しら-, しろ.い

Origin: An emperor, as we all know, is a ruler - something like a king but higher in status. The white bird perched above the king, elevating him to imperial heights, is the messenger he sends back and forth to the gods to request advice and special favors, something that white birds have long done in folklore throughout the world.
Mnemonic1: Ancient Rome had Emperors instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an emperor is a king in white. (make sure you picture a roman emperor not a japanese one and you´ll be ok).
Mnemonic2: The white dove descended on the king and he was promoted to emperor.
Compo: 白: white　王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: Wholeness suggests physical and spiritual health, "having your act together." The kanji-image for wholeness depicts being "king under your own umbrella," that is, giving order to your own life. I know it sounds terribly abstract, but what could be more abstract than the word whole?
Mnemonic1: The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro´s story. "fat" makes a more vivid image for me.).
Mnemonic2: The king takes up the whole space under his umbrella.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: The sage talks rapidly with his tongue wagging in his mouth, while the brush of the scribe runs apace to write down the master 'swords.
Mnemonic1: Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down.
Mnemonic2: The calligrapher had a peculiar habit: when using her brush to write, she would stick out her tongue, just slightly.
Compo: 聿: brush; rake (RTK)　日: day; sun

Origin: This key word here refers to abstract matters. The elements are: one . . . mouth . . . rake. Note how the rake handle reaches out the top and bottom of the character.
Mnemonic1: I had to take one day off from work due to ´personal matters´ after stepping on a rake and having the handle snap up and smack me across the mouth. I certainly wasn´t going to tell anyone about it.
Mnemonic2: Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.
Compo: 事: thing; matter

Origin: You can think of this kanji as a stylized pictograph of the nose, that little drop that Mother Nature set between your eyes. The Japanese refer to themselves by pointing a finger at their nose - giving us an easy way to remember the kanji for oneself.
SubOrigin: The same meaning of oneself can be kept when this kanji is used as a primitive element, but you will generally find it better to give it the meaning of nose or nostrils, both because it accords with the story above and because it is the first part of the kanji for nose (Frame 733).
Mnemonic1: Faced with his clone, our hero valiantly cut a mark on his forehead right above his eye so that his comrades could tell his true oneself from the enemy.
Mnemonic2: To use an eyedropper by oneself, aim from above to put a drop into the eye.
Compo: 目: eye　丶: dot; drop
Kunyomi: みずか.ら, おの.ずから*

Origin: To remember the primitive elements that make up this kanji, an eye and animal legs, you might be tempted to think of it as a pictograph of a shellfish with its ridged shell at the top and two little legs sticking out of the bottom. But that might not help you recall later just how many ridges to put on the shell. Better to imagine a freakish shellfish with a single, gigantic eye roaming the beaches on its slender little legs, scaring the wits out of the sunbathers.
SubOrigin: When used as a primitive, in addition to shells, the meanings oyster and clam will often come in handy.
Mnemonic1: Eye thought I saw a shellfish legging it down the beach!
Mnemonic2: Stare at the shellfish, it looks like an eye with legs.
Compo: 目: eye　ハ: animal legs (RTK)

Origin: The elements that compose the character for see are the eye firmly fixed to a pair of human legs. Surely, somewhere in your experience, there is a vivid image just waiting to be dragged up to help you remember this character....
Mnemonic1: As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. (the giant eyeball with legs...) Makes for easy stories later on.
Mnemonic2: Eyes and legs are all you need to see the world.
Compo: 目: eye　八: eight; go in (RTK)
Kunyomi: み.る, み.える, み.せる

Origin: With a little imagination, one can see a muscle in this simple, two-stroke character meaning power.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, either muscle or power can be used.
Mnemonic1: I always refer to the power of the KATAKANA "KA".
Mnemonic2: I have a very powerful muscle カ in my driveway!
Compo: 力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Although this character no longer looks very much like a sword, it does have some resemblance to the handle of the sword. This is to our advantage, in that it helps us keep make a distinction between two primitive elements based on this kanji.
SubOrigin: In the form of the kanji, this primitive means a dagger. When it appears to the right of another element, it is commonly stretched out and takes the sense of a great and flashing saber, a meaning it gets from a character we shall learn later (Frame 1801).
Mnemonic1: This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.
Mnemonic2: If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there sword in his ass!
Compo: 刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: To the right we see the dagger and next to it the number seven whose primitive meaning we decided would be diced (Frame 7). It is hard to think of cutting anything with a knife without imagining one of those skillful Japanese chefs. Only let us say that he has had too much to drink at a party, grabs a dagger lying on the mantelpiece and starts dicing up everything insight, starting with the hors d'oeuvres and going on to the furniture and the carpets....
Mnemonic1: The seven samurai used their swords to cut their opponents.
Mnemonic2: Seven swords cut better than one.
Compo: 七: seven　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Kunyomi: き.る, -き.る, き.り, -き.り, -ぎ.り, き.れる, -き.れる, き.れ, -き.れ, -ぎ.れ

Origin: Think of using a dagger as a razor blade, and it shouldn't be hard to imagine cutting yourself. See the little drop of blood clinging to the blade?
Mnemonic1: The part of a sword where a drop of blood can usually be found is the blade.
Mnemonic2: A drop of blood on the blade of my sword.
Compo: 刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Go in . . . dagger.
Mnemonic1: When something is entered by a dagger, it ends up being cut in several parts.
Mnemonic2: (This kanji also has the meanings of "understand" and "minute"). It´s important to understand that were you to enter an hour with a dagger and cut it into parts, those parts would be minutes.
Compo: 八: eight; go in (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Kunyomi: わ.ける, わ.け, わ.かれる, わ.かる, わ.かつ
Ex2English: One's social position; one's rank, identity

Origin: Come in . . . elbows. Use the key word in its adjectival sense, not as a noun.
Mnemonic1: I always open the doors to the public restrooms with my elbows because I don´t want to touch the door with my hands.
Compo: 八: eight; go in (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: In the Old East, the samurai and his saber were never separated. They were constant companions, like the cowboy of the Old West and his six-shooter. This character depicts what must have been the height of separation-anxiety for a samurai: to be bound up with a rope and unable to get at his saber leaning only a few feet away from him. Look at that mouth bellowing out for shame and sorrow! Note the order in which the element for tied up is written - just as it had been with the character for ten thousand.
Mnemonic1: I don´t know about you but to me this seems like someone´s head is about to be separated from his body. You can see he´s kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.
Mnemonic2: A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their mouths bound up to keep them quiet) in a separate room from his sabers. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.
Compo: 口: mouth　勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: In line with the story of the preceding frame, the hair that needs the hairpin is long.
SubOrigin: The primitive of this kanji has two more shapes in addition to that of the kanji itself. Above its relative primitive, it is abbreviated form will mean hair. Further abbreviated, it will mean the long, mangy mane of an animal.
Mnemonic1: The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.
Mnemonic2: The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here´s my story: The girl´s hair was so long that she had to use staples instead of hairpins. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.
Compo: 長: long; leader

Origin: Rice fields . . . power. This character is the gender-specific man, not the generic human person of frame 951.
Mnemonic1: Male is seen here as muscles working in the field, in other words working in the rice fields is the work of the male who are usually stronger. This is more or less the meaning of the original Chinese character.
Mnemonic2: When it comes to choosing a MAN, I prefer brains over muscles.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting woman drawn behind this character, with two legs at the bottom, two arms (the horizontal line) and the head poking out the top. A little farfetched, until you draw the character and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes. Remembering the kanji is easy; being able to write it beautifully is another thing.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning is the same: woman.
Mnemonic1: To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a "kunoichi". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一(kanji, ichi=one).
Mnemonic2: My mother taught me that a woman should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).
Compo: 女: woman
Onyomi: ジョ, ニョ, ニョウ

English: Child, Son, Noun Suffix, Small Object
Origin: This kanji is a pictograph of a child wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young children who cannot get around by themselves. The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air; the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up; and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's neck.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the meaning of child is retained, though you might imagine a little older child, able to run around and get into more mischief.
Mnemonic1: A child who is ten will still ask for his ma (top looks a bit like katakana ma).
Mnemonic2: A pictograph of a child, with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).
Compo: 子: child

Origin: The phrase "to be fond of someone" has a natural gentleness about it, and lends a tenderness to the sense of touching by giving us the related term "to fondle." The character likens it to a woman fondling her child.
Mnemonic1: A woman is fond of her child.
Mnemonic2: Jane Fonda carrying a Vietnamese child. Pro-war protesters hold signs, "I´m not fonda Jane!"…
Compo: 女: woman　子: child
Kunyomi: この.む, す.く, よ.い*, い.い*

Origin: To be told that the place of the woman is in the house may not sit well with modern thought, but like all cultural habits the Chinese characters bear the birthmarks of their age. So indulge yourself in a Norman Rockwell image of relaxing after a hard day's work: the scruffy and weary woman of the house slouched asleep in the living room chair, her hair in curlers and a duster lying in her lap.
Mnemonic1: It´s funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive... well... if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman relaxing. Cheapest place to do that is in one´s own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? 家で休暇を取るは安いですね。.
Mnemonic2: You can only relax, when you have woman under roof to do all chores.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　女: woman
Kunyomi: やす.い, やす.まる, やす, やす.らか

Origin: Without much effort, the elements relax . . . tree suggest a hammock strung between two trees in your backyard, and you stretched out in it, hands folded behind your head, planning something or other. After all, it's something we all do from time to time: kick up our legs on the nearest piece of furniture and daydream about the best plan of action to take. Be sure to relate the relaxation to the tree, so that you don't end up with something else in its place (like "legs" or "desk" or "table").
Mnemonic1: I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.
Mnemonic2: If you bring a woman to your house, generally its not a good plan to stick your wood up her bottom, she may scream in pain あん!
Compo: 安: relax　木: tree; wood

Origin: Here is the character for character itself. Not just kanji, but any written character from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet. It shows us simply a child in a house. But let us take advantage of the double-meaning of the key word to note that just as a child born to a Japanese house is given characters for its name, so it is also stamped with the character of those who raise it from infancy on.
Mnemonic1: CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE.
Mnemonic2: Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father? "Shut up! It builds character!".
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　子: child

Origin: The child in the little red schoolhouse is there for one reason only: to study. Anyone who has gone through the schooling system knows well enough that study is one thing and learning quite another again. In the kanji, too, the character for learning (Frame 616) has nothing to do with the schoolhouse.
Mnemonic1: In the school house there are kids always studying. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字).
Mnemonic2: Children in schoolhouses are there to study, nothing else!!!
Compo: ⺍: small　冖: crown 　子: child

Origin: The kindness and hard work of the ideal father is seen in this abbreviation of the taskmaster that leaves off his rod or whip (the first stroke) and replaces it with the sweat of the father's brow (the two drops at the top).
Mnemonic1: Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).
Mnemonic2: Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.
Compo: 父: father

Origin: Under the familiar top hat we see a crisscross pattern or design, like that found on woodwork or garments. This should make an ugly enough image to help remember it. It can be associated with sentence by thinking of a sentence as a grammatical pattern.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning for this character will be plaid, the familiar crisscross pattern frequently used in textiles.
Mnemonic1: A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct sentences, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.
Mnemonic2: The teacher in the tophat puts an X on all the grammatically incorrect sentences.
Compo: 文: literature; plaid (RTK)

Origin: Top hat . . . father.
Mnemonic1: Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can´t give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.
Mnemonic2: Darth Vader tries to mingle with his troops. He even weares one of the helmets of the stromtroopers. (one of them laughs: white helmet, black suit. Darth Vader thereby slashes him in 2).
Compo: 交: mingle
Kunyomi: まじ.わる, まじ.える, ま.じる, ま.ざる, ま.ぜる, -か.う, か.わす

Origin: Tree . . . mingle.
Mnemonic1: With the exam scores posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around looking at the results. test. 試.
Mnemonic2: Note: this Kanji does not mean exam. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as school by itself is not used elsewhere. Examples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief); 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).
Compo: 木: tree; wood　交: mingle

Origin: Look closely at this kanji and you will find the outline of the kanji for woman in it, the second stroke of which has been expanded to make space for the two breasts that make her a mama. Likening this sound to a baby nursing at its mother's breast has afforded some scholars of comparative linguistics a way to explain the presence of the same word across a wide range of language groups.
SubOrigin: As a primitive we shall add the meaning of breasts in accord with the explanation given above. Take careful note of the fact that the form is altered slightly when this kanji serves as a primitive, the final two dots joining together to form a longer stroke. An example follows in the next frame.
Mnemonic1: The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.
Mnemonic2: This mama had twins, one mouth for each nipple.
Compo: 母: mother (毋); breasts (RTK)

Origin: Behind every successful person lies a woman..., who usually turns out to be one's mama!
Mnemonic1: Freud believed every man wants to lie down with his mother.
Mnemonic2: Who does every person want to lie down with? Yo´ MAMA!
Compo: 𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　母: mother (毋); breasts (RTK)

Origin: Behind every drop of water, a sea from which it originated.
Mnemonic1: Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea.
Mnemonic2: As depicted in the classic SF film Fantastic Voyage, every drop of water is a sea, if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast sea teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). Note: Take care not to confuse with ocean (#549).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　毎: every
Ex1English: Ocean day (japanese national holiday, third monday in july)

Origin: Old man . . . sun. This key word looks to be difficult because of its proximity to somebody. In fact, it is a very common kanji that will cause you no difficulty at all. Its meaning should be seen as the human referent for the abstract noun "something."
SubOrigin: As a primitive it means a puppet-on-a-string.
Mnemonic1: I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it´s 者 who can 忍 great 拷!
Mnemonic2: Back in the day, the old man used to be someone. His name was in the papers and all that. I use CHUCKY from the movie Child´s Play as my major alternate meaning for this primitive.
Compo: 老: old man　日: day; sun

Origin: The pictograph of an I beam, like the kind used in heavy construction work on buildings and bridges, gives us the character for craft in general.
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, the key word retains the meaning of craft and also takes on the related meanings of I beam and artificial.
Mnemonic1: I consider craft to be one of the harder primitives to use in stories so I´ve personified it as Bender the crafty robot from Futurama who was designed to bend I-beams.
Mnemonic2: I crafty.
Compo: 工: craft; construction

English: Form, Style, Manner, Ceremony, Rite, Formula
Origin: Take style in its sense of some fashion design or model. Then let the element arrow and craft stand for the well-known style of shirts known as "Arrow shirts" because of the little arrow sewn on each one.
Mnemonic1: Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain style..
Mnemonic2: The latest style is shirts crafted out of arrows.
Compo: 弋: ceremony; arrow (RTK)　工: craft; construction

Origin: We use the Roman numeral II here to stress that this kanji is an older form of the kanji for two. Think of two arrows in a quiver, standing up like the numeral II.
Mnemonic1: II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).
Mnemonic2: Once you have two old arrows left in your quiver, you better start running...!
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　弋: ceremony; arrow (RTK)　二: two

Origin: With a quiver of arrows set on one's back, the goal of the warrior depicted here is not to attack but merely to stop the attack of others: the oldest excuse in history!
Mnemonic1: ONE-ARROW can STOP a warrior.
Mnemonic2: A great warrior can stop any opponent with one arrow.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　弋: ceremony; arrow (RTK)　止: stop; footprint (RTK)

Origin: Remember when your granny used to ask you to bend your arms at the elbows and hold them out so that she could use them like a rack to hold a skein of string or yarn (here thread) while she rolled it up into a little ball? Now can you see the two elbows (with the second stroke doubling up) at the top, and the character for little below?
Mnemonic1: I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I´ve opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as dainty (#1363) and accumulate (#1364).
Mnemonic2: You´ll be seeing this one a lot. Seriously.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)

Origin: We waited to introduce this character until now, even though the pieces have been available for some time, because it helps to reinforce the odd kanji of the last frame. Picture the butcher hacking away with his knife at a slab of meat on his table with a pair of ram's horns placed in front of him (or on his head, if you prefer). There is no need to worry about confusing this kanji with that for before (Frame 263), since it will not appear as a primitive in any other character used in this book.
Mnemonic1: When I get horny my flesh sword sticks out in front of me.
Mnemonic2: If you stand in front of a bull´s horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer).
Compo: 丷: animal horns (RTK)　刖: butcher

Origin: Line . . . cocoon . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self behind.
Mnemonic2: after a grub goes through the cocoon stage, it leaves its walking legs behind for a life of flight.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)
Kunyomi: のち, うし.ろ, うしろ, あと, おく.れる
Ex2English: After this, from now on, in future; thereafter

Origin: With a bit of stretching, you might see a horse's head pointing leftwards in this character. That gives the primary meaning of the Chinese zodiacal sign of the horse, which corresponds to the hour of noon. Note how this kanji primitive differs from that for cow (Frame 260).
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character gets the meaning of a horse. Any horse image will do, except that of a team of horses, which will come later (Frame 2132) and get its own primitive.
Mnemonic1: Noon is a good time for a ten minute nap (using lie down as nap).
Mnemonic2: Noon is the hour of the horse.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　干: dry

Origin: Can you the "doodle" of a cow that has just been run over by a steamroller? The small dot in the first stroke shows its head turned to one side, and the next two strokes, the four legs.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the same sense of cow is kept. Note only that when it is placed OVER another element, its tail is cut off. In this case, and when the element appears on the left, the stroke order is changed.
Mnemonic1: A cow tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off.
Mnemonic2: A cow bleeds vermilion when you cut off two of it´s legs.
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)

Origin: In an odd fashion, the kanji for year joins together the element for horse, on the top, and the right half of the element for sunglasses. Think of it as a horse wearing sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later.
Mnemonic1: A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year.
Mnemonic2: A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like descend (#1308).
Compo: 年: year

Origin: Person . . . cow.
Mnemonic1: Note: this kanji refers to event or case. Current Affair headline: Mr. T has affair with cow. "It´s only animal ´man´ enough for me".
Mnemonic2: I´m having a hard time keep straight just which animal Mr. T is having an affair with. chamcham´s story made me realize that Mr. T is not having an "affair", he´s having an "heifair." Get it?
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　牛: cow (⺧)
Ex1English: Matter (of business), things to be done

Origin: Geppetto made walking legs for his little Pinocchio from two twigs of a tree, giving him a set of "twiggy" shanks.
Mnemonic1: They all say they have a TREE between their WALKING LEGS but most only have a TWIG.
Mnemonic2: Don´t confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping twigs. A twig is always the kind of wood that snaps when the hunter´s walking legs just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter´s presence.
Compo: 夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Person . . . spoon.
Mnemonic1: Referring to a scene in the movie "The Matrix" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine Mister T who changes a spoon into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of "spare change", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as "shape" or "turn into".
Mnemonic2: Mr. T reaches into his wallet for some spare change but it has all changed into spoons.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　匕: spoon
Ex1English: Change oneself into, take the form of; disguise oneself

Origin: Flower . . . change.
Mnemonic1: The flowers change with the seasons.
Mnemonic2: The flower is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual flower involves both the concept of flower plus change.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　化: change

Origin: The cold air from the north is so strong that we see two people sitting on the ground back to back, their arms interlocked so they don't blow away. (Pay special attention to the drawing of the first 3 strokes.)
Mnemonic1: Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!
Mnemonic2: In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.
Compo: 北: north

Origin: With two spoons, one in each hand, you are comparing your mother's cooking with your mother-in-law's.
Mnemonic1: A gay couple about to turn around to compare which role is better...
Mnemonic2: Compare the two spoons... the one on the left is funny-looking.
Compo: 匕: spoon　匕: spoon

Origin: One's stature is measured according to the "northern-most" part of the body.
Mnemonic1: While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller stature because of all the flesh they eat!
Mnemonic2: Up in the Great White North, we eat a lot of meat - thus giving us great STATURE. Mmmm.... baby seals.
Compo: 北: north　月: moon; month
Kunyomi: せ, せい, そむ.く, そむ.ける

Origin: You may keep the whole range of connotations for this keyword, car, provided it does not interfere with the pictograph. Look for the front and back wheels (the first and last horizontal strokes) and the seat in the carriage in the middle. As an exercise, try to isolate the primitives on your own and make a story out of them.
SubOrigin: Car, cart, wagon, and vehicle may all be used as primitive meanings.
Mnemonic1: My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.
Mnemonic2: Rather than hobbling along with a walking stick to cross through a span, it´s much better to use a car. (Imagine an old man with a walking stick creeping along a span of road, and you, in a car, whizzing right by him. It´s funny ´cause it´s true.) Also, it´s important to include the word "through," so you know the walking stick goes right THROUGH the span.
Compo: 車: car

Origin: The spirit in this character refers to the changeable moods and airs of one's personality as well as to the more essential combination of vital forces that distinguish things and individuals one from the other. Its elements are: reclining . . . floor . . . fishhook . . . sheaf. Do not confuse with spirits (Frame 1930).
Mnemonic1: You´re reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you´ve been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit.
Mnemonic2: Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws.
Compo: 气: spirit　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)

Origin: Think of this character as a sibling of that for spirit. Simply replace sheaves with drops of water on the left in order to get vapor.
Mnemonic1: Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.
Mnemonic2: Wolverine disappears into water vapor, seemingly his spirit dissipating into nothingness.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　气: spirit

Origin: State of mind . . . cell.
Mnemonic1: Sex is the only state of mind for many men through their whole life.
Mnemonic2: When you´re in the state of mind for creating new lives.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　生: life; cell (RTK)

Origin: Looking at the primitives, a fireplace and a rice field, we find the essential ingredients for a farm: a warm hearth to sit by at night, and a well-plowed field to grow one's crops in by day.
Mnemonic1: Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.
