Mnemonic2: When creating a farm, the prospective farmer must first set fire to the forest to clear the ground. Only then can he plow the fields. Fire before fields to make a farm.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)
Kunyomi: はた, はたけ, -ばたけ

Origin: Grow up . . . moon.
Mnemonic1: The last time I saw a blue moon was in my youth when I was growing up.
Mnemonic2: Once in a blue moon refers to a rare event. But originally "blue moon" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we´re talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.
Compo: 龶: grow up, master (RTK)　月: moon; month
Kunyomi: あお, あお-, あお.い

Origin: Grow up . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: BARLEY beverages give GROWN UPs teetering WALKING LEGS.
Mnemonic2: Grown up barley, i.e. beer, is what gets you tottering legs.
Compo: 龶: grow up, master (RTK)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)

Origin: Grow up . . . thread.
Mnemonic1: This kanji has nothing to do with elementary school - it means element, elemental, basic, bare. Imagine the thread as a thread connecting all life, starting from the basic elements and growing up into everything.
Mnemonic2: This is a pictogram of string theory. Strings are the most elementary particles of matter, which then grow up to become matter itself.
Compo: 龶: grow up, master (RTK)　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)

Origin: Grow up . . . breasts.
Mnemonic1: If you grow up with a mother that drinks and smokes, you can be sure it´s poison in the stuff you get from her breasts.
Mnemonic2: You can use silicone implants to to make your breasts "grow up" but if they leak, it's poison.
Compo: 龶: grow up, master (RTK)　母: mother (毋); breasts (RTK)

Origin: Take this key word in its physical, not its temporal, sense (even though it refers to both). If you have a cow with human legs, as the elements show us here, it can only be because you have two people in a cow-suit. I always thought I'd prefer to be the one standing before, rather than the one that holds up the rear and becomes the "butt" of everyone's laughter.
Mnemonic1: I´ve never seen a cow with human legs before!
Mnemonic2: Nasty story but it keeps the meaning true to the kanji. "BEFORE you stick it in a COW and SPREAD the legs (the bottom stroke of this cow looks like two legs) make sure she has HUMAN LEGS"-------------sorry, I´ll remove if I get enough reports, but will keep if I get more stars.
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　儿: human legs
Ex3English: Point, tip; the future; destination; first, ahead of; before, earlier

Origin: This character is so logical that one is tempted to let the elements speak for themselves: water . . . before. But we have already decided we will not allow such rationalism to creep into our stories. Not even this once. Instead, let us change the character from the Peanuts comic strip called "Pigpen," who is always preceded by a little cloud of dust and grime, and rename him "Wash-Out." Everywhere he walks, a spray of water goes before him to sanitize everything he touches.
Mnemonic1: In Japan, you always wash with water from the shower before you enter the bathtub.
Mnemonic2: You wash things with WATER to get them back to the clean state they were in BEFORE.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　先: before; ahead

Origin: In the beginning... starts that marvelous shelf of books we call the Bible. It talks about how all things were made, and tells us that when the Creator came to humanity she made two of them, man and woman. While we presume she made two of every other animal as well, we are not told as much. Hence we need only two and a pair of human legs come to the kanji that means beginning.
Mnemonic1: In the beginning were just two who walked on human legs.
Mnemonic2: In the beginning God created woman, and God asked her how she liked his work. Woman replied, "Well, you know how I have two eyes, two arms, two legs... it seems redundant to have three breasts. It would look more symmetrical with two." God nodded, and the middle breast fell off... and it was good. Woman picked up the breast and said, "Thank you, God! But what do I do with this useless boob?" And God created man. That´s why the women today only have two boobs to match their two human legs.
Compo: 二: two　儿: human legs
Ex2English: Originally, from the first; by nature

Origin: There are really only 2 primitives here, little and human legs. The 4th stroke that separates them is added for reasons of aesthetics. (If that doesn't make sense, try writing the kanji without it and see how ugly the results look, even to your beginner's eye.) Now if you have wondered what those little particles of "dust" are that dance around in the light-rays that come through the window and fall on your desk, try imagining them as little and disembodied human legs, and you should have no trouble with this character.
Mnemonic1: A ray of light is not a wave but made of little photons with human legs.
Mnemonic2: The ray from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people little - ha! look at them run around on their tiny legs!
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　兀: dangerous

English: Go Away, Leave; Go By, Elapse
Origin: Soil . . . elbow.
Mnemonic1: Going, going, GONE!, said the gravedigger as he shoveled soil onto the body´s protruding elbow (the last bit left to cover).
Mnemonic2: If you want the soil stains gone from your clothes, then you´ll need to put some elbow grease into cleaning them.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . gone.
Mnemonic1: This kanji shows up in a lot of words related to the legal process. Try this image: using a very outdated judicial method, the people of Salem dunked accused witches in the water until they were all gone.
Mnemonic2: There already was a system (#418) for butchering cows, a technique (#421) for turning smoke into flowers - why can´t there be a method of about the same relevance for making water gone? Evaporation anyone?
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　去: gone
Onyomi: ホウ, ハッ-, ホッ-
Ex3English: Way of life, art of living

Origin: Running, we are told here, mends the soil. Observe in the following frames how this kanji can embrace other elements from below, much the same way as the element for road does; and how, in order to do this, the final stroke needs to be lengthened.
Mnemonic1: Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!
Mnemonic2: The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been RUNNING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)

English: The Present, The Said, This/That, Hit (The Mark); Correspond To; Allot
Origin: Little . . . broom.
Mnemonic1: Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.
Mnemonic2: Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a broom like a javelin and throw it, trying to hit the center of a very small target. The target is so small, in fact, that if someone does manage to hit it, the operator turns in surprise and says, "Whoa, really?! (本当?!)".
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)
Kunyomi: あ.たる, あ.たり, あ.てる, あ.て
Ex3Kana: いちにちあたりせんえん

Origin: Brains . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Think with your brain NOT your heart.
Mnemonic2: To think is to use your brain over your heart.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: This kanji is actually a picture of the first flower of the day, which we shall, in defiance of botanical science, call the sunflower, since it begins with the element for sun and is held upon a stem with leaves (the pictographic representation of the final two strokes). This time, however, we shall ignore the pictograph and imagine sunflowers with needles for stems, which can be plucked and used to darn your socks. The sense of early is easily remembered if one thinks of the sunflower as the early riser in the garden, because the sun, showing favoritism towards its namesake, shines on it before all the others (see frame 10).
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, this kanji takes the meaning of sunflower, which was used to make the abstract key word early more graphic.
Mnemonic1: The sun up is early, well before ten.
Mnemonic2: An early sun-flower looks like a miniature sun perched on a needlelike stems.
Compo: 日: day; sun　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)
Kunyomi: はや.い, はや, はや-, はや.まる, はや.める
Ex4English: A little early, with time to spare

Origin: Perhaps you know the custom of seeding grass randomly or in some particular pattern with the flower called the crocus, which blooms for a few days each year in early spring. As the grass begins to turn green again after winter has passed, these tiny flowers dot up here and there. Now just look out your window at a patch of grass somewhere and think what a nice idea it would be to have your name spelled out in flowers once as a sort of early harbinger of spring.
Mnemonic1: Grass grows in earlier than flowers.
Mnemonic2: This grass is very long. The only flowers you can see are sunflowers – the rest are hidden by the grass.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　早: early; fast; sunflower (RTK)

Origin: On the right we see the moon fading off into the first light of morning, and to the left, the mist that falls to give nature a shower to prepare it for the coming heat. If you can think of the moon tilting over to spill mist on your garden, you should have no trouble remembering which of all the elements in this story are to serve as primitives for constructing the character.
Mnemonic1: There is mist as the moon fades away in the morning.
Mnemonic2: Morning has come "ten" hours "early"!!! The "moon" is still in the sky!
Compo: 𠦝: mist (RTK) 　月: moon; month

Origin: Before we get to explaining this character, take a look at it and see if you can figure out the primitive elements on your own.... On the left is the water - that much is easy. On the right we have only one primitive, the kanji for morning learned back in Frame 53. See how an apparently complex kanji falls apart neatly into manageable pieces? To get the meaning of the key word tide, just think of it in connection with the character for eventide that we learned back in Frame 115. Here we have the morning-tide, its complement. By the way, if you missed the question about the number of primitives, it is probably because you forgot what we said earlier about kanji becoming primitives, independently of the pieces that make them up. As a rule, look for the largest kanji you can write and proceed from there to primitives stranded on their own.
Mnemonic1: The morning tide is basically, well, WATER in the MORNING.
Mnemonic2: This is not the eventide, but the water of the morning tide.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　朝: morning

Origin: Two hands . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: Everyone in the kindergarten came up with fun and interesting shapes made out of Play-Doh, except for the kid with the amputated arm. Seems like you really need both hands.
Mnemonic2: With your two hands, outline the shape of a curvaceous woman. Is that a universally understood gesture? (Careful: mould (#680) which has two hands and soil/clay].
Compo: 开: open; start　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

English: Start, Generate, Emit, Issue, Open Up, Develop,
Origin: This key word refers to the discharging of guns, trains, people, and even words. The elements: teepee . . . two . . . human legs. Contrast the writing with frame 63.
Mnemonic1: Two pairs of human legs poking out of a teepee: you know there´ll be a discharge soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.
Mnemonic2: I spent some time in her TEEPEE...just the TWO of us...but I looked between her HUMAN LEGS and I saw a nasty DISCHARGE...so I made my 出発 rather hastily.
Compo: 癶: teepee (RTK)　二: two　儿: human legs

Origin: Cave . . . discharge.
Mnemonic1: Slaves have been discharged from the caves where they were kept thanks to the abolition of slavery.
Mnemonic2: Guns were abolished, so gun enthusiats left for the hills to discharge their guns in caves.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　発: discharge

Origin: The kanji for sound depicts something standing in the air over a tongue wagging in a mouth, much the same as a sound does for the briefest of moments before disappearing.
SubOrigin: The primitive from this kanji also means simply a sound.
Mnemonic1: If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you´d be making sound.
Mnemonic2: The tongue wagging in a mouth produces a very high-pitched sound, breaking a nearby vase.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　日: day; sun

English: Mind, Thoughts; Opinion, Will, Meaning, Sense
Origin: Sound . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: When you get a good IDEA you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it´s pounding so hard.
Mnemonic2: Picture someone who´s just had a great idea, but in place of a blinking light bulb over their head, you see a heart thumping with great noise. Imagine the greater the idea, the louder the sound of the beating heart.
Compo: 音: sound　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Person . . . saw.
Mnemonic1: Mr T.´s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he´s a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools.
Mnemonic2: When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, Mr. T salvages a saw from the wreckage and says, "I don´t know about y´all foos, but I´m gonna make a raft.".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　乍: peg holes, staple gun (RTK); saw (RTK)
Kunyomi: つく.る, つく.り, -ずく.り

Origin: Day . . . saw.
Mnemonic1: One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday.
Mnemonic2: Yester-DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away...
Compo: 日: day; sun　乍: peg holes, staple gun (RTK); saw (RTK)

Origin: This kanji, also a primitive, is one of the clearest instances we have of a complex pictograph. The top line is the sky, the next 3 strokes a pair of clouds, and the final 4 dots the rain collected there and waiting to fall.
SubOrigin: As a primitive it can mean either rain or weather in general. Because it takes so much space, it usually has to be contracted into a crown by shortening the second and third strokes into a crown.
Mnemonic1: From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.
Mnemonic2: Towel hung out on a line to ....oops, it´s rain.
Compo: 雨: rain

Origin: Rain/weather . . . eel.
Mnemonic1: Think of a two natural sources of electricity: electrical storms (a form of weather) and electrical eels. 電話 でんわ phone, call.
Mnemonic2: This kanji was invented by the first Chinaman to discover electricity. He was so unfortunate, he stepped on an electric eel and got struck by lighting at the same time.
Compo: 雨: rain　电: electricity, eel (RTK)

Origin: What we have to do here is turn a shellfish into a page of a book. The one at the top tells us that we only get a rather short book, in fact only one page. Imagine a title printed on the shell of an oyster, let us say "Pearl of Wisdom," and then open the quaint book to its one and only page, on which you find a single, radiant drop of wisdom, one of the masterpiece poems of nature.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji takes the unrelated meaning of a head (preferably one detached from its body), derived from the character for head (Frame 1549).
Mnemonic1: A shellfish carrying a page balanced on its head.
Mnemonic2: One drop of ink from a shellfish can fill a whole page.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　丶: dot; drop　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Reading this kanji from the top down, we have: horns . . . nose. Together they bring to mind the picture of a moose-head hanging on the den wall, with its great horns and long nose. Now while we would speak of cutting off a moose's "head" to hang on the wall, the Japanese speak of cutting off its neck. It's all a matter of how you look at it. Anyway, if you let the word neck conjure up the image of a moose with a very l-o-n-g neck hanging over the fireplace, whose horns you use for a coat-rack and whose nose has spigots left and right for scotch and water, you should have no trouble with the character. Here we get a good look at what we mentioned when we first introduced the element for horns: that they can never be left floating free and require an extra horizontal stroke to prevent that from happening, as is the case here.
Mnemonic1: The V shape is your neck on top of your collar bone, or the straight line. Yourself, or the rest of your body is below that!
Mnemonic2: The mooses neck supports it´s big horns and long nose.
Compo: 首: neck

Origin: The key word carries both the sense of a road for transit and a way or method of doing something, but the former is better for forming an image. The primitives read: the neck of a road. Think of a crowded road-way where traffic has come to a standstill - what we commonly refer to as a "bottleneck."
Mnemonic1: When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that´s why I take the train! ).
Mnemonic2: Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel´s neck over a dusty road. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her neck be ground into the road, spilling it´s precious contents into the dust?
Compo: 首: neck　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Chop-seal . . . utilize . . . road. By combining the first two primitives into a single image, you will be able to use that image in a few instances later, one of which comes immediately.
Mnemonic1: I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). (Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].
Mnemonic2: Building on gorgon´s story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the traffic. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge chopseal that they utilize to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the road.
Compo: 甬: road with walls on both sides　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: とお.る, とお.り, -とお.り, -どお.り, とお.す, とお.し, -どお.し, かよ.う

Origin: Fledglings . . . hook.
Mnemonic1: A fledgling is being nursed at a zoo, it is fed milk through a small tube that is bent in the shape of a hook (so that it fits inside its beak). The fledgling soon becomes addicted to milk, giving us this very catchy mnemonic: “fledgling hooked on milk”.
Mnemonic2: Drinking milk not only reduces cavity (#96)´s but also strengthens nails (claws) thanks astgtciv.
Compo: 孚: nourish; fledglings (RTK)　乙: fishhook; hook

Origin: This kanji depicts a pot of beans, although it looks more like a table on which the pot is resting.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji will mean table.
Mnemonic1: If I eat BEANS, after ONE MOUTHful I fart like some kind of HORNED ANIMAL.
Mnemonic2: I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let´s call this one Mr. Bean! He´s an easy character to build stories with.
Compo: 豆: beans; table (RTK)

Origin: Here we meet at last the full kanji on which the primitive for head is based. The elements: table . . . head.
Mnemonic1: The head of the family sits at the head of the table.
Mnemonic2: Mr Bean´s head.
Compo: 豆: beans; table (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)
Kunyomi: あたま, かしら, -がしら

Origin: Think of this character as identical to the halberd (Frame 1311) except that the final stroke has been omitted. Return to that character and devise some image to take this difference into account.
Mnemonic1: Beforehand, this was a halberd but I cut it short so it could be for hand to hand combat.
Mnemonic2: Your halberd doesn´t have a handguard? You should have thought of that beforehand (i.e., before you were missing your hand).
Compo: マ: ma; chop-seal (RTK)　了: finish

Origin: The halberd's battle-ax head and long shaft are depicted here. Take care with the number and order of the strokes.
Mnemonic1: マオ Zedong always carried a halberd.
Mnemonic2: Make the halberd a heroic warrior (perhaps of scandinavian origin) who weilds this polearm - the most effective, brutal and vicious one - with great skill. He can use it to hook, pierce and chop (the three strokes).
Compo: 矛: halberd
Ex1English: Spearhead; the aim (of an attack); the brunt (of an argument)

Origin: Beforehand . . . head.
Mnemonic1: Depositing money into your savings account is something you do beforehand if you use your head. If you´re in Japan your passbook says 預金機（よきんき）when you make a deposit.
Mnemonic2: You bang your head on the ATM, wishing you´d deposited some money beforehand.
Compo: 予: beforehand　頁: page; head (RTK)
Ex1English: Receive on deposit, take charge of

Origin: By combining the two primitives bound up and mouth, we can easily see how this character can get the meaning of a phrase. After all, a phrase is nothing more than a number of words bound up tightly and neatly so that they will fit in your mouth.
Mnemonic1: Some Japanese phrases are difficult to wrap your mouth around.
Mnemonic2: A bound mouth cannot utter a single phrase.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: There simply is not a good phrase in English for the block often days which this character represents. So we resurrect the classical phrase, decameron, whose connotations the tales of Boccaccio have done much to enrich. Actually, it refers to a journey of ten days taken by a band of people - that is, a group of people bound together for the days of the decameron.
Mnemonic1: Hesig should be BOUND for a DAY (or maybe 10 days - a decameron) for calling this Kanji DECAMERON. See martyrdom (#809).
Mnemonic2: If you bind up ten days, you get a decameron.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　日: day; sun
Ex1English: First ten days of a month
Ex2English: Middle ten days of a month
Ex3English: Final ten days of a month

Origin: If you want to bind up drops of anything - water, soup, lemonade - you use something to scoop these drops up, which is what we call a ladle. See the last drop left inside the ladle?
Mnemonic1: A ladle binds drops together.
Mnemonic2: Forget about the primative ´bound up´. Imagine instead the shape of a ladle and holding it upside down to drink the last DROP (of water).
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: The elements white bird and ladle easily suggest the image of a bull's eye if you imagine a rusty old ladle with a bull's eye painted on it in the form of a tiny white bird, who lets out a little "peep" every time you hit the target.
Mnemonic1: I managed to hit the bull´s eye by throwing my white ladle.
Mnemonic2: A white, bound up, drop in the center is the bull´s eye. (why Heisig had to use "ladle" instead of the original two primitives that make up "ladle" I´ll never understand!).
Compo: 白: white　勺: ladle

Origin: Consider for a moment the etymology of the word "promise" in order to notice its roots in the activity of putting one thing (e.g., one's word of honor) in place of another (e.g., the fulfillment of a task). For as it turns out, this character also means "to abridge, economize, and abbreviate" - all activities that involve putting one thing in place of another. With that in mind, we may now work with the elements: thread . . . ladle.
Mnemonic1: He tied a thread around the ladle as a reminder of his promise to do more house work.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman promised to get Aunt Mae´s ladle back. He started to do a blood oath by spilling drops of blood but Aunt Mae stopped him and bound up the wound. "It´s only a ladle Peter".
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　勺: ladle

Origin: First take the primitive meaning of this character: knot. Think of it as the piglet minus its body (the horizontal stroke), that is, the curly tail that looks like a knot. As an exception, we will use the homonym to remember the abstract key word, not.
Mnemonic1: This kanji is NOT a piglett.
Mnemonic2: The butcher is standing over the piglet. "This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!".
Compo: 勿: not
Ex1English: Wasteful; to be more than one deserves

Origin: Cow . . . knot.
Mnemonic1: The cow´s "thing" is tied in a knot! ouch.
Mnemonic2: A cow is not a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　勿: not

English: Direction, Side; Locality; Person, Way, Method, Square,
Origin: Spinning a dagger about on its hilt on the top of a top hat - waiting to see in which direction it points when it comes to rest - one leaves to fate where one is going next. Take care in writing this character.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character will take the sense of a compass, the instrument used to determine direction.
Mnemonic1: Note: The primitives are top hat and bound up. Compare ten thousand (#64). Story: A rich man wearing a top hat and bound up from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for directions to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.
Mnemonic2: I always keep my directions bound to the bottom of my top hat so I won´t lose them.
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . compass.
Mnemonic1: A giant compass is The Pinnacle´s self-defense system. It points in the direction of any invaders so the city is prepared well ahead to ward off the intruders.
Mnemonic2: To ward off enemies, the ancient Greece kept watch from the Acropolis, where they had a clear view in all directions.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　方: direction; compass (RTK)

Origin: Imagine a mask over your head with eyes peeping out from all over the head, a hundred in all (the element for eye displacing the fifth stroke of that for hundred).
Mnemonic1: If you´re wearing a mask, a hundred eyes can look at you but none of them will know who you are.
Mnemonic2: When Jim Carrey puts on The Mask, he can make it seem like he has 100 eyes popping out of his head.
Compo: 面: mask
Kunyomi: おも, おもて, つら

English: Picture, Draw; Kanji Stroke, Draw Up A Plan
Origin: In forming an image for the key word, it is helpful to know that this kanji is used for artistic representations (like a completed painting), and as a counter for the number of brush-strokes in a character (as, for instance, in Indexes II and III at the end of this book). Its elements are: ceiling . . . sprout . . . shovel.
Mnemonic1: You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.
Mnemonic2: To paint a kanji in your ceiling with only natural materials, you use a sprout as a brush and shovel some dirt to use as paint for your strokes. (modified from johnskb´s].
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)　凵: open box; shovel (RTK)
Ex2English: Mark off, demarcate; plan, map out

Origin: Ceiling . . . belt . . .  mountain. Note that the writing order follows the order in which the primitives are given here.
Mnemonic1: Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　山: mountain

Origin: Here we see a mountain goat "mounted" under a glass canopy. In this and the following frames, think of a particular Mount you know.
Mnemonic1: White mount , Fuji mount , olympus mount whatever ....The choice is yours but wherever you go they sell those snowglobe souvenir : under a GLASS HOOD you can see the mount with a MOUTAIN GOAT standing on top of it .... So kitsch you just can´t forget it .
Mnemonic2: This has the same meaning as 丘, so my "Mount" is a hill with mountain goats on it under a glass canopy. It´s obviously an effort by the locals to add some Mount atmosphere to their hill. As a primitive, it has the meaning "sturdy" (really), which Heisig has not used for some reason, but I will. The glass canopy must be pretty sturdy to keep the goats inside (bulletproof glass, I´m sure).
Compo: 岡: mount

Origin: Water . . . flowers . . . both. Given the abstract nature of this last primitive, you may want to borrow the image from the previous frame.
Mnemonic1: Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.
Mnemonic2: I was thirsty so I gulped down the water. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the flowers. Yes, I am responsible for both the missing water and the missing flowers. Yes, I´m afraid both. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite full now.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　両: both
Kunyomi: み.ちる, み.つ, み.たす
Ex2Kana: コップをみずでみたす

Origin: Lad . . . head.
Mnemonic1: A lad's head still has a baby's face.
Mnemonic2: When I was a lad, a pretty face was all it took for someone to get in my head, and I´d fill pages of lovelorn letters to them.
Compo: 彦: boy; lad (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Vase . . . cliff . . . cell.
Mnemonic1: If you were to stand up all the products you have accumulated over the course of your entire life on top of one another, the result would probably be as tall as a cliff.
Mnemonic2: The salesman is standing on the cliff´s edge. "Buy my products!! Buy my products! Or else I´ll take my own life"! Man, that´s selling on pressure.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　厂: cliff　生: life; cell (RTK)
Kunyomi: う.む, う.まれる, うぶ-

Origin: The primitives in this kanji show us one and mouth under a hood. Let us take the key word to connote the sameness that characterizes the life in community of the monk. They all have the same habits, including the "habit" they wear on their backs. Here we see the monk's cowl, drawn down over the eyes so that all you can see when you look at him is a mouth. But since monks also speak their prayers in common, it is but a short step to think of one mouth under a hood as the kanji for the sameness of monastic life.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this will mean monks dressed in a common habit.
Mnemonic1: Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the same, you can just see ONE MOUTH and very little else.
Mnemonic2: Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !
Compo: 冂: hood; belt (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Something referred to as "over yonder" is usually far off in the distance and barely within sight - like a wee drop in the distance - and is usually an expression used in giving directions or pointing something out. Hence this kanji begins with a drop. Then we find a sort of transparent helmet with no eyes or nose, but only a prominent mouth under it, obviously an extraterrestrial. And what is it jabbering on about with its mouth open like that? Why, about his spaceship way over yonder with its fuel tank on empty.
Mnemonic1: Look over yonder ! That tiny dot is robin hood at the mouth of his secret cave !
Mnemonic2: There was an old woman named Wanda,// Who wanted to make herself blonder.// She covered her くち// With a glass hood from Gucci// And dropped some hair dye on from yonder.
Compo: 丶: dot; drop　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　口: mouth
Kunyomi: む.く, む.き, -む.き, む.ける, -む.け, む.かう, む.こう, む.こう-

Origin: Above we see the primitive for little attached to one of those glass canopies you might use to display a family heirloom. The littleness is important, because what is in fact on display is the shrunken, stuffed, and mounted mouth of an esteemed ancestor. We may be used to esteeming the words our forebears leave behind, but here we also esteem the very mouth that spoke them. I leave it to you to imagine a suitable place in your room for displaying such an unusual conversation piece.
Mnemonic1: An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.
Mnemonic2: Remember that scene from Star Wars, where Luke is wearing that helmet that only his mouth could see, and was swinging at that little thing buzzing around the room? That was Obi-Wan´s trick to get Luke to build his self-esteem, or his confidence in the Force.
Compo: 尚: esteem; outhouse (RTK)

Origin: Recalling an image from frame 195, first see the mouth under the extraterrestrial's glass hood, and then the mouth under the top hat of one of his mates who has tried on the strange earthling's headgear only to find that it makes him look much, much taller than everyone else.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character keeps its sense of tall and its position at the top of other primitives, but its writing is abbreviated to the first 5 strokes.
Mnemonic1: Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.
Mnemonic2: Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a TALL hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　口: mouth　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　口: mouth
Kunyomi: たか.い, たか, -だか, たか.まる, たか.める

Origin: One of the things that causes the erosion of soil is the excessive pressure of the topsoil on the lower soil. This can be caused by any number of things from heavy rainfall to heavy buildings to the absence of sufficient deep-rooted vegetation to hold the layers together. Here we see a steep cliff without a tree in sight. The slightest pressure on it will cause a landslide, which, with a little help from your imagination, you will be able to see happening in this character.
Mnemonic1: The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.
Mnemonic2: For physics people: p = F/A (p:pressure, F:Force, A:Area). Where the force is from the immensity of the cliff. The area on the cliff is covered by soil. So the equation becomes p = F/A = cliff/soil which preserves the position of the primitives.
Compo: 厂: cliff　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Soil and a scorpion (an "earth animal"). This is, of course, the full character from which the primitive for ground derives.
Mnemonic1: Picture the ground as an extent of soil where scorpions are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying ´no trespassing, scorpion mines´ if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.
Mnemonic2: The soil is littered with scorpions everywhere and no ones dares put their foot on the ground.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　也: to be; scorpion (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . scorpion. It would be easy to slip into a "lazy image" in cases like this one, picturing, let us say, a scorpion near the water. But if you picture rather a scorpion letting its venom out drop by drop until it has made a whole pond of the stuff, the image is more likely to remain fixed.
Mnemonic1: Remember the story of the scorpion that begged the turtle for a ride across the pond? Halfway across the water, the scorpion stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.
Mnemonic2: Water scorpions loves to live in the pond.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　也: to be; scorpion (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . scorpion.
Mnemonic1: Old latin saying: homo hominis scorpio (people are scorpions to other people).
Mnemonic2: It´s one or the other: fight Mr. T, or be thrown into the scorpion pit.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　也: to be; scorpion (RTK)

Origin: Turkeys . . . atop a tree.
Mnemonic1: Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have gathered on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!
Mnemonic2: Gather the turkeys for Thanksgiving. Gather the trees for Christmas. In that order...
Compo: 隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: あつ.まる, あつ.める, つど.う

Origin: Turkey . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Why did the turkey cross the road? To advance to the other side, of course.
Mnemonic2: (re: raulir] Animals on the road: Turtles escape (#283) and Pigs pursue (#539), while the Turkeys advance (looking very formidable indeed).
Compo: 隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex4English: Advancing to the next level of schooling

English: Move Inward, Into, Emphatic Verbal Suffix
Origin: Enter . . . road.
Mnemonic1: During a traffic jam it is impossible to get your car to enter the roadway as it is crowded with cars. Think of a grid lock so bad cars are litterally scraping up against each other like people on a Japanese train during rush hour.
Mnemonic2: Everybody tries to enter the road during rush hour. That´s why it´s so crowded.
Compo: 入: enter; insert　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex1English: Put into; go into; be crowded

Origin: This character represents a picture of an ax, the two vertical lines being the handle and the horizontal strokes of the blade. Note the writing order carefully.
Mnemonic1: Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.
Mnemonic2: The axe-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!).
Compo: 斤: axe

Origin: Ax . . . road. Be careful not to confuse with draw near (Frame 204) or bystander (Frame 1090).
Mnemonic1: The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road...
Mnemonic2: An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long road. To make A and B near, take an ax, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.
Compo: 斤: axe　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: To keep the environs clean and safe, you could cement daggers in the road, blades pointed upwards, so that no polluting traffic could pass by. You could, if you were an ecologically-minded terrorist.
Mnemonic1: Caution: this kanji doesn´t mean environment; it means "environs; boundary; border; vicinity". To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road.
Mnemonic2: To protect the environs around their village, samurai would travel the roads with their swords.
Compo: 刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex2English: The year before last or thereabouts

Origin: Sun . . . take.
Mnemonic1: TAKE the UTMOST care when you SUN bath all DAY, or you´ll get burned from your EARS to your CROTCH.
Mnemonic2: Do your utmost - seize(take) the day.
Compo: 日: day; sun　取: take
Ex2Kana: もっともだいじなこと

Origin: The kanji for a dish is, clearly, the pictograph of a painted or carved bowl, seen from the side.
Mnemonic1: Three dishes stacked side-by-side in a dishwasher.
Mnemonic2: Pictograph of a dish with a three-layer cake slice on it.
Compo: 皿: dish

Origin: The drop in the dish is blood. It is similar to the drop we saw earlier on the dagger in the character for blade (Frame 88).
Mnemonic1: Vampire orders blood in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of blood spraying everywhere.
Mnemonic2: Image: Holy Grail with a drop of Jesus blood on it.
Compo: 皿: dish　丿: katakana no

Origin: Water . . . sun . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: If you leave water out in the sun in a dish, naturally it will get warm.
Mnemonic2: To distinguish from warmth (#1949), which refers to warm weather, remember that this means warm objects or feelings. Imagine a plastic kiddy pool in the backyard full of lukewarm water. The kiddy pool is shaped like a huge dish, and it's been under the sun all day - that's why the water is warm now.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　日: day; sun　皿: dish
Kunyomi: あたた.か, あたた.かい, あたた.まる, あたた.める
Ex4Kana: にっこうであたたまる

Origin: Water . . . sun . . . row.
Mnemonic1: You first wash you clothes with water and wring them until they are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. If you don´t wring them damp first they will take days to dry!
Mnemonic2: If your things are damp, lay them up in a row under the sun and let the water evaporate. (thx Raichu)…
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　日: day; sun　业: spikes

Origin: This character is a pictograph of a bird's claw, and from there comes to mean animal claws in general (including human fingernails).
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall use the graphic image of a vulture, a bird known for its powerful claws. It generally appears above another primitive, in which case it gets squeezed into the form ⺥.
Mnemonic1: A pictograph of Wolverine´s adamantium claws.
Mnemonic2: Pictograph, see book. * I prefer the primitive meaning of an eagle rather than vulture. Somehow vulture makes me think more about meat and dead corpses than claws. An eagle however immediately brings to my mind the image of an eagle plunging into a stream catching fish in his claws, or that of the great eagles rescuing Bilbo and his party in Jrr Tolkien´s novel “Bilbo the Hobbit”.
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)

Origin: The only thing that distinguishes this from the claw is the addition of the elbow, made by doubling up the third stroke and adding a fourth.
Mnemonic1: 何これ???? ok, sorry to be crude... if you claw at a girls melons, she is gonna give you the elbow.
Mnemonic2: Vegetarian vultures are fighting for a melon, each trying to elbow its way to it with claws.
Compo: 瓜: melon

Origin: This character depicts a bolt of cloth wrapped around a pole. From there it gets its meaning of a towel.
Mnemonic1: If it looks like a towel, speaks like a towel and walks like a towel... I wonder why Heisig didn´t include this one (as an actual kanji) in RtK 1.
Mnemonic2: Primative from RTK1.
Compo: 巾: towel

Origin: The maid, towels by her side, distributes the linen.
Mnemonic1: A matador holding his red linen by his side.
Mnemonic2: The first rule of the Hitch-Hiker´s Guide to the Universe is "DON´T PANIC!" The second rule, of course, is to always have a towel by your side. Personally, I prefer the linen sort.
Compo: 𠂇: side　巾: towel

Origin: Dressed in nothing but a bath towel and top hat, one sets off to the market place in search of a bargain or two.
Mnemonic1: My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I´m wearing only a top hat...and a towel.
Mnemonic2: At the MARKET you find lots of nice TOP HATS and TOWELS.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　巾: towel

Mnemonic1: A towel dangles under his mouth to keep him clean at dinner.
Mnemonic2: Dangle a bib or towel under my baby son's mouth.
Compo: 口: mouth　巾: towel
Kunyomi: つ.る, つ.り, つ.るす

Origin: Call to mind the image of a fresh, bubbling spring of water, and you will probably notice how the top of the spring you are thinking of, the part where the "bubbling" goes on, is all white. Happily, the white is just where it should be, at the top, and the water is at the bottom.
SubOrigin: We will keep this image of a spring when using this kanji as a primitive, but not without first drawing attention to a slight change that distinguishes the primitive from the kanji. The final 4 strokes (the element for water) are abbreviated to the three small drops that we learned earlier as the kanji for little.
Mnemonic1: White is a symbol of purety, so white water is pure water, the precise definition of spring water.
Mnemonic2: Perhaps the most common appearance of this kanji is in the word 温泉 (おんせん, onsen), a Japanese hot spring. The kanji is an excellent image of someone enjoying a Japanese hot spring: a little white towel on top, water below. (This helps keep all associations: spring, little and onsen).
Compo: 白: white　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Though the kanji is broad enough to embrace both meanings, the meadow you should imagine here is not a flatland plain but a mountain meadow in the Austrian Alps. (Perhaps the opening scene of "The Sound of Music" will help.) Simply think of little springs bubbling up across the meadow to form a sort of path that leads you right to the brink of a precipitous cliff. Now if you can see Schwester Maria skipping along merrily, dodging in and out of the springs, and then falling headlong over the cliff, you have a ridiculous story that should help fix this kanji in memory.
Mnemonic1: Follow the springs down the cliff and you will find a nice meadow.
Mnemonic2: Sorry about this, but Heisig was stupid calling this kanji meadow, used in composite words the most common meaning is ORIGIN... To remember just think that life may have begun in pounds or springs in a land with many cliffs ... Just to answer correctly the review lessons think of meadow as the origin of a huge forest.
Compo: 厂: cliff　白: white　小: little; owl (RTK)

Origin: With the advice of the last frame in mind, it is easy to see water and meadow in this character for source. Both in its etymology (it has a common parent with the word "surge") and in popular usage, source suggests the place water comes from. In this kanji, it is under the meadow, where we just saw it breaking the surface in those bubbly little springs.
Mnemonic1: The water that flows from the meadow is the source of life for the wild antelope.
Mnemonic2: The source of clean water is from the meadow (#134): it comes from that spring at the bottom of the cliff. Pay no attention to Julie Andrews lying face down in spring. The water´s clean. Trust me.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　原: meadow; original

Origin: Thread . . . spring.
Mnemonic1: This kanji is used for train lines. Spiderman does a hot spring tour of Japan using the train lines. You can see the Spidey costume hanging on the washing line as he enjoys the onsen.
Mnemonic2: Japan´s train lines are like threads that spring from Tokyo station.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　泉: spring

Origin: Thread . . . white . . . towels.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman´s polyethylene suit starts to ride up after a while, so he always looks forward to the white cotton towels he wears while lounging around his apartment.
Mnemonic2: Cotton is the preferred thread for making white towels.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　白: white　巾: towel

Origin: Thread . . . mouth . . . flesh.
Mnemonic1: Silk threads are coming out of the caterpillar's mouth to cover its flesh while it transforms into a cocoon.
Mnemonic2: Spider-man loves to run his mouth all over Mary Jane´s silky flesh.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　口: mouth　月: moon; month

Origin: A strip of white towel and some scraps of metal have the makings of a primitive kind of brocade.
Mnemonic1: Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel.
Mnemonic2: Never heard of this word before encountering it here. So it turns out that the fanciest brocade in the world is actually a towel used by a Turkish monarch. It´s embroidered with gold and cocaine. Yes, cocaine - what you thought it´d be something else? That is some true art right there. I think a great many people would want to own this towel.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　白: white　巾: towel

Origin: A meadow and a head are all we are given to work with in the kanji for petition. Since the key word already suggests something like a formal request made of some higher power, let us imagine a gigantic Wizard-of-Oz head located in the middle of the flowery meadow we used in the last frame. Then just picture people kneeling hopefully before it, petitioning for whatever it is they want. (The scarecrow wanted brains, the lion, courage, and the tin man a heart. What about you?)
Mnemonic1: Let´s petition to save that beautiful MEADOW from overdevelopment by signing on this PAGE.
Mnemonic2: Japanese hippies PETITION to save a meadow by getting people on the street to sign their page - as you pass by they call out: "お願いします、おねがいします。”.
Compo: 原: meadow; original　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . belt. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of hood here because the person runs THROUGH the element, not under it.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T´s new belt is huge! When he´s inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground!
Mnemonic2: How is a person ever supposed to get inside that girl when she´s wearing such a huge chastity belt? I guess that´s kinda the point, eh?
Compo: 冂: hood; belt (RTK)　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)

Origin: Let this doubling of one of the elements for "inside" yield the sense of "insides" to approach the key word, meat. The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of flesh or part of the body for the kanji 月.
Mnemonic1: Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.
Mnemonic2: A person´s inside - fleshy, raw, pink, meat.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)

Origin: Pack of wild dogs . . . puppet.
Mnemonic1: My love doll is made of special pheremone impregnated vinyl. Unfortunately, a pack of wild dogs mistook her for a wild boar and tore her to pieces. Oh dear!
Mnemonic2: (Image: a pack of wild dogs chasing Pinocchio who´s trying to escape by riding on the back of a boar. See him bouncing around as they race along?).
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　者: person; puppet (RTK)

Origin: Flesh . . . sow.
Mnemonic1: Pork comes from the flesh of a sow.
Mnemonic2: One possible pictograph for "sow" primitive: the top line is a feeding trough, the stroke touching it is the head, the long curved stroke is the body (with a little hook at the end for the curly tail), and the four remaining strokes are the sow´s legs.
Compo: 月: moon; month　豕: pig; sow (RTK)

Origin: This is the full character whose primitive form we learned already. To help a little, this kanji recalls the times when the "domestic" animals were, as the word itself suggests, really kept in the house. Hence: house . . . sow.
Mnemonic1: Think of "The Three Little Pigs". There was a house made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a pig. So, naturally, housetop over pig means house, the central element of that story.
Mnemonic2: Man, ever hear of cleaning? This house is a pig sty.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　豕: pig; sow (RTK)

Origin: There are actually a number of kanji for the word I, but the others tend to be more specific than this one. The key word here should be taken in the general psychological sense of the "perceiving subject." Now the one place in our bodies that all five senses are concentrated in is the head, which has no less than five mouths: 2 nostrils, 2 ears, and 1 mouth. Hence, five mouths = I.
Mnemonic1: I have 5 senses.
Mnemonic2: I eat five times at day.
Compo: 五: five　口: mouth

Origin: Hand . . . fiesta. Note how the second stroke of the hand is stretched across to double up as the first stroke of the tasseled arrow we use for fiesta. Compare to frames 17, 36, and 564.
Mnemonic1: Someone with a huge EGO is too good for any romantic partner and as such has nothing but personal "hand fiestas" with himself every night.
Mnemonic2: Did you hear about the guy who had such a big EGO that he threw a fiesta for his left hand?
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)
Kunyomi: われ, は, わ.が-, わが-

Origin: Whereas the character for say focused on the actual talking, that for words stresses the fact that although it is I who say them, the words of a language are not my own. You can see the clear distinction between I and words just by looking at the kanji.
Mnemonic1: The simplest word to say is I.
Mnemonic2: May I say a word about that?
Compo: 言: word; say　吾: I; my

Origin: Person . . . rising cloud. Hint: the Amerindians' smoke signal scan help provide a good image for this kanji, whose key word is meant to include transmissions of all sorts.
Mnemonic1: Mister T transmits a message with rising clouds (smoke) signals, to a nearby American Indian tribe. The smoke signals spell : "I p-i-t-y y-o-u f-o-o !".
Mnemonic2: Hanging one-handed under Cloud City, the Jedi-in-training Luke, uses the force to transmit his distress to Leia.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　云: say; rising cloud (RTK)
Kunyomi: つた.わる, つた.える, つた.う, -ずた.い

Origin: As the wheels of the car revolve, they kick up small rising clouds of dust and debris behind them.
Mnemonic1: The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.
Mnemonic2: Just a note to remember the cloud primative: The name of Goku´s pet cloud that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is Nimbus ( http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg ]. The katakana-ization of this is {ニム}バス, so the rising cloud primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style.
Compo: 車: car　云: say; rising cloud (RTK)
Kunyomi: ころ.がる, ころ.げる, ころ.がす, ころ.ぶ

Origin: The secret technique of making a rising cloud of smoke turn into a bouquet of flowers is shown here.
Mnemonic1: Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: "Try my rising cloud flower technique!!!" smash pow crack!! .
Mnemonic2: One technique to smoke weed is to vaporize it and inhale those rising clouds to create a stronger effect.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　云: say; rising cloud (RTK)

Origin: Meeting . . . wall. This is the full character for meeting, from which the abbreviated primitive that we met back in lesson 12 gets its name.
Mnemonic1: At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business meeting in a very special room where the walls are ... meeting. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these meetings, he´s the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion.
Mnemonic2: The only thing created in most meetings is a lot of hot air. Imagine a cloud of it rising to the roof.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　云: say; rising cloud (RTK)

Origin: The kanji for fit reads literally, top to bottom, as a meeting of mouths - which is a rather descriptive way of speaking of a romantic kiss. We all know what happens when there is no meeting of minds and when people's ideas don't fit with one another. But this kanji invites us to imagine what would happened to the romance of a certain unfortunate couple whose mouths didn't fit.
Mnemonic1: I wouldn´t mind a meeting of mouths with her, she´s really fit !
Mnemonic2: He had such a big mouth that he could easily fit one whole umbrella in it.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth
Onyomi: ゴウ, ガッ-, カッ-
Kunyomi: あ.う, -あ.う, あ.い, あい-, -あ.い, -あい, あ.わす, あ.わせる, -あ.わせる

Origin: The final stroke of this kanji is a rare shape, which we have not met before and will only meet in this character and others that include it as a primitive. We are more accustomed to seeing it straightened out as part of other shapes - for instance, as the second stroke of mouth. If you need any help at all with this character, you may picture it as two hands of a clock pointing to what time it is now. The element above it, meeting, should easily relate to that image.
SubOrigin: We shall use clock as the primitive meaning of this character, in line with the above explanation.
Mnemonic1: My MEETING is at 7- but that´s NOW!
Mnemonic2: (re: ruuku35) The meeting is not at quarter to seven but now!
Compo: 今: now; clock (RTK)
Ex1English: Till now, so far, up to the present

Origin: Meeting . . . chop-seal.
Mnemonic1: (re: dingomick) "These are your orders," declares the general while passing out documents at the meeting. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims "Oh wait! I need to certify these orders!" and went around stamping each paper with his personal chop-seal.
Mnemonic2: These are your orders, declares the general at the meeting as he stamps them with his chop-seal. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one´s they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.).
Compo: 令: orders

Origin: Clock . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Someone wishing from the bottom of their heart that the clock would stop. A mid-life crisis perhaps.
Mnemonic2: Remember in the Wizard of Oz when the tin man wished for a heart and the wizard gave him that dinky little clock instead?
Compo: 今: now; clock (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: At last we come to the general character meaning stamp. Its elements: staples . . . stamp.
Mnemonic1: Before sticky backs, they had to staple stamps to letters.
Mnemonic2: Aaaagh, this old stamp doesn´t stick! Okay I´ll just staple it.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　丨: line; stick　二: two　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: This character connotes life in general, but also the particular life that is fated one by virtue of the distinctive character with which one is born. Its elements are: fit . . . stamp. The bottom portion of fit is nudged to the left in order to make room for the stamp.
Mnemonic1: When you´re born, your fate is measured, fitted, and stamped onto your soul. Good luck defying it.
Mnemonic2: Your ability to resist FATE can be fit on a postage stamp.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: A top hat hanging on a hook in the front hall, right where the deceased left it the day he died, reminds us of him and his kanji.
SubOrigin: In addition to deceased, the primitive meaning of to perish will also be used for this character.
Mnemonic1: The top hat hanging on a hook belonged to the now deceased Charlie Chaplin.
Mnemonic2: The recently DECEASED are said to hang their hats on a hook by the door to the afterlife.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　匚: box; hook (RTK)

Origin: This kanji has a pictographic resemblance to a number of grains of rice lying on a plate in the shape of a star.
SubOrigin:
As a primitive, it keeps its meaning of rice, and is meant to connote a very ordinary, commonplace grain, in contrast to the primitive for wheat that we just learned. (This meaning accords well with Japan, where the output of rice far exceeds that of wheat.)
It occasionally takes a different shape when it stands on its own, or is joined to a line above. In this case, we shall have it refer specifically to grains of rice. This primitive is not to be confused with the similar-looking primitive for water. While the stroke orders are nearly alike, grains of rice has 5 strokes, while water only has 4 because it joins the second and third strokes into one.
Finally, we may note that by itself the kanji for rice is an abbreviation used for the United States, which can then also serve as an alternate reading for the main primitive form, if you so wish.
Mnemonic1: Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA.
Mnemonic2: Two drops of rice in a tree, simple.
Compo: 米: rice

Origin: Rice . . . vase.
Mnemonic1: A sage is using rice to fill up a vase, but as an exercise in patience, he´s doing it grain by grain.
Mnemonic2: There´s a contest...whoever guesses the number of grains of rice in a vase wins.
Compo: 米: rice　立: stand up; vase (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: The first step to harmony is having enough wheat to feed every mouth in the world. Once we are all fed it is easier to get a long in harmony.
Mnemonic2: People who live in harmony with nature live in the country. they are yokels or hillbillys. See Billy-bob sitting on the porch in their denhim dungarees a sheaf of wheat, sticking from their mouth.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　口: mouth
Kunyomi: やわ.らぐ, やわ.らげる, なご.む, なご.やか

Origin: Wheat . . . elbow. Like the characters for I (Frame 17) and ego (Frame 690), this kanji is also representative of the subject, with the special connotation of privacy.
Mnemonic1: Warning sign: "Private wheat, trespassers will be elbowed".
Mnemonic2: I already know this as watashi, or "I". In order to associate the keyword of private, I´ll think of this one as "Private I", like a detective.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: Cave . . . elbow.
Mnemonic1: The Batcave is very wide and has a lot of elbow room for Batman to do his yoga.
Mnemonic2: A wide cave has a lot of "elbow room".
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)
Kunyomi: ひろ.い, ひろ.まる, ひろ.める, ひろ.がる, ひろ.げる

Origin: Thread . . . brains.
Mnemonic1: Dainty women would always rather work with thread than in a field.
Mnemonic2: Spider-Man used to just be a dainty, brainy nerd.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)
Kunyomi: ほそ.い, ほそ.る, こま.か, こまか.い

Origin: Learn this frame in connection with the next one. A grove is a small cluster of trees. Hence the simple reduplication of the kanji for tree gives us the grove.
Mnemonic1: A grove has at least two TREEs.
Mnemonic2: Two tree huggers saying that protecting the environment is grovey man…
Compo: 木: tree; wood　木: tree; wood
Ex1English: Standing in close proximity (as of buildings)

Origin: A forest is a large expanse of trees, or "trees, trees everywhere," to adopt the expression we used back in frames 22 and 23.
Mnemonic1: The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that´s so u dont mess up with their possition like i do.
Mnemonic2: Another tree planted within a grove turns it into a FOREST.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　林: grove; forest

Origin: Tree . . . public.
Mnemonic1: Following up with the "entering public restrooms" story for the right-hand primitive: public restrooms always reek of pine tree scented disinfectant.
Mnemonic2: A pine tree is a public tree: they are frequently planted in public squares, in commemoration of the respect Conficius held for them.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　公: public; official

Origin: Bamboo grows upwards, like a straight nail, and at each stage of its growth (which legend associates with the arrival of the new moon) there is a jointed rootstock (the first stroke). Two such bamboo stalks are pictured here.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the meaning remains the same, but the vertical lines are severely abbreviated so that they can take their place at the top where, like flowers, they are always to be found.
Mnemonic1: Pandas like to eat bamboo. I´m using panda as the primitive name when it fits the story. ^__^.
Mnemonic2: Two reclining victims impaled on bamboo spheres…
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)

Origin: Someone . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: In a metropolis people are just puppets inside city walls, there is no individuality if you live so close together.
Mnemonic2: A vision of a futuristic METROPOLIS: standing at the window of your 400th floor apartment, hand in hand with your LOVE DOLL, gazing out at the gigantic CITY WALLS that you can never escape.
Compo: 者: person; puppet (RTK)　邑: village; city walls (阝)
Ex4English: Metropolitan, under control of the tokyo metropolitan government

Origin: When we think of a capital city today we think of tall skyscrapers dwarfing the endless swarms of little folk scurrying here and there about their business.
Mnemonic1: Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings).
Mnemonic2: The capital is where the powerful act formal wearing top hats, open their mouths, and get little done.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　口: mouth　小: little; owl (RTK)

Origin: To the many definitions for politics that already exist, this character offers yet another: correct taskmastering. Think about what the primitives tell us. On the one hand, we see the pessimistic wisdom that politics has to do with taskmastering, maneuvering people with or without their will. And on the other, we see the campaign assurances that this duty can be performed correctly if only the right candidate is given a chance.
Mnemonic1: Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster.
Mnemonic2: Insane political correctness on the left, and facists taskmasters on the right- thats politics in a nutshell right there.
Compo: 正: correct; justice　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

English: Urban Prefecture (Kyōto Or Ōsaka), Government Office
Origin: Cave . . . adhere.
Mnemonic1: A municipality, like any type of government, adheres to having caves for offices (see government office (#591)).
Mnemonic2: Even if a municipality is in a cave, you have to adhere to its policies.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　付: attach; adhere

Origin: Ceiling . . . flag.
Mnemonic1: Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as "noren," hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don´t usually hang from the ceiling.
Mnemonic2: A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door).
Compo: 戸: door

English: Place, Point, Part, Particle Of Nominalization, "-Ation"
Origin: Door . . . ax.
Mnemonic1: You outsiders better learn your place! An axe stuck in the door when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best place for you.
Mnemonic2: A place for everything and everything in its place. To the right of the door is the standard place for the axe.
Compo: 戸: door　斤: axe
Kunyomi: ところ, -ところ, どころ

Origin: Wall . . . soil. The key word allows for the full variety of connotations: to peak, to arrive at the end, and the like.
Mnemonic1: Sexual climaxes don´t always happen on the bed; they sometimes happen against a wall or on the ground!
Mnemonic2: The climax of the Berlin Wall affair was the tearing of it to ground.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil
Ex3English: To tokyo (as on the edge of a map)

English: Bring About, Lead To, Do Humbly
Origin: The archaic English form for "does" indicates a humble form of the verb "to do." It is made up of climax and taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: To reach climax I doth the bidding of my dominatrix taskmaster.
Mnemonic2: This character is used in two very high-frequency words: "you are welcome" (どう致しまして) and the honorific form of onegaishimasu (お願い致します; おねがいいたします). Can´t you just picture this ridiculously polite S&M picture? A businessman, who DOTH the bidding of his taskmistress, is climaxing and yelling out "お願い致します" while she whips and says "どう致しまして". (This kanji also means "to bring about" and "do humbly", which is perfect for this image).
Compo: 至: climax　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Flag . . . climax. Note that this kanji has no relation to the drawing of a "roof" used in the primitive for house.
Mnemonic1: Flag at the climax (highest point) of a castle roof.
Mnemonic2: A couple climaxing on the roof, draped in the American flag. The neighbors are mortified and call the landlady...
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　至: climax

Origin: House . . . climax.
Mnemonic1: You book a room in a love hotel called "Climax House".
Mnemonic2: A simple room is made up of a roof, some walls, and a dirt floor.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　至: climax

Origin: The primitive elements that compose this character are ten and mouth, but you may find it easier to remember it as a pictograph of a tombstone with a cross on top. Just think back to one of those graveyards you have visited, or better still, used to play in as a child, with old inscriptions on the tombstones. This departure from the primitive elements in favor of a pictograph will take place now and again at these early stages, and almost never after that. So you need not worry about cluttering up your memory with too many character "drawings."
SubOrigin: Used as a primitive element, this kanji keeps its key-word sense of old, but care should be taken to make that abstract notion as graphic as possible.
Mnemonic1: Tombstone and cross on an old man´s grave.
Mnemonic2: You get OLD fast if you have ten open mouths to feed.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　口: mouth
Kunyomi: ふる.い, ふる-, -ふる.す

Origin: Flag . . . old. Do not confuse with dwell (Frame 1027).
Mnemonic1: A humongous American flag in Florida marks the place where all the old people reside.
Mnemonic2: It is an old tradition that people plant a flag on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. set (#1064).
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　古: old

English: Bureau, Office, Limited Part, Locality, Situation
Origin: Flag . . . phrase. Note how the flag's long stroke doubles up for the first stroke of phrase.
Mnemonic1: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has email scanners that flag certain phrases.
Mnemonic2: They do nothing at the bureau other than repeating the stupid catchphrase they have on their flag.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　句: phrase

English: Old; The Late, Incident, Reason, Cause
Origin: Call it fate or providence or plain old Lady Luck, happenstance is the oldest taskmaster we know. It nearly always has its way.
Mnemonic1: An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.
Mnemonic2: Need to disambiguate from enemy (#443) as it´s easy to mix up antique and old here. Let´s think of an accidental president -- he is an old taskmaster who has managed to win the election by happenstance .
Compo: 古: old　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
古: old　月: moon; month
Ex1English: Ancient countries in the north or west of china; barbarous country

Origin: Water . . . old . . . flesh. You have heard of legends of people being abandoned in the mountains when they had become too old to work. Well, here is a legend about people being set adrift in the waters of a stormy lake because their flesh had gotten too old to bear the burdens of life.
Mnemonic1: This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the lake and looking at the MOON reflected in the lake. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji.
Mnemonic2: Water reflects the old moon in the lake.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　古: old　肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)
Ex2English: The great lakes (lakes superior, michigan, huron, ontario and erie)

Origin: Old . . . pent in. Leave the people out of your story to avoid complications later when we add the element for person to form a new kanji (Frame 1047).
Mnemonic1: Fossils are old things pent in that have hardened.
Mnemonic2: Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was harden, which kept it pent in until it grew old enough to evolve into Butterfree..
Compo: 古: old　囗: box; pent in (RTK)
Kunyomi: かた.める, かた.まる, かた.まり, かた.い

Mnemonic1: Dragon Quest - You find a hardened bamboo stick, perfect for a weapon, but you can´t pick it up because your items are full.
Mnemonic2: You´ve entered in a chinese shop where apparently the only item in sale is old, dusty, hardened bamboo (for construction for example). It looks like these items have been there forever. Asking the clerk if anything else is available, he doesn´t understand and instead asks - "Two items? Three items?" (the kanji is a counter for items) - thinking you want to buy something.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　固: harden

English: Individual, Single Unit, General Counter (For Things Or Articles)
Origin: Person . . . harden.
Mnemonic1: This keyword gave me trouble, I could write the kanji from memory but could not remember the keyword the other way around. In such case the dictionary definition can be helpful : "Middle English, single, indivisible". Here we have Mr. T. who is so hardened (all the body workout he´s had) that he became in-dividual, that is, in-divisible. "I pity da foo who can be divided into smaller units.".
Mnemonic2: Mr. T insists that people be individual. He appears on television, saying, "Being an individual is hard! But you gotta do it! Harden yourself, and be individual!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　固: harden

English: As Well As, Moreover, Both … And …
Mnemonic1: Moreover is a literary term to shelve what you had just been talking about, to come back to it later.
Mnemonic2: Same as darg_sama. Play on words. I imagine visiting someone who has an impressive collection of medals and trophies (chess champion, for example). After spending an hour showing you all the trophies in the glass shelf, you think "Whew! It´s over." ... but the person says "... and wait, there´s "moreover" !", pointing at more trophies lined atop the glass shelf.
Compo: 且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: A common thread associates the knick-knacks on your knick-knack shelf. Souveneirs from Spain on one, from Japan on the other.
Mnemonic2: Watch this: http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r249/sith_lord10/updated%20showroom%20july/s29.jpg The leader of the Spiderman association has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.(Zactacular).
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: Just as the word evening adds a touch of formality or romanticism to the ordinary word "night," so the kanji for evening takes the ordinary looking moon in the night sky and has a cloud pass over it (as we saw in the last frame).
SubOrigin: The primitive keeps the same meaning and connotation as the kanji.
Mnemonic1: The evening is young, the moon is not full.
Mnemonic2: In the evening, I try my best to remember the katakana symbol for "TA" (ie. "ta ta!").
Compo: 夕: evening

Origin: On the left, the primitive for evening, and on the right, that for the magic wand. Now, as every magician worth his abracadabra knows, bringing your magic wand out into the evening air makes your magic much more powerful than if you were to stay indoors. Hence, evening and magic wand takes you naturally outside.
Mnemonic1: A young magician likes to practice outside in the evening with his magic wand (as opposed to the old magician who wakes early to practice with his wand in eminent (#51)).
Mnemonic2: Outside in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.
Compo: 夕: evening　卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)
Kunyomi: そと, ほか, はず.す, はず.れる
Ex2English: Besides, in addition; the rest, others

Origin: Many moons ago, begins much of Amerindian folklore - a colorful way of saying "Once upon a time" and a great deal of help for remembering this kanji. Here we have two moons (three of them would take us back to the beginning of time, which is further than we want to go), lacking the final stroke because they are partially hidden behind the clouds of time.
Mnemonic1: Two evenings too many!
Mnemonic2: This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: "He who eats many prunes sits on toilet many moons".
Compo: 夕: evening　夕: evening

Origin: In the next lesson we will meet the character for morning-tide and the element for drops of water. Meantime we have a perfect blend of picture and idea in this kanji to play on the English word for nightfall, eventide: drops of water inching their way up the shore in the evening.
Mnemonic1: Eventide is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.
Mnemonic2: Drops of water shower the beach as the evening tide approaches: eventide.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　夕: evening

Origin: Perhaps you have heard of the custom, still preserved in certain African tribes, of a father creeping into the tent or hut of his newborn child on the night of the child's birth, to whisper into its ear the name he has chosen for it, before making his choice public. It is an impressive naming custom and fits in tidily with the way this character is constructed: evening . . . mouth. At evening time, a mouth pronounces the name that will accompany one throughout life.
Mnemonic1: In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your name so that people can recognise you.
Mnemonic2: In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my name.
Compo: 夕: evening　口: mouth

Origin: This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the Heavens. (You may, of course, use the elements ceiling and St. Bernard instead.)
SubOrigin: The primitive can mean either the heaven of eternal bliss or the general term for sky, the heavens. Pay special attention to the fact that in its primitive form the first stroke is written right to left, rather like the first stroke of thousand (Frame 40), rather than left to right. From the next character, we shall give it the primitive meaning of a witch.
Mnemonic1: If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.
Mnemonic2: The ceiling that all large dogs aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, All Dogs Go to Heaven.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)

Origin: As the key word suggests, this kanji has to do with something not quite over and done with. More concretely, it shows us a tree that is not yet fully grown. The extra short stroke in the upper branches shows new branches spreading out, leaving one with the feeling that the tree has a ways to go yet before it reaches maturity. In other words, the kanji conveys its meaning pictographically, playing on the earlier pictograph of the tree.
Mnemonic1: I believe a better version of that by mameha1977: (Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) does not yet (未) have exremities (末) of vermilion (朱).
Mnemonic2: (Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (末) vermilion (朱).
Compo: 未: not yet

Origin: This character is best learned in connection with that of the previous frame. The first stroke shows a branch that is longer than the main branch, indicating that the tree has reached the extremity of its growth, so that its branches stop spreading and start drooping downwards. Be sure to keep this imagery in mind, to avoid confusing this key word with synonyms that will appear later.
Mnemonic1: The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.
Mnemonic2: There are no great stories for this one yet, and I always forget it.. So, let´s try something ridiculous: The man lived by himself in the wilderness, with no females within miles. So, his only way of relief was to stick his extremity into a small hole in a tree.. The poor guy. Which horizontal stroke is the extremity? The longer one or the shorter one? That, my friends, is up to your own imaginations. I´d prefer not to dwell on that point, myself. ;).
Compo: 末: extremity

Origin: When a tree has not yet finished growing, it produces fruit with a full flavor. When the official taster (the professional mouth to the left) determines that full flavor has been reached, the tree is pruned back so that it remains permanently not yet grown. A neat little agricultural trick and an easy to way see the sense of flavor hidden in this character.
Mnemonic1: My mouth has not yet swallowed the food because the flavor is so delicious that I keep chewing it.
Mnemonic2: To enjoy a food´s FLAVOR, it must be in one´s MOUTH but NOT YET swallowed.
Compo: 口: mouth　未: not yet

Origin: This odd but common kanji is built up of the character for not yet into which a pair of animal horns has been inserted.
Mnemonic1: You horny bastard, don´t come, at least not yet!
Mnemonic2: Here I see, of all things, Bambi. His animal horns have not yet come out. (As we can see in the kanji, the animal horns are not at the top, not "poking through". ) Remember: Bambi will soon come to have a great set of animal horns but they have not yet come out.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　米: rice
Kunyomi: く.る, きた.る, きた.す

Origin: Red pepper . . . ax.
Mnemonic1: Don't confuse left primitive with catalpa (#1498). Every time the farmer cuts down the peppers from the red pepper plant, he has to use a brand new axe. This is because the spicy peppers cause the metal to erode very quickly, thereby rendering the axe completely useless.
