Mnemonic2: Axe-man grows a patch of red pepper plants in his back garden. He rubs red peppers on the edge of his axes, and this seems to keep them sharp like brand new.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　木: tree; wood　斤: axe
Kunyomi: あたら.しい, あら.た, あら-, にい-

Origin: Red pepper . . . see.
Mnemonic1: A wise parent lets their kids learn. A kid wants to try to eat the red pepper plant, the wise parent says "Try it and see for yourself".
Mnemonic2: I remember this one the way the Japanese do: a parent standing on top of a tree watching what his or her kid is doing.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　木: tree; wood　見: see
Kunyomi: おや, おや-, した.しい, した.しむ

Origin: The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a lack of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, it can mean either yawn or lack.
Mnemonic1: To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.
Mnemonic2: When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.
Compo: 欠: lack; yawn (RTK)
Kunyomi: か.ける, か.く, か.かす
Ex1English: Lack, be deficient, be vacant; be broken off

Origin: This key word connotes the "next in line" of a succession of people or things. Let there be a lack of ice on the hottest day of summer, and you stand impatiently in line waiting for the distributor to call out "Next!"
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character can either retain its key word meaning of next or the related meaning of second.
Mnemonic1: Is this store lacking ice? Let´s try the next one, then.
Mnemonic2: A rapper called "Ice" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. Next...
Compo: 冫: ice　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)

Origin: Caverns . . . towel.
Mnemonic1: Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).
Mnemonic2: You´re tired from walking the tour at this cavern and there´s no benches to sit down on, so you take a towel and sling it up into a hammock-like seat using the stalagmites. (Big no-no).
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　廿: twenty; 20　巾: towel

Origin: This key word refers to a gradation of measurement, not to academic diplomas. Its primitives: caverns . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: The cavern refugees are so poor that they can´t afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their crotches inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in degrees from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs...
Mnemonic2: The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　廿: twenty; 20　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . degrees.
Mnemonic1: This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the water if it´s not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees.
Mnemonic2: The transit system in Tokyo is one of the best in the wrold, but why is it that when it is 35 degrees outside, it is about 2 degrees on the train? Or when it is 2 degrees outside, it is 35 degrees inside the train. This degree of difference means I am always sweating then getting the chills! I think I caught a fever!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　度: degrees
Kunyomi: わた.る, -わた.る, わた.す

Origin: Pinnacle . . . silver.
Mnemonic1: He was pushed to the limit at the end of the marathon, climbing on top of the Acropolis, but had to settle for the silver medal.
Mnemonic2: At The Pinnacle, they limit how much silver you can have. Too much silver will lead to wrongfulness.
Compo: 邑: village; city walls (阝)　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)
Kunyomi: かぎ.る, かぎ.り, -かぎ.り

Origin: Metal . . . silver.
Mnemonic1: Like gold, silver is a metal.
Mnemonic2: Not sure why Heisig find the right side so troublesome. My grandma´s hairpin (just before long (#1920)) is made of silver, the metal that best reflects sun light. I´m sure you can see the flash from her hair as she walks by on a sunny day. Note that the two elements (sun and hairpin) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . silver.
Mnemonic1: Since trees eat through their roots, one could imagine roots as tree silverware.
Mnemonic2: The roots of the magical tree are silver.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)
Ex1English: Digging around the roots; maneuvering behind the scenes

Origin: Drop of . . . silver.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, use the image of a saint's halo. As with silver, when this element is drawn on the left, the penultimate stroke is omitted.
Mnemonic1: With a drop of silver, the forces of good can vanquish the werewolves.
Mnemonic2: A drop of silver is good, but a whole bar of it is better!
Compo: 丶: dot; drop　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)

Origin: Halo . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: The daughter is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The son is a good boy that grows up to defend the city walls.
Mnemonic2: A good son stays within the city walls so he can care for his parents…
Compo: 郎: son

Origin: Cave . . . son.
Mnemonic1: Your son plays in the corridor pretending he´s exploring a cave.
Mnemonic2: (ロウ) I think of the corridor found in the cave that Yoda made Luke Skywalker walk through as part of his Jedi training in Empire Strikes Back. It was in this corridor that Luke met Darth Vadar, cut off his head and found himself behind Darth Vadar´s mask. An early little hint that Luke was Darth Vadar´s son.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　郎: son

Origin: If halo and umbrella aren't enough, break the halo down into drop and silver - or "silverware," an additional primitive.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji can mean either eating or food. As with silver, on the left the final two strokes of this element are combined into one.
Mnemonic1: That umbrella looks good enough to eat!
Mnemonic2: Umbrella + Good: Let's go eat at that restaurant - the table with the umbrella looks good.
Compo: 食: eat; food
Kunyomi: く.う, く.らう, た.べる

Origin: Food . . . yawn.
Mnemonic1: My experience with Japanese enkais (dinner parties): plenty to drink drink drink, but a severe lack of food, T_T.
Mnemonic2: When you lack food, just drink something to fill you up.
Compo: 食: eat; food　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)

Origin: By replacing the maestro's baton (the drop) with the roof of a house, we have his equivalent in the institutional world of big government: the bureaucrat.
Mnemonic1: No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.
Mnemonic2: Bureaucrat, def: The maestro without a baton, the one who orchestrates oppressive rules, regulations and taxes on every household.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　𠂤: maestro (RTK)

Origin: The abbreviation of Building suggests that this kanji is used in proper names, as indeed it often is. Keep your connotation distinct from Inst. (Frame 1401) when working with the elements: food . . . bureaucrat.
Mnemonic1: This Bldg. is like all the other government buildings - they house bureaucrats who sit around sipping wine and eating expensive meals at the taxpayers expense.
Mnemonic2: A building that eats bureaucrats!!!!!!!!
Compo: 食: eat; food　官: bureaucrat

Origin: House . . . person . . . hundred.
Mnemonic1: The Toyoko Inn can house 100 people or 1 Mr. T.
Mnemonic2: The inn is like a big house that can addomodate a hundred persons. Only this time, there´s just Mister T and he´s booked all the rooms!
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　百: hundred
Kunyomi: やど, やど.る, やど.す
Ex2English: Lodge together, stay in a camp for training

Origin: We know that the character for large takes on the meaning of the St. Bernard dog when used as a primitive. In this frame we finally see why. The drop added as a fourth and final stroke means that we have to do with a normal-sized dog, which compared to the St. Bernard is no more than a drop in the kennel.
SubOrigin: As a primitive this character can take two meanings. In the form given here it will mean a very small dog (which we shall refer to as a chihuahua for convenience sake). When it takes the form 犭 to the left of a character, we shall give it the meaning of a pack of wild dogs.
Mnemonic1: A large dog, dripping drool.
Mnemonic2: If we remember large (#107) as a man with his arms outstretched, the drop represents man´s best friend - a dog.
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Plump is one of those delightful English words that almost sound like their meaning. No sooner do you hear it than you think of a round and ample-bodied person falling into a sofa like a large drop of oil plopping into a fishbowl - kerrrr-plump!
Mnemonic1: A large person with a big drop of sweat dripping off of him because he is so plump.
Mnemonic2: Fat("plump") men always have small penises.....the kanji is a combination of "large" with a drop(representing the small penis between his legs).
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: The picture in this kanji is not a pleasant one. It shows a large and fluffy St. Bernard dog stretched out on a table all stuffed and stewed and garnished with vegetables, its paws in the air and an apple in its mouth. At each corner of the table sits an eager but empty mouth, waiting for the utensils to arrive so the feast can begin.
Mnemonic1: Imagine four hungry mouths all sitting around the table. They are all banging their utensils on the table waiting for a big meal to be placed in the centre.
Mnemonic2: Note: 器 by itself means container/caliber/vessel. And 食器 means eating utensils ("food container", hehe).
Compo: 口: mouth　口: mouth　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　口: mouth　口: mouth

Origin: Sheaf . . . shovel.
Mnemonic1: Here the villain digs a hole with a shovel and covers it with a sheaf, hoping someone will fall in.
Mnemonic2: Wolverine (sheaf, see reap (#1488)) takes out a villain who can´t be cut by smacking the crap out of him with a shovel.
Compo: 乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　凵: open box; shovel (RTK)

English: Divide Into Sections, District, Ward, Borough
Origin: The ward referred to here is a subdivision of a large city. Its elements: box . . . sheaves. When used as a primitive element, it may be helpful at times to break it up into these same composite elements.
Mnemonic1: In the homeless ward of the city you see people sleeping in CARDBOARD BOXES using a SHEAF as a pillow.
Mnemonic2: That´s the homeless ward of the city. Wolverine lives in a cardboard box there.
Compo: 匚: box; hook (RTK)　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)

Origin: Pent in . . . Big Dipper. Hint: among the songs dating from the days of slavery that have become part of American folklore is one called "Follow the Drinking Gourd." It referred to the nighttime travel of runaway slaves (those pent in) who had no maps other than the stars to guide them, among them the bright and predominant Big Dipper, the "Drinking Gourd."
Mnemonic1: Can´t see direct relation to Big Dipper (#1177) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it´s written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.
Mnemonic2: A pictograph of a treasure map. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず map; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do.
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　斗: dipper; measuring cup (RTK)

Origin: This key word has been chosen for its overlay of several meanings similar to those of the kanji: a turn of duty, a round, a number, and so forth. Its composite elements: animal tracks . . . rice field.
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, we choose the image of a pair of dice which it is your turn to throw.
Mnemonic1: The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.
Mnemonic2: They take turns alternating between wheat and rice in this field…
Compo: 釆: separate; animal tracks (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)
Ex3English: Be on duty; have one's turn

English: Number, Designation, Title, Name, Sign, Signal
Origin: Mouth . . . snare.
Mnemonic1: My nickname is "No Lips". Yep, I shouldn´t have put my mouth on that bear trap...
Mnemonic2: When certain nickname snares to people´s mouths, they will call you that way forever.
Compo: 口: mouth　丂: snare, slingshot (RTK)

Origin: As in the character for sparkle, the triplication of a single element in this character indicates "everywhere" or "heaps of." When we think of goods in modern industrial society, we think of what has been mass-produced - that is to say, produced for the "masses" of open mouths waiting like fledglings in a nest to "consume" whatever comes their way.
Mnemonic1: Three boxes of goods are devoured by the hungry mouths of waiting consumers.
Mnemonic2: Three hungry mouths waiting for the goods to come.
Compo: 口: mouth　口: mouth　口: mouth

Origin: Dove . . . sparkler . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: Zelda: Ocarina of Time - The white sparkly thing is Navi. She´s hovering/dancing around a tree to the legendary Lost Woods music.
Mnemonic2: There we were at the concert...her voice was like a dove...her dress sparkled...then suddenly, a tree fell on her.....
Compo: 白: white　水: water (氵) (氺)　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: たの.しい, たの.しむ

Origin: Flowers . . . music.
Mnemonic1: New-age medicine involves using things like music and flowers (aromatherapy) as treatment.
Mnemonic2: Oh man, this medicinal marijuana is making me hear MUSIC and see FLOWERS everywhere...
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　楽: music

Origin: Look more closely at your lidded crock and you will see little ruler marks along its bottom edge. This is so you can use it to calculate the circumference of your motorcycle helmet: just begin at a fixed point and turn the lidded crock around and around, keeping it flush against the side of the helmet, until you come back to your starting point. If you kept track of how many turns and part-turns your lidded crock made, you now know the circumference.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character can take the added significance of a lap.
Mnemonic1: If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.
Mnemonic2: You´re at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the circumference of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.
Compo: 冂: hood; belt (RTK)　吉: good luck; lidded crock (RTK); aerosol can (RTK)

Origin: Picture a circular road with 7 markers on it, one for each day of the week. When you have walked one complete lap on this road, you shall have completed one week.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth.
Mnemonic2: Actually the week is like a never ending road where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the circumference is always the same. circumference (#317) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth -- all important for measuring all kinds of time periods.
Compo: 周: circumference; lap　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

English: Tone, Note, Condition, Investigate, Prepare,Make Ready
Origin: A complete tune is composed not only of a succession of notes but also of one lap of the words that go with it.
Mnemonic1: To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what´s being said.
Mnemonic2: words + circumference The most catchy tunes are words the go round and round the circuference of your head and you can´t get it out of your mind.
Compo: 言: word; say　周: circumference; lap
Kunyomi: しら.べる, しら.べ, ととの.う, ととの.える
Ex1Kana: ゆうしょくをととのえる

Origin: In the same way that we were able to see the sun in the tree within the kanji for east, here we see a square container in the shape of a mouth.
Mnemonic1: Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn´t drop the bundle.
Mnemonic2: Unlike in 杏, this big mouth isn´t content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in bundles.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　口: mouth
Kunyomi: たば, たば.ねる, つか*

Origin: Bundle . . . taskmaster . . . correct.
Mnemonic1: Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your bundles are organized correctly otherwise the taskmasters won´t accept them.
Mnemonic2: When a bundle of taskmasters organize something chances are it won´t be done correctly because they are constantly arguing.
Compo: 束: bundle　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)　正: correct; justice
Kunyomi: ととの.える, ととの.う

Origin: Rice . . . woman . . . taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: Young taskmaster is learning numbers by watching women haul sacks of rice past him. "One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!".
Mnemonic2: Women toil in the rice fields carrying heavy sacks of rice to be numbered and counted by the taskmaster.
Compo: 米: rice　女: woman　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Rice . . . St. Bernard dog . . . head.
Mnemonic1: Note this character means sort in the sense of what kind, I believe a better keyword would be "variety" and this character does appear in some dictionaries with the primary meaning as variety, my story: I´m in a Chinese restaurant and the waiter says "What sort of rice would you like with your dog head?".
Mnemonic2: Condi Rice is the SORT of person that would give HEADaches to a BIG DOG.....This story has been edited because of people reporting it. I like it better without "aches", but whatever works for you!
Compo: 米: rice　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Although the elements two and little are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. Something placed atop the altar is put on show for all to see.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji means altar. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the altar in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for cloak, identical except for the one final short stroke.
Mnemonic1: A boy made an altar, but he´s afraid to show it to God because he thinks it´s two little.
Mnemonic2: I´ll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!, she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)

Origin: Grove . . . altar.
Mnemonic1: Similar to radical tyro´s story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably "no smoking" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will).
Mnemonic2: Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol "for sacremental purposes" and share it with his kin (きん).
Compo: 林: grove; forest　示: altar; show (礻)

Origin: This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of salutation so important in Japanese culture. Its elements: altar . . . fishhook.
Mnemonic1: Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away.
Mnemonic2: You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　乙: fishhook; hook

Origin: Altar . . . soil. The company referred to here is that of the modern business world.
Mnemonic1: When you enter a Japanese company it´s like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.
Mnemonic2: Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb "to speak." It is written by a tongue wagging in the mouth with a walking stick rammed through it and coming out at both ends.
SubOrigin: While this kanji has obvious affinities to the "seed" group, it also happens to be the zodiacal sign of the monkey (the one who speaketh no evil, among other things). We shall therefore take monkey as its primitive meaning.
Mnemonic1: I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the "s" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth.
Mnemonic2: I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 sayeth (#578). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in "moshi moshi" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say "hello, this is X speaking.".
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　丨: line; stick
Ex3English: Say, tell, speak humbly; (have the honor to) do

Origin: Altar . . . monkey.
Mnemonic1: The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus´ latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant "speak no evil" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .
Mnemonic2: Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　申: monkey (RTK)
Kunyomi: かみ, かん-, こう-

Origin: How do we get a mouth over a shellfish to mean an employee? Simple. Just remember the advice new employees get about keeping their mouths shut and doing their job, and then make that more graphic by picturing an office building full of white collar workers scurrying around with clams pinched to their mouths.
Mnemonic1: An employee (member of the company) has to clam up his mouth if he wants keep the job!
Mnemonic2: An employee is basically a shellfish with a mouth.
Compo: 口: mouth　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

English: Quality, Nature, Matter, Substance, Pawn, Hostage
Origin: Two axes . . . shells.
Mnemonic1: What is this substance on this clam? I´ve already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問).
Mnemonic2: Another keyword that I do not like by Heisig. 質【しつ】 (n,n-suf) quality. Story: Your at a local ax dealer and you have TWO AXES which you are testing for QUALITY by trying to split CLAMS right down the opening. Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird SUBSTANCE comes out of the shell...eww (I don´t like clams).
Compo: 斤: axe　斤: axe　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Think of this key word as referring to a political party, not a gala affair. Its elements: human legs . . . sticking out of an outhouse window.
Mnemonic1: Every major political party, if personified, would look like a giant outhouse walking around with human legs spewing out a constant stream of bullshit.
Mnemonic2: Every political party is full of shit. But nobody ever says how they get that way. Well, here´s your answer - a political party memer is in the outhouse, greedily chowing down on the contents inside. He´s grown so accustomed to the taste that he´s in all the way, and all you can see are his legs through the window. He´ll come inside later to the auditorium to make a speech and spew everything out.
Compo: 尚: esteem; outhouse (RTK)　儿: human legs

Origin: Outhouse . . . land.
Mnemonic1: There is a secret hall buried in the soil underneath the outhouse.
Mnemonic2: In most communities you will be hauled into city hall if you use the ground as an outhouse.
Compo: 尚: esteem; outhouse (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Outhouse . . . towel.
Mnemonic1: It´s usual to take your towel with you when you go to the outhouse at the onsen (hot springs bath in Japan) so everybody doesn´t see your stuff.
Mnemonic2: In the outhouse toilet you´d usually hope to find toilet paper to wipe your ass. If it´s already gone, which is usually the case, simply use the towel.
Compo: 尚: esteem; outhouse (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: Outhouse . . . shellfish.
Mnemonic1: This is a bit silly.. or maybe not only a bit, but.. You know some foodstuffs (cereals come to mind) sometimes have prizes mixed in them? Well, in this case, the prize was a shell (money, remember) and you only notice in the outhouse... (see also secret (#904)).
Mnemonic2: As a prize for being the 1,000,000th person to use the restaurant´s outhouse, I got all the clams I could eat.
Compo: 尚: esteem; outhouse (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . prize.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T says, "This ain´t no prize, foo! This is reparations for slavery!".
Mnemonic2: NOTE: do not confuse with compensation (#476)賠. However, 賠 is always used in conjunction 賠償... But 償 is used in various other compounds. Mr. T sold all his jewelry to give as reparations to slave families. The governent tried to honor his charity by giving him a prize, but it was a shitty outhouse filled with clams.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　賞: prize
Ex2English: Recompense, make up for, atone for

English: Palm Of One'S Hand, Take Charge Of
Origin: Outhouse . . . hand.
Mnemonic1: If you´re going to manipulate your body with your hand, then go do it in an outhouse, at least!
Mnemonic2: Instead of magazines, we keep a Rubiks Cube in the outhouse to manipulate with your hands while you do your business.
Compo: 尚: esteem; outhouse (RTK)　手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)

English: Perceive, Sense; Realize, Wake Up, Commit To Memory
Origin: The idea of memorizing things is easily related to the schoolhouse; and since we have been at it for more than a hundred pages in this book, the idea that memorizing involves seeing things that are not really there should make it easy to put the two elements together.
Mnemonic1: In a schoolhouse in class: 1) you see something on the blackboard, then 2) you memorize it.
Mnemonic2: You´ll never memorize all the kanji by seeing them in a school house. You need Heisig and RtK!
Compo: ⺍: small　冖: crown 　見: see
Kunyomi: おぼ.える, さ.ます, さ.める, さと.る**

Origin: I know of an Indian religious sect which teaches that enlightenment is to be had by covering the eyes with one's index fingers, the ears with the thumbs, and the mouth with the little fingers. While these differ a bit from the five holes that we used to represent the "I" (frame 17), the idea of achieving a special state of mind by covering those five places can help you learn this kanji. You might try the position out while you are learning this character.
Mnemonic1: Enlightenment is a state of mind that goes beyond the five senses.
Mnemonic2: Data finds enlightenment when he discovers the answer to the question, "Who am I?". (Image: Data meditating in a sitting lotus position).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　吾: I; my
Ex1English: Be ready for; be resigned; make up one's mind

Origin: Mouths . . . marching . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Emotion is a march of mouths inside your heart telling you what to feel.
Mnemonic2: Strong EMOTIONS don´t stay hidden. They march right out of one´s heart (below) and out one´s mouth (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of emotion it is!).
Compo: 戍: protection; march (RTK)　口: mouth　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: The elements depict a St. Bernard with its head and paws keeping their stick-like form, but with the middle or center of its body filled out in a box-like shape.
Mnemonic1: Youve got the st bernard dead centre in your sights (the box).
Mnemonic2: The center of a dog´s universe is his mouth: bark, eat, bite. What a life!
Compo: 央: center; middle

Origin: Sun . . . center.
Mnemonic1: In the solar system, the Sun is the central source of all light, everything else just reflects it.
Mnemonic2: A solar power plant consists of thousands of mirrors reflecting the sun´s rays, concentrating the energy on a focal point at the centre. See here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_Two.
Compo: 日: day; sun　央: center; middle
Kunyomi: うつ.る, うつ.す, は.える, -ば.え
Ex1Kanji: 映画をスクリーンに映す
Ex1Kana: えいがをスクリーンにうつす
Ex1English: Project a motion picture on a screen
Ex3Kana: みずうみにやまがうつる
Ex3English: The mountain is reflected on the surface of the lake

Origin: The etymology of decide (de-cidere = cut off) will help here; the elements are: water . . . guillotine.
Mnemonic1: Decide! "Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?" I asked.
Mnemonic2: To decide if someone is a witch or not first dunk them in water. If they don´t drown they are a witch and can be sent to the guillotine.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　夬: decide; guillotine (RTK)
Kunyomi: き.める, -ぎ.め, き.まる

Origin: State of mind . . . guillotine.
Mnemonic1: A large crowd in a cheerful state of mind applaude each criminal as they become victims of the guillotine.
Mnemonic2: A cheerful crowd of insulted aliens applaude as Data´s head is chopped off by guillotine.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　夬: decide; guillotine (RTK)

Origin: Flowers . . . center. This is another abbreviation used to identify a country by the pronunciation of the kanji.
Mnemonic1: The original great seal of the king of England had a very ornate flower in the center.
Mnemonic2: England is a country where people think they´re the flower at the center of the world. (a description that would fit China much better.. 中華).
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　央: center; middle

English: Line Up, Place In A Row; Average, Ordinary
Origin: This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of the kanji for stand up. By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes, you will see how this is done.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji, but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shape this element can undergo. It is the most difficult one you will meet in this book. When it appears BENEATH its relative primitive, the top three strokes are omitted, though the third horizontal stroke may be doubled up with the bottom horizontal stroke of the element above it. ATOP its relative primitive, it can keep its kanji shape. When it does not, the top three strokes are removed and all of them are replaced BELOW the primitive's bottom line. We shall acknowledge this latter transformation by changing its meaning to upside down in a row.
Mnemonic1: This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing in a row.
Mnemonic2: Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a rowing boat. In a rowing boat people sit in rows, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for "rowboat" coming at frame 1876. The rowing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for "rowboat" has a generic meaning of "a small boat". In any case, the kanji for "rowboat" will not appear as a primitive in the book.
Compo: 並: average; row (RTK)
Kunyomi: なみ, な.み, なら.べる, なら.ぶ, なら.びに
Ex1English: Parallel, going side by side; occurring together
Ex2English: (vt] line up, place in order; enumerate

Origin: This character is easiest remembered as a pictograph of a water lily floating on the surface of the water, which gives it its meaning of even. The fourth stroke represents the calm, smooth surface of a pond, and the final stroke the long stem of the plant reaching underwater.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji can keep its pictographic meaning of a water lily.
Mnemonic1: There´s an even covering of water lilies on the pond at 金閣寺（きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.
Mnemonic2: Frogs stay dry (#1648) 干 even as rain drops on their lily pads…
Compo: 平: plain
Kunyomi: たい.ら, -だいら, ひら, ひら-

Origin: Although the writing order is different, one can remember the appearance of this character by seeing it as a little needle - the kind used for splitting hairs in half. (Again, according to rule, little takes a stroke beneath it in order to be placed over an element that has no horizontal line at the top.)
Mnemonic1: Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.
Mnemonic2: I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in half and there are still two more to go.
Compo: 半: half

Origin: Let the extra vertical stroke in the mane combine with the first vertical stroke to give an image of the horse's long neck. The only odd thing is the tail feathers at the end, but that should present a good image to remember the character by. The fact that the last stroke of mane and the first of tail feathers coincide should no longer surprise you.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji will mean a team of horses as distinct from the single horse whose primitive we met earlier.
Mnemonic1: Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail "feathers". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though.
Mnemonic2: The top part is half a comb (see frame 1920) with an extra vertical stroke to account for a sturdier version used to comb a horse mane. As a primitive I used the theme of the Trojan Horse. Not the modern computer viruses, but the large wooden horse which led to the demise of Troy and of the Trojans. Either its size (much greater than a live horse), or the fact that it conceals things into its belly, will set it appart from the horse primitive that came in frame 568 ("noon").
Compo: 馬: horse

Origin: The key word shaku has actually come into English in the word shakuhachi, the ancient Japanese flute that measured "one shaku and eight sun" (the "sun" being about an inch in length). Since the shaku is about one foot in length, this makes about 20 inches. Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the flag.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this will mean the shakuhachi flute.
Mnemonic1: Slang for blowjob and that´s priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length.
Mnemonic2: Since this is SLANG for BLOW JOB and since it looks like an "R", let´s have the primitive be the R in BROW JOB. :).
Compo: 尺: shaku
Ex1English: End-blown bamboo flute (having a traditional standard length of 1.8 <shaku>)

Origin: Shakuhachi . . . ice.
Mnemonic1: A women is so exhausted by her "shakuhachi" that see needs to ice her jaw.
Mnemonic2: That´s not ice...it´s my last drops and I´m exhausted! ;).
Compo: 尺: shaku　冫: ice
Kunyomi: つ.くす, -つ.くす, -ず.くし, つ.きる, つ.かす
Ex3English: Be exhausted; come to an end

Origin: Team of horses . . . shakuhachi.
Mnemonic1: Anyone living in Japan knows that train stations play little melodies when the train is about to arrive. In Ye Olden Days, when horses and carriages were used for transport, the carriage driver would play a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know the carriage was arriving at the next station.
Mnemonic2: A homeless horse playing the flute at the station to make a dime.
Compo: 馬: horse　尺: shaku

Origin: Dove . . . one . . . tail feathers. This is, of course, the character from which we derived the primitive meaning of dove. Note the lengthening of the second stroke.
Mnemonic1: There is only one bird with such beautiful white tail feathers: the albino peakcock.
Mnemonic2: The BIRD let loose a WHITE ONE from it´s TAIL FEATHERS...right on my new car!
Compo: 鳥: bird

Origin: The bird's tail is tucked under here, because it has come to stop on a mountain to rest from its journey across the waters. Thus the kanji comes to mean an island.
Mnemonic1: This island is the home of the terrible mythical bird Roc. It sits mighty atop the mountain waiting for the next hapless ship to pass by.
Mnemonic2: Birds living on remote mountainous islands have few preditors. Tail feathers aren´t really needed are they? Evolutionary process at work!...
Compo: 鳥: bird　山: mountain

Origin: Bound up . . . glass canopy . . . walking stick . . . two. If you write the character once, you will see why we avoided using the element for soil, which would prompt you to write it in improper order.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, imagine the tool used by draftsmen and carpenters to draw right-angles.
Mnemonic1: A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an angle.
Mnemonic2: The gates have been bound up together leaving no angle to get through…
Compo: 角: angle

Origin: Work with the pictograph as you wish.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this insect will refer to the whole insect kingdom; it can be further specified for each kanji that contains it.
Mnemonic1: I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an insect biting into the arm, sucking some blood.
Mnemonic2: Insect in one drop of amber. Think Jurassic Park.
Compo: 虫: insect

Origin: Angle . . . insect.
Mnemonic1: For insects to get in contact with each other, they need to place their antennae at just the right angle.
Mnemonic2: Wow, he threw that BOOMERANG with such skill, it made CONTACT with that INSECT in mid flight.
Compo: 角: angle　虫: insect
Ex3English: Touch, feel; come into contact with

Origin: Angle . . . dagger . . . cow.
Mnemonic1: Did you know that you can unravel a cow? If you stick the dagger in at exactly the correct angle, the whole cow will just unravel.
Mnemonic2: Unravel the mystery by determining at what ANGLE the SWORD went into the COW.
Compo: 角: angle　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　牛: cow (⺧)
Kunyomi: と.く, と.かす, と.ける
Ex1English: (vi] come loose, come undone; be solved

Origin: Think of this key word in connection with bachelorhood. The elements: wild dogs . . . insect.
Mnemonic1: The bachelor´s apartment looked like it had been attacked by a pack of wild dogs. There were even insects in the kitchen. No wonder he´s single!
Mnemonic2: A SINGLE guy is a WILD DOG who BUGS many women.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　虫: insect

Origin: Cave . . . fortune-telling.
Mnemonic1: Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.
Mnemonic2: The fortuneteller has a store in a cave.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　占: fortune-telling

Origin: This is one of those kanji that is a real joy of simplicity: a divining rod with a mouth - which translate directly into fortune-telling. Note how the movement from top to bottom (the movement in which the kanji are written) is also the order of the elements which make up our story and of the key word itself: first divining rod, then mouth. This will not always be possible, but where it is, memory has almost no work at all to do.
Mnemonic1: Fortune-telling: using a mouth as a divining rod.
Mnemonic2: A great number of people who do fortune-telling are "almost old".
Compo: 卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: If you look into the flickering of a fire for a long time and then turn aside, you will see spots before your eyes. Although nobody ever thought of such a thing before - as least as far as know, they didn't - imagine using those spots as a technique for fortune-telling. The old witch sits before her cauldron and watches the spots that show up when she turns to look at you, and from that tells your fortune. Think of it as a kind of spot-check on your future.
Mnemonic1: The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.
Mnemonic2: You have to stimulate the G-spot with your magic wand in order to get her on fire. Or you can juste use your mouth...
Compo: 占: fortune-telling　火: fire (灬)
Ex3English: On that point, in that respect

English: Military Man, Man Of Learning, Professional Suffix,
Origin: The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for soil by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's gentlemen.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning reverts to the more colorful image of the samurai, Japan's warrior class.
Mnemonic1: What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He´s like a modern samurai!
Mnemonic2: A gentleman has broad shoulders and doesn´t soil himself.
Compo: 士: gentleman; samurai

Origin: See the peddlar standing atop his motorcycle helmet as if it were a soapbox, hawking his wares to passersby. The legs and mouth represent the tools of the trade of making a deal any way you can.
Mnemonic1: I use what I think is the real etymology for this kanji which is so shocking it sticks. The STANDING member at the top is a certain part of the body that all men have and it is approaching the HOLE between TWO LEGS (the HOOD) with extra marks to show they are FLESHY - ie a womans legs. So this shows the oldest DEAL of all time - prostitution.
Mnemonic2: Slick Willy standing on the motorcycle helmet he´s trying to sell you to demonstrate how rugged it is. His legs crash through the top of it and after a moment of awkward silence his mouth opens and says, "hey, we can still make a deal.".
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　儿: human legs　口: mouth

Origin: Eye . . . shellfish.
Mnemonic1: When something catches my eye, I take out a few clams and buy before anybody else does.
Mnemonic2: Rules to Buying: 1. You´ve had your eye on it for a while. 2. You have enough shells to afford it.
Compo: 目: eye　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: A samurai, out of a job, is going door-to-door selling little windup crowns with human legs that run around on the floor looking like headless monarchs.
Mnemonic1: The samurai happened to find an extra large crown that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his legs. I wonder if he will sell it to me?
Mnemonic2: A "samurai" will never sell his "crown" (king), even it meant having both his "human legs" chopped off!
Compo: 士: gentleman; samurai　冖: crown 　儿: human legs

Origin: Thread . . . sell.
Mnemonic1: If you attach strings to the things you sell, you will be able to continue making profit from them even after the fact.
Mnemonic2: Even though Peter Parker has become Spiderman, he continues to sell pictures that he takes as a photographer.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　売: sell

Origin: In the age of advertising, most words we read are out to sell some product or point of view.
Mnemonic1: Read the WORDS used to SELL things.
Mnemonic2: People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don´t believe everything you read (読).
Compo: 言: word; say　売: sell
Onyomi: ドク, トク, トウ

Origin: Salad . . . animal legs.
SubOrigin: The primitive retains the meaning of together. Imagine things strung together like fish on a line, beads on a thread, or whatever. The main thing is to avoid putting them in a straight row, which would confound this element with the previous one. As we saw with bushel basket, this primitive can join its legs to the final horizontal stroke and stretch them to form an enclosure.
Mnemonic1: The character for deluge (#1799) gave me the idea to use together as a primitive for Noah´s Ark. Noah kept plenty of salad on board to entice the animals with their animal legs to scurry on board together, two by two.
Mnemonic2: The conjoined twins, who are always together, have trouble eating together because one is a vegetarian, eating salad and the other is a avid meat eater, eating chicken legs.(Thanks fuaburisu!].
Compo: 共: together

Origin: Submit here is a transitive verb, meaning to offer or present. Its elements: person . . . strung together.
Mnemonic1: You have to SUBMIT all required documents together, in person!
Mnemonic2: When people are together and form a group, they suddenly submit their personal responsibility to the mob mentality.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　共: together
Kunyomi: そな.える, とも, -ども
Ex3English: To offer something to the spirit

Origin: Water . . . strung together.
Mnemonic1: Lots of water coming together is called a deluge.
Mnemonic2: A real deluge of water, as if all water worked together, as if strung together haphazardly.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　共: together

Origin: Salad . . . days. This is the character with which Japanese fairytales commonly begin.
Mnemonic1: Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day.
Mnemonic2: For those who don´t know the expression, "salad days" means the time of one´s youth. (originally from Shakespeare´s Antony and Cleopatra - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days). I suspect Heisig chose "salad" as the name for the radical just for this phrase...
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　日: day; sun
Ex1English: Past and present, yesterday and today

Origin: Walking legs slipping on the ice are a sure sign of winter.
Mnemonic1: Don´t slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet.
Mnemonic2: In winter my walking legs feel like blocks of ice.
Compo: 夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)　冫: ice

Origin: House . . . celery . . . animal legs . . . ice.
Mnemonic1: Don't mix up with cool (#1404), when the cool boys order each other around. This kind of cold has to do with weather. When its cold outside, I stay at home and have hot celery soup with chicken legs to keep out the ice. 寒い ＝ さむい ＝cold.
Mnemonic2: Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn´t get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　共: together　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　⺀: ice (冫)

Origin: Bonsai . . . sun.
Mnemonic1: In the springtime bonsai get plenty of sun.
Mnemonic2: When it´s springtime you can only leave the bonsai out when the sun has gone down. Their little leaves can´t handle too much heat.
Compo: 𡗗: bonsai (RTK)　日: day; sun

Origin: In the summer, fatigued by the heat, your head hangs down nearly as far as your walking legs, or rather, your "dragging legs." Note how the walking legs (instead of "animal legs") are the only thing that distinguishes this character from that for page (Frame 64).
Mnemonic1: In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.
Mnemonic2: I personally think it was too confusing to try and use head as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the animal legs are replaced with walking legs instead of human legs?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot summer and you want to keep oneself under a ceiling not out jogging around.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　自: oneself; nose (RTK)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . fire.
Mnemonic1: In AUTUMN, the WHEAT looks the color of FIRE, meaning it´s time to harvest it.
Mnemonic2: Every autumn the wheat is set on fire to clear the way for next year´s crop...
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: A man's home is his castle, goes the proverb from an age where it was the male who was lord of the household. Fundamentally, it means only that every one of us is a bit (or drop) of a king in our own environment. As for the positioning of the elements, if you take care to "read off" the primitives in this way, you won't end up putting the drop down below, where it turns the kanji into a jewel.
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, we set the key word aside entirely and take it as a pictograph of a solid brass candlestick (with the drop representing the flame at the top).
Mnemonic1: A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy.
Mnemonic2: Although this kanji´s meaning hasn´t caused me much trouble, I´ve had problems remembering the direction of the drop above king, since drops at tops of kanji often seem to appear in different directions. To remember this one, I think of the placement of the drop in jewel (#256). Both of them use the king primitive and include a short drop stroke going from the top left to bottom right.
Compo: 丶: dot; drop　王: king; ball (RTK)
Kunyomi: ぬし, おも, あるじ*

Origin: Person . . . candlestick.
Mnemonic1: When Mr T shows people round his dwelling he takes a big candlestick (with a candle in it!) so that the light shows off his collection of bling bling jewellery.
Mnemonic2: Mister T dwells in a big brass candlestick, the flame of which serves as a beacon for the boats in the nearby harbour. Sometimes in the morning, Mister T has to clear the wax that has landed and solidified in front of the door.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　主: lord; candlestick (RTK)
Kunyomi: す.む, す.まう, -ず.まい
Ex1Kanji: どこに住んでいますか
Ex1Kana: どこにすんでいますか

Origin: Team of horses . . . candlestick.
Mnemonic1: In the olden days you had to park your horse next to a candlestick, a primitive parking meter that you start by lighting a fire and tracks the time by burning down.
Mnemonic2: In the olden days parking lots used to have reserved spaces for where the lord (of the set of houses, shops, whatever) could park his team of horses. nowadays it´s pretty much the same...reserved parking in front for the big bosses´ cars....
Compo: 馬: horse　主: lord; candlestick (RTK)

Origin: Picture pouring water from a lighted candlestick. What could be more ridiculous, or simpler, as a way to recall this kanji?
Mnemonic1: Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to pour it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere.
Mnemonic2: Like water the hot wax poured down the side of the candlestick.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　主: lord; candlestick (RTK)

Origin: Samurai . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: A samurai´s intentions always come from the heart.
Mnemonic2: Gentleman always have hearts full of good intentions.
Compo: 士: gentleman; samurai　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: こころざ.す, こころざし

Origin: Words . . . intention.
Mnemonic1: A will is an important document that contains your final word on how you intend to distribute your assets.
Mnemonic2: This is quite simple: a document is a set of words describing your intentions.
Compo: 言: word; say　志: intention

Origin: Person . . . samurai. The key word means to wait on someone or serve them.
Mnemonic1: Back in the day, a person who stands beside a samurai is usually attending to them or working for them.
Mnemonic2: (+fuaburisu] Mr T attends to Tom Cruise in the Last Samurai, who is doing hara-kiri. Imagine Tom Cruise outside in the final scene, stabbing his knife into his stomach, while Mr T looks patiently on. "I pity da foo....no, really.".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　士: gentleman; samurai
Ex2English: Doer; protagonist in a noh drama

Origin: Person . . . porter.
Mnemonic1: It is always Mr. T´s responsibility to be the porter and carry around everyone´s luggage because he´s so strong.
Mnemonic2: In pregnancy (#507), the woman was the porter for the first nine months. Now, as a new father, Mr.T is assuming all the RESPONSIBILITIES that comes with it. Can´t you just see him here as the new porter, wearing a harness with a his little dude (who already has a little matching mohawk)?
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　壬: porter (RTK)
Ex1English: Leave (up) to, entrust with; leave alone

English: Branch, Support, Prop Up, Be Obstructed
Origin: Needle . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: Picture sliding down the branch of a tree (in this case a pine tree or any tree with needles) and getting a bunch of needles stuck in your crotch--ouch!!
Mnemonic2: A special branch of the military called the Needle Crotch Unit. Their only weapon is the needle embedded in their crotches, and they´re quite adept at using them.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)
Kunyomi: ささ.える, つか.える, か.う

Origin: Cliff . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: I think of an anti-hero (Dirty Harry etc.) for this primitive, whose trademark for disposing of villians is not an honorable fight, but a kick in the crotch and then a shove off a cliff (perhaps whilst the villain´s back is turned).
Mnemonic2: Many cultures are so anti-sex you´d think they just want people to throw their crotches over a cliff.
Compo: 厂: cliff　又: again; crotch (RTK)
Onyomi: ハン, ホン, タン

Origin: Ground . . . anti-.
Mnemonic1: As the villain (pushed off by the anti-hero) is tumbling down the slope, he activates gadget skis to escape, spraying soil everywhere as he flies down the slope.
Mnemonic2: This kanji depicts a classic enviornmental problem: erosion. Erosion occurs when all of the soil washes of the side of the cliff, eventually causing the cliff to disappear, leaving a slope (an anti- cliff if you will) in its place.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　反: anti-

Origin: This character is used for proper names, much as the English word "Heights" is. Its primitives: pinnacle . . . anti-.
Mnemonic1: If you´re scared of Heights, you don´t want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with "mountain".
Mnemonic2: People are being displaced in 大阪 to make room for a new development, Osaka Heights, the pinnacle of modern Japanese housing. An angry mob of protestors are outside with Anti-Osaka Heights signs.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　反: anti-

Origin: Food . . . anti-.
Mnemonic1: After I eat a meal, I always have to take an anti-acid.
Mnemonic2: I´m anti-fastfood. Sit down and eat a real meal!
Compo: 食: eat; food　反: anti-

Origin: Anti- . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Pretty obvious: to return is to turn back on the road you´re on and go the opposite way.
Mnemonic2: In "The Return of the anti-hero", Clint Eastwood kicks the villain in the crotch, pushes them off the cliff and onto a busy highway. A tiring movie franchise to say the least....
Compo: 反: anti-　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: かえ.す, -かえ.す, かえ.る, -かえ.る

Origin: Baseball . . . trees . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Newscast: "Among today´s miscellaneous stories, we have a report on a baseball team that was chased up a tree by a turkey. Stay tuned for this and more!".
Mnemonic2: On the left we have baseball and wood, which obviously means a baseball bat. Instead of balls, there are miscellaneous other objects you may hit with it. While beating people may be one favorite use, in this case we see it used for making turkey mash.
Compo: 九: nine; baseball (RTK)　木: tree; wood　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: In a riot, manners are laid aside and tempers get short, even in so courtesy-conscious a land as Japan. This kanji shows what happens to a rioting tongue: it gets "barbed" like a fishhook, and sets to attacking the opposition, to hook them as it were.
Mnemonic1: The riot police broke up the riot by dragging the rioters away by their tongues with fishooks.
Mnemonic2: A tongue with a hook can cause a riot.
Compo: 舌: tongue　乚: hidden; hook (RTK)
Kunyomi: みだ.れる, みだ.る, みだ.す
Ex2English: Be disordered, be confused; be chaotic

Origin: This kanji actually stood for a small measurement used prior to the metric system, a bit over an inch in length, and from there acquired the sense of measurement. In the old system, it was one-tenth of a shaku (whose kanji we shall meet in frame 1151). The picture, appropriately, represents one drop of a ten (with a hook!).
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall use this to mean glue or glued to. There is no need to devise a story to remember this, since the primitive will appear so often you would have to struggle hard NOT to remember it.
Mnemonic1: The decimal system uses drops of ten as a measurement.
Mnemonic2: Glue two sticks together to make the best measurement. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).
Compo: 寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: You have heard of people "attaching" themselves to a particular sect? Here is your chance to take that metaphor literally and imagine some fellow walking into a Buddhist temple with a fervent resolve to attach himself to the place. Since there is plenty of unused land around the precincts, he simply picks out a suitable patch, brushes the soles of his feet with glue, steps down firmly, and so joins the Buddhist temple as a "permanent member."
Mnemonic1: At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation.
Mnemonic2: To be allowed to join the Buddhist temple, imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the soil for a long time in a measurement of his resolve.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: What is time? asked St. Augustine in his memoirs. "Ask me not, and I know. Ask me, and I cannot tell you." Here we have the kanji's answer to that perennial riddle. Time is a sun rising over a Buddhist temple. It sounds almost like a Zen kōan whose repetition might yield some deep secret to the initiated. At any rate, imagining a monk seated in meditation pondering it might help us remember the character.
Mnemonic1: When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it´s time to get up.
Mnemonic2: In ancient Japan, TIME of ´´day´´ was announced at the ´´buddhist temples´´. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the time of day.
Compo: 日: day; sun　寺: Buddhist temple

Origin: Fingers . . . Buddhist temple.
Mnemonic1: At the BUDDHIST TEMPLE you´ll see wonderous things, such as the priest that can HOLD himself upside down with just a FINGER.
Mnemonic2: In Kyaiktiyo, there is rocking stone which sits on the edge of a cliff, and there is a Buddhist temple built on the top of it. You can rock the stone by pushing it with your finger, but it still holds in place. It´s true, see here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyaiktiyo.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　寺: Buddhist temple

Origin: Despite the strong phonetic similarity, there will be no problem keeping the key word special distinct from the character we met earlier for specialty (Frame 47), since the latter has immediate connotations lacking in this kanji. Anyway, we shall let the key word of this frame refer to something in a special class all its own - like the sacred cows of India that wander freely without fear of being butchered and ground into hamburger. Even though the practice is originally a Hindu one, and in any case no longer followed among the majority of Japanese Buddhist monks, the Buddha's refusal to take the life of any sentient being makes it only fitting that the cows should be placed on the sacred grounds of a Buddhist temple in this kanji.
Mnemonic1: Think of not special people, but special animals. The sacred Hindu cows are special - they can wander around the temple without fear of becoming roast beef.
Mnemonic2: The Church Lady is traveling through Japan and notices with distaste a sacred cow relieving itself inside a Buddhist Temple. "Well, isn´t that special".
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　寺: Buddhist temple

Origin: Line . . . Buddhist temple.
Mnemonic1: A line queued up outside the Buddhist temple, waiting to see the shrine on New Year´s Day.
Mnemonic2: The COLUMNS of this TEMPLE are a well-know meeting spot. You can always see someone WAITING there.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　寺: Buddhist temple

Origin: Column . . . nightbreak . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: To gain more knowledge of what´s goin on in the world I´m reading column after column of articles in the newspapers, and it takes so much time I´m glued to it till nightbreak.
Mnemonic2: Imagine fat people......they avoid going outside to exercise and stay glued to their TV set until nightbreak....so of course they gain weight.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)
Ex1English: Acquire, gain; can, be able to

Origin: Person . . . Buddhist temple. The key word is deceptively modern, but the kanji is actually another way of writing "samurai." Be careful not to confuse with attend (Frame 1033).
Mnemonic1: Mr. T infiltrates the secret samurai Buddhist temple as a waiter with a tray of green tea. (Careful: attend (#960)).
Mnemonic2: Remember the kanji for wait, 待. Well, now we have a waiter, and he´s dropped a dish. See: 侍! 待 crash 侍.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　寺: Buddhist temple

Origin: Since silence is treasured so highly at a Buddhist temple the words spoken there must be well-chosen. Perhaps this is why the records of the monks often read to us like poems. Before going on, back up a frame and make sure you have kept poem and recitation distinct in your mind.
Mnemonic1: A poem is a temple of words.
Mnemonic2: WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That´s why most people will speak using a poem if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.
Compo: 言: word; say　寺: Buddhist temple

Origin: Silver . . . stamp.
Mnemonic1: He scratches off the silver stamp and discovers that he is an instant winner.
Mnemonic2: For instant postal delivery, buy a silver stamp!
Compo: 艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

English: Joint, Node, Section, Space; Space Out, Economize, Season, Time
Origin: Bamboo . . . instant.
Mnemonic1: Counting the nodes on bamboo is an instant way to tell its age.
Mnemonic2: A certain species of bamboo is considered the fastest growing plant in the world. A new node can be formed in an instant.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　即: instant

Origin: Bamboo . . . part of the body . . . power. Here we see how the primitive meaning of muscle was derived from the kanji for power.
Mnemonic1: Muscle is part of the body that gives strength, and can be both supple and tense like the bamboo.
Mnemonic2: Lifting BAMBOO STICKS is an old way for your BODY to put on lots of MUSCLE.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　月: moon; month　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)
Ex2English: Reason, thread (of an argument), coherence; systematic method

Origin: Bamboo . . . Buddhist temple.
Mnemonic1: The Bamboo Buddhist Temple has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, etc. etc. etc.
Mnemonic2: So what´d you see in Japan? - "Bamboo, temples...etc.".
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　寺: Buddhist temple

Origin: The level this key word refers to is not the carpenter's tool but rather the even surface of a thing. It pictures soil being scooped up into a ladle and then made level (apparently because one is measuring soil). The excess drops of soil are brushed off the top, which accounts for the added drop at the ladle's edge.
Mnemonic1: Soil is scooped up into a ladel. The extra drop is brushed off to make it level.
Mnemonic2: To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil from the ladle falling out onto the ground when you level it.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　冫: ice

Origin: Wheat . . . child.
Mnemonic1: There´s a season for planting wheat and there´s mating season for having children.
Mnemonic2: Look at this adorable child with a bale of wheat on his head! He´s playing Autumn in his school play the "Four Seasons". Aww...too cute! Perhaps we should light the wheat on fire to complete his Autumn costume. (I know, twisted...but I kept forgetting what was on his head).
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　子: child

Origin: Wheat . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: Female WHEAT farmers decide to create a COMMITTEE, which they fittingly name “The WHEAT WOMEN COMMITTEE.”.
Mnemonic2: At committe meetings, Japanese bureaucrats slurp ramen noodles off of naked women.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　女: woman
Ex2Kana: じょうにんいいんかい

Origin: House . . . eight.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji uses an alternate form: the primitive for eight is replaced with that for human legs.
Mnemonic1: A black hole is a "House of Infinity". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways "8", but here we have a Japanese "8" instead.
Mnemonic2: Billiards anyone? House rules here state that the first person to pot the eight ball into the hole wins the game.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　八: eight; go in (RTK)

Origin: Hole . . . craft.
Mnemonic1: The craft of creating a black hole is in creating an emptiness which can attract things.
Mnemonic2: Hole-craft is the way of making empty spaces, like the sky.
Compo: 穴: hole　工: craft; construction
Kunyomi: そら, あ.く, あ.き, あ.ける, から, むな.しい*, す.く*

Origin: By one's side . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: A good friend is always at your side. ---- I teach at a Japanese High School, and I often see chummy male students grabbing each other´s crotches in a joking manner. It´s still weird to me, but apparently reaching to your side and grabbing you neighbor´s crotch is a great way to express friendship.
Mnemonic2: Think of a sex friend (a fuck buddy if you will). The benefit of such a relationship is that there will always be a crotch by your side. (the Japanese refer to such a friend as セフレ, just as we do).
Compo: 𠂇: side　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: The picture here is of someone with a slab of meat dangling by the side, perhaps from a belt or rope tied around the waist. Think of it as an evil spirit in possession of one's soul, who can be exorcized only by allowing fresh meat to hang by one's side until it begins to putrefy and stink so bad that the demon departs. Take careful note of the stroke order.
Mnemonic1: Possessed by the Earth´s gravity, the moon stays by its side.
Mnemonic2: By my side I POSSESS a moon of flesh, better known as your big ass!
Compo: 𠂇: side　月: moon; month

Origin: By combining the primitive and the kanji of the last two frames and reading the results, we get: by one's side . . . craft. Conveniently, the left has traditionally been considered the "sinister" side, where dark and occult crafts are cultivated. Note how the second stroke droops over to the left and is longer than the first.
Mnemonic1: The LEFT side of my brain posesses the faculties needed for logical crafts, like engineering.
Mnemonic2: The left side of my brain, is for crafts.
Compo: 𠂇: side　工: craft; construction

Origin: When thinking of the key word right, in order to avoid confusion with the previous frame, take advantage of the double meaning here, too. Imagine a little mouth hanging down by your side - like a little voice of conscience - telling you the right thing to do. Here the second stroke should reach out to the right and be drawn slightly longer than the first.
Mnemonic1: The right hand is for putting food in your mouth. (The other hand is for ass-wiping!).
Mnemonic2: Always keep your right to free speech (mouth) by your side!
Compo: 𠂇: side　口: mouth

Origin: With a mouth under a cliff, what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern, before which a great stone has been rolled so that none may enter. Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their treasures, in which case that magic word known to every school child who ever delighted over the tales of the Arabian Nights should be enough to push the stone aside. But take care - the cliff is steep, and one slip will send you tumbling down into the ravine below. This is the one and only time that the second stroke in cliff will reach over to the middle of the horizontal stroke. If you think of the edge jutting outwards (in keeping with the story above), the problem should be taken care of.
SubOrigin: The stone is a quite common primitive element, which is not restricted to great boulders but used of stones or rocks of any size or shape.
Mnemonic1: Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of cliff just in time to evade the huge STONE rolling out of the mouth of the cave!
Mnemonic2: There´s a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the cliff thing isn´t working for you... Just see it as a stone (いし] being hammered by a miner searching for jewel stones (ほうせき] ;).
Compo: 丆: hang; cliff　口: mouth
Onyomi: セキ, シャク, コク
Ex3English: Kill two birds with one stone

Origin: Here we see a flower held in the right hand. You can imagine yourself in a magic garden where flowers picked with the right hand grant eternal youth; and those picked with the left, premature senility. Go ahead, pick one with each hand and watch what happens.
Mnemonic1: The young little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.
Mnemonic2: In Hawaii, if you wear a flower over your left ear, it means you are taken. A flower over the right means you are not. The younger you are, the more likely you are to have a flower over your right ear…
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　右: right
Kunyomi: わか.い, わか-, も.しくわ, も.し*

Origin: The picture of suffering we are given here is that of a flower that has grown old. When a flower ages, it pales and dries up, and probably even suffers. If you think that plants are incapable of such feelings, then ask yourself why so many people believe that talking to their flowers helps them bloom better.
Mnemonic1: Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.
Mnemonic2: The derivates from opium poppies such as morphine can be used to tame the suffering of the old.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　古: old
Kunyomi: くる.しい, -ぐる.しい, くる.しむ, くる.しめる, にが.い, にが.る

Origin: Genie in the bottle . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: Genie in the bottle does exist but you need to dig deep into the soil to find one.
Mnemonic2: You wipe the soil from the bottle, only to have a genie float out above you, saying: ´I am the genie in a bottle, what is your wish?´ So now you know that they do exist.
Compo: 𠂇: side　丨: line; stick　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Genie in the bottle . . . a child. Hint: focus on the key word's connotation of "make believe".
Mnemonic1: How do you suppose they manage to cram a genie inside a bottle? Well, I suppose they put him in there while he´s still a little child...
Mnemonic2: Villagers on a little remote island one day find a bottle washed out by the sea onto the beach. After wiping the bottle and taking a closer look, they are amazed to see a (very small) child in it. The villagers suppose that the child is a genie in a bottle.
Compo: 𠂇: side　丨: line; stick　子: child

Origin: It is best to see this kanji as a pictograph of a revolving circular clothesline (viewed from the side). Spin it around quickly in your mind's eye to give it the connotation of to dry.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning is clothesline.
Mnemonic1: Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline.
Mnemonic2: Note: the book shows the strokes for potato rather than dry...dry does not have the hook at the end.
Compo: 干: dry
Kunyomi: ほ.す, ほ.し-, -ぼ.し, ひ.る
Ex3English: A number of, some, a little

Origin: Dry . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published.
Mnemonic2: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry. This gives the government a chance to censor the news: they cut up unwanted stories with a sabre. Therefore, only state-approved stories are published.
Compo: 干: dry　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Water . . . dry.
Mnemonic1: The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off.
Mnemonic2: When you sweat your clothes become soaked with water, prompting you to hang them to dry on a clothesline.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　干: dry
竹: bamboo (⺮)　干: dry

Origin: Wheat . . . saber. Be careful not to confuse with gain (Frame 941) or earnings (Frame 959).
Mnemonic1: In the middle ages there where only 2 ways for peasantry to make a profit. one by being a farmer, 2 to be a mercenary and live by the way of the sword.
Mnemonic2: 1. Steal a bunch of wheat from a wheat field by cutting it down with your saber. 2. ????? 3. Profit!
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: House . . . grow up . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: With kids growing up in your house, you have to keep them from harm of putting anything in their mouth, paint chips, bleach, knvies, etc.
Mnemonic2: This is silly, but.. If a house suddenly grows up from your mouth, you will come to great harm.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　龶: grow up, master (RTK)　口: mouth
Ex1English: Interests, what one stands to gain or lose

Origin: Poised over the dish here is a pair of animal horns that are attached to a pair of animal legs by a single horizontal stroke.
Mnemonic1: The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first.
Mnemonic2: The benefit of being an animal with horns and fast legs is in keeping it from becoming a dish for the other animals! (shaydwyrm).
Compo: 䒑: weeds　ハ: animal legs (RTK)　皿: dish
水: water (氵) (氺)　益: benefit
Kunyomi: あふ.れる, こぼ.れる, こぼ.す

Origin: Harm . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: (proportion; comparatively; divide; cut; separate; split] Hey, don´t take this out of proportion! I did you just a little harm, no need to come over here with a saber...
Mnemonic2: As shown on this pie-chart, the proportion of people harmed by sabres is relatively a small slice compared to those harmed by guns.
Compo: 害: harm　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Kunyomi: わ.る, わり, わ.り, わ.れる, さ.く

Origin: The key word refers to the fundamental guiding principles of a government or other organization. Its elements: House . . . grow up . . . eyes . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: The constitution is important. At least my parents thought so. In the house where I grew up, it was framed on the wall. Under the watchful (sideways) eye of my mother, we had to study it until we knew it by heart.
Mnemonic2: The constitution states the following rights: You may live in your own house and grow up. And you will never be watched by big brother's eye so they cannot control your heart (your believes).
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　⺷: grow up　目: eye　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: From the pictograph of two bird-wings, we get feathers.
SubOrigin: The related image of wings can be added as a primitive meaning. It can also take the form <sup>ョョ</sup> when used as a primitive, as we shall see in frames 618 and 619.
Mnemonic1: Pictograph. Easy enough.
Mnemonic2: These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their FEATHERS.
Compo: 羽: feathers; wings

Origin: Feathers . . . vase. Be sure to contrast the connotation of this keyword with that for next (Frame 510).
Mnemonic1: The following segment is sponsored by...Swiffer - who make excellent feather dusters for cleaning your vases.
Mnemonic2: Your feathers would also stand up if you were a hen in a slaughter house and you heard: "The following!".
Compo: 羽: feathers; wings　立: stand up; vase (RTK)

Origin: Feathers . . . white bird.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a white bird loosing a couple feathers as it is learning to fly. You learn a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you learn that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”...
Mnemonic2: Learning is all about adding more feathers to your cap and the most prestigious of all is the beautiful pure white feather you´ll receive when you have learned the kanji!
Compo: 羽: feathers; wings　白: white

Origin: This character pictures the bent wooden bow. Later we will learn how to make the bowstring that goes with it (Frame 1490). If you stretch this character out and see the indentation on the left as its handle, the pictography should be clearer.
Mnemonic1: My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.
Mnemonic2: I have a BOW made from a SNAKE that I BOUND UP. He sure wasn´t happy!
Compo: 弓: bow

Origin: Bow . . . walking stick.
Mnemonic1: Put a walking stick in the bow and pull it back, ready to fire at the geezer.
Mnemonic2: This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). Pull and release to fire!
Compo: 弓: bow　丨: line; stick
Kunyomi: ひ.く, ひ.き, ひ.き-, -び.き, ひ.ける
Ex1English: Draw, pull, haul, tug; drag, trail

Origin: Vast . . . insect. Note how the elbow of vast is shrunken and elevated to make room for the insect beneath.
Mnemonic1: An insect who can fly vast distances is strong.
Mnemonic2: Legolas is so strong that he can even shoot down vast numbers of tiny insects at vast distances with ease.
Compo: 弓: bow　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　虫: insect
Kunyomi: つよ.い, つよ.まる, つよ.める, し.いる

Origin: Two bows . . with ice on them.
Mnemonic1: Two weak archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it´s wintertime and their bows are coated in ice.
Mnemonic2: BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and WEAK.
Compo: 弓: bow　冫: ice　弓: bow　冫: ice
Kunyomi: よわ.い, よわ.る, よわ.まる, よわ.める

Origin: Windy . . . drops of . . . insects. Hint: think of the last two primitives as representing a swarm of gnats, those tiny drops of pesky insects.
Mnemonic1: They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of WIND that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.
Mnemonic2: The WIND usually carries things around in it - drops of rain or snow, and lots of insects.
Compo: 几: table; wind (RTK)　丿: katakana no　虫: insect

Origin: The kanji carries the abstract sense of the self, the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology has often depicted as a snake - which is what the kanji shows pictographically. Be sure to keep it distinct from the similar keywords, oneself (frame 36) and I (frame 17).
SubOrigin: As a primitive element, this kanji can be used for the snake - of which it is a pictograph - or any of the various concrete symbolic meanings the snake has in myth and fable.
Mnemonic1: This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".
Mnemonic2: When Superman looks at himself in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.
Compo: 已: oneself; snake (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . snake.
Mnemonic1: A scribe writes down the words spoken by a snake (i.e. a lawyer).
Mnemonic2: Snakes have no hands. So, when a snake needs to write down something, it has to call in a SCRIBE, who will write down all the sayings of the snake.
Compo: 言: word; say　已: oneself; snake (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . snake.
Mnemonic1: In a CHRONICLE the THREAD of the story can twist and turn like a SNAKE.
Mnemonic2: Worst fan fiction ever....SPIDERMAN joins the CHRONICLES of narnia to battle a big SNAKE!!
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　已: oneself; snake (RTK)

Origin: Pluralizing the snake and focusing on a single taskmaster may help recommend the image of Ireland's most famous reformer, St. Patrick, who, legend has it, drove away the snakes from the land.
Mnemonic1: The taskmaster of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a snake ) plans a reformation of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle-born. こわいですね！.
Mnemonic2: This is a Meiji reformation taskmaster, trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a snake in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).
Compo: 已: oneself; snake (RTK)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Kunyomi: あらた.める, あらた.まる

Origin: Run . . . snake.
Mnemonic1: Be careful when you´re RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and ROUSE a sleeping SNAKE. Then you´ll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!
