Mnemonic2: Nothing will rouse you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you´ve never run before!
Compo: 走: run　已: oneself; snake (RTK)
Kunyomi: お.きる, お.こる, お.こす ・

Origin: Woman . . . cell.
Mnemonic1: When women marry, they adopt the surname of their husband, signifiying the start of a new life together. (adapted from gorgon).
Mnemonic2: Woman change their surname when they "start their new life".
Compo: 女: woman　生: life; cell (RTK)

Origin: The "wherefore" of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a rice field sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and wherefore of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the flower appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full seedling.)
SubOrigin: As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean shoot or sprout.
Mnemonic1: Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo? (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet´s dinner plate and rolled off).
Mnemonic2: Cogito ergo sum. Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it´s often mistranslated as "where" when in fact it´s an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. (A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.].
Compo: 由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . sprout.
Mnemonic1: The liquid oil that sprouts from an oil field.
Mnemonic2: In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified Brussel sprouts (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the water to suck up oil spills.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)

Origin: Recalling that there are no circular strokes, and that the shape of the square and the square within a square (Frame 630) have already been used, it should be relatively easy to see how this character can be consider a pictograph of a well.
Mnemonic1: I nearly died by falling in a well. Actually, on two separate occasions. I´m glad to see they´ve added these fence posts. Now the well will be much safer.
Mnemonic2: Have you ever seen an old fashioned japanese well? == http://cruises.about.com/od/southeastasiacruise1/ig/Osaka-Japan/Ancient-Well-at-Osaka-Castle.htm.
Compo: 井: well

Origin: Well . . . pent in.
Mnemonic1: The village surrounded the well with a wall so kids wouldn´t fall in.
Mnemonic2: You get good surround sound when your pent-up in well.
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　井: well
Kunyomi: かこ.む, かこ.う, かこ.い

Origin: <i style="font-weight: bold; ">Donburi is a bowl of rice with eel or meat on it. The character is a pictograph, perhaps designed by someone who felt that the portion of meat he was served with his bowl of rice looked to be no more than a tiny drop in the well.
Mnemonic1: A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!
Mnemonic2: I drop a domburi down into the well for the goblin living there.
Compo: 井: well　丶: dot; drop
Ex1English: Bowl of rice topped with beef

Origin: The picture here is of a street sign on a long pole: Hollywood and Vine, if you please, or any street that immediately conjure sup the image of a street sign to you.
SubOrigin: Used as a primitive, we change the meaning of the key word and take the shape to signify a nail or a spike. Should it happen, on reviewing, that you find the pictographs get jumbled, then think of jerking a street sign out of the ground and using it as a nail to repair your garage roof.
Mnemonic1: Today, the program "Sesame Street" is brought to you by the letter "T".
Mnemonic2: Two streets make a T-intersection.
Compo: 丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: House . . . heart . . . eye . . . spike.
Mnemonic1: A pretty tough kanji. Think of elegant old housewives with English accents dining together at a HOUSE party. The hostess brings out a dish of hors d´oeuvres: a SPIKE of metal with an EYEBALL and a HEART skewered on it. Upon being offered this treat, one of the housewives says in her English accent, "I´d RATHER not.".
Mnemonic2: Rather a house with a heart than an eye with a spike.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　目: eye　丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: Street signs standing at the corner of the rice fields depict the village limits. (Remember what was said earlier: when used as a primitive, a kanji may either take its primitive meaning or revert to the original meaning of its key word.)
Mnemonic1: Actually this means town, like one that has lots of streets and is surrounded by all the rice fields.
Mnemonic2: Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. "Pillage the village, for the rice and and the tea." the street primitive on the right looks like a ´t´.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　丁: street; nail (RTK)
Ex1English: (downtown) business quarters, old part of tokyo

Origin: Since it is very hard to read by the fireplace without going blind from the flickering of the flames or burning up from the heat, our ancestors invented a way to nail down a bit of that fire, just enough to light up the text of their evening newspapers and no more. Voilà! The lamp.
Mnemonic1: Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.
Mnemonic2: A lamp is fire you can hang from a nail.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: Cave . . . a spike.
Mnemonic1: Some bureaucrats at a government office decided that the tunnels of caves need to get street signs, which are then nailed to the walls of the cave.
Mnemonic2: In some of the scarier countries, when someone is invited to visit a "government office", it´s actually a dungeon where they´re dragged into a cave and nailed to the wall.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: To avoid confusing this frame with the last one, try to think of savings as actual money. The only difference is that our currency is not paper bills but shells, a not uncommon unit of exchange in older civilizations. The nail under the roof of the house points to a hiding place in the rafters on which one strings up one's shells for safekeeping.
Mnemonic1: It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.
Mnemonic2: My SAVINGS plan - I nail my moneybags up in the rafters below my roof. I´m very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big mustache (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　宀: house (RTK)　丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: Sun . . . knot.
Mnemonic1: The sun is not an easy place to get to.
Mnemonic2: Under the sun, it is easy to untie a knot. Under a pitch-dark sky, it is knot so easy.
Compo: 日: day; sun　勿: not

Origin: Shells . . . easy.
Mnemonic1: A grant is easy money.
Mnemonic2: Do you want free shells from the government? It´s easy with my new book, "How to Get a Free Grant from the Government!" Call today!
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　易: easy

Origin: Soil . . . piggy bank.
Mnemonic1: You´re looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that´s easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to remember like this kanji.
Mnemonic2: Don´t confuse with place (#1127). Think of location not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You´ve buried your piggy bank in the dirt in your backyard, but you can´t remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of location to find your piggy bank.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . piggy bank.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!
Mnemonic2: Hot water is a phrase that can mean "getting into trouble." This kanji pictures just one of the many meanings of that phrase: it´s water that you get into (with creditors and the like) when your piggy bank is empty!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)

Origin: The pictograph of two swinging gates is so clear in this kanji that only its stroke order needs to be memorized. In case you should have any trouble, though, you might doodle with the shapes on a piece of paper, taking care to note the difference in the stroke order of the two facing doors. The gates usually serve as an enclosure, and are written BEFORE whatever it is they enclose.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall continue to give it the meaning of gates, but recommend the image of swinging doors (like the kind once common at entrances to saloons) to distinguish it from the primitive for door.
Mnemonic1: Heisig´s stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the "sun" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you´ll get the stroke order exactly correct.
Mnemonic2: The gates to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or ... Bill Gates?
Compo: 門: gate

Origin: Gates . . . sun/day. This interval applies to time and space alike, but the latter is better for creating an image.
Mnemonic1: The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them.
Mnemonic2: We open the gates at regular intervals to let a bit of sun in.
Compo: 門: gate　日: day; sun
Ex1English: Be in time; answer the purpose; can do without

Origin: Gates . . . genie.
Mnemonic1: The gates are too big to be closed by man. Only a genie can. "Close sesame!".
Mnemonic2: Alright none of you GENIUSES could figure out how the door is CLOSED, so I invented these. They are called the SALOON DOORS. With these, you don't need to.
Compo: 門: gate　才: genius
Kunyomi: と.じる, と.ざす, し.める, し.まる

Origin: Gates . . . two hands.
Mnemonic1: Sure you can squeeze through these gates by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide open, you need to do that with both your hands.
Mnemonic2: To open the gate, use your both hands.
Compo: 門: gate　开 : open; two hands (RTK)
Kunyomi: ひら.く, ひら.き, -び.らき, ひら.ける, あ.く, あ.ける

Origin: Gates . . . golden calf.
Mnemonic1: At the airport, the woolly mammoth was too big. When he tried to go through his flight's gate he got stuck and missed his connecting flight.
Mnemonic2: The wooly mammoth Smashes the gates down restoring the connection between the glacier and the low lands.
Compo: 門: gate　关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)
Kunyomi: せき, -ぜき, かか.わる
Ex2English: Sumo wrestler of the second highest rank

Origin: Gates . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: A mouth on the Gates of Hell says "Answer me these questions three, or thru the gates ye soon will be".
Mnemonic2: Hark! Who goes there? is the expected question from the mouth of the guard at the gate…
Compo: 門: gate　口: mouth
Kunyomi: と.う, と.い, とん

Origin: Gates . . . ear. Compare the story you invented for the kanji meaning listen (Frame 890).
Mnemonic1: Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside.
Mnemonic2: To distinguish from listen, you hear someone at the door (gate).
Compo: 門: gate　耳: ear

Origin: When making a courtesy call on a dignitary, one has to gauge one's words with great care. Hence the need for a compass.
Mnemonic1: When you call on someone, you point your words in their direction.
Mnemonic2: When calling on a girl, you´d better what what sweet words will turn her fancy in your direction. (Image: last century teenagers on a frilly couch in the sitting room, she with her back to him, and he fumbling for the right words to turn her around).
Compo: 言: word; say　方: direction; compass (RTK)
Kunyomi: おとず.れる, たず.ねる

Origin: Road . . . golden calf.
Mnemonic1: The St Bernard with devilish animal horns must be non other than Cerberus, guard dog of the netherworld. In this frame Cerberus is seen along the road to hell, escorting those who have been sent off to join Hades in his realm.
Mnemonic2: The woolly mammoth got quite a send off before he wandered up that road never to be seen alive again.
Compo: 辶: walk; road; way (RTK)　关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)

Origin: Quarter . . . dagger.
Mnemonic1: Entering the movie, the dude asks for your ticket, so he can tear it in half. He looks at you funny when you hand him a ticket already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into quarters after you show him your dagger with a smile.
Mnemonic2: In Japan, the JR railway ju-hachi-kippu seasonal discount ticket can be cut into quarters with a dagger and shared with your friends. (its actually sort-of true).
Compo: 关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Bind up . . . snake.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning of wrap should always be used with the snake in mind to avoid confusion with similar terms. Just let "wrap" mean "with a snake coiled about it."
Mnemonic1: The snake bound up its prey by wrapping his body around it.
Mnemonic2: Imagine Jessie sending in her Ekans (snake pokemon), and telling it to use bind attack to wrap up pikachu.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　已: oneself; snake (RTK)

Origin: Quarter . . . snake. The key word refers to a manuscript rolled up into a scroll, not to a hanging scroll (Frame 435).
Mnemonic1: At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only 25¢. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous snake. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...
Mnemonic2: How to make snake maki: Take a snake. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a scroll. Cut into quarters and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.
Compo: 关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)　已: oneself; snake (RTK)
Kunyomi: ま.く, まき, ま.き

Origin: This key word refers to a realm or orbit, not to a ball. Its elements: pent in . . . scroll.
Mnemonic1: I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done.
Mnemonic2: (RPG] You´re fighting a powerful enemy. Your mage uses a scroll/quartersnake of protection, and he´s pent in a sphere of protection.
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　巻: roll up; scroll (RTK)

Origin: Moon . . . quarter . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: After your VICTORY cut your enemy´s FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.
Mnemonic2: After England´s victory over Scottish rebel William Wallace, they had his flesh drawn and quartered and then sent around Britain to demonstrate their power.
Compo: 月: moon; month　关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Simple . . . fiesta.
Mnemonic1: George W. Bush´s plans for war were so SIMPLE. To him, its all just a big FIESTA.
Mnemonic2: So there´s this fiesta in downtown Compton. It´s a simple party, but someone invited people from the wrong gangs and the simple fiesta turns into an all-out turf war.
Compo: 単: simple　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)

Origin: Owl . . . brain . . . needle. The sense is "not complex."
Mnemonic1: Owls are smart...for this owl everything is simple coz his brain is ten times more powerful than mine.
Mnemonic2: An owl´s brain is ten times smarter than other simple minded birds…
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . interval.
Mnemonic1: (simplicity; brevity] The ししおどし is a bamboo device for scaring birds from the gates of your garden by clacking against a stone at regular intervals. Its design is simplicity itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco).
Mnemonic2: The simplicity of bamboo plant is in all its joints being at equal intervals.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　間: interval; space

Origin: Jawbone . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Jaws XII~! Jaws strikes the highway! Man, they´re really overdoing it now.
Mnemonic2: In ´American History X´ Edward Norton´s character overdoes it when he makes the dude that tried to steal his car lie face down with his jawbone open over the pavement of the roadway and then stamps on the back of his head. My teeth still tingle when I think of that!
Compo: 咼: evil; jawbone (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: す.ぎる, -す.ぎる, -す.ぎ, す.ごす, あやま.つ, あやま.ち

Origin: This kanji and primitive refers to the part of the body composed of the bones and their joints. The top part of the kanji, terminating in the element for crown, is a pictograph of a bone joint. I leave it to you to put the pieces together, so to speak.
Mnemonic1: Your body meat is attached to the bone joints of your skeleton.
Mnemonic2: The top box 口 is the skull and the brain 田 has shriveled to the size of marble (but following kanji convention it is depicted as a square) and rolled into the bottom right hand corner. With all the hair and flesh gone the crown has slipped down to the shoulders like a necklace. 月 represents the rest of the body of the skeleton. (Idea for position of crown thanks to n1williams].
Compo: 骨: bone; skeleton (RTK)

Origin: Shakuhachi . . . nightbreak.
Mnemonic1: Roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime.
Mnemonic2: In a Zelda game, you can warp to the daytime if you play your shakuhachi to bring about nightbreak... or your ocarina if you don´t have a shakuhachi.
Compo: 尺: shaku　旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)

Origin: First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of night with those of evening (Frame 114) and nightbreak (Frame 30). Its elements: top hat . . . person . . . walking legs . . . drop.
Mnemonic1: Actually, the lower-right primitive isn´t quite "walking legs." It´s a little more like "evening" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town...
Mnemonic2: Here we have Mister T sleepwalking, wearing a top hat as if he was the ambassador of the night, walking, and walking and walking on his tired walking legs, until he drops (back into his bed).
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Water . . . night.
Mnemonic1: A wet dream........water fluid that comes out at night....
Mnemonic2: I imagined some kind of liquid (water) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at night, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　夜: night

Origin: Two hands . . . fiesta.
Mnemonic1: Two hands, fiesta.....when moses received the ten commandments with two hands, he went back down the mountain and threw a fiesta with the jews, celebrating the arrival of the commandments.
Mnemonic2: When Moses returned with the commandments in his hands he saw that his people were throwing a fiesta. At first he was excited. Then he looked around and got pissed. "Awww, c´mon guys. Golden idols? Really?".
Compo: 戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　廾: twenty; 2 hands

Origin: Two cocoons . . . person . . . fiesta.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji will mean an abacus, the bead-instrument used in the Orient to calculate how many.
Mnemonic1: It is a little awkward when you are at a fiesta and the host serves some rare delicacy, like moth cocoons, the guests must decide how many it would be polite to eat. You do the math in your head and it comes out to two cocoons per person. This is why the horizontal line is a fraction bar with two cocoons on the top, and one person the bottom.
Mnemonic2: How many went to the party? Two aliens and one person (I feel sorry for that person).
Compo: 幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　戍: protection; march (RTK)
Kunyomi: いく-, いく.つ, いく.ら

Origin: Two cocoons . . . field . . . fiesta.
Mnemonic1: People aside, I wonder how many rice fields there are in the capital suburbs.
Mnemonic2: How many brains does it take to run the capital suburbs?
Compo: 幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)
石: stone; rock (RTK)　幾: how many; abacus (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . abacus.
Mnemonic1: An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many ´anythings´.
Mnemonic2: To avoid confusing with contraption (#677), focus on the "ism" of mechanism. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish; mechanism here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable tree (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching abacus that smashes enemies between its giant beads.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　幾: how many; abacus (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . commandment.
Mnemonic1: The ten commandments were heavy. So to help carry them, Moses made a wooden contraption; the ark of the covenant.
Mnemonic2: Think of a complex wooden contraption capable of giving you a two-handed fiesta.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　戒: commandment

Origin: The two large hooks have little propellers (the two drops on each hook) attached to them for flying. Beneath is the measuring box, which serves as the body of this flying contraption. The stroke order will cause some problems, so take care with it.
Mnemonic1: Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?
Mnemonic2: Two hummingbirds flying into a measuring box serving as a bird feeder…
Compo: 飛: to fly
Kunyomi: と.ぶ, と.ばす, -と.ばす

Origin: Pay close attention to the stroke order of the elements when learning to write this character. The elements: a long drop . . . fishhook . . . a one . . . fishhook.
Mnemonic1: Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.
Mnemonic2: The family name is important to me! Drop me from a building, torture me with a fishhook, I´m keeping my one family name. Hook me with a second fishhook, I refuse to change my family name.
Compo: 氏: family

Origin: In place of the drop at the start of the character for family name, we have a mouth, which makes you think of the "vox populi."
Mnemonic1: All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths.
Mnemonic2: How many of you know what "vox populi" means?
Compo: 民: people

Origin: Thread . . . family name.
Mnemonic1: All that threads you to your family name is a piece of paper. (birth certificate).
Mnemonic2: I imagine a ridiculously expensive, and rather pointless, Japanese type of paper for writing letters, with one´s family name woven in fine thread somewhere in a corner.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　氏: family

Origin: Person . . . calling card.
Mnemonic1: A person bows low when presenting his business card.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T travels to Japan and knows he must bow lower when presenting his business card.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　氐: name of an ancient tribe; calling card (RTK)
Kunyomi: ひく.い, ひく.める, ひく.まる

Origin: Fingers . . . calling card.
Mnemonic1: Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a business card, resist the impulse to fiddle around with it with your fingers, and by all means resist the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your fingernails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don´t know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you.
Mnemonic2: Most japanese find it impossible to resist pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned business cards into your fingers.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　氐: name of an ancient tribe; calling card (RTK)
Ex1English: Generally, mostly, for the most part

Origin: Calling card . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: The business card says his residence is just to the left of the city walls. Can you find it? Yep, got it.
Mnemonic2: So fed up am I, I´ve finally built city walls around my residence to keep these Japanese from soliciting me with their business cards.
Compo: 氐: name of an ancient tribe; calling card (RTK)　邑: village; city walls (阝)

Origin: Cave . . . calling card.
Mnemonic1: I put all those useless business cards at the bottom of a cave.
Mnemonic2: In the deepest bottom of this cave complex, spelunkers leave their calling cards to prove they made it all the way.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　氐: name of an ancient tribe; calling card (RTK)
Ex4English: From the bottom of one's heart

Origin: This kanji depicts a gigantic "pop-eye," which accounts for its shape. Be sure not to confuse it with the slave (retainer) we just learned.
Mnemonic1: This is actually the top view of a porn star with a gigantic erect penis. The top and bottom are his arms and the middle is his penis. Imagine him making the pumping motion while he´s banging some chick. The arms move in, the penis moves out and vice versa.
Mnemonic2: The letter E, with a GIGANTIC middle stroke.
Compo: 巨: giant

Origin: This kanji is actually a pictograph for an eye, distorted to make it appear that the pupil is protruding towards the right. This may not be an easy form to remember, but try this: Draw it once rather large, and notice how moving the two vertical lines on the right as far right as possible gives you the pictograph of the eye in its natural form. The "pop-eye" image belongs to an Emperor's retainer standing in awe before his ruler.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the meaning of the key word becomes slave.
Mnemonic1: Its a pictograph of a teeth with a retainer in the middle.
Mnemonic2: Retainer = A slave (for the purposes of this kanji.) This is a pictograph of a slave collar with two handcuffs dangling from it.
Compo: 臣: subject; slave (RTK)

Origin: Bushel basket . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: Fundamentals of chess: use the rooks to protect your ground.
Mnemonic2: A Bushel-basket full of earth contains the fundementals of farming. i.e. earth.
Compo: 其: that, Bushel-basket (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Bushel basket . . . month. As the month indicates, this has to do with periods of time.
Mnemonic1: The slowest remote chess game ever: a one month period between every move.
Mnemonic2: The girl´s panties are all in the bushel basket as it´s that time of the month again... her period.
Compo: 其: that, Bushel-basket (RTK)　月: moon; month

Origin: This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of hand to produce fur. If you reverse your hand and put its palm down, you will have the side on which fur grows.
Mnemonic1: I´ve heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That´s not hair, that´s fur!
Mnemonic2: Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats don´t like you rubbing your hand backwards over their fur.
Compo: 毛: fur

Origin: Flag . . . fur.
Mnemonic1: A dog waves its furry tail like a flag.
Mnemonic2: A FLAG of FUR is a TAIL.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　毛: fur

Origin: Since the key word has to do with raising children to be strong both in mind and body, it is easy to coordinate the primitive elements: infant . . . meat.
Mnemonic1: Bringing up your offspring means raising them from infant until they are meat ready to be harvested. What, cannibalism is in poor taste? Forget I ever brought it up. But bring up will forver be infant meat to me. I want my baby back baby back baby back ribs!
Mnemonic2: I will bring up my infants to eat meat. I´ll not endure any vegetarian children in my house!
Compo: 𠫓: infant　肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)
Kunyomi: そだ.つ, そだ.ち, そだ.てる, はぐく.む

Origin: This pictograph shows the animal horns at the top attached to the head (3rd stroke), the front and back legs (strokes 4 and 5) and body (final stroke).
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning of sheep can add the further connotations given in the following frame. As we saw with the cow, the "tail" is cut off when it is set immediately over another element: ⺷. Note the change in stroke order, as exemplified in the following frame.
Mnemonic1: Picture of a sheep run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.
Mnemonic2: Our Lord and King put on ears and a tail to become a lowly sheep for the slaughter.
Compo: 羊: sheep

Origin: Water . . . sheep. Be sure to keep the stories and key word of this kanji distinct from those for sea. (Frame 500).
Mnemonic1: This kanji refers to the waters of the Pasheephic ocean.
Mnemonic2: Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across oceans of water in order to recover the fleece of a certain sheep.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　羊: sheep

Origin: The composition of this kanji shows three elements, which we list in the order of their writing: bound up . . . rice field . . . cooking fire. Not much to work with at first sight. But we can join them together by thinking of a three-part story: first a fish is caught and bound up on a line with its unfortunate school-mates; when the fisherman gets home, he cuts off the head and tosses it, with the entrails, out into the rice fields for fertilizer; and the rest he sets in a skillet over a cooking fire for his supper.
Mnemonic1: The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish.
Mnemonic2: Bind that FISH and cook his brains! Yarhh!
Compo: 魚: fish
Kunyomi: うお, さかな, -ざかな

Origin: Fish . . . sheep.
Mnemonic1: The freshest fish is caught in the middle of the night while most people are "counting sheep." (If you´ve ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean).
Mnemonic2: This one´s easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased fresh. To remember which foods, take the first letter of fresh, "F", to stand for fish and the final sound of fresh, "SH", to stand for sheep: FreSH. It even puts the primitives in the right order.
Compo: 魚: fish　羊: sheep
艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　魚: fish　禾: grain; wheat (RTK)
Ex1English: Be revived, be resuscitated, be restored
Ex2English: Be revived, be resuscitated, be restored

Origin: Words/speaking . . . sheep.
Mnemonic1: Trembling from head to hoof from such a traumatic experience, the sheep gives a very detailed worded account to the detective about his wolf attack. "We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you".
Mnemonic2: Say! detailed sheep, not like that! DE-TAILED sheep. Got it?
Compo: 言: word; say　羊: sheep

Origin: Altar . . . sheep.
Mnemonic1: Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering.
Mnemonic2: On this ewe-spicious occasion, you sacrifice a sheep at the altar. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　羊: sheep

Origin: Try to think of what the Chinese were on to when they associated the idea of beauty with a large sheep.
Mnemonic1: I guess this kanji proves it´s not just the Welsh whose idea of beauty is a large sheep.
Mnemonic2: A Sheep on top of a dog is NOT a beautiful thing.
Compo: 羊: sheep　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)

Origin: In a row upside down . . . not yet.
Mnemonic1: The oldest profession: prostitution. I was once in a brothel in Amsterdam where the working girls had a group of businessmen blindfolded and hanging upside down in a row, not yet spanked and whipped, but waiting eagerly.
Mnemonic2: A bunch of kids are hanging upside down in a row on the monkeybars. Naturally, they haven't chosen a profession, at least not yet.
Compo: 业: spikes　䒑: weeds　未: not yet

English: Real, Actual, True, Fruit, Bear Fruit
Origin: House . . . bonsai.
Mnemonic1: Bonsais are grown in a house, away from the harsh reality of the real world where they wouldn´t survive.
Mnemonic2: On this rather boring ´big brother´ type reality show, they have locked up bonsai inside a house and everyone is watching them on TV 24x7. The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　𡗗: bonsai (RTK)

Origin: Sheep . . . food. The key word has the sense of promoting the development of something, especially in a psychological or spiritual sense.
Mnemonic1: A sheep became the foster parent for a wolf pup, feeding it with milk. This story cannot end well...
Mnemonic2: Judy Foster in "The Silence of the Lambs" is what Dr. Hannibal-the cannibal-Lecter would like to eat.
Compo: 羊: sheep　食: eat; food

English: Mode, Manner, Way (Of Doing), Style, Formal Title
Origin: The abbreviation Esq. will help associate this character with the honorific form of address to which it belongs. Its elements are: tree . . . sheep . . . grains of rice. Note that the final vertical stroke in the element for sheep is extended to form the first stroke for grains of rice.
Mnemonic1: Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble Esq. You must posses a forested estate, herds of sheep, and granary full of grains of rice.
Mnemonic2: This is -Sama, a generic high term of respect for someone in an unusual profession. If you met a person that created a wooden sheep that was squeezing a single grain of rice out of its ass, you´d definitely call that person -sama. Because that is impressive.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　羊: sheep　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: To undertake a project is to take some idea floating in the air and stop it so that it can be brought down to earth and become a reality. Here we see some undertaking made to stop under a beach umbrella.
Mnemonic1: Mary Poppins floated down with her umbrella to undertake the job of stopping the children´s misbehaving.
Mnemonic2: The Undertaker is an evil WWE wrestler - he beat his opponent with an umbrella until he stopped moving.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　止: stop; footprint (RTK)
Kunyomi: くわだ.てる, たくら.み*

Origin: Picture yourself grabbing hold of the two strokes poking out the top of the kanji and wrenching them apart, thus giving the sense of bend. If you think of them as deriving from the element for brains beneath (of course, the middle stroke has been reduplicated and pulled out to where it can be grabbed hold of), you can associate the key word with bending someone's mind to your own point of view.
Mnemonic1: It looks like the mouth of Bender the robot, from Matt Groening´s animated series "Futurama". Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive.
Mnemonic2: Also means "melody". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to bend the strings to make a melody.
Compo: 曲: compostion, bend (RTK)
Ex4English: Excellent piece of music, famous tune

Origin: We introduce this character here because of its connection to the book-related kanji treated above. It is based on the character for bend (frame 1256), whose last stroke is lengthened to coincide with the first stroke of the element for tool.
Mnemonic1: Coding is a tool which you can use to bend the computer to your will.
Mnemonic2: Think "codex" (mnemonic help) or "code of laws", or even Leonardo Da Vinci´s code. Here I see a codex as a tool used to bend the masses into submission. Picture a huge codex book lifted down on crowds to bend them down in submission. Another: if you bend to the code without asking questions, you are a tool!
Compo: 曲: compostion, bend (RTK)　八: eight; go in (RTK)

English: Rise To Prosperity, Rouse Up, Amusement, Interest
Origin: Mortar . . . same . . . tool. Be careful to make an image that keeps same in the middle.
Mnemonic1: To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be entertained. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the same: staples. What tools! (ayoung24].
Mnemonic2: Photographically, this kanji simply looks like a set of two speakers (the staples primitives) between the sub-woofer (primitive for same) -- all this as a tool to entertain a group of drunks at a club.
Compo: 臼: mortar　同: same; equal; monk (RTK)　丌: table
臼: mortar　車: car　八: eight; go in (RTK)

Origin: Vase . . . eel. In order not to confuse this kanji with the zodiacal sign of the dragon, which we will meet later (Frame 2164) and use as a primitive, you might think here of a paper parade dragon.
Mnemonic1: Have you ever seen an asian DRAGON? it looks like an eel, but can stand up because it has legs.
Mnemonic2: If the poor villagers don´t provide him with a vase full of eels each day, the dragon will lay waste to the village.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　电: electricity, eel (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . vase . . . eels. To avoid the confusion mentioned in the previous frame, the character learned there for dragon should not be used as a primitive.
Mnemonic1: The Water Dragon dwells in the waterfall.
Mnemonic2: Ever went under a waterfall, vase in hand, trying to catch eels from the water as it pours down?
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　竜: dragon
竹: bamboo (⺮)　龍: dragon; imperial
Kunyomi: かご, こ.める, こも.る

Origin: Cliff . . . two . . . hairpins.
Mnemonic1: I'm going with the Mortal Kombat Symbol, as it's the closest thing to a sign of the dragon I know. In that game, there's a place called the pit to which you can throw your opponent on round two, but only with a hairpin punch.
Mnemonic2: The kid said "I don´t believe you! Dragons don´t exist!" so we made a little surprise for him: we pinned a huge dragon (it was just a sign really) on a nearby cliff. "Whoaaa! Dragon!" the kid said. "But why won´t it move?" "I tell you why, cause it´s pinned there with two hairpins" I thought to myself.
Compo: 辰: sign of the dragon

Origin: Bend . . . sign of the dragon.
Mnemonic1: Imagine if you could bend a dragon to your will. Helpful in war, yes, but also a boon for agriculture. The dragon could use its sharp claws to plough the ground, and use its firey breath to clear the land. But first you'd have to bend the dragon to your will -- not an easy task.
Mnemonic2: It's a good agricultural sign when, as the farmer is bending down, he discovers some plants arranged in the sign of the dragon. It means the weather and earth will be supportive of the crops.
Compo: 曲: compostion, bend (RTK)　辰: sign of the dragon
Ex2English: Warriors, farmers, artisans and tradesmen (the four classes of edo-era japan)

Origin: Among other things, the key word refers to the thick consistency of liquids. Its elements: water . . . agriculture.
Mnemonic1: The agriculture of Florida is concentrated on making concentrated orange juice. Just add water! Imagine a can of FCOJ, dumping it into a pitcher and adding water.
Mnemonic2: Concentrated water is going to revolutionize the agriculture! Just add water... oh wait...
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　農: agriculture; farmers

Origin: Bend . . . table. Think of a bountiful harvest, and you will not be far from the meaning of this character.
Mnemonic1: The bountiful feast was so bountiful that it bent the table below it under its weight! いただきま〜す！.
Mnemonic2: Her bust and bum was so bountiful I couldn´t resist the urge to bend her over a nearby table and...
Compo: 曲: compostion, bend (RTK)　豆: beans; table (RTK)

Origin: Here we see a samurai standing on a street with an open mouth, which people walk up to and look down deep inside of for good luck.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall take this shape to mean an aerosol can, from the mouth and the very tightly-fitting lid (note how it differs here from the lidded crock).
Mnemonic1: The samurai´s wife gives him a (uhum) before battle for good luck.
Mnemonic2: A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, "Good luck" to his opponents before a match.
Compo: 士: gentleman; samurai　口: mouth

Origin: A piece of writing that is pregnant with meaning and needs to be reread several times to be understood we refer to colloquially as "packed." The character sees the words as sealed tightly inside an aerosol can.
Mnemonic1: WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.
Mnemonic2: Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of words and aerosol cans and then makes sure the words get tightly packed inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!
Compo: 言: word; say　吉: good luck; lidded crock (RTK); aerosol can (RTK)
Kunyomi: つ.める, つ.め, -ず.め, つ.まる, つ.む

Origin: Thread . . . aerosol can.
Mnemonic1: Ok, here, you have to think of the phrase "TIE the knot" , which means a wedding (this kanji is used in the marriage compound 結婚 けっこん ). Now, at US weddings, it ends with the couple driving away with cans being dragged behind the car. So here, think of SPIDERMAN, who will TIE the knot with Mary Jane. At his wedding, Spider THREAD attached (or TIED) to SPRAYCANS are being drug behind the limo as they drive off.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman and a fan have a competition to see who can tie up the most enemies fastest. Spidey´s using his webs and the fan is using an aerosol can of silly string. So far they are tied.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　吉: good luck; lidded crock (RTK); aerosol can (RTK)
Kunyomi: むす.ぶ, ゆ.う, ゆ.わえる

Origin: Fingers . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: Well, you usually use your fingers to throw objects used as missile weapons. Easy. By the way, for those of you looking for a less anachronistic image for the missile primitive as a modern rocket, try a slingshot. it´s a crotch (originally a tree branch) that sends missile projectiles flying into/like the wind. And for this present kanji, it is something you naturally use with your fingers...
Mnemonic2: If you use the primitive "semen" (flying in the wind from your crotch) instead of missile then all kanjis with this primitive will hilariously create a perfect story.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Going . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: Japanese kamikaze pilots (and the American from Dr. Strangelove) are so devoted to their duty that they go with their missiles.
Mnemonic2: Imagine those poor saps in charge of nuclear silos, responsible for ICBMS, those towering column missiles. When the order comes they must decide whether to obey their concience or do their duty and damn the world to atomic annihilation.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: (Note: this kanji is more collapse/cave-in/sink (#1888) than humans drowning) A water missile? A torpedo! And when it hits it´s target? The ship collapses then sinks and everyone drowns!
Mnemonic2: The submarine´s hull was breached after being struck by a torpedo ("water missile"), causing the entire crew to drown.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: Establishment can be attacked by words or by missiles. Writers will use words, whereas militars will use missiles.
Mnemonic2: When you attack the establishment with words, it fights back with missiles.
Compo: 言: word; say　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: The kanji connoting rank or class shows us a new element on the left: the familiar primitive for staples with an additional stroke cutting through the vertical stroke. It is easiest in these cases to make a primitive related to what we already know. Hence, we call it a staple gun. To the right, missile.
Mnemonic1: This is a military-grade staple gun! It can be loaded with real missiles.
Mnemonic2: 1st grade: staple gun, 9th grade: missiles.
Compo: 乍: peg holes, staple gun (RTK); saw (RTK)　殳: lance, missile (RTK)
Ex2English: Program, plan, step, course of action

Origin: Sheaf . . . tree . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: X marks the spot on the tree where the missile hit. No doubt, it was meant to kill us.
Mnemonic2: I suppose when this kanji was made, it was most effective to kill your enemies with sheafs of wood used as missiles.
Compo: 乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　木: tree; wood　殳: lance, missile (RTK)
Onyomi: サツ, サイ, セツ

Origin: The key word here is the noun meaning "a breif moment." Its elements: sheaf . . . tree . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: The kendo artist takes a brief moment to practice his skills: he throws sheafs over the tree and tries to cut them with his saber when they come down again.
Mnemonic2: Wtf moment? This kanji means temple. Wooden x-men statues with sabres guard the entrance to the Professor Xavier temple. Might help if you imagine the two x-men as Wolverine and Sabretooth.
Compo: 乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　木: tree; wood　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Sheaf . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: A SABRE is used to cut the stalks of plants being REAPED at harvest. They are then combined into a SHEAF.
Mnemonic2: The Grim Reaper´s name is メリ(Mary)…
Compo: 乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Thread . . . meeting.
Mnemonic1: There´s never a picture of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker... I wonder why?
Mnemonic2: When all the Threads finally Meet the Picture will emerge...
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　会: meet

Origin: Thread . . . fit.
Mnemonic1: If your threads 糸 don't fit 合 right you're not going to be able to get a job with a decent salary.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman has so little free time in his schedule that he is unable to fit in a job with a good salary.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　合: fit
巳: sign of the snake
Ex1English: Circular pattern of three commas; three-sided fight

Origin: Bound up . . . mosaic.
Mnemonic1: Ever look closely at mosaics? They contain a bunch of images bound up into a larger one. It seems amazing until you realize that the only quality of the smaller images that really matters is their colour.
Mnemonic2: Bound up in the Rubik´s cube are the 6 different colours.
Compo: 色: color

Origin: The samurai at the top is familiar enough. The combination beneath, which looks like a flag with a line running through it, is not. Try to devise some way to take note of it, and pay attention to the writing.
Mnemonic1: Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag.
Mnemonic2: When an enemy´s flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　丨: line; stick
Ex3English: Tone of voice, style; tone (in chinese phonetics)

Origin: The flag here has an extra vertical stroke in it. Think of it as an eyebrow pencil stuck in the eye.
Mnemonic1: The eyebrows hover over the eyes like a divided flag.
Mnemonic2: Pictograph: opera glasses over eyes ビ ミ まゆ.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　丨: line; stick　目: eye

English: Village, Countryside, League, Ri (About 3.9 Km Unit)
Origin: That's right - a ri. Don't bother looking it up in your English dictionary; it's a Japanese word for measuring distances. One ri is about 4 kilometers or 2.5 miles. The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used. Atop we see the rice field, and below the element for land. Those four sections you see in the rice field (and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14) are actually measurements of land, much the same as farm-sections in the United States have given us the notion of a "country mile." The land division based on the size of a rice field is called a ri.
SubOrigin: To get a more concrete primitive meaning for this kanji, we shall refer to it as a computer, a meaning deriving from the kanji for logic, which we will meet in Lesson 12.
Mnemonic1: The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.
Mnemonic2: Hint: Heisig makes here a severe disservice to everyone by using a weird keyword for this character. You´ll save a lot (and I mean, a whole lot) of trouble later by giving it instead its intended meaning: House of the Parents.
Compo: 里: village; computer (RTK)

English: Reason, Logic, Basic Principle, Law, Manage, Put In Order
Origin: We first referred to this character back in frame 185, to which you might want to return to have a peek. The image of logic we are given is something like a central jewel in a computer, like the jewels in old clocks that keep them running smoothly. Try to picture yourself making your way through all the rams and roms and approaching this shining jewel, a chorus of voice sand a blast of trumpets in the background heralding the great seat of all-knowing logic.
Mnemonic1: The king of LOGIC is the computer.
Mnemonic2: Computers are ruled by logic (it is the king of computers).
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　里: village; computer (RTK)
Ex2English: Put in order, arrange; liquidate; retrench

Origin: When we speak of burying something (or someone, for that matter), we usually mean putting them under ground. Only here, we are burying our beloved computer that has served us so well these past years. Behind us a choir chants the "Dies irae, dies illa" and there is much wailing and grief among the bystanders as they pass by to shovel a little dirt into what will be its final resting place. R.I.P.
Mnemonic1: You can´t bury computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices.
Mnemonic2: I used SOIL to BURY my COMPUTER.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　里: village; computer (RTK)
Kunyomi: う.める, う.まる, う.もれる

Origin: This character refers to rustic life and rustic fields primarily, and from there gets derived meanings. Its elements: computer. . beforehand.
Mnemonic1: These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the plains.
Mnemonic2: The plains are a challenging place to get any work done. Be sure you recharge your computer´s battery beforehand, or you won´t get anything done.
Compo: 里: village; computer (RTK)　予: beforehand

Origin: Like most things electrical, a computer, too, can overheat. Just imagine flames pouring out of it and charring the keyboard, the monitor, and your desk a sooty black color.
Mnemonic1: If you burn the GROUND of a RICE FIELD with FIRE, eventually it will turn black.
Mnemonic2: If your parent´s home catches on fire, it will turn black.
Compo: 里: village; computer (RTK)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Besides meaning black ink, this kanji also appears in the word for an inked string that is pulled taut and snapped to mark a surface, much the same as one might used a chalked string. Here it is used to mark off the dirt with black lines for a foot ballgame (played, I presume, on a white field).
Mnemonic1: Theres BLACK on the GROUND...most likely someone spilt some black ink.
Mnemonic2: Anyone who has worked with laserjet ink cartridges will know the black ink looks like powdered dirt.
Compo: 黑: black　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: This frame shows up the image of a juvenile hacker standing on top of a computer, or rather jumping up and down on it, because it refused to come up with the right answer.
Mnemonic1: The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.
Mnemonic2: The movie Zoolander is a little JUVENILE and silly, but I love it nonetheless. Just remember Owen Wilson standing on the desk, hitting the computer like a monkey. (The files are IN the computer - IN the computer...).
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　里: village; computer (RTK)

Origin: Think of quantity as having to do with measuring time and distance, and the rest is simple: you have a quantity of time in the new day that begins with nightbreak, and a quantity of distance in the rural ri.
Mnemonic1: I did such a quantity of work that when NIGHT BREAK came, I was asleep on the COMPUTER.
Mnemonic2: If you find that by nightbreak, you´re still playing at your computer, chances are your World of Warcraft character has a high quantity of levels. (thanks to ssmoler] ..... To remember that nightbreak appears ABOVE computer, think of looking UP from your computer at the window to realize you´ve been playing until nightbreak.
Compo: 旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)　里: village; computer (RTK)

English: Heavy, Pile On Top Of; Layer, -Ply; Duplicate
Origin: Thousand . . . ri. Note how the long vertical stroke doubles up to serve both elements.
Mnemonic1: The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now.
Mnemonic2: To me it looks like a car with two extra wheels, like a truck. As it is a very heavy vehicle I suggest an image of a huge mining truck, like the yellow Liebherr T282B. Remember that the first "wheel" is a bit bent. http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html.
Compo: 千: thousand　里: village; computer (RTK)
Kunyomi: え, おも.い, おも.り, かさ.ねる, かさ.なる

Origin: Heavy . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: Even though the furniture is heavy, it´ll be easy to move with all the muscles that he has.
Mnemonic2: His MUSCLES are so HEAVY, he barely can move...thats ironic.
Compo: 重: heavy　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . move. Do not confuse with labor (Frame 924).
Mnemonic1: A person who moves something is doing work, physically speaking.
Mnemonic2: Mr T, move. Mr Ts new exercise video called "Work it suckaz". Here is shouting "move it work it move work it!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　動: move

Origin: Schoolhouse . . . power.
Mnemonic1: Those jocks who always tried to show their muscles in the schoolhouse are now the ones out there doing manual labor jobs while we sit here and learn Japanese. Ha!
Mnemonic2: At the schoolhouse, the administration develops the children´s muscles by making them do manual labour.
Compo: 龸: classroom; schoolhouse (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: This prefix should be kept distinct from inter (Frame 222) and mutual (Frame 819). Its elements: needle . . . triceps.
Mnemonic1: The nurse says : “If you co-operate, that needle (syringe) in your triceps won´t hurt”. Note: both co- and cooperate are meanings for this kanji.
Mnemonic2: Co-operation: 3 persons can have the power of ten if they co-operate.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . heavy.
Mnemonic1: Our species has a wheat heavy diet...
Mnemonic2: This kanji also means "Seed." STORY: Scientists have developed a new SPECIES of WHEAT that has large HEAVY seeds. Now we can feed the world.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　重: heavy

Origin: In this kanji, the abbreviation for Asia, you should be able to see the character for mouth behind the Roman numeral II.
Mnemonic1: In Asian countries, people use II chopsticks to get things into their mouths. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks.
Mnemonic2: A mouth barred up and not aloud to speak freely is the sign of asia (korea, China, pakistan etc).
Compo: 亜: Asia; sub

Origin: Asia . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Because Asian people started to eat Western food, their hearts became bad and they started having heart attacks.
Mnemonic2: Asian hearts are bad and evil. They invented so much martial arts: karate, judo, kungfu, muay thai, silat, etc... just to hurt each other. They torture their own people (China, North Korea). They torture other people (Japan in China and Korea). And they are able to hide all this behind their nice facade of kindness. Bad, bad Asians. (did i shatter some people´s ideas on Asia? my bad).
Compo: 亜: Asia; sub　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: わる.い, わる-, あ.し*

Origin: Old West . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: (ヨウ) When Clint needs a woman, he likes to be on top.
Mnemonic2: In some movie with the theme of the Old West, the population of a town finds themselve in dire need of women, after all of the town´s womens became crazy and started gunshooting and participating in duels and such.
Compo: 西: west (覀)　女: woman

Origin: Person . . . Old West.
Mnemonic1: In the West, people have no value. Only money is important.
Mnemonic2: What might it mean for a person in the old west to be of value? Their face is on a "Wanted!" poster, of course. Imagine the reward...
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　西: west (覀)

Origin: First note the stroke order of this character, which did not really evolve from the heart, even though we take it that way. If one takes it as a pictograph "dividing" the heart in half, then one has one of those invariably true bits of human anatomy: the fact that each heart is divided into two halves.
Mnemonic1: You swear you´ll be in love forever, but invariably there comes a time when your heart is divided.
Mnemonic2: For this kanji I invariably got the stroke order wrong. I nearly lost heart, but decided to stick (pun) to it. Then I noticed the order is 1) katakana ソ (altered slightly); 2) fishhook; 3) two drops. Now I invariably get it right.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　丿: katakana no

Origin: Words that testify to the correctness of some fact are classified as evidence. (Here we see a good example of how the more common primitive element takes the "strong" position to the left, even though it has more strokes.)
Mnemonic1: Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as evidence.
Mnemonic2: If what you say is indeed correct, we could use use your testimony as evidence.
Compo: 言: word; say　正: correct; justice
不: not　正: correct; justice
Kunyomi: ゆが.む, ゆが.み, ゆが.める, ひず.む, ひず.み, いびつ

Origin: Negative . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: To distinguish between 否 negate, and 不 negative (#1217): Note that negate contains 口, which is a kind of gate.
Mnemonic2: Negative mouths negate everything.
Compo: 不: not　口: mouth

Origin: Both the stretching out of the walking legs and the little bit of wind tucked in on the right suggest using one's legs to kick something out of the way, or dispose of it.
Mnemonic1: The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.
Mnemonic2: To dispose of rubbish you should walk it to the bin not throw it to the wind.
Compo: 夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)　几: table; wind (RTK)
Ex1English: Manage, deal with, dispose of; process, treat

Origin: Fingers . . . dispose.
Mnemonic1: When rockclimbing, when your weight disposes of the valuble foothold, all that´s left is your fingers keeping you from death. Meanwhile, your walking legs are left dangling in the wind.
Mnemonic2: Once you have a good foothold, you can dispose of your fingerhold.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　処: manage; dispose (RTK)

Origin: Words and a meter's needle combine to form the sense of plot: to talk over plans and to calculate a course of action.
Mnemonic1: A plot is a summary of a book that can be given in ten words.
Mnemonic2: Say-ten´s (satan´s) evil plot.
Compo: 言: word; say　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: In frame 10 we referred ahead to this full character from which the primitive for needle (on the right) derives. Since we already expect that needles are made of metal, let us picture a set of solid gold darning needles to complete the kanji.
Mnemonic1: Remember the story of the needle in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a needle if it wasn´t a GOLD NEEDLE?
Mnemonic2: A golden needle is worth ten times more than an ordinary needle.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: This kanji, meaning universal or widespread, is composed of three elements: thread . . . public . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman could not achieve general acceptance by the media even after winning the public´s heart.
Mnemonic2: General or universal refers to the common thread running through the public's heart.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　公: public; official　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: House . . . human legs . . . elbow . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: The top primitive is similar to hole (#1316). A window is a hole (#1316) in your house that you occassionally sit next to while leaning on your ELBOW and gazing out, a picture of a lonely HEARTedness.
Mnemonic2: Anna stood inside the house 宀 on her human legs 儿 enjoying some private 厶 time, looking out the window and communing with the feelings that were in her heart 心. The first five strokes are actually 穴、あな, "hole," introduced later. 窓、まど, window; 窓口、まどぐち, ticket window; 車窓、しゃそう, car window.
Compo: 穴: hole　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: When shot high into the heavens, the dart gets so small it looks like a mere drop. Although this character could as well mean "arrow," it has no connection with the primitive of that meaning. Hence the new key word.
Mnemonic1: Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens.
Mnemonic2: Do not mistake with LOSE 失.
Compo: 矢: arrow; dart (RTK)

Origin: Dart . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: I should know. After all, I did graduate from Dartmouth!
Mnemonic2: (know; wisdom] (An arrow 矢 like mouth 口] If you know the answers, they will fly like darts from your mouth.
Compo: 矢: arrow; dart (RTK)　口: mouth
Kunyomi: し.る, し.らせる, し.れる

Origin: Box . . . dart.
Mnemonic1: Easily confused: Dr. (#47), doctor (#1694), examination (#1673), check-up (#1724), medicine (#1736). To avoid confusion I renamed this medic, and picture the medic from Team Fortress 2 returning to his box of darts in the supply cupboard every time his syringe gun is empty.
Mnemonic2: This DOCTOR prefers to use DARTS instead of syringes for injections. Here, he pulls out his BOX of DARTS, and the child on the examination table squirms.
Compo: 匚: box; hook (RTK)　矢: arrow; dart (RTK)

Origin: Dart . . . table.
Mnemonic1: He is so short so he has to throw darts from the table.
Mnemonic2: Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw darts over a table at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be short.------------ This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.
Compo: 矢: arrow; dart (RTK)　豆: beans; table (RTK)

Origin: To lose here takes the sense of "misplace," not the sense of defeat, whose kanji we learned in frame 67. It pictures a husband with something falling from his side as he is walking along, something he loses.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this character can also mean to drop.
Mnemonic1: The drop falling here is the husband´s toupee... he´s already lost his hair once, now he´s losing it again. Such is life, I suppose.
Mnemonic2: Note: Heisig´s stroke order is wrong. It´s the same as vermilion, drop first. Homer loses/drops his wedding ring.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　夫: husband; man

Origin: Metal . . . to drop.
Mnemonic1: Iron is a metal that gradually becomes lost due to oxidation and rust.
Mnemonic2: Compare with pig-iron (#270). In moving from pig-iron to iron, some of the metal´s maleability is LOST. (The only difference between the two kanji is that IRON has knee-less, unbending legs, while PIG-IRON (270) has very supple, bendable legs.).
Compo: 金: gold; metal　失: loss; to drop (RTK)

Origin: The kanji for a husband or "head of the family" is based on the kanji for large and an extra line near the top for the "head." Recall the kanji for heavens already learned back in frame 457, and be sure to keep your story for this kanji different.
Mnemonic1: Even though it is argued size is not important, I´m sure most women would like their husband to have a big one.
Mnemonic2: Homer Simpson, as a primitive.
Compo: 夫: husband; man

Origin: That red-orange color we call vermilion is found in nature during the fall when the leaves lose their sugar and begin to change color. This kanji depicts the very last leaf on a tree in the fall (the drop hung in the first stroke), the leaf that has not yet fallen as it one day must. Look at its color - vermilion. (Well, not really. The truth is, vermilion is made from a mercuric sulfide, but I'm sure you will agree that autumn leaves area lot easier to work with.)
Mnemonic1: It´s autumn: only one vermilion leaf on the tree has not yet fallen.
Mnemonic2: (Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (未)(correction wrong character before] vermilion (朱).
Compo: 丿: katakana no　未: not yet

Origin: The stocks bought and sold on the market by the tens of millions each day get their name from a comparison to a healthy tree, in which one takes "stock" in the hopes that it will grow and produce more and more trees like itself. Usually good stocks are referred to as "blue chip," but here we are asked to associate the key word with the color vermilion, perhaps because one can assess the value of a tree from the color of its autumn leaves.
Mnemonic1: Which tree would you buy stocks in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one vermilion leaf left on the right?
Mnemonic2: Ideally, one buys stocks when a company is young, "green," and rapidly growing -- then sells them just before the last vermillion leaf falls off, and a period of dormancy or limited growth begins.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　朱: vermilion

Origin: Banner . . . dart.
Mnemonic1: With a banner declaring "Keep Out!" and blow darts to back it up, the Amazon tribe is not that friendly.
Mnemonic2: Once tribes shot darts under their war banners, now they are putting banner ads on the internet for betting on dart-games at their casinos :(.
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　矢: arrow; dart (RTK)

Origin: Let the last 4 strokes, which are also the concluding strokes to the character for garment, represent a rag as its primitive meaning. We shall meet this only on one other occasion. This gives us as our elements: banner . . . rag.
Mnemonic1: The boat starts to leave on it´s trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says "Bon Voyage", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic.
Mnemonic2: After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Banners . . . children . . . road.
Mnemonic1: The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD.
Mnemonic2: There is always a stupid banner talking about children at play near the road. They mean "drive slowly", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) children that are at play.
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　子: child　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Banner . . . scorpion.
Mnemonic1: Under their banner, volunteers are requesting alms for scorpion sting victims.
Mnemonic2: ALMS for the poor cries the beggar under his tattered BANNER. An evil bastard instead drops a SCORPION into his begging bowl.
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　也: to be; scorpion (RTK)

Origin: A banner . . . a zoo. Hint: think of a merry-go-round.
Mnemonic1: A merry-go-round with a big banner on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual rotation accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos...
Mnemonic2: Don´t confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner.
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)

Origin: Banner . . . bushel basket.
Mnemonic1: The national flag of Croatia. It's a banner with the Croatian coat of arms, commonly referred to as the Chessboard (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Croatia).
Mnemonic2: The national flag is the banner of a country; stored in a whicker basket at night and taken out to the flagpole in the morning.
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　其: that, Bushel-basket (RTK)

Origin: The taskmaster sets an unruly servant free, giving him no more than a quick glance at the compass and a boot from behind.
Mnemonic1: Go in any direction away from your taskmaster when you are set free.
Mnemonic2: When slaves were set free from their masters, they set off in all directions…
Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Kunyomi: はな.す, -.っぱな.し, はな.つ, はな.れる, ほう.る

Origin: Some cosmic taskmaster hovering overhead whips up the waves to make them dash violently against the shore. In the white foam that covers the water we see a broken compass floating, all that remains of a shipwreck.
Mnemonic1: When the taskmaster found his favorite white compas damaged by water, he became the most violent taskmaster there ever was.
Mnemonic2: Overnight the slave got Violent and was Set Free. Overnight....Set Free.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　白: white　方: direction; compass (RTK)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Ex2English: Shake violently; be thrown into turmoil

Origin: When it is time to breed new cattle, the bull is usually willing but the cow is often not. Thus the taskmaster to the right forces the cow into a compromising position, so to speak, so that she and her mate can breed.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to "start breeding, and start doing it now!", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.
Mnemonic2: Hint: This is the kanji from which taskmaster is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with breed, and a lot to do with pastures and shepherds (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don´t differenciate between animals). Think of a cowboy (taskmaster) who brings his cows to the pasture.
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Ex1Kana: (1] ぼくじょう (2] まきば
Ex1English: (1] stock farm, pasture; (2] pasture, grazing land

Origin: Person . . . vase.
Mnemonic1: Mr T ranks first position in the stand-up competition (doing knee flexions). Just picture him doing hundreds of these while the rest of the participants are already completely exhausted after a mere hundred.
Mnemonic2: Rank A person´s standing.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)

Origin: One cries and cries until one is standing up knee-deep in water (or until one has a vase-full of water).
Mnemonic1: Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is crying.
Mnemonic2: She stood up to leave the room when her eyes started to water...
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . heavens.
Mnemonic1: When the people tried to build a tower of bamboo to reach the heavens, the gods just laughed and laughed.
Mnemonic2: That Panda is in bamboo heaven! Just look at him laugh!
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　夭: calamity; witch (RTK)

Origin: Ten . . . rice fields . . . glue. That is how one would read the primitive elements of this kanji from top to bottom. Now if we make a simple sentence out of these elements, we get: "Ten rice fields glued together." A specialty, of course, refers to one's special "field" of endeavor or competence. In fact, few people remain content with a single specialty and usually extend themselves in other fields as well. This is how we come to get the picture of ten fields glued together to represent a specialty.
Mnemonic1: After you have chosen your 10 fields of study, measure how good you are at each to find out your specialty.
Mnemonic2: 10 brains glued together allows you to specialize in any specialty that you want. Imagine each brain having its own specialty.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　由:reason　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Ten . . . fields (or: needle . . . brains) . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Too easy. Imagine the Wizard of OZ. There, the three heroes asked the Wizard for three FAVORS: the lion wanted courage of TEN men, the scarecrow wanted a BRAIN, and the tin man wanted a HEART. Ok, the lion bit is stretching but you have it memorized now, so who cares?
Mnemonic2: Do yourself a favor and take ten minutes to think about your decison…
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Ex3English: Bestow a favor, show kindness to

English: Link, Connect, In Succession, In A Row
Origin: What you are meant to take along in this kanji are not things but people. The image of the car on the road should ground your image for picking up your friends to take them along to wherever you are going.
Mnemonic1: When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don´t confuse with carry (#303).
Mnemonic2: This kanji also means "linked" or "series" so I´ve changed the kanji meaning to "GO ALONG (WITH EACH OTHER)." Well, a ROAD and a CAR certainly GO ALONG with each other. And the CAR will help you to GO ALONG the ROAD. This Kanji is the "Union" in Soviet Union and the "United" of United Nations (the countries that "go along with each other" at least some of the time).
Compo: 車: car　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: つら.なる, つら.ねる, つ.れる, -ず.れ

Origin: The crowned vehicle depicted here is a "chariot," symbol of an army.
SubOrigin: Used as a primitive this kanji means only chariot.
Mnemonic1: British army cars are at the service of the crown.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a crown is the hood ornament on every army car.
Compo: 冖: crown 　車: car

Origin: A long string of "sweet" chariots "swinging low" to our roads is a sure sign that the Lord is "comin' for to carry" someone home.
Mnemonic1: Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you).
Mnemonic2: Roads carry armies (in contrast to seas carrying navies or skies carrying air forces).
Compo: 軍: army; chariot (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　連: take along
Ex1English: Nichiren (13th century founder of the nichiren sect of buddhism)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . animal horns . . . sow.
Mnemonic1: Every regiment of The Pinnacle´s army is lead by a Miss Piggy with a viking helmet on.
Mnemonic2: Every regiment of The Pinnacle´s army has an animal name. This regiment is called "Horned Pig Regiment". They´re wearing Wiking helms and are usually cowered in mud.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　丷: animal horns (RTK)　豕: pig; sow (RTK)

Origin: The trick to remembering this character lies in associating the key word with the line from the nursery rhyme about 4 and 20 blackbirds baked in a pie: "Wasn't this a dainty dish to set before the king?" If we think of display in terms of that famous line, and the king with his head thrown back and his mouth wide open as 4 and 20 blackbirds fly in one after the other, we shall have satisfied both the elements and their position.
Mnemonic1: The mouth of the king is displaying his bling.
Mnemonic2: What a pathetic display! The king is sprawled on his throne, head back and mouth wide open, fast asleep. We should never have let him drink so much at that banquet last night.
Compo: 口: mouth　王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . display. Do not confuse with extremity (Frame 230) or boundary (Frame 523).
Mnemonic1: The extent to which some people will go to create ´wheat displays´, or as some call them ´crop circles´, is truly amazing.
Mnemonic2: The wheat crop has come in, and the mouth of the king is gobbling it all up. Everyone is waiting to see... to what extent will the king manage to eat it this year?
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　呈: display
Ex4English: Process of manufacture, work schedule, amount of work

Origin: Ear . . . mouth . . . king.
Mnemonic1: The trick for me is to remember that the 耳 is to the left of the 口. However, this is easy because a true holy man uses his ear to listen (i.e., to God or his supplicant) before he opens his mouth to speak, unlike a charlatan who just makes something up. Of course, kings are often true holy men and prophets (e.g., King David in the bible).
Mnemonic2: A holy man hears with his ears before he speaks with his mouth, which places him higher than a king in people´s esteem.
Compo: 耳: ear　口: mouth　王: king; ball (RTK)

Mnemonic1: Pictograph of a stanchion, which includes two vertical posts to restrain cows so they can be milked, with a horizontal stroke showing the number of cows per stanchion: one. A stanchion is a great symbol for the SIGN OF THE COW, since modern, domesticated cows are often stanchioned in barns.
Mnemonic2: 77 cows behind a fence.
Compo: 丑: sign of the cow
糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　丑: sign of the cow

Origin: After the flowers at the top (painted on the leather for decoration), we see the element for car with the middle stroke left out. Think of the seats having been taken out so that they can be reupholstered with this decorated leather.
Mnemonic1: I asked the street vendor the price of the LEATHER jacket. He said TWENTY, but with my MOUTH, I talked him down to TEN. (correct stroke order).
Mnemonic2: You can feed twenty mouths for a year for the price of ten leather coats.
Compo: 革: leather

Origin: Leather . . . change.
Mnemonic1: Leather shoes are nice because they change shape to fit your foot.
Mnemonic2: Leather is often changed into shoes.
Compo: 革: leather　化: change
革: leather　包: wrap

Origin: The simplest way to remember this character is to see it as built up from that for branch. The first stroke can then stand for something "hanging" down from the branch, namely its bark or pelt. The barb at the end of the second stroke is the only other change. Merely by concentrating on this as you write the following small cluster of characters should be enough to fix the form in your mind. By way of exception, you might doodle around with the kanji's form to see what you can come up with.
Mnemonic1: A pelt is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”.
Mnemonic2: To be honest, this is one of those cases where I have found it easier to "just remember it" as a radical, as it occurs so frequently: 彼（かれ him）波（なみ wave）and so on.
Compo: 皮: skin; pelt (RTK)

Origin: Rock . . . pelt.
Mnemonic1: Before the invention of scissors or knives, sharp STONES were used to REND PELTs, so that caveman designers could complete new styles for the upcoming year.
Mnemonic2: Rend is a violent, primitive kind of word. (Image: cavemen rending pelts right off live animals with stone tools).
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　皮: skin; pelt (RTK)

Origin: Going . . . pelt. This kanji refers to the third person singular personal pronoun, generally in its masculine form.
Mnemonic1: What´s the main difference between a he and a she? The he has a column covered in a pelt... a penis. Badum-ching.
Mnemonic2: The ultimate he-man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar (column), and he wears a ragged pelt as his only clothing. To remember the column, imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　皮: skin; pelt (RTK)

Origin: Water's . . . pelt.
Mnemonic1: Waves are the ocean´s pelt (skin).
Mnemonic2: The Inuit used water-proof seal pelts for their kayaks, to travel the waves.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　皮: skin; pelt (RTK)

English: Fruit, Result, Accomplish; Come To An End
Origin: The final stage of the seed is reached when the plant has reached its full growth (the tree) and comes to fruition, producing fruit full of new seeds that can return to the earth and start the process all over again. The main thing to notice here is the element for brains at the top, which might prove more helpful than rice field for creating an image. The writing, however, follows the order of a sun with a tree whose trunk runs through the sun.
Mnemonic1: If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree.
Mnemonic2: Eve ate fruit from the tree and knowledge filled her brain.…
