Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: はた.す, -はた.す, は.てる, -は.てる, は.て

English: Assignment, Task, Lesson, Assign, Impose, Levy
Origin: Words . . . fruit.
Mnemonic1: After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I´ve learned. (Thanks Misha!).
Mnemonic2: Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It´s good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy´s "War and Peace" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you´d very quickly run out of fruit).
Compo: 言: word; say　果: fruit

Origin: Owl . . . fruit.
Mnemonic1: The nest atop of a tree contains the fruit of the owl: its offspring.
Mnemonic2: The wise old OWL makes her nest out of FRUIT, carving out the middle for her chicks, because then it´s less work: no running back & forth to get food!
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　果: fruit

Origin: Flowers . . . fruits.
Mnemonic1: This candy is made in the shape of a flower, each petal with the taste of a different fruit.
Mnemonic2: Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　果: fruit

Origin: As everyone knows, tea is made from tea leaves. But the tea plant itself has its own flowers, which can be quite beautiful and add a special flavor to the tea, as the Chinese found out already over 4,598 years ago. With the image of a terrace of flowering tea bushes in mind, picture a number of brightly painted and very l-o-n-g wooden poles (Frame 207) placed here and there in their midst, with a tiny umbrella at the top to shade the delicate-tasting tea flowers.
Mnemonic1: Some people think drinking tea is boring and quaint. That´s why I spice mine up by adding a cocktail umbrella, which of course is made from a wood-en toothpick supporting a paper umbrella with flowers printed on top.
Mnemonic2: When I drink herbal tea I like to drink it under a parasol. If it´s too hot I go "ho, ho, ho !!" (katakana ホ).
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　丿: katakana no　丶: dot; drop

Origin: We generally consider one generation as a period of thirty (or ten plus ten plus ten) years. If you look at this kanji in its completed form - not in its stroke order - you will see three tens. When writing it, think of the lower horizontal lines as "addition" lines written under numbers to add them up. Thus: ten "plus" ten "plus" ten = thirty. Actually, it's a lot easier doing it with a pencil than reading it in a book.
Mnemonic1: 3 tens = generation.
Mnemonic2: They SAY a generation is ten+ten+ten years, with the big first ten providing a grounding, and the next ten providing a little more grounding for the final ten. But I wish the next generation didn´t always SAY "yo!". (ON reading is SEI, KUN reading is yo).
Compo: 世: generation; world
Ex2English: Society, the world; the public, people

Origin: Three elements are given here: flower . . . generation . . . tree. The first and last seem logical enough, since it is the leaf that feeds the flowers on a tree. The element for generation interposed between the two suggests that the movement of a tree from one generation to the next is like its "turning over a new leaf."
Mnemonic1: On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below.
Mnemonic2: The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　世: generation; world　木: tree; wood

Origin: Infant . . . buckle (See frame 444) . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: Think of a really loud and annoying baby, you want to abandon it but it keeps coming back...so you take of your belt by the buckle, and buckle the baby to a tree!
Mnemonic2: As in sash (#415), I treat the one mountain in the middle to mean Mt. Fuji (Japan´s ichiban mountain). Now we see an infant being abandoned on top of Mt. Fuji well above the tree line to die of exposure.
Compo: 𠫓: infant　丗: thirty; buckle (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Thread . . . broom . . . rice grains.
Mnemonic1: When you attend a green tea (緑茶=りょくちゃ) ceremony, you can cherish the threadwork on the kimonos people don, the broom-like whisk (茶筌 =ちゃせん) you use to grind up your tea, and the delicious rice cakes you eat with your tea!
Mnemonic2: In summer, all of Japan turns green with the green threads that fan out like brooms to later produce grains of rice. An easy image if you have ever looked out the window of the train to see all the summer rice paddies...
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Metal . . . broom . . . rice. Note how the final stroke of the broom is extended slightly when an element below is attached directly to it.
Mnemonic1: A monk won a gold metal for breaking the current record for most swept rice in one minute.
Mnemonic2: This character is about a recording for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a metal broom and the little pins on the cylinder are like metal grains of rice.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　彔: carve (录)

Keyword: Strip Off, Peel Off, Come Off
English: Strip Off, Peel Off, Come Off
Compo: 彑: snout　水: water (氵) (氺)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Kunyomi: は.げる, は.がれる, は.ぐ, は.がす, む.ける*, む.く*

Origin: Thread . . . broom . . . sow.
Mnemonic1: There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. Spiderman finally caved in and decided to keep the little pig under one condition: the pig was to take a broom and sweep up all of Spiderman´s leftover threads after having fought crime. The pig felt such affinity for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too.
Mnemonic2: Certain people have an affinity for romantic partners who are handy with thread and a broom - it is of no consequence if they look like pigs. hmm...
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　豕: pig; sow (RTK)

Origin: The idea of something getting jammed into something else is depicted here by having a walking stick get jammed into an umbrella frame by someone shoving it into an already occupied slot in the umbrella stand at the door. First notice the vertical strokes: on the left is the curved umbrella handle, and on the right the straight walking stick. Now try to imagine the two parties tugging at their respective properties like two kids on a wishbone, creating a scene at the entrance of an elegant restaurant.
Mnemonic1: The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for "jammed in.".
Mnemonic2: Two people jammed in under an umbrella. A woman with a dress and a man (straight). It´s always me that ends up getting wet.... but the tail of the skirt is this time!
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　丿: katakana no　丨: line; stick

Origin: As the world gets jammed with more and more people, there is less and less space. Imagine yourself taking an air flight over a world so densely populated that every bit of it is sectioned off like a gigantic checkerboard (the rice fields). If you look closely at the character, you should be able to see a kind of movement taking place as still more is being jammed into that already narrow space.
Mnemonic1: One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.
Mnemonic2: A famous philosopher once said that his world consisted of all the things he could jam into his brain.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　介: jammed in

Origin: Water . . . fledglings.
Mnemonic1: Floating rubber ducky!!!
Mnemonic2: A nest of fledglings somehow fell into the water (maybe it was perched on a tree bending over the river), but they are safe for now as the nest is floating. The fledglings are enjoying the cruise but they are soon coming to a great waterfall... ( a little drama to help us remember the story).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　孚: nourish; fledglings (RTK)
Kunyomi: う.く, う.かれる, う.かぶ, う.かべる

Origin: Turtle . . . vulture . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: The leader in this race is the turtle! It appears he has covered the vulture’s feet in glue, so that the vulture cannot get off the starting block.
Mnemonic2: X-men and TMNT join forces: Their new leader is an awsome asshole. He is simply Wolverine and Raphael glued together back to back (the biggest assholes from both groups combined).
Compo: 丬: left-side; turtle (RTK)　爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Leader . . . St. Bernard dog. Do not confuse with urge (Frame 300).
Mnemonic1: It´s easy to picture a LEADER that uses a BIG dog to EXHORT his people to do more.
Mnemonic2: Here we have a St.Bernard exhorting the vulture to become the leader in the race against the turtle, but he can´t because of the glue. see leader (#731).
Compo: 将: leader　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)

English: Form, Shape, Condition, State, Letter, Note
Origin: Did you ever hear of the turtle who fell madly in love with a chihuahua but could not have her because their two families did not like the idea of their children intermarrying? Like all classic stories of ill-fated love, this one shows how the young upset the status quo with an emotion older and more powerful than anything their elders have devised to counter it: blind love.
Mnemonic1: It was left to the turtle to make right with the dog and thus maintain the status quo..
Mnemonic2: A turtle mounting a chihuahua clearly disrupts the status quo.
Compo: 丬: left-side; turtle (RTK)　犬: dog (犭)

Origin: Sickness . . . third class.
Mnemonic1: Caveman got ill after flying third class. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ).
Mnemonic2: If you hang around a third class hospital, you´ll get ill with the sickness everyone else has.
Compo: 疒: sickness　丙: 3rd
Ex2English: The mind is the root of sickness and health

Origin: Sickness . . . correct.
Mnemonic1: Once you have all the symptoms right, you have correctly identified the sickness.
Mnemonic2: A sickness can only be correctly diagnosed if the symptoms are identified correctly.
Compo: 疒: sickness　正: correct; justice

Origin: Sickness . . . chop-seal . . . utilize.
Mnemonic1: Think of the phrase pain in the xxx. Then think of a pogostick up your xxx. That's painful, right? The real question is why a pogostick is up your xxx. That's sick, dude.
Mnemonic2: When I was feeling sick my mum said I shouldn´t go out to play on my pogo stick until I felt better. Well I wasn´t strong enough to stay up on it and so fell over and have the pain to prove my mum right.
Compo: 疒: sickness　龴: Ma; chop-seal (RTK)　用: to use; screwdriver (RTK)
Kunyomi: いた.い, いた.む, いた.ましい, いた.める

Origin: State of mind . . . idea.
Mnemonic1: Recollection is about bringing ideas back to your mind.
Mnemonic2: Data´s recollection powers are unparalled. He never loses a single idea.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　意: idea

Origin: Flesh . . . idea.
Mnemonic1: Cowardice is the situation where you get the thought that maybe running away and saving your flesh is a good idea.
Mnemonic2: Cowardice is when you are not willing to sacrifice your flesh for your ideas.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　意: idea

Origin: Person . . . idea.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T has an clear idea of what he would do if he ever got hundred million dollar. (I guess it would be a enormous gold chain !).
Mnemonic2: Mr. T´s bright idea is to get a hundred million kids to vow not to use drugs. "C´mon, foo! Sign the paper!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　意: idea

Origin: Altar . . . see.
Mnemonic1: The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a "visual once over" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?).
Mnemonic2: (inspection; regard as; see; look at] Inspection: you 示 show (#1086) and someone else 見 see (#57).
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　見: see

Origin: Husband . . . see.
Mnemonic1: In the male-dominated world of yesterday, the husband´s way of seeing things was considered the standard point of view. Women who dared to disagree were frowned upon.
Mnemonic2: Unfortunately, Homer Simpson is the standard model of a husband in American society. (Placement: You have to look in the RIGHT places to find one that doesn´t fit that mold.).
Compo: 夫: husband; man　見: see

Origin: The character depicts a clam alongside a great and flashing saber. Think of digging for clams in an area where there are gaming rules governing how large a find has to be before you can keep it. So you take your trusty saber, which you have carefully notched like a yardstick, crack open a clam and then measure the poor little beastie to see if it is as long as the rules say it has to be.
Mnemonic1: When you have both money and the power of the sword, you can make the rules.
Mnemonic2: If you´ve got CRABs on your SABER, then you didn´t follow the rules of safe sex!
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Person . . . rule. See frame 92 for help.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T rulezzz! I am on his side!
Mnemonic2: Chuck Norris´s rules are easy to live by, just be on his side.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　則: rule

Origin: Connoting the measurement of the depth of water, the keyword fathom begins with the water primitive. To its right, we see the compound-primitive for rule (Frame 92) which we learned in the sense of a "ruler" or "measure." Hence, when we rule water we fathom it. What could be simpler? But be careful; its simplicity is deceptive. Be sure to picture yourself fathoming a body of water several hundred feet deep by using a ruler of gargantuan proportions.
Mnemonic1: A fathom is the unit you use when making rules about water´s depth.
Mnemonic2: You can´t fathom how deep this water is. Perhaps you should use a ruler to measure it?
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　則: rule

Origin: Old man . . . slingshot. Remember: you already have kanji for discriminating (Frame 521), deliberation (Frame 692), and think (Frame 651).
Mnemonic1: Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences.
Mnemonic2: Even though he had the old man Mr. Wilson within the sights of his slingshot, Dennis the Menace considered what he was doing and stopped.
Compo: 老: old man　丂: snare, slingshot (RTK)
Kunyomi: かんが.える, かんが.え

Origin: First, do not confuse this character with venerable old man (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an old man begins with an abbreviation of the character for somebody, the nose having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the soil drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when "dust to dust" begins to take on a personal meaning; the diagonal walking stick for getting around; and the spoon for being spoon-fed.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the meaning is the same, but the final two strokes are omitted so that they can be replaced with other elements.
Mnemonic1: An old man, wondering what it´s like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air.
Mnemonic2: Old man sits in the dirt, having a stroke.
Compo: 老: old man　匕: spoon

Origin: Old man . . . child.
Mnemonic1: This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders.
Mnemonic2: #ERROR!
Compo: 老: old man　子: child

Origin: When we refer to someone as thick-skinned or thick-headed, we are usually quick to add - even if only under our breath - something about their upbringing. Perhaps it is because deep down we cherish the belief that by nature people are basically tender and sensitive. Be that as it may, the Japanese character for thick depicts a child abandoned out on the wild cliffs, exposed to the heat of the sun, and thus doomed to develop a head and skin as thick as the parent who left it there.
Mnemonic1: In Sparta we throw our Children over a Cliff. Under the Sun, they fight other Children. In the end, if they survive, they sure have thick skin.
Mnemonic2: The thick cliff walls protected the children from the sun.
Compo: 厂: cliff　日: day; sun　子: child

Origin: Filial piety . . . taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it.
Mnemonic2: You could say that the taskmistress is teaching you filial piety when she whips you and asks, "Who´s your daddy?!".
Compo: 孝: filial piety　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Kunyomi: おし.える, おそ.わる

Origin: In order not to confuse the key word perfect with others nearly synonymous in meaning, pull it apart to have a look at its native Latin roots. Per-factum suggests something so "thoroughly made or done" that nothing more needs to be added to it. Now look at the kanji, which does something similar. We see a house that has been made perfectly from its beginnings in the foundation to the roof on the top. Now return to frame 101 and make sure not to confuse this key word with the kanji for complete.
Mnemonic1: Make the perfect impression in the beginning by removing your shoes upon entering a Japanese home.
Mnemonic2: In the beginning, Adam and Eve had a home in Eden. It was perfect.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　元: beginning; origin

Origin: This key word, the abbreviation for Institution, represents the use of that word as a suffix affixed to certain buildings and organizations. Its primitive elements: pinnacle . . . perfect.
Mnemonic1: The Institution of The Pinnacle is perfect in every way. It is the new House of God, his chosen city.
Mnemonic2: To reach the pinnacle of kanji perfect you need to attend the Heisig Inst.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　完: perfect

Origin: We choose the city of Nara as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in Nara; and also because of Nara's famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: St. Bernard dog . . . altar.
Mnemonic1: It´s beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave!
Mnemonic2: Nara is just a big show for tourists.
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　示: altar; show (礻)

Origin: House . . . altar.
Mnemonic1: I never really did figure out what religion my host family was - all I knew was that they kept an altar in their home.
Mnemonic2: All the RELIGIONS have their own temples, which are houses where they place their altars.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　示: altar; show (礻)

Origin: Flesh . . . crotch . . . altar. Note how the second element is cut short, giving a tent-like effect to the character.
Mnemonic1: A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.
Mnemonic2: There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　又: again; crotch (RTK)　示: altar; show (礻)
Kunyomi: まつ.る, まつ.り, まつり

Origin: Pinnacle . . . ritual.
Mnemonic1: Many rituals are practiced every day (blessing before meals, evening prayer, etc.) Only the peak rituals (wedding, Bar Mitzvah, etc.) qualify to be called an occasion.
Mnemonic2: On occasian, rituals are held at the very tip of The Pinnacle.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　祭: ritual

Origin: Guess here has the sense of a measured conjecture. Its elements: house . . . ritual.
Mnemonic1: I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performet at.
Mnemonic2: It´s anyone´s guess who´s house she will wake up in the morning after the festival (祭-matsuri)
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　祭: ritual

Origin: Altar . . . ax.
Mnemonic1: Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the altars at the local missions, and if anybody refused to pray, they would get the axe.
Mnemonic2: A warrior prays for victory before the battle. He kneels at the altar, his battle axe at the ready.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　斤: axe

Origin: Altar . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: The ancestor worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.
Mnemonic2: The urns of ancestors are kept on shelves next to the altar.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: Shelf . . . power. The reason why the shelf appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power, the stronger primitive. Indeed, the only exception in all the kanji is the character for add (Frame 932).
Mnemonic1: HELP! Someone´s pinned under this bookshelf and it´s gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!
Mnemonic2: Can you help me move this shelf? I don´t have the muscle to do it alone.
Compo: 且: moreover; shelf (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)
Kunyomi: たす.ける, たす.かる, すけ

Origin: Person . . . in.
Mnemonic1: When negotiating a hostage situation, Mr. T acted as the go-between, or person in the middle, for law enforcement and the terrorist.
Mnemonic2: Go-between The person in the middle.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　中: middle; in (RTK)

Origin: In the middle of a . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Their true loyalty exists in the middle of their hearts.
Mnemonic2: Your loyalty is to what´s in your heart.
Compo: 中: middle; in (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: This kanji could hardly be simpler. The key word open sea readily suggests being out in the middle of a great body of water .Thinking of it in this way should avoid confusion with the kanji for "open," which we will meet later on.
Mnemonic1: Open sea is a lot of water in the middle of nowhere.
Mnemonic2: Water in the middle of the ocean is referred to as open sea.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　中: middle; in (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . mouth . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T opens his mouth from the top of the tree saying "I pitty da foo who don´t protect the trees!".
Mnemonic2: Tip: Heisig later combines mouth and tree into 呆 dumbfounded (#2181). Story: Your person (Mr. T. or whoever) is dumbfounded when told to protect the bad guys rather than fight them.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　口: mouth　木: tree; wood
口: mouth　木: tree; wood

Origin: The notion of guarding something easily brings to mind the image of someone standing guard, like the royal soldiers in front of Buckingham Palace or the Pope's Swiss Guard. The whole idea of hiring guards is that they should stick like glue to your house to protect it from unwanted prowlers. So go ahead and glue a guard to your house in imagination.
Mnemonic1: A GUARD is usually "glued" to the house he watches.
Mnemonic2: A guard provides a measure of security to those under a roof.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)
Kunyomi: まも.る, まも.り, もり, -もり

Origin: Glued . . . pent in.
Mnemonic1: When you are admitted into a group like the Yakuza, you´re well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the group like glue, and you will be pent-in for life, never being able to leave.
Mnemonic2: A pent-in group will naturally be more cohesive, or "glued together.".
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

English: Opposite, Counter To; In Relation To, Oppose
Origin: Plaid . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: When sitting vis-a-vis, Scots will glue their kilt down to avoid embaressment.
Mnemonic2: The word vis-a-vis is like sentence glue, it kind of joins sentences together.
Compo: 文: literature; plaid (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: The character for village was associated with rice fields (Frame 96). That for town, a step up on the evolutionary path to cities, shows a circle of trees glued together to measure off the confines of a town.
Mnemonic1: If you´ve ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you´ll remember that every town was all bordered off by a line of trees with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were glued together so you could only exit town through the main or side gates, (so you couldn´t escape the important scripted scenes.).
Mnemonic2: Pfft. At it´s core, a town is just a bunch of wood glued together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Whatever one is particularly adept at - one's special "genius" - one can do very easily, "with one finger" as the phrase goes. This kanji is a pictograph of that one finger. Note how its distinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the element for fingers backwards.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning, genie, derives from the roots of the word genius. Use the genie out in the open when the primitive appears to the right of or below its relative primitive; in that case it also keeps its same form. At the left, the form is altered, and the meaning becomes a genie in the bottle.
Mnemonic1: Spinal tap: "Every other band´s amps go to ten. But you see my extra stroke of genius - these go to eleven.".
Mnemonic2: A TEN year old had a STROKE of GENIUS and wrote this joke: 何歳ですか？ 。。。天才です！.
Compo: 才: genius
Ex2Kana: じゅうはっさいみまん

Origin: Clam . . . genie.
Mnemonic1: If you´re a money genius, you can afford a lot of property.
Mnemonic2: The keyword refers to property in the sense of money or funds rather than of buildings or real estate. Keep this one distinct from frame 193 (“wealth”) and frame 473 (“assets”). Here we have a genie, gulping down oysters. Someone tries to grab an oyster and the genie puts his big arms around his oysters and states his “right of ownership” : “They´re mines, my property!”.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　才: genius

Origin: Tree . . . genie.
Mnemonic1: A TREE GENIUS is a LUMBER jack. Duh.
Mnemonic2: Just when the were about to turn the last tree into lumber, the Lorax (the tree-genie) jumps out and puts a stop to the whole affair.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　才: genius

Origin: The technique for sinking used in this kanji is unique. Rather than the biblical image of tying a millstone about the victim's neck, here we see a crown tied about one leg before the unfortunate party is tossed into the water.
Mnemonic1: (thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn´t have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend´s schemes.
Mnemonic2: This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling "Eureka! Eureka!" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　冘: lame
Ex3English: Sink, send to the bottom, submerge

Origin: Tree . . . crown tied around leg of person.
Mnemonic1: The guy who was thrown into the river to sink was given one last request. "If I´m gonna be sleeping with the fishes," he said, "can I at least have a pillow? I´m real sensitive." The mafia bosses laughed. "Look, my doctor said I can only use wooden pillows, I have a real serious condition. Can I at least die comfortable-like?" The mafia dudes said fine, and let him have his pillow. They tossed him the river and drove off...and after a minute, he bobbed to the top, thanks to his floating wood pillow.
Mnemonic2: WOODEN PILLOWS do not sink (#1888) in water.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　冘: lame

Origin: The length whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with arms at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from large (Frame 112).
Mnemonic1: Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.
Mnemonic2: This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare "length" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldn´t show "it" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your length. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji.
Compo: 丈: length
木: tree; wood　丈: length

Origin: Person . . . locket.
Mnemonic1: LOCKETs often carry inside them a picture of a PERSON we find ADMIRABLE.
Mnemonic2: For locket: The locket (key dangling from something, the vertical stroke) opens like a mouth, but you need a jeweler´s monocle to make out the pictures within. ----- Dracula survives a staking attempt when the locket with Mina´s admirable picture deflects the blow. "It was an admirable attempt," he admits as he sucks his attacker´s blood.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　韋: tanned leather; locket (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . locket.
Mnemonic1: The thread that holds the locket around my neck is choker-length so it stays horizontal.
Mnemonic2: Hint : this kanji also means "latitude", which are the horizontal lines on a globe. Do you remember James Heisig's story for frame 175 "black ink" ? Here a cartographer on a ship, is using his "thread locket" to mark horizontal lines on a map. He pulls a chalked thread from the locket, and snaps it to mark horizontal lines. Imagine the "thread-locket" in the shape of a globe, filled with dark powder and a little bobbin of thread.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　韋: tanned leather; locket (RTK)

Origin: Boulevard . . . locket. Do not confuse with ward off (Frame 1399), protect (Frame 1072), guard (Frame 198), or safeguard (Frame 756).
Mnemonic1: (defense; protection] For "defense against the dark arts" class, you go the magical boulevard and buy an enchanted locket.
Mnemonic2: Since it was in the middle of the boulevard, everyone could see she hit the man only in self-defense, as he was trying to steal her valuable locket.
Compo: 行: going; journey　韋: tanned leather; locket (RTK)

Origin: As with Italy (Frame 1245) and Africa (Frame 1391), this character simply abbreviates the full name of Korea. Its elements: mist . . . locket.
Mnemonic1: There´s a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama´s picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called "Winter Sonata".
Mnemonic2: This character represents the flag of South Korea: a locket (circular taegeuk) in the middle of the mist (white background). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_South_Korea.
Compo: 𠦝: mist (RTK)　韋: tanned leather; locket (RTK)
Ex2English: Japan and south korea, japanese-south korean

Origin: Locket . . . road.
Mnemonic1: You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they´ve seen it, but no luck. "Just buy another one," someone says. "I mean, what´s the difference?" Then of course you say "Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don´t want a different one! " Then of course they understand.
Mnemonic2: An odd version of The Road Less Traveled: "I found a locket in the road, and that has made all the difference.".
Compo: 韋: tanned leather; locket (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: ちが.う, ちが.い, ちが.える, -ちが.える

Origin: Fingers . . . wrap.
Mnemonic1: When embracing someone, wrap your fingers around her butt for added effect. You may think of "bound with snakes" as a description of the fingers slithering around the buttocks, if you want a particularly graphic image.
Mnemonic2: Here, I´m picturing that scene from ET (the extra terrestrial), where ET hugs Elliot before leaving. You see that EMBRACE is ET´s long FINGERS that WRAP around Elliot.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　包: wrap
Kunyomi: だ.く, いだ.く, かか.える
Ex3English: Hug, embrace, hold in one's arms
Ex4English: Have (in one's mind), bear (a grudge, etc.), hold (a hope, etc.)

Origin: Stones . . . wrap.
Mnemonic1: Primitive cannons fired stones wrapped with poisonous snakes.
Mnemonic2: Cannon = stone projectile wrapped by a barrel.
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　包: wrap

Origin: Water . . . wrap.
Mnemonic1: When water forms a bubble, it wraps a pocket of air.
Mnemonic2: To prevent people from popping bubble wrap for fun, the post office has started filling the bubbles with water.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　包: wrap

Mnemonic1: How about a rusty cinnabar colored dilapidated boat, found abandoned somewhere. The smoke-stack and the keel have fallen off...
Mnemonic2: Rusty old boat with the bottom and top missing.
Compo: 冂: hood; belt (RTK)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: After the drop and the glass canopy, we come to a combination of three strokes that we met only once before, in the character for mama (frame 105). The pictographic meaning we gave it there has no etymological relationship to this character, but use it if it helps.
Mnemonic1: I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks.
Mnemonic2: Cinnabar (丹) colored boat, the extra drop signifying that the paint hasn´t dried yet. The stick represents the oars.
Compo: 舟: boat

Origin: Boat . . . gully.
Mnemonic1: A boy floats his toy boat in a gully and imagines it as an immense ship.
Mnemonic2: Aargh, hard to keep this separate from boat. How about this: the phrase "shape up or ship out!" This phrase originally meant that a soldier had better get his act together, or else face being shipped off into a combat zone. Here we see a poor WW-I soldier who has been shipped off to a combat zone. He´s riding in the boat overseas to fight in the trenches (gulley).
Compo: 舟: boat　㕣: marsh, gully (RTK)

Origin: The type of boat connoted by this key word is a large oceangoing liner. The important thing here is to work with the elements boat and dove to make an image distinct from that of the former frame. Don't count on size alone to distinguish the boat from the liner.
Mnemonic1: The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice.
Mnemonic2: A liner is to boat as an emperor (#261) is to a king (#255), or a chief (#967) is to a person (#951): in each case we need only add white to the latter in order to get the former.
Compo: 舟: boat　白: white

Origin: Boat . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: Carrier?! This means "general" (as in the general public or generally). OK.. Carriers, i.e. boats with missiles, are not available to the general public.
Mnemonic2: In general, carrier boats have missiles.
Compo: 舟: boat　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . carrier.
Mnemonic1: When workers neglect workplace safety, their fingers get cut off and carried away by the conveyor belt, which looks like a ´finger carrier´ in that case.
Mnemonic2: During WWII, morse code was the primary means of communication from sea. The morse code specialist was the conveyor of messages to and from the crew of the carrier, using his fingers to tap out the secret messages. (This works especially well for 搬送周波数 carrier frequency and 搬送波 carrier wave, being the radio waves/frequencies used in morse code).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　般: carrier

Origin: Carrier . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: What do you call a "CARRIER" of DISHes? A TRAY.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a restaurant set in Disney´s Fantasia or maybe in Harry Potter´s university, where dishes are magically landing and taking off of a carrier tray.
Compo: 般: carrier　皿: dish

Origin: Footprint . . . rice . . . shovel.
Mnemonic1: Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you´ll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead.
Mnemonic2: My dentist used his foot and a shovel to dislodge the rice stuck between my teeth.
Compo: 止: stop; footprint (RTK)　米: rice　凵: open box; shovel (RTK)

Origin: Ice . . . orders.
Mnemonic1: To keep your water cool, just order some ice.
Mnemonic2: The Japanese boss gives an order at the meeting: eat ice to stay cool (since they won´t be running the air conditioning anymore).
Compo: 冫: ice　令: orders
Kunyomi: つめ.たい, ひ.える, ひ.や, ひ.ややか, ひ.やす, ひ.やかす, さ.める, さ.ます

Origin: This character is used to express the years of one's age. Its elements: teeth . . . orders.
Mnemonic1: You know you are fast approaching a ripe old AGE when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH.
Mnemonic2: This has the nuance of a life milestone. Here it's represented by the life-cycle of teeth: In childhood, your teeth give the orders, growing whenever they want. As a teenager, we give orders to the teeth, by putting braces on them. In old age, we order new teeth!
Compo: 齒: tooth　令: orders

Origin: First we need to look at the fourth stroke, the drop at the bottom that has been extended into a longer diagonal stroke leaning left. This happens because a single, isolated drop will NEVER appear beneath its relative primitive in its normal size, for fear it would drop off and get lost. As for the meaning, let the tiny drop indicate a further belittling of what is already little - thus making it a few of something little.
Mnemonic1: Only a few people can make an ugly face like that.
Mnemonic2: Few usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　丿: katakana no

Origin: Good sand for beaches has few or no stones in it. That means that all of us whose feet have been spoiled by too much time in shoes don't have to watch our step as we cavort about.
Mnemonic1: Here´s how I remember that stone is on the left. This is because sand starts as stones, and only later they become few.
Mnemonic2: In good SAND, stones are few, if any.
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　少: few

Origin: Footprints that follow one another a few at a time indicate walking.
Mnemonic1: When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls.
Mnemonic2: When you learn to walk, you take your steps a few at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every few steps but keeps getting up to try again.
Compo: 止: stop; footprint (RTK)　少: few

Origin: To ford a body of water means to walk across it.
Mnemonic1: The new Ford Jesus. It can do everything except WALK on WATER.
Mnemonic2: A ford is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　歩: walk

English: Ministry, Save, Cut Down, Leave Out, Introspect, Reflect
Origin: When we think of focusing on something, we usually take it in a metaphorical sense, though the literal sense is not far behind. It means to block out what is nonessential in order to fix our eye on a few important matters. The kanji suggests picking up a few things and holding them before one's eye in order to focus on them better.
Mnemonic1: You focus by concentrating your eye on fewer objects.
Mnemonic2: Success (or survival?) method for accelerated juggling course: focus on a few nitroglycerine filled juggling balls flying OVER your eyes ---(I have trouble with this few primitive that can be anywhere in a kanji. To build in its location in the story is important somehow).
Compo: 少: few　目: eye
Kunyomi: かえり.みる, はぶ.く
Ex4Kana: こうせいろうどうしょう
Ex4English: Ministry of health, labor, and welfare

Origin: The prefix inter- stirs up associations of cooperation among people. From there we read off the elements: tree . . . eye. With only a slight leap of the imagination, those two words call to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the block of timber out of one's own eye before helping your neighbors with the splinter in theirs. What more useful rule for inter-human relationships, and what more useful tool for remembering this kanji!
Mnemonic1: The prime minister is having inter-course behind that tree! All you can see are his eyes poking out from the righthand-side of the tree.
Mnemonic2: ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. "Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other´s aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck (首, neck (#70)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)".
Compo: 木: tree; wood　目: eye

Origin: To distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame, focus on the sense of the "con-" in the word "concept." Its elements are: inter- . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: The concept of love is basically two hearts inter-acting as one.
Mnemonic2: ´´Inter-heart´´ is a new therapy CONCEPT that helps macho guys share their feelings with each other.
Compo: 相: inter-　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Wheat . . . reclining . . . little.
Mnemonic1: Taking appellation to mean the act of naming, we have the little baby superman reclining in the space craft that landed in a wheat field. Mr. and Mrs. Kent look down and decide to call him Clark. (I also thought of Jesus but he was born in a barn full of hay not wheat).
Mnemonic2: WHEAT that is RECLINING and LITTLE (small) can´t get the APPELLATION "quality wheat".
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　尓: you; little man

Origin: Bow . . . reclining . . . little.
Mnemonic1: The bow dug more and more into the small of his back as he reclined on it. Will someone please tell the idiot to get up?
Mnemonic2: If I recline back, I can pull my bow open a little more and more.
Compo: 弓: bow　尓: you; little man

Origin: When you draw this character think of linking two walls together, one right side up and the other upside down.
Mnemonic1: The 69 position allows both parties to mutually give themselves pleasure.
Mnemonic2: If you can combined your walls with another house´s walls, both houses would mutually benefit, by the increase in size....
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　彑: snout

Origin: Halberd . . . taskmaster . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: It is with the halberd he holds that the taskmaster exerts his power over those actually performing the task.
Mnemonic2: So many video games have a "boss" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your task is to use your halberd to beat the taskmaster with the huge, bulging muscles.
Compo: 矛: halberd　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)
Kunyomi: つと.める, つと.まる
Ex1English: Perform one's duties; play one's part

Origin: Halberd . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: (tender; weakness; gentleness; softness] Love me tender, Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I´ll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree...
Mnemonic2: Use a halberd to tenderize a tree: halberds can chop, poke, and slash, so it´s all good!
Compo: 矛: halberd　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: やわ.らか, やわ.らかい

Origin: If the cushions of one's car are too soft, one may begin yawning at the wheel.
Mnemonic1: Cars are rough steel things, lacking softness.
Mnemonic2: If your car has really soft seats, you may start yawning and eventually fall asleep at the wheel (imagine that this seat is a huge soft beanbag that nearly swallows the driver, and it will be easier to remember).
Compo: 車: car　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)
Kunyomi: やわ.らか, やわ.らかい

Origin: Combine the primary and secondary meanings of this keyword to form your story. Begin with the car whose tires get caught in a rut and spin without going anywhere. Then go onto the baseball team who can't win a game because it has fallen into a rut of losing.
Mnemonic1: My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again.
Mnemonic2: I got my car stuck in a rut ! I´m gonna have to call 999 !
Compo: 車: car　九: nine; baseball (RTK)
Ex1English: Track, railway; planetary orbit; beaten track

Origin: This kanji, a counter for houses, is made up of cars . . . dry.
Mnemonic1: Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else.
Mnemonic2: Small flats (garages) for cars help keeping them dry.
Compo: 車: car　干: dry
Ex1English: Row of houses; all round, across the board

Origin: Car . . . shoot.
Mnemonic1: The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis.
Mnemonic2: An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car´s wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis.
Compo: 車: car　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)

Origin: Cars . . . mingle.
Mnemonic1: The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles.
Mnemonic2: Our world of today, cars mingling on busy streets, is in stark contrast to the one of yesteryear, where it was people who would mingle on the streets.
Compo: 車: car　交: mingle

Origin: Cave . . . car.
Mnemonic1: I think of the Batcave. It´s a big cave that Batman uses as a warehouse to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.
Mnemonic2: Have you ever worked in a warehouse? It´s like a giant metal cave. Watch out for that forklift!
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　車: car

Origin: Flowers . . . parade . . . slaves.
Mnemonic1: The storehouse is overgrown with slaves. The slaves are to be sold in the store, to differentiate from a warehouse, which doesn´t have the word "store" in it.
Mnemonic2: Slaves moved flowers from the storehouse in preparation for the parade.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　臣: subject; slave (RTK)　戊: halberd; parade (RTK)

Origin: The single gate is used here not in order to represent one gate, but many of them, indeed a meeting of gates. Add mouth (as an entrance here) and you end up with godown. That should help keep this character distinct from warehouse (Frame 633).
Mnemonic1: A godown is a dockside warehouse. This is actually a meeting of large doors and mouths. The stroke order is the same as door, not gates, just with the top stroke moved down into the now larger door.
Mnemonic2: Note: this is not gate but actually a variation of door and is written as such, with the vertical stroke last not first.
Compo: 亼: assemble; meeting　尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Godown . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers.
Mnemonic2: I prefer to have girls Godown on my sabre to prevent unwanted GENESIS of babies............創造 そうぞう (creation).
Compo: 倉: storehouse; godown　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Folklore throughout the world tells us of talking animals who show a wisdom superior to that of human beings, and that same tradition has found its way into television shows and cartoons right into our own century. This character depicts revelation through the mouth of a cow, suggesting oracular utterances about truths hidden to human intelligence.
Mnemonic1: The revelation makes the cow´s mouth drop down, "Hamburgers are made of what?!".
Mnemonic2: When you get a revelation, you may drop to the ground with your mouth wide open.
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　口: mouth

Origin: Think of creating as making something out of nothing. Then recall how the way of revelation laid out in the Bible begins with the story of how God created the world out of a dark and chaotic nothingness.
Mnemonic1: A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path.
Mnemonic2: CREATION is the ROAD to REVELATION (if you´re feeling artsy) :).
Compo: 告: announce; revelation　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: つく.る, つく.り, -ずくり

Origin: At the top we see the top hat, and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a garment. If you break the "4-fold" fold into 2 sets of 2 strokes, you will find it easier to remember.
SubOrigin:
Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of cloak or scarf will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here.
When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ネ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean cloak. At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the top hat) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a scarf.
On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a top hat and scarf.
And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of garment in general.
Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is "unhooked."
Mnemonic1: The only garments allowed in this club are top hat and scarf.
Mnemonic2: The garments most commonly associated with the craft of a magician are the top hat and the magic wand. (It´s a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.).
Compo: 衣: clothes; garment (RTK)
Ex2English: Food, clothing, and shelter; the necessities of life

Origin: Person . . . garment.
Mnemonic1: Mr T is reliant (depends on) on his garment (the gold chains).
Mnemonic2: Mr. T. is so self-reliant he even makes his own garments.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Substitute . . . garment.
Mnemonic1: A sack is an easy substitute for a garment.
Mnemonic2: A worker who was recently sacked from his job, is wearing a sack of potatoes as a substitute garment (naked otherwise), in some kind of protest. The kanji is close to frame 1547 "bag", and although the later really refers to a "straw sack", I use the image of a sack of potatoes here, and that of a "plastic bag" for frame 1547. The keywords would have been better swapped in my opinion, but the relevancy is not so important at this point (see notes of Lesson 31 in the book).
Compo: 代: substitute　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Top hat and scarf . . . protect. Note that the "tree" in protect becomes a wooden pole here.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T is praised for his protecting of the trees by being given a top hat and scarf which he wears over his mohawk and chains, respectively.
Mnemonic2: An old lady puts a top hat and scarf on her poodle and praises him for how cute he is. The dog thinks, "Someone protect me from this psycho!"…
Compo: 衣: clothes; garment (RTK)　保: protect

Origin: An innocent looking top hat and scarf lying there in front of you, turned over, reveal a hidden computer sewn into the back of each - obviously the tools of a master spy. Such experiences teach one always to have a look at the back side of things.
Mnemonic1: The computer had carefully dressed up in clothes to look human. It wasn´t until I looked at the back and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was.
Mnemonic2: Can computers be gay? I´m not sure, but mine always wears a top hat and scarf, and for some reason its back door port is always open...
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　里: village; computer (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)
Ex1English: Back, reverse, other side, inside; background

English: Express, Manifest, Surface, Outside, Front, Table, Chart
Origin: Grow up . . . rags. This character represents the "outside" of a garment, just as the kanji for back (Frame 426) depicted the "inside" or lining.
Mnemonic1: When I was GROWING UP, the SURFACE of my SCARF was always covered with snot from blowing my nose on it.
Mnemonic2: (Thanks to zerOrange) I grew up underground, and whenever I went to the surface I wore a scarf to avoid scrutiny.
Compo: 龶: grow up, master (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)
Kunyomi: おもて, -おもて, あらわ.す, あらわ.れる

Origin: Do not think of a "gift" here, but of the present moment, as distinct from the future and the past. The kanji gives us a ball in which we see the present - obviously a crystal ball that enables us to see things going on at the present in faraway places.
Mnemonic1: The KING ... can SEE clearly the PRESENT state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?).
Mnemonic2: Hey, I want my money back! This crystal ball is out of order, I can see the present instead of the future!
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　見: see
Kunyomi: あらわ.れる, あらわ.す

Origin: Flowers . . . puppet.
Mnemonic1: Here I am, putting a wreath of flowers on my love doll´s head and pretending she is someone of great renowned.
Mnemonic2: This someone is so renowned they are covered with flowers every time they perform on stage.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　者: person; puppet (RTK)
Kunyomi: あらわ.す, いちじる.しい

Origin: This kanji show a unique system for leading cows to the slaughterer's saber: one ties a belt about their waist and fixes that belt to an overhead cable, pulling the cow up into the air where it hangs suspended, helpless against the fate that awaits it.
Mnemonic1: The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword.
Mnemonic2: Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn´t have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he´s part of the bushi SYSTEM. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very Special Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, "Moo!".
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　巾: towel　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: A label indicating that a garment was made in U.S.A. or Taiwan or Japan is itself a symbol for the systematization of the garment industry.
Mnemonic1: Made in china - a system of exploitation . making garments for nothing.
Mnemonic2: A SYSTEMATICALLY made GARMENT will no doubt have MADE IN on the label.
Compo: 制: system　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: The primitives here take care of themselves: cloak and dagger .What I leave to you is to decide on an appropriate connotation for "first time" to take advantage of them.
Mnemonic1: This is the first time we´ve been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo! Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger.
Mnemonic2: On his FIRST TIME, he cloaked his dagger with a Trojan.
Compo: 衤: cloak (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Kunyomi: はじ.め, はじ.めて, はつ, はつ-, うい-, -そ.める, -ぞ.め

Origin: Cloak . . . fruit.
Mnemonic1: Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were naked, and so clothing themselves in a cloak.
Mnemonic2: Hey honey, I´m naked underneath this cloak. I´ve got some nice melons and a fresh peach waiting for you. Don´t you want to taste my forbidden fruits...?
Compo: 衤: cloak (RTK)　果: fruit

Origin: Scarecrow . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Learning Kanji is difficult for Turkeys.
Mnemonic2: It is difficult for a scarecrow to scare a turkey or else they would´ve been called scareturkeys.
Compo: 堇: cabbage, scarecrow (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)
Kunyomi: かた.い, -がた.い, むずか.しい

Origin: Ice . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Quasi-modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn´t actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!
Mnemonic2: An iced turkey is only quasi-as-good-as fresh turkey.
Compo: 冫: ice　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Think of this in terms of the semifinals of some sports competition. Water . . . turkeys . . . needle.
Mnemonic1: The anhinga, or water turkey, has a needle-like nose, so really it´s only a semi-turkey http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anhinga.
Mnemonic2: At the turkey fighting semi-final, turkeys are injected with drugs via needles and splashed with water to help them last the match.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . flowers . . . cliff . . . screwdriver. In cases like this you can jumble up the primitive into any order that seems best for the composition of a story, provided you feel confident about the relative position that those primitives take to one another in the completed character.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.
Mnemonic2: An RPG where you´re using Mr T as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the flower cliff screwdriver. This is a small screwdriver obtained at the bottom of a cliff that, when used in battle, shoots out pink flowers. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　厂: cliff　用: to use; screwdriver (RTK)
Kunyomi: そな.える, そな.わる

Origin: Bones . . . spoon. Note how the first stroke is extended to the right, forming a sort of "roof" overhead.
Mnemonic1: Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they´re out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.
Mnemonic2: Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of death), carrying a spoon made of human bones instead of a scythe.
Compo: 歹: bones　匕: spoon

Origin: Flowers . . . death . . . two hands. Do not confuse with bury (Frame 191).
Mnemonic1: I imagine an interment as a funeral. At this funeral it´s an open casket, and the dead body (death) is holding flowers with both of its hands.
Mnemonic2: During the interment ceremony, the grandchildren placed flowers over the dead body while the widow sat praying with two hands.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　死: death; die　廾: twenty; 2 hands

Origin: Bones . . . saber. The sense of the key word is of people or things lined up in a row.
Mnemonic1: A line of skeletal warriors, all armed with sabers.
Mnemonic2: Skeleton army rank and file. Dudes made of bones carrying sabres.
Compo: 歹: bones　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: File . . . oven fire.
Mnemonic1: The nazis were ardent believers in the master arian race, see them marching everyone else into the oven fires, single file.
Mnemonic2: The undead, marching single file, prove how ardent they are be walking across a field of flame. Fun fact, ardent used to mean to burn.
Compo: 列: file　火: fire (灬)

Origin: File . . . garment.
Mnemonic1: They tried issuing the skeleton warriors with proper garments to wear, but they kept getting split by the sharp bones or by their sabres. In the end, it was decided they look scarier naked anyway.
Mnemonic2: Someone takes a sword made of bone to split the garment right down the middle. Very effective.
Compo: 列: file　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . file.
Mnemonic1: Mr T shows the example to the kids, and stays in the file (at supermarket, ...). “I pity da foo who does not follow my example !”.
Mnemonic2: When Mr. T. wants to make an example out of a group of people, he lines them up all single file and knocks them all out with one punch!
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　列: file

Origin: Two hands . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: This kanji is for severe punishment. A man has his shackled hands placed on a wood block and they´re chopped off with a saber. No more stealing bread in the Middle East...
Mnemonic2: In Arab countries they punish theives by cutting off BOTH HANDS with a SABRE.
Compo: 开: open; start　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Punish . . . soil. In cases like this, you might find it easier to break the character up into its more basic elements, like this: two hands . . . saber . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: A famous ninja once pressed his two hands and saber into the soil of his temple, before going onto a mission from which he never came back. Think of some sort of signature that he left behind him. The mould of his two hands and saber has since become a popular attraction in the area.
Mnemonic2: As a PUNISHMENT they made me lay face down in the DIRT leaving a nice imprinted MOULD of my whole BODY.
Compo: 开: open; start　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Stone . . . two hands.
Mnemonic1: My stones are so huge that it takes two hands to polish them!
Mnemonic2: You use two hands to polish a stone: one to hold it and the other to rub it.
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　开: open; start

Origin: Cliff . . . fingerprint.
Mnemonic1: Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was.
Mnemonic2: Sherlock Holmes is very unlucky: he just fell off a cliff while he was looking around for fingerprints.
Compo: 厂: cliff　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: Bound up . . . unlucky.
Mnemonic1: If you live a dangerous life, eventually you're bound to get unlucky.
Mnemonic2: While rock climbing you are bound to the cliff by just your fingerprints, which is why it´s so dangerous.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　厄: unlucky
Kunyomi: あぶ.ない, あや.うい, あや.ぶむ

Origin: Bamboo . . . car . . . fingerprint.
Mnemonic1: This pattern made of bamboo is for a new model of car designed to leave as small an ecological fingerprint as possible.
Mnemonic2: I just had a new bamboo-leaf pattern spray-painted on my car. Don't touch it, you'll leave fingerprints!
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　車: car　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: Mailbox . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: I couldn´t drop my grudge against him. So I put a severed pig´s heart in his mailbox. He got the message.
Mnemonic2: To hold a grudge is actually the act of keeping negative feelings you received in the mailbox of your heart.
Compo: 夕: evening　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: うら.む*, うら.み*, うら.めしい*

Origin: Flowers . . . mailbox.
Mnemonic1: Japanese "gardens" aren´t anything more than a pot of flowers on top of the mailbox.
Mnemonic2: My mailbox is actually right in the middle of my garden, which kind of sucks since the mailman has to trample all my flowers to get to it.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　夕: evening　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: House . . . mailbox.
Mnemonic1: Your address should be displayed on your house and mailbox.
Mnemonic2: For the primitive: This is a hi-tech Japanese mailbox, it automatically lights up in the evening, and has a biometric fingerprint scanner. --- Each house´s address, even if it´s hard to see in the evening, is like its own unique fingerprint.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　夕: evening　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)
石: stone; rock (RTK)　宛: address

Origin: Part of the body . . . address.
Mnemonic1: Like in Memento, I tattoo my address on my forearm flesh so I don´t forget it.
Mnemonic2: In Iraq people are having their addresses tattooed on their bodies, usually their arms, so they can be identified if they are killed. (true story).
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　宛: address

Origin: Gone . . . stamp.
Mnemonic1: (instead; on the contrary; rather] Gone is the time for stamps - use e-mail instead.
Mnemonic2: If you tried to attach money to an envelope to pay for postage it would be GONE before it arrived at the post office. That´s why we use STAMPS instead.
Compo: 去: gone　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)
Ex3English: Sell off, dispose of by sale

Origin: Part of the body . . . instead. This character has more or less the same meaning as that for leg learned back in frame 1372. It can also indicate the part of the legs from the shins down, which explains the choice of the key word.
Mnemonic1: Shins are the part of the body that one uses instead of one´s eyes, for finding furniture in the dark. (Ouch!).
Mnemonic2: Shins are the part of the body that Japanese traditionally sit on instead of their asses.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　却: instead

Origin: Wild dogs . . . fingerprint.
Mnemonic1: Crimes can often be solved using the tools of dogs and fingerprints.
Mnemonic2: This crime gang has yet to be caught because their pack of wild dogs takes care of licking off the fingerprints from all the crime scenes.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: A lunatic is literally one driven mad by the light of the moon, and the most famous of the "looneys" are the legendary lycanthropes or "wolfmen." Sometimes the transformation is only a temporary phenomenon, sometimes it is permanent. In the latter case, the poor chap takes off on all fours to live with the beasts. To remember this kanji, imagine one of these lycanthropes going looney and setting himself up as king of a pack of wild dogs that roams about and terrorizes innocent suburban communities.
Mnemonic1: Oh no ! A pack of dogs has bitten the king. He has turned into a rabid lunatic !
Mnemonic2: Think of King Nebuchadnezzar, who for 7 years lost his sanity and had to live like a wild animal.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　王: king; ball (RTK)
Kunyomi: くる.う, くる.おしい, くる.わす, くる.わせる

Origin: Although we did not make note of it at the time, the kanji for dog is also a low-grade term for a spy. And later (Frame 1517) we will meet another association of criminals with dogs. The prison here depicts a pack of wild dogs (the long-timers and hardened criminals) into which the poor little chihuahua (first offender) has been cast. The only thing he has to protect himself against the pack are his shrill and frightened words.
Mnemonic1: The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.
Mnemonic2: The only thing keeping the new chihuahua inmate from being ´initiated´ by the pack of wild dogs were his quick words in prison.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　言: word; say　犬: dog (犭)

Origin: This key word, a negating prefix, is a doodle of a heavy iron pole with bars extending in both directions, to create the picture of a jail cell. From there to "un-" is but a short step.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall draw on the explanation above for the meaning of jail cell.
Mnemonic1: This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That´s an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague.
Mnemonic2: People in the jail cell are un-friendly, un-comely, and un-cooperative.
Compo: 非: mistake; jail cell (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . jail cell.
Mnemonic1: When ordered to go to the jail cell, the defendant gave the judge the finger and said he repudiated all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail.
Mnemonic2: He reached his fingers through the bars of his jail cell, trying to touch his beloved. But she repudiated him and left.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　非: mistake; jail cell (RTK)

Origin: This character is used for the haiku, the 17-syllable poem that is one of Japan's best-known literary forms. Its elements: person .. . jail cell.
Mnemonic1: I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando).
Mnemonic2: I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail/ I pity the fool.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　非: mistake; jail cell (RTK)

Origin: Eye . . . jail cell.
Mnemonic1: Guilty under the eyes of the law, therefore sentenced to jail. (note: ´UNDER the eye of the law´ works in penalty (#833) as well.].
Mnemonic2: It is his guilt that is causing them. He is having these nightmares where the great (sideways) eye appears at the top of his jail cell, and is staring down intently at him. Guilt is a merciless tormentor.
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　非: mistake; jail cell (RTK)

Origin: Eye . . . words . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: For Japanese, when the mind´s eye (the sideways eye) feels guilty for something bad that the body has done, there are two penaltys to choose from. One, you can say I´m sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I´m sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ).
Mnemonic2: There is a 3-way masterplan for every goalkeeper to prevent a goal at penalty shootout: 1. Look directly into the eyes of the player --- 2. Confuse him by screaming senseless words --- 3. Pull out you your saber and ... (that´s up to you).
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　言: word; say　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Person . . . half.
Mnemonic1: The person who is your consort is most commonly "your other half".
Mnemonic2: Mr. T wants to splits himself in half so he can be his own CONSORT.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　半: half

Origin: Half . . . saber. You might recall the famous judgment of King Solomon, who offered to slice a baby in two with a saber to give half to each of the mothers who claimed it as her own.
Mnemonic1: In the bible, King Solomon´s JUDGMENT was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was.
Mnemonic2: It takes good judgement to cut things in exactly half with a saber.
Compo: 半: half　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Words . . . water lily.
Mnemonic1: Good evaluation should always be words of even fairness.
Mnemonic2: You get an evaluation copy of MS Word because you want to evaluate whether it´s worth buying the full version. At the end of the evaluation period the CD turns into a lilypad so you can´t use it any more (an innovative new copy-protection trick).
Compo: 言: word; say　平: plain

Origin: Finger . . . compare.
Mnemonic1: Think of the two most famous critics, Ebert and Roeper. On their show, they compare thumbs (which are technically fingers) with each other before dispensing criticism.
Mnemonic2: My criticism earned me the FINGER when I COMPARED her cooking to my mother´s.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　比: compare

Origin: Maestro . . . towel.
Mnemonic1: The COMMANDER is a military MAESTRO who never throws in the TOWEL.
Mnemonic2: The greatest of them all; Commander James Bond, 007. Here he is the maestro of undressing women, removing the towel from some bond girl. Of course the towel symbolises her last vestige of resistance.
Compo: 𠂤: maestro (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: Maestro . . . ceiling . . . towel.
Mnemonic1: A maestro in a large auditorium with high ceilings is conducting his orchestra of expert musicians at a fever-pitch, sweat pouring out of him. When the piece is over he reaches for his towel to wipe his brow.
Mnemonic2: Maestro is such as expert, he can conduct even with a towel hanging from the ceiling in front of him.
Compo: 𠂤: maestro (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: Cave . . . assembly line . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: CONGRATULATIONS YOU´RE HALFWAY THERE!!!! =).
Mnemonic2: Coal mine (cave); tea break time; the assembly line stops and everyone sit or squat on the dirt floor, in a long line, to rest.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　坐: sit
从: two people; assembly line (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

English: Graduate, Come To An End, Private, Soldier
Origin: Top hat . . . assembly line . . . needle.
Mnemonic1: Ph.D graduation for assembly line of doctors(needles) with the cap and tassel(top hat). It took them 10 years (Bachelor´s, Masters, PhD) to get there.... :-p.
Mnemonic2: When you graduate, you wear a hat and graduate in an assembly line while your parents sit on pins and needles because it will take ten years to pay off those loans.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　从: two people; assembly line (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Mysterious . . . sparkler . . . ten. Do not confuse with proportion (Frame 1673).
Mnemonic1: It´s quite mysterious how each sparkler gives of sparkles at a precise ratio of ten to one. Physicists have been studying this effect for decades, known as the Sparkler Effect, and using it to explain why stars look like sparklers in the night sky.
Mnemonic2: It's mysterious how there's always a ratio of ten sparklers to one package.
Compo: 玄: mysterious　水: water (氵) (氺)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Umbrella . . . two assembly lines . . . needle.
Mnemonic1: FOUR PERSONS can fit under this UMBRELLA if they are thin as a NEEDLE.
Mnemonic2: There are two assembly lines at the umbrella factory. One is responsible for making the top of the umbrella, and the other for making the handle. The two lines cross at the end, where one man tries frantically to jam the sets of parts together.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　从: two people; assembly line (RTK)　从: two people; assembly line (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . vase.
Mnemonic1: The bamboo vase was beautifully crafted, but the tourist didn´t know what it was and wore it as a little bamboo hat.
Mnemonic2: The bamboo part is easy. Just remember that this kanji refers to those particular bamboo hats that are worn primarily by Buddhist monks, who always seem to stand outside of train stations, collecting alms.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)

Origin: Sun . . . cell.
Mnemonic1: The sun is the nearest star to the only planet with life - Earth.
Mnemonic2: Sun is a star that has given life. Can´t say that of any other stars yet.
Compo: 日: day; sun　生: life; cell (RTK)

Origin: To make soup, one begins with water and then starts adding things to it, often leftovers from the icebox. This is how the thick soup or stew called "seven-in-one" is made. This kanji does it three better, giving us a ten-ingredient soup.
Mnemonic1: To make soup you just take water and add (+) the rest of your ingredients.
Mnemonic2: To make soup you just take water and add ten tasty ingredients.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: The Big Dipper here is of course the constellation of Ursa Major, of which this kanji is a sort of pictographic representation.
SubOrigin: Since we already have a primitive element for a "dipper" - namely, the ladle - we shall let this one stand for a measuring cup. By the way, it would make a rather large one, since the kanji is also used for a measure of about 18 liters!
Mnemonic1: Since the meaning of "big dipper" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.
Mnemonic2: Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?
Compo: 丶: dot; drop　丶: dot; drop　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Measuring cup . . . rice.
Mnemonic1: When buying rice, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don´t just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup.
Mnemonic2: Samurai(s) once received their fee in the form of rice that had been carefully weighed in a measuring cup beforehand.
Compo: 米: rice　斗: dipper; measuring cup (RTK)

Origin: Think here of the faculty or department you entered in university, using the elements: measuring cup . . . wheat.
Mnemonic1: The national DEPARTMENT of WHEATS and MEASURES. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this.
Mnemonic2: Agriculture/astronomy departments…
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　斗: dipper; measuring cup (RTK)

Origin: The key word in this frame refers to a suffix that gives the word before it an adjectival quality; hence we refer to it as "sort of thing." Reverting to the time when dog was more widely eaten than it is today (See frame 127), we see here a large cauldron boiling over an oven flame with the flesh of a chihuahua being thrown into the whole concoction to make it into a "hot-diggity, dog-diggity" sort of thing.
Mnemonic1: Flesh of a dog over a cooking fire = "hotdog". There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. Believe me, you don´t want to know what sort of things . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr´s. Thanks!).
Mnemonic2: There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. (I use hot dog for this primitive (meat of a dog over a cooking fire). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.).
Compo: 夕: evening　犬: dog (犭)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Hearth . . . sort of thing. Beware of letting the simple reading off of the primitive elements do your work for you. Unless you make a vivid image of something burning and relate it just as vividly to those primitive meanings, you can count on forgetting this character very quickly.
Mnemonic1: Any sort of thing can burn in the fire.
Mnemonic2: Somebody from PETA is really angry that they sell dog meat in China, so they´ve gone to burn down the whole cart (my mnemonic for "sort of thing" was seeing strips of dog flesh roasting, and saying "well, that´s just the sort of thing they do here in China).
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　然: -like; sort of thing (RTK)
Kunyomi: も.える, も.やす, も.す

Origin: Oddly enough, the character for silence shows us a black chihuahua. Actually, the cute little critter's name is Darkness, as I am sure you remember from the famous song about silence that begins, "Hello, Darkness, my old friend...." Note how the four dots reach all the way across the bottom of the character.
Mnemonic1: The computer won´t stop beeping, which is making the chihauhua bark, and it´s driving this guy insane. The only solution he can come up with is to throw them both on the fire and finally enjoy the silence.
Mnemonic2: Your neighbor is so sick of you playing Led Zeppelin that he takes your copy of the song Black Dog and burns it. Finally, silence in the neighborhood.
Compo: 里: village; computer (RTK)　犬: dog (犭)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Owl . . . rice field . . . one . . . mouth . . . chihuahua.
Mnemonic1: The owl looks for its prey in the rice field. It sees so many potential animals to eat but since it only has one mouth, it decides that the tasty looking chihuahua will be its meal for tonight. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006).
Mnemonic2: I have a strange story for this one but it works. I imagine a owl getting into a rice field which serves as a boxing ring. His opponent is a little chihuahua. The fight starts, the owl takes one punch to the mouth and is out cold. In the chihuahua´s corner is that coach from Rocky saying "Your an ANIMAL!!". A vivid image of this story works pretty well for me.
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth　犬: dog (犭)

Origin: Pack of wild dogs . . . owl . . . wind . . . cornstalk.
Mnemonic1: (game-hunting; shooting; game; bag] According to unicode.org and wwwjdic, 鼡 and 鼠 (mouse (#2065)) are variants. So, for 鼡 (which I´ll call rat) I have: an owl, flying in the wind, can easily spot a rat even if it´s hiding in the cornstalks. Now 猟 is easy: wild dogs are having fun by game-hunting rats.
Mnemonic2: The WILD DOGS are GAME HUNTING the OWL who flies like the WIND through the CORN STORKS.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　鼠: rat (鼡)
