Origin: To the story we have just made about fish, this kanji for the profession of fishing adds yet another element BEFORE the others: namely the water, where the fish was happily at home before being caught, disemboweled, and eaten. Be sure to get a clear image of the water when you put it all together.
Mnemonic1: You need WATER and FISH for fishing.
Mnemonic2: If you are confusing this with angling like me, take fishing to mean not the act of catching a fish but the act of being a fish not living but fishing (i.e. in the water).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　魚: fish

Origin: One of the worst problems you have to face when you go hunting is to guard your take from the wild dogs. If you imagine yourself failing at the task, you will probably have a stronger image than if you try to picture yourself succeeding.
Mnemonic1: Actually when hunting it may be a good idea to use a pack of dogs as your personal guard.
Mnemonic2: After a pack of wild dogs hunt some food, they will guard it fiercely.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　守: guard; protect

Origin: Wild dogs . . . child . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: The fierce WILD DOG attacked the CHILD who came near his feeding DISH.
Mnemonic2: If you want to make your wild dogs fierce, feed them a child. Children are the holy grail of dogfood you know...
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　子: child　皿: dish

Origin: Hearth . . . Old West . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: In the Old West, they used to light fires in the ground to make smoke signals.
Mnemonic2: Should be easy. SMOKE brings to mind "Where there´s SMOKE, there´s FIRE". So, the FIRE in the OLD WEST can tell people we´re you´re at, so put out the FIRE with SOIL to keep the SMOKE to a minimum.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　西: west (覀)　土: ground; land; soil
Kunyomi: けむ.る, けむり, けむ.い

Origin: Hearth . . . straw man. Take care to distinguish this kanji from cook (Frame 507) and burn (Frame 549) when you compose your story.
Mnemonic1: Ah, there´s no better way to bake a pizza than an oven fueled by a burning strawman. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen. Think of this image: http://users.mtrx.net/funnypics/content/-rdm1-ABCD1234-rdm1-/2005/2005-08-23-0002/Doughboy.jpg.
Mnemonic2: Too lofty (#2095)尭 a career choice for the strawman becoming a baker. He was fired soon after starting his first shift. Literally!...
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　尭: high; straw man (RTK)
Kunyomi: や.く, や.き, や.き-, -や.き, や.ける

Origin: Sun . . . straw man.
Mnemonic1: The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.
Mnemonic2: The first person to see the sun at daybreak is of course the straw man who stands outside all day.
Compo: 日: day; sun　尭: high; straw man (RTK)

Origin: A walking stick is needed for days of olden times, since days, too, get old - at least insofar as we refer to them as the "good old days." The main thing here is to think of "good old days" when you hear the key word olden times. The rest will take care of itself.
Mnemonic1: Age 18 = olden times.
Mnemonic2: The old man with a walking stick kept talking of olden times all day long.
Compo: 丨: line; stick　日: day; sun

Origin: The top part of the kanji in this frame, you will remember, is the character for olden times, those days so old they needed a walking stick to get around. Western mythical imagination has old "Father Time" leaning on his sickle with a newborn babe crawling around his legs, the idea being that the circle of birth and-death goes on. This is the first of three times that the kanji for olden times will appear as a primitive element in another kanji, so try to make the most of it.
Mnemonic1: In the olden times, a newborn babe came out legs first.
Mnemonic2: Only 18 and already got a newborn babe. Young girls are so quick to spread their legs these days…
Compo: 旧: old times　儿: human legs
亦: also; apple (RTK)

Origin: Ground . . . dagger . . . little. The two strokes of the dagger take the place of the middle stroke of little.
SubOrigin: As a primitive on the left, this kanji keeps the same form. Elsewhere, the first two strokes are abbreviated to a single dot. This latter form will take the meaning of an apple.
Mnemonic1: He was stabbed with a dagger, and little drops of red blood dropped onto the ground.
Mnemonic2: There was red all over the soil after Little Red Riding Hood plunged a dagger into the wolf. Those two dots we see are wolfies animal legs we see, by the way (a la smithsonian).
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　亦: also; apple (RTK)
Kunyomi: あか, あか-, あか.い, あか.らむ, あか.らめる

Origin: Apple . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: It´s quite unusual and abnormal to see an apple with walking legs running away from the person who wants to eat it!
Mnemonic2: Imagine an apple on walking legs on stage singing "It´s not unusual to be loved by anyone" (Tom Jones). Keyword can be confused with uncommon (#1797).
Compo: 亦: also; apple (RTK)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)
Kunyomi: か.わる, か.わり, か.える

Origin: Apple . . . insects.
Mnemonic1: The barbarian picks an apple from above and eats it even though there is a worm (insect) in it.
Mnemonic2: Barbarians eat apples with worms still in them.
Compo: 亦: also; apple (RTK)　虫: insect

Origin: Apple . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: The romance between Snow White and Prince Charming started when Snow White took a bite of poison apple and her heart stopped.
Mnemonic2: A childhood romance: a boy takes a red apple to school to try to win the heart of his beloved.
Compo: 亦: also; apple (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: こ.う, こい, こい.しい

Origin: Birdhouse . . . heart . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: If you really love someone, you won´t keep them in a cage-like bird house relationship, but rather open the door and let their heart walk around freely. Think less about "I" (あい) and more about "we".
Mnemonic2: The man is about to enter the ´birdhouse´ (brothel) when he remembers his true love at home, and, following his heart, uses his walking legs to go straight home.
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　冖: crown 　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)

Origin: Head . . . crown . . . heart . . . walking legs. Two things merit mention here. First, the doubling-up of the last stroke of head with the top of the crown serves to make the whole more aesthetically beautiful. It happens so rarely that the exceptions are easily learned. Second, try to make a single image out of the four elements. (Religious statuary of melancholy figures should offer plenty of suggestions.)
Mnemonic1: Melancholy makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so ´emo´. In order to play up his feelings he bares his head and holds his crown over his heart then walks (on walking legs) around the palace making everyone see how melancholy he is. What a wuss.
Mnemonic2: This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His crown of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his head and his heart. His walking legs can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How MELANCHOLY!
Compo: 百: hundred　冖: crown 　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)
Kunyomi: うれ.える, うれ.い, う.い, う.き
Ex2Kana: しょうらいをうれえる

Origin: Person . . . melancholy.
Mnemonic1: The A-Team is on a mission to help Hamlet. With uncharacteristic tenderness, Mr. T consoles the melancholy Hamlet. "No, I really DO pity the poor foo. There, there little guy...take my hanky". (Careful: benevolence (#885).
Mnemonic2: Someone can´t be melancholy for long if just one person treats them with a little tenderness.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　憂: melancholy
Kunyomi: やさ.しい, すぐ.れる

Origin: Old West . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: Chestnut tree, west nut tree.
Mnemonic2: The cowboy climbed the tree to see where they were in the woods. The poor guy chose a chestnut tree. ouch ouch.
Compo: 西: west (覀)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Old West . . . altar.
Mnemonic1: In the Old West there were no ballot boxes. Afraid of fraud and fighting among the gunslingers, the ballots were posted into a slot in the top of the local church altar instead. They may have been rough, but the cowboys wouldn´t fight in the church.
Mnemonic2: In western political elections (US), peoples ballots will often depend on religion and at which altar the prospective president prays.
Compo: 西: west (覀)　示: altar; show (礻)

Origin: Tree . . . ballot.
Mnemonic1: Trees were frequenly used as signposts in those days, indicating where one had to go to cast their ballots.
Mnemonic2: Large wooden signposts are planted on peoples lawns, with the faces of their representatives all saying: "Vote (1] Me!" for the upcoming ballot.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　票: ballot

Origin: Water . . . ballot.
Mnemonic1: In Florida, Bush through Kerry´s ballots into the water, watching them drift away and setting the whole country adrift.
Mnemonic2: The political fanatic stole all the ballots and dumped them in the stream. He calmly watched them drift away as the cops came to a screech behind him.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　票: ballot

Origin: West . . . St. Bernard dog . . . snake . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Since the days of the Old West, traveling has transitioned from trying not to step on big snakes to driving on big roads.
Mnemonic2: The west has gone through quite a transition, gone are the days when dogs and snakes roamed the desert, it´s all roads and casinos now.
Compo: 西: west (覀)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　已: oneself; snake (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Suum cuique goes the popular Latin proverb. A certain disease of the English language makes it almost impossible to translate the phrase without gender bias. In any event, here we see someone walking with his/her mouth between his/her walking legs, giving us an image of "To each his/her own."
SubOrigin: The sense of the proverb should help when using this kanji as a primitive; otherwise, reduce it to its original elements. But do not associate it in any way with the word "every," which we shall meet later in another context.
Mnemonic1: Son, I´ve never told you this but each woman has a second mouth between their fiiiiiine walking legs.
Mnemonic2: Each and every one of us walks and talks differently.
Compo: 夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)　口: mouth
Ex2Kana: おのおののかんがえで

Origin: When you are a guest in a courteous town, each house hold has its own way of welcoming you, and each house becomes your home.
Mnemonic1: Each person under my roof is treated as a guest.
Mnemonic2: In my house I welcome each guest.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　各: each; every
Ex1English: Visitor, guest; customer, client; spectator; passenger; outsider

Origin: Wooden leg . . . each.
Mnemonic1: When pirates try to hide, it´s always easy to find them. Their wooden legs leave distinctive prints, showing where each is hiding and the exact path he took.
Mnemonic2: I have a wooden leg for each type of path. One with a rubber stopper at the end for absorbing shocks on paved paths, and one with a wide foot to distribute weight better on mud paths.
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　各: each; every

Origin: If you can imagine trees as status symbols (as they might well be for those living in Japan's congested cities, where greenery has become something of a luxury item), then each might be aiming to have his/her own tree, just to keep up with the Suzukis.
Mnemonic1: Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree. "Errr, Each tree sir?" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. "That´s Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!".
Mnemonic2: A man measures his own status by the size of his woody...and compares it to each one he sees.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　各: each; every

Origin: Thread . . . each.
Mnemonic1: When threads become entwined, each thread is tangled to another.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman entwines each villain in a tangled mess of spidersilk.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　各: each; every
Kunyomi: から.む, から.める, から.まる

Origin: Each field has its own abbreviations (chemistry, philosophy, sports, etc.). Needless to say, the "stronger" primitive - thatis to say, the simpler and more often used one - takes the dominant position on the left, even though the story would read them off the other way around.
Mnemonic1: There are so many abbreviations and acronyms nowadays that no brain can remember each of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation.
Mnemonic2: A very anal farmer wants to catologue each grain of rice in his rice field. Imagine him scribbling a tiny abbreviation of his name and a number on each grain.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　各: each; every

Origin: Gates . . . each.
Mnemonic1: To keep this distinct from other kanji such as "watchtower" and "pagoda", I use the mnemonic "towering tower". -- In some old 8-bit kung-fu videogame, with a plot similar as Bruce Lee´s last, unfinished movie, the hero must break through a gate at each level of the towering tower, fighting with opponents using various styles of kung-fu until he meets the finale at the topmost level of the "towering tower".
Mnemonic2: Remember the two towers from lord of the rings... each has it´s own - very difficult to master - entrance gate.
Compo: 門: gate　各: each; every

Origin: When water falls, it splats and splashes; when flower petals fall, they float gently in the breeze. To each thing its own way of falling.
Mnemonic1: Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.
Mnemonic2: (It´s been suggested on the forum (http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079) that flower across the full width of the kanji and water on the left below it should have its own keyword; seaweed is a popular choice. See also dilute (#227), clan (#1912), seaweed (#2035). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers falling through the sky -- suddenly each one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori seaweed to carry them safely down.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　水: water (氵) (氺))　各: each; every
Kunyomi: お.ちる, お.ち, お.とす

Origin: Belt . . . happiness. Note how the belt runs through the middle of happiness.
Mnemonic1: South of my belt leads to happiness.
Mnemonic2: In the south (Southern Alabama, Southern Africa, picture any south, but choose one and stick with it) "they measure happyness by the belt". If someone has a larger belly (and a longer belt), it is believed they are well fed and thus are happy.
Compo: 冂: hood; belt (RTK)　幸: happiness

Origin: To our way of counting directions, the west always comes fourth. So it is convenient to find the character for four in this kanji. But since we want only one of the four directions, the west adds the one at the top and sucks the human legs a bit out of their mouth in the process.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the meaning of west can be expanded to refer to the Old West of cowboy-movie fame, just as the meaning of the character for east was expanded into the East. Note, however, that in its primitive form the legs are straightened out and reach down to the bottom of the mouth. Hence, we get the shape ⻃. With the exception of one kanji, given in the following frame, this element always appears at the top of its relative primitives.
Mnemonic1: The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare sign of the bird (#1427) whiskey bottle about one third full).
Mnemonic2: Note: this kanji is also used to denote Spain.
Compo: 西: west (覀)
Ex1English: West side; west european countries and america

Origin: Though we shall later encounter the kanji for bird, we introduce this one for the tenth sign of the zodiac mainly because of its use as a primitive, where it has a different meaning.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, it means whiskey bottle. In its pictograph, you can see the loosely corked lid, the bottle and the contents (about one-third full). You might also think of the Spanish "porrón," a decanter shaped like a long-necked bird.
Mnemonic1: The sign of the bird on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.
Mnemonic2: Normally birds fly south, but one bird flew west. People were worried about it and kept asking "Is there any sign of the bird – you know, the one that flew west?".
Compo: 西: west (覀)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . whiskey bottle.
Mnemonic1: Sake is just watered down whisky.
Mnemonic2: Sake is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is whiskey and water.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　酉: alcohol
Ex2English: Sake; alcoholic drink, wine, liquor, beer

Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　西: west (覀)

Origin: Whisky bottle . . . snake.
Mnemonic1: To DISTRIBUTE WHISKY during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a SNAKE.
Mnemonic2: I imagine a bartender serving whiskey to his patrons, and using that snake-like sprayer to distribute soda water into each glass.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　已: oneself; snake (RTK)

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . license . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: The prostitute carries an old whiskey bottle filled with acid to throw at any difficult Johns.
Mnemonic2: Dealing alcohol requires a license, dealing acid requires fast legs (to run from the police).
Compo: 酉: alcohol　允: license　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)

Origin: Wild dogs . . . animal horns . . . whiskey bottle.
Mnemonic1: The waver for this kanji means to hesitate. I wavered before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.
Mnemonic2: I wavered when the pack of wild dogs was blocking the way, but then I drank some Red Bull and charged through. (thanks shakkun).
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　丷: animal horns (RTK)　酉: alcohol

Origin: Animal horns . . . whiskey bottle . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: People don't know this, but ("revered" patriot) Paul Revere had trouble staying awake during his midnight ride, so he drank Red Bull (horns) and whiskey (a drink invented by his friend Sam Adams) and glued himself DOWN to the saddle. (thanks to akahige].
Mnemonic2: Red Bull, the chieftain (#2906) is so revered in his clan that everyone sticks to him like glue.
Compo: 丷: animal horns (RTK)　酉: alcohol　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)
Kunyomi: たっと.い, とうと.い, たっと.ぶ, とうと.ぶ

Mnemonic1: You must abide by the revered rules of the road! No devil´s brew and stay glued to your lane in the road!
Mnemonic2: Even the most revered person must still abide by the rules of the road -- no exceptions are granted to anyone.
Compo: 尊: honor　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: When we accept someone's guidance, we permit ourselves to be glued to a certain road or way of doing something, and try to "stick" to it.
Mnemonic1: For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car.
Mnemonic2: Good guidance will help you stay glued to the right path.
Compo: 道: road-way　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Standing in awe of someone, you get self-conscious and may try to speak in flowery phrases out of veneration or fear. The taskmaster at the right is drilling you in the practice of your "honorifics."
Mnemonic1: The flowery phrases of the schoolmaster held the students in awe.
Mnemonic2: 敬 【けい】 (n) reverence; respect. 敬語 【けいご】 (n) honorific; term of respect; (P) STORY: The TASKMASTER demands RESPECT. If you don´t talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　句: phrase　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Here you have a perfect example of how an apparently impossible snarl of strokes becomes a snap to learn once you know its elements. The idea of being admonished for something already sets up a superior-inferior relationship between you and the person you are supposed to stand in awe of. While you are restricted to answering in honorifics, the superior can use straightforward and ordinary words.
Mnemonic1: To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words.
Mnemonic2: Watch in awe as mom admonishes the rude clerk with words that you´ve never heard her use before.
Compo: 敬: awe　言: word; say

Origin: Awe . . . team of horses.
Mnemonic1: You stand in AWE at the 8th WONDER of the world, a huge TROJAN HORSE.
Mnemonic2: This is another word for surprise. 驚く＝おどろく= surprise. The Trojans stood in awe of the magnificent Trojan Horse that they thought was a gift. But imagine their surprise (wonder) when a bunch of Greeks came rushing out of it! (To further cement the connection between the primitives, if needed: It´s a wonder that the Trojans managed to speak keigo 敬語 even then, saying "わたくしたちを殺さないでください!!お願い致します!!").
Compo: 敬: awe　馬: horse
Kunyomi: おどろ.く, おどろ.かす

Origin: Salad . . . flesh . . taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: The taskmaster is dissatisfied with the meal she´s served, and scatters the salad & meat across the floor for the servants to clean up.
Mnemonic2: Perhaps you´ve heard of Nyotaimori or Nantaimori (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyotaimori) in which sushi is ate from the flesh of a naked person, the story comes easily. Scatter salad over the flesh of the taskmaster in preperation for some nantaimori :).
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　月: moon; month　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Kunyomi: ち.る, ち.らす, -ち.らす, ち.らかす, ち.らかる, ち.らばる

Origin: Spike . . . ear . . . taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: Only a truly daring Japanese student would wear a spike in his ear under the gaze of the Japanese teacher taskmasters!
Mnemonic2: See that ear nailed over there ? It´s the ear of the last person who was too daring with the taskmistress.
Compo: 丅: under; spike (RTK)　耳: ear　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Ex3English: As a temporary measure, for now

Origin: Owl . . . cliff . . . daring.
Mnemonic1: This represents a stern looking owl, perched up on a cliff. This cliff is quite famous for daring individuals to cliff dive off of, but is any of them daring enough to threaten the owl?
Mnemonic2: The daring mouse gets a stern look after he climbs onto the owl´s cliff…
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　厂: cliff　敢: daring
Kunyomi: おごそ.か, きび.しい

Origin: Person . . . elbow.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T says, "I ain´t afraid o´ no foo! I´ll give anyone an elbow to the face, I don´t care if it´s Buddha himself!".
Mnemonic2: Buddha is a person who always seems to have his elbows bent.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: Finger . . . elbow.
Mnemonic1: You´re at a restaurant and raise your finger to indicate to the waiter that you want to pay. Your friend elbows you in the ribs -- it´s his shout, and he insists on taking care of the bill.
Mnemonic2: You are walking out of the restaurant when the waiter uses his FINGERS to grab you at the ELBOW and says, "excuse me sir, didn´t you forget to PAY?".
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . wide. The connection with the previous character is very close. Beware.
Mnemonic1: Japanese girls are tight and may require fingers inserted to broaden them and make them wide enough before you can...
Mnemonic2: Spread your fingers wide to broaden your hand.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　広: wide

Origin: Remember the story about the "Little Engine that Could" when you hear this key word, and the rest is simple. See the determined little locomotive huffing and puffing up the mountain - "I think I can, I think I can...." - spitting railroad spikes out of its mouth as it chews up the line to the top.
Mnemonic1: A mouth on the street asking for things: "Can I get some help?! Can I get directions, Can I have some money? Can you please speak English?!".
Mnemonic2: I can eat nails.
Compo: 丁: street; nail (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Person . . . can.
Mnemonic1: What can Mr T do? ´You mean: what can´t MR T do, you fool´.
Mnemonic2: What can´t Mr. T not do?
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　可: can
Kunyomi: なに, なん, なに-, なん-

Origin: A nosegay of flowers make a nice gift, but if those flowers are poison oak, they can amount to bullying. Be sure to emphasize the word can when you repeat this little phrase to yourself.
Mnemonic1: How many flowers can I stuff in your nostrils? Well I´m just gonna have to go and see. Bullying at its worst!
Mnemonic2: Flowers, you ask if they can feel pain, do you? ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ They sure -can-!! ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^!!
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　可: can
Kunyomi: いじ.め*, いじ.める*, いら*, さいな.む*

Origin: Flowers . . . what.
Mnemonic1: TSA guard: What´s in the baggage?! It´s just flowers, I swear!
Mnemonic2: Your girlfriend arrives at the airport. You give her flowers, but she brushes you off and says "here, carry my BAGGAGE." Dumbfounded at her rudeness, you say, "what?".
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　何: what

Origin: The character in this frame represents a step up from the stream we met in Frame 134; it is a full-sized river. The water to the left tells us what we are dealing with, and the can at the right tells us that our "little engine that could" has now become amphibious and is chugging down the Mighty Mississip' like a regular riverboat.
Mnemonic1: A river CAN exist only if there is WATER.
Mnemonic2: I kept confusing this with stream. My Japanese friend said that to him this is for an artificial river. Looking at kanji compounds with this there are two that struck me: One is the Yellow River in China (黄河), and the other is the Milky Way (銀河). Now I either think of the Little Engine that could dragging a bunch of stuff down a river in China and polluting it (so it turned yellow) or I see the Little Engine that Could flying across the sky making the Milky Way.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　可: can

Origin: This kanji, an abbreviation for Africa, is now used chiefly for its sound, "a," not unlike the kanji for Italy and the sound "i" that we met earlier (Frame 1245). Its composite elements are: pinnacles . . . can.
Mnemonic1: Can you see Africa from The Pinnacle? I can! I can!
Mnemonic2: A kinda pictogram: ´BoT´, the first 3 letters in ´Botswana´ an African country.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　可: can

Origin: Clothes hanger . . . one . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: The porn director has one big mouth. "Don´t bother putting your clothes on a hanger, just get started.".
Mnemonic2: The director sticks a clothes hanger in each actor´s mouth and hangs them from the ceiling until he needs them.
Compo: ヿ: enclosure; clothes hanger (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: This honorific form of call on (Frame 534) is made up of: person . . . director.
Mnemonic1: That person, being the director, is someone you need to pay your respects to.
Mnemonic2: If Mr. T gets a role in a film, he doesnt pay respects to the director, the director pays respects to Mr. T.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　司: director
Ex1English: Inquire (about), be told; pay a visit
Ex2English: Question, inquiry; consulting the oracle; call, visit

Origin: The key word, parts of speech, refers to nouns, verbs, adjective, adverbs, and so on. The elements: words . . . directors.
Mnemonic1: Parts of speech act as word directors, giving it meaning and indicating its correct placement and usage in grammar.
Mnemonic2: The big mouthed diretor is even picky about the parts of speech you use, shouting, "More verbs! Less adjectives!" and such all the time.
Compo: 言: word; say　司: director

Origin: Eat . . . director. The sense is of rearing of animals.
Mnemonic1: When you DOMESTICATE a animal, you are the DIRECTOR of it´s life and what it EATS.
Mnemonic2: After a pride of hungry lions ate the director, the producer decided to tone down his documentary and film domesticated cats instead.
Compo: 食: eat; food　司: director

Origin: This key word is a counter for books. It differs from scrapbook both in the writing order and in the extension of the second horizontal stroke.
Mnemonic1: Pictograph. I think of that Harry Potter spell book that had to be bound shut coz it wanted to eat you.
Mnemonic2: 冊 さつ 1: counter for books A heavy scrapbook so full that flowers are sticking out. Only if a scrapbook is that full, it can be called a heavy book.
Compo: 冊: counter for books; scrapbook (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . scrapbook . . . director.
Mnemonic1: The lawyer called all the heirs into a meeting. Everybody else received cars, property, and the like. When it got to be my turn the lawyer informed me I would be receiving a scrapbook. My mouth dropped open. A scrapbook?! No Ferrari, no mansion, ...scrapbook?! Turns out the scrapbook was of my great uncle's company, and I had been named the new director of the multi-million dollar business. My mouth literally hit the scrapbook when I learned I'd be director.
Mnemonic2: My mouth hung open when I found out I was the heir to not only my father's scrapbooks, but he also left me as director of the company.
Compo: 口: mouth　冊: counter for books; scrapbook (RTK)　司: director
司: director　見: see
Ex1English: Peek, look into; stick out, peek through

Origin: The song in this kanji is being sung by a chorus line of can-can girls. Why it should be eliciting nothing but yawning from the audience, I leave to you to decide.
Mnemonic1: Can-Can-ers lack the ability to sing a song, so they just dance.
Mnemonic2: Can-can dancers are supposed to be big-bosomed girls who dance. Yet these so called can-can dancers are flat-chested and singing a song, so audience of men is yawning in boredom.
Compo: 可: can　可: can　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)

Origin: There is a lot of money to be made of one's songs are "popular." This is depicted here as a stream of clams spewing out of the mouth of someone performing a pop song.
Mnemonic1: The new generation of pop songs have no depth. They just mouth empty lyrics to get money. Not like the pop songs of my day.
Mnemonic2: A new way for sluts to use their mouths to make alot of money.
Compo: 口: mouth　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Above we have the condensed form of bound up, and below the familiar shellfish. Now imagine two oysters engaged in shell-to-shell combat, the one who is defeated being bound and gagged with seaweed, the victor towering triumphantly over it. The bound shellfish thus becomes the symbol for defeat.
Mnemonic1: Tied up, the shellfish had to accept defeat!
Mnemonic2: Defeat is defined by a shellfish in binds.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)
Kunyomi: ま.ける, ま.かす, お.う
Ex1English: Bear on the back; take upon oneself

Origin: The taskmaster is acknowledging the failure of a clam to make the grade in some marine school or other.
Mnemonic1: If you end up in failure, you give money to the taskmaster to train you.
Mnemonic2: The shell who was defeated before (defeat (#63)) is being chastised by the taskmaster for his failure to win.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Grow up . . . oyster.
Mnemonic1: As one grows up, one typically starts to blame all of their problems on money.
Mnemonic2: This is the story of a poor fisherman and his wife. A long time ago he caught an oyster with a small but precious pearl. The intelligent wife told him to sell the pearl immediately: the greedy husband figured if he kept the oyster and fed it, it would grow up and yield an even bigger pearl. One day the oyster grew so big, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, blaming his blind greed for their poverty.
Compo: 龶: grow up, master (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . blame. This key word has to do with measurement, and should be kept distinct from the kanji for quantity (Frame 189) - even though the meanings are similar.
Mnemonic1: On many wheat cereal boxes, there is a disclaimer stating that "This package is sold by weight, not by volume. Some settling of contents may have occurred." well they only say that because they don´t want to be blamed by people getting really disappointed after they see what a small volume of cereal the box really contains.
Mnemonic2: The volume of the wheat crop is way down this year! Blame the weather!
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　責: blame
Kunyomi: つ.む, -ずみ, つ.もる, つ.もり

Origin: Person . . . blame. The key word refers to financial bonds.
Mnemonic1: Bonds are guarnteed by the government so if they fail there is one person you can blame - the prime minister!
Mnemonic2: Mr. T´s plot of world domination is foiled. Who is to blame? Bond. James Bond.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　責: blame

Origin: Water . . . blame.
Mnemonic1: When pickling you MUST use distilled water! When it doesn´t come out right, generally it is the water that is to blame.
Mnemonic2: Bad water is to blame for the process of pickling.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　責: blame
Kunyomi: つ.ける, つ.かる, -ず.け, -ずけ

Origin: For the kanji that means the spinning of thread and other fibers we have the elements: thread . . . compass.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman can spin his webs in any direction.
Mnemonic2: You keep me spinning right round, baby right round, like a compass baby. Spidey is making a retro 80s music video, spinning right round on his giant compass, singing his favourite song.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　方: direction; compass (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . blame.
Mnemonic1: Spidey´s exploits are world famous but still The Daily Bugle´s pages blame him for every problem out there.
Mnemonic2: (Geek alert] A lot of modern software is full of exploits which can be abused by hackers. I blame multi-threading.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　責: blame

Origin: Here is the full kanji on which the last frame is based. If you can think of a table full of carpenter's tools of all sorts, each equipped with its own eye so that it can keep a watch over what you are doing with it, you won't have trouble later keeping the primitive and the kanji apart.
Mnemonic1: Keep an eye on your tools while you work at the table.
Mnemonic2: One tool nobody should be without - a Mordor-type eye that floats over the workbench. It jerks around, monitoring all who come near, and if anyone so much as removes a stapler from the bench - ZAP.
Compo: 目: eye　丌: table

Origin: Here again we meet the composite element, eye of the needle, which here combines with tool to give us a measure of what is true and what is not.
Mnemonic1: A compass is a tool with a needle on top that points to true north.
Mnemonic2: Ten tools are all a true craftsman needs.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　具: tool

English: Straight, Direct, Upright, Put Straight, Correct
Origin: Begin with the top two primitives, needle and eye. Together they represent the eye of a needle. Below them is a fishhook that has been straightened out and its barb removed so that it can pass through the eye of the needle.
Mnemonic1: If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital straightaway.
Mnemonic2: I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back straightaway.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　目: eye
Onyomi: チョク, ジキ, ジカ*
Kunyomi: ただ.ちに, なお.す, -なお.す, なお.る, す.ぐ*

Origin: You have no doubt seen how people practicing the Japanese art of bonsai take those helpless little saplings and twist them into crippled dwarves before they have a chance to grow up as they should. The more proper way to plant a young tree and give it a fair shake in life is to set it into the earth in such a way that it can grow up straight.
Mnemonic1: Plants don´t become trees straightaway.
Mnemonic2: When you plant plants, you use a piece of WOOD to make the plant grow STRAIGHT.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　直: straightaway

Origin: Bones . . . straightaway.
Mnemonic1: Advertisement for Breast Implants -- Tired of nights all alone? Want to get boned straightaway? AUGMENT your breasts and all your troubles will be solved!
Mnemonic2: In the movie “Gattaca”, Vincent Freeman (played by Ethan Hawke) augments his size by straightening his bones (his legs), in order to match up with the genetically “perfect” population, and reach his goal of travelling in space. The stretching of his lower leg bones involved multiplying the bone cells, another sense of this key word.
Compo: 歹: bones　直: straightaway
Ex3English: Increase of production; enhancement of one's fortune

Origin: Person . . . straightaway.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T (person) tells the used car salesman to tell him the real price straight away, and when he doesn´t he throws him through the windshield.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T is shopping for new chains. He knows what he wants and money isn´t an issue. "Cut the jibba-jabba, tell me the price, straightaway!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　直: straightaway

English: Place, Put In Place; Leave In Place
Origin: Eye . . . straightaway.
Mnemonic1: On the JET Programme, many people have their eye on a placement in Tokyo, Osaka or another big city, and write it on their application form. They are usually sent to the countryside straightaway.
Mnemonic2: Working in retail you learn the placement of any item should be at eye level so it´s seen straightaway.
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　直: straightaway

Origin: Above, an eye and a fishhook, and below the primitive for little. Although apparently the simplest of these first six kanji, when you begin to work on its plot and story you will soon find out that the number of strokes and visual complexity of a kanji does not make it easier or harder to remember. It is the primitives you have to work that are the critical factor, as in this case where the meaning of the key word is so seemingly distant from the elements. Remember, you can always break larger elements down (eye of a needle into eye and fishhook) if you think it helps.
Mnemonic1: In Japanese this is KEN, as in Barbie´s boyfriend. He has lovely blue eyes, a girlfriend who is as thin as a straightened out fish hook. But, down where it counts, he has very little to show...
Mnemonic2: After sticking a fishhook in your eye, the yakuza boss probably has little more to do to convince you to move to a different prefecture.
Compo: 目: eye　L: shelf; fishhook　小: little; owl (RTK)

Origin: Here we see drops of land (little islets) rising up out of a stream, creating a kind of sandbar or breakwater. Ever wonder how the state-line is drawn between states separated by a river? If there were little drops of land as in the kanji, there'd be nothing to it.
Mnemonic1: There were 3 little islands in the stream who all decided to set themselves up as independent states.
Mnemonic2: シュウ The original meaning of this character was "sandbar", and for me this conjures up images of the Mississippi River, which is very wide with many sandbars and which was used to define the borders in ten American states. Picture Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer floating by state after state as they adventure down the mighty Mississippi, occasionally beaching their raft on sandbars.
Compo: 巛: river (川); flood (RTK)　丶: dot; drop　丶: dot; drop　丶: dot; drop
水: water (氵) (氺)　州: state; province

Origin: Fingers . . . vase . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: A pervert meets a woman. The pervert tries to touch the women with his lustful fingers. The woman takes a vase, lifts it over her head and smashes it on the pervert´s head...
Mnemonic2: CHIKAN!! These are the perverts who use their fingers to touch standing women on crowded trains.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)　女: woman

Origin: Thread . . . rice . . . fishhook. Compare frame 1218.
Mnemonic1: A poor chinese fisherman could expect to inherit: the thread for his pole, a hook for catching something to eat, and some rice to live off of. (not concentrating on stroke order, sorry if that throws anyone off). (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006).
Mnemonic2: Spider-Man is hooked on rice--it´s all he inherited from his Uncle Ben. (thanks Nukemarine).
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　米: rice　L: shelf; fishhook

Origin: Fishhook . . . rice . . . ax.
Mnemonic1: (Based on fuaburisu´s] A man puts some rice on a fishhook as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his axe and sever the line lest he be dragged into the depths.
Mnemonic2: When you get the ax at work, use your severance pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.
Compo: 米: rice　L: shelf; fishhook　斤: axe
Ex3English: Refuse, reject; give advance notice, inform

Origin: Cave . . . heart. The sense of the key word here is of something appropriate that fills a particular need, and hence "applies."
Mnemonic1: In the videogame Zelda, Link enters a CAVE to visit a fairy that will APPLY magic to fill his HEART containers.
Mnemonic2: (bravo, scottamus!] To apply for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the heart of the cave past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say "Those who don´t make it to the heart of the cave need not apply.".
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Ex1English: Correspond to, answer to; be equivalent; deal (cope] with
Ex4English: Respond to, act in accordance with; be suitable

Origin: Cave . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So these can be considered as beds.
Mnemonic2: (based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a bed.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Cave . . . grove. If it helps, this is the hemp marijuana comes from.
Mnemonic1: (Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin´ a huge doob in a secret corner of the Batcave where he nurtures his hemp grove).
Mnemonic2: Where is the best place to hid your grove of hemp trees? In a cave, you dope!
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　林: grove; forest

Origin: That same grove of trees we met in frame 226 shows up here in the character for curriculum (in the sense of a record of one's life or academic achievements, the curriculum vitae). Instead of the grove making its way slowly through the surface of the cliff as before, here we see it stopped, much the same as a curriculum vitae calls a halt to the calendar and talks only about the past.
Mnemonic1: A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun.
Mnemonic2: A little like a calendar, your CV records your footsteps through time.
Compo: 厂: cliff　林: grove; forest　止: stop; footprint (RTK)

Origin: Look at this character in reverse order, from bottom up. First we see the primitive for days, an appropriate enough way to begin a calendar. Next we see a grove of trees growing under a cliff. The laws of nature being what they are, the trees would be stunted under such conditions, unless they were strong enough to keep growing upwards until they passed through the layers of rock and soil, right up to the surface. Now imagine that in those little boxes marking off the days on your wall calendar, you see that very process taking place step by step: 365 or so time-lapse pictures of that grove of trees each month, from January under the cliff to December on top of the cliff. The story is not as complex as it sounds, particularly if you happen to have a calendar nearby and can flip through it with this image in mind.
Mnemonic1: Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR.
Mnemonic2: This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page.
Compo: 厂: cliff　林: grove; forest　日: day; sun

Origin: Slave . . . reclining . . . goods. The key word suggests both looking ahead to something and "seeing to" what is at hand. Consistent with everything we have learned about the role of the key word, this means that you must choose ONE meaning and stick to it.
Mnemonic1: The slave is look to the future, "One day" he thinks "I will be able to recline with all my goods, a tv, stereo and washing machine, and when that day comes I shall be truly happy" he sighs.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a slave(or in this case, a female porn star) looking to her new gangbang film where she reclines and gets all 3 holes filled at the same...........OK. Very vulgar, but I was inspired by raulir´s clever use of "3 holes".........
Compo: 臣: subject; slave (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　品: goods
Ex1English: Attend, be present at; face, look out over

Origin: Pent in . . . lidded crock . . . scarf.
Mnemonic1: A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket).
Mnemonic2: There was a homeless man living in a box at the park so I gave him a lidded crock filled with hot curry tied with a scarf...
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　袁: long kimono

Origin: A distant figure on the road is such a blur it looks like a lidded crock wearing a silk scarf.
Mnemonic1: Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb.
Mnemonic2: When traveling to a distant land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?
Compo: 袁: long kimono　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Slingshot . . . one. Later we shall learn the character for give (Frame 2046), but even so, it is a good idea already at this point to distinguish this key word from impart (Frame 795) and grant (Frame 1131).
Mnemonic1: David went to battle with a slingshot and it only took him one shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to bestow upon David the throne of all Israel.
Mnemonic2: In The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, one of the first weapons bestowed on Link was the slingshot.
Compo: 与: give; bestow
Ex3English: Take part in, participate in, be concerned in

Origin: Crown . . . bestow.
Mnemonic1: A crown was bestowed to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy.
Mnemonic2: True fact: in the UK the right to print a copy of the KJV Bible is bestowed by the crown -- there are only a few authorised bible printers. (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Bible#Copyright_status).
Compo: 冖: crown 　与: give; bestow
Ex1English: Be photographed, appear in a photograph

Origin: Wheat . . . many.
Mnemonic1: Picture the WHEAT field, filled with MANY, MANY stalks of WHEAT. Notice how they SHIFT like waves in the slightest breeze. When you hear SHIFT, just picture that scene.
Mnemonic2: Many people are making the shift from white to whole wheat bread.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　多: many

Origin: The left primitive is a union of a horse and footprint. To the right, the stamp.
Mnemonic1: Wholesale refers to the sale of goods in quantity to retailers for resale. When this kanji was invented, large loads of goods needed to be transported by horses who left steep footprints because of the weight they carried. The wholesale goods needed a special stamp to indicate that they were legal for resale.
Mnemonic2: If you need horseshoes (shoes that fit your horse´s footprint), buy them at the wholesale shop. They lick and paste stamps in your membership card so you can get free merchandise later.
Compo: 午: noon　止: stop; footprint (RTK)　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)
Kunyomi: おろ.す, おろし, おろ.し

Origin: Line . . . wholesale.
Mnemonic1: An honorable man will not try to cut in front of the line at the wholesale stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!).
Mnemonic2: If a trader has an honorable reputation- then people will line up to buy his wholesale goods.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　卸: wholesale

Origin: In its original and etymologically transparent sense, to duplicate something means to double it back with a fold, like the fold of a cloak.
Mnemonic1: My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!
Mnemonic2: In Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Hermione uses a device called a "time-turner" to double back in time, but this creates duplicates. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione´s time-turner with Harry´s invisibility cloak. That way, one could double back in time without creating any visible duplicates.
Compo: 衤: cloak (RTK)　复: repeat; double back (RTK)

Origin: If you double back (fold over) most animals - or people, for that matter - in the middle, the part of the body where the crease comes is the abdomen.
Mnemonic1: The only body part that doubles over.
Mnemonic2: Imagine getting punched in the abdomen, a fairly tender part of flesh, and instead of doubling forward, you double back. That would be pretty painful.
Compo: 月: moon; month　复: repeat; double back (RTK)

Origin: Going . . . double back.
Mnemonic1: Before going all the way to the Boss in a Final Fantasy game, you should probably double back to save at a restore point.
Mnemonic2: The column of soldiers has to double back to restore the peace in the village they just left.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　复: repeat; double back (RTK)

Origin: Column . . . candlestick. This character has the special sense of journeying to someplace or other.
Mnemonic1: In Medieval Japan, going to see your lord was often a long journey.
Mnemonic2: The fellowship of the ring is on a long journey through the depths of Khaz Modan. Imagine they walk through the hall of pillars, with only light being from their own candlesticks that. Soon they will meet much more light than they would ever want to...
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　主: lord; candlestick (RTK)

Origin: The pillar referred to here is the wooden beam that stands at the entrance to a traditional Japanese house. Carve it in imagination into the shape of a gigantic candlestick and your work is done.
Mnemonic1: The main pillar in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the lord of the trees.
Mnemonic2: Why has this pillar been carved in the shape of a giant penis?! "You said that ´it should be made of wood´, My Lord.".
Compo: 木: tree; wood　主: lord; candlestick (RTK)

Origin: Column . . . correct.
Mnemonic1: America seeks to GO and CORRECT other nations. But really what they do is subjugate them...
Mnemonic2: To subjugate is to have somebody stand still and stiff as a column and behave one hundred percent correctly.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　正: correct; justice

Origin: Column . . . animal horns . . . mending.
Mnemonic1: The line of viking soldiers is always accompanied by a horn mending specialist.
Mnemonic2: I´m going to accompany the horny girl to her room so I can "mend" her.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　丷: animal horns (RTK)　疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)
Onyomi: ジュウ, ショウ, ジュ
Kunyomi: したが.う, したが.える
Ex3English: In accordance with...; in proportion to...

English: Follower, Pupil, Fellow(S), Going On Foot
Origin: Line . . . run.
Mnemonic1: Junior is GOING to RUN the family business one day...
Mnemonic2: The junior employee is always RUNNING around GOING here and there for his superiors.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　走: run

Origin: Thread . . . accompany.
Mnemonic1: When Spider-man does his amazing vertical wall climbing, a throng of photographers accompanies him to get a good shot of the action.
Mnemonic2: True vertical can be found by hanging a plumb line - a thread accompanied by a weight.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　従: accompany

Origin: This character is a kind of pictographic image of how prolonging is a clever way of stopping things by trying to stretch them out a little bit at a time (the extra drop at the top of stop). Be sure to get a concrete image of this process, by imagining yourself prolonging something you can really, physically, stretch.
Mnemonic1: Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching...
Mnemonic2: Here´s a great mnemonic: "stop, drop, and stretch (!?)." Now let´s associate it with ´prolong´: if you´re ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just PROLONG the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it´ll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!
Compo: 正: correct; justice　廴: stretch
Kunyomi: の.びる, の.べる, の.べ, の.ばす

Origin: Person . . . monkey.
Mnemonic1: Here we see Mr. T. expanding his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.
Mnemonic2: A person expands into an ape man. I swear this is the only time I'll use Dragon Ball, but think of Goku expanding into that Saiyajin giant ape beast.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　申: monkey (RTK)
Kunyomi: の.びる, の.ばす, の.べる

Origin: Thread . . . monkey.
Mnemonic1: Monkeys are very adept at swinging around trees. But when they met Spiderman, who could swing around even better than they could, they all quickly addressed him as sire.
Mnemonic2: From the fairy tale ‘emperor’s new clothes.’ sire, i know you say it's made of the finest threads, but i’m afraid someone has made a monkey of you.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　申: monkey (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . inn.
Mnemonic1: After spending the night at an inn, spider man discovered to his dismay that his costume had shrunk in the wash, and no longer fit!
Mnemonic2: Don´t let the Inn wash your threads, they will shrink them!
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　宿: inn
Kunyomi: ちじ.む, ちじ.まる, ちじ.める, ちじ.れる, ちじ.らす

Origin: The key word of course calls to mind the feast of Christmas. As the famous poem at the start of St. John's gospel tells us, the nativity we celebrate at Christmas had its origins at the very start of time and governs all of human history: it represents the prolongation of the eternal Word in time and space.
Mnemonic1: Nativity = born, being born. Think of birth as a painful and prolonged event. And of course, all the words and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her!
Mnemonic2: When you are being born ( nativity ), your mother´s WORDS are PROLONGED. (Thiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiis huuuuuuuuuuuuuurtss a lottttttttt~!! Owwwwwww!!!).
Compo: 言: word; say　延: prolong

Origin: Those who rule the courts, the porters of justice and order, are often found to stretch the law to suit their own purposes. Recall the kanji for prolong from frame 419 and keep it distinct.
Mnemonic1: A porter has run away from his master. His punishment is to be stretched out on the rack. So say the courts in this barbaric time.
Mnemonic2: The gentleman stretched the truth a bit in court.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　士: gentleman; samurai　廴: stretch

Origin: Cave . . . courts.
Mnemonic1: When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the courtyard.
Mnemonic2: Back in caveman days, courts were held in caves. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the courtyard (the yard outside the cave court ) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　廷: courts

Origin: Boat . . . courts.
Mnemonic1: Rowboats are a classic way to court (go on a date with) someone...
Mnemonic2: Courts in olden times would often punish convicts by sentencing them to a life of being the rower crew for large rowboat ships (there were no engines or boilers back then)... Yo ho, Yo ho....
Compo: 舟: boat　廷: courts

Origin: Flag . . . salad . . . hairpin.
Mnemonic1: Unfold flag, take out the salad, pin the flag down with hairpins and have a picnic.
Mnemonic2: You use an American flag to wrap up a salad for a picnic and bind it with a hairpin. Now imagine unfolding it to open up the bounty you´ve fixed up for yourself.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Flags . . . strung together . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: Mr. President in his palace, ordering missiles to be fired at a harmless enemy in order to unite us together under the flag.
Mnemonic2: Mr. President! We all stand here together under a national flag. One thing is certain: we´ll never give in. We are launching nuclear missiles now to implement mutually assured destruction protocol.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　共: together　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Brains . . . together.
Mnemonic1: Brains together with beauty is an uncommon combination.
Mnemonic2: It´s uncommon to find a pair of together twins who are connected at the brain! When such a set does turn up, they are inevitably showcased on TV.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　共: together

Origin: Feathers . . . uncommon.
Mnemonic1: The thing about feathers is that they usually cover the entire bird. A creature with feathers only on its wings would be very uncommon.
Mnemonic2: WINGS without any FEATHERS would be an UNCOMMON site. Well, unless you like to eat chicken WINGS alot.
Compo: 羽: feathers; wings　異: uncommon

Origin: Rice field . . . threads. Make use of the position of the elements to distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame.
Mnemonic1: When you accumulate knowledge in your brain, neural pathways are constructed. All those pathways end up like a huge ball of thread tangled together. The more knowledge you accumulate the more threads you throw into the mix!!
Mnemonic2: (dingomick) Venom is upset because Spidey is just that much brainier than he is! He chooses to accumulate as many brains as he can, snatching them out of people´s heads and storing them on top of his own, till there´s just one massive brain on top of his head!
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)

Origin: The kanji of this frame refers to the four bases that are placed at the corners of a baseball infield. The elements: field . . . sparkler . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: Playing baseball in a rice field with sparklers stuck into the ground to act as bases.
Mnemonic2: The traditional New Year´s baseball game in Japan is held at midnight in a rice field. They stick sparklers in the ground for the bases so they can be seen, and to be more festive.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: One . . . mouth . . . tucked under the arm.
Mnemonic1: One officer can change the course of history.
Mnemonic2: One officer, namely Napoleon, changed the course of history. (Thanks, ayoung24). Napoleon is also my primitive meaning.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　史: history

Origin: Person . . . officer.
Mnemonic1: Of course Mr. T will tell a police officer if he catches someone using drugs, foo!
Mnemonic2: Mr. T uses the officer as a punching bag.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　吏: officer
Kunyomi: つか.う, つか.い, -つか.い, -ずか.い

Origin: A mouth . . . tucked under the arm.
Mnemonic1: I sleep in history class with my mouth tucked under my arm.
Mnemonic2: History students usually going to school with a history book tucked under their arm. But now instead of a book, you have a small talking mouth that tell you about history. "When I was young, I used to walk 5 miles everyday.....".
Compo: 史: history

Origin: The implication behind the meaning of grow late is that things are changing in the same way that the day turns into night. The elements: ceiling . . . sun . . . tucked under the arm.
Mnemonic1: At nightbreak (#30) the sun rises above the floor, so it is logical that when it is growing late, the sun would rise to the ceiling. Time to pack up your things and take your belongings under your arm.
Mnemonic2: It´s starting to GROW LATE, so God will take the SUN, and TUCK IT UNDER HIS ARM, and walk away. In the morning, he´ll bring it back, so don´t worry.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)
Kunyomi: さら, さら.に, ふ.ける, ふ.かす

English: Convenient, Postal Delivery, Transportation Service, Flight, Excreta
Origin: Person . . . grow late. Hint: this kanji also means that unmentionable material that one disposes of when one goes to the "conveniences."
Mnemonic1: Mr. T loves the convenience of the new konbini. Not only does it stay open even if it grows late, they have brand new toilets, and a Post Office!
Mnemonic2: Mr. T takes a dump on the floor of a convenience store. Well, it was growing late and he couldn´t wait. He pities the fool who will have to clean it up!
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　更: grow late

Origin: Rocks . . . grow late.
Mnemonic1: A stiff drink on the ROCKs after it GROWS LATE is a way to unwind after a long day...
Mnemonic2: Stones are so stiff that even if you spent all day straining trying to change their shape, it would grow late far before you ever accomplished your task.
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　更: grow late

Origin: Try relating this kanji to that of the previous frame. For instance, you might imagine that the test of ability envisioned here is removing the bear from the oven fire.
Mnemonic1: This man may have the dis-ability of no flesh below the elbows, but he can eat with 2 spoons, on in each foot.
Mnemonic2: Kid from the Oracle´s place in the Matrix (whose head is shining like the moon) is holding a a spoon and making it bend using his special ability. When Neo asks to learn this ability the child replies, " Remember the truth Neo, there is no spoon." Neo Proceeds to the kitchen pondering these words of wisdom. The Child smiles mischeviously and pulls a second spoon hidden up his sleeve in the crook of his elbow. "That´s right Neo," the child laughs, "there is no spoon...there are two spoons!".
Compo: 厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　月: moon; month　匕: spoon　匕: spoon

Origin: Ability . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: This guy has an attitude problem – lots of ability, but his heart´s not in it.
Mnemonic2: Having a good attitude means believing in your heart that you have the ability to do anything - like memorizing more than 2000 kanji, for example.
Compo: 能: ability　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Elbow . . . meat . . . spoon ATOP spoon . . . oven fire.
Mnemonic1: Most don´t know it, but bears have the ability to walk on fire. They´re invincible creatures!
Mnemonic2: Note : I don´t know why James Heisig put "bear" ahead of "ability" (next frame), but I sugget to skip this, learn the next kanji ("ability") then go back here and use ability as a primitive.
Compo: 能: ability　火: fire (灬)

Mnemonic1: Hey, screw you! Don´t you look down on me! I have the ability to quit anytime I want!
Mnemonic2: My eye doesn´t seem to have the ability to quit staring at her…
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　能: ability

Origin: Eye . . . fiber.
Mnemonic1: Lots of girls in Japan wear gauze patches over one eye made of course white fibers. They think it is cute, and I must admit, I have come to think so too.
Mnemonic2: Rocky won the match but left with a nasty eye injury, and needs some gauze for it. I use a modified version of the Rocky theme song to remember this one -- "the eye and the fiber".
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　維: fiber

Origin: Here is the full character for cloud from which the primitive for a rising cloud derives. Clouds begin with vapors rising up in small clouds from the surface of the earth, and then gathering to make clouds that eventually dump their rain back on the earth.
Mnemonic1: Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops).
Mnemonic2: Every cloud is a potential rain cloud.
Compo: 雨: rain　云: say; rising cloud (RTK)

Origin: We refer to days when the sun is covered by the clouds as cloudy weather.
Mnemonic1: Cloudy weather is when a cloud blocks the sun (up above).
Mnemonic2: In cloudy weather, the sun is still there even if obscured by the clouds…
Compo: 日: day; sun　雲: cloud

Origin: Rain that undergoes a change so that it can be swept aside with a broom is snow.
Mnemonic1: SNOW isn´t all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures.
Mnemonic2: Rain just soaks into the soil. Snow has to be swept away with a broom…
Compo: 雨: rain　ヨ: broom (RTK)

Origin: The full rumble and roar and terror of thunder is best felt not with your head tucked under your pillow safe in bed, but out in an open rice field where you can get the real feel of the weather.
Mnemonic1: If it´s raining and you´re standing in the middle of a rice field, you´re sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal.
Mnemonic2: Thunder is a sure sign of rain coming. When you hear the thunder, you´ve got time to get out of the field before it starts raining.
Compo: 雨: rain　田: rice field; brain (RTK)

Origin: Rain . . . orders.
Mnemonic1: The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.
Mnemonic2: Despite the rain, the zero pilot flies on. He has kamikaze orders.
Compo: 雨: rain　令: orders

Origin: Weather . . . sign of the dragon.
Mnemonic1: An earthquake is a sign that a dragon is awakening after a heavy rain... It is angry for having been woken up and it makes the earth thunder and quake above it.
Mnemonic2: Instant mythology: When heavy rains disturb a dragon hiding under the earth, an earthquake may result.
Compo: 雨: rain　辰: sign of the dragon

Origin: Fingers . . . sign of the dragon.
Mnemonic1: Your mother shakes herfinger violently - no, no, no - no Mortal Kombat today!
Mnemonic2: If you're talking to someone and notice that theirfingers are starting to shake, it's often a sign of the dragon being behind you where the other person can see him coming.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　辰: sign of the dragon
Kunyomi: ふ.る, ぶ.る, ふ.り, -ぶ.り, ふ.るう, ふ.れる

Origin: This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for bound up and a person. Think of a mummy, and the key word will not be far behind.
Mnemonic1: Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり . Long time no see mummy! (A bound up person).
Mnemonic2: This is a picture of a person bowing "long time no see!".
Compo: 久: long time
貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　辰: sign of the dragon
Kunyomi: にぎ.わう, にぎ.やか

Origin: Since this supposedly pictographic representation of a hill looks like anything but, picture a row of axes driven into the ground up to their heads, and see if that doesn't present a more memorable image of hill - at least a riskier one sliding down!
Mnemonic1: Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the axe planted on top of a hill.
Mnemonic2: At Capitol Hill proposals get axed on the floor.
Compo: 丘: hill

Origin: Hill . . . animal legs.
Mnemonic1: Listen up soldiers! We´re going to take that hill. You are no longer men with human legs. You are voracious animals, with animal legs! Got it? Animal legs! Now take that hill!
Mnemonic2: The hill is so steep that you almost have to have animal legs to walk on it. However, the soldiers have no problem because they´ve been trained to march there.
Compo: 丘: hill　ハ: animal legs (RTK)

Origin: Think of the key word as referring to proper names of mountains, but do not confuse with mountain pass (Frame 835). The elements are: hill . . . mountain.
Mnemonic1: A point is a extra little hill at the top of a mountain. We´ll call it ´Fireman´s Point´.
Mnemonic2: This actually means a high mountain. So, to cater to the keyword, it´s surely obvious (ahem) that if something gets such a fine title as Point, it must be more magnificent than the average mountain. It´s as if there was a hill on top of an average mountain, adding to its height.
Compo: 丘: hill　山: mountain

Origin: Water . . . soldier.
Mnemonic1: Seacoast -> Coast Guard -> "water soldiers" lined up on the seacoast defending our shores.
Mnemonic2: Imagine Normandy after the strikes on the beach. The water of the entire seacoast dyed red with the blood of thousands of soldiers.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　兵: soldier

Origin: A lidded crock with an umbrella overhead gives us a mixture of the modern and the nostalgic in this design for a cottage.
Mnemonic1: The cottage is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth.
Mnemonic2: My vacation cottage is nothing but a hole in the ground covered by an umbrella.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　吉: good luck; lidded crock (RTK); aerosol can (RTK)

Origin: Jewel . . . with a belt hung on it. Note how the belt is drawn right after the first stroke of jewel.
Mnemonic1: The king has eaten too much and has to get a new belt again. See his fat rolls hanging over?
Mnemonic2: This is a belt with a non-adjustable jeweled buckle. Everytime you go back to the leathersmith telling him to move the buckle because you´ve packed on a few pounds (but that this is the last time!), he says "Again?!? Weren´t you just here last month?".
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: The kanji in this frame recalls the famous Bengali fable about the group of magicians (the magic wand) who decided to make a tiger. It seems that each of them knew how to make one part of the beast, so they pooled their talents and brought all the pieces (diced into pieces) together, at which point the fabricated tiger promptly ate its makers up (the bodiless human legs). Whatever the parable's significance for modern civilization and its arsenals, it should help with this kanji. Oh yes, we should not forget that cliff-like element. Think of it as an abbreviation of the primitive for zoo (the first and fourth strokes, actually), in order to fit the tiger somewhere into the picture. In fact, the abbreviation is perfectly logical, since the bottom elements usurp the room for the rest of the primitive for zoo.
SubOrigin: As a primitive element itself, the human legs are also swallowed up, but the meaning of tiger is kept, and the whole serves as a roof for what comes beneath 虍, giving the tiger something else to eat.
Mnemonic1: Magic wand + first two strokes of pelt (皮) + diced + human legs. A wizard who turns people he doesn´t like into newts with his magic wand goes for variety - he has always wanted a tiger pelt - but things go awry when the tiger promptly dices and eats him, leaving only a pair of legs. (a fitting end for a wicked wizard).
Mnemonic2: Tigger, the tiger, (from Pooh stories) is happy to have found a magic wand. Using it he can bounce up to a the top of a cliff, seven times as high as some human legs could bounce. Tigger thinks "Its great to be a tiger!
Compo: 虍: tiger　儿: human legs
Ex1English: Key, crib, pony; secret(of a trade)

Origin: House . . . ceiling . . . sprout . . . animal legs. Compare, and do not confuse with, the kanji in frame 1887.
Mnemonic1: I don't know why but when I read sign of the tiger I get the "eye of the tiger song" stuck in my head. So I see rocky training in his house. Hes hitting the ceiling (no punching bag) eating brussel sprouts to keep in good health and running with only the animal legs his dog.
Mnemonic2: The sign of the tiger is that he´s eaten all of the yellow (#1750) salad in the house.
Compo: 能: ability

Origin: Water . . . sign of the tiger.
Mnemonic1: Studies have shown that Rocky's PERFORMANCE increases if he downs WATER mixed with gatorade while in a match.
Mnemonic2: I remember seeing advertisements growing up with the sign of the tiger saying to "Put a tiger in your tank", meaning that it would increase the performance of the drops of gasoline you put in.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　寅: sign of the tiger

Origin: Salad . . . sprout . . . animal legs.
Mnemonic1: The salad did not look very appetizing... The sprouts were yellow and there were animal legs sticking out of it.
Mnemonic2: I order a salad with sprouts. I´m asked if I´d like to add chicken. Yes please. My salad then arrives . . . . topped with these horribly gnarled yellow things. Chicken feet! (animal legs) ugh.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)　ハ: animal legs (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . yellow.
Mnemonic1: A tree went all yellow. It died and fell down, ending up sideways.
Mnemonic2: In a horrible accident, a yellow schoolbus gets wrapped sideways around a tree.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　黄: yellow

Origin: Tree . . . funnel.
Mnemonic1: Ideal posture is standing tall like a tree and having a V shape like a funnel
Mnemonic2: I fell out of a tree and broke my neck. So they put one of those white funnels around my neck to correct my posture.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　冓: put together; funnel (RTK)
Ex1English: Set up (a house); assume a posture, make ready

Origin: Words . . . funnel.
Mnemonic1: I have a funnel attached to my laptop that takes my prof´s lecture and puts the words into a text file. The bigger the funnel, the more accurate the conversion, so picture a bunch of laptops with large, unwieldy funnels attached to the USB port.
Mnemonic2: Image: a professor walking around with a funnel and simply pouring his words into each students head instead of a lecture. (Primitive: FUNNEL, who got the celery stuck in the funnel again?! You know it´s not supposed to be used for that!).
Compo: 言: word; say　冓: put together; funnel (RTK)

Origin: Shells . . . funnel. The key word is meant to suggest magazine subscriptions and the like.
Mnemonic1: Subscription is like a money funnel, because the receiving end is small (just one company) and the other end is wide (the whole country).
Mnemonic2: My subscription to Money magazine came with a free coin funnel.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　冓: put together; funnel (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . funnel.
Mnemonic1: A gutter funnels water.
Mnemonic2: A gutter takes the water that falls as rain and funnels it off to where it can be dealt with appropriately.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　冓: put together; funnel (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . anti-.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T was offered a job in the Iraq Provisional Authority, but he turned it down, because he´s anti-war. "I pity da fool thinks this sand pit worth invadin´ when our schools be in such sad shape!".
Mnemonic2: Mr. T is anti anything provisional. "I pity da foo´ who´s so indecisive that he can´t make nothin´ permanent".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　反: anti-

Origin: This kanji is based on the pictograph of a tree with some branches going upwards and others hanging down, split right down the middle. When that picture's right side is isolated, it becomes the kanji for one-sided, in the sense of only one part of a whole.
Mnemonic1: Fuaburisu´s pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.
Mnemonic2: Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn´t see any trees or branches in there).
Compo: 片: piece; one-side (RTK)

Origin: Although this character also carries the sense of an "edition" of a publication, the elements, one-sided and anti-, more readily suggest its other meaning of a printing block.
Mnemonic1: Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn´t be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true.
Mnemonic2: Nazi propaganda. Picture the printing blocks producing very one-sided (Aryan), anti-Jewish propaganda spreading posters to hang around town.
Compo: 片: piece; one-side (RTK)　反: anti-

Origin: Tree . . . anti-.
Mnemonic1: Of course, trees are anti-plank. Wouldn´t you be if you were a tree?
Mnemonic2: Trees are naturally opposed to, or anti, the making of planks.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　反: anti-

Origin: Shells/money . . . anti-.
Mnemonic1: The goal of marketing is to get people who are naturally anti-buying to spend their shells (money).
Mnemonic2: 『MARKETING: MONEY, ANTI』 The wide presence of MARKETING in our society has led people to become ANTI-MONEY.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　反: anti-

Origin: Sheep . . . ego.
Mnemonic1: Righteous Christians are sheep with egos (reworked from raulir, fixes word order to match radical order).
Mnemonic2: On the other hand, Woman tend to have too much self-righteousness to allow any man to touch their wooly black sheep this results in similar hand fiestas.
Compo: 羊: sheep　我: ego
Ex3English: Sense of duty (honor], obligation, debt of gratitude; justice; courtesy

Origin: Words . . . righteousness.
Mnemonic1: Careful deliberation produces words of righteousness.
Mnemonic2: At the worst of times, a jury´s deliberation descends into a war of words between competing self-righteous, power-tripping bastards.
Compo: 言: word; say　義: righteousness
Ex4English: Member of an assembly, diet member

Origin: Person . . . righteousness.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T is the master of ceremonies because he is a righteous dude.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T was briefly a rapper, that is an M.C., that is a master of CEREMONIES (the origin of the phrase). But he sang only RIGHTEOUS songs, no cursing or anything like that. (all true: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_rBidCkJxo ).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　義: righteousness

Origin: Cow . . . righteousness. Do NOT use the image of an animal sacrifice here, as that will have it own character later on.
Mnemonic1: A cow that is righteous sacrifices her milk for the human race.
Mnemonic2: Cows are truly righteous animals. They SACRIFICE their milk so that we can have some. And if they don´t have any left, they give a sheep a hand fiesta (good lord this is going too far) and give us that instead. What righteous cows.
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　義: righteousness

Origin: Cow . . . cell.
Mnemonic1: Animal sacrifice = taking the life of a cow.
Mnemonic2: In the 21st century, animal sacrifice is no longer really necessary. We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods.
Compo: 牛: cow (⺧)　生: life; cell (RTK)

Origin: Something is so downright delicious that one spends the entire day with a spoon in hand gobbling it up.
Mnemonic1: Use a spoon to eat a DELICIOUS hot fudge sundae. Duh..
Mnemonic2: It´s sooo delicious I could spoon it in all day.
Compo: 匕: spoon　日: day; sun

Origin: Finger . . . delicious.
Mnemonic1: Finger lickin´ delicious.
Mnemonic2: I remember this not as finger which has too many uses elsewhere but as "fingering" then its easy: fingering some delicious...
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　旨: delicious
Ex3English: Aim for, have an eye on

Origin: Finger . . . chariot.
Mnemonic1: A military leader in his chariot is brandishing his finger at the enemy, crying "chaaaaaaaaarrrgggeeee!".
Mnemonic2: Think of the movie Gladiator but instead Maximus is brandishing a giant foam brand name (nike, rebok, adidas, whatever) finger like you see at a baseball game. He´s riding in a chariot using the foam finger to kill his enemy.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　軍: army; chariot (RTK)

Origin: Take advantage of the first syllable of the key word to think of the ray of light to the left. Now add the glittering chariot that is emitting those rays and you have radiance.
Mnemonic1: Rays of light emitted from Apollo´s chariot = radiance. Don´t put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!
Mnemonic2: Radiance is an army of rays.
Compo: 光: ray; light　軍: army; chariot (RTK)

Origin: Thorns grow on a bush here that has wrapped itself around a tree like a belt, cutting into the poor tree like little sabers.
Mnemonic1: A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS.
Mnemonic2: The BELT TREE has THORNS like SABERS.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Kunyomi: さ.す, さ.さる, さ.し, さし

Origin: Bamboo . . . belted tree (See frame 446).
Mnemonic1: (Elaboration of jameserb´s story:) A clever scheme from Wile E Coyote -- he ties one of those rubber belts to some trees and uses it to launch a bamboo spear at the roadrunner...
Mnemonic2: The temples in kyoto belt bamboo around trees in a scheme to protect them from the huge number of tourists. (true story)-----------対策 たいさく measure, countermeasure.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　朿: thorn; belted tree (RTK)

Origin: Wool . . . craft.
