Mnemonic1: This New-Zealand pro-gamer has won many distinctions playing WoolCraft (a massively multi-user game in which the goal is to shear sheep).
Mnemonic2: Noob players make no distinction between what games they play, whether it´s the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of Wool-craft!
Compo: 羊: sheep　丿: katakana no　工: craft; construction
Ex1English: Extend (one's hand); offer; hold (an umbrella); wear (in one's belt or hair)

Origin: I cannot resist doing this one for you, since it clearly describes donning (putting on) one's clothes as "pulling the wool over one's eyes."
Mnemonic1: A pullover is donned by pulling wool over your eyes.
Mnemonic2: Someone who is donning a disguise does that in order to pull the wool over your eyes.
Compo: 羊: sheep　丿: katakana no　目: eye
Kunyomi: き.る, -ぎ, き.せる, -きせ, つ.く, つ.ける

Origin: Hand . . . eyes.
Mnemonic1: It´s a hot day of summer with a clear sky, you´re sitting outside a cafe (or maybe on a reclining chair in the garden), and you watch over the kids with a hand covering your eyes from the sunlight (next time, don´t forget the sunglasses).
Mnemonic2: Think of the monster from Pan´s Labrynth, that watched over the poor girl with eyes in the palm of his hands.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　目: eye

Origin: Climax . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: Http://img168.imageshack.us/img168/7731/karatesd3.jpg Just look at this image...
Mnemonic2: Just as we were about to climax her father arrived with a sword.
Compo: 至: climax　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Ex2English: After all, in the long run

Origin: Person . . . arrival.
Mnemonic1: The A-Team are planning to overthrow the government. However, they can´t do a damn thing until Mr T arrives.
Mnemonic2: In Return of the Jedi, after a climactic light sabre battle, Luke and Vader overthrow the emporer (literally throwing him over the balcony).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　到: arrival
Kunyomi: たお.れる, -だお.れ, たお.す

Origin: Words . . . meeting . . . scrapbook. The argument here is a process of academic reasoning, not a personal quarrel or spat.
Mnemonic1: Right part: academic conference (a meeting, some of the attendees making notes in scrapbooks during presentation). Argument at academic conferences is naturally carried out using words.
Mnemonic2: It´s very difficult to present a good argument if you don´t bring along a scrapbook with some key words jotted down to the meeting.
Compo: 言: word; say　侖: think

Origin: Person . . . meeting . . . scrapbook.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T talks about ethics at the academic conference. "I pity the fool who gets caught plagarizing someone else´s stuff!".
Mnemonic2: Mr. T has no ethics at the scrapbooking convention. He´ll do whatever it takes to beat all those ladies.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　侖: think

Origin: Car . . . meeting . . . scrapbook.
Mnemonic1: During a talk at the academic conference, speaker shows an introductory slide depicting the structure of car, and then moves on to the more narrow topic of wheels.
Mnemonic2: Someone stole all the wheels off the ladies´ cars at the scrapbook convention.
Compo: 車: car　侖: think

Origin: On the left we see a vehicle used for transport. On the right, we see a new tangle of elements that need sorting out. The first three strokes, you will remember, are the primitive for meeting. Below it we see the elements for flesh and saber, which combine to create a compound element for a butcher and his trade. Together they give us the image of a "trucker's convoy."
Mnemonic1: The car is a cattle-car, used to transport animals for the butcher´s meeting - a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front.
Mnemonic2: The vehicle transports animals for a meeting with the butcher.
Compo: 車: car　亼: assemble; meeting　刖: butcher

Origin: The stern tone of a rebuke is seen here in the image of words spoken at a meeting of butchers (See frame 307) waving their choppers at one another and "cutting one another down" as only butchers can.
Mnemonic1: A PETA activist speaks at a meeting of butchers to rebuke them.
Mnemonic2: I imagine Socrates gate-crashing a meeting of butchers and REBUKING them: ´You´ve been killing things again; you have, haven´t you?´ while the embarrassed butchers blush and try to hide their knives behind their backs and stand in front of hanging sides of beef.
Compo: 言: word; say　亼: assemble; meeting　刖: butcher

Origin: State of mind . . . butchers (See frame 307).
Mnemonic1: At the meeting of butchers, in their narrow state of mind, they throw lame jokes around like, ´Oh hello, it´s a pleasure to meat you´, and find this rather pleasing.
Mnemonic2: Image : Data attending a meeting of the butchers union. As a joke to begin his speech he says, ´Its a pleasure to MEAT you all.´ (thanx to Shibo & nestOr).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　亼: assemble; meeting　刖: butcher

Mnemonic1: (Think rpg!) We were in dire need of healing. Our party was fighting the cavemen, but we didn't fare too well. It was more like a butcher's meeting than a fight... just as they were about to pierce my heart, luckily a priest came along and used his healing spell in the nick of time (#2433).
Mnemonic2: Note: meeting of butchers + heart are later combined into 愈 in the nick of time (#2433). Story: For healing to take place, you must catch the sickness in the nick of time.
Compo: 疒: sickness　愈: healing

English: Stand, Pedestral, Platform, Counter For Machines And Vehicles, Taiwan
Origin: Elbow . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: When someone´s elbow is above your mouth he/she is probably standing on a pedestal.
Mnemonic2: After training your whole life, you manage to get a bronze medal in the Olympics. You´re extremely proud of your accomplishment as you step up to receive your medal. The guy in first place is up on a pedestal, towering above you, his elbow level with your mouth. Being a smug bastard, he "accidentally" knocks his elbow into your mouth, causing you to bleed and lose a tooth. Just cause he won the gold doesn´t mean he can place himself on such a high pedestal and do whatever he wants!
Compo: 厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　口: mouth
Ex1Kana: じどうしゃじゅうだい

Origin: Water . . . pedestal.
Mnemonic1: Build a moat around your pedestal to protect your reign of power.
Mnemonic2: From his water pedestal Neptune reigns over his Sea Empire.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　台: pedestal
Kunyomi: おさ.める, おさ.まる, なお.る, なお.す
Ex2English: Govern a country, manage a state

Origin: Ice . . . pedestal.
Mnemonic1: The secrets of metallurgy and smithing: get your redhot metal and bang it against the pedestal as an anvil. Then cool it quickly with lots of ice.
Mnemonic2: An ICE PEDESTAL is useless in METALLURGY since it will just melt.
Compo: 冫: ice　台: pedestal

Origin: Sickness . . . pup tent.
Mnemonic1: On the battlefield, the only place to heal from your sickness is inside the medic's pup tent. Think of M.A.S.H.
Mnemonic2: Sick caveman has to sleep in his pup tent. Not the cave because to humid and cold but a nice small pup tent in the sun will heal him from his cold.
Compo: 疒: sickness　尞: fuel used for sacrifices; pup tent (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . pup tent. Choose some connotation of the key word that will keep it distinct for you from companion (Frame 19), friend (Frame 760), consort (Frame 1287), and comrade (Frame 1765).
Mnemonic1: A colleague implies someone that you share work with, such as in your company or profession, etc. Here your colleague helps you to erect your pup tent during a company outing. Note: Heisig's warning to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as companion (#19), friend (#704), consort (#1203) and comrade (#1637). That is why I chose to have the person element pictured as someone (the colleague in this case) helping with the work of building the pup tent.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T began working in a japanese compagny. As he sees that his colleague accept to do some extra work during the week-end and even sleep at the office, he says to them: "I pity da fool who work during week-end! You might as well install a pup tent in the office and forget about your home".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　尞: fuel used for sacrifices; pup tent (RTK)

Origin: Eye . . . pup tent.
Mnemonic1: Open your eyes, it's obvious that not all of us can fit into that small puptent!
Mnemonic2: It´s obvious that the pup tent with a huge eye on the side belongs to the dark lord Sauron.
Compo: 目: eye　尞: fuel used for sacrifices; pup tent (RTK)

Origin: House . . . pup tent.
Mnemonic1: A dormitory is right in the middle between living in a house and living in a pup tent.
Mnemonic2: This guy would rather use his pup-tent as a house, than sleep in the dormitory. So he effectively turned that pup-tent into a house by getting a postal address for it etc. (just to emphasize house).
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　尞: fuel used for sacrifices; pup tent (RTK)

Origin: Woman . . . pedestal.
Mnemonic1: Many men, before they commence their relationship with the woman of their desires, place her on something of a pedestal, which often leads to disappointment later on.
Mnemonic2: If you want to commence a relationship, just put a woman on a pedestal and she´ll love ya forever.
Compo: 女: woman　台: pedestal
Kunyomi: はじ.める, -はじ.める, はじ.まる

Origin: Thread . . . winter.
Mnemonic1: This winter is so cold that spiderman´s web gets brittle! Could this be the end of spiderman?
Mnemonic2: The thread of life begins with the spring and ends with the winter.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　冬: winter
Kunyomi: お.わる, -お.わる, お.える
Ex1English: From beginning to end, at all times

Origin: Learn this character by returning to frame 99 and the image given there. The only difference is that the "arms" have been left off (actually, only tucked inside). Thus a child with its arms wrapped up into the back-sack is the picture of a job successfully completed.
Mnemonic1: The experiment was a complete failure! The child was made without any arms!
Mnemonic2: A child with the arms inside the blanket will be completely wrapped up.
Compo: 了: finish

Origin: The sense of passive acceptance or reception of information is contained in this key word. The form is based on the middle portion of the preceding character, with three additional strokes, best thought of as the kanji for three.
Mnemonic1: To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give.
Mnemonic2: To get someone to acquiesce, duck them completely in aqua (=water) three times. (variation on dingomick´s).
Compo: 了: finish　三: three　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: The flower at the top and the floor with the oven fire beneath are familiar. The problem is what comes in between. It is formed by the character for complete, whose vertical stroke doubles up as the first stroke of water.
Mnemonic1: Think of a picture of someone steaming vegetables. On top you see the flowers of cauliflower or something else that is being steamed. Underneath, the pan is completely full of water. Below the pan is a floor - that's the hotplate - and under that the oven fire. Caution: don't confuse with boil (#1257), or the steam radical in spirit (#1885).
Mnemonic2: When you want to steam some flowers/vegetation you don't cover them completely with water, rather you have just a little at the floor of the saucepan and then heat.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　丞: help　火: fire (灬)
Kunyomi: む.す, む.れる, む.らす

Origin: The top two strokes show someone reclining, and the next six are a pictograph of an oaken tub ribbed with metal strips, like the kind once used for bathing. At the bottom, the sunglasses round off the character.
Mnemonic1: The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem dances naked for him.
Mnemonic2: I learned nothingness (#1775) first because it is a very common kanji. Probably easier to think of this kanji in that context. Attractive dancers should dance wearing nothing but sunglasses.
Compo: 𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　卌: forty　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　舛: sunglasses (RTK)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . rice . . . sunglasses.
Mnemonic1: America thinks it is the pinnacle of the world, looking down on all neighboring countries through its mirrored, aviator sunglasses.
Mnemonic2: All the neighboring communities to the Pinnacle have a major problem. The kids at the Pinnacle have a habit of throwing down rice from the city walls in all directions, so people in neighboring communities are forced to wear sunglasses all the time in order to avoid getting rice in their eyes.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　米: rice　舛: sunglasses (RTK)
Ex2English: Adjoin, be next door to each other

Origin: Eye . . . birdhouse . . . sunglasses.
Mnemonic1: Imagine Snoopy winking with his big eyes (and a happy smile) standing next to Woodstocks Birdhouse, woodstock being so cool that he wears little sunglasses.
Mnemonic2: What a dilemna, you wore SUNGLASSES over your EYES when you went to the BIRDHOUSE so you wouldn´t be recognized - but now you can´t WINK at the girl you want!
Compo: 目: eye　爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　冖: crown 　舛: sunglasses (RTK)

Origin: To have a dream after going to bed is really the crown to a perfect evening. The flower petals over the eyes (instead of the "sand" that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning) only confirms the image of a pleasant dream suggested by the rest of this rather complex kanji.
Mnemonic1: Last night´s date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening.
Mnemonic2: In the movie American Beauty, Kevin Spacey liked to DREAM about his daughter´s friend and have a rose petal fall onto his eye from the ceiling. He did this lying in his bed each evening. You can almost see him lying in his bed in this kanji.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　冖: crown 　夕: evening
Ex4English: As if in a dream; madly, like crazy; intently

Origin: Tree . . . branch. Take a moment to focus on the differences between a bough, a branch, and a twig (Frame 319).
Mnemonic1: The tree´s primary branch is known as the bough.
Mnemonic2: Differentiate between BOUGH and branch (#711): ´branch´ is smaller, and can also refer to the branch of a store (支店), which has nothing to do with a tree. But a BOUGH is a main part of a tree, perhaps where the trunk splits into several large boughs, and so it logically utilizes the 木 radical.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　支: branch

Origin: Fingers . . . branch.
Mnemonic1: (Adapted from darg_sama´s) Balancing a branch on your finger is the prototypical example of a skill that is nothing more than a skill (i.e., it is completely useless).
Mnemonic2: I think of a guy balancing a branch on his finger, which definitely takes some minimal amount of skill.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　支: branch

Origin: Person . . . branch.
Mnemonic1: Mr T is dancing and singing and all that, but he´s doing it on a branch. All that talent and can still still keep his balance? That´s a real performing artist.
Mnemonic2: (note: this is the ´ki´ from kabuki).//The performing artist is a person doing Kabuki theater and dancing around with a branch in his hand.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　支: branch

Origin: Mountains . . . branch.
Mnemonic1: On the left, there are three mountains. The road branches off to each of them. (Note: This kanji is mostly used for branches in the road).
Mnemonic2: In a lot of Super Nintendo-era RPGs, there are mountain levels to get through. You view them from overhead, so you can see a mazelike path with many branches. Picture your sprite characters at one such fork in the mountain path, as it branches off in two directions.
Compo: 山: mountain　支: branch

Origin: Mountain . . . above . . . below.
Mnemonic1: Heisig mentions at kanjiclinic.com that he wishes he´d chosen mountain pass for this keyword as it´s closer to what the word means. If we do this, the kanji makes complete sense because a mountain pass is just below the mountain top.
Mnemonic2: To the north of Lorien lies the Misty Mountains, and below their towering peaks are the Mines of Moria. The Fellowship of the Ring first tried for the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes above, but were halted by the wizardry of Saruman at Caradhras, and so are forced to take the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes below, through the mountain - a path long feared by Gandalf for the ancient evil that lurks there. Note : the kanji does in fact refer to a "mountain pass".
Compo: 山: mountain　上: above; up　下: below

Origin: Maestro . . . needle.
Mnemonic1: The maestro lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over ten decibels without anyone giving a damn.
Mnemonic2: Note to those who have not got this far in the book: This is the full kanji for the Pinnacle primitive (i.e. only the left-hand version of the primitive). The full kanji for the City Walls primitive is city walls (#2180). Beyonce went for an invigorating walk up a large hill on a summer´s afternoon. Since the grass was so lush and cool, she took off her sandals and immediately stepped on a used hypodermic needle. 岐阜県 ぎふけん Gifu Prefecture.
Compo: 𠂤: maestro (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Bound up . . . broom . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: She was always bound to a broom, her heart pounding in a hurry to finish before she was punished for being slow.
Mnemonic2: Fantasia: Bound up brooms out of control send Mickey´s heart racing--he has to hurry and figure out how to stop them before the magician returns!
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Ex2English: Urgently, with all haste, at once

Origin: Bound up . . . rake.
Mnemonic1: This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.
Mnemonic2: A boxing ring is bound up by the ropes. The contender is cheating and using a rake.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　肀: rake (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . blue. Do not confuse with emotion (Frame 662).
Mnemonic1: Data is feeling blue about not having any feelings ... hey, wait a minute.
Mnemonic2: Feeling blue is a state of mind where you´re dominated by your feelings.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　青: blue; green

Origin: Water . . . blue.
Mnemonic1: Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.
Mnemonic2: Bottles of water claim to be pure. They´re generally in blue containers, because blue makes you feel like its that much more pure.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　青: blue; green
Kunyomi: きよ.い, きよ.まる, きよ.める

Origin: Take the key word in its associations with the weather (unless that tempts you to include the primitive for weather, which doesn't belong here). Its elements: sun . . . blue.
Mnemonic1: Sun and blue sky! Yep, the weather´s cleared up!
Mnemonic2: When we speak of clearing up we easily think of both the sun and blue skies. But in another since to clear up is the absence of weather. And therefor the reason weather has no place in its writing.
Compo: 日: day; sun　青: blue; green
Kunyomi: は.れる, は.れ, は.れ-, -ば.れ, は.らす

Origin: Rice . . . blue.
Mnemonic1: Very refined people in the upper classes have skin as pale as rice and blue blood.
Mnemonic2: Uh, why is your rice blue? "It's been refined! And by 'refined' I mean it's been in the back of my fridge for a few months.".
Compo: 米: rice　青: blue; green

Origin: Words . . . blue.
Mnemonic1: People who try to solicit you to buy things come up to you and just start taking out of the blue
Mnemonic2: That door-to-door salesman can stand outside ringing my doorbell until he´s blue in the face. There´s a big sign on my front door, and the words clearly say "No Soliciting".
Compo: 言: word; say　青: blue; green

Origin: Blue . . . contend. Do not confuse with calm (Frame 1230).
Mnemonic1: When someone you know who is normally talkative goes quiet, it´s usually a sign that they are contending with the blues.
Mnemonic2: Don't confuse with silence (#240), something achieved through action. On the other hand, quiet refers to a personal quality of not speaking out. Members of Blue-man group jump into the wrestling ring of contenders for tag-team wrestling. Though the other contenders are screaming, the blue men never say anything - they are a very quiet bunch, that Blue-man group. Primitive order: blue man group's first and main characteristic is being blue and quiet; only later did they decide to become wrestling contenders.
Compo: 青: blue; green　争: contend
Kunyomi: しず-, しず.か, しず.まる, しず.める

Origin: Water . . . contend.
Mnemonic1: Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the cleanest.
Mnemonic2: The water contends against the dirt in the ultimate battle for cleaninless.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　争: contend

Origin: Bamboo . . . eyes . . . two hands.
Mnemonic1: Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It´s not as easy as a calculator, but you don´t need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands.
Mnemonic2: Tip : you may see this as an Abacus, which is used to calculate. This particular ancient chinese Abacus has eyeballs in place of beads, and its frame is made of bamboo. You´d be amazed at how fast people can calculate with this, especially if they can use both hands at once to move the ... eyeballs.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　目: eye　廾: twenty; 2 hands
Ex3English: Exact calculation, adjustment (as of a train fare)

Origin: Bamboo . . . fit.
Mnemonic1: The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the bamboo pieces fit together.
Mnemonic2: For the frustrated housewife the solution came in form of a BAMBOO stick that FITS her well.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　合: fit

Origin: Bamboo . . . adhere.
Mnemonic1: I dropped my token down the drain, so I used a piece of bamboo with chewing gum on the end to retrieve it.
Mnemonic2: At the arcade, Mr. T adheres a bamboo rod to his token so that he can put it in the machine and pull it out repeatedly.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　付: attach; adhere
Ex2English: Note; phonetic grapheme of a kanji

Origin: At the left we have the needle; at the right, the kanji for specialty, plus an extra drop at the top. Think of a Dr. who is a specialist with a needle (an acupuncturist) and let the drop at the top represent the period at the end of Dr. In principle we are trying to avoid this kind of device, which plays on abstract grammatical conventions; but I think you will agree, after you have had occasion to use the right side of this kanji in forming other kanji, that the exception is merited in this case.
SubOrigin: The primitive form of this kanji eliminates the needle on the left and gets the meaning of an acupuncturist.
Mnemonic1: Ten specialties grants you the title of Dr. with a dot.
Mnemonic2: Watch for doctor (#1694), the sooner the better! In fact this kanji refers to someone well "learned", with extensive knowledge. This could apply to any kind of field. The kanji 医 ("doctor") is directly related to medicine. I would suggest to take away completely the idea of medicine here, and use a popular character whose name includes the keyword such as "Dr. Who", "Dr. Jekyll", even "Dr. Dobb´s" if you´re into programming.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　尃: speciality

Origin: Threads . . . acupuncturist.
Mnemonic1: Spidey received good word that the acupuncturist working down the road was actually the evil Doctor Octopus! Spidey headed over to the clinic, and trussed the acupuncturist Doc Oc up using the maniac´s own metal limbs!
Mnemonic2: Because people are so afraid of the procedure, string has to be used by the acunpunturist to truss up his victims, er, patients.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　尃: speciality

Origin: Bamboo . . . water . . . acupuncturist.
Mnemonic1: Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 227), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won´t stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon´s story.
Mnemonic2: This doctor dilutes (see 227) his patients with bamboo stalks rather than the flowers of a standard diluting acupuncturist hence he needs to be on the Bamboo Accumpunturist Diltuers (BAD) register. Pumping that much water into a body can be dangerous; see the huge bamboo stems with gallons of water sloshing in and out of the patient.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　水: water (氵) (氺)　尃: speciality

Origin: Take a good look at this kanji: the "strong" element here is really the flower, not the water as you might have thought on first glance. To the right is the acupuncturist from frame 48. Taking the key word to connote diluting the vital humors of the body, we can imagine our acupuncturist performing his task with flowers in place of needles, and using their hollow stems to pipe water into the body of the patient.
Mnemonic1: A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine.
Mnemonic2: Note This character belongs to a set of characters which share the flower/water primitive such as:: dilute (#227), fall (#299), clan (#1912), and seaweed (#2035).... (落 薄 藩 藻) It may be helpful to create a primitive keyword for this occurrence (like seaweed or watering can) which can save a lot of time distinguishing them from characters like Sino 満 and Full 満, where the water primitive is larger than the flower primitive.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　水: water (氵) (氺)　尃: speciality
Kunyomi: うす.い, うす-, -うす, うす.める, うす.まる, うす.らぐ, うす.ら-, うす.れる

Origin: Vulture . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: You ever wondered why this appeared as a primitive in so many RTK1 kanji? Well, you should know that once a vulture grabs hold of a tree, he can never let go. Even Heisig couldn´t shake him loose.
Mnemonic2: A common meaning for this kanji is ´DICE´. --- Ever wonder what vultures do up in the trees? They play DICE. But of course, being vultures, they are always grabbing the dice away from each other.
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Flower . . . grab.
Mnemonic1: A vegetarian vulture is munching on a flower, perched on a tree, patiently waiting for a patch of vegetables to grow.
Mnemonic2: Wolverine is turning into total hippie. He said he only eats vegetables now and last time I saw him sitting in a tree with flowers in his hair.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　采: dice; grab (RTK)

Origin: Unlike pick up (Frame 720), this character is used for picking fruits from trees. Its elements: finger . . . grab.
Mnemonic1: You pick cheries with your fingers, then along comes a giant vulture and picks up the whole tree with its claws.
Mnemonic2: Tip: vulture + tree : Heisig later combines these into a single kanji 采 called grab (#2090). Story: As you go to pick your nose, your parent grabs your finger and pulls it away (& gives you a lecture on social etiquette). REF: "grab" also appears in vegetable (#734), coloring (#1714).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　采: dice; grab (RTK)

Origin: Vulture . . . tree . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: In Sydney we occasionally get exotic birds. You first notice a colouring in a tree. You look more carefully and you make out the shape of a bird (here represented by its claws).
Mnemonic2: When coloring something in you grab the crayon of choice to fill in the shapes.
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　木: tree; wood　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: Cedar is an evergreen tree that keeps its SHAPE all year long. That is, it doesn´t loose its needles/leaves in the winter.
Mnemonic2: Cedar is a wood that keeps its shape. (This is true, it's rot resistant.).
Compo: 木: tree; wood　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: This is the character from which the sense of boulevard mentioned in frame 938 derives. Its elements: boulevard . . . ivy.
Mnemonic1: The boulevard of boulevards, the Champs Elysées, with the Arc de Triomphe covered in ivy to give the champions a heroes´ welcome.
Mnemonic2: Specifically... ivy boulevard... think hollywood & vine.
Compo: 行: going; journey　圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)

Origin: Boulevard . . . resin.
Mnemonic1: Behold the "Boulev´Art" : a life-size section of a boulevard cast in a huge block of resin. Some call it ... art.
Mnemonic2: The definition of art is getting more and more loose these days. Why even some resin spilled onto the boulevard is now counted as art! Hmmph!
Compo: 行: going; journey　朮: a type of herb; resin (RTK)

Origin: Resin . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Why are the roads leading through the woods so sticky and dirty? Hmm... I think the forest ranger mentioned something about excess resin on the roads...
Mnemonic2: No-body mentioned that there was resin on the road. Now I´m stuck!
Compo: 朮: a type of herb; resin (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Umbrella . . . potato . . . little. The last stroke of potato and the first of little coincide in this character.
SubOrigin: Since the phrase "too much" is overly abstract, we shall take the image of a scale whose indicator spins round and round on the dial because too much weight has been set on it. It will help to use this image in learning the kanji itself.
Mnemonic1: You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.
Mnemonic2: This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol ">" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using two (#2) and little (#105) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means "two much" (more than 2) or "two little". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　于: going; potato (RTK)　ハ: animal legs (RTK)
Kunyomi: あま.る, あま.り, あま.す

Origin: Pinnacle . . . scale.
Mnemonic1: You won´t make it unless you exclude something. The climb to the pinacle cannot be completed if you are carrying too much. You just have to decide what you can afford to exclude.
Mnemonic2: To become a member of The Pinnacle, they test you on a scale. If you weigh too much, they exclude you.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　余: surplus; scale (RTK)

Origin: Line . . . scale.
Mnemonic1: You can´t expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit going to the scale to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually.
Mnemonic2: I set up a column chart next to my scales so I could record my weight gradually changing.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　余: surplus; scale (RTK)

Origin: Scale . . crotch. The key word has to do with conferring ranks, titles, and awards. It should not be confused with bestow (Frame 1335) or impart (Frame 795).
Mnemonic1: Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.).
Mnemonic2: If there is such a thing as too much crotch, the guy who gets that much should have an honor conferred upon him.
Compo: 余: surplus; scale (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Scale . . . measuring cup.
Mnemonic1: The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side.
Mnemonic2: The constellation of libra (meaning " scales" in latin) is diagonal to the handle of the big dipper.
Compo: 余: surplus; scale (RTK)　斗: dipper; measuring cup (RTK)

Origin: Scale . . . road.
Mnemonic1: On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road.
Mnemonic2: There are too many roads, so you need to plan a route.
Compo: 余: surplus; scale (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex3English: One's future, prospects; distance yet to cover
Ex4Kana: はってんとじょうこく

Origin: Water . . . scale . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground.
Mnemonic2: A true artisan mixes his own paint from water and soils on a scale in careful proportions.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　余: surplus; scale (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Water . . . tree . . . umbrella . . . grains of rice.
Mnemonic1: LACQUER is a type of WATERY type of liquid used to protect items made from TREES, sort of an UMBRELLA of protection. So protective, you can carry around RICE in the LACQUERED, WOODEN product.
Mnemonic2: Water is falling from a tree onto the umbrella underneath which is protecting the rice underneath it. But it´s completely dry since the umbrella is lacquered.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　木: tree; wood　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Person . . . mountain.
Mnemonic1: A HERMIT is a PERSON who lives in the MOUNTAINS.
Mnemonic2: After living as an hermit (recluse) for a while in the mountains, Mister T becomes an immortal mountain fairy ("fairy" is another meaning of this kanji).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　山: mountain

Origin: A drop of . . . silage . . . walking stick . . . floor. The character is written in the order of its elements.
Mnemonic1: The thousand head of cattle let their heads droop as they devour the silage (animal fodder) that is lying on the floor around them.
Mnemonic2: Even a drop of silage is enough to make an old man with a walking stick droop low down to the floor. (rgravina - fixed up order).
Compo: 丿: katakana no　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　廾: twenty; 2 hands　土: ground; land; soil
Kunyomi: た.れる, た.らす, た.れ, -た.れ

Origin: The simplest way to remember this character is to find the sprig of wheat in it, hidden because it doubles up with one stroke of silage.
Mnemonic1: It´s a hay ride! You sit on piles of silage and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of wheat sticking out of their mouths.
Mnemonic2: (ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to ride on biomass fueled vehicles. Good news for those who have wheat silage surplus.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　廾: twenty; 2 hands　木: tree; wood

English: Combine, Cannot, Find It Difficult To
Origin: At the top we have the animal horns and the single horizontal stroke to give them something to hang onto. Below that, we see one rake with two handles. Finally, we see a pair of strokes splitting away from each of the handles, indicating that they are both splitting under the pressure. The composite picture is of someone holding down two jobs concurrently, using the same kit of tools to move in two different directions and ending up in a mess. Take the time to find this sense in the kanji and it will be easy to remember, despite initial appearances.
Mnemonic1: Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a rake, is suddenly attacked from both left and right concurrently by bulls with animal horns. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle).
Mnemonic2: You decide to take the bull by the horns and do both chores concurrently, grabbing your double-handled rake before attempting to clean up both your´s and your neighbours´ garden. But unfortunately, it´s not long until your rake splits in two.
Compo: 丷: animal horns (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　丨: line; stick　丨: line; stick　ハ: animal legs (RTK)

Origin: Ride . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: If you go for a ride and find a saber beside you, perhaps you got into an Army surplus jeep.
Mnemonic2: Remember the wheat we cut with scythes (farmer's equivalent of a saber) for profit (#906)? Well, we harvested too much and have to use the surplus for silage. 過剰 (かじょう) : excess.
Compo: 乗: ride　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Eyes . . . droop.
Mnemonic1: Our eyes droop when we are drowsy.
Mnemonic2: Hint : the eyes of Droopy Dog (see droop (#1582)). When you are drowsy you have "droopy eyes". That is, you have Droopy´s eyes!
Compo: 目: eye　垂: hornbeam; droop (RTK)
Ex1Kana: いっすいもしなかった

Origin: Eyes . . . people.
Mnemonic1: In an Orwellian sense, the eye watching the people never sleeps.
Mnemonic2: The little boy from The Sixth Sense couldn´t sleep because before his very eyes he saw a dead crowd of people everywhere.
Compo: 目: eye　民: people

Origin: Droop . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: The drooping citywalls was generating a lot of angry mail for the city officials. Hint: think "hate mail" and you will remember this one. (thx CharleyGarrett].
Mnemonic2: The city walls droop down in one spot so that the mailtman can throw the mail over.
Compo: 垂: hornbeam; droop (RTK)　邑: village; city walls (阝)

Origin: Metal . . . droop.
Mnemonic1: Wasn´t it a cursed spindle that Sleeping Beauty pricked her finger on? Therefore the spindle was the metal that caused her to droop and eventually sleep for 100 years.
Mnemonic2: Spindle: the needle that drops on an LP record player. This is made of metal. It droops. Viola.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　垂: hornbeam; droop (RTK)

Origin: Flower . . . silage . . . needle.
Mnemonic1: The Queen of England taking a walk round a village: ´Excuse me, I couldn´t help noticing the splendour of the flowers in your garden. Simply splendid. Ten out of ten.´ The villager gruffly replies: ´No it ´aint. It´s all muck. An´ I´m gonna cut it all down and sell it to the farmer for silage.´.
Mnemonic2: (I'm substituting greenhouse for silage. It is also full of all types of plants, and the shape resembles the windows that cover the building to let in the light.) See the splendor of the roses filling the greenhouse, beauty atop a stem of needles (thorns).
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　垂: hornbeam; droop (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch. Gather the elements on the right into a composite image that can serve you in the next two frames.
Mnemonic1: The parson ENCROACHES on the French maid; driven wild by her little broom, dainty tiara and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers (crotch)!
Mnemonic2: Mr T. hits a condom salesman (broom + crown + crotch) over the head with a broom because the dude ENCROACHed Mr. T´s privates area during the sale.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　冖: crown 　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!).
Mnemonic2: After being hit in the head with the broom, the condom salesman IMMERSED his head in some water.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　冖: crown 　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Do not confuse this key word with either the element for reclining or the character for prostrated (Frame 1035). Its primitive elements are: house . . . turtle . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: After work, the French maid goes home and lies down with a turtle. Turtle? Well, he´s sloooow and always hard... (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!).
Mnemonic2: After being hit on the head encroach (#1148), the condom salesman goes back to his house to lie down. He hasn´t made a single sale today, so he doesn´t have enough money to buy a pillow. He lies down on his pet turtle and cries himself to sleep.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　丬: left-side; turtle (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　冖: crown 　又: again; crotch (RTK)
Kunyomi: ね.る, ね.かす, ね.かせる

Origin: Fingers . . . broom . . . apron.
Mnemonic1: Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON.
Mnemonic2: FINGERS of the HOUSEWIFE (in itself, holding a BROOM, with an APRON) busily SWEEP the floor.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: Woman . . . broom . . . apron.
Mnemonic1: In high society, a lady is a woman who never touches a broom or an apron.
Mnemonic2: The LADY of the house is nothing more than a WOMAN who´s a HOUSEWIFE (BROOM and APRON anyone?).
Compo: 女: woman　ヨ: broom (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: Spear . . . broom . . . apron. The character for lady (Frame 1234) shares the same right side as this character, which does not bode for a very happy homecoming.
Mnemonic1: A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).
Mnemonic2: Well, the boss man warrior upon his homecoming has set aside his spear. Remember the lady (#1151) (who put aside her broom and apron)? I wonder what they´re doing now?
Compo: 刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　帚: broom

Origin: The key word signals a "coming back" or return to some place or activity. Its elements: door . . . St. Bernard dog.
Mnemonic1: The St. Bernard dog whining at the door of his master’s house in order to re-enter / re-turn inside.
Mnemonic2: Think about hachiko, the dog waiting at the door of the station, waiting for his master to re-turn.
Compo: 戸: door　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . re-. Do not confuse with cry (Frame 463).
Mnemonic1: I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye.
Mnemonic2: Tears are watery (water + re).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　戻: re-; return

Origin: I shot an arrow into the air, And it landed I know not where goes the poem. (The poor poet obviously loses a lot of arrows.) This kanji, however, tells us where it did land. Its elements: somebody . . . glued to.
Mnemonic1: You SHOOT SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun.
Mnemonic2: The aim of shooting is to end up with a bullet stuck in someone´s body.
Compo: 身: body　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)
Ex2English: Light shining into / piercing one's eyes

Origin: Words . . . shoot.
Mnemonic1: Dick Cheney...
Mnemonic2: The famous speech by the man that Dick Cheney shot in the face: "I´m sorry for the trouble I have caused the Vice President".
Compo: 言: word; say　射: shoot

English: Study, Examine, Suppress By Armed Force
Origin: Words spoken to chastise us stick to us like glue in a way no other words can.
Mnemonic1: I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!
Mnemonic2: In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had words glued to them. A famous example is the "A" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, words glued to you are supposed to chastise you and prevent further breaches of chastity.
Compo: 言: word; say　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: After completing the first draft, you revise it by nailing down your words and "hammering" them into shape.
Mnemonic1: Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down.
Mnemonic2: Remember how Martin Luther revised the words of the catholic church and nailed his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?
Compo: 言: word; say　丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: Finger . . . spike.
Mnemonic1: You´re using a hammer to drive a nail into a plank, but you miss and strike your fingers, ouch ! PS: the character does not mean "to go on strike", it will be very helpful in the long run to create images that convey the proper sense of the character!
Mnemonic2: My teacher used to strike my fingers with a street sign.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　丁: street; nail (RTK)
Ex1English: Strike (drive] into, ram down; devote oneself to, be absorbed in

Origin: Car . . . missile . . . hand.
Mnemonic1: Your car has missles?! That beats mine, hands down.
Mnemonic2: Think 3 methods of attack all combined into 1 kanji: 1. Vehicle to transport troops 2. Once troops have disembarked they have their missiles 3. If they run out of missiles they resort to hand to hand combat to beat the enemy.
Compo: 車: car　殳: lance, missile (RTK)　手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . style.
Mnemonic1: Why carry a handkerchief? I wipe my nose finger-style.
Mnemonic2: If you are going to wipe your nose with your fingers, better do it in a grand style.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　式: style

Origin: When a manufacturer produces a new style for the market, the first thing that is done is to run a test on consumers, asking them to speak their opinions frankly about the product. Never mind the anachronism (the kanji was there well before our capitalistic market system) if it helps you remember.
Mnemonic1: In an essay test, you are judged on both your choice of words and your writing style.
Mnemonic2: The Japanese oral exam was a test of my speaking style.
Compo: 言: word; say　式: style
Kunyomi: こころ.みる, ため.す

Origin: Tree . . . awl.
Mnemonic1: After intense cross-examination from the prosecutor, the tree confessed to murdering the wood-pecker with an awl... "He just kept at it, he kept poking at me with that beak, so I thought I'd see how HE liked it!!" The autopsy examination revealed at least a dozen puncture wounds, what a brutal case.
Mnemonic2: Don´t confuse with exam (#1278), test (#354), evaluate (#1487). Think of examination as a doctor´s examination. You´re having problems getting wood in bed. You go in for a doctor´s examination. The doctor shoves an icepick into your manhood as part of the examination.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　僉: all

Origin: Team of horses . . . awl.
Mnemonic1: We just verification that there are indeed no soldiers in the belly of this trojan horse. We´re just gonna stab it in the belly with this awl to check.
Mnemonic2: The verification proves the horse is real by poking it with an ice pick.
Compo: 馬: horse　㑒: awl (RTK)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . awl.
Mnemonic1: The rock climber trying to get up to the pinnacle is dangling from a precipitous edge, hanging only one with his icepick.
Mnemonic2: Well I have someone climbing an inflatable precipitous pinnacle. Once at the top it is so precipitous that the person is afraid to climb down and instead punctures the inflatable pinnacle with an awl to get safely and slowly back to the ground.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　僉: all

Origin: Person . . . awl.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T is as frugal as they come. He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.
Mnemonic2: Khatzumoto needs to be frugal after spending all his money on Japanese media and none on food. His waist has shrunk and he needs a new belt, but being frugal he just punches another hole with his awl.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　僉: all

Origin: Awl . . . saber. As we promised way back in frame 87, here at last is the kanji on which the primitive element of the same name is based.
Mnemonic1: If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They´re basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...
Mnemonic2: Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of "The Awl and the Sabre". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill. And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : "The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can´t use the sabre.".
Compo: 㑒: awl (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Go in . . . an umbrella . . . a mouth. Because of space restrictions, the element for go in is shortened in this character. If you stand on your head and look at this kanji, the image of a valley stands out more clearly: the mouth of the river whose water flows down at the intersection of the two mountains, with the final two strokes adding the element of perspective. Now get back on your feet again and see if the image still remains clear. If not, then return to the primitives and make a story in the usual way.
Mnemonic1: This could be seen as a very accurate pictograph of another type of valley: a valley mouth open under the umbrella of inner labia, with the outer labia parted above. There are even more connections to be made among the primitive keywords and the visuals, but i will enter no further...
Mnemonic2: Think of the classic anime 風の谷のナウシカ (Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind). We see Nausicaa entering the valley mouth gliding on an umbrella.
Compo: 谷: valley
Ex3English: Bottom of a ravine, valley bottom

Origin: Valley . . . yawn. Be sure to keep the key word distinct from pining (Frame 683).
Mnemonic1: Guess what? Japanese has dirty words too! (In fact, a lot of them) A sexual story is NOT inappropriate here, as this kanji is very sexual, such as in 性欲; lust. As for a story: the lack of contact with a woman´s valley will leave a man LONGING for love.
Mnemonic2: The valley has something my life is lacking.... something I´ve been longing for.. peace and quiet.
Compo: 谷: valley　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . valley.
Mnemonic1: This story is quite lascivious, sorry... Now, imagine you are at a 混浴 （こんよく） (two kanjis we now know] Onsen (温泉), and you are watching a woman bathe. Just picture the water dripping down her cleavage (that valley in between her breasts). Note: cleavage in Japanese is 谷間.
Mnemonic2: The mountain man uses the water from the valley to bathe.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　谷: valley

Origin: This character depicts a house so large that it can contain an entire valley.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a house big enough to contain an entire valley. might want to live there. And now imagine cleaning it. . . . Maybe not . . .
Mnemonic2: Biodome.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　谷: valley

Origin: Water . . . contain.
Mnemonic1: Think of what happens when the snow on top of the mountains melts: it turns into water and flows down onto the rooftops of all the houses in the valley below.
Mnemonic2: (melt; dissolve; thaw] An ice cube is melting, loosing the water it contained.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　容: contain; form; looks
Kunyomi: と.ける, と.かす, と.く

Origin: Person . . . valley. The key word should be taken in its older sense of "popular" or "commonplace."
Mnemonic1: Mr. T says, "Don´t be like them valley girls, always speaking vulgar language and acting all vulgar! They ain´t nothing but foos!".
Mnemonic2: Mr T meets the vulgar (common) people of the valley and participates in the vulgar customs (folkways). Looking at the vulgar (common) people, Mr T says - “I pity you foo!”.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　谷: valley

Origin: This character shows the typical cloak of valley folk, which, unlike the tailor-made, high-fashion overcoats of city folk, is loose-fitting and free-form. Hence the key word's meaning of abundant.
Mnemonic1: Again using the fact that cleavage in Japanese is called "valley of the chest": a woman with abundant cleavage tightly wraps up her bosom in a form-fitting cloak, but leaving her valley exposed. Another unforgettable image (thank you, thank you, I´ll be here all week).
Mnemonic2: Welcome to cloak-valley, the valley where everyone wears cloaks and every shop sells cloaks. Mnemonic : “cloaks are abundant in the valley”.
Compo: 衤: cloak (RTK)　谷: valley

Origin: The house of flowers or "hothouse" has become a metaphor for a narrow-minded, biased, and intolerant attitude distrustful of change. Tolerance, in contrast, is open-minded and welcomes novelty. The way to encourage tolerance in those who lack it is first to have them see through their own hothouse attitudes, which is the very counsel we are given in this kanji.
Mnemonic1: A tolerant person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend.
Mnemonic2: To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning "beautiful things") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　見: see

Origin: This kanji is a pictograph of a small wicker basket. (The extra short stroke in the middle helps keep it distinct from the character for twenty.) All one needs to add is some image of sweet cakes or breads carried in the basket, and the union of picture and meaning is complete. Take care not to confuse with confectionary (Frame 1203).
SubOrigin: As a primitive, the pictograph's meaning of a wicker basket is used, a small one like the kind used for picnics.
Mnemonic1: Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with sweet baked cookies for granny.
Mnemonic2: Girls are kinda sweet and sexy until they reach their twenties. So 20 minus ONE.
Compo: 甘: sweet; wicker basket (RTK)
Kunyomi: あま.い, あま.える, あま.やかす

Origin: Thread . . . wicker basket.
Mnemonic1: Thanks raulir - As many Japanese perverts know, navy blue threads conceal school girl sweetness underneath.
Mnemonic2: Much like Violet Beauregarde from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Spiderman failed to heed Willy Wonka´s warnings, and upon chewing on the 3 course meal chewing gum turned a very navy shade of navy blue.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　甘: sweet; wicker basket (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . craft.
Mnemonic1: After Spider-Man is whacked in the head with a I-beam, crimson blood flows from the wound.
Mnemonic2: A person's first piece of thread craft is often stained crimson due to bleeding from the needle wounds sustained in the process.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　工: craft; construction

Origin: The special craft of successful taskmasters is their ability to remain constantly on the aggressive, never allowing their underlings a moment to ponder a counter-aggression of their own.
Mnemonic1: Aggression is the craft of a good dominatrix.
Mnemonic2: AGGRESSION is a well-honed craft for any decent taskmaster.
Compo: 工: craft; construction　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Craft . . . power.
Mnemonic1: The great achievements of humankind, were crafts completed by muscle power: the pyramids, the Eiffel tower, etc.
Mnemonic2: All of Arnold Schwarzenegger´s achievements started with him crafting his muscles.
Compo: 工: craft; construction　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Craft . . . snare.
Mnemonic1: Adroit: dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I´ll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the crafting of a bear trap, one must be particularly adroit. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device.
Mnemonic2: To be adroit one must have mastered the crafting of snares.
Compo: 工: craft; construction　丂: snare, slingshot (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . snare. Do not confuse with rot (Frame 1099).
Mnemonic1: This snare isn´t terribly effective, because it´s swinging from a decaying tree. Imagine the tree as being so decayed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess.
Mnemonic2: 枯 wither The decay of an animal in the TREE was from something caught in a SNARE.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　丂: snare, slingshot (RTK)

Origin: What makes a tree begin to wither up, and perhaps even die, is a kind of arteriosclerosis that keeps its sap from flowing freely. Usually this is due to simple old age, as this character shows us. Be sure to picture a wrinkled old tree, withering away in a retirement center so that the commonsense explanation does not take over.
Mnemonic1: A tree withers away as it gets old.
Mnemonic2: When flowers get old they suffer (frame 225), but old trees just WITHER away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad).
Compo: 木: tree; wood　古: old

Origin: Water . . . two . . . snare. Note that the first two strokes for snare doubles up with the first stroke for two.
Mnemonic1: A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are dirty.
Mnemonic2: Washing your dirty snare in water, the extra line represents the water level as you submerge the snare.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　丂: snare, slingshot (RTK)
Kunyomi: けが.す, けが.れる, けが.らわしい, よご.す, よご.れる, きたな.い

Origin: This is the character for the little wooden box that the Japanese use for measuring things, as well as for drinking saké out of. Simply imagine the outside as spiked with a thousand sharp needles, and the quaint little measuring box becomes a drinker's nightmare! Be very careful when you write this character not to confuse it with the writing of thousand. The reason for the difference gives us a chance to clarify another general principle of writing that supersedes the one we mentioned in frame 4: when a single stroke runs vertically through the middle of a character, it is written last.
Mnemonic1: It is a thousand or ten? I need my measuring box.
Mnemonic2: I can fit a thousand needles into my measuring box, but only if I bend the thousand.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　廾: twenty; 2 hands

Origin: Elbow . . . two hands.
Mnemonic1: Opening a stuck valve requires 2 hands and a lot of elbow grease.
Mnemonic2: The cubans build a pipe to flood the USA. Castro just has to turn the valve on it, and USA is flooded. Suddenly, CIA agents tackle him from behind, grabbing both his arms. But Castro manages to open the valve with his elbow, by raising the elbow above his head. Success! USA is no more...
Compo: 厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　廾: twenty; 2 hands

Origin: Our image here is made up of two primitive elements: a sun and a measuring box. Just as the sun can be seen rising up in the morning from - where else - the Land of the Rising Sun, this kanji has the sun rising up out of a Japanese measuring box - the "measuring box of the rising-up sun."
Mnemonic1: This kanji does not mean "get up" or "awake." It means rising, like the rising of a salary, or a promotion. STORY: You know that your salary has RISEN UP when your MEASURING BOX has enough dollar bills in it to reach the SUN.
Mnemonic2: We Measure the Sun to decide when we should Rise Up out of bed.
Compo: 日: day; sun　升: measuring box

Origin: Teepee . . . table. Do not confuse with rise up (Frame 43).
Mnemonic1: When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to ASCEND to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky.
Mnemonic2: When I was a kid I went out camping in a teepee. I ate beans for dinner, and afterwards I produced so much gas that my teepee actually ascended in the air!
Compo: 癶: teepee (RTK)　豆: beans; table (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . ascend.
Mnemonic1: Scuba divers know that when you ascend in the water, your lucidity increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too.
Mnemonic2: A few drops of acid/peyote and the Indians obtain lucidity on their vision quest, as if they were floating in the lucid sky.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　登: ascend
Kunyomi: す.む, す.ます, -す.ます

Origin: Infant . . . human legs.
Mnemonic1: Scene at the baby factory: Manager: "Good news! Your infant has been allotted human legs". Parent to be: "Thanks a lot!".
Mnemonic2: In China, to prevent too many human legs walking around, couples are alloted only one infant…
Compo: 𠫓: infant　儿: human legs

Origin: Metal . . . allot.
Mnemonic1: Everyone is allotted a metal gun (US constitution according to the NRA).
Mnemonic2: What is a gun but a device for allotting pieces of metal? One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...etc.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　充: allot

Origin: Thread . . . allot.
Mnemonic1: Spidey is alloted the biggest crime fighter jurisdiction in NYC because his OVERALL arrest record is the best.
Mnemonic2: According to Greek mythology, there´s a thread alloted to everyone, and its length is the overall determinant of your fate.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　充: allot

Origin: Water . . . infant . . . flood. Be sure to distinguish the two water primitives from one another in making your story.
Mnemonic1: INFANT Moses placed in the WATER and sent down the current of the STREAM.
Mnemonic2: A water-breathing infant (genetically modified?) is caught in a flood, and drifts with the current, apparently enjoying himself in the process.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　𠫓: infant　巛: river (川); flood (RTK)
Kunyomi: なが.れる, なが.れ, なが.す, -なが.す

Origin: Rock . . . infant . . . flood.
Mnemonic1: Sulphur is like a rock, but it can stink like a stream of infant doodie.
Mnemonic2: Infants are baptised in streams inorder to prevent their descent into a place of sulphur and brimstone.
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　𠫓: infant　巛: river (川); flood (RTK)

Origin: If one's eyes perish before death, one remains blind for the rest of life.
Mnemonic1: Deceased eyes! Easy ;).
Mnemonic2: A person with deceased eyes is blind.
Compo: 亡: deceased; perish　目: eye

Origin: Perish . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: You only truly forget her when she has perished in your heart.
Mnemonic2: To forget means that something perishes from your heart.
Compo: 亡: deceased; perish　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: State of mind . . . perish.
Mnemonic1: Busy (as in "occupied") means a state of mind where all other thoughts are perished.
Mnemonic2: ^^^Make the "state of mind" primitive Data (from Star Trek) instead right now and save yourself the headache; ´state of mind´ is too vague! (Data can stay so busy as not to sleep without dying. He´s a robot).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　亡: deceased; perish

Origin: The flowers that perish in the flood are taken here as symbols of an area that has been laid waste.
Mnemonic1: After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream.
Mnemonic2: Laying waste is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like flowers, more like deceased flowers, and it´s flushed down into a stream of sewage. Use "waste" to avoid destroy (#365) demolition (#400).
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　亡: deceased; perish　巛: river (川); flood (RTK)
Kunyomi: あら.い, あら-, あ.れる, あ.らす, -あ.らし
Ex1English: Become rough; run wild; be devastated

Origin: State of mind . . . laid waste.
Mnemonic1: (re: wazzab) The state of mind of the people of New Orleans as they examined their city´s concert hall laid waste can best described as disconcerted.
Mnemonic2: Data walks in and sees Picard weeping. "What is the matter, Captain?" Picard looks up, and replies that his entire home planet has been laid to waste. Data, the master of tact, offers up this consolation: "Ah. I can see how that would be DISCONCERTing". It turns out that the flow of tears was really just because Picard had lost his chance at getting at some rare (and thus valuable) flowers on his home planet.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　荒: laid waste
Kunyomi: あわ.てる, あわ.ただしい
Ex1English: Be flurried, be confused, be in a hurry

Origin: The story of ambition talks of a king walking under the perishing (or "waning") moon dreaming great dreams about his kingdom. (The roots of ambition are from the same word as "ambulate," meaning to walk about.)
Mnemonic1: You´re dead meat, buddy, my ambition is to be king.
Mnemonic2: The ambitions of kings often result in dead bodies.
Compo: 亡: deceased; perish　月: moon; month　王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: Sheaf . . . linen.
Mnemonic1: I hope this works, you say as you stuff a sheaf of stalks under your blanket but above your linens. Your real hope is that your parents don´t find out that you left the house.
Mnemonic2: Wolverine (sheaf, see reap (#1488)) hopes they invent linen sheets that he won´t keep shredding in his sleep.
Compo: 乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　布: linen; cloth
禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　希: hope; beg; request; pray; beseech; Greece; dilute (acid); rare; few; phenomenal

Origin: Finger . . . tongue.
Mnemonic1: Teacher was always telling us to fasten our lips by pulling a zipper shut with our fingers. It always frightened me because I imagined getting my tongue stuck in the zipper.
Mnemonic2: On the plane, you refuse to FASTEN your seatbelt and even go so far as to give the stewardess the finger and stick out your tongue at her. The crew comes and pins you down and forces you to FASTEN it.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　舌: tongue

Origin: Fingers . . . phrase.
Mnemonic1: You approach the thief from behind, stick your finger at his back to fake a gun, and say the phrase "You´re under arrest".
Mnemonic2: Giving the police the finger and a colorful phrase is a surefire way to get arrested.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　句: phrase

Origin: Fingers . . . fit together. Compare frame 698.
Mnemonic1: I tried to PICK UP the bowling ball...but my FINGERS didn´t FIT in the holes.
Mnemonic2: Try PICKING UP a girl by trying to FIT your FINGER in you know what... let me know how that works.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　合: fit

Origin: Fingers . . . cottage.
Mnemonic1: Someone stuck their fingers in my cottage cheese! I´m going to have to discard the lot!
Mnemonic2: The wicked witch from Hansel and Gretel only likes the meaty parts of kids. Outside her candy cottage, you can see a pile of discarded fingers.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　舎: cottage

Origin: Child . . . melon.
Mnemonic1: An orphan will never know the joys on sucking on his mother´s melons........
Mnemonic2: Unlike the celebrated story of Momotaro the peach boy, no one knows the story of the melon boy who was left an orphan.
Compo: 子: child　瓜: melon

Origin: Bow . . . melon.
Mnemonic1: When you use a bow to shoot a melon, the arc varies depending on how far away you are.
Mnemonic2: Joan of Arc ("arc" also means "bow" in french) is practicing with a bow, shooting at melons in a distant field.
Compo: 弓: bow　瓜: melon

English: Projectile, Bullet, Spring Back; Play On (Stringed Instruments)
Origin: Bow . . . simple.
Mnemonic1: Hunting with a bow is too complicated. I´m switching to something simpler--using a bullet.
Mnemonic2: The bow was a weapon for simple times, but nowadays it has been replaced by bullets.
Compo: 弓: bow　単: simple
Kunyomi: ひ.く, -ひ.き, はず.む, たま

Origin: Altar . . . simple.
Mnemonic1: Knowing ZEN’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a ZEN ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE.
Mnemonic2: Simple-minded blond girl (see frame 1928) is very good at Zen, which isn´t surprising since she doesn´t think much. She has this bad habit of meditating perched on the main temple altar, which infuriates the Zen buddhists. When they get up to her and tell her rudely to step down the altar, she just smiles and teases them : "Not very zen are you ?". Who would have thought simple-minded blond girl would teach the Zen buddhists a lesson !
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　単: simple

Origin: The single stroke added to the beginning of the primitive for thread gives the image of threads woven into a single cord. Hence the meaning, lineage.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall give this kanji the meaning of yarn, as the uniting of many threads into a single strand is most obvious with yarn.
Mnemonic1: A single drop of your blood holds the proof of the unbroken thread of your lineage.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman´s lineage (who his family is etc...) can be found in his DNA in a drop of blood. The villain that gets blood of Spidey will be able to find out who is family and lineage is. be carfefull spidey...
Compo: 丿: katakana no　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)
Ex4Kana: にっけいブラジルじん

English: Connect, Relate To, Person In Charge
Origin: Person . . . yarn.
Mnemonic1: Mister T gets a DNA test, and discovers that he was meant to be the person in charge after all.
Mnemonic2: The person in charge usually must come from a long standing lineage of persons in charge.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　系: lineage; yam (RTK)
Kunyomi: かか.る, かかり, -がかり, かか.わる*

Origin: Child . . . yarn.
Mnemonic1: Your grandchild is the child of your DNA.
Mnemonic2: Your child continues the family lineage by passing on your DNA, giving you a grandchild.
Compo: 子: child　系: lineage; yam (RTK)

Origin: Prefecture . . . yarn . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: The prefecture has suspended all DNA research for heart disease because of corruption. All involved will be suspended by their wrists.
Mnemonic2: There's a suspension bridge connecting one of the prefectures to the Japanese heartland. The supporting cables of the bridge actually look like DNA double-helices. That's Japan for you!
Compo: 県: prefecture　系: lineage; yam (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Person . . . door . . . scrapbook. The sense of the key-word is that of having a bias or preference for someone or something.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T is partial to konbini hentai. He reads them for hours every day after work at his local konbini. (Primitive: KONBINI HENTAI, all the magazines(scrapbooks) by every konbini door in Japan).
Mnemonic2: Mr. T is very partial to hentai comic books. I know because he dropped a pile of them when I accidentally bumped into him at the door to kinokuniya!
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　戸: door　冊: counter for books; scrapbook (RTK)
Ex2English: Be one-sided, be prejudiced, be unfair

English: All Over, Everywhere, Counter For Times
Origin: Door . . . scrapbook . . . a road.
Mnemonic1: Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics EVERYWHERE, newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are everywhere here along the road.
Mnemonic2: Go down any road in Japan and you´ll find konbini hentai everywhere.
Compo: 戸: door　冊: counter for books; scrapbook (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . door . . . scrapbook.
Mnemonic1: Raulir has a good idea. I prefer to think of the manga compilations as the individual comics (serials from the anthologies) bound together with a coarse thread down the spine, produced quickly and put on the market. Good way to recycle those pulpy manga, and since when has the consumer not gotten screwed in Japan? ;-).
Mnemonic2: A Japanese comic book is a compilation of the individual chapters (which have already appeared in weekly comic magazines) with a thread (story arc) going through it.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　戸: door　冊: counter for books; scrapbook (RTK)
竹: bamboo (⺮)　扁: level; small

Origin: Row . . . sun.
Mnemonic1: A row of suns is actually a normal, plain, and ordinary occurrence in an infinitely large and expanding universe. FUtsuu.
Mnemonic2: To me, row is way too close to file (#812), so I´m adopting Fab´s meaning of rowboat from the previous frame. Universal Studios went through a number of logo animations before settling on the one they are most famous for: the letters UNIVERSAL orbiting the Earth. One of the most ridiculous of these involved a man rowing himself in a boat around the sun.
Compo: 並: average; row (RTK)　日: day; sun

Origin: Words . . . universal.
Mnemonic1: Musical scores are in a universal language.
Mnemonic2: A musical score can be read, but not like ordinary words. Music is a universal language.
Compo: 言: word; say　普: universal

Origin: The key word refers to one's occupation, or position of employment. Its elements: ear . . . kazoo.
Mnemonic1: Worst post in history: quality checker at the kazoo factory. Imagine the toll on your ears!
Mnemonic2: Buckingham Palace guards are famous for staying at their post no matter what, even if you blow a kazoo in their ear!
Compo: 耳: ear　戠: sword; kazoo (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . kazoo.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman weaves his way through the skyline while listening to his theme song on his ipod. It is played, of course, by kazoos.
Mnemonic2: Play the kazoo magically and the thread will weave itself.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　戠: sword; kazoo (RTK)
Kunyomi: お.る, お.り, おり, -おり, -お.り

Origin: A person of discriminating intellect can tell the difference between mere kazoo-buzzing and words spoken wisely.
Mnemonic1: Words are difficult to discriminate/discern from sounds in the middle of a fiesta.
Mnemonic2: I have discriminating taste. I´d rather listen to the words of a lecture than attend a kazoo concert. (Picture some snobby guy in a tweed jacket turning up his nose at entering a loud raucous kazoo recital).
Compo: 言: word; say　戠: sword; kazoo (RTK)
Ex1English: Be conscious of, be aware of

Origin: Bones . . . decameron.
Mnemonic1: Think of the early Christian martyrs who suffered martyrdom because of their faith. See them held in cells for 10 days (a decameron) before being fed to the lions. They appear before the chanting Roman crowds as bones to be devoured. Think of what was leftover after the lions finished them off....nothing, not even a pile of bones to bury.
Mnemonic2: The boney man martyred himself during his 10 day hunger-strike.
Compo: 歹: bones　旬: 10-day period; decameron (RTK)

Origin: Road . . . silver.
Mnemonic1: If you see silver on the road (eg. gun, armour, sword) => retreat!
Mnemonic2: In the land of Oz, you advance by following the golden road, but you reatreat by following the Silver Road.
Compo: 艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: しりぞ.く, しりぞ.ける

Origin: Eye . . . silver.
Mnemonic1: Be careful putting silverware near your eyes: you could lose an eyeball!
Mnemonic2: Eyeballs made of silver. That´s what they use to play pachinko with, isn´t it?
Compo: 目: eye　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)

Origin: Know . . . sun.
Mnemonic1: Wisdom is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER).
Mnemonic2: Knowing more each day, brings wisdom.
Compo: 知: know　日: day; sun

Origin: To refer to the fullness of humanity that can only be achieved in dialogue with another (person . . . two), Confucius used this character.
Mnemonic1: The beginning of humanity required at least TWO people. Mr. T and Mrs. T!
Mnemonic2: Mr. T shows his humanity by giving two bucks to every homeless person he sees.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　二: two
Ex3English: The five confucian virtues (humaneness, justice, courtesy, wisdom, and sincerity)

Origin: Blade . . . heart. Endure here means long-suffering patience.
Mnemonic1: A ninja must be able to endure the pain of clinging to a ceiling, motionless, for hours at a time, waiting for just the right moment to drop down and thrust the blade of his sword into the hearts of his enemies. By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (ninja) which is why I choose to use ninja as its primitive meaning.
Mnemonic2: Someone with a razor blade stuck in their heart has to endure the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.
Compo: 刃: blade; edge　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: しの.ぶ, しの.ばせる

Origin: Words . . . endure.
Mnemonic1: You are given a speech about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to endure the whole thing, because all you can do is acknowledge.
Mnemonic2: I never read the "acknowledgements" section of books or theses, because they are mostly just boring words that i must endure reading, before i can get to the interesting part. :).
Compo: 言: word; say　忍: endure; bear; put up with; conceal; secrete; spy; sneak

Origin: Let the drop in the upper right-hand corner of this character close the right angle off to make an arrowhead. Whenever we find the needle with that drop in an element that has no other special meaning, we will take advantage of this primitive meaning. At the bottom, we see the grains of rice, the vertical line doubling up for the two elements. Do not confuse with petition (Frame 143).
Mnemonic1: Enemy: "Any final requests?" // MacGyver: "Just an arrowhead and some grains of rice." (MacGyver then throws the grains of rice at the enemy and uses the arrowhead to cut his hands free from the rope.).
Mnemonic2: Robin Hood holds his rich victim at arrowpoint and kindly requests that he hands over his grains of rice.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Request . . . taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: Like in the biblical sense, someone looks skyward and makes a request for salvation from this horrible taskmaster...
Mnemonic2: For salvation you have to request forgiveness from God (the ultimate taskmaster).
Compo: 求: request　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Ball . . . request.
Mnemonic1: Someone files a request to see the family jewels and, to their surprise, you show them your balls!
Mnemonic2: The KING REQUESTS your presence at the ball ... game.
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　求: request

Mnemonic1: The game characters from Worms sleep in their barracks at night.
Mnemonic2: Earthworm jim sleeps in a barracks because he is a soldier... apparently.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　屮: left hand; old grass radical (no. 45)

Origin: Thread . . . earthworm.
Mnemonic1: For remembering the primitive earthworm: Drops of rain were falling so I took my shovel to dig up some earthworms to put them on my fishook..... My story: To have a genuine fishing line you don't just pick up a stick but you also attach some thread onto it and at the end an earthworm must be hung.
Mnemonic2: You need to attach a genuine earthworm to the thread. With plastic bait you won´t catch anything.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　屯: police station; earthworm (RTK)

Origin: Metal . . . earthworm.
Mnemonic1: The metal hook is too dull to even pierce an earthworm....
Mnemonic2: From the earthworm´s perspective, it most be pretty dull when you are put in a metal bowl, just waiting for being put on the hook on the fishing trip the next day.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　屯: police station; earthworm (RTK)
Kunyomi: にぶ.い, にぶ.る, にぶ-

Origin: A sword or dagger posed over a mouth is how the character for "beckoning" is written. The related but less tame key word seduce was chosen because it seemed to fit better with the - how shall we put it? - Freudian implications of the kanji. (Observe if you will that it is not sure whether the long slender object is seducing the small round one or vice versa.)
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning remains the same: seduce. Just be sure to associate it with a very concrete image.
Mnemonic1: A man is easily seduced by a mouth to his "sword.".
Mnemonic2: To seduce is to make a sword of one´s mouth.
Compo: 刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　口: mouth

Origin: Finger . . . seduce.
Mnemonic1: A Geisha beckons you with her index finger, and as you approach she runs her fingers all over her body in an attempt to seduce you. Keyword meaning : “invite”.
Mnemonic2: I bet you all know the Maneki Neko, or beckoning cat, who with its raised fingers tries to seduce all good things (success, happiness and harmony) to its owner.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　召: seduce

Origin: Unlike the meadow with its cliffs, the marshlands are low and near a source of water that feeds them until they get soggy through and through. Why certain land becomes marshy is probably due to the fact that it felt thirsty, and so tried its best to seduce the water over to its side. But, like most inordinate seductions, the last state of the victim is worse than the first. Hence the slushy marsh.
Mnemonic1: The marshlands near Mordor seduce Frodo into gazing upon them, and he falls into the water--splash!
Mnemonic2: A marsh is where water is seduced into the ground.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　召: seduce

Origin: Thread . . . seduce.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman seduces all the girls he´s introduced to.
Mnemonic2: You only get one chance to make a first impression, so make sure you're wearing nice threads when you get introduced to a girl. Otherwise you might have trouble seducing her.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　召: seduce

Origin: The imperial edict, spoken with the force of unquestionable law, is made up of words intended to seduce the masses - be it through fear or respect - to follow obediently.
