Mnemonic1: The mnemonic "words to seduce the masses" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus "seducing" the masses.
Mnemonic2: The emperor did not need an imperial edict; his words were more than enough to seduce Anakin to the dark side.
Compo: 言: word; say　召: seduce

Origin: In order to keep this character distinct from that for an imperial edict (Frame 366), we must draw again on a pun. Think of the order here as a mail order or an order of pizza phoned in by the Emperor for delivery to the imperial palace. Then it will not be hard to put together bundle and muscle to form a story about an imperial order.
Mnemonic1: This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles.
Mnemonic2: Imperial order carries quite a bundle of executive power.
Compo: 束: bundle　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Let the key word suggest shining one's shoes, the purpose of which is to seduce the sun down on them for all to see.
Mnemonic1: Shining is the sun´s seduction.
Mnemonic2: The sun was shining so bright that it seduced Icarus and he flew too close.
Compo: 日: day; sun　召: seduce

Origin: Although the range of possible meanings that the kanji for illuminate can have is about as rich as the connotations of the English word, we need to focus on just one of them: to make something shine. If you glaze a pot and put it into the oven to fire it, you in fact illuminate it. Hence the kanji for illuminate compares the kanji for shining with the primitive element for the oven's fire.
Mnemonic1: SHINING FLAMES illuminate!
Mnemonic2: The sun was seduced to give us fire, by which we illuminate the night.
Compo: 昭: shining; bright　火: fire (灬)
Kunyomi: て.る, て.らす, て.れる

Origin: When one is running after something, the goal that seduces one is said to transcend the seeker.
Mnemonic1: A successful marathon runner needs to be able to transcend seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.
Mnemonic2: To transcend oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to transcend his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and....
Compo: 走: run　召: seduce

Origin: Here we see two parades in competition, each trying to surpass the other by running at high speed from one town to the next. Note the little "hook" at the end of the first stroke of the element for parade. This is the ONLY time it appears like this in the kanji treated in this book.
Mnemonic1: The person in charge of running the parade surpassed all our expectations (by just a extra drop...).
Mnemonic2: The parade of runners are all trying to SURPASS each other - and they end up running all the way to Vietnam (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).
Compo: 走: run　戉: warrior; parade (RTK)
Kunyomi: こ.す, -こ.す, -ご.し, こ.える, -ご.え

English: Purport, Gist, Meaning, Flavor, Distinctive Charm
Origin: Run . . . take.
Mnemonic1: The gist of it is this: We take the money and run!
Mnemonic2: Pickpocket advice: It´s simple, FIRST run, then take. Yeah, that´s the gist of it!
Compo: 走: run　取: take

Origin: In proceeding to a new city or a new job, something in you runs ahead with excitement, and something else holds you back, like a divining rod built into your psyche warning you to check things out carefully before rushing in too wildly.
Mnemonic1: Don´t run into trouble, Dumbledore tells Harry. "Proceed with caution with your wand out.".
Mnemonic2: While running, my magic wand tells me where to proceed.
Compo: 走: run　卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)

Origin: The words of this obituary work like a magic wand, conjuring up the desceased.
Mnemonic1: Obituary. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the words of his obituary until a magician, with a wave of his wand, restored the man back to health.
Mnemonic2: In the Harry Potter world, obituary's are magical. If you wave your wand over them you can hear the person's last words. Creepy!
Compo: 言: word; say　卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)

Origin: As all magicians who have passed their apprenticeship know, one makes one's wand out of a hazel branch and is careful not to alter the natural form of the wood. For the magic of the wand derives its power from its association with the hidden laws of nature, and needs therefore to be kept in its crude, natural state.
Mnemonic1: Wooden wands are the crudest. They are nothng compared to their carbon fibre equivilents.
Mnemonic2: A beginner magician starts with a crude wooden magic wand. Later he´ll upgrade to magicite, of course.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . ivy . . . magic wand.
Mnemonic1: Think RPG. The wizard points his finger to the guard and the ivy he has just animated with his magic wand climbs down the wall to hang the poor guy, opening the way for the adventurers into the dungeon.
Mnemonic2: 3 ways you could hang something: 1) the normal way, with your finger putting something on a hook or whatever, 2) hanging from a vine the natural way, or 3) by means of the magic of the wand.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)　卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)
Kunyomi: か.ける, -か.ける, か.け, -か.け, -が.け, か.かる, -か.かる, -が.かる, か.かり, -が.かり, かかり, -がかり

Origin: Finger . . . antique.
Mnemonic1: My grandma always pinched me with her fingers when i was playing with her antiques. Imagine her fingers, also quite antique, thin, bony and hard, pinching at your hand. "Keep your fingers away from my antiques!!".
Mnemonic2: >_< Don´t you hate when your aunt (who is an antique) PINCHES your cheeks with her antique fingers?
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　亠: roof; hat (RTK)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　古: old

Origin: Picture water dripping on what you thought were precious antiques, only to find that the artificial aging painted on them is running!
Mnemonic1: DRIPS of WATER were collected in ANTIQUE VASES since the museum had a leaky roof.
Mnemonic2: You must never let water drip onto antiques.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　啇: the base; antique (RTK)

Origin: The phrase legitimate wife would have no meaning if there were not such things as "illegitimate wives," taken because one's legal woman has turned into an antique. The very offense of the idea should help you remember the kanji.
Mnemonic1: Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.
Mnemonic2: Your legitimate wife is like an antique bong. Its not your favorite but you still hit it sometimes...
Compo: 女: woman　啇: the base; antique (RTK)

Origin: Can you imagine anything less suitable to do with one's precious antiques than to display them in the middle of a crowded road-way?
Mnemonic1: Think of the term from televison "suitable for all audiences" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more suitable for the whole family than the "antiques road(show)".
Mnemonic2: That old thing in your attic might be suitable to be shown on the Antiques Roadshow.
Compo: 啇: the base; antique (RTK) 　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex1English: Suitable, fitting; fitting one's preference, irresponsible

Origin: Picture your most precious antique (it doesn't matter how old it really is, so long as it is the oldest thing YOU own) being knocked over by your most unlikeable taskmaster, and you have a good picture of how people make themselves enemies for life.
Mnemonic1: The taskmaster became my enemy for life when he smashed the antique vase holding my wife´s ashes.
Mnemonic2: Indiana Jones is an enemy of taskmasters in search of antique artifacts.
Compo: 啇: the base; antique (RTK) 　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . accept.
Mnemonic1: Please accept this finger, you say, imparting it to your yakuza boss.
Mnemonic2: This character depicts a student and teacher. The teacher imparts his knowledge on the student, pointing the way and guiding with the finger. Meanwhile, the student sits there passively accepting the tutelage of his superior.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　受: accept
Kunyomi: さず.ける, さず.かる

Origin: Fingers . . . migrating ducks.
Mnemonic1: You abet the escape of migrating ducks by pointing them the way.
Mnemonic2: Aiding and abetting: You are accuse of abetting a drug dealer, by smuggling drugs in migrating ducks. Of course, this means you have to stick your fingers in their mouths.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　爰: lead on to; migrating ducks (RTK)

English: Damsel, Young Lady Of Noble Birth
Origin: Woman . . . migrating ducks.
Mnemonic1: You want to know about a beautiful woman? There´s a woman that´s so beautiful, the birds migrate to her instead of the sun!
Mnemonic2: As I saw the most beautiful woman on Earth, a flock of migrating ducks passed by and let their poop fly. That just ruined the moment...
Compo: 女: woman　爰: lead on to; migrating ducks (RTK)
Ex2English: Damsel, young lady of noble birth

Origin: Thread . . . migrating ducks.
Mnemonic1: (slacken; loosen; relax; lessen; be moderate; ease] The thread in this story is a cable line, something like a power or phone line. The thread was tense with all the migrating ducks perched on it, but got back to being slackened when the entire flock flew away. (darg_sama-modified,2-11-2005).
Mnemonic2: Spiderman is a slacken off. He lays around all day in the park watching migrating ducks…
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　爰: lead on to; migrating ducks (RTK)
Kunyomi: ゆる.い, ゆる.やか, ゆる.む, ゆる.める

Origin: Unlike the character for warm weather learned earlier (Frame 1560), this kanji and its key word can also refer to the warmth of human congeniality. Its elements are: sun . . . migrating ducks.
Mnemonic1: Note: Just confirming Heisig has confused these two characters. This is used primarily for weather and climate (and colours).
Mnemonic2: A massive group of migrating ducks is blocking the warmth of the sun as they pass over your house/barbecue/picnic. Their formation is so humongous they block the warmth for a good 10 minutes while they pass over. Mnemonic for the migrating ducks primitive : the migrating ducks stick together like the best of friends, flying together as one (fifth stroke), they are not easy prey for the great eagles / vultures.
Compo: 日: day; sun　爰: lead on to; migrating ducks (RTK)
Kunyomi: あたた.か, あたた.かい, あたた.まる, あたた.める

Origin: Pegasus . . . see.
Mnemonic1: Microsoft Outlook works about as well as a pegasus that can´t see: they both crash all the time.
Mnemonic2: I used to hate birds.They´re loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a pegasus. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to look up. I saw it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my outlook completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.
Compo: 隺: bird flying; pegasus (RTK)　見: see

Origin: Pegasus . . . power.
Mnemonic1: Mnemonic "pegasus persuasion power". I think of the hippogriff from Harry Potter as being like a pegasus. To befriend a hippogriff, you have to persuade it you mean no harm, you can do this if you have "pegasus persuasion power".
Mnemonic2: It would take a powerful argument to persuade me Pegasus was real…
Compo: 𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . Pegasus.
Mnemonic1: I have Eric Cartman of the “South Park” animated series, wearing a cop uniform, riding a wooden Pegasus (such as on a funfair), and yelling “RESPECT MY AUTHORITAH!!!”.
Mnemonic2: No one has the authority to tie up a pegasus to a tree!
Compo: 隺: bird flying; pegasus (RTK)

Origin: Again I cannot resist sharing my own associations. If you've ever seen Disney's animated interpretation of classical music, "Fantasia," you will recall what was done there with Beethoven's "Pastoral Symphony" (the 6th), and the flying horses that figured in it. The mares are bathing in the stream and the stallions begin to gather. As dusk sets in, the flying horses all start yawning and pair off for the night: a perfectly delightful portrait of delight.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her delight when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday... and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly... hence the yawn.
Mnemonic2: I would be delighted if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.
Compo: 𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)

Origin: Turkey house . . . bird. The first element appears on only one other occasion, back in frame 609.
Mnemonic1: Do you know how cranes came to be? Well, they used to keep the poor bird cooped all the time. But the crane really wanted to be free, so it would always streatch its head and neck out of the coop trying to be free.
Mnemonic2: The original version of the "Ugly Duckling" was about a crane who grew up in a turkey coop. All the other birds made fun of it for not having a wattle or a snood or fanning its tail...
Compo: 寉: crane (bird)　鳥: bird
Ex1English: String of a thousand folded paper cranes

Origin:
On the left you see the rock, which is familiar enough. But pay attention to the right. Taking careful note of the unusual stroke order that has the "chimney" on the house doubled up with the first stroke of the turkey, we may see the right side as a turkey house (or "coop").
We shall see this pattern only on one other occasion (Frame 2093), but even for these two characters it is well worth the trouble to single it out as a primitive.
Mnemonic1: To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!
Mnemonic2: You´ve heard the expression "killing two birds with one stone." (一石二鳥 is-seki-ni-chou). We´ll, there´s another one that roughly translates as "killing an entire coop with a giant boulder. " That´s the method that hunters use when they want absolute assurance of taking home a bird.
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　冖: crown 　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)
Kunyomi: たし.か, たし.かめる

Origin: State of mind . . . mandala.
Mnemonic1: I´ll focus on the mandala primitive here. I guess Heisig chose this keyword for phonetic reasons and as a character it´s the "man" in mandara/mandala (曼荼羅). A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the sun representing the cosmos, the eye represents the human observer, the crotch represents the animal instincts.
Mnemonic2: He´ s often ridiculed for having his eye on crotches all day.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　曼: wide; mandala (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . mandala.
Mnemonic1: One obscure Tibetan sect-- the Otaku cult-- has an unusually loose interpretation of mandala drawing practice. Instead of traditional mandalas they draw mangas (漫画). They then pour water on the image to wash it away, and begin anew.
Mnemonic2: Even NELSON MANDALA dreams of drops of WATER glistening on comic book/ anime girls with LOOSE morals. (This story has been edited in response reports).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　曼: wide; mandala (RTK)

Mnemonic1: You know how missing childrens´ pictures often appear on milk cartons? Well here we have a missing hare. His concerned family is having his picture printed on the backs of receipts and even on stamps. So far, however, there has been no SIGN OF THE HARE.
Mnemonic2: rabbit ears.
Compo: 卯 : sign of the hare

Origin: Fingers . . . box . . . stamps.
Mnemonic1: They would repress dissents by cutting off their fingers and mailing them to relatives in small boxes (of course including stamps for proper postage).
Mnemonic2: A true stamp collecting nerd won´t be able to repress the urge to get his fingers on the latest box of collector stamps!
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　卬: high

Origin: This character is used both for lying on one's back faceup, and for looking up to someone with respect and awe. Its elements: person . . . box . . . stamps.
Mnemonic1: Mr T with the post package at the post office: ´these stamps don´t stick to the box, foo´ Postguy:´ Try it again but this time with the stamp, face-up.´.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T, his "acting career" in its twilight, must now FACE-UP to the fact that his mug will never appear on a BOX of cereal or on a STAMP.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　卬: high

Origin: Box . . . stamps . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Welcome home daddy! Is that box for me? You were on the road a long time! I collected all the stamps from the letters you wrote me :-) …
Mnemonic2: Stamp-collectors sit and wait on the road to welcome new mail arrivals.
Compo: 卬: high　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex4English: Fight the attack of an enemy

Origin: Tree . . . receipt . . . stamp.
Mnemonic1: Having decided to use SIGN OF THE HARE rather than RECEIPT and STAMP my mnemonic goes as follows: The WILLOW is the TREE that droops likes a HARE´s ears.
Mnemonic2: A strange thing about the japanese willow tree is, it grows eggs... but the eggs have no yokes. weird eh?
Compo: 木: tree; wood　卯: the hare

Origin: Receipt . . . stamp . . . and a drop in each side to represent a little smear of egg yoke. The third stroke is drawn slightly higher to close the egg up tightly and keep the yoke inside.
Mnemonic1: The Easter Bunny dropped an egg on my desk and got yolk all over my receipts and stamps.
Mnemonic2: The 卯sign of the hare (#2041) hides eggs in his ears for Easter…
Compo: 卯: the hare　丶: dot; drop　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Zoo . . . bundle. Note that the element for zoo is flattened out on the left just as leg (Frame 1372) had been. This is the only time we will meet this form in this book.
Mnemonic1: (True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.
Mnemonic2: This kanji is so strange that it was alienated at the kanji zoo. The bundle of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.
Compo: 疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)　束: bundle

Origin: Bundle . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the bundled sticks in the middle of the road. (dingomick).
Mnemonic2: Uh oh. The stork just dropped the bundle of joy in the middle of the road. Somebody save it, quick!
Compo: 束: bundle　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: はや.い, はや-, はや.める, はや.まる, すみ.やか

Origin: Flag . . . sheep . . . road.
Mnemonic1: A sheep crossing guard waves a SLOW flag for his fellow sheep crossing the road.
Mnemonic2: Road sign (flag): "Sheep on highway! Drive slowly.".
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　羊: sheep　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: おく.れる, おく.らす, おそ.い

Origin: Take the first two strokes in the sense we gave them back in frame 10, as the pictograph of a cross, and set it on a road to create a "crossing."
Mnemonic1: Cross-road.
Mnemonic2: This kanji appears in the remarkable compound, 辻斬り 【つじぎり】 (n): killing a passerby in order to test a new sword. Imagine a cross by the road, at a busy crossing, marking the spot of the unfortunate passerby´s death.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Here we see a crossing in the form of a barbed fishhook, suggesting a swifter alternate not only to the roundabouts used in Europe but also to the "cloverleaf" design used on superhighways in the United States.
Mnemonic1: The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.
Mnemonic2: In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image ten giant fish hooks sweeping across the road, with our hapless hero ´froggy´ forced to make a swift crossing or end up as fish bait.
Compo: 卂: to fly rapidly　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Muscles . . . mouth. This is the only case in which the primitive for muscle appears on the left; note should be taken of the fact in composing one's story.
Mnemonic1: If you eat anymore, you will be adding more カロries. (katakana karo).
Mnemonic2: This is Power Mouth, the most annoying neighbour in the world who always has something to add.
Compo: 力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　口: mouth
Kunyomi: くわ.える, くわ.わる

Origin: A group of unquenchable mouths sets out on a march across the country, drinking water wherever they find it until the water supply has dwindled to a trickle, triggering a national disaster.
Mnemonic1: When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to DWINDLE.
Mnemonic2: When water supplies dwindled, the population became a horde of dry mouths, marching to seize the water in the neighboring kingdom.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　戍: protection; march (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Picture a march of flames demonstrating against the Fire Department for their right to destroy, but being doused with water by the police riot squads.
Mnemonic1: Water flows down to destroy the march of fire.
Mnemonic2: Use a water cannon to destroy a line of marching fire monsters. I keep mixing this one up with disaster (#167) and demolition (#400). Remember, you DESTROY monsters (think of the Godzilla movie "Destroy All Monsters!"). Fires and floods are natural DISASTERs. And DEMOLITION is something you carefully do while wearing protective garments. (vaguely based on stefanot´s balrog story).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　戍: protection; march (RTK)　火: fire (灬)
Kunyomi: ほろ.びる, ほろ.ぶ, ほろ.ぼす

English: Might, Power; Majesty, Threaten By Force
Origin: Here we see a march of women demonstrating on behalf of equal rights, something extremely intimidating to the male chauvinist population.
Mnemonic2: Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of "dignity" and "threaten." I can see how a march of women in Japan would be seen as intimidating by most men.
Compo: 戍: protection; march (RTK)　女: woman

Mnemonic1: To upbraid someone, you criticize them in a menacing way. In other words, you jaw at them with your MOUTH until both sides of their face turn RED (hence the double-red).
Mnemonic2: Tip: Heisig later names 赫 "red + red" as incandescent (#2908). Story: "So the boss upbraided you, huh?". "Yep, his mouth was incandescent.
Compo: 口: mouth　赤: red　赤: red
戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　口: mouth　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)

Origin: The first three elements, fiesta . . . mouth . . . floor, appeared together once already in frame 380. Beneath them, once again, the heart.
Mnemonic1: She was beguiled/mislead by his charm: at the party he kissed her on the mouth, they did it on the floor and thus he stole her heart. Poor girl!
Mnemonic2: The same cowboy from frame # 356 (elements mouth, floor and fiesta), kisses the floor with his mouth, once again, before going to the fiesta. There, he uses his good looks to beguile women (gets them to buy him drinks or such), by playing with their hearts.
Compo: 戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　口: mouth　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: From its original meaning of a defined area or zone, a range has also come to mean a grazing land where cowboys roam and do whatever it is they do with cows. When the herds have all been driven to market, there is a great homecoming fiesta like that pictured here. As soon as the cowboys come home, home on the range, the first thing they do is kiss the ground (the mouth on the floor), and then get on with the fiesta.
Mnemonic1: An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight.
Mnemonic2: Instead of Heisig´s "Fiesta" I use "Spear". Why? A spear is just a DROP extra on an Arrow. 域, range actually means range as in limits/boundary/border sort of range(In a box it was the old meaning for Country國 (581). Ok way too much etymology here, but back to story. With your SPEAR standing in a HOLE on the FLOOR with SOIL to its left9as you dug some out), you can see the RANGE of the spear in attacking a possible enemy (re Diablo and other RPGs, spear´s have range).
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)

Origin: Cornucopia . . . crotch. Keep distinct from both fare (Frame 1079) and salary (Frame 1449).
Mnemonic1: Prostitutes can make a veritable cornucopia of income by using their crotches -- they put the "come" in "income." (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like profit (#906) or earnings (#893)).
Mnemonic2: Women love men with money. If you have a high income you can get a cornicopia of crotches.
Compo: 丩: to join; cornucopia (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)
Kunyomi: おさ.める, おさ.まる

Origin: Thread . . . inside.
Mnemonic1: Have you heard about patients who have surgery and the doctor mistakenly leaves a medical instrument INSIDE the patient’s body and proceeds to stitch up the patient’s incisions with stitching THREAD? Can you say “malpractice SETTLEMENT”? .
Mnemonic2: Spider-Man was working as a surgeon´s assistant. By accident, he threw his spider webs inside the patient, causing his death. Fortunately, the hospital reached an out-of-court settlement with the victim´s family.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　内: inside
Onyomi: ノウ, ナッ-, ナ, ナン, トウ
Kunyomi: おさ.める, -おさ.める, おさ.まる

Origin: South . . . chihuahua.
Mnemonic1: A South Korean street vendor is offering chihuahu snacks.
Mnemonic2: If you go to someones place and the food sucks, you lower it down south of the table as an offering to their dog.
Compo: 南: south　犬: dog (犭)

Origin: A tribute has a kind of double-meaning in English: honor paid freely and money collected by coercion. Simply because a ruler bestows a noble name on a deed is hardly any consolation to the masses who must part with their hard-earned money. Little wonder that this ancient craft of getting money by calling it a tribute has given way to a name closer to how it feels to those who pay it: a tax.
Mnemonic1: This next song is a TRIBUTE to a little SHELLFISH friend of mine who was tragically crushed by an I-shaped table..
Mnemonic2: Tribute is the craft of raising money.
Compo: 工: craft; construction　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Clock . . . shellfish.
Mnemonic1: Whatever you covet at the moment (now), can be bought with money. Well, _almost_ anything....
Mnemonic2: One begins one's life coveting money. One ends one's life coveting time -- those precious seconds ticking away on the clock. Remember to always put time over money (in this kanji and in life).
Compo: 今: now; clock (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)
世: generation; world　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Part . . . shells/money.
Mnemonic1: In the case of true poverty, not having money is only part of the problem. There are other components as well, like lack of education, class structuring, etc., but that doesn´t really matter. Just remember that the money is only part of it, not the whole.
Mnemonic2: Parting with your money will lead to poverty.
Compo: 分: part; segment　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Responsibility . . . shells/money.
Mnemonic1: It´s your own responsibility to pay the bus fare with the correct number of shells/money.
Mnemonic2: In Japan they have automatic ticket gates so you cant easily cheat on your train fare. In England however the ticket gates are fairly open. It is a different kind of system. In England you are given the RESPONSIBILITY to put in the right amount of MONEY, but if you are caught cheating, the fines are stiff and you feel like a real CHINCHIN. "un.CHIN".
Compo: 任: responsibility　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Substitute . . . shells/money.
Mnemonic1: In order for the bank to lend you money, you need to put up some sort of collateral as a substitute for the money.
Mnemonic2: The poor substitute teacher asks the class to lend him some money for the bus fare home.
Compo: 代: substitute　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)
Kunyomi: か.す, か.し-, かし-

Origin: Change . . . shells.
Mnemonic1: Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don´t confuse with the similar 賃 fare (#1004).
Mnemonic2: This is a freight train that runs on spare change. Imagine getting on the freight train with a bunch of spare change. You put in some change and it starts up...goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there´s actually a slot for spare change and one for regular shells. Your call, but it seems to prefer spare change over shells.
Compo: 化: change　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: The first shells (money) you earn, you use to pay your debts. From then on, the next shells you accumulate become your assets.
Mnemonic1: Assets are the next best thing to money.
Mnemonic2: The first SHELLS you get you obviously spend, but the NEXT SHELLS are your ASSETS, you should bury them in a low safe place (placement!).
Compo: 次: next; second (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Two husbands . . . shells.
Mnemonic1: Out of two potential husbands, which would you approve of? Well, the one with shells (money) of course!!!
Mnemonic2: Bush´s campaign- "John Kerry approves using taxpayers´ money to support gay marriage. I don´t." "I approve this message".
Compo: 夫: husband; man　夫: husband; man　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)
Ex2English: Approval or disapproval, yes or no

Origin: Two husbands . . . day.
Mnemonic1: A show like "Trading Spouses" called "exchanging husbands" where 2 husbands are exchanged for a day (thanks dingomick).
Mnemonic2: Marge´s dream: to exchange Homer for another husband for just one day.
Compo: 夫: husband; man　夫: husband; man　日: day; sun
Kunyomi: か.える, か.え-, か.わる

Origin: Water . . . exchange.
Mnemonic1: When a submarine or similar vessel SUBMERGES an EXCHANGE of air for WATER takes place in special compartments.
Mnemonic2: The two husbands exchange for a day on the reality TV show (see exchange (#842)) finally goes underway. One of the two husband´s first job is to fix the water faucet in his new family´s apartment. Unfortunately, he isn´t very good at fixing things and after a few failed attempts the entire apartment is submerged in water.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　替: exchange

Origin: Receipt . . . dagger . . . shells. Though the meanings are related, do not confuse with make a deal (Frame 471) or wholesale (Frame 1499).
Mnemonic1: There´s a buyback program where you can trade in your dagger for money. But it´s quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the original receipts can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers.
Mnemonic2: The new RANSOM note (a receipt stuck to a door with a dagger) from DETAIN (1423) appears again (probably after you went to the field as instructed) now gives instruction to TRADE the victim for CURRENCY you were told to bring.
Compo: 卯: the hare　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Receipt . . . dagger . . . rice field.
Mnemonic1: The use of RANSOM NOTE (think of a receipt with a dagger through it on a door) works great with DETAIN. Here the RANSOM NOTE says that the girl has been DETAINED in an undisclosed location. To get her back take the RANSOM to a empty FIELD.
Mnemonic2: Got a receipt for that dagger, son? If not, we´re going to detain you and send you to work in the rice fields.
Compo: 卯: the hare　田: rice field; brain (RTK)
Kunyomi: と.める, -と.める, -ど.め, と.まる, とど.まる*

Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　留: detain; fasten; halt; stop

Origin: Add . . . shells.
Mnemonic1: When someone at work gets married, you pass around an envelope to which you add some money and a card which you sign with your congratulations.
Mnemonic2: Congratulations are so much better when you add money to them.
Compo: 加: add　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Add . . . trees. Hint: if you ever played with an "Erector Set" or "Tinker Toys" as a child, don't pass up the opportunity to relate it to this kanji's key word and the element for trees.
Mnemonic1: Instant wood. Just add Viagra.
Mnemonic2: I´m not sure I know about erector sets or tinker toys but I do know about jenga. You play by taking wooden pieces from the middle of a wooden tower and adding them to the top. In this way you erect a very unstable structure.
Compo: 加: add　木: tree; wood

Origin: Water . . . nine . . . tree. From those elements you must compose a plot for the key word, dye. Here, as elsewhere, any of the alternate meanings of the primitives may be used, provided they do not require a position other than that of the kanji in question.
Mnemonic1: To make this dye, I used water and the barks of nine different trees.
Mnemonic2: The baseball team hangs their freshly dyed dripping jerseys at the top of a tree to dry.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　九: nine; baseball (RTK)　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: そ.める, -ぞ.め, -ぞめ, そ.まる, し.みる, -じ.みる, し.み

Origin: Profit . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: The Japanese pear tree is the most profitable in the world, because it produces its fruit in pairs (sorry for the awful pun].
Mnemonic2: And a profit in a pear tree...12 days of christmas.
Compo: 利: profiit　木: tree; wood

Origin: Person . . . sunglasses . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: My wise person says greatness does not come from wearing shades (sunglasses) but from planting trees to shade everyone.
Mnemonic2: Mr T stands in front of you, his greatness radiating out from him so brightly. You need to put on your sunglasses and hide behind a tree to even talk to the guy. "Recognise, foo!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　舛: sunglasses (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Purse . . . shells.
Mnemonic1: Inside your purse is all of your money and your keys (き) etc. All of your precious valuables.
Mnemonic2: Frodo kept the precious in the purse but did a switch with some worthless shells when he went to sleep. Heres gollum opening the purse "ahhh my preciousssssss.....why you m***** *****!!!!!.
Compo: 中: middle; in (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)
Kunyomi: たっと.い, とうと.い, たっと.ぶ, とうと.ぶ

Origin: Water . . . precious.
Mnemonic1: Man continues to defile precious water and it may prove to be his downfall (Think of Exxon, BP, etc.).
Mnemonic2: ...Faramir and Frodo watched the tiny creature far below. "Shall we shoot him?" Faramir asked. "This Gollum has defiled the waters of the Forbidden pond, looking for his Precious, and for that the penalty is death"...
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　貴: precious
Ex1English: Crush, smash; butcher, kill; ruin, wreck

Origin: Precious . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Bequeath is an odd old word, isn´t it? Basically, it just deals with how I want my precious possessions dealt out, after I die, later down the road. "Being of sound, but antiquated, mind, I bequeath this to you!".
Mnemonic2: Bilbo bequeathes the "PRECIOUS" to Frodo, who will carry it on the long ROAD to Mordor.
Compo: 貴: precious　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: This kanji takes away the maestro's baton and replaces it with a purse. The road represents his being dispatched on his way a san obvious misfit. You will remember that when he did have his baton, he was being chased down the road by his fans. All of which shows what a difference a single stroke can make!
Mnemonic1: Bond has stolen a lady spy's purse while she was asleep after their evening together. When she discovers it's gone, she dispatches some henchmen on the road after him to dispatch him, but Bond evades them and escapes with the purse.
Mnemonic2: Apart from meaning DISPATCH, this kanji can mean "to give (to someone lower than you)," "to do," and to even "have intercourse." STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to DISPATCH some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO´S baton? You don´t wanna know...
Compo: 中: middle; in (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　㠯　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: つか.う, -つか.い, -ず.かい, つか.わす

Origin: Maestro . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Maestro, coattails flapping wildly, is being chased down the road by his fans.
Mnemonic2: Maestro primative = James Bond. Here he gives chase down the road to the bad guys. I´m thinking of the car chase in ´The Man with the Golden Gun´ - NOT pursue (#539). I think about ´Race N Chase´ (a scalextric type toy)...there were no pigs in ´Race N Chase´, only cars.
Compo: 𠂤: maestro (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: To urge someone to do something, you make the way as appealing as possible, perhaps even white washing it a bit.
Mnemonic1: When you have the URGE to go to White Castle, you know it´s time to hit the road.
Mnemonic2: When you start down the road of cocaine, you´re sure to feel some pretty bad URGEs soon.
Compo: 白: white　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex1English: Draw near, press; become acute, grow tense

Origin: When you stop at an inn for an overnight rest, all you expect is a bit of water for a wash and a set of clean white sheets to wrap your weary bones in.
Mnemonic1: Please supply a guest who stays overnight with WATER and WHITE sheets.
Mnemonic2: When I go to an OVERNIGHT party, all I need is a bit of water and some of that hard white. (crack). (not really, but come on. much easier to recall than white sheets).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　白: white

English: Older Sibling Of Parent, Count, Earl
Origin: Person . . . white dove.
Mnemonic1: If Mr T was white I am sure he would have been commander in chief of the USA, he just the sort of clown Americans love to vote for. (NB: I tried with the indian chief motif but kept adding feathers by mistake).
Mnemonic2: Mr T was originally supposed to be the chief of the A-Team, but then the producers realized that America didn´t want to see a Black guy as the chief of a prime-time TV show. So here, we see Mr T doing a bunch of cocaine, and then spreading it all over his face to look white, and trying out for the part of Hannibal. The directors were so impressed that they let him stunt double for Hannibal in a few episodes. OR, Mr T chiefin´ on some crack cocaine. You make the call.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　白: white

Origin: Fingers . . . white.
Mnemonic1: (Image: the most snooty prim and proper English Lord with white gloves clapping only with his fingers. "Oh bravo old chap. Bravo...").
Mnemonic2: I clapped so hard, my fingers became white.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　白: white
Ex1English: Time, beat, rhythm; chance, the moment

Origin: A bow . . . wrapped around a walking stick.
Mnemonic1: Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier´s weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences.
Mnemonic2: Send your condolences to the old geezer whom you shot the walking stick into with your bow. (see pull (#1232)).
Compo: 弓: bow　丨: line; stick

Origin: Water . . . dollar sign.
Mnemonic1: Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary water, but it will instantly seethe when it comes in contact with counterfeit dollar bills. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes).
Mnemonic2: When his daughter used a lot of water for her shower, the father could practically see the dollar signs, so he was seething with anger.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　弗: dollar

Origin: Puppet . . . oven fire.
Mnemonic1: I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use "puppet." So i thought of "voodoo doll" but then found "love doll" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit...
Mnemonic2: There is a lesser known voodoo practice of boiling a puppet over an oven fire, to really make your victim feel the heat!
Compo: 者: person; puppet (RTK)　火: fire (灬)
Kunyomi: に.る, -に, に.える, に.やす

Origin: Dollar sign . . . shells/money.
Mnemonic1: An expense is an expense, whether you put it in dollars or in local money.
Mnemonic2: A dollar sign next to an amount of money denotes an expense.
Compo: 弗: dollar　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)
Kunyomi: つい.やす, つい.える

Origin: Horns . . . dollar sign.
Mnemonic1: Younger brothers are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little horns on him and the dollar signs on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme.
Mnemonic2: The younger brother was a horny dollar -chasing bastard.
Compo: 丷: animal horns (RTK)　弔: condolences　丿: katakana no

Origin: The key word No. is the abbreviation for "number." Its elements: bamboo . . . dollar sign.
Mnemonic1: The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future.
Mnemonic2: Bamboo bling is the newest Asian Rapper, No. 1 on the charts right now.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　弔: condolences　丿: katakana no
Ex1English: The first, no. 1; the best; to begin with, above everything else
Ex2English: Order; circumstances, reasons; as soon as

Compo: 弟: younger brother; faithful service to elders　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: By now kanji like this one should "look like" something to you even though it is more of an "ideogram" than a "pictograph." The large mouth on top and the human legs below almost jump off the page as a caricature of elder brother, the one with the big mouth (or if you prefer a kinder image, the one who "has the say" among all the children).
SubOrigin: As a primitive this character will take the meaning of teenager, in accord with the familiar image of the big mouth and the gangling, clumsy legs.
Mnemonic1: My elder brother was basically a mouth on legs when he was a teenager.
Mnemonic2: Mother, why is elder brother´s mouth between the neighbor girl´s legs?
Compo: 口: mouth　儿: human legs

English: Free Of Charge, Just, Only, Ordinary
Origin: When we run across abstract key words like this one, the best way to get an image it to recall some common but suggestive phrase in which the word appears. For instance, we can think of the expression "it's the only one of its kind." Then we imagine a barker at a side-show advertising some strange pac-manlike creature he has inside his tent, with only a gigantic mouth and two wee animal legs.
Mnemonic1: Imagine an animal with only a mouth and legs.
Mnemonic2: My girlfriend insists that the only thing I want from her is what´s between her legs.. She´s drawn me this pictograph to demonstrate. It´s a head and two legs spread apart.. I explain that I also love her breasts, and then she smacks me in the face. I´ll never understand women.. (I keep failing this kanji, hopefully this silly story will help me!).
Compo: 口: mouth　ハ: animal legs (RTK)
Ex1English: Just now; at present, presently; i'm home!
Ex3English: Free of charge; just, only; ordinary

Origin: Wheat . . . devil.
Mnemonic1: Nobody likes the tax man, so here it is only fitting that the person who comes over to take some of your wheat is depicted here as a devil. Keep in mind that in feudal societies there was no kind of money to speak of, so taxes were paid by serfs in wheat to the devils who came over to keep them poor.
Mnemonic2: This is an easy one. Taxes is like the devil taking away your hard earned wheat.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　兑: devil (RTK) (兌)

Origin: Metal that has been pointed (as an awl, a pick, a nail, or a knife) tends to serve the devil's purposes as well as civilization's: our tools are also our weapons.
Mnemonic1: Pointed is the metal devil´s pitchfork.
Mnemonic2: The Horny teenager who worked part time at a gold smelting plant always had uncontrollable errections that pointed out all the time, this is not a good thing to have when you work in a gold smelting plant, surely he will one day end up with a Goldmember!
Compo: 金: gold; metal　兑: devil (RTK) (兌)

Origin: Not inappropriately, this character likens an explanation to the devil's own words.
Mnemonic1: The words of a horny teenager typically fall into one of two categories: either rumors or explanations.
Mnemonic2: The words of the devil incite rumours and false explanations.
Compo: 言: word; say　兑: devil (RTK) (兌)

Origin: To undress is to expose the flesh and tempt the devil in the eyes of one's onlookers. Ignore the moral if you want, but not the devil.
Mnemonic1: HORNY TEENAGERS love to UNDRESS FLESH.
Mnemonic2: Before you undress I should warn you -- the sight of flesh brings out the devil in me.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　兑: devil (RTK) (兌)
Ex4English: Hair removal; falling out of hair

Origin: Gates . . . devil. Keep the connotation of this key word distinct from those of inspection (Frame 1174), revise (Frame 362), and perusal (Frame 919).
Mnemonic1: A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you´re evil enough to get in.
Mnemonic2: As I was reviewing for my exam at a quiet saloon, the devil popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that´s cheating. Besides, I´m just reviewing things I already know. I won´t fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance gates.
Compo: 門: gate　兑: devil (RTK) (兌)

Origin: Altar . . . teenager.
Mnemonic1: It´s a Bar Mitzvah. At the altar, the teenager is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We´ll all celebrate when that part is over!
Mnemonic2: When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the altar at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a teenager.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　兄: elder brother; teenager (RTK)
Ex2English: To congratulate; to celebrate; to observe (a festival)

Origin: This key word is a connector used to link contrasting phrase sand sentences together with much the same flavor as the English phrase but of course. Just picture yourself ready to go off on your first date as a teenager, and having your mother grill you about your manners and ask you embarrassing questions about your hygiene. "Did you have a good shower?" "But of course," you reply, annoyed. So water and teenager combine to give us but of course.
Mnemonic1: If you ask your teenager if what he´s drinking is water (and not Vodka), he will answer "but of course".
Mnemonic2: キョウ But of course, this character really means "situation/condition". "Elder brother gulped some water and said, ´What the hell was Heisig´s mental CONDITION when he came up with this definition? Heisig must have a drinking CONDITION. But of course, if Heisig sticks to water, rather than sake (like me, water quaffing, situation assessing, sober elder brother), his SITUATION may improve.´" (MODEL COMPOUND: 状況 (じょうきょう) state of affairs; conditions].
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　兄: elder brother; teenager (RTK)
Ex2English: War situation, progress of a battle

Origin: State of mind . . . devil.
Mnemonic1: ECSTASY alters our STATE OF MIND and makes us DEVILS.
Mnemonic2: The state of mind that horny teenagers are looking for.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　兑: devil (RTK) (兌)

Origin: In this frame we get a chance to use the kanji we just learned in its primitive meaning of teenager. The needle on top indicates one of the major problems confronting the teenager growing up in today's world: drugs. Many of them will fall under the shadow of the needle at some time during those tender years, but only when a whole generation rises up and decides that "We Shall Overcome" the plague, will the needle cease to hangover their heads, as it does in this character.
Mnemonic1: Ten elder brothers can overcome anything.
Mnemonic2: A teenager addicted to heroine must overcome the needle.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　兄: elder brother; teenager (RTK)

Origin: Two teenagers are seen here standing up to one another, vying for the attention of their peers.
Mnemonic1: TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER!
Mnemonic2: Two crazy brothers vying for the guiness records books of stupidity by trying to stand on their heads the longest.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　兄: elder brother; teenager (RTK)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)　兄: elder brother; teenager (RTK)

Origin: Of all the women of the family, it is the elder sister who has the duty to go to market to do the shopping.
Mnemonic1: Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market!
Mnemonic2: She´s old enough to be allowed to go to the market.
Compo: 女: woman　市: market; city; town

Origin: The younger sister in the family is the woman in the family who, like the newest branch in a tree, is not yet old enough or mature enough to do everything the elder sister can do (See frame 442).
Mnemonic1: My younger sister is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.
Mnemonic2: Is your younger sister a woman? Not yet! Damn!
Compo: 女: woman　未: not yet

Origin: Take care to keep the meaning of this kanji distinct from that for jewel. Think of the most enormous pearl you have ever seen, a great vermilion-colored ball sitting on your ring and making it extremely difficult to move without falling over from the weight of the thing.
Mnemonic1: The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion pearls!
Mnemonic2: King Vermillion is a little queer and likes to wear pearl necklaces.
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　朱: vermilion

Origin: Bones . . . vermilion.
Mnemonic1: A t-bone steak is vermilion - particularly if served rare.
Mnemonic2: Castlevania -- The vermillion skeletons (bones) are particularly hard because they just keep regenerating.
Compo: 歹: bones　朱: vermilion

Origin: Cave . . . beforehand.
Mnemonic1: The preface to all human history was written beforehand in caves.
Mnemonic2: Rename the "beforehand" part to be glove (because you have to wear gloves beforehand if you want to wield the halberd, which is why this primitive is an incomplete halberd). The story: a winter morning. A textbook author is holed up in his tiny office, a veritable cave. He wants to start his masterpiece textbook by first writing the preface. But he can´t get started. He sits and stares at empty paper until evening. It gets cold and he puts on gloves, shivering, but still unable to start his preface.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　予: beforehand

Origin: Wheat . . . drop.
Mnemonic1: Think of REGULARITY in terms of bowel movements. Enough WHEAT in your diet will help your DROPS with improved REGULARITY.
Mnemonic2: Eating plenty of wheat will improve regularity and help you lose weight.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　失: loss; to drop (RTK)

Origin: To drop . . . road.
Mnemonic1: When you get lost, you just take an alternate road to get back on track.
Mnemonic2: When you lose your way, you can always try to tell the wife that you merely took an alternate road. To save time you know. I´m not LOST, I´m just taking an alternate road. Ahem.
Compo: 失: loss; to drop (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex1English: Reshuffle, change (as of government officials), exchange places

Origin: Drum . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: The samurai sitting on the drum is on a stage, and the people below him are rejoicing with their mouths in unison. It helps me to imagine the placement this way.
Mnemonic2: In the taiko (drum (#1444)) song of rejoicing, the drummers shout with open mouths.
Compo: 壴: drum　口: mouth
Kunyomi: よろこ.ぶ, よろこ.ばす

Origin: Sheep . . . horns . . . mouth. Pay special attention to the writing of this character.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a priest´s teaching: "To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God´s flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell.
Mnemonic2: To be virtuous, a good rule to follow is to put your sheepishness (discretion) over your horns (anger) before using your mouth. In other words, "discretion is the better part of virtue".
Compo: 羊: sheep　丷: animal horns (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Thread . . . virtuous.
Mnemonic1: After a day being virtuouos and keeping the city safe, Spiderman´s outfit is in need of some repair. Luckily, as he can shoot out threads darning is very easy for him to do.
Mnemonic2: Darning is too obscure a word for me, I prefer to just think of it as repair. And obviously, repairing someones broken cloth things is a virtuous thing to do, and you need thread to do it.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　善: virtuous

Origin: Flesh . . . virtuous.
Mnemonic1: Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the dining trays are especially virtuous and never let any man touch their flesh.
Mnemonic2: The virtuous vegan will not touch this dining tray because it has had a piece of meat on it.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　善: virtuous
Ex1English: Low four-legged tray for serving food

Origin: State of mind . . . emotion. Hint: the etymology of "remorse" indicates a memory that returns again and again to "bite at" one's conscience and disturb one's peace of mind.
Mnemonic1: Remorse is the state of mind where I feel bad for what I did while I was tired and emotional!
Mnemonic2: Tip: If you are confusing this keyword, remorse, with repent (#625) and regret/resentment (#1460), then note that rEMOrse contains EMOtion.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　感: emotion

Origin: State of mind . . . silver.
Mnemonic1: The athlete´s state of mind is nothing but resentment after getting the silver medal.
Mnemonic2: Data´s greatest resentment is getting a silver medal in Science Olympiad. (Image: Data fuming on the podium muttering about being half robot).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)
Kunyomi: うら.む, うら.めしい

Origin: State of mind . . . once upon a time. The sense of the key word is that of a lost opportunity or bad turn of affairs, as in the phrase "What a pity!"
Mnemonic1: What a pity! My state of mind when i think of the opportunities I missed from once upon a time.
Mnemonic2: Data says "What a pity" when he hears that once upon a time there were no robots.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　昔: olden days; once upon a time (RTK)
Ex3English: Begrudge, be sparing of; value; regret

Origin: Fingers . . . once upon a time.
Mnemonic1: Long ago our ancestors set aside the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it´s 昔 once upon a time (#1184) rather than 旧 olden times (#35) is that they began to use cutlery to eat salad. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in Once upon a time, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.).
Mnemonic2: Once upon a time... Oh hell, you´re just too old for this. You close your fairy tale book and set it aside, pushing it away with your fingers.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　昔: olden days; once upon a time (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . once upon a time.
Mnemonic1: Once upon a time I let Mr T borrow my salad bowl, but he won´t give it back. "This be mine now, foo!".
Mnemonic2: Mr. T borrowed a copy of Cinderella and won´t give it back. He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the Fairy Godmother does her magic.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　昔: olden days; once upon a time (RTK)

Origin: Metal . . . once upon a time.
Mnemonic1: A long time ago, people of the world got confused because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro.
Mnemonic2: Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient "art" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.).
Compo: 金: gold; metal　昔: olden days; once upon a time (RTK)

Origin: This primitive (named for its associations with the kanji of the following frame) is composed of a pair of horns growing out of a brain with a tongue wagging in the mouth beneath. Think of "former" in connection with administrators or heads of state who have just left office but continue to make a nuisance of themselves by advertising their opinions on public policy.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning, increase, comes from the next frame. Always think of something multiplying wildly as you watch.
Mnemonic1: The Artist formerly Known as Prince has the horniest brain around, and I think you can imagine what his wagging tongue is doing...
Mnemonic2: Formerly, horned animals were used to plough the ricefield, and it took all day. Nowadays it´s done by machine.
Compo: 丷: animal horns (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　日: day; sun

Origin: This kanji depicts an increase of soil, multiplying so fast that it literally buries everything in its path.
Mnemonic1: Prices always INCREASE for LAND that was FORMERLY cheaper.
Mnemonic2: Farmers work the land so they can INCREASE their formerly puny crop supply.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　曽: formerly; increase (RTK)
Kunyomi: ま.す, ま.し, ふ.える, ふ.やす

Origin: Flag . . . increase.
Mnemonic1: The strata have piled up in an ever increasing pile of dirt. As the geologists go down the rocks, they flag each stratum with the name of the corresponding era.
Mnemonic2: Archaeologists at a dig site place small flags marking layers or strata of rock. Each of these layers was formerly the top layer. (This is not increase! Hseige keeps messing up).
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　曽: formerly; increase (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . increase.
Mnemonic1: Like the saying goes, Hate just begets Hate. A state of mind that just increases and increases until it explodes.
Mnemonic2: Data´s one true emotion is hate for Prince´s music. (Image: Data hunched over hands to his ears and screaming while Picard bobs to Purple Rain).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　曽: formerly; increase (RTK)
Kunyomi: にく.む, にく.い, にく.らしい, にく.しみ

Origin: Person . . . increase.
Mnemonic1: While a waiter at the Buddhist temple (see FRAME 976), Mr T increases in wisdom and becomes a Buddhist priest.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T and the artist formerly known as Prince, who by the way is a buddhist, want to form a new heavy metal band. Instead of "Judas Priest" they will be called "Buddhist Priest".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　曽: formerly; increase (RTK)

Origin: The presents offered here are money that increases each time you give it away. Do not confuse with the temporal word "present" (Frame 275).
Mnemonic1: Presents represent money that was formerly yours.
Mnemonic2: Imagine if the number of presents you get increases with each birthday. So on your first birthday, you receive just one shell as a present, but the next year it increases to two shells as presents, and so on, increasing and increasing so by the time you´re elderly, the number of shells you´ll get as presents will have increased to an awful lot of presents. GOT IT YET? PRESENTS = SHELLS + INCREASE.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　曽: formerly; increase (RTK)

Origin: To the left we have the primitive for a shellfish, and to the right the kanji we just learned for possess. Keep the connotation of the last frame for the word possess, and now expand your image of shells to include the ancient value they had as money (a usage that will come in very helpful later on). Now one who is possessed by shells is likely to abandon any higher principles to acquire more and more wealth. These are the easiest ones to bribe with a few extra shells.
Mnemonic1: To bribe someone, money is a necessary possession.
Mnemonic2: If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　有: possess

Origin: To those who believe in the inevitability of graft in government, everything has a price - or as this character has it, to each office its outlay of shells.
Mnemonic1: It might sound simple to bribe someone, but then you have to graft the guy above him and the guy below him, and soon you´re just giving shells to each and everyone!
Mnemonic2: When I was caught by the police doing some graft (graffiti), I gave each cop some clams and told them to be on their way. 賄賂【わいろ】 bribe.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　各: each; every

Origin: A certain portion of shells (money) is collected by the warrior from the local villages as he passes through to defray the costs of keeping the land safe, and this is called a levy.
Mnemonic1: A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass.
Mnemonic2: Drove my Chevy to the levy but the levy was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you´ll die. Pay up the clams or you´ll die....
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　武: warrior

Origin: From a burglar's point of view, a fiesta is an occasion to takeout the old lock picking needle and break into the unattended safe filled with the family shells (the old form of money, as we saw in frames 84 and 206).
Mnemonic1: Burglars... those guys!!! Burglars only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)!
Mnemonic2: After the fiesta, we found out that some burglar had stolen our money, probably breaking in with a lockpick needle...
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)

Origin: The part of the apron where one finds the buckle (represented pictorially by the first 5 strokes) is on the sash.
Mnemonic1: First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the "number 1" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan´s #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it´s royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king´s kimono.
Mnemonic2: Beautiful "Miss Housewife Japan" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the number one mountain) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an apron tied with a sash. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.).
Compo: 丗: thirty; buckle (RTK)　冖: crown 　巾: towel
Ex2English: Wear a sword at one's side
Ex4English: Wear, carry; take on; be tinged with

Origin: People that have been "sashed" to something (whether their mother's apron strings or a particular job) for too long become like water that has stopped moving: they start to stagnate.
Mnemonic1: History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one´s karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren´t their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????
Mnemonic2: A moat is a stagnate ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　帯: sash

English: Not Go Smoothly, Astringent, Juice (Of Unripe Persimmons)
Origin: Water . . . footprint . . . sparkler.
Mnemonic1: I think that Heisig meant this as the "slightly bitter but fresh" meaning that it can have to describe foods like lemons (しぶい). So imagine a guy trying a cocktail (water), feeling like he´s been kicked in the face (footprint) and sparks are flying from his tongue. ´How did it taste?´. ´Hmm, yes, slightly bitter, but fresh".
Mnemonic2: If you eat something astringent water will stop the sparkly sensation in your mouth.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　止: stop; footprint (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)
Kunyomi: しぶ, しぶ.い, しぶ.る

Origin: Fingers . . . ear . . . sparkler. Do not confuse with substitute (Frame 1080).
Mnemonic1: Now that I´m a responsible adult, I have to get my vicarious thrills from watching stupid people put sparklers up to their ears and burn their fingers.
Mnemonic2: I put my fingers in my ears to avoid going deaf while getting a vicarious thrill from watching kids light off sparklers and fireworks on Chinese New Year.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　耳: ear　水: water (氵) (氺)
Ex3Kana: カロリーのせっしゅりょう

Origin: This character rightly belongs to the previous lesson, but we held it until now because of the final element, the tail feathers. After the drop at the outset, the next three strokes are completely novel and should be given special attention.
Mnemonic1: In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: "So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna DO it?" "Only if you (ユ) do" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS.
Mnemonic2: Do me from behind, says the bird, as she shakes her tailfeathers.
Compo: 為: do
Ex2English: For the sake of...; so that...

Origin: Person . . . do.
Mnemonic1: A person who claims he didn't do something while he actually did, is telling a falsehood.
Mnemonic2: It depends on what your definition of do, uh, is, says Mr. T giving falsehood about his affair with a peacock.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　為: do

English: Participate, Visit A Holy Place; Go Somewhere; Refer To
Origin: Elbow . . . St. Bernard dog . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: I´m going to visit my grandpa in the hospital. He broke his elbow, and it became really big and contorted into a weird shape. I hope he will be all right!
Mnemonic2: Whenever the postman has to pay a visit to this place, he brings an elbow-shaped thingy that he throws to the St. Bernard.
Compo: 厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: A state of mind . . . visit.
Mnemonic1: Whenever I have to visit the relatives... that puts me in one hell of a wretched state of mind.
Mnemonic2: Data feels wretched because he has no family to visit.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　参: visit (RTK)
Ex2Kana: みじめなおもいをする

Origin: This character is rather like a picture of two of the vertebrae in the spine linked by a single stroke.
Mnemonic1: Spine connects head and body.
Mnemonic2: The spine goes from one opening mouth/opening (mouth/face) to another mouth/opening (genitals). Just think of these openings being enlarged to represent the head and the body. The bottom is bigger because the body is bigger than the face.
Compo: 口: mouth　丿: katakana no　口: mouth

Origin: Person . . . spine.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T don´t take a partner, especially one with no spine. "I pity da foo got no spine", he says.
Mnemonic2: As a PARTNER, I want a PERSON with a strong SPINE.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　呂: spine

Origin: Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for spine. The two other characters in which it is used we can now learn together in this and the following frame. Here a Shinto shrine is composed of house and spine.
Mnemonic1: This Shinto shrine is built with human spines. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for "sedlec ossuary", it´s quite a sight.
Mnemonic2: A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: "house with a spine, Shinto shrine"!
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　呂: spine
Onyomi: キュウ, グウ, ク
Ex2English: Shinto shrine; grand shrine at ise

Origin: Schoolhouse . . . spine.
Mnemonic1: The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation.
Mnemonic2: During the German occupation, this Nazi officer´s occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : "the occupation´s spine schools"). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also "barracks; camp; encapment". This story should help avoid confusion with post (#824) and employ (#1083). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 "detention barracks".
Compo: ⺍: small　冖: crown 　呂: spine

Origin: Schoolhouse . . . insect.
Mnemonic1: Bugs have to go to school to learn how to become lightning bugs. Only the brightest bugs graduate to become lightning bugs.
Mnemonic2: Q: Who´s the smartest insect in school? A: The lightning-bug. Because he´s so bright! (Image: lightning bug in school with glasses, pocket protector, etc. Maybe even have some cool kids teasing him).
Compo: ⺍: small　冖: crown 　虫: insect

Origin: The botanical connotations of the word flourish (to bud and burst into bloom, much as a tree does) are part of the ideal of the schoolhouse as well.
Mnemonic1: The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there´s no room for the students any more.
Mnemonic2: Students are like young trees. They tend to flourish in the schoolhouse.
Compo: ⺍: small　冖: crown 　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: さか.える, は.え, -ば.え, は.える

Origin: Owl . . . tool . . . saying.
Mnemonic1: This owl´s reputation skyrocketed after he created a tool in order to speak human words.
Mnemonic2: By word of mouth, owl-luring tool (raise (#1938)) gained a reputation of amazingly effective and reliable device.
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　八: eight; go in (RTK)　言: word; say

English: Nominate, Cite, Noteworthy Act, Raise (One'S Hand)
Origin: Owl . . . tool . . . hand.
Mnemonic1: The owl was asked to raise his hand if he needed anything, but he had a wing, not a hand! So he made a tool that looked like a hand which he used when he needed to raise his hand. For raiseing, owl has a tool hand.
Mnemonic2: What raises mankind above others is the wisdom of an owl, the use of tools, and his hand with an opposable thumb. (compare with reputation (#1939)).
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　八: eight; go in (RTK)　手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)

Origin: Quarter . . . hand. Be careful to keep this key word distinct from the primitive element of the same meaning we met back in Frame 741.
Mnemonic1: 1) I hold a roll of quarters in my hand when I make a fist. 2) I hold a quarter in my hand as I prepare to play the Iron Fist Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade.
Mnemonic2: Quarter, hand: If you have a roll of quarters in your hand, your fist will deliver a much more effective punch.
Compo: 关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)　手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . owl . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: I was taking a picture of my girlfriend under the cherry tree during 花見, when an owl happened to poop on her at the exact moment the shutter snapped. It´s really my favorite picture , just don´t tell her that.
Mnemonic2: The tree in Japan that represents both wisdom (the owl) and femininity (the woman). This is a sakura (さくら), or cherry tree.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　小: little; owl (RTK)　女: woman

Origin: Vulture . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: Overly gentle women are vultures who want to marry you and steal your money - not true but an easy mnemonic!
Mnemonic2: An eagle must be extra gentle to pick up a dainty woman in its sharp claws.
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　女: woman

Origin: Mouth . . . golden calf.
Mnemonic1: The mouth of the wooly mammoth was so big and furry that plants would actually grow and blossom there.
Mnemonic2: From the mouth of the hell hound blossoms, not flowers, but evil spawns of DOOOOOOM.
Compo: 口: mouth　关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)

Mnemonic1: The queen is not happy. "We (majestic plural) are not amused that the hunger for the flesh of the wooly mammoth has caused it's extinction. Poor Charles is particularly upset.
Mnemonic2: The king says "Only We are allowed to partake of the flesh of the golden calf.".
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　天: heavens; sky

Origin: Flower . . . spool.
Mnemonic1: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Just get a flower and carefully wrap some toilet paper around its stalk. Spool also appears in suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), diameter (#882), sutra (#1360).
Mnemonic2: PRIMITIVE: soiled crotch = soiled underwear. To precent anyone from picking the beautiful flower, the gardner hung soiled underwear on the stalk.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　圣: holy; spool (RTK)

Origin: Line . . . spool.
Mnemonic1: Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a line of thread off a humongous spool until it got to the other side.
Mnemonic2: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Measure the diameter of a column (maybe Nelson´s Column in London?) using a roll of toilet paper. Spool also appears in stalk (#715), suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), sutra (#1360).
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　圣: holy; spool (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . spool.
Mnemonic1: When you´re suspicious, your state of mind twists round and round like a spool of thread.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a loud farting sound on The Enterprise (sorry). Everyone looks around trying to find who did it. The one looking most suspicious is Data. His soiled crotch gives him away.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　圣: holy; spool (RTK)
Kunyomi: あや.しい, あや.しむ

Origin: Car . . . spool.
Mnemonic1: Fact: this kanji is used to denote a certain class of vehicles in Japan whose engines are under a certain size (less than 750cc I think) and are called light vehicles here. Imagine a so-called light vehicle or a light-truck with a load of spools driving down a road ever so lightly, careful not to let any of the spools roll out onto the street.
Mnemonic2: I want to tread lightly on the environment.... That´s why I CAR-SPOOL to work everyday.... I know, lame.
Compo: 車: car　圣: holy; spool (RTK)

English: Pass Through, Longitude, Manage, Sutra, Scripture
Origin: Thread . . . spool.
Mnemonic1: The word ‘sutra’ literally means a rope or thread that holds things together. Here we see that it is a spool that is holding the threads together.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman is intriqued by some of the positions of the karma sutra, but reluctant to take part in an sutra orgy as he´d have to reveal his soiled underwear.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　圣: holy; spool (RTK)

Origin: Plaid . . . fenceposts . . . two. Do not confuse with just so (Frame 414).
Mnemonic1: The Scotsman goalkeeper adjusted himself. He reached down and adjusted the two things between his skinny fencepost legs.
Mnemonic2: HINT: this kanji as a primitive can mean goalkeeper. The "fence posts" are goalposts, and the two goalkeepers wear plaid uniforms (this kanji also means uniform as in even), making them uniform with each other and distinguishing them as goalkeepers from the rest of the team.
Compo: 齊: adjust (RTK)
Ex1English: All together, all at once, simultaneously

Origin: Plaid . . . fenceposts . . . altar. This is a "religious" purification, which distinguishes it from the simple kanji for pure (Frame 1659).
Mnemonic1: Purification? I think of Japanese during new year's eve praying(saying sentences) in front of Itsukushima's shrine torii(fenceposts) and its altar. They expect to enter the new year totally purified.
Mnemonic2: Kind of vulgar, but here the SCOTSMAN got tired of adjusting himself so decided try PURIFICATION. Sadly, he did it by straddling the ALTAR with his skinny LEGS.
Compo: 文: literature; plaid (RTK)　丿: katakana no　示: altar; show (礻)　丨: line; stick

English: Settle, Pay Back, Come To An End, Relieve, Save
Origin: Water . . . adjust. Do not confuse with complete (Frame 101), end (Frame 1452), or perfect (Frame 199).
Mnemonic1: When the goalkeeper finishes the game, he drinks a lot of water and adjusts himself.
Mnemonic2: Finish him! Subzero adjusts the water in your body and crushes you into a few million pieces.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　齊: adjust (RTK)
Kunyomi: す.む, -ず.み, -ずみ, す.まない, す.ます, -す.ます, す.ませる

Origin: Adjust . . . saber. Think of this as a dose of medicine.
Mnemonic1: When my medicine dose is way too large, I adjust it by cutting it into smaller pieces with my saber.
Mnemonic2: We had to adjust his dose slightly, after he went on a rampage with a sabre.
Compo: 齊: adjust (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: To "divide and conquer" you use a saber and a muzzle.
Mnemonic1: When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That´s why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.
Mnemonic2: Divide and conquer - first you cut them up (saber) , then you shut them up (muzzle).
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　口: mouth　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . muzzle.
Mnemonic1: In case of emergency, The Pinnacle has auxiliary guard dogs, but they keep them muzzeled until they´re needed.
Mnemonic2: When you climb the pinnacle you´ll need to take a muzzle of auxiliary oxygen.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: The barrel hoops used by many Japanese farmers to stretch clear plastic over row of vegetables in a garden patch in the hopes of cultivating bigger and bigger vegetables is a way of muzzling the soil.
Mnemonic1: To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it´s unruly, chaotic nature.
Mnemonic2: The illegal immigrants cultivate the land but are socially and politically muzzled (wear muzzles while they work too).
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　立: stand up; vase (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Picture a clam used as a muzzle to quiet the complaints of a fisherman's widow asking compensation for her husband lost at sea.
Mnemonic1: Compensation is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).
Mnemonic2: Compensation is a kind of euphemism for hush money here. Money that muzzles.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: The key word in this frame has do with posting bills to a billboard. In this case, the billboard is standing at the exit to a Chinese restaurant displaying the latest alternative to the tradition fortune-telling cookies. Look closely and you will see rows of leftover shells of clams with little slips of paper sticking out of them posted to the billboard.
Mnemonic1: Fortune teller writes your fortune on a piece of paper and tells you to affix it to a shell and throw into the ocean for it to come true. Picture licking the back of the shell like a stamp and affixing it to the fortune.
Mnemonic2: I gots a fix for your current bad luck: just pass some extra clams over to the fortune teller, and they will make sure you have a very bright fate instore.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　占: fortune-telling

Origin: Rice . . . fortune-telling.
Mnemonic1: This is another way of fortune telling -- throw sticky rice against the wall, and look for the message in whatever sticks.
Mnemonic2: CONDI RICE was told by the FORTUNE TELLER that she will get STICKY...
Compo: 米: rice　占: fortune-telling

Origin: Boulevard . . . bound up . . . brains . . . St. Bernard dog.
Mnemonic1: To maintain the social equilibrium in a future dystopian society, the brains of citizens are bound up (hypnotized). The government is using mental wave emitting statues shaped like St. Bernard´s dogs put alongside the boulevards.
Mnemonic2: I think BALANCE is an easier keyword. I was walking down a busy French boulevard when between the rushing traffic I saw the wierdest thing. BALANCING on the central crash barrier was a St. Bernard dog, BALANCING a fish on its nose. As I looked closer, I realised it was a trick; it was holding the fish´s tail in its teeth, and only pretending to BALANCE it. (keeps the position of the elements!).
Compo: 行: going; journey　勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　犬: dog (犭)

Origin: Fingers . . . four St. Bernard dogs bound up.
Mnemonic1: After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling four bound up St. Bernard dogs: one snap of your fingers and they interchange their positions.
