Mnemonic2: On the snap of your fingers, the four St. Bernard dogs bound up interchange places.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　奐: clear; bright
Kunyomi: か.える, -か.える, か.わる

Origin: The mouth on the left is obvious. The rest is harder. Try this: four St. Bernard dogs bound up in a bunch. Together they should supply a clear enough portrait of a yell, provided you are careful to see all four of them. Note how the final stroke of the four is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the St .Bernard.
Mnemonic1: Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I´m imagining lots of yelping.
Mnemonic2: Yell? You mean, Old Yeller. Here, we see four St Bernard dogs all yelling for a chance to play a part in Old Yeller. They´re so loud that you have to bound them, and their mouths, up.
Compo: 口: mouth　奐: clear; bright

English: Break Off, Cut Off, Come To An End, Without Match
Origin: Thread . . . color.
Mnemonic1: I can't finish my sewing project because the thread color I was using was discontinued.
Mnemonic2: As times move on and fashion tastes inevitably change, threads of certain colors often get discontinued.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　色: color
Kunyomi: た.える, た.やす, た.つ

Origin: This character is used for excusing oneself for a failure of courtesy. The elements are: bound up . . . sun (oddly enough, laid on its side) . . . human legs.
SubOrigin: For the primitive meaning, we shall refer to this character as a rabbit, for which the old form of the character is 兔.
Mnemonic1: Obviously this is the rabbit from Alice, excusing himself and rushing away on his legs, as he has a binding day schedule. This is at the same time an image, with bound=ears, day=head and legs are just legs. The image is used in rabbit (#2093).
Mnemonic2: What is the rabbit´s excuse for being such a jerk? Well he was bound up for a whole day while being stepped on by peoples human legs in some make-up labratory. Yeah I think I can excuse him after knowing that.
Compo: 免: dismiss; rabbit (RTK)
Kunyomi: まぬか.れる, まぬが.れる

English: Let Slip, Deviate From The Norm
Origin: Rabbit . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Word play to differentiate elude/evade: elude ~= e-lewd. Alice is following Mr. Rabbit on the road. Mr. Rabbit flashes her in a lewd way and disappears, completely eluding her.
Mnemonic2: Even though the white rabbit was late, he eluded the wrath of the the Queen of Hearts because Alice was coming up the road.
Compo: 免: dismiss; rabbit (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Rabbit . . . muscle. Notice how the last stroke of rabbit is stretched out to underlie the element for muscle.
Mnemonic1: When RABBITS hop around, they EXERT tremendous force using their MUSCULAR legs.
Mnemonic2: The energizer bunny's exertion of power keeps going and going...
Compo: 免: dismiss; rabbit (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Sun . . . rabbit.
Mnemonic1: At nightfall the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep.
Mnemonic2: This is EASY!!! Japanese people see a RABBIT ON THE MOON (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_rabbit ) and so nightfall is when the sun leaves to make way for the rabbit.
Compo: 日: day; sun　免: dismiss; rabbit (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . horse.
Mnemonic1: If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.
Mnemonic2: Mr Ed ( a famous talking horse ) was finally at a loss for words when told he would need a permit for public speaking.
Compo: 言: word; say　午: noon

Origin: A rabbit's head with the body of a sow represents an elephant. Little wonder that the kanji also means "phenomenon"!
Mnemonic1: An elephant has huge ears, like a rabbit, and a big, fat body, like a sow.
Mnemonic2: An animal with huge ears like a rabbit, and a body fat like a pig... ¡An ELEPHANT! For the "phenomenon" connotation you could use Dumbo, or Joseph Merrick (the "elephant man") ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Merrick ).
Compo: 象: elephant

Origin: Person . . . elephant.
Mnemonic1: Statues of people are made the same size as statues of elephants.
Mnemonic2: One of the most famous statues is of course the Statue of Liberty, which is known for the first thing a person sees when coming into New York. However, did you know that the first thing a person used to see (between the years of 1885 to 1896) was actually a huge elephant statue on Coney Island? It's true too... ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island - search Coney Island Elephant).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　象: elephant

Origin: The two primitives here, circumference and shape, belong naturally to the special connotations that differentiate carving from engraving (see frame 1639).
Mnemonic1: A lathe is used to carve a shape with circumference into wood or metal.
Mnemonic2: Start with a circumference and carve away until you get the shape you want.
Compo: 周: circumference; lap　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: Scenery is depicted as a sun rising over a capital city, which is a bit of natural scenery the city dwellers themselves rarely get to see!
Mnemonic1: Imaging the sun rising over the capital--classic postcard scenery.
Mnemonic2: Anyone who´s been to Kyoto doesn´t need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a sunny day in the old capital, and there´s no better scenery.
Compo: 日: day; sun　京: capital

Origin: Scenery . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: The sun over the capital cast a shadow with the same shape.
Mnemonic2: You're out hiking looking at the SCENERY, suddenly out of the corner of your vision you see a large SHADOW's indistinct SHAPE... could it be a grizzly? (cmp shade (#1592)).
Compo: 景: scenery　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: Finger . . . utmost. This character is used for taking photographs. Note how, conveniently, the element for "take" is included in it.
Mnemonic1: Take the utmost care that you don´t have your finger in the way when you take a snapshot.
Mnemonic2: When I learned photography from my dad as a little girl, he explained the basics to me: "when you take a snapshot, be careful not to put your fingers before the lens, and don´t look towards the sun (this was in the days that photographs would be spoiled by direct sunlight).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　最: utmost

Origin: Capital . . . chihuahua with a human leg in place of one of its paws.
Mnemonic1: In the capital they have been having hearings concerning bioethics and bioengineering they call as their first witness a chihuahua with one human leg.
Mnemonic2: Ahem...CONCERNING your recent science fair project, it was a CAPITAL idea, but the CHIHUAHUA with a HUMAN LEG is freaking out the other contestants!
Compo: 京: capital　尤: superb

Origin: Since few things are as refreshing on a warm day as a cool shower (the water), here we picture an entire capital city treating itself to one, and in full view of everyone.
Mnemonic1: When you´re a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing.
Mnemonic2: The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so refreshing!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　京: capital

Origin: The whale swallows a whole school of fish, who turn their new abode into a proper little fish-capital.
Mnemonic1: If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital.
Mnemonic2: When the whale was first discovered it was the biggest fish people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire capital city!
Compo: 魚: fish　京: capital

Origin: Pinnacle . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . glass canopy . . . human legs . . . spike. You might want to compare the kanji for dissolve (Frame 1123).
Mnemonic1: The Pinnacle, to me, is a city that makes itself out to be perfect but is filled with dirty secrets that photographers are always trying to reveal (see dissolve (#1044) The city´s councilmen have isolated all professional photographers to make sure they don´t photograph these "dirty secrets". (which are up to your imagination).
Mnemonic2: The people of the pinnacle isolate themselves, dissolving any outside friendships.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　鬲: tripod
Kunyomi: へだ.てる, へだ.たる

Origin: Ceiling . . . mouth . . . hood . . . human legs . . . spike . . . insect. This is the maximum number of elements to appear in any story in the book.
Mnemonic1: I have created the element "old camera" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject´s point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air.
Mnemonic2: I´ve seen this crazy thing with only one mouth that can dissolve up to 4 nails and an insect at the same time. Sweet! (It´s a venus flytrap, btw).
Compo: 鬲: tripod　虫: insect

Origin: The word resemblance should suggest, among other things, a son's resemblance to his father. A "chip off the old block" is the way we often put it, but the character is more simple. It speaks of a little bit of flesh.
SubOrigin: When used as a primitive, the sense of resemblance is replaced by that of spark or candle. (If you want an explanation: the kanji for moon also carries a secondary sense of fire, which we omitted because we are keeping that meaning for other primitives.)
Mnemonic1: Using DNA matching, a very little bit of flesh can be used to show the resemblence between family members.
Mnemonic2: Hey baby, it might be a little bit of flesh now, but in a moment it´ll bear a strong resemblance to a candlestick.(nudge nudge, wink wink).
Compo: 小: little; owl (RTK)　月: moon; month

Origin: Among the many things water is useful for is extinguishing fires, and that is just what we have here. First of all, take the water at the left as the drops of water that are used to depict water in general. In the best of all possible worlds, the most efficient way to extinguish a fire would be to see that each drop of water hits one spark of the conflagration. An unthinkable bit of utopian fire fighting, you say to yourself, but helpful for assigning this key word its primitives.
Mnemonic1: To extinguish a SPARK, you need WATER.
Mnemonic2: You need a few drops of water to extinguish the candle.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　肖: resemblance; spark, candle (RTK)

Origin: The word nitrate should immediately suggest a beaker of nitric acid, which, as every high-school chemistry student knows, can eat its way through some pretty tough substances. Here we imagine pouring it over a rock and watching the sparks fly as it bores a hole through the rock.
Mnemonic1: That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured nitrate acid on it.
Mnemonic2: Salpetre is the common name for Nitrate coming from Latin "sal petrae" or stone salt. It is also a component of gun powder so including a candle in this kanji can be quite explosive!
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　肖: resemblance; spark, candle (RTK)

Origin: As the days grow shorter and shorter, or so the northern European myth goes, the fear grows that the sun will take its leave of us altogether, abandoning the world to total darkness. Fixing candles to the branches of evergreen trees, it was believed, would lure the sun back (like things attracting like things), whence the custom of the lighted tree that eventually found its way into our Christmas customs. The story is a lot longer and more complex than that, but it should help to fix the image of climbing high up into the treetops to fix candles on the tree.
Mnemonic1: At Christmas time, on the treetops, people used to place great big candles (Now we usually place a star instead).
Mnemonic2: If you cut off the treetops, they still resemble the trees they used to be part of. Treetops=tree resemblance.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　肖: resemblance; spark, candle (RTK)
Ex1English: Tip, end; tip of a twig

Origin: Long before the invention of the carpenter's plane, people used knives and machetes (or here, sabers) to smooth out their woodwork. If you have ever seen the process, you will have been amazed at the speed and agility with which the adept can plane a hunk of wood into shape. Indeed, you can almost see the sparks fly from their sabers.
Mnemonic1: Sparks will fly if you attempt to PLANE your sabre.
Mnemonic2: With today´s strict air regulations, carrying a sabre onto a plane could spark quite a commotion.
Compo: 肖: resemblance; spark, candle (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: As the key word hints, the kanji in this frame refers to the late evening or early morning hours, well after one should be in bed asleep. It does this by picturing a house with a candle in it. The reason is obvious: whoever is living there is "burning the candle at both ends," and working night after night into the wee hours.
Mnemonic1: I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!
Mnemonic2: I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means "early evening", not "wee hours" (Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 "but of course" -- what the hell???). Oh well.] "Every house lights candles in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the wee hours". E.G. 宵の口（よいのくち）early evening; 今宵（こよい）this evening; tonight.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　肖: resemblance; spark, candle (RTK)

Origin: To carry on from the last frame, we note the entire day of work that comes between a woman and her house in preparing for a dinner banquet, pictorially "interrupting" her relaxation.
Mnemonic1: The WOMAN spent all DAY preparing a banquet in the HOUSE.
Mnemonic2: Under the roof, all day long, the woman prepared for the banquet (this wording helps me remember the order of this kanji´s elements).
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　日: day; sun　女: woman

Origin: Cocoon . . . silver . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: Your hometown is where you broke out of your cocoon (born), and where you left when your hair was silver (died), your whole life was spent inside the city walls.
Mnemonic2: Your home town is where you earned enough silver to enable you to break out of your giant cocoon (leave home) and explore outside the city walls.
Compo: 幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　邑: village; city walls (阝)
郷: hometown　食: eat; food

Origin: Hometown . . . sound.
Mnemonic1: People´s voices are like echoes of sounds from their hometowns....you can always tell where they´re from by how they talk.
Mnemonic2: My hometown is a ghost town, any sounds echoes and echoes.
Compo: 郷: hometown　音: sound

Origin: In this frame, we see a mound of dirt that is being turned into a castle (the way you may have done as a child playing on the beach).
Mnemonic1: The sand castle is just the soil (#150) that turns into a castle.
Mnemonic2: Someday this mound of dirt here will turn into our CASTLE, the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　成: turn into
Ex2Kana: ばんりのちょうじょう

Origin: The sure sign of sincerity is that one's mere words are turned into deeds.
Mnemonic1: Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something.
Mnemonic2: Sincerity is turning your words into actions.
Compo: 言: word; say　成: turn into

Origin: Here boom refers to something that is popular and prospering. Its elements: turn into . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: Japan´s economic boom turned their empty plates into full ones.
Mnemonic2: The boom of satellite TV has made antennas turn into dishes.
Compo: 成: turn into　皿: dish
Kunyomi: も.る, さか.る, さか.ん
Ex1English: (1] heap up; fill (a bowl (tray]); (2] prosper, thrive

Origin: The radiant, effulgent splendor of he sun makes it king of all the planets and other stars. Just to be sure you don't take this too abstractly, picture the sun seated on a throne, flourishing its scepter this way and that.
Mnemonic1: The Sun King (Louis XIV) was known for his effulgent reign.
Mnemonic2: (+katsuo] This is the Sun King. Sayeth Wikipedia: "The Sun King (in French le Roi Soleil) because of the idea that, just as the planets revolve around the Sun, so too should France and the court revolve around (the king] ("http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France). And just like the sun, he was quite effulgent and actually emitted sunlight.
Compo: 日: day; sun　王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: Part . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: The part of the kitchen sink in which you wash dishes in is the basin.
Mnemonic2: I'm not an expert, but it seems that as a basin this refers more to an oceanic basin that a kitchen one, and in any case seems most common in reference to the famous O-Bon festival. So, a story: in the O-Bon festival, so many dishes are broken that all the parts have to be thrown into a deep oceanic basin.
Compo: 分: part; segment　皿: dish

Origin: Flowers . . . gone . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: The lid of this dish is gone! Now the whole room smells of the flowers that were used in the cooking.
Mnemonic2: When the magician lifted the LID, the flowers were gone from the dish.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　去: gone　皿: dish

Origin: Next . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: You are so poor you dont know where your next dish will come from all you know is that you will have to steal it.
Mnemonic2: The first thing to steal is the silverware; next, the dishes.
Compo: 次: next; second (RTK)　皿: dish

Origin: Bright . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: In order to form alliances, you should sit down for a meal and eat until your dish is bright or clear; in other words, get to know people first, before you talk business.
Mnemonic2: A new alliance is proclaimed at the end of a meal between officials. As a symbol of their alliance they clean up together one dish, and present it to the photographers. The clean dish under the flash lights appears very bright, and it´s pretty much all you can see on the photo that appears on the next morning´s newspapers, with the title "New alliance, one bright dish!".
Compo: 明: bright; light　皿: dish

Origin: Ground . . . reclining . . . mouth . . . dish.
Mnemonic1: In the old days, salt was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone reclining on the ground, mouth to plate, getting every last grain of that delicious salt.
Mnemonic2: The eccentric explorer lay down on the earth 土, opened his mouth 口, and licked it. "As I suspected!" he said, "It's salt. Something to spice up our dishes 皿 with!"
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　口: mouth　皿: dish

Origin: Person . . . reclining . . . piggy bank.
Mnemonic1: If someone doesn't have a fat piggy bank to cover their medical costs and happen to get wounded somewhere, they'll be reclining there forever.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T gets wounded by reclining on his piggy bank.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)
Kunyomi: きず, いた.む, いた.める

Origin: Fingers . . . piggy bank.
Mnemonic1: My piggy bank is so heavy that I cannot HOIST it using just my fingers.
Mnemonic2: Picture a major robbery where some dudes are breaking into a bank to steal their money. They get their man in the vault through the ceiling - now he´s hanging from a rope a few feet from the ground (like in the movies, dodging laser beams). He reports back that he has found the loot, and its all in a large piggy bank in the center of the vault. The alarm sounds and he´s got to think fast. He jams the four fingers of his right hand in the piggy bank slot and tells his team to hoist him up, he´s got the loot!
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)
Kunyomi: あ.げる, -あ.げ, あ.がる
Ex2English: Raise, hoist; fry in deep fat

Compo: 申: monkey (RTK)　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)

Origin: Different from the primitive for sun (which figures in the character) and the kanji for ray (Frame 125), the key word sunshine is meant to convey the meaning of the masculine principle in nature, or "Yang." (The dark is viewed mythically as the feminine principle; see frame 1718.) From there it comes to mean sun also. The elements are: pinnacle . . . piggy bank.
Mnemonic1: A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people´s eyes, far below.
Mnemonic2: The Pinnacle is environmentally friendly. They collect solar power through sunshine on their piggybank shaped solar arrays.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)

Origin: Just as the sunshine (Frame 1397) represents the masculine principle in nature (Yang), the shade stands for the feminine principle (Yin). Its elements are: pinnacle . . . clock . . . rising cloud.
Mnemonic1: There are three types of shade: 1. natural (a high pinnacle), 2. man-made buildings (a clock tower), 3. meteorological (a cloud).
Mnemonic2: Frosty the snowman is running around the pinnacle, staying in the shade. As he looks at his clock to see how much longer he can last, small clouds rise (steam) from his body. Nooo, Frosty!
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　今: now; clock (RTK)　云: say; rising cloud (RTK)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . vulture . . . broom . . . heart. Compare the element sat the right to the kanji for calm (Frame 1230).
Mnemonic1: The wheat farmer´s heart is calm (#1147) about the eagle not stealing his crops because of the broom scarecrow. But he still conceals all his wheat at The Pinnacle in case anyone else trys to steal it.
Mnemonic2: Move the broom with a vulture perched on top, and you´ll find the concealed entrance to the heart of The Pinnacle.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: かく.す, かく.し-, かく.れる

Origin: Wheat . . . vulture . . . broom . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: The farmer is calm knowing that his wheat fields are protected from vultures by his strawman with a heart (all the better to do the job properly).
Mnemonic2: This whole kanji is a picture of calmness. The wheat has been harvested and even the vultures sit calmly watching the humans sweep and clean-up after the harvest is over. Hearts are peaceful and calm at this time of the year. Even the days are calm without storm.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Wheat . . . favor.
Mnemonic1: The pilgrims only had wheat, so they asked the Indians to do them a favor and trade them for some ears of corn.
Mnemonic2: The "ear of a plant" is the seed-bearing spike of a cereal plant, such as corn. In other words, it is the part which feeds us. Hence -- "the ear (of a plant) is the favor of the wheat".
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　恵: favor
Ex1English: Spike (ear] of grain; spike of a spear; tip of a writing brush
Ex2English: Shaped like an ear of grain

Origin: Wheat . . . vulture . . . olden times.
Mnemonic1: The rice plant is common in Japan because all the wheat was eaten by vultures in the olden times.
Mnemonic2: It used to be that wheat was grown in Japan. However, this was often stolen by vultures, so in olden times, the gods gave the Japanese the rice plant.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　旧: old times

Origin: Autumn . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: In AUTUMN, the farmer´s HEART is in DISTRESS as to if he has enough crops. Even better, the farmer will experience great DISTRESS in his HEART if his WHEAT catches FIRE!
Mnemonic2: Here we have distressed (think "gloomy") people with "seasonal mood disorder" during the autumn season. Hence "autumn heart" is distressed (gloomy).
Compo: 秋: autumn　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: You might think here of garment that have been specially tailored for Thanksgiving celebrations to look like traditional Pilgrim garb.
Mnemonic1: The tailor was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best garments for thanksgiving.
Mnemonic2: The tailor worked hard after thanksgiving to alter garments so they´d fit people who´d eaten too much at their thanksgiving dinners.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: One loads bales on a wagon or cart in preparation for the great Hay Ride that follows the Thanksgiving dinner each year.
Mnemonic1: After eating a big Thanksgiving dinner, you have to be careful in the car ride home not to drop a load in your pants.
Mnemonic2: After ´Thanksgiving´ dinner, my girlfriend gave me a BJ on the drive back home. I blew my ´load´ and ´soiled´ the ´car´. But it was LOADS of fun! Please report this story if this makes you feel uncomfortable :).
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　車: car
Ex1English: Be placed upon; appear in print

Origin: On a fruit plantation it is the trees that one is particularly grateful for at the time of Thanksgiving. Imagine yourself inviting a few representative trees from the fields and orchards to join you around the table to give thanks.
Mnemonic1: The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.
Mnemonic2: During Thanksgiving, all the trees on the plantation celebrate the harvest. It´s a good time for them, too.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Red . . . taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: The student blushed until his face was red, so the schoolmaster decided to pardon him.
Mnemonic2: There aren´t many pardons given by the Red taskmasters in China. 80% of the world´s death penalties are performed there…
Compo: 赤: red　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Wooden leg . . . apple.
Mnemonic1: Pirate pokes the tip of his wooden leg into an apple to disguise his tracks.
Mnemonic2: To hide his distinctive wood-leg tracks, this pirate is throwing apples after his tracks in order for animals to come and confuse his tracks.
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　亦: also; apple (RTK)

Origin: Wooden leg . . . religion. The key word refers to a trail of footprints or tracks left behind.
Mnemonic1: A trail of destruction is left by pirates and religion invaders.
Mnemonic2: The followers of the crazy satanic religion are following the footprints of the escaped human sacrifices who fled from the altar.
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　宗: religion

Origin: Sickness . . . silver.
Mnemonic1: I suffer from silver-sickness, that is, if anything made of silver even touches my skin it leaves a scar.
Mnemonic2: I got sick and needed surgery, but the silver lining is that now I have these awesome scars I can show off!
Compo: 疒: sickness　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)

Origin: Wooden leg . . . concerning.
Mnemonic1: The soccer player was concerned that his peg leg would affect his ability to kick.
Mnemonic2: I kick with my FEET in the CAPITAL of all the ONE LEGGED CHIHUAHUAS. It is such a great fun, since they cannot kick me back! lol.
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　就: concerning

Origin: Wooden leg . . . chop-seal . . . utilize.
Mnemonic1: The winner of the long jump competition was disqualified when they found he used a pogo stick tied to his leg to jump further.
Mnemonic2: The high jumper has his wooden leg fitted with a pogo stick, and can now jump even higher. (See my note at traffic (#1408) for pogo stick). EDIT (2 years later): Keyword "jump" leads to confusion later on (see cjon256´s post), "Dancing" would be better (but be sure to keep it distinct from dance (#1774)). New Story: I was no good at dancing due to my wooden leg... until I had it fitted with a pogo stick!
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　甬: road with walls on both sides

Origin: The meaning of this character is virtually identical with that of the last frame. Be sure to come up with distinct connotations suggested by phrases in which each is commonly used. Wooden leg . . . water . . . sun.
Mnemonic1: You have to watch your step when moving your leg on a watery day.
Mnemonic2: So, we´ve walked on the moon, but it´s going to take a pirate with a wooden leg, with a huge supply of cooling water to land on the sun and take that "one small step for a man".
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)　日: day; sun

Origin: Wooden leg . . . feathers . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Well, there are weekdays weekday (#576) and there are laundry days laundry (#577), and on February 29th leap day, the manufacturer recommends servicing or replacing your peg leg because they tend to wear out every 4 years.
Mnemonic2: (Story for people following katsuo in making feathers+turkey a ´futon´ primitive] If you´re going to leap from a high place, better hope there´s a futon below -- otherwise you´re going to break your leg at the very least...
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　羽: feathers; wings　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . feathers . . . turkey
Mnemonic1: At the laundry you stuff your large futon (made from turkey feathers) in the machine, thereby causing it to break -- as shown by the water spurting out the side.
Mnemonic2: When turkeys do the laundry, they put their feathers in water (they don´t have clothes).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　羽: feathers; wings　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: The elements we are given to work with here are St. Bernard dog and can. Lots of phrases pop to mind to attach these words to the key word, but they end up too abstract because of the word can. It is important in such cases (and there will be plenty of them as we go along) to stick closely to the elements, in this case, mouth and nails. Now all we need do is create a fictitious "Strange But True" column in the Sunday funnies, featuring a St. Bernard whose mouth has been nailed shut because he was hitting the brandy keg around his neck too hard.
Mnemonic1: I find it strange that so many people commit suicide in Tokyo by throwing themselves in front of the train. To me when I look at this kanji, I see a train just about to come out of a tunnel, and above the man waiting for his oppourtunity where he can end it all.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a ST. BERNARD DOG carrying a CAN instead of a barrel in rescue missions. How strange!
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　可: can

Origin: Let the idea of drawing near suggest something dangerous or eerie that one approaches with fear and trembling. Here we see a strange house - perhaps the haunted House of Usher that Edgar Allen Poe immortalized, or the enchanted Gingerbread House that lured Hansel and Gretel to draw near.
Mnemonic1: The strange house has a sign saying "DRAW NEAR" in its window, instead of a ´Beware´ sign. It must be a trick!
Mnemonic2: Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The house is very strange. The characters draw near to one another for protection against the unknown.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　奇: strange
Ex2English: Approach, draw near to; call on
Ex4English: Draw near, allow to approach; gather

Origin: Team of horses . . . strange.
Mnemonic1: Equestrian events are where you get horses to do strange things.
Mnemonic2: If the equestrian team used trojan horses, it would be really strange.
Compo: 馬: horse　奇: strange

Origin: Instead of making a chair out of wood from a tree, this kanji has us making the whole tree into a chair, which looks most strange sitting in your living room where the sofa used to be.
Mnemonic1: To the Japanese, the first time they saw a chair, it looked like a strange use of wood! Probably why they still like to sit on the floor...
Mnemonic2: A strange kind of tree grows in the shape of a chair.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　奇: strange

Origin: Mountain . . . strange. Hint: you might save yourself the trouble of a story here simply by recalling the kanji for cape (Frame 164) and toying around with the differing images suggested by the key words promontory and cape.
Mnemonic1: This is “Cape Strange” from FRAME 153, only with mountain in place of soil. Interestingly, there is also 碕 which is made of the primitives stone and strange. The three kanjis 碕, 埼 and 崎 all have the same meanings and pronunciations. They have very little uses other than names, for which promontory is the clear winner with over 2300 uses in place and people names, while the other two kanjis account for less than 200 names.
Mnemonic2: A promontory is a small, strange mountain that juts out into the sea.
Compo: 山: mountain　奇: strange

Origin: The cape pictured here is a jut of land like Cape Cod. The soil on the left tells us we have to do with land, and the strange on the right tells us it is a cape where unusual things go on. Put a haunted house on it, an eerie sky overhead, and a howling wind rustling through the trees, and you have yourself a picture of Cape Strange (or, if you prefer, Cape Odd).
Mnemonic1: This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.
Mnemonic2: Cape Cod "odd" is a land where odd=strange things happen.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　奇: strange

Origin: Like the cape (Frame 164) and the promontory (Frame 840), the headland refers to a jut of land. Its elements: mountain . . . roots.
Mnemonic1: A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!).
Mnemonic2: Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain).
Compo: 山: mountain　甲: armor; roots (RTK)

Origin: Ah, but haven't modern graveyards become a parody of their ancestors! The flowers are plastic, the writing on the stones is unimaginative and cold, and the whole thing looks more like a marble orchard than a right and proper graveyard. This kanji continues with the modernization trend by picturing imitation trees in the graveyard. But of course, how convenient! They don't need pruning or fertilizing, their leaves don't fall, and they remain the same color all year long.
Mnemonic1: If I find out this furniture you´re selling me is made of imitation wood, I´ll put you in the graveyard.
Mnemonic2: The Japanese are so enamored of everything plastic, they even put IMITATION plastic trees in their graveyards! (No, not really, but I wouldn´t be surprised).
Compo: 木: tree; wood　莫: must not; graveyard (RTK)

Origin: The part of the body first affected by a stroll through a haunted graveyard is the skin, which gets goose bumps. But we save the word "skin" for another kanji, and use the odd word "membrane" here. Think of being so scared through and through that the goose flesh moves from the outside in, giving you goose membranes.
Mnemonic1: In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss.
Mnemonic2: The membranes in your flesh rot when placed in the graveyard.
Compo: 月: moon; month　莫: must not; graveyard (RTK)

Origin: Think of the key word as having to do with something viewed through a haze, or in the twilight and from a distance, so that only its outlines are vaguely discernible. Now we are back again to the essence of the true graveyard. The water may be taken as the sound of waves dashing up against the rocks or the dripping of moisture on cold rock - anything that helps you associate vagueness with the graveyard and keep it distinct from the imitation we met in the last frame.
Mnemonic1: The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague.
Mnemonic2: The water in the graveyard has worn away the headstones, so the writing is vague.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　莫: must not; graveyard (RTK)

Origin: A dirty towel draped over the entrance to the old graveyard is painted to look like the curtain of death that leads to the otherworld.
Mnemonic1: There is a graveyard outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a curtain so I can get a good nights sleep.
Mnemonic2: When you´re dead in the graveyard, "it´s curtains for you.".
Compo: 莫: must not; graveyard (RTK)　巾: towel
Ex2English: Raising of the curtain; opening scene
Ex3English: Closing days of the tokugawa shogunate

Origin: The mounds of soil with crude wooden crosses set at their head suggests those boot-hill graves we all know from cowboy lore. The only odd thing about this kanji is that the soil comes UNDER the graveyard, rather than to its left, where we might expect. Just think of the bodies as "lying under boot-hill" if you have any trouble. By the way, this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that we learn a kanji whose key word is the same, or almost the same, as a primitive element based on it, but whose shape differs somewhat. There is no cause to worry. By using the primitive in a variety of other characters, as we have done here, the confusion will be averted as a matter of course. In most cases, as here, the primitive element is taken from a part of the fuller kanji.
Mnemonic1: The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.
Mnemonic2: A grave is a patch of soil in a graveyard.
Compo: 莫: must not; graveyard (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Graveyard . . . power.
Mnemonic1: The necromancer hangs out at the local graveyard and uses his dark powers to recruit an army of undead. Emphasize the verb form to keep distinct from the noun cadet (#1173).
Mnemonic2: WANTED: Hardworking GRAVEYARD diggers. Must have 6 months experience with POWERFUL muscles as will be working in South Africa burying deceased elephants.
Compo: 莫: must not; graveyard (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)
Ex4English: Apply for, subscribe to, enlist for

Origin: Imagine that you have chosen the occupation of the keeper of a graveyard and spend your days tending to other's dead hood in order to make your means of livelihood.
Mnemonic1: He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.
Mnemonic2: The gravedigger makes his LIVELIHOOD digging in the graveyard all day For graveyard, imagine an idyllic picture: beautiful grass with the sun shining down...and a dog peeing on one of the graves. Don´t confuse with occupation (#1034). Hold onto the irony of making your LIVElyhood from tending dead people.

Mnemonic2: Morticia and Gomez (of the “Addams Family”) are spending their Valentine´s Day at the graveyard, pining for each other´s affection.

Origin: Water . . . heavens . . . valentine.

Mnemonic2: Annexed to the U.S.A. in 1898, Hawaii is nestled in the waters of the Pacific, a little drop of heaven, often visited on Valentines.. (from Ihatobu with the date corrected. Hawaii became a state in 1959)…

Origin: Strung together . . . valentine.

Origin: Sun . . . strung together . . . rice grains.

Compo: 日: day; sun　共: together　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Fire . . . outburst.

Origin: Water . . . gully. The key word is meant to refer to things like rivers and railway tracks that run alongside something else.
Mnemonic1: Water in a gully runs alongside the path.
Mnemonic2: Picture one of those idiots that run alongside the bicyclists in the Tour de France trying to give them water. Watch as the cyclist shoves the person into a gully that runs alongside the road.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　㕣: marsh, gully (RTK)

Origin: This character depicts a cornerstone as a stone set at the end of a wildlife preserve (the "zoo in the grove").
Mnemonic1: Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo.
Mnemonic2: A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the cornerstone has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious mending.).
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　楚: whip; cane

Origin: Spoon . . . dart . . . chop-seal . . . zoo.
Mnemonic1: (Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. ´Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.´ cool ´and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong´ ....´ please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.´ ´lion feeding time is. bla bla´ You are having serious doubts about if you still want to go into this zoo.
Mnemonic2: A very doubtful story: At the entrance to my local zoo they issue you with a special spoon (to feed the animals) and a dart gun (to defend yourself in case of animal attack). You must then hanko (seal) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the zoo. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I doubt they’ll let you in).
Compo: 匕: spoon　矢: arrow; dart (RTK)　マ: ma; chop-seal (RTK)　疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . set free.

Origin: Keep this kanji distinct from that for sack (Frame 1081). Its elements are: person . . . surface.
Mnemonic1: Superficial people (ie those who are only concerned about the surface) are obsessed with expensive bags.
Mnemonic2: Do you know why every person in Japan has a Louis Vuitton bag? After the 1985 JAL air crash that killed 520 people (the world´s worst). An image on tv of the crash showed Louis Vuitton bags (whose LV logo covered surface was somehow impervious) litering the crash site. From that point on they stuck in Japanese people´s mind´s as durable and high quality. (True story).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　表: surface

Origin: The key word refers to a very familiar way of referring to oneself, typically used by men. Its component elements: person . . . St. Bernard . . . eel.
Mnemonic1: I did it all by myself! Mr T stands there proud as holding a moray eel in his hand. He´s brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish... what a guy.
Mnemonic2: As astridtops mentions, this is "Ore". In Japanese r = l, so could write it "Ole". So picture a bullfight with person as the matador and a dachshund replacing the bull. The crowd keep shouting "Ole! (Ore)".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　电: electricity, eel (RTK)
广: cave (RTK)　奄: cover; suffocate; obstruct

Origin: This key word is yet another synonym for "I," somewhat more familiar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men use to refer to themselves. Its elements: person . . . husbands . . . in a row upside down.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.
Mnemonic2: Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it´s the kanji for "boku." Males usually use either "boku" or "ore" (instead of "watashi") to refer themselves. "Boku" is slightly boyish and soft; "ore" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use "ore" -- but when he´s one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to "boku" when he pleads "come on baby, it´s ME!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　业: spikes　䒑: weeds　夫: husband; man

Origin: Fingers . . . upside down in a row . . . husbands.
Mnemonic1: After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and slap them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn´t get me banned…).
Mnemonic2: Here we have badly behaving HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. Each wife approaches her HUSBAND, berates him, gives him a sharp SLAP in the face and, Three-Stooges style, pokes him in the eyes with her FINGERS.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　业: spikes　䒑: weeds　夫: husband; man
口: mouth　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . fiesta. Hint: recall the German legend of the English missionary, Saint Boniface, who felled the sacred oak tree dedicated to Thor at Geismar (in lower Hessia), occasioning a great fiesta for the Christians in the neighborhood to mark the defeat of their pagan competition. Be sure to fit your special person into the story if you use it.
Mnemonic1: At a fiesta, Mr. T tries to knock down a large pinata, but in his overly enthusiastic swings to get "the sucka," he actually FELLS the tree the piñata is hanging from, crushing some party goers. “I pity da fools who got crushed by my FELLED tree!”.
Mnemonic2: Mr T at the fiesta fell over blind drunk.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)

Origin: Gates . . . fell.

Origin: Gates . . . table . . . glue. Do not confuse with contend (Frame 1238).

But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out.

Mnemonic2: Through the gates of hell there is no sound, no light, its all pitch dark.
Compo: 門: gate　音: sound

Compo: 門: gate　木: tree; wood

Origin: Part of body . . . drag . . . rag.

Origin: This character, used for everything from little humps of hills to camel humps, easily suggests the hunch on the pig's back and hind parts where the best cuts of meat are to be found (and hence the English expression for luxury, "living high off the hog.") The elements we have to work with are: pinnacle . . . walking legs . . . cell.
Mnemonic1: You are struggling to the top across the humps, but you suddenly see the pinnacle and you feel new life in your walking legs.
Mnemonic2: A woman takes her bra off and what happens? Nine months later the hump in her belly pops out between her legs as a new life.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)　生: life; cell (RTK)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . walking legs . . . sunglasses with a lens popped out. Distinguish from fall (Frame 320) and crash, which we considered in the previous frame.
Mnemonic1: Sunglasses-missing-one-lens is obviously the monocle. The proper, high-class way to descend The Pinnacle is wearing a monocle with your walking legs splayed to a full gentlemanly stride.
Mnemonic2: After a cool, hip businessman angered the executives at The Pinnacle, they beat him up, popping out a lens from his sunglasses, and tossed out the window, head first, walking legs second. One executive later commented, "It was like he was descending into Hell from Heaven!".
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)　ヰ: sunglasses with a lens popped out (RTK)

It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 sew (#1563), 逢 tryst (#2417), 蜂 bee (#2687), and 鋒 sword´s point (#2768), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. "Pointy" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a summit is the pointy end of a mountain.
Mnemonic2: Upon reaching the summit of the mountain, I noticed my walking legs were all gouged up from walking through prickly bushes.
Compo: 山: mountain　夆: resist

Origin: Ward . . . yawn. Like the kanji of frame 1776, this character is an abbreviation of the name of a geographical region.

Mnemonic2: In this hospital ward, the personnel is assaulted by missiles. Think of a ward where crazy old people assault the personnel because they don´t like the food, they don´t want to take their medicines, they want to go home, etc. The patients use whatever they can get their hands on as missiles.
Compo: 区: ward; district　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Team of horses . . . ward.
Mnemonic1: You have to be craaazzzzyy to drive a buggy led by a team of horses through a ward of Tokyo!
Mnemonic2: You use teams of horses to drive you and your carriage around the ward.
Compo: 馬: horse　区: ward; district

Origin: Team of horses . . . crotch . . . insect.
Mnemonic1: Or more precisely: the team of horses are getting boisterous because one of them got bitten in the crotch by a horse fly. The kanji also means to roar, make up noise, to kick up a fuss and to make merry. Perhaps it is exactly the etymology behind this kanji.
Mnemonic2: The hidden Greeks inside the Trojan Horse are getting boisterous as one of them is bitten in the crotch by a nasty insect. If they don´t shut up, the Trojans will hear them...
Compo: 馬: horse　又: again; crotch (RTK)　虫: insect

Origin: This character is a sort of nickname for the Japanese flag with its well-known emblem of the rising sun. If you can picture two seams running down that great red sun, and then imagine it sitting on a baseball bat for a flagpole, you have a slightly irreverent - but not altogether inaccurate - picture of how the sport has caught on in the Land of the Rising Sun.
Mnemonic1: 9am carries with it the rising sun.
Mnemonic2: Nine planets revolve around our rising sun.
Compo: 九: nine; baseball (RTK)　日: day; sun

Origin: While we normally refer to the start of the day as "daybreak," Japanese commonly refers to it as the "opening up of night" into day. Hence the choice of this rather odd key word, nightbreak. The single stroke at the bottom represents the floor (have a peek again at frame 1) or the horizon over which the sun is poking its head
Mnemonic1: A nightbreak happens when the sun rises over the horizon (floor).
Mnemonic2: It may be easier to think of the keyword "DAYBREAK" or "MORNING" for this kanji (other kanji dictionaries do). Then the mnemonic phrase "SUN rising over the HORIZON" works better. It is an infrequent kanji, but can be found in: 旦夕 （たんせき） morning and evening, or 元旦 （がんたん） New Year´s Day.
Compo: 日: day; sun　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)
Ex1English: Once; for a while; one morning

Origin: Person . . . nightbreak.
Mnemonic1: However drunk Mr T is when he comes back to his place, he always get up at nightbreak. “I pity da foo who gets up after nightbreak !”, says Mr. T.
Mnemonic2: MR.T leads a busy life, however he always makes sure to be in bed by NIGHTBREAK, however much he might want to stay up watching A-Team re-runs.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)
Ex1English: Provided that, on condition that, however, but, only

Origin: The key word of this frame refers to shouldering a burden of some sort. Its elements are: fingers . . . nightbreak.
Mnemonic1: One of Hercules´ labors was to hold the world in his fingers for Atlas and not move until nightbreak, shouldering the considerable burden.
Mnemonic2: One of the classic stories of shouldering a heavy burden is that of the kid who had to stick his finger on a dam until nightbreak to prevent it from breaking down.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)

Origin: Sunrise, sunset, sunrise, sunset... goes the song of the Fiddler on the Roof. You can almost see the journey of the sun as it moves from one horizon (the floor) to its noonday heights in the sky overhead (ceiling) and then disappears over the other horizon - day after day, marking the span of our lives.
Mnemonic1: The sun spans from horizon to horizon in a day.
Mnemonic2: The span of the day is the time between the sun goes up and comes down.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . span.
Mnemonic1: Constancy is holding the same state of mind over a long span of time. (tweaking PepeSeco and mspertus).
Mnemonic2: Data is the epitome of constancy. As a robot, his consistency spans the entire day.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　亘: span; request

Origin: The hedge depicted in this frame is the miraculous hedge of briar roses that completely spanned the castle grounds in which Sleeping Beauty lay for a hundred years, so that none but her predestined beloved could find his way through it.
Mnemonic1: Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across.
Mnemonic2: The HEDGE of roses growing from the castle grounds fully spanned the castle walls.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　亘: span; request

Origin: Under the primitive for house we meet the kanji for span. Think of the key word in its religious sense of missionary preaching: "proclaiming the good news to all nations" and "shouting it from the housetops." That should be enough to help you remember this simple kanji, used in fact both for traditional missionary work as well as for one of its contemporary replacements: advertising.
Mnemonic1: You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.
Mnemonic2: I heard young Muslims have to memorise the Koran and proclaim it aloud as a kind of rite of passage. Imagine the SPAN of hours spent under a ROOF practising that! It must surely be worse than trying to get through Heisigs RTK - count yourself lucky.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　亘: span; request
口: mouth　宣: proclaim; say; announce
Kunyomi: かまびす.しい, やかま.しい

Compo: 口: mouth　華: splendor; flower; petal; shine; luster; ostentatious; showy; gay; gorgeous

Origin: Mouth . . . droop.
Mnemonic1: When some people are sleeping, their mouths droop open, and saliva drips out.
Mnemonic2: Saliva drools from a mouth that droops. つば.
Compo: 口: mouth　垂: hornbeam; droop (RTK)
土: ground; land; soil　冖: crown

Origin: This kanji belongs to an old Japanese system of measurement and indicates an area of about 36 square feet, or the area taken up by two tatami mats. Its elements: ground . . . water lily.
Mnemonic1: A two-mat area is just about as much ground as you will need for a lily pond.
Mnemonic2: A two-mat area is plenty of space for sleeping in a tent but you won´t be comfortable unless the ground is even.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　平: plain

Origin: Rice field . . . half. The key word here refers to the ridges that rise up between the sections of a rice paddy.
Mnemonic1: A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.
Mnemonic2: Think about a large rice field as a big square. Then you draw a line down the middle, halving it into two. Then you draw a line across the middle, halving it again into four... These halvings are paddy-ridges that separate the rice field into separate sections. I dunno the reason why, but that´s how it´s done.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　半: half

Origin: Blood . . . drag . . . rag.
Mnemonic1: Masses of zombies, splattered with blood. (any zombie movie).
Mnemonic2: When the masses are hurt, say in a natural disaster like an earthquake, they can be seen everywhere dragging their bloody rags.
Compo: 血: blood　乑: stand side by side
Ex1Kana: たいしゅうしょうせつ
Ex2Kana: アメリカがっしゅうこく

Origin: Used chiefly in proper names, and given the sound "i," this kanji can be remembered as an abbreviation of Italy, for which it is still used today in Japan. Its primitives: person . . . mop.
Mnemonic1: The "boot" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T?
Mnemonic2: Here I have Mister T cleaning up with a mop, a real mess of spaghetti, in front of the Piza (in Italy).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　尹: an official rank; mop (RTK)

Origin: The somewhat highbrow British term of address is chosen hereto represent the kanji for a form of address used towards one's juniors. It is composed of: mop . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: There´s a tendancy in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. "Well old boy," a senpai might say, "If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago".
Mnemonic2: The Beatles, english old boys, had hairs like mop and a good singing mouth.
Compo: 尹: an official rank; mop (RTK)　口: mouth
Ex3English: Imperial reign; title of japanese national anthem

Origin: Old boys . . . sheep.
Mnemonic1: Good ol´ boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together.
Mnemonic2: A little girl herder calls out, "羊君、きて！" to the sheeps and they flock to her at once.
Compo: 君: you; old boy (RTK)　羊: sheep
Kunyomi: む.れる, む.れ, むら, むら.がる

Origin: Old boy . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: The old boy had never been outside of his own county because he couldn't get over the city walls.
Mnemonic2: The old boys of Hazard COUNTY never got past the city walls.
Compo: 君: you; old boy (RTK)　邑: village; city walls (阝)

Origin: Sword . . . two . . . city walls. Used classically to indicate an interrogative part of speech, this character is used chiefly now for its sound.
Mnemonic1: If you arrive with two swords at the city walls, expect some interrogatives before they´ll let you in.
Mnemonic2: Interrogation at the city walls: "Any weapons, question mark." "Just a blade." "Why the two scratches on the blade, question mark." "To remind me that I cut off my other ear too, exclamation mark (exclamation (#2680)).".
Compo: 那: what
Ex1English: Master, husband, patron, protector; sir; donor

Origin: Bushes . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: He reminisced about his home country: "Ah, back in my home country, the bushes grew so high that they covered the city walls!".
Mnemonic2: It's easier if you think of the USA as the HOME COUNTRY. To the northern border you have it protected by BUSHES, while to south you have it protected by CITY WALLS (or a 800 mile long fence).
Compo: 丰: abundant; bushes (RTK)　邑: village; city walls (阝)

Origin: Mingle . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: The country folk and and the city folk mingle at the outskirts of town, just past the city walls.
Mnemonic2: The city walls mark the outskirts of the inner city, where it begins to mingle with the suburbs.
Compo: 交: mingle　邑: village; city walls (阝)

Origin: Mingle . . . power. Note the distinct connotations that separate merit from achievement (Frame 927).
Mnemonic1: Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit.
Mnemonic2: There is great merit in mingling with the powerful.
Compo: 交: mingle　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . mingle.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman hates going to parties and having to mingle. He wants to strangle someone after just a little small talk.
Mnemonic2: At the elegant cocktail party of VIP's, the spy, dressed like everyone else in formal evening wear, sneaks in and strangles his victim with a very thin wire - a thread. Afterwards he mingles in with the crowd and disappears.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　交: mingle
Kunyomi: しぼ.る, し.める, し.まる

Origin: Fingers . . . hole . . . saw.
Mnemonic1: You have trouble squeezing your hand through the hole so you use a saw to enlarge it.
Mnemonic2: (Thanks DrJones) You squeeze the teats of the cow with your fingers but it´s your first try and you don´t have any milk come through the holes, so you take a saw and cut the teats to make bigger holes. Poor cow, this story squeezes my heart.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　穴: hole　乍: peg holes, staple gun (RTK); saw (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . plaid.
Mnemonic1: The Scottish weave their family crests with thread on plaid fabric.
Mnemonic2: A family crest sown on to a garment with thread sometimes has a Latin sentence as a motto.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　文: literature; plaid (RTK)

Origin: Flower . . . bound up . . . rice.
Mnemonic1: Chrysanthemum flower consists of many tiny petals, just like many rice grains bound up together.
Mnemonic2: (+astgt] Chrysanthemum is a terrorist orginization whose sole objective is to tie up Condi Rice. One day, Condi Rice is standing outside when a group of chrysanthemum agents swoop in from the sides, bound her up with chrysanthemum rope, and dash off. They leave a lone yellow chrysanthemum flower on top of the bound Condi Rice as a sign to let her discoverers know who committed this brave and noble act.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　米: rice

Origin: An uncommon, but not altogether unlikely picture of a reigning sovereign has him standing up in his apron, presumably at the behest of HIS sovereign (she who is to be obeyed), who needs help with washing the dishes.
Mnemonic1: The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That´s why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public.
Mnemonic2: This one is so tricky for me. The key is to remember that the bottom stroke on the standing element takes those little crown "winglets" on the right and left. The most effective image might be of QEII (who is quite short) using her crown as a kind of stool. She´s standing on her crown rummaging through a high cupboard looking for her apron. I guess the sovereign´s servants have the day off.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: Thread . . . sovereign.
Mnemonic1: The sovereign appears to be ruling, but in reality someone behind him (for instance his wife) has a thread around his throat, and if he dares to make a decision she doesn´t like, she starts pulling the thread and tightens it around his throat.
Mnemonic2: (astridtops) Spiderman managed to get behind the sovereign. (pick your favourite nowadays country ruler who isn´t doing a good job). Spidey has tightend a web around the sovereing´s throat. As long as the sovereign says what spidey whispers, he will be fine. Sovereign yelping : ´ we will draw are troops back! and we will spend more money on healthcare, schools and less on wars!´ Spidey whispering: ´ If you continue at this pace, you might be doing good things AND the people will like you.´.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　帝: sovereign
Kunyomi: し.まる, し.まり, し.める, -し.め, -じ.め
Ex1English: Closing day, deadline; closed, no entrance

Origin: The key word renunciation has to do with the wisdom and clarity of mind in knowing when to "let go." This is what makes the words of acquiescense sovern.
Mnemonic1: The words of the sovereign king inspire the people: never give up! Never surrender! Okay...maybe it wasn´t a king.
Mnemonic2: Anytime I think to give up Japanese, I remember giving my word that I would become sovereign of Japanese! And I watch あきら to get pumped about it. Note: to give up - 諦める is read あきらめる).
Compo: 言: word; say　帝: sovereign

Origin: Tall children receive more attention. Tall children grow up to make better wide receivers. Take your pick, depending on whether you prefer child psychology or American football. At any rate, be sure you have some particular tall child in mind, someone who really was outstanding and always attracting attention, because he or she will come in handy in the next two frames.
Mnemonic1: In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention.
Mnemonic2: Tall children receive all the attention. They also make great receivers in football... this kanji also means ´catch´ (therefore a football receiver is a great image).
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　口: mouth　子: child

Origin: Receive . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: The city finally received the enclosure that it desperately needed, city walls to protect it against attacks from the tall kids.
Mnemonic2: Even the tall kids can´t get out of the enclosure that is the city walls.
Compo: 享: enjoy; receive　邑: village; city walls (阝)

Origin: Think of all the pavilions at County Fairs or World Expos you have wandered into or seen advertised in the media, and you will no doubt see rising up among them the towering tall crowned nail (the crown being a revolving restaurant) - that architectural monstrosity that has become a symbol of science and technology at such events.
Mnemonic1: The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen.
Mnemonic2: The tallest Pavilion crowns the street.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　口: mouth　冖: crown 　丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . pavilion.
Mnemonic1: Halt fool - Mr T acting as a bouncer at the pavillion.
Mnemonic2: Mister T makes a halt at the African pavilion at the World´s Fair. He eats all the snacks on offer, and chats up the ladies - "“I pity da foo who does not halt by your pavilion, it´s the best !".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　亭: pavilion
Ex2Kana: バスのていりゅうじょ

Origin: By comparing apes with anthropoids, we not only discover the latter have descended from those progenitors educated in the higher branches, but that the very idea of seeing everything descended from everything else, one way or another, means that there is "nothing new UNDER the sun."
Mnemonic1: Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their DESCENDANTS.
Mnemonic2: Japanese people have compared themselves as being descendants of the sun. (Amaterasu, the sun godesss). Sun, comparing = descendants.
Compo: 日: day; sun　比: compare

Origin: Mixed marriages, this character suggests, water down the quality of one's descendants - the oldest racial nonsense in the world!
Mnemonic1: People have to mix their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants.
Mnemonic2: Give plants the right mix of water and sun. Then compare the results…
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　日: day; sun　比: compare
Kunyomi: ま.じる, -ま.じり, ま.ざる, ま.ぜる, こ.む

Origin: Think of the housewives in TV commercials "comparing the whiteness" of their laundry across the fence, a typical advertisement for the popular detergent known as All. (If you don't know the brand, surely you've heard the phrases "all-purpose detergent" or "all-temperature detergent.")
Mnemonic1: If you compare colors, you will find that white is produced from the mix of all the others.
Mnemonic2: Sometimes, Dr. Heisig´s keyword choices are really quite bizarre. This doesn´t mean all, it means everyone!! Picture two ku klux klansmen comparing whose skin is whiter...finally, they agree that everyone there is white.
Compo: 比: compare　白: white

Origin: The key word refers to kanji that are written in full, squared form, as opposed to cursive writing which is more flowing andabbreviates some of the strokes. Here block letters are pictured as tidy rows of trees that are all the same size and can be read easily by all, whatever calligraphic skills they possess.
Mnemonic1: Block letters (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like wood; they're all the same size so that all can read them.
Mnemonic2: all the hiragana are in "block letters" on wooden blocks, like children's toys.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　皆: all
Ex1English: Block (square] style used in writing or printing chinese characters

Origin: The harmoney of "a place for everything and everything in its place" is applied here to the orderliness of all the words one speaks.
Mnemonic1: To have orderliness, your words must be in all the right places.
Mnemonic2: 起立(きりつ)！ Hearing these words, all the students immediately stand at attention. The orderliness of classes in Japan is incredible.
Compo: 言: word; say　皆: all

Origin: The story of this character refers to floors in a building. The elements: pinnacle . . . all.
Mnemonic1: All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don´t have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey!
Mnemonic2: Some stupid kid has pushed all the buttons in the elevator. As it stops at all storeys you reach a pinnacle of impatience. Finally you reach your storey, the last one, at the pinnacle of the building.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　皆: all

Origin: This key word indicates a title of address to royalty. Its elements: pinnacle . . . compare . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: Your highness is the pinnacle of finesse compared to all of us commoners who are but like dirt on the ground.
Mnemonic2: His Highness, the main man at the Pinnacle, often compares those who live outside the city´s walls to dirt.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　比: compare　土: ground; land; soil
Ex2English: His majesty the emperor, his imperial majesty

Origin: The sense of land carried by this kanji is distinct from soil (Frame 161) and ground (Frame 554) in that it is meant to represent land seen from a distance, that is, land as opposed to "water." Its elements: pinnacle . . . rice seedlings . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: My rice-seedlings have become sentient and will go on a mission. I can only apologise for the next 6 frames. In the distance, there is a pinnacle, which the newly-awakened rice-seedlings who are still stuck in the ground can see. Could it be the Promised Land?
Mnemonic2: When sailors see land in the distance, they first see the pinnacles of the new land, but when they come close enough they´ll be able to make out the rice seedlings, and finally the ground!
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　圥: mushroom; rice seedlings (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil
Ex3English: Land, ground; shore; track and field

Origin: Eye . . . rice seedlings . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: The farmer was never very intimate with his wife. He always kept his eye on his precious rice seedlings in the soil.
Mnemonic2: I keep an intimate relationship with my rice seedlings -- I never take my eye from the soil.
Compo: 目: eye　圥: mushroom; rice seedlings (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil
Kunyomi: むつ.まじい*, むつ.む*

Origin: Rice seedlings . . ground . . . fat man . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: What power makes rice seedlings in the ground grow into well rounded plants? The forces of nature.
Mnemonic2: The forces of nature need to be just right for the rice seedlings in the ground to become fat and strong.
Compo: 圥: mushroom; rice seedlings (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil　丸: round; fatman (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Rice seedlings . . . ground . . . fat man . . . oven fire.
Mnemonic1: Heat up those RICE SEEDLINGS you pulled from the SOIL in a ROUND pan over a low FLAME. (Note: the hot pan image helps reinforce the idea that this kanji for "atsui" refers to something hot to the touch, as opposed to hot weather).
Mnemonic2: Just a comment on Erikkusan's story: Although one of the pronunciations of this kanji is "atsui" this isn't the atsui that you feel in Tokyo in August, (which is Frame 1260's "sultry' 暑). This atsui is the one when you touch something hot, like a fry pan. Another reading of this is "netsu," which is the "fever" this fat man may feel after planting the rice seedlings.
Compo: 圥: mushroom; rice seedlings (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil　丸: round; fatman (RTK)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: The tall and fat children from the last frame are here cast into a cauldron over an oven flame until they have sufficiently mellowed that they can return to the normal life of a student.
Mnemonic1: Imagine tall children sitting round the fire toasting marsh-mellows.
Mnemonic2: The cram school (309) tortures its students - especially the tall and fat ones who need to grow up - over a fire until they mellow. (Note that here the keyword ´mellow´ only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill; not the colloquial meaning of ´chill out´).
Compo: 享: enjoy; receive　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Cram schools are after-hours educational institutions where kids can do concentrated preparing for their coming entrance examinations or drill what they missed during regular class hours. The exception are the tall children who are out on the school grounds practicing sports, and the fat ones who are out there burning off calories. So this character depicts those who do NOT go to the cram schools, rather than those who do.
Mnemonic1: Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds.
Mnemonic2: You can receive a well-rounded education if you study at our cram school says the advertisement. "Just come to our school grounds and check it out yourself!".
Compo: 享: enjoy; receive　丸: round; fatman (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil
Ex1English: Private school for the study of english

Origin: Pinnacle . . . rice seedlings . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: Ancient Japanese built a mausoleum for the "unknown rice farmer". It's on the pinnacle of Mt. Fuji, and it has a statue of a guy with huge walking legs planting rice seedlings as he goes.
Mnemonic2: At the pinnicle is a mausolem. The ground is sown with rice seedings to stop the dead from rising on walking legs.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　圥: mushroom; rice seedlings (RTK)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)

Origin: Named after a diamond-shaped flower (the water caltrop), this key word refers to things shaped like a diamond. Its elements: flower . . . rice seedlings . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: Some girls want diamonds, but others will be satisfied with just flowers. However if you think you can win her over with rice seedlings, expect her to get up on her walking legs and walk on out!
Mnemonic2: Not a real diamond but a baseball one. No proper bases so we improvise, 1st is a bunch of flowers, 2nd is the pile of rice seedlings and so on... watch the running legs charge around after a big hit!
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　圥: mushroom; rice seedlings (RTK)　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . license . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: The entire town wants to get rid of legal prostitutes, but the sagacious Mr T realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay.
Mnemonic2: (re: sweetneet) Since he is not very sagacious, Mr. T failed his driver´s license and now needs to resort to his walking legs to get around.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　允: license　夂: winter; walking legs (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . license . . . walking legs.
Mnemonic1: I named the right part legal prostitute has it represents a walker (walking legs] with the license. It´s easy to imagine a legal prostitute tempting a man with her mouth.
Mnemonic2: Prostitutes in Amsterdam have a license to show off their walking legs and tempt customers with their mouths.
Compo: 口: mouth　夋: None
竹: bamboo (⺮)　舌: tongue
Ex1English: That is to be expected, you would think so

Origin: Bamboo . . . puppet.
Mnemonic1: Bamboo, lovedoll: At dinner, my lovedoll decided to eat her meal the Japanese way using chopsticks. But well, what a problems she had getting those bamboo shoots into her mouth (which should not be that difficult, I would say!).
Mnemonic2: I´ve always wanted to use bamboo chopsticks to eat sushi off a naked woman. Unfortunately, there is no woman in my life, so this love doll will have to do.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　者: person; puppet (RTK)

Origin: The key word refers to the heat of summer. Its elements: sun . . . puppet.
Mnemonic1: Ahh, a fine sultry day with my love doll under the hot sun. I think she´s getting a tan!
Mnemonic2: (from decamer0n] This is the kanji for atsui (暑い) as in hot. If you´ve ever been in Japan in the summer no doubt you have heard hoards of people bellowing "Atsui! Atsui!" Here you are laying with your love doll under the hot sun. Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow "Atsui! It´s so sultry!".
Compo: 日: day; sun　者: person; puppet (RTK)

Origin: Eye . . . puppet.
Mnemonic1: Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the LOVEDOLL, you should EYE over the LOVEDOLL for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE.
Mnemonic2: The ninja´s signature move was to paralyse people just by looking in their eyes.
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　者: person; puppet (RTK)
日: day; sun　署: signature; govt office; police station
Ex1Kana: じだい のあけぼの

Origin: Shells/money . . . puppet.
Mnemonic1: When we gamble at the shell game, I always win against my love doll.
Mnemonic2: People who gamble compulsively are like puppets controlled by money.
Compo: 貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)　者: person; puppet (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . puppet. Do not confuse with miscellaneous (Frame 604).
Mnemonic1: Because i get tired of saying the same old thing, I have lately been trying to use various terms of endearment to my love doll. I think she appreciates it too.
Mnemonic2: When you pull the string at the back of Chucky, he will say various things. "Hidey-ho! Ha ha ha!" "Hi, I´m Chucky. Wanna play?" "I´m going to eat your liver, bitch!".
Compo: 言: word; say　者: person; puppet (RTK)
Ex2English: Ladies and gentlemen, my friends, you

Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　諸: various; many; several; together
Kunyomi: もう.ける, もう.かる, もうけ

Origin: Thread . . . puppet. Although we usually think of a thong as coming at the end of a piece of string, this character's meaning allows for it to come at the beginning as well.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman has a secret fetish, he likes nothing better than to dress his lovedoll in a thong. Wierd, eh!
Mnemonic2: A thread is just the right size for a puppets thong.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　者: person; puppet (RTK)
Ex1English: Together; at the same time; in a lump

Origin: Public . . . feathers.
Mnemonic1: The venerable old man is the public figure head of the Native American Village, answering all questions and solving all problems. The higher in rank you get in this tribe, the more feathers decorate you. Imagine this old man covered in beautiful feathers.
Mnemonic2: The venerable old man is using the public restroom in the park where he feeds the pigeons. But, alas, there is no toilet paper! So, he´s caught a pigeon and is using it to wipe his bottom. (note the feathers on the bottom of the kanji, this helps remember placement). Can you see the feathers flying everywhere?
Compo: 公: public; official　羽: feathers; wings

Origin: Waves . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: An old woman is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases).
Mnemonic2: You know "The Old Man and the Sea." Well, this is the sequel, "The Old Woman and the Sea Waves.".
Compo: 波: waves; billows; Poland　女: woman

Origin: This kanji depicts a woman's figure as a sort of second self.
Mnemonic1: The next woman always has a better figure! Thinking like that, you´ll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!
Mnemonic2: Whenever I am next to a woman, I can´t help but take notice of her figure.
Compo: 次: next; second (RTK)　女: woman

Origin: Second . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: A selfish person doesn't care about the next person's heart, only their own.
Mnemonic2: Selfish lover breaks your heart and moves on to the next lover. (And yawns with a heart of ice at your suffering).
Compo: 次: next; second (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: The "ideal woman" one daydreams about is no more than a delusion. Hence, perish the thought of her.
Mnemonic1: I had a problem with remembering that "deceased" went over the "woman". So, here´s my story: The delusional woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.
Mnemonic2: If you think you should perish for that woman, you have a major delusion.
Compo: 亡: deceased; perish　女: woman

Origin: Flowers . . . committee.
Mnemonic1: Oh, the committee´s in for a surprise: I put some nightshades into their drinks. They´ll be numb for sure, probably worse.
Mnemonic2: The keyword numb makes no sense. I choose 萎む（しぼむ）"to fade away". A girl lies in a wheat field at the same time every day. A photo is taken every day showing this scene and a time lapse video shows the wheat growing through the year until the wheat is tall and the top sprouts to look like its flowers. At this point, the girl can no longer be seen in the photos and she fades away.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　委: committee
Kunyomi: なえ.る, しぼ.む*, しお.れる*, しな.びる*

Origin: Ten . . . rakes . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman.
Mnemonic2: (I´m really not sexist, this just helps me remember the kanji): I make my WIFE do all the yard work, and as a really mean joke, I bought her TEN RAKES for her birthday this year. "Do the yardwork, WOMAN! You have TEN perfectly good RAKES to choose from!".
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　肀: rake (RTK)　女: woman
Ex1English: Husband and wife, mr. and mrs.

Origin: Ice . . . wife.
Mnemonic1: His wife has a nifty way of making all types of ice cream in her home freezer.
Mnemonic2: Sugoi! Sugoi! Ice Wife Sugoi!
Compo: 冫: ice　妻: wife
Kunyomi: すご.い*, すさ.まじい*, すご.む*

Origin: Try to imagine a club badge pinned to your lapel in the form of a mammoth sunflower protruding from a wee little vase.
Mnemonic1: In the military, badges are given out early in the day, with everyone standing at attention.
Mnemonic2: Ash Ketchum stood up early in the morning, and said, "Pikachu, let´s go get us another badge!".
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　早: early; fast; sunflower (RTK)
Ex3English: Crest, family insignia, coat of arms

Origin: Badge . . . shape. The key word is synonymous with "clear" or "openly expressed."
Mnemonic1: The shape of a sheriff´s badge makes it patent who he is.
Mnemonic2: It was patently absurd when the fellow tried to arrest me--his badge was the wrong shape: a vase and a sunflower? Come now.
