Compo: 章: chapter; badge (RTK)　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . badge.
Mnemonic1: The officer at the gate to The Pinnacle with a giant badge sewn to his chest hinders all visitors. But not the handicapped. They´re hindered enough already. They´re given a badge and can pass right into The Pinnacle.
Mnemonic2: The pinnacle of racism was that of the Nazis. They made the Jews wear a badge on their clothes to identify them. They hindered their every movement. Moreover the peace-loving Dutch all wore the badges so that the Jews would be unidentifiable. Effectively hindering the Nazi plot.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　章: chapter; badge (RTK)
Ex4English: Malfunction, breakdown; hindrance, obstacle, accident; objection, protest

Origin: This character pictures food whose taste is so hot and spicy that it makes the hairs on your body stand up as straight as needles.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall use this meaning of spicy, except when the two extra strokes are added to the bottom, giving it the form of a tree. Then we take its alternate meaning of a red pepper plant. The connection is obvious.
Mnemonic1: Eating spicy food makes you stand up ten times faster than usual, ´cause you just need to get something to drink!
Mnemonic2: Eating spicy food makes you stand up as if you had sat on a needle.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)
Ex2English: (1] pungent, hot; salty; dry (wine); (2] painful, tough, bitter

Origin: House . . . spicy.
Mnemonic1: The superintendent of a Japanese school district needs a spicy relationship at home after watching girls in miniskirts all day.
Mnemonic2: The superintendent of an old-age house has to make sure the food is never too spicy.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　辛: spicy (RTK)

Origin: Spicy . . . bundle.
Mnemonic1: The bitter taste was so awful that I put whole bundle of spice in my mouth to get rid of it.
Mnemonic2: I'm rather bitter that someone stole my spice bundle.
Compo: 辛: spicy (RTK)　束: bundle

Origin: Tongue . . . spicy.
Mnemonic1: This guy´s job is tasting the spicy curry at the local Indian Food Factory. He has to resign from his job before his tongue is rendered completely useless after all the spicy food that he has to try all day long...
Mnemonic2: After my tongue touched the most spicy pepper of all, I had to resign from the contest...too hot for me!
Compo: 舌: tongue　辛: spicy (RTK)

Origin: Ketchup . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?
Mnemonic2: Primitive for Ketchup: When the taste is too spicy your mouth has basically given up trying to handle it ..or in other words raised the white flag of surrender. But unlike war , putting Ketchup on it will usually solve the problem. Wall(dingomick); Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?
Compo: 辟: law; ketchup (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: The holed gem to which this kanji refers is a flat, circular object of about a foot in length, made of stone or glass and having a large hole in the middle. It's elements: ketchup . . . ball.
Mnemonic1: Even more valuable and perfect (完璧) than a holed gem is a delicious meatball (ball = たま = 玉) with ketchup. Yum!
Mnemonic2: It's a little known fact that ketchup is highly corrosive and is used to cut holes into gemstones so they can be put onto chains. This kanji shows a piece of Jade with a blob of ketchup on the top eating a hole through it.
Compo: 辟: law; ketchup (RTK)　玉: jewel; ball

Origin: Sickness . . . ketchup.
Mnemonic1: Caveman has a bad mannerism of putting ketchup on everything he eats. I guess that´s ok since raw mammoth can´t be too good...
Mnemonic2: This mannerism is a sickness of the modern generation. It was only recently that we started putting ketchup on everything.
Compo: 疒: sickness　辟: law; ketchup (RTK)
Ex2English: Way (habit] of saying, one's favorite phrase

Origin: Ketchup . . . road.
Mnemonic1: You can try and evade them, but they´ll ketchup with you on the road... Sorry, couldn´t resist it.
Mnemonic2: In order to evade the bear, you lie down on the road, put ketchup on yourself, and play dead.
Compo: 辟: law; ketchup (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Simply by turning the dot at the top of the primitive for spicy into a cross shape, we move from things bitter and spicy to things happy.
Mnemonic1: Happiness adds a bit (or ten) of spice to your life.
Mnemonic2: This is one of those rare occasions when I forgo Heisig for other methods. 「幸せから一本取ると辛い」 -- if you take but one stroke away from happiness, you get painfulness. (oh well, Heisig used similar one for 百).
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　辛: spicy (RTK)
Kunyomi: さいわ.い, さち, しあわ.せ

Origin: Flesh . . . stamp . . . crotch. Note how the stamp is stretched out here.
Mnemonic1: It´s customary to cover the flesh with clothing, but some designs are so outrageous they´re not bigger than a stamp that just covers your crotch.
Mnemonic2: Modern clothing shows a lot of flesh -- some is practically no more than a postage stamp covering your crotch!
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Happiness . . . stamp . . . crotch. Compare frame 1501.
Mnemonic1: Recall the fashion model wearing just a stamp over his crotch (clothing (#1399)). When he got happy, of course, it ended up in the news report.
Mnemonic2: The long awaited report, 'Maximising Male Happiness In The Workplace' concluded that making bikinis, with only a stamp sized piece of cloth covering the crotch, compulsory for attractive female staff, was the most cost-effective means of achieving this aim.
Compo: 幸: happiness　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

English: Execute, Perform, Seize, Hold Fast To
Origin: Happiness . . . fat man.
Mnemonic1: Tenacious-D is happy band led by a fat man. (It´s Tenacious-D time, ya muthafucka´, gwaoh!).
Mnemonic2: To be tenacious, you need to have deep stores of happiness (so troubles don´t discourage you) and you need to be big and round (so hunger doesn´t drive you to give up). The most tenacious person of all time was happy round Buddha!
Compo: 幸: happiness　丸: round; fatman (RTK)
Ex1English: Be attached to; hold fast to

Origin: Of the many and widely different meanings of this kanji, we select the verbal meaning of clasp, which fits in well with its primitive elements: tenacious . . . hand.
Mnemonic1: When you clasp something you tenaciously 執 hold on to it with your hand 手, te. 真摯、しんし, sincerity, earnestness.
Mnemonic2: This kanji shows Santa Claus (refer to frame tenacious (#1506)) clasping the reins of his deers with his hands, holding onto dear life as he almost falls off his carriage.
Compo: 執: tenacious　手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)

Origin: The key word is meant to connote someone "skilled" at something. On the road we find soil OVER a sheep. You may have to work with this one a while longer.
Mnemonic1: Dolly (the first cloned sheep ever) grow tired of being a celebrity and escaped from the labs by digging a tunnel. She turned out to be an ACCOMPLISHED escapist, as she managed to dig a road under the soil. /Imagine Dolly performing a escape, like those movies where the main character has to escape from jail.
Mnemonic2: The dirty sheep had come far down this road and had accomplished many things.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　羊: sheep　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Halo . . . moon.
Mnemonic1: (Image: ´Moonlight sonata´] The moon has inspired many good composers (like Ludwig van Beethoven) to write something melodious.
Mnemonic2: A glowing halo surrounds a magnificent full moon. A perfect image of the mythic and melodious music of the spheres.
Compo: 良: good; halo (RTK)　月: moon; month

Origin: Water . . . halo.
Mnemonic1: Water is a good thing to have when you´re out wandering.
Mnemonic2: John the Baptist with a halo sprinkling water on people as he´s wandering the wilderness.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　良: good; halo (RTK)
Ex3English: Roam about from place to place

English: Kingdom Of Wu, Give; Do For (Someone)
Origin: The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult, because of the fourth stroke, which is rare (see frames 33 and 34). The mouth and tool are already familiar.
Mnemonic1: Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, "My uncle gave me this watch." Following -て form of another verb, means "to do the favor of": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, "Won't you open the window (do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?" Usu. written in hiragana.
Mnemonic2: I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!
Compo: 呉: give (RTK)

Origin: Woman . . . give.
Mnemonic1: A woman gives up her recreation time in order to raise a family.
Mnemonic2: Typical male fantasy of recreation: women "giving it up".
Compo: 女: woman　呉: give (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . give.
Mnemonic1: You must give words of apology when you make a mistake.
Mnemonic2: It is a rookie mistake to believe the words when your sweetie says "You don´t have to give me anything for my birthday." Trust me, your sweetie wants something, something shiny, and if you disappoint, you will suffer.
Compo: 言: word; say　呉: give (RTK)

Origin: Here we have the original character on which the primitive element for wealth is based. In keeping with the story introduced back then, note how all the wealth is kept under the roof of the same house.
Mnemonic1: Remember Ducktales? That rich duck had that room in his house where he kept all the wealth! He had so much in that house you could even swim in it!
Mnemonic2: In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth　田: rice field; brain (RTK)

Origin: The key word vice has the sense of someone second-in-command. The great and flashing saber to the right (its usual location, so you need not worry about where to put it from now on) and the wealth on the left combine to create an image of dividing one's property to give a share to one's vice-wealth holder.
Mnemonic1: The wealthy guy with the sword standing next to the king, that´s the vice-roy who does all the dirty work.
Mnemonic2: Vice-president Cheney: a wealthy saber rattler.
Compo: 畐: to fill; wealth (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: A towel owned by the wealthiest tycoon in the world is made into a hanging scroll after his death and auctioned off to the highest bidder.
Mnemonic1: In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars... In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don´t have any clean towels, they simply grab a hanging scroll off the wall and use it to dry off!
Mnemonic2: The towels of the wealthy: hanging scrolls.
Compo: 巾: towel　畐: to fill; wealth (RTK)

Origin: Altar . . . wealth.
Mnemonic1: This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you´re called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah.
Mnemonic2: Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.).
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　畐: to fill; wealth (RTK)

Origin: Altar . . . footprint.
Mnemonic1: And in front of every altar, she stopped to pray for the welfare of the others.
Mnemonic2: Religious Republicans regularly go to the altar to pray for a stop to welfare.
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　止: stop; footprint (RTK)

Origin: Altar . . . jawbone.
Mnemonic1: Continued from auspicious (#1088). Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. But if the gods are feeling particularly mischievous, they´ll send down a jawbone to the altar. The people see this as a sign of calamity to come. The gods think of it as an amusing prank.
Mnemonic2: Calamity Jane went to the altar to confess her sins and the priest´s jawbone fell to the floor…
Compo: 示: altar; show (礻)　咼: evil; jawbone (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . jawbone.
Mnemonic1: Grampa´s flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool!
Mnemonic2: A whirlpool is water opening its jaws to swallow anything whole.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　咼: evil; jawbone (RTK)

Origin: Metal . . . jawbone.
Mnemonic1: A gruesome kind of cauldron that Snape might have used is a metal pot in the shape of a skull.
Mnemonic2: A metall pot with non-thermoconductive jawbones as handholds.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　咼: evil; jawbone (RTK)
艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　闌: rise high; be well along
Ex1English: Dutch studies (edo era studies of western texts brought by dutch traders)

Origin: Tree . . . gates . . . east.
Mnemonic1: (column; handrail; blank; space] I think about oriental (eastern) Torii gates: they have two supporting columns made of wood.
Mnemonic2: A column of text scratched on a black tree beside the gates of Hell: To the East lies The Beast.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　闌: rise high; be well along

Origin: Water . . . gates . . . king.
Mnemonic1: Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got wet.
Mnemonic2: (I had the same idea as Dingomick) I imagine some prankster who put a bucket full of water on top of the huge gates, so that it would fall on the king as he came through them. See the king now, between the gates, all wet, dripping drops of water.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　門: gate　王: king; ball (RTK)
Kunyomi: うるお.う, うるお.す, うる.む

Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　丿: katakana no　丨: line; stick

Origin: Water . . . skeleton.
Mnemonic1: Don´t give water to a skeleton. When he drinks it, it´ll sluice right through his bones, forcing you to put one of those "Caution - Slippery Floor" signs up on the resultant puddle.
Mnemonic2: Slippery surfaces are very dangerous for skeletons, since their bone feet slip easily... a few drops of water, and zweep! A large mess of bones to pick up and reassemble!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　骨: bone; skeleton (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . chihuahua with one human leg . . . delicious.
Mnemonic1: After a hard day of training, wheat is understandably delicious.
Mnemonic2: After training hard and eating Wheaties for months, you are understandably thrilled to sink your spoon into a delicious hot fudge sundae.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　尤: superb　旨: delicious

Origin: Door . . . flesh.
Mnemonic1: The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don´t ever try this. Use your foot).
Mnemonic2: The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm´s story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below.
Compo: 戸: door　月: moon; month

Origin: Triceps . . . part of the body.
Mnemonic1: Compare the primitive positions of armpit (#870) and threaten (#871). When your triceps rest alongside your body, they fit snugly against your armpit. When you hold them above your body, however, your posture becomes quite threatening.
Mnemonic2: Don´t threaten a warewolf. He´s three times as powerful ON a full moon.
Compo: 力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)
Kunyomi: おびや.かす, おど.す, おど.かす

Origin: Seeing footprints on someone's flesh indicates a rather brutal way of having secured that person's agreement.
Mnemonic1: A secret agreement between a covert gov´t agency and aliens states that we will not step foot on the moon again in return for alien technology.
Mnemonic2: NASA and Armstrong made an agreement: They´d never tell anyone that no-one actually stepped foot on the moon.
Compo: 止: stop; footprint (RTK)　月: moon; month

Origin: The crotch reduplicated gives us a pair.
Mnemonic1: Crotch to crotch is how many pairs spend their private time together. . .
Mnemonic2: The animals boarding Noah´s Ark all came in pairs – but Noah had to carefully check the two crotches in each pair to ensure that the animals were of different sexes and thus able to further their species after the flood.
Compo: 又: again; crotch (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Unlike the river, the ocean, the lake, and the pond, the creek is often no more then a dribble of water trickling down a small gully. While the geological history of the larger bodies of water is hard to surmise sometimes, all of us know from our childhood how creeks are made. You probably even dug one or two in your time. All you need to do is find a mainstream of water somewhere and dig a little path into dry land. The creek is thus a lesson in water-craft, as this kanji would agree.
Mnemonic1: A CREEK is a small trail of water easily crafted with a stick.
Mnemonic2: Creeks are small water, easily crossed with a simple i-beam.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　工: craft; construction

Origin: Water . . . apple . . . bow.
Mnemonic1: In his most daring feat, William tell used his bow to shoot an apple off the head of his son across the water of the gulf.
Mnemonic2: An army of archers must cross a gulf of water. Fortunately there are millions of apple trees growing in the cliffs above the gulf. The archers use their bows to shoot down apple after apple, which all fall into the water and slowly fill up the the gulf until the archer soliders can cross on foot.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　亦: also; apple (RTK)　弓: bow

Origin: Deluge . . . snakes.
Mnemonic1: During a deluge, all the poor snakes get washed into the harbour.
Mnemonic2: All throughout the deluge Noah had been kicking himself for forgetting to bring any snakes onto the Ark. It wasn´t until the deluge had finished, and Noah had brought the Ark safely back to the harbour that he realised that the snakes had been under the Ark all along.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　巷: on the street; snake (RTK)

Origin: Two snakes . . . strung together . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Isn't this how the US presedential election works? You are given a choice between two snakes. Their politics are actually strung together but you get to feel as though you chose which one you want to lead you down the political road for the next four years. So which snake are you going to elect?
Mnemonic2: You´re driving on the road and you see two snakes together. You can´t avoid both, so you have to elect which one gets run over.
Compo: 巽: southeast　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . shakuhachi.
Mnemonic1: Hand job or "shakuhachi", choose.
Mnemonic2: Depending on where you choose to put your fingers, the shakuhachi will produce a different note.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　尺: shaku

Origin: Water . . . shakuhachi.
Mnemonic1: You´re hiding from the enemy underwater in a swamp. To breathe, you have your shakuhachi flute poking up through the surface of the water.
Mnemonic2: Sirens in the swamp play eerie music on their shakuhachi flutes to lure you in - you follow the enchanting music then its too late as you get trapped in the swamp!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　尺: shaku

Origin: Words . . . shakuhachi.
Mnemonic1: You cannot pretend to translate into words the melody of the shakuhachi!
Mnemonic2: You all know that ´shakuhachi´ is a slang word for blowjob, right? In this kanji you got a job as a TRANSLATOR for Japanese porno movies. So you sit there all day translating dirty WORDS and watching girls perform SHAKUHACHI. This is the life!
Compo: 言: word; say　尺: shaku

Origin: Animal tracks . . . shakuhachi.
Mnemonic1: Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I´d purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They´re so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he´s playing.
Mnemonic2: An interpretive dance of some kind where somebody follows animal tracks, a shakuhachi providing the soundtrack, suggesting the tracker's thoughts and intentions.
Compo: 釆: separate; animal tracks (RTK)　尺: shaku

Origin: At the top we have the arrowhead whose vertical line joins it to the rice field (or brains) below it. Beneath it, the compass; and to the right, the taskmaster.
Mnemonic1: Instead of being glued to one specialty (#46) 専, I decided to spread my attention in many directions 方, and be a taskmaster at none.
Mnemonic2: Arrowheads are spread all over the field. The taskmaster profiteerer forces you to find them all using a compass.
Compo: 甫: for the first time; dog tag (RTK)　方: direction; compass (RTK)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . soil . . . compass . . . taskmaster. You may, of course, take the character for emulate from the previous frame as the basis for this kanji, adding to it only the element for soil.
Mnemonic1: He showed his arrogance as he poured dirt on those who tried to emulate him.
Mnemonic2: Your arrogance has soiled your attempt to emulate such an honorable effort.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil　方: direction; compass (RTK)　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: The hearing referred to in this character relates to trials in the courts. The elements: house . . . dice.
Mnemonic1: At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. ("I can´t believe what I´m hearing!" you say).
Mnemonic2: In the courthouse the judge decides your hearing with a roll of the dice.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　番: turn; dice (RTK)

Origin: Flowers . . . water . . . dice.
Mnemonic1: This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans´ location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29.
Mnemonic2: In the particular clan depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her turn watering the flowers.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　水: water (氵) (氺)　番: turn; dice (RTK)

English: Turn Over, Render In Another Form, Translate,
Origin: Dice . . . feathers.
Mnemonic1: Flipping the bird: After finding out the dice is crooked, you kindly present the middle feather to the dealer.
Mnemonic2: When the birds out the back are playing dice, they flip their feathers (not their finger) at their opponents.
Compo: 番: turn; dice (RTK)　羽: feathers; wings
Kunyomi: ひるがえ.る, ひるがえ.す

Compo: 羊: sheep　羽: feathers; wings

Origin: Tree . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: Like the "ero inquiry" that had been partially swept under the rug (see inquire (#1145)), this kanji depicts the investigation into the forestry scandal being shelved.
Mnemonic2: The result of the inverstigation of the missing Trees? Why, most of them had become shelfs!
Compo: 木: tree; wood　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: The EU and US impose such high tariffs on food imports that third world wheat (the most basic of staples) never reaches first world supermarket shelves.
Mnemonic2: According to Henshall, this kanji originally represented the harvested rice (the wheat primitive) that farmers paid as a tithe. Its meaning today would seem to be very similar. Imagine the farmer putting aside some of his harvested wheat on a shelf in order to pay the tariff to his lord.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: Rice . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: Japanese carpenters don't use sandpaper, they use rice-paper(rice glued on to some paper). Here the carpenter is using the coarse paper to smooth out the shelf he's making.
Mnemonic2: Ugh, why does this shelf feel so coarse? Because it´s made of rice, of coarse! Get it? Of coarse?? Hahahahahahahahahah god i hate my life.
Compo: 米: rice　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: Pinnacle . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: Keeping porn on the pinnacle of a bookshelf can thwart snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya).
Mnemonic2: The shortness of the Japanese thwarts their attempts to reach the topmost (pinnacle) shelf without grabbing a chair.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: Pack of wild dogs . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: When her home was invaded by a pack of dogs, the little girl climbed on the shelf and aimed various items at the dogs below.
Mnemonic2: I think the dogs purposely aim at your shelves to deal the most damage.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)

Origin: This kanji, a polite way of expressing one's best regards to another. Its elements: house . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their best regards, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I´ve gotten so many that I had to buy a second house which contains nothing but several fancy shelves. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.
Mnemonic2: We have a shelf in our house where we put Christmas cards from people who send best regards for the holiday season…
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)
Kunyomi: よろ.しい*, よろ.しく*
Ex3Kana: よろしくおつたえください

Origin: Rice field . . . crown . . . shelf.
Mnemonic1: The king is peacefully sleeping on his new tatami mat when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.
Mnemonic2: Making tatami mats from rice field waste was Japan´s crowning achievement, but for some reason other countries just shelved the idea.
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　冖: crown 　且: moreover; shelf (RTK)
Kunyomi: たた.む, たた.み-, たたみ

Origin: This kanji reverses the element for sprout, giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the rice field. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, armor.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning is roots. Important to that word is the image of "pushing downwards," as roots do.
Mnemonic1: Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai´s armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the "turtle samurai" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.
Mnemonic2: It looks like a bird´s eye view of a tank (modern armor).
Compo: 甲: armor; roots (RTK)

Origin: The kanji shown here actually represents the "second" position in the old Chinese zodiac, which the Japanese still use as an alternate way of enumeration, much the same way that English will revert to Roman numerals. Among its many other meanings are "pure," "tasteful," "quaint," and - get this! - fish guts. Since it is a pictograph of a fishhook, it should not be hard to associate it with the key word.
SubOrigin: We will keep fishhook as the primitive meaning. Its shape will rarely be quite the same as that of the kanji. When it appears at the bottom of another primitive, it is straightened out, almost as if the weight of the upper element had bent it out of shape. And when it appears to the right of another element, the short horizontal line that gets the shape started is omitted and it is stretched out and narrowed, all for reasons of space and aesthetics. Examples follow.
Mnemonic1: This is a fish hook, that pulls out the fishguts.
Mnemonic2: You cut a fish in a z shape on the belly to make it easier to open the fish and rip out its fish guts silly!
Compo: 乙: fishhook; hook

Origin: Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from ceiling . . . person . . . belt. The kanji meaning "inside" should not be used because of its proximity to the element for "in."
Mnemonic1: In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it´s almost pictographic here!).
Mnemonic2: But third class is so small Mr. T´s head hits the celing.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　内: inside

Origin: Tree . . . third class.
Mnemonic1: This is a "design" as in a "pattern", not a verb as in "to design". The tree grain design was too expensive for the third class airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it.
Mnemonic2: Half Way!!!!
Compo: 木: tree; wood　丙: 3rd
Ex1English: Social standing of a family; lineage

Origin: Fingers . . . roots. Compare and contrast with pluck (Frame 1187).
Mnemonic1: Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling.
Mnemonic2: Use your fingers to make sure the roots of your plant are deep underground by pushing them down, down, down.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　甲: armor; roots (RTK)
Kunyomi: お.す, お.し-, お.っ-, お.さえる

Origin: Fingers . . . sprout.
Mnemonic1: (When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers.
Mnemonic2: If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . monkey . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch.
Mnemonic2: If you are familiar with the Monkey legends (西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While searching for the end of the universe, monkey reaches to his crotch and urinates on Buddha´s fingers. (Update: new link http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RYXFppaKLL4).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　申: monkey (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Flag . . . sprout.
Mnemonic1: In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don´t have that in Australia.).
Mnemonic2: A Japanese man ordered some Brussel sprouts from Belgium. They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat).
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)
Kunyomi: とど.ける, -とど.け, とど.く

Origin: House . . . shoot.
Mnemonic1: Jack´s beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT.
Mnemonic2: Hahaha, the image of walking into a house and finding a sea of brussel sprouts floating mid-air is enough for me to remember. Maybe there´s a magician in the kitchen shouting a reassuring "Don´t mind the sprouts!".
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . sprout.
Mnemonic1: Flute is made of bamboo sprout.
Mnemonic2: You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)

Origin: Cloak . . . sprout.
Mnemonic1: Imagine some magic cloak, that when worn, has little green sprouts appearing on the sides that grow into sleeves.
Mnemonic2: The bad magician says, "As you can see, there´s nothing up my sleeves!" Then he trips over his cloak and brussel sprouts fall everywhere.
Compo: 衣: clothes; garment (RTK)　由: reason; sprout (RTK); shoot (RTK)

Origin: Cloak . . . prohibition.
Mnemonic1: A collar is the part of your cloak that, if tightened too tight, will prohibit breathing.
Mnemonic2: Collars are prohibited from wizarding cloaks. Blood purists say they´re too muggle.
Compo: 衣: clothes; garment (RTK)　禁: prohibition
衣: clothes; garment (RTK)　今: now; clock (RTK)

Origin: Cloak . . . reside.
Mnemonic1: Something is residing in the hem of your cloak. Maybe you should consider cleaning it? キョ コ すそ cuff; hem; foot of mountain.
Mnemonic2: If you reside in the slums, you start off as a small child with a very large cloak. As you grow it gets hemmed. The rich kids just get new cloaks.
Compo: 衤: cloak (RTK)　居: reside

Origin: Fingers . . . reside.
Mnemonic1: The man set his finger firmly on the map and said "Here is where they reside, I am certain of it".
Mnemonic2: Cf. reside (#1063): you set the flag with your fingers on the place where you reside: an old tradition.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　居: reside
Ex1English: Set in position, install; set (a table); lay (a foundation)

Origin: Fingers . . . roof.
Mnemonic1: Fingers gripping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie.
Mnemonic2: (This is the にぎ of sushi). A sushi chef climaxes into a rice ball, wraps it in an American flag, and grips is firm with his fingers to form the "Fuck You America Onigiri.".
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　屋: roof; shop
手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　前: in front; before
Kunyomi: そろ.える, そろ.う, そろ.い, -ぞろ.い
Ex2English: Be uniform (even], match; be complete, make a pair; assemble, be all present

Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　無: nothingness

Origin: Words . . . lock of hair.
Mnemonic1: When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don´t keep their word).
Mnemonic2: In "The Lord of the Rings", Galadriel consigned a lock of her hair to Gimli the dwarf, along with some wise words.
Compo: 言: word; say　乇: to entrust with; lock of hair (RTk)

Origin: House . . . lock of hair.
Mnemonic1: This kanji is, of course, pronounced "taku", and it seems the owner of this home is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up locks of hair suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his house. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose home you wouldn´t want to visit.
Mnemonic2: Home is where the hair is.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　乇: to entrust with; lock of hair (RTk)
言: word; say　宅: home; house; residence; our house; my husband

Origin: House . . . potato.
Mnemonic1: Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants.
Mnemonic2: Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　于: going; potato (RTK)

Origin: Flowers . . . potato.
Mnemonic1: If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster.
Mnemonic2: If your potatoes are growing flowers, you need to store them in a more dry place, like hanging them on hooks so they don´t accumulate moisture on the floor.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　于: going; potato (RTK)

Origin: Bushes . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: In an attempt to increase a bush's longevity, an incompitent gardener glues all the leaves back on that have fallen off. Maybe he should have tried watering it instead.
Mnemonic2: This old China man glued shrubs to his body. The added intake of oxygen from the shrubs was, according to him, the secret of his longevity. Sometimes he would sit all day in meditation without moving, and the locals believed the old man had actually turned into a shrub !
Compo: 三: three　丿: katakana no　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Metal . . . longevity. As you probably guessed from the elements, the key word refers to the casting of metals.
Mnemonic1: We take a casting because metal will have much greater longevity than the original.
Mnemonic2: They made a metal casting of the Chinese man who glued shrubs to himself to increase his longevity. It´s now sold around the world as it´s thought that having one will increase your own longevity..
Compo: 金: gold; metal　寿: longevity

Origin: Take inscription in the sense of the name you ask the jeweler to carve on a gold bracelet or inside a gold ring to identify its owner or communicate some sentimental message. It will help if you can recall the first time you had this done and the feelings you had at the time.
Mnemonic1: A piece of metal with a name on it. Well, this is basically the definition of inscription.
Mnemonic2: I imagine ancient Egyptian inscriptions: Pharaohs´ names written in gold.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　名: name

Origin: After lakes but before glass, polished metal was used for mirrors. These metal mirrors are recalled in this character for a mirror.
Mnemonic1: Mirror should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a Golden mirror so she can stand in front of it all day vainly admiring her lovely human legs.
Mnemonic2: metal + stand up + sun + legs remember the legend of Amaterasu who retired in a cave. the other Gods brought a MIRROR made of polished METAL at the entrance of the cave. Amaterasu who was STANDING UP saw her image of the SUN and began to dance with her LEGS.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　竟: end; mirror (RTK)

Origin: Imagine the boundary of a plot of land marked with gigantic mirrors enabling the landowner to keep trespassers in sight at all times.
Mnemonic1: In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put mirrors on the boundary of his land so it feels much bigger.
Mnemonic2: This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the boundary of your land and theirs. When they approach the boundary, what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn´t any better than their own and they head back home.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　竟: end; mirror (RTK)

Origin: Jewel . . . eye . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . scarf. The number of elements is large here, so take extra care. Learn it in conjunction with the next frame, since these are the only two cases in this book where the combination of elements to the right appears.
Mnemonic1: Together with the next kanji, the keywords spell “send back the ring”. First we have a jewel. Next we have the great eye of Sauron searching for the fellowship hiding under the many ceilings during their journey. The fourth and fifth primitives are the mouth of Gollum always mumbling “My preciousss”; and Pippin´s scarf! Placement: the eye appears at the top similarly to how the Great Eye of Sauron is perched atop the Dark Tower.
Mnemonic2: In conjunction with send back (#837)....... When I tried to give her the jewel ring, she eyed me, threw it to the floor, opened her mouth and tried to speak, she said nothing. She grabbed her scarf and left.
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth　𧘇: clothers; scarf (RTK)

Origin: Road . . . eye . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . scarf.
Mnemonic1: You´ve probably guessed it by now, this is the road that Sam and Frodo take to send back the ring to Mount Doom! (see previous frame, the jewel is replaced by the road).
Mnemonic2: Continued from ring (#836)....... So I´m on the road going to send back the ring minus the jewel, the hit to the floor knocked it out.
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth　𧘇: clothers; scarf (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex2English: Completion of the traditional sexagenary cycle, 60th birthday

Origin: Dragging . . . ten eyes.
Mnemonic1: You paint 10 huge eyes on your shield to scare the enemy, but consequently your shield is so big and heavy that you have to drag it.
Mnemonic2: From Wikipedia: "If a Spartan hoplite were to return to Sparta alive and without his shield, it was assumed that he threw his shield at the enemy in an effort to flee; an act punishable by death or banishment." Picture the enemy of a Spartan soldier poking his eyes out with a sewing needle and trying to steal his shield. However, the Spartan desperately clutches on, and is dragged around for a while, preferring to die than to lose his shield.
Compo: 厂: cliff　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　目: eye

Origin: Line . . . shield.
Mnemonic1: This is mostly used in the word 循環, "circulation" (of buses through their routes, of blood, etc). So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system.
Mnemonic2: A column of shielded soldiers advancing sequentially to avoid revealing the size of their army (Think "Sandpeople always ride single file to hide their numbers" from Star Wars).
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　盾: shield

Origin: A virtual flood of motorcycle police washing down a road is this kanji's image for a patrol.
Mnemonic1: The cops don´t PATROL anymore - they just flood the road.
Mnemonic2: The Venice cops patrol on river roads.
Compo: 巛: river (川); flood (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex4English: Patrol, make a round of inspections

Compo: 言: word; say　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Ex1English: Crawl on all fours, stay flat
Ex2English: Crawling sideways; flat (as of sales numbers)

Origin: Drag . . . cornstalk . . . belt . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Picture a crude drag-sled - in this case, made from cornstalks that have been belted together - filled with parcels, that the postman drags along behind him down the road along his delivery route.
Mnemonic2: (I prefer 2 towels over cornstalk and belt) - Have you ever wondered why your parcels always end up in such bad condition when you get them? Or why you never get them at all? That´s because you´ve never looked at how they´re actually delivered - each postman is given a load of parcel post and 2 towels to drag them down the road on.
Compo: 厂: cliff　二: two　巾: towel　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Nose . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Your breath brings oxygen in through your nose which is then pumped around your body by your heart.
Mnemonic2: I think I´ve met my dream girl, but there´s a problem. her breath is horrible! So, do I listen to my nose or my heart?
Compo: 自: oneself; nose (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Tongue . . . nose . . . heart. The sense of breath from the last frame should not be used; it could lead you to put only the nose over the heart and leave the tongue off to one side.
Mnemonic1: Recess to me is a school break. At recess some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. Tongues and noses are nothing special. The new cool is to have your heart done!
Mnemonic2: Ah recess; tongues slandering, noses being turned up, and beneath it all, young hearts being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of tongues, which helps me remember that in this kanji tongue comes first.
Compo: 舌: tongue　自: oneself; nose (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Let me share a rather grotesque image to help with this kanji. Imagine taking your two hands and reaching up into someone's nostrils. Once inside you grab hold of the brain and yank it out. At the end, you would have a picture something like that of this character, the full kanji for nose.
Mnemonic1: An Egyptian embalmer reaching both hands into the dead pharaoh´s nose and yanking out handfuls of brain.
Mnemonic2: I sneezed so hard that through my NOSE I blew out my BRAINS into BOTH HANDS.
Compo: 自: oneself; nose (RTK)　畀: to give

Origin: Probably the one thing most children fear more than anything else is the dentist's chair. Once a child has seen a dentist holding the x-rays up to the light and heard that ominous word cavity, even though it is not likely to know that the word means "hole" until it is much older, it will not be long before those two syllables get associated with the drill and that row of shiny hooks the dentist uses to torture people who are too small to fight back.
Mnemonic1: The child´s arms flailed around at the sight of the hooked tool the dentist was going to use to fill his cavity.
Mnemonic2: I warned him about cavities, but the child is still hooked on sweets.
Compo: 子: child　乚: hidden; hook (RTK)

Origin: This character is a bit friendlier to the animal world. Our friend the St. Bernard is alive and well, its nose in the air sniffing suspiciously after something stinking somewhere or other.
Mnemonic1: The ST. BERNARD DOG lifted his large NOSE high in the air to find out where the stinking smell comes from.
Mnemonic2: When I is big, Ego stinking.
Compo: 自: oneself; nose (RTK)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)
Kunyomi: くさ.い, -くさ.い, にお.う, にお.い

Origin: You have seen those scratch'n'sniff advertisements for perfumes. This one is for a mouthwash that replaces one stinking oder with another.
Mnemonic1: Your mouth stinks: you need to sniff your breath.
Mnemonic2: You open your mouth and gasp for air, 1 sniff of that stinking chihuahua is too much. *Edited thecite's to reflect the keyword in the supplement.
Compo: 口: mouth　臭: stinking

Origin: A drop . . . pent in . . . rice . . . St. Bernard dog. Notice that the horizontal line of the bottom primitive doubles up as the final stroke for pent in.
Mnemonic1: In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It´s very dangerous, so they´ve trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he´s adding more drops of rice as necessary.
Mnemonic2: 奥さん （おくさん) is a common way to say "wife". In the innermost core of the house, the bored pent up housewife drops her chores and consumes so much rice she becomes a very large housewife.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　米: rice　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)
小: little; owl (RTK)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)
Ex2English: Be pointed, be sharp; become irritated

Origin: Hole . . . St. Bernard dog.
Mnemonic1: When you stab something you often leave a big hole.
Mnemonic2: The police have recruited a special breed of St. Bernard that can lick the wounds of a stabbing victim. The bleeding will stop instantly, saving the victim´s life. One quirky side-effect, however, is that this treatment leaves behind a rather large hole...
Compo: 穴: hole　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)

Origin: Hole . . . climax.
Mnemonic1: Sticking a plug up your hole will lead to stronger climaxes.
Mnemonic2: Here we have a Hole and Climax to mean PLUG UP. This is so butt-f**king easy, pun intended. If you PLUG UP her Hole, she will Climax.
Compo: 穴: hole　至: climax

Origin: Hole . . . cut.
Mnemonic1: This more commonly means "steal", like how a thief cuts a hole to steal the jewels.
Mnemonic2: Stealth bombers cut holes through the enemy radar.
Compo: 穴: hole　切: cut

Origin: Boulevard . . . heavy.
Mnemonic1: Two heavy trucks in a game of chicken collide while racing toward each other on the boulevard.
Mnemonic2: 衝 【しょう】 (n) (1) important point (e.g. on a route); (2) important role (responsibility, etc.); (3) (astronomical) opposition. STORY:Two HEAVY trucks are playing a game of chicken on the BOULEVARD. However, they both missed the IMPORTANT POINT: that they have to turn in different directions. Naturally, they COLLIDE when they both turn in the same direction. (ty dingomick).
Compo: 行: going; journey　重: heavy

Origin: Grow up . . . dagger . . . St. Bernard dog. The connotation of this character should be kept distinct from that for vow (Frame 1214) and promise (Frame 1462).
Mnemonic1: Imagine a totalitarian regime where, while growing up, you have to pledge allegiance to the flag at dagger-point and with St. Bernard guard dogs watching you.
Mnemonic2: In order to pledge into her sorority, Alice had to stab a St. Bernard with a dagger. (Come on! DO it, Alice!).
Compo: 龶: grow up, master (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . pledge.
Mnemonic1: This means eat/drink/smoke. Maybe you make a pledge to stop gutsing/binging/puffing, but your own mouth is tempting you to put something in it.
Mnemonic2: I make my mouth pledge to consume less.
Compo: 口: mouth　契: pledge

Origin: Water . . . grow up . . . dagger . . . thread. Do not confuse with upright (Frame 58).
Mnemonic1: To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her threads, even when she went into the water.
Mnemonic2: (rgravina) To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her Spiderman underwear (to remember the position of thread), even when she went into the water.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　龶: grow up, master (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)

Origin: Every . . . person.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T has scorn for every fool.
Mnemonic2: People full of scorn tend to hate every person (including themselves).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　毎: every
Ex3English: Despise, disdain, hold in contempt, make light of

Origin: Behind every Jack Horner's pie maker, a tree full of plums.
Mnemonic1: Plums actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn´t know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. Plums are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some plum-loving scientists are working on a way to hack every tree´s genetic code so that every tree will bear nothing _but_ plums.
Mnemonic2: EVERY Japanese person asks you if you like UMEBOSHI. No I say, I prefer to eat my PLUMS fresh from the TREE.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　毎: every

Origin: State of mind . . . every (See frame 497).
Mnemonic1: For all have sinned... so everyone´s state of mind should be to repent.
Mnemonic2: When you repent, you heal your state of mind by going over every thing you regret doing.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　毎: every
Kunyomi: く.いる, く.やむ, くや.しい

Origin: Behind every successful taskmaster, the cleverness of a fox to outwit his charges.
Mnemonic1: Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of cleverness.
Mnemonic2: Cleverness is something every taskmaster must have. Every taskmaster has cleverness.
Compo: 毎: every　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)

Origin: Cleverness . . . thread.
Mnemonic1: Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When Venom realized he couldn´t beat Spider-Man in a fair fight, he showed his cleverness by spraying venom all over Spider-Man´s luxuriant garden.
Mnemonic2: Venom is covered in a luxuriant and surprisingly clever symbiotic suit, but it´s also the taskmaster for his every evil act.
Compo: 敏: cleverness; agile　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)
車: car　殳: lance, missile (RTK)　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)
Kunyomi: つな.ぐ, つな.がる, かか.る

Origin: The sense of the key word overgrown is of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess - in this case a whole parade of weeds (outcast flowers). By way of exception, the flowers take their normal place over the enclosure.
Mnemonic1: The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers.
Mnemonic2: When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it´s like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　戊: halberd; parade (RTK)

Origin: The bridge shown here is made of trees in their natural form, except that the trunks have been carved into the forms of angels, a sort of "Ponte degli Angeli."
Mnemonic1: The nicest bridge is not in Hollywood or Los Angeles, but in San Francisco.
Mnemonic2: A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, "Don´t worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you." The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, "What are you doing with that wood?" "I´m trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels.".
Compo: 木: tree; wood　喬: high; angels (RTK)

Origin: Dart . . . angel. Compare your stories for correct (Frame 405), revise (Frame 362), and reformation (Frame 567).
Mnemonic1: Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man...
Mnemonic2: The darts of the angel Cupid are supposed to bring people joy, but usually just make things a lot worse. Here we see another angel flying around shooting people with the anti-darts (antidote), to rectify the situation.
Compo: 矢: arrow; dart (RTK)　喬: high; angels (RTK)

Origin: The key word connotes the preliminary composition of a plan or manuscript. Its elements: wheat . . . tall.
Mnemonic1: The first DRAFT of catcher in the rye was actually called "catcher in the TALL WHEAT"...good thing they changed it. I read it in 高校.
Mnemonic2: Aliens often draft their plans for invasion by cutting designs among the tall wheat.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　高: tall; high; expensive
糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　高: tall; high; expensive

Origin: Bamboo . . . float. Note that the drawing of the primitive for float uses the abbreviated form that has become standard in the general-use kanji and as we met it earlier (Frames 393-95). Until such time as typesetting fonts make the adjustment, only the older form has been approved. Here we have opted for the simpler, avant garde drawing.
Mnemonic1: Note: the spelling should be stationery (= paper, office supplies), not stationary (= not moving). The error is in the original book.
Mnemonic2: The two fiestas communicated to each other on their respective floats by using bamboo stationery.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)

Origin: Bones . . . (parade) float.
Mnemonic1: The remainder of the bones have been thrown from the float (for the dogs maybe, at the end of the parade).
Mnemonic2: Throwing all those coins (see coin (#368)) was a really bad idea; people got mad with greed. The only remainders left were the bones of those that was on the float.
Compo: 歹: bones　㦮: float (RTK)
Ex1English: Remain, linger, stay; be left over; survive

Origin: Prior to the use of metal, trees were once cut down and bound together for use as scaffolding material. In the case of this kanji, what is being constructed is not a skyscraper but a simple float.
Mnemonic1: Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html).
Mnemonic2: You need a SCAFFOLD made of WOOD to build a FLOAT if it will be several stories high.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　戔: float

Origin: Those special gold-colored tokens minted each year for the Mardi Gras and thrown into the crowds from people on the floats give us the kanji for coins.
Mnemonic1: Political hopefuls in Rome threw gold COINS from floats when they were campaigning for office.
Mnemonic2: Interesting fact: The Japanese one yen coin is the only coin in the world that can float on water. http://www.hanamiweb.com/floatingyen.jpg.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　戔: float

Origin: Wooden leg . . . parade float.
Mnemonic1: The pirate with the wooden leg chased after the parade float and was run over by the next one, leaving tread marks all over him and his leg.
Mnemonic2: Pirates must tread carefully when walking on parade floats, so as not to break through the weak plaster with their wooden legs.
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　戔: float

Origin: An entourage of floats going from one town to the next must always seek a shallow place to cross the water. Try to picture what happens if they don't.
Mnemonic1: The water can´t be too SHALLOW if you expect to float.
Mnemonic2: The water isn´t shallow enough to ford (#372). We´ll have to cross by float!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　戔: float
水: water (氵) (氺)　曳: pull; tug; jerk; admit; install; quote; refer to
Kunyomi: も.る, も.れる, も.らす

Origin: Robust is seen as a turtle turned samurai.
Mnemonic1: Half of a turtle shell as a shield makes a samurai more robust.
Mnemonic2: The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are robust gentlemen aren´t they?
Compo: 丬: left-side; turtle (RTK)　士: gentleman; samurai

Origin: The villa pictured here is filled with exotic flowers at every turn, and has a pair of turtle-samurai standing before its gates.
Mnemonic1: A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average.
Mnemonic2: The teenage mutant samurai turtles live in a villa with flowers on the roof so that the neighbours don´t get suspicious.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　壮: robust

Origin: The character for attire can be remembered as a picture of what we may call a "turtle-samurai" sweater. At the top we see the turtle-samurai and at the bottom the element for garment.
Mnemonic1: The TURTLE SAMURAI needs special GARMENTs for his ATTIRE since his body is much more ROBUST than others.
Mnemonic2: The ninja turtles tried to go eat at a fancy restaurant, but they were told to come back after their were dressed in proper attire. However, it´s too difficult for them to find proper garments because they bodies are so robust! (sannomiya + drwarrior12).
Compo: 壮: robust　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: The key word in this frame refers to the underworld, the world of the dead. By way of the classic Greek association, it is also used for the "dwarf planet" Pluto. Since no one knows precisely when this part of the cosmos was finished, we may imagine it as the crowning deed of day six of the creation.
Mnemonic1: The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666.
Mnemonic2: In Hades you have to work six days a week before crowning it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Oh wait, that´s Japan.
Compo: 冖: crown 　日: day; sun　六: six
Ex2English: Bliss in the next world, soul's repose

Origin: When "darkness covered the earth" at the beginning of time, there was neither sun nor sound.
Mnemonic1: Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then...nothing. Everything would plunge into darkness.
Mnemonic2: In places of complete darkness, such as caves where the sun can´t reach, creatures such as bats have learned to navigate by sound rather than sight. The poor guys must have to fly around screaming "Marco!" and "Polo!" all the time.
Compo: 日: day; sun　音: sound

Origin: Poetry restricted to verses that rhyme often finds it has to abandon clarity of thought in order to make the rhyme of the words work. In this kanji's picture, one becomes a kind of "sound-employee."
Mnemonic1: What is a RHYME but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.
Mnemonic2: Dr Seuss´s employee finally rebels against him: "I´m tired of odd sounds all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in RHYME!".
Compo: 音: sound　員: employee

Origin: Finger . . . employee.
Mnemonic1: Boss yells, "Who damaged the Xerox machine?!" fingers of employees point at one another.
Mnemonic2: If you finger your employee, you risk incurring many damages from a possible sexual harassment lawsuit.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　員: employee
Kunyomi: そこ.なう, -そこ.なう, そこ.ねる, -そこ.ねる

Origin: Fingers . . . dog tag.
Mnemonic1: I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to catch them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off.
Mnemonic2: Dog tag: This is a wild animal track device. It has an arrowhead and screwdriver-shaped radio beacon. It´s evidently fired in animals to track their movements. When animal has a dog tag, it´s easy to catch it: just take a dog tag in your fingers.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　甫: for the first time; dog tag (RTK)
Kunyomi: と.らえる, と.らわれる, と.る, つか.まえる, つか.まる

Origin: Fingers . . . thousand . . . roots. Observe how the writing order does not follow the elements in order, because the final stroke is used for two different elements.
Mnemonic1: A rice farmer´s delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and thousand of root-like tentacles are inserting themselves in... well, I think you can fill the rest.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　千: thousand　日: day; sun

Origin: Cloak . . . dog tag.
Mnemonic1: I usually hear supplement in "dietry supplement". So you´re given a cloak for extra fibre and dogtags for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down.
Mnemonic2: The name and number printed on a soldier´s cloak is a supplement to his main I.D. tag; his dog-tag, in helping identify the soldier.
Compo: 衤: cloak (RTK)　甫: for the first time; dog tag (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . dog tag.
Mnemonic1: The water of the bay washes all the dog tags up after the battle.
Mnemonic2: Otis Redding is sitting on the dock of the bay, looking over the water while clutching the dog tags of his fallen friend from Vietnam.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　甫: for the first time; dog tag (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . dog tag.
Mnemonic1: The scaredy-cat soldier puts his dog tags in his mouth and suckles them nervously. It sounds like he's a suckling infant.
Mnemonic2: suckle: this mother had heptuplets. Wow! But she had to put dog tags on the mouths of her babies to keep track of which ones had been suckled.
Compo: 口: mouth　甫: for the first time; dog tag (RTK)

Origin: Cottage . . . dog tag. The key word refers to the noun, not the verb.
Mnemonic1: A shop in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it.
Mnemonic2: Normal cottages (舎 actually means a building) don´t have tags advertising their names, but shops do.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　吉: good luck; lidded crock (RTK); aerosol can (RTK)　甫: for the first time; dog tag (RTK)
手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　国: country
Kunyomi: つか.む, つか.まえる, つか.まる

Origin: Fingers . . . leg.
Mnemonic1: I felt a finger on my leg as someone tried to nab my wallet.
Mnemonic2: Fingers nabs Davy Jone´s wooden leg: Argh! Bring me back me leg, ya scurvy dog!
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . leg.
Mnemonic1: Mr T, ever the optimist, is trying to stimulate Capt Ahab´s wooden leg by rubbing it down. Capt Ahab normally wouldn´t let anyone do that, but he appreciates Mr T´s stimulating conversation.
Mnemonic2: You stimulate a person by giving him a kick.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . brush.
Mnemonic1: Bamboo is the best material from which to make a brush if you want it to be a writing brush.
Mnemonic2: Bamboo would make an excellent writing brush as the ink could flow through the hollow center like an ink pen...
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　聿: brush; rake (RTK)

Origin: Seeing the tiny boats of poor mortals tossed about in a stormy sea like so many corks, the All-Merciful took its brush and drew little inlets of water where the hapless creatures might seek shelter. And so it is that we have havens.
Mnemonic1: A brush laying in dirty water is a haven for bacteria.
Mnemonic2: The haven for a BRUSH is in WATER.. Otherwise they get dry and withered and cant be used?!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　聿: brush; rake (RTK)

Origin: This character depicts a calligrapher's brush and its rhythmic sway as it flows down a column writing kanji on the way.
Mnemonic1: The calligrapher´s brush is moving down a column of a script, in rhythm with his meditation.
Mnemonic2: The army COLUMN walked to the RHYTHM made by the drummer using a cool BRUSH like drum stick. Picturing the brush as a drum stick is not difficult if you´ve seen such a thing in jazz videos.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　聿: brush; rake (RTK)

Origin: Think of apprehending criminals. The elements are: sieve . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals.
Mnemonic2: In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to apprehend Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying "Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!".
Compo: 隶: extend; slave; sieve (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: To construct a building, you first draw a set of plans (the writing brush) and then s-t-r-e-t-c-h your drawing out to scale in reality.
Mnemonic1: Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it´s just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.
Mnemonic2: A construction worker´s classic morning. Stretch, brush his teeth, and then start to build.
Compo: 聿: brush; rake (RTK)　廴: stretch
Kunyomi: た.てる, た.て, -だ.て, た.つ

Origin: Person . . . build.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T in a public service announcement yells, "I´m healthy because every day I build a food pyramid, foo!".
Mnemonic2: Mr.T, sir, how do you stay so healthy? I asked. "Simple, foo," he answered, "you gotta build the body up by bodybuilding!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　建: build

Origin: Cave . . . sieve.
Mnemonic1: A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease).
Mnemonic2: People on the cave age became more sane after they started using sieves to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康, health).
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　隶: extend; slave; sieve (RTK)

Origin: Cave . . . rake . . . screwdriver.
Mnemonic1: To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.
Mnemonic2: When I first moved in to my new cave, all I had was a bed (see bed (#592)). But now I´ve settled in, got myself a few handy things like a rake and a screwdriver, and made myself more comfortable.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　肀: rake (RTK)　用: to use; screwdriver (RTK)

Origin: Rake . . . rice . . . fenceposts. Take special care to draw this character in the same order as the primitive. Note too, that the fourth stroke for rice is already taken care of by the fourth stroke of rake.
Mnemonic1: Even though it´s a maddening task, the monks stay solemn as they rake rice between the fenceposts.
Mnemonic2: Note: This is not sieve as it has a full rice and not rice grains and the hook is missing from rake. Also the given stroke order is incorrect (fenceposts should come last).
Compo: 聿: brush; rake (RTK)　米: rice　丿: katakana no　丨: line; stick
糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　粛: solemn; quietly; softly

Origin: The key word here refers of course to the T'ang Dynasty in China (and not to the name of the drink astronauts take with them into outer space, though this could be useful for the next frame). Its elements: cave . . . rake . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, "What about this – T´ang, do you think?" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, "Yes, it does tang a bit".
Mnemonic2: Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical caves, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden rakes to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their mouths to see if it´s tasty or not.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　ヨ: broom (RTK)　亅: hook　口: mouth

Origin: Rice . . . T'ang.
Mnemonic1: Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour.
Mnemonic2: The T´ang are the ones who began using sugar in China--of course, the first thing they tried it on was rice.
Compo: 米: rice　唐: T'ang; China

Origin: Rice . . . cave . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: Condy Rice is actually white, but she uses special cosmetics made from dirt she found in a cave to appear black - it´s better for the political situation.
Mnemonic2: Modern cosmetics are just the descendants of the old RICE flour and CAVE DIRT (´cause it´s darker) used in the past.
Compo: 米: rice　广: cave (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Rice . . . quantity.
Mnemonic1: Imagine Japanese army provisions like obentou boxes, always containing the same quantity of rice. (thanks darg_sama, emphasizing quantity and the nuance of food "rations", "food supply": the kanji also appears in "military provisions" and "army rice").
Mnemonic2: All Japanese provisions contain a certain quantity of rice... they eat it with just about every meal!
Compo: 米: rice　量: quantity

Origin: Rice . . . part.
Mnemonic1: Parts of parts of parts of parts of rice... is flour. (Image: geishas patting their face with RICE flour to make it white. Not wheat flour...).
Mnemonic2: In the United States, part of every meal is made from flour.
Compo: 米: rice　分: part; segment

Origin: Thread . . . part.
Mnemonic1: It is easy for arguments to get distracted from the main thread by a tendency to part threads (splitting hairs).
Mnemonic2: Spiderman got distracted when someone yelled, "Spiderman, wait a minute." He turned around and flew into a building. ("part" also means "minute").
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　分: part; segment
Kunyomi: まぎ.れる, -まぎ.れ, まぎ.らす, まぎ.らわす, まぎ.らわしい
Ex2English: Be confused with, be mistaken for; be diverted from

Origin: Thread . . . cornucopia.
Mnemonic1: A cornucopia is a twisted goat's horn decorated with coloured threads.
Mnemonic2: (twist; ask; investigate; verify] Stories full of twists are difficult to write, because of the cornucopia of threads the author has to manage.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　丩: to join; cornucopia (RTK)

Origin: Rice . . . game of cricket. (See frame 121.)
Mnemonic1: In extremely chic restaurants, you have to pay 90 bucks for a bowl of rice.
Mnemonic2: Americans think that tattoos with Chinese characters are chic, but nine out of ten times they end up with something trivial tattooed on their arm, like rice.
Compo: 米: rice　卆: soldier; game of cricket (RTK)

Origin: We begin with the two elements on the right, baseball and needle. Since they will be coming together from time to time, let us give the two of them the sense of a game of cricket in which a needle is laid across the wicket. Then imagine using a rock for a ball. A smash hit would probably splinter the bat in all directions, and a smashing pitch would do the same with the needle wicket.
Mnemonic1: To SMASH a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.
Mnemonic2: The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they´ve done a new SMASH hit!
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　卆: soldier; game of cricket (RTK)

Origin: You might think of the frame this character refers to as the sort of frame we have created by drawing a dark line around this kanji and its explanation. Then think of that line as made of very thin wood; and finally note how each time the line bends it forms a 90° angle, thus giving us the nine and the ten.
Mnemonic1: wood at 90 (9 * 10) degrees.
Mnemonic2: Nine out of ten picture frames are made out of wood. The rest are made of metal or plastic.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　九: nine; baseball (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . baseball . . . needle.
Mnemonic1: God you´re drunk! How many whiskeys did you have? 9? 10?
Mnemonic2: Whiskey with 90 percent alcohol will get you drunk. I don´t care who you are.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　卆: soldier; game of cricket (RTK)

Origin: Whisky bottle . . . star.
Mnemonic1: On awakening the first thing I notice is a (nearly empty) whiskey bottle by my bed. Then I see the stars are still shining. “I think I’ll go back to sleep and try awakening again later.”.
Mnemonic2: You´ll need an awakening after the whiskey bottle makes you see stars.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　星: star

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . state.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey.
Mnemonic2: Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will repay the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　州: state; province

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . revelation.
Mnemonic1: It´s cruel to pour alcohol down a cow´s mouth.
Mnemonic2: There is a saying that a drunk man's words are a sober man's thoughts. Be careful about giving someone a bottle of whiskey, you may get some revelations about their cruelty. Of course, they'll just say that it's the whiskey speaking.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　告: announce; revelation

Origin: While we refer to something insignificant as a "drop in the bucket," the kanji for mediocre suggests the image of a "drop in the wind."
Mnemonic1: A drop of breeze is naught but a mediocre wind.
Mnemonic2: Is there anything as mediocre as a drop of piss in the wind?
Compo: 几: table; wind (RTK)　丶: dot; drop
几: table; wind (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: A sail made of a towel makes a mediocre vessel.
Mnemonic1: When stranded at sea, we needed a Sail. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND.
Mnemonic2: A towel makes a mediocre sail.
Compo: 巾: towel　凡: mediocre

Origin: The sense of the key word here is the "all-inclusive" we find in terms like "Pan-American Games." (It is also the character used in mathematics for "partial" as in partial differentials, in case you are a math major and want to take your story in that direction.) Instead of a water sports event that brings together the best talent, think of a meet of the region's most mediocre athletes, many of whom cannot even tread water. Now try to find a sponsor for the "Pan-Mediocre Water Sports Competition."
Mnemonic1: Yeah, all our water is fairly mediocre, but if we work together in some pan-continental union, we can make some better water! As if.
Mnemonic2: This is pan- as in the prefix meaning "all". I think of Pangea as being a mediocre continent with water covering the rest of the planet. This was before it broke up into the first-class, well-distributed continents we got now.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　凡: mediocre

Origin: Craft . . . mediocre . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: If your heart surgeon is mediocre in his craft, you have plenty of reason to fear. ("Oops, I think I left my scissors in there").
Mnemonic2: My deep dark fear at the bottom of my heart is that I am mediocre at my craft.
Compo: 工: craft; construction　凡: mediocre　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: おそ.れる, おそ.る, おそ.ろしい

Origin: State of mind . . . linen.
Mnemonic1: Someone in a dreadful state of mind has crawled into his bed and is hiding under the sheets (linens).
Mnemonic2: Being an android, Data is white as a sheet. Doctor Crusher always has to remind herself that this is perfectly normal. From a doctor´s perspective, he really does look dreadful.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　布: linen; cloth

Origin: Bamboo . . . craft . . . mediocre . . . wood/tree.
Mnemonic1: Bamboo crafting is a mediocre substitute for wood when you are building or fabricating a house. While it may look good and might attract a chick (ちく) or two, the kids´ll (きず) just tear it to pieces as its not sturdy enough.
Mnemonic2: A bamboo fabrication is a mediocre substitute for wood.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　工: craft; construction　凡: mediocre　木: tree; wood

Origin: Broom . . . craft . . . mouth . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.).
Mnemonic2: As a verb this means, this means "to ask; to enquire; to search; to look for; to look into; to investigate;". Imagine the police inquiring in an in-depth investigation. They are interrogating a suspect. But the suspect has a crafty mouth and is very sly. He/she also knows when to keep their mouth shut(glued) at the right moments to avoid self-incrimination. As a final measure, the police torture the suspect by tickling him/her with a broom while they inquire.
Compo: ヨ: broom (RTK)　工: craft; construction　口: mouth　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: To seek the words of a second mouth is to consult with someone about something.
Mnemonic1: Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.
Mnemonic2: Consulting with is having words with the next mouth.
Compo: 言: word; say　咨: investigate

Origin: Fingers . . . a whirlwind.
Mnemonic1: Gandalf confronts the evil beast, shouting "you shall not pass!". He holds up a single finger and sends forth a whirlwind.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a thumb war. A confrontation of fingers in a whirlwind.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　亢: high spirits; whirlwind (RTK)

Origin: Boat . . . whirlwind.
Mnemonic1: To navigate a "boat" through a "whirlwind" takes a skilled navigator.
Mnemonic2: In Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, you can navigate your boat by summoning whirlwinds.
Compo: 舟: boat　亢: high spirits; whirlwind (RTK)

Origin: A whirlwind begins to dig its way into the soil like a drill until it makes a deep pit.
Mnemonic1: A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit.
Mnemonic2: Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a pit into the soil. Note: Take care difference between pit and rut.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　亢: high spirits; whirlwind (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . bush . . . suspended from the ceiling.
Mnemonic1: I put my fingers together in worship of the bush that hangs from the ceiling -- that wonderful mistletoe which has gotten me kissed by many a girl.
Mnemonic2: Because I worship her, I only finger ONE BUSH, her´s, and no others!
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　三: three　丨: line; stick

Ex3English: Bow in veneration, worship; pay one's respects with joined hands, entreat

Origin: Christmas tree . . . well.
Mnemonic1: If you just grow your christmas tree in a well, there will be no need to till the soil.
Mnemonic2: A man was tilling a new plot to plant xmas trees but his tractor hit an old covered-up well and fell halfway in, he´s asking for a new tractor for xmas..
Compo: 耒: plough; christmas tree (RTK)　井: well

Origin: Christmas tree . . . fur.
Mnemonic1: The amount of "fur" (needles) on a Christmas tree decreases, until it doesn´t look all that good.
Mnemonic2: Real fur coats and real christmas trees are dereasing the last couple of years. Plasctic chrismas trees and fake fur it is nowadays.
Compo: 耒: plough; christmas tree (RTK)　毛: fur

Origin: Mountain . . . religion.
Mnemonic1: In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to adore the gods who live on Mount Olympus.
Mnemonic2: I would adore the religious people if they just went and threw themselves off a mountain top.
Compo: 山: mountain　宗: religion

Origin: The kanji for ashes naturally includes the primitive for fire, or more specifically, a fireplace. Now what do you do with that bucket of ashes you have just cleaned out of the fireplace? You walk to the edge of a cliff and tip it upside down, watching as they are swept away in the wind like a swarm of gray mosquitoes. Thus the fire, once it has turned to ashes, ends up at the bottom of the cliff.
Mnemonic1: The fire underneath the cliff will eventually turn everything above to ashes.
Mnemonic2: Scene from "The Big Lebowski" : Walter scatters Donny´s ashes, but a wind blows much of the ashes into "The Dude" Lebowski´s face. Upset, The Dude lashes out at Walter.
