Walter apologizes and hugs The Dude, before suggesting "Fuck it, man. Let´s go bowling." I bet you that The Dude wanted to cremate (fire) Walter right there and then, at the top of the cliff! (thanks Elktapestry).
Compo: 厂: cliff　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Mountain . . . ashes.
Mnemonic1: Burn enough charcoal and you´ll have a mountain of ash.
Mnemonic2: You get charcoal from volcano ("fire mountain", 火山) ashes.
Compo: 山: mountain　灰: ashes

Origin: Mountain . . . cliff . . . dry.
Mnemonic1: At the base of mountain cliffs, there is usually a beach. You often can see people lying there, drying off after a swim.
Mnemonic2: Three impossibilities for a beach: There cannot be a beach at the top of a mountain. There cannot be a beach on the top of a cliff. There cannot be a beach that is completely dry.
Compo: 山: mountain　厂: cliff　干: dry

Origin: Mountain . . . rock.
Mnemonic1: A mountain-sized stone is known as a boulder.
Mnemonic2: Here we see mountain rocks rolling down the mountain, gathering into a single monstrous boulder crushing everything in its path. Think snowball effect, even if it wouldn´t work with rocks.
Compo: 山: mountain　石: stone; rock (RTK)

Origin: Mountain . . . companion.
Mnemonic1: Sam and Frodo were steadfast companions even as Mount Doom crumbled above them.
Mnemonic2: September 11. (lol it also has 11 strokes], whoever reported this story is a loser, get alife. This is the best story on the website.
Compo: 山: mountain　朋: companion; friend
Kunyomi: くず.れる, -くず.れ, くず.す

Origin: Mountain . . . winds.
Mnemonic1: Storm is a full-blown wind that rips the mountains off the ground (you see one flying here).
Mnemonic2: Winds are gathering at the base of the mountain (note the hint to primitive placement), going up, and turning into a huge mountain storm.
Compo: 山: mountain　風: wind

Origin: Mountain . . . cliff . . . ivy.
Mnemonic1: Standing at the base of the bluffs I announce, "I´m going to climb those ivy-covered cliffs, and then the mountain on top of them." My friends don´t believe me, "He bluffs!" they say.
Mnemonic2: The ivy-covered cliff we saw on the horizon (#157) ... the sheer beauty of the mountain that overlooks these bluffs is enough to make you want to swim for shore yourself!
Compo: 山: mountain　厂: cliff　圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)

Origin: Hermit . . . turkey. Note what has happened to the mountain in the element for hermit. In order to make room for the turkey, it was raised and condensed.
Mnemonic1: And now a word from our sponsor. We see Mr. T, doing a sort of George Foreman thing, grilling Mountain Turkeys. "I pity da foo who don´t have a Mr. T grill!".
Mnemonic2: Mister T sponsors a meeting in the mountains (he´s an hermit), talking over a megaphone “I pity da foo who does not come to my event !”. The old turkey comes, and Mister T catches it and cooks it for dinner, muahaha.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　山: mountain　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Turkey . . . oven fire.
Mnemonic1: When I put the turkey over the oven fire, it always ends up being charred beyond recognition. I´m not a very good cook.
Mnemonic2: Char could be any meat over oven fire. So why is it a turkey in this kanji? Because charred turkey is what sticks out most in your mind as the thing that ruined Thanksgiving dinner.
Compo: 隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　火: fire (灬)
Kunyomi: こ.げる, こ.がす, こ.がれる, あせ.る
Ex3English: Be impatient, be in a hurry

Origin: Rocks . . . char.
Mnemonic1: Coral reefs are now dying off due to our abuse of the environment and now look like charred stone. For a picture illustrating this, see http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg.
Mnemonic2: Reefs are often formed from volcanic rock, or "rock that has been charred".
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　焦: char

Origin: St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . rice field/brains.
Mnemonic1: The St. Bernard dog pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?
Mnemonic2: Gruesome, but it makes it easy to remember. Here goes: The St. Bernard stirred up a crowd of turkeys and caught one. It bit the head, brains spilling onto the rice field.
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)

Origin: Whereas burglary (Frame 381) implies clandestine appropriation of another's property, robbery refers to taking by force. The primitive elements: St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: Remember the scene in A Christmas Story where the big dogs robbed the family of their Christmas turkey? Well, the following year Ralphie´s mom glued the holiday bird to the kitchen table, just as a precaution.
Mnemonic2: Don´t let the neighbor´s St.Bernard rob tonight´s turkey....glue it to the table if you must.
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

English: One Of A Pair, Counter For Ships
Origin: The key word indicates the Japanese generic term for counting ships. Its elements: turkey . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: On Vessels that travel long distances, sailors often get quite lonely. They keep TURKEYS on the VESSELS, but not for use as food. The lonely sailors take turns enjoying the turkey´s CROTCH.
Mnemonic2: Donald Duck is a big bird that does not wear pants. It´s good to use him as a mnemonic because he is a sailor, and this kanji is used to count vessels.
Compo: 隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: A pack of wild dogs . . . flowers . . . vessels. Do not confuse this with the character for arrest (Frame 706).
Mnemonic1: A pack of genetically-modified wild dogs is seized by a group of Greenpeace activists and taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (the flower vessel, see safeguard (#700)).
Mnemonic2: Customs just seized a crate of poppies (flowers) detected by trained wild dogs who inspected the vessel.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　隻: vessels

Origin: Wheat . . . flowers . . . vessels. Compare frames 756 and 757 for the right side.
Mnemonic1: The harvest of genetically modified crops is taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (see the flower vessel in safeguard (#700)).
Mnemonic2: Wheat is harvested; the grain (flower) is put into vessels for shipping.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　隻: vessels

Origin: Words . . . flowers . . . vessels.
Mnemonic1: Think of the flower-vessels as a the Greenpeace vessel “Arctic Sunrise”, only instead of a rainbow there is a big flower painted on the hull (this will come back in seize (#701) and harvest (#908)). Think of “flower-power” and of the “peace” in “Greenpeace” and it will make some sense hopefully. -- In this kanji, we see an inauguration speech being given before the Greenpeace vessel is set afloat and sent to safeguard our planet.
Mnemonic2: (With sarcasm) A Bush speech telling how all the US vessels are always welcomed, covered with flowers and words of gratitude for safeguarding democracy from the evil doers.
Compo: 言: word; say　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　隻: vessels

Origin: Words . . . grass skirt.
Mnemonic1: Speaking complicated words to set her head spinning, the island girl in the grass skirt says demurely "I defer (yield) to your judgment, wise one".
Mnemonic2: I talked to my Japanese spouse, who confirmed that this kanji does not mean "defer" as in "put off, delay". It means "defer" in the sense of "submit" or "yield".
Compo: 言: word; say　襄: to raise; grass skirt (RTK)

Origin: Woman . . . grass skirt.
Mnemonic1: Conversation at a party: A: "Who is that lass?" B: "Which one?" A: "The woman wearing the grass skirt." B: "Alas, I don´t know".
Mnemonic2: Two Irishmen visit Hawaii and see a woman wearing a grass skirt and nothing else. "That´s some lassie," says one to the other. "But alass Danny Boy, you can´t be bringing her home.".
Compo: 女: woman　襄: to raise; grass skirt (RTK)

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . grass skirt.
Mnemonic1: Grass Skirt primitive: Picture some Hawaiian girls, wearing grass skirts and tropical scarfs (or leis), doing a dance. "3, 4, 5, 6 pick up all the celery sticks!".
Mnemonic2: A classic alcohol commercial: whiskey being brewed while girls dance around, scantily clad in their grass skirts.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　襄: to raise; grass skirt (RTK)

Origin: Ground . . . grass skirt. The lot of this key word refers to a portion of land.
Mnemonic1: My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a grass skirt.
Mnemonic2: On the island of JOU, in order to be considered a lot, a ground must be big enough to grow sufficient grass for a grass skirt.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　襄: to raise; grass skirt (RTK)

Origin: The right half of this character shows a garment woven so fine that it can pass through the eye of a needle, fittingly draped around the slithering, ethereal form of a poltergeist. In this frame, our eerie visitor brushes its robes against a nearby block of apartments and completely demolishes them, razing them to the ground.
Mnemonic1: If you stand too close to a DEMOLITION site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty.
Mnemonic2: Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . needle . . . eyes . . . garment.
Mnemonic1: (re: taijuando) When you are in New York City you have to be alert, i.e. in the "New York State of Mind": you need ten eyes to make sure no one will go through your garments and pick your pockets.
Mnemonic2: Imagine Darth Vader´s state of mind when he discovers his garment has not pockets. " D O NOT WANT!".
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)
Kunyomi: ふところ, なつ.かしい, なつ.かしむ, なつ.く, なつ.ける

Origin: Going . . . needle . . . eye . . . heart. Refer back now to the note in frame 890.
Mnemonic1: Hearkening back to the kanji for LISTEN... Benevolence is a good listener who is willing to go the distance to help.
Mnemonic2: In a rare act of benevolence, the Sparten column removes the needle from the cyclops´s eye, and he repays them by eating their hearts.
Compo: 彳: going, act; line; column (RTK)　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Ear . . . needle . . . eye . . . heart. Compare frame 427 for this and the following kanji, and then once again when you get to frame 950.
Mnemonic1: I promise to use my ear to do nothing but listen ... stick a needle in my eye, cross my heart and hope to die! (Intentionally said backwards to get the order of the primitives correct).
Mnemonic2: Listening to others is different from hearing (1626] with the ear. One must allow the words to pierce through the eyes (the window of the soul) and reach deep into the heart...a symbol of thinking about and contemplating on what was said, not just the sounds of words spoken. A married man while reading his newspaper, his wife going on about something suddenly, says, "You´re not listening to me, are you?" He replies, "I heard every word you said. You said..." “Yes, but you´re not listening.".
Compo: 耳: ear　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Ex4English: Listen to the voice of the people

Origin: Ear . . . heart. It is most rare to have the heart at the right, rather than at the bottom. Take advantage of this fact when you compose your story.
Mnemonic1: Amelia Ear-Heart (sic) brought shame to those who said women couldn´t fly.
Mnemonic2: Vincent Van Gogh´s greatest shame was cutting off his ear to win the heart of a woman.
Compo: 耳: ear　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: は.じる, はじ, は.じらう, は.ずかしい

Origin: Wool . . sign of the cow.
Mnemonic1: The sheep had his coat shaven in the winter and a sign of th cow branded on him. How humiliating.
Mnemonic2: (+melchan] The sheep was humiliated by being branded with the sign of the cow (which is a major insult to anyone, even sheep) and tries to cover it up with it's wool.
Compo: 羊: sheep　丿: katakana no　丑: sign of the cow

Origin: Vulture . . . eye . . . silver . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: The baron is very suspicious, always looking around with vulture eyes and keeping the silver glued to the table so no one can steal it.
Mnemonic2: Here we see an evil baron - a vulture perched on his shoulder, and a siver eye-patch glued to his eye.
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . key . . . dart. Hint: the pun suggested by the pronunciation of the key word and the primitive for key may come in helpful.
Mnemonic1: Marquis Keydartee (make-believe french name, Key+dart+T).
Mnemonic2: (Going off various) Mr. T. is made a marquis and given the key to the city. But somebody disagrees with it and assassinates him with a dart.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　ユ: key (RTK)　矢: arrow; dart (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . marquis.
Mnemonic1: I think of "clearing your throat". Some stuffy guy opens his mouth to clear his throat so the marquis can speak.
Mnemonic2: The Marquis de Sade was kinda gay. He used to mouth down a lot of deep-throat action.
Compo: 口: mouth　侯: marquis

Origin: Marquis . . . walking stick. Note where the walking stick is positioned in this kanji.
Mnemonic1: The marquis has absolutely no interest in issuses of climate change. He´s old and near death. (Don´t forget the walking stick to symbolize his old age.].
Mnemonic2: The marquis moves to a warmer climate after he gets old enough to need a walking stick to get around.
Compo: 侯: marquis　丨: line; stick

Origin: Person . . . walking stick . . . taskmaster . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T is a harsh taskmaster who will discipline you (beat you into shape) with his walking stick.
Mnemonic2: You may not have known it, but Mr. T is into discispline. Not just self discipline, in order to get into shape, but what he really likes is when the Task master spanks him with her walking stick. Don´t tell Mr. T I told you. I pity da fool, and da fool would be me!!!
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)丨: line; stick攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Kunyomi: おさ.める, おさ.まる

Origin: Person . . . walking stick . . . taskmaster . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T ventured out into a remote area to visit with his wise, old taskmaster who must use a walking stick to get around and originally gave Mr. T the heart to fight crime for the good of the community.
Mnemonic2: Yoda, the Jedi with the walking stick who was a hard taskmaster for Luke but who had a big heart, was permanently exiled on the remote planet Dagobah.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　丨: line; stick　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Ex1English: Calmly, leisurely; easily, without difficulty; boundlessly

Origin: In this kanji we are shown someone spending an entire day at mending one stocking, because they want the job done "just so." Be sure to make a clear image of a finicky old fusspot to make the abstract idea as concrete as possible.
Mnemonic1: ´Sun´ ´Mend´ - It just so happens that sunshine can mend your gloomy spirits.
Mnemonic2: My image here is of Fabrice (the guy who runs this website) spending all day obsessively mending the code so this page looks just so....
Compo: 日: day; sun　疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)
Ex1English: Right and/or wrong; by all means, at any cost

Origin: Fingers . . . just so.
Mnemonic1: When a man PROPOSES to a lady, he takes her FINGER and places the ring on it JUST SO, and the moment sweeps her away.
Mnemonic2: I tried to propose to my girlfriend, but the ring was too small to fit her finger. Instead of saying yes, she just uttered an annoyed sigh. So I rushed to the jeweler where he made it bigger. But now it was too big, so I rushed back to make it smaller. This spiel kept going on until the ring was finally just so. Her eyes lit up and she said yes.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　是: just so; justice

Origin: A dike is a successful bit of engineering only if the amount of earth piled up is measured just so for the height and pressure of the water it is meant to contain.
Mnemonic1: Making a dike is all about arranging the soil just so....
Mnemonic2: The little Dutch boy has his finger stuck in the dike, and that´s the only thing keeping his town from going under. He really really needs to go to the bathroom though, so he devises a plan to carefully add a bit of dirt - there, place individual bits in just so - there, I think it´s good enough. Pull it out -----yes! Success!
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　是: just so; justice

Origin: In many kinds of research, one can find information on a given topic only if the headings are prepared just so.
Mnemonic1: The "TOPIC" of the day´s newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention.
Mnemonic2: You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The topic---FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!
Compo: 是: just so; justice　頁: page; head (RTK)
是: just so; justice　匕: spoon

Origin: Remember when you were young and your mother told you never to look directly into the sun for fear you might burn out your eyes? Probably you were foolish enough to risk a quick glance once or twice; but just as probably, you passed that bit of folk wisdom on to someone else as you grew older. Here, too, the kanji that has a sun above and an eye right below looking up at it has the meaning of risk (see frame 12).
Mnemonic1: Don´t look at the sun directly with your eyes, it´s risky!
Mnemonic2: You´ll risk your eyesight if you look up at the sun.
Compo: 日: day; sun　目: eye

Origin: What we mentioned in the previous two frames about 3 of something meaning "everywhere" or "heaps of" was not meant to be taken lightly. In this kanji we see two suns, one atop the other, which, if we are not careful, is easily confused in memory with the three suns of sparkle. Focus on the number this way: since we speak of prosperous times as sunny, what could be more prosperous than a sky with two suns in it? Just be sure to actually SEE them there.
Mnemonic1: If you work from Sun UP to Sun DOWN you will be prosperous.
Mnemonic2: I kept getting this mixed up with meanings like ´fortune´, so here is a fool proof story! Remember the Vulcan salute from ´Star Trek´ (a fiction of the sci-fi genre in which heavenly bodies such as SUNS play a huge role) used with the phrase ´live long and PROSPER´? If that´s not enough of a visual reminder, the Vulcan salute shows the fingers parted in to 2 sets of 2, and visually kind of looks like this kanji if you think about it.
Compo: 日: day; sun　日: day; sun

Origin: This one is easy! You have one mouth making no noise (the choirmaster) and two mouths with wagging tongues (the minimum for a chorus). So think of the key word, chant, as monastery singing and the kanji is yours forever (see frame 11).
Mnemonic1: Someone chanting with their mouth open for two consecutive days.
Mnemonic2: Chants from our mouths are meant to reach the sun and the stars. Stars are just suns just further away so they seem smaller.
Compo: 口: mouth　日: day; sun　日: day; sun

Origin: What else can the word sparkle suggest if not a diamond? And if you've ever held a diamond up to the light, you will have noticed how every facet of it becomes like a miniature sun. This kanji is a picture of a tiny sun in three places (that is, "everywhere"), to give the sense of something that sparkles on all sides. Just like a diamond. In writing the primitive elements three times, note again how the rule for writing given in frame 4 holds true not only for the strokes in each individual element but also for the disposition of the elements in the character as a whole.
Mnemonic1: A diamond sparkles as brightly as three suns.
Mnemonic2: Sparkle is a forest (#197) of suns!
Compo: 日: day; sun　日: day; sun　日: day; sun

Origin: Because of the risk involved (of getting the sun in one's eyes),one puts together a makeshift cap out of a dirty old towel.
Mnemonic1: If you wear a towel as a cap, you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports.
Mnemonic2: Originally the first cap was a turban which was a towel wrapped around the head to keep the sun out of the eyes.
Compo: 巾: towel　冒: risk

Origin: If the piece of wood in the roof known as the ridgepole points east, the sunrise will be visible from the front door.
Mnemonic1: Feng Shui states that the ridgepole of a house should be made of wood and face east.
Mnemonic2: Ok just a note to the ´ridgepole facing east story´ im making up a story to JUSTIFY why that is the case. Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a ´sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is´, back in those days when people used ridgepoles they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).
Compo: 木: tree; wood　東: east

Origin: The whole secret to breaking the ice with the East is to peek behind those mysteriously "frozen smiles."
Mnemonic1: Eastern Siberia is often frozen by ice. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself...it made it stick for me!
Mnemonic2: The ice will stay frozen until the sun is visible through the trees.
Compo: 冫: ice　東: east

Origin: The appearance of the primitive for water in its full form tells us that we have something to do with water here. The extra drop to the left, added as a second stroke, changes the picture from a splash caused by a walking stick dropped into water to form an icicle. If it helps, when you hold an icicle up to the light, you can usually see little crystallizations of five-pointed stars inside of it, which is the shape we have in this kanji.
Mnemonic1: Icicles start with 1 frozen drop of water.
Mnemonic2: A drop in temperature turns water into an icicle.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: This kanji also uses the full form of water, though its meaning seems to have nothing at all to do with water. Remember what William Blake said about seeing "infinity in a grain of sand and eternity in an hour"? Well, reading this character from top to bottom, we see "eternity in a drop of water."
Mnemonic1: It would take an eternity to count all the drops of water.
Mnemonic2: It takes but one drop from the most special water: the fountain of youth (and it is written in a special way to with an extra horizontal line on the top) to live for an eternity. (In order to remember that the drop is at the top, think that the drop must come from the topmost water in order for its effects to be true).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: The primitive to the left, you will recall from Frame 137, represents water. To the right, we see the kanji for eternity. Knowing how much children like swimming, what could be a better image of eternal bliss than an endless expanse of water to swim in without a care in the world?
Mnemonic1: With that much WATER (2 actually) you would need to swim for an ETERNITY.
Mnemonic2: If you don´t know how to swim, you´ll be in that water for eternity.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　永: eternity; long; lengthy

Origin: Listening to the words of poets reciting their poetry is like being transported for a moment into eternity where the rules of everyday life have been suspended.
Mnemonic1: Listening to the words in a recitation of Vogon poetry is worse than spending an eternity in hell. (Note: I assume those 2 reports are to warn against possible confusion with poem (#346) but how can you confuse Vogon poetry with an actual poem? Anyway, it´s the next frame, so it should be easy to keep them straight... Or maybe there´s a kanji for Vogon in RTK3?].
Mnemonic2: If you study some words for a recitation, there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all eternity.
Compo: 言: word; say　永: eternity; long; lengthy

Origin: The tags you see hanging on trees in public places in Japan are helpful to identify what sort of trees they are. Next time you see one, imagine the bit of wire that fixes the tag to the branch as a large fishhook. REALLY imagine it, illogical as it is, and you will never have trouble with this kanji again.
Mnemonic1: Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.
Mnemonic2: Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for "Paper Money" w/ the reading さつ (千円札＝1000 Yen paper bill)... It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 ("trump" playing cards). For the tag meaning I like to think of wooden tags hung on hooks from trees... but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to "hook you in" so to speak.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　乚: hidden; hook (RTK)

Origin: English counts thin, flat objects, like bed linen and paper, in sheets. The kanji does this with a taskmaster whipping a tree into producing sheets against its will.
Mnemonic1: The taskmaster is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one sheet of really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the wood fibers.
Mnemonic2: This taskmaster is the bathroom nazi: he counts how many sheets of toilet paper and tissue you use, and then tells you what % of a tree you just killed.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)
Ex2English: Number of sheets/pages/plates/panes of glass, etc.

Origin: Tree . . . negative.
Mnemonic1: The maple tree is very negative about it, but the farmer still collects cupfuls of maple syrup from it.
Mnemonic2: A few cupfuls of sake can create a very negative situation. Like smashing into that tree…
Compo: 木: tree; wood　不: not
Ex1English: A cup (as of tea), a glass (as of beer)

Origin: Tree . . . ax.
Mnemonic1: We chop down trees with axes to analyze their rings.
Mnemonic2: Wood + axe = chop? how much more simple can it get?
Compo: 木: tree; wood　斤: axe

Origin: Fingers . . . ax. Hint: make an image out of the Japanese art of "origami" (paper-folding).
Mnemonic1: It´s the latest Japanese game show: Forudo! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to fold it into a complex origami shape. If they´re not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in folding, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off.
Mnemonic2: Fold some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It´s even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　斤: axe
Kunyomi: お.る, おり, お.り, -お.り, お.れる
Ex2English: Folded paper; the art of paper folding

Origin: Fingers . . . assembly line . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: I sprained my fingers when I sat in meditation (by sitting in a strange position).
Mnemonic2: I sprained in my finger doing a complicated mudra while sitting in meditation.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　坐: sit
Ex3English: Be sprained, be broken, be crushed

Origin: This kanji does not refer to the tool but to the act of twisting. Its elements: fingers . . . wish.
Mnemonic1: Ever try WRENCHING a bolt with just your FINGERS? Trust me, you´ll WISH you had a wrench for WRENCHING to save your FINGERS.
Mnemonic2: I have an unfortunate habit of wrenching off other people’s fingers when I pull a wishbone with them.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　念: wish
Ex2English: (vt] twist, turn; contrive a solution (to); easily defeat

Origin: Fold . . . words.
Mnemonic1: This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then folded it into an origami, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- "the folded words are vows". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive "fold".
Mnemonic2: A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with origami cranes with their vows written on the BOTTOM.
Compo: 折: opportunity; fold　言: word; say

Origin: The connotation is of a "dearly departed" who has passed away. The elements: fold . . . road.
Mnemonic1: One of the dearest of Japan´s dearly departed is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for folding more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still fold origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire road lined with folded cranes.
Mnemonic2: The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently departed victims who died when the roads folded (from the earthquake).
Compo: 折: opportunity; fold　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Fold . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are folding sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the mouth of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.
Mnemonic2: I fold my mouth, therefore I am.
Compo: 折: opportunity; fold　口: mouth

Origin: Car . . . ax.
Mnemonic1: A "chop shop" is a place where stolen cars are taken, and parts chopped off with an axe, to be sold.
Mnemonic2: I wanted a convertible so I chopped off the top of my car with an axe.
Compo: 車: car　斤: axe
Ex1English: Cut (someone) with a sword, cut down, kill

Origin: Water . . . chop off.
Mnemonic1: I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window.
Mnemonic2: Water + Car + Axe: The steadily rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　斬: beheading; chop off (RTK)

Origin: Chop off . . . days.
Mnemonic1: Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car.
Mnemonic2: Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can temporarily (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.
Compo: 斬: beheading; chop off (RTK)　日: day; sun
Ex1English: A while; a good while; for the time being

Origin: Ax . . . a drop of.
Mnemonic1: The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?
Mnemonic2: The quality expectations are very high in our axe manufacturing facility. If there´s one drop of rust on any axe, it gets rejected.
Compo: 斤: axe　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Words . . . reject.
Mnemonic1: I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words.
Mnemonic2: Words that make you feel rejected.
Compo: 言: word; say　斥: reject

Origin: Words . . . public.
Mnemonic1: Take care what words you say in public lest you be sued.
Mnemonic2: (+radical_tyro] Socrates was giving a speech in public. Things were going rather well, until his robe opened a bit and people saw his, well, not-public area. He was promptly sued for public indecency. Certain things shouldn´t be made public in public, you know?
Compo: 言: word; say　公: public; official

Origin: Hole . . . baseball.
Mnemonic1: Most research scientists have 9 holes.....two nostrils, two ears, a mouth, and four eyes...... :-).
Mnemonic2: Scientiest are researching , and have already found nine black holes !
Compo: 穴: hole　九: nine; baseball (RTK)

Origin: Hole . . . somebody . . . bow.
Mnemonic1: Hard up = nothing but your body, living in a hole, with just a bow to hunt for your food.
Mnemonic2: Somebody so hard up for cash, the volunteered to explore a black hole with nothing but a bow.
Compo: 穴: hole　身: body　弓: bow
Kunyomi: きわ.める, きわ.まる, きわ.まり, きわ.み
Ex1English: Carry to extremity, reach an extreme

Origin: The poles this key word refers to are the extremities of the earth or the terminals of an electric field. The elements are: tree . . . snare . . . mouth . . . crotch . . . floor.
Mnemonic1: Can simplify this using decay (#1243). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor.
Mnemonic2: (modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using decay (#1243). You travel to the poles, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is decayed (see story for decay (#1243)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your mouth as your lips turn blue, then your crotch also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the floor.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　亟: fast
Kunyomi: きわ.める, きわ.まる, きわ.まり, きわ.み

Origin: This is the character from which the element for shovel derives. Within it comes the element for snare, with the sparkler surrounding it.
Mnemonic1: Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin.
Mnemonic2: (thegeezer3) Damn racoons... I´ll show them. I´ll put a SNARE in the BIN as well as a few SPARKLERS so as to scare the shit out of the buggers, then hit them with a SHOVEL.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)　凵: open box; shovel (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . paper punch . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: A pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting groped by perverts on the train. The fingers of course, a crown (her too short skirt) and her legs below (which to be honest are pretty thick like tree trunks).
Mnemonic2: Note: The combination "crown +human legs" appears seven times in Heisig. In four cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) the crown is above the human legs, and in the other three cases (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. The naming is inconsistent, so I call the first pattern "Miss World" (who is wearing a crown she won due to her attractive human legs) and the second "garter" (one human leg passes through the crown and wears it as a garter).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　㓁: a net; paper punch (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Water . . . paper punch . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: If the groper´s "tree" goes up the girl´s miniskirt too deep, he´ll ejaculate fluid. (Sorry it´s kinda coarse but it works.).
Mnemonic2: Thrown in deep water, the Japanese School girl tries to reach a floating tree to save herself.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　㓁: a net; paper punch (RTK)　木: tree; wood
Kunyomi: ふか.い, -ぶか.い, ふか.まる, ふか.める

Origin: State of mind . . . chestnut.
Mnemonic1: Shudder. If chestnut trees were sentient, shudder would be their state of mind as the tree shaker approaches. Note: Tree shakers are used commercially to harvest nuts and cider apples. A tree shaker makes a tree shudder causing all the ripe chestnuts to fall.
Mnemonic2: shudder: You’re in the state of mind of shuddering with fear when the chestnut tree is falling over towards you.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　栗: chestnut

Origin: State of mind . . . tool.
Mnemonic1: My mind found the tool disquieting.
Mnemonic2: Its disquieting to my state of mind when tools are arranged messily.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　具: tool

Origin: State of mind . . . truth.
Mnemonic1: Humility is the state of mind of accepting the truth about yourself - both favorable and unfavorable. (tweaked version of Raichu´s).
Mnemonic2: Humility is a state of mind when you consider yourself in accordance with the truth (you neither boast nor demean yourself).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　真: true

Origin: The first lie-detector machines of the twentieth century worked by wiring pieces of metal to the body to measure the amount of sweat produced when questions were asked. It was discovered that nervousness produced more sweat, indicating subconscious reactions when the truth was getting too close for comfort. Nowadays, people can take drugs that tranquillize them in such a way as to neutralize the effect of the device, which is why other means have had to be developed.
Mnemonic1: Tranquilize - using a metal syringe to get the truth.
Mnemonic2: Enough gold can tranquilize the truth in anyone.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　真: true

Origin: Woman . . . family name . . . day.
Mnemonic1: Marriage is the day in this woman´s life where she gets a new family name.
Mnemonic2: Tip: Heisig later introduces the kanji 昏 dusk (#2451). Story: Never enter into marriage with a woman at dusk (wait until you see them in daylight). Note: This is an ancient proverb . . . (probably).
Compo: 女: woman　氏: family　日: day; sun

Origin: Person . . . pent in.
Mnemonic1: A person pent in is obviously captured. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money.
Mnemonic2: Mr. T can´t be captured. This kanji is lying.
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)

Origin: Pent in . . . trees.
Mnemonic1: I´m supposed to make an enclosure for my tree, but if I use its wood for the enclosure, there won´t be anything left to be pent-in. What a quandary!
Mnemonic2: You are pent in the garden of eden with one tree, but outside is the whole world to explore! What a quandary -- should you stay in paradise with the tree of knowledge or should you go out into the world?
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　木: tree; wood
木: tree; wood　困: quandary; become distressed; annoyed

Origin: St. Bernard dog . . . pent in.
Mnemonic1: We once had a dog with big paws // and oh what great trouble he´d cause // we built a huge pen // to keep him pent in // and stop him from breaking more laws //.
Mnemonic2: Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the cause is that you kept the dog pent in the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　大: large; St Bernard (RTK)

Origin: Woman . . . cause. Think here of the "state of matrimony" and you will not confuse it with other characters involving marriage, one of which we have already met (Frame 581).
Mnemonic1: Matrimony is the state in which the woman has got you pent in like a dog so that you cannot go after other bitches.
Mnemonic2: When the woman gets angry, she treats her man like a pent in dog (i.e., puts him in the doghouse). It´s a perfect metaphor for the state of matrimony.
Compo: 女: woman　因: cause

Origin: Mouth . . . cause.
Mnemonic1: You can´t breathe very well, so the doc looks inside your mouth to find the cause. "Oh, I see the cause of your windpipe blockage. There´s a St Bernard penned up in there!".
Mnemonic2: Imagine a group of windpipes chatting: “That mouth is the cause of all my problems, you know, always breathing in germs, etc.”.
Compo: 口: mouth　因: cause

Origin: Take grace in its sense of a favor freely bestowed, not in its meaning of charming manners or fluid movement. The primitives: cause . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Grace here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a big dog pent up in a small cage and adopt him. That will cause a warm feeling in your heart!
Mnemonic2: This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause, grace is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a graceful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart.
Compo: 因: cause　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Flowers . . . pent in . . . wheat.
Mnemonic1: Can also mean bacteria.....imagine the wheat pent in your fridge growing to the point where they resemble flowers.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-).
Mnemonic2: Actually it means germs as in microorganisms. So for example, you have to keep wheat enclosed so it isn´t exposed to other plants. That way it can´t catch any germs (like fungi) from them.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　囗: box; pent in (RTK)　禾: grain; wheat (RTK)

Origin: Water . . . scarecrow. The key word has come to refer to things Chinese in general, including the kanji themselves (for which this character is used).
Mnemonic1: Sino- (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat/water into learning the kanji. For right-hand kanji primitive - The dumb Western husband of a Japanese woman buys her flowers to apologise, after he opened his big mouth and said "kanji are a stupid writing system"..
Mnemonic2: In the water between Japan and China, the Sino- side has put scarecrows in the water to try and keep the Japanese away.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　堇: cabbage, scarecrow (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . scarecrow.
Mnemonic1: A sigh escapes the mouth of the scarecrow, who laments: "...if I only had a brain, I could learn kanji".
Mnemonic2: I will let out a huge sigh of relief from my mouth when I learn the last kanji.
Compo: 口: mouth　堇: cabbage, scarecrow (RTK)
Kunyomi: なげ.く, なげ.かわしい

Origin: Cabbage . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: With enough diligence, Koreans can turn ordinary cabbage into powerful kimchi.
Mnemonic2: Growing cabbages takes muscle and diligence.
Compo: 堇: cabbage, scarecrow (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)
Kunyomi: つと.める, -ずと.め, つと.まる

Origin: Words . . . cabbage.
Mnemonic1: Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I discreetly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog.
Mnemonic2: Cabbage primitive: When a cabbage is growing up, you must put it in your mouth before it flowers, because that´s when it becomes bitter. Seriously, it´s called ´bolting´ or something. When you´re discreet, you try to make your words like a cabbage: well-layered, but in an unassuming way.
Compo: 言: word; say　堇: cabbage, scarecrow (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . cabbage.
Mnemonic1: To a big guy like Mr. T, eating a whole cabbage at once is nothing. "What? a cabbage? That's just a trifle, foo, where's the meat?".
Mnemonic2: To MR.T swallowing a whole CABBAGE is no more than a TRIFLE.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　堇: cabbage, scarecrow (RTK)

Origin: Chapel (see frame 930) . . . thread.
Mnemonic1: A coaxial cord has a needle-like pin, a crown cap for screwing it in, and insulation made of thread.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman has been captured and given the ultimate torture: they forced a crown of needles on his head and attached it to an electrical cord, which they are about to plug into an outlet...
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　冖: crown 　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)
Ex1English: Look up (a word in a dictionary), search for, refer to

Compo: 玄: mysterious　牛: cow (⺧)
宀: house (RTK)　牛: cow (⺧)

Origin: Door . . . taskmaster . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and DISCLOSE information.
Mnemonic2: You signed a non-disclosure agreement with the taskmaster but you opened your mouth as soon as you got out the door!
Compo: 戸: door　攵: strike; taskmaster (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: Caverns . . . oven fire.
Mnemonic1: Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel.
Mnemonic2: If you are so poor that you are a commoner, you will have to live twenty commoners to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share.
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　廿: twenty; 20　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Commoner . . . road.
Mnemonic1: The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle!
Mnemonic2: If don´t want your secret message to be intercepted, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a commoner while traveling on the road.
Compo: 庶: commoner　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
廿: twenty; 20　口: mouth　北: north　火: fire (灬)
少: few　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Few . . . muscles.
Mnemonic1: I have an inferiority complex because I have fewer muscles than everyone else at the gym. They all look like Macho Man Randy Savage (power) to me.
Mnemonic2: I had trouble remembering the relative position of the components, so now I use this story: Even muscular men have inferiority if they have few things above their muscles (i.e., brain cells).
Compo: 少: few　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . a few.
Mnemonic1: You can extract her juices by inserting a few fingers.
Mnemonic2: The mafia want to extract information from you. You don´t say a word, so out comes the knife. They cut of your fingers until you only have a few left and then you speak.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　少: few

Origin: The reference here is to a second of time. The elements: wheat . . . few.
Mnemonic1: An hourglass filled with wheat counts time. A few wheat seeds drop every second.
Mnemonic2: I´ll be with you soon... please wheat a few seconds.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　少: few

Origin: The primitive for woman is on the left (there and at the bottom of another primitive is where you will always find her), and to the right the element for few. When we refer to a woman as exquisite, we mean to praise her as the sort of person we meet but few and far between. If you are interested in etymologies, it might help to recall that the Latin phrase lying at the root of the English word exquisite carries this same sense of "seeking out" the rare from the ordinary.
Mnemonic1: Exquisite women are few and far between.
Mnemonic2: A geisha is an exquisite and delicate (another meaning of this kanji) women, however, even in the past there was only few of them.
Compo: 女: woman　少: few

Origin: We have already learned the kanji for sand (Frame 122), so let's use it to remember the character for grains of sand. Instead of the "few stones" that make for nice sand, here we have a few drops of water, one for each grand of sand - a beach in perfect ecological balance.
Mnemonic1: Wet sand is simply sand but to see beautiful grains of sand, the water must be few.
Mnemonic2: Near the water is one of the few places you will find grains of sand.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　少: few

Origin: This character can mean both to cleanse and to make dirty. We will choose the latter and imagine someone who is displeasingly plump going to a skinny spa whose medicinal waters promise to cleanse him of his unwanted corpulence. Picture him sitting in the spa as the pounds melt away, leaving a greasy scum on top of the water.
Mnemonic1: I couldn´t find any reference to this kanji as meaning cleanse. It seems to be most often used in the following compound 沙汰（さた）to mean affair. The other meanings seem to be closer to ´select´ so maybe Heisig meant cleanse in the ethnic sense here.. I´m going to use the keyword "selection", as in natural selection. Story: natural selection first began in the water, and those that were too plump were selected out.
Mnemonic2: Water is used to cleanse a plump man´s colon.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　太: plump; thick
Ex1Kanji: ご無沙汰しております
Ex1Kana: ごぶさたしております
Ex1English: (polite] i haven't seen you (been in contact with you] for a long time

Origin: Think of roasting the guest of honor at a party - literally, in front of an oven-fire.
Mnemonic1: In many asian restaurants, meat is roasted right in front of you over flames.
Mnemonic2: At the roast, they make the roastee sit in front of everyone else, over the flames to speak, as the comedians roast him a new one!
Compo: 前: in front; before　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Better to picture what happens when you do not pay attention to your work in the kitchen. Here we see a blazing fire and an inattentive, yawning cook who let things get out of control.
Mnemonic1: Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi.
Mnemonic2: This character shows the difference between a cook and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love; a cook only stands there with a pan over a fire, with no passion and just yawning.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)
林: grove; forest　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Flowers . . . new.
Mnemonic1: New flowers grow in areas of forests which have been chopped down for firewood.
Mnemonic2: If your firewood is too new and still has flowers on it, it´s unsuitable for burning. You need drier wood.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　新: new

Origin: This pictograph of a clenched fist is another of the "hand primitives." Take note of its rather peculiar drawing. Try to think of drawing a fist (the primitive meaning) "from" this character to give yourself a connotation for the otherwise abstract key word.
SubOrigin: The primitive meaning is taken from the pictograph: a fist.
Mnemonic1: FROM a pictograph of a thumbs up. That´s how it also gets the primitive meaning of fist.
Mnemonic2: Think Charlton Heston: "From my cold, dead fists". Speech given to the National Boxing Association, in response to stricter control on boxing gloves.
Compo: 乃: from; fist (RTK)

Origin: This character is now used chiefly in proper names, and is best learned as the character closest to the hiragana え, though in fact it has no relation to it.
SubOrigin: In order to give this kanji a more concrete meaning when it is used as a primitive element, think of it as referring to building blocks with the hiragana written on them, much the same as the A-B-C blocks you played with as a child.
Mnemonic1: Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write.
Mnemonic2: The Z of Zorro (and yes he has a hat).
Compo: 之: this; building blocks (RTK)
止: stop; footprint (RTK)　匕: spoon
甘: sweet; wicker basket (RTK)　八: eight; go in (RTK)

Origin: Drop of . . . building blocks.
Mnemonic1: Children in complete destitution have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny drop of a building block they are overjoyed.
Mnemonic2: Just one drop (of alcohol) and he starts walking in zig-zags – no wonder Zorro´s living in destitution. (Note: As a primitive let 之 be Zorro or Zig-Zag: it´s pictographic).
Compo: 丿: katakana no　之: this; building blocks (RTK)

Origin: Flowers . . . building blocks.
Mnemonic1: Artificial turf made easy: flowers stuck on top of building blocks that you can place anywhere.
Mnemonic2: Zorro, with a flower between his teeth for the ladies, defends his turf against evildoers. "This is my turf! And this...is for the lady.".
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　之: this; building blocks (RTK)

English: Reach To, Extend To; Be Equal To; As Well As, And
Origin: The addition of a final stroke transforms this character from the primitive for a clenched fist into the kanji for reaching out, much as a stroke of kindness can often turn anger into acceptance.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this shall stand for outstretched hands. Only take care not to confuse it with that for beg (Frame 501)
Mnemonic1: I like to think of this as a fist with with brass knuckles because of the extra line. An old school thug reaches out to help you up but then with his other hand ( with the brass knuckles) punches you.
Mnemonic2: Reach out and fist someone (Do you see the person primitive?).
Compo: 乃: from; fist (RTK)　乀: stretch
Kunyomi: およ.ぶ, およ.び, および, およ.ぼす

Origin: Finger . . . outstretched hands.
Mnemonic1: See suck (#689): if it´s too big to handle, just use your fingers instead...
Mnemonic2: One of the first thing a baby can do with his hand is to reach out and grab your finger as if it was a little handle.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　及: reach out; outstretched hands (RTK)
Kunyomi: あつか.う, あつか.い
Ex2English: Handling, dealing, treatment; trading, selling; handling, manipulation, operation; service

Origin: Threads . . . outstretched hands.
Mnemonic1: This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a "class of students" or "classroom," but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend´s answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge.
Mnemonic2: We can almost see the outstreched hands of the lower classes wearing just a few threads in this kanji.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　及: reach out; outstretched hands (RTK)
Ex3English: Higher grade, advanced class, high class

Origin: Mouth . . . outstretched hands. Hint: use the image of a nursing baby.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a baby reaching out and holding mom´s breast as if it were bottle, and sucking on it to get some milk.
Mnemonic2: An open mouth and reaching hands : a baby wants to suck at his mother´s breast.
Compo: 口: mouth　及: reach out; outstretched hands (RTK)

Origin: To blow is really no more than a deliberate effort to make one's mouth lack all the air that is in it.
Mnemonic1: This is clearly a BLOWJOB, we can see the MOUTH and the LACK OF condom. (I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind).
Mnemonic2: I keep confusing this with suck (#689). Consider someone blowing bubbles using their chewing gum because they´re lacking attention in class.
Compo: 口: mouth　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . water lily. Note: this is the one time that the "stem" has a barb at the end. Work this fact into your story.
Mnemonic1: Budd' - 'weis' - 'er' call the frogs mouths from the liliy pads, working to get you hooked on beer.
Mnemonic2: I´m a lazy fisher, so I genetically engineered a lily pad with a fishing hook at the stem and a mouth to call me whenever it catches something.
Compo: 口: mouth　乎: question mark; water lily (RTK)

Origin: We have here a rather small mouth (it is always compressed when set on the left) next to a much larger piece of dirt. It is not hard to imagine what you might do if you got a mouth full of dirt. As least I know what I would do: spit it out as fast and far as I could!
Mnemonic1: The only things that come out of my MOUTH and onto the GROUND are spit and vomit. Everything else (words, song) floats on the air.
Mnemonic2: SPIT goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.
Compo: 口: mouth　土: ground; land; soil
Ex2English: Spew, vomit; exhale; emit, send forth

Compo: 口: mouth　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)
Ex2English: Grant (a request), fulfill (expectations), answer (a person's prayer)
Ex3English: Be fulfilled, be realized, be granted

Origin: Recall some particularly harsh scolding you got as a child in school. This character has you sitting on the ground in the corner as your teacher stands over you, her mouth wide open as she reprimands you in front of the entire class.
Mnemonic1: A kid gets scolded if they don´t put the spoon properly into their mouth when eating.
Mnemonic2: If I got scolded, I could expect a spoon of castor oil in my mouth.
Compo: 口: mouth　七: seven

Origin: Mouth . . . cornucopia.
Mnemonic1: There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.
Mnemonic2: You can hold a CORNUCOPIA up to your MOUTH (like a megaphone) to SHOUT lounder. Also notice that the shape of CORNUCOPIA implies the shouts are 4 letter words.
Compo: 口: mouth　丩: to join; cornucopia (RTK)

Origin: As we have already learned characters for poem (Frame 370), chant (Frame 21), and song (Frame 508), it is important to protect this key word with an image all its own. Its elements are the same as those above; only the position has changed: mouth . . . clock.
Mnemonic1: Versify this kanji as follows: Hickery dickery dock, the mouth ran by the clock.
Mnemonic2: To versify, words of rhythm needs to shoot out of your MOUTH with a CLOCK-like regularity.
Compo: 口: mouth　今: now; clock (RTK)

Origin: Clock . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: This clock includes a mouth that will tell you what the time is now. Hearing impaired people have this kind of watches... now imagine them as a big mouth under the clock.
Mnemonic2: Batteries included with this clock. Open the mouth at the back and insert them after purchase.
Compo: 今: now; clock (RTK)　口: mouth

Origin: A pair of jewels . . . clock.
Mnemonic1: Two kings were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). So they had a clock built into it that would measure how long each one played it. That way they could be sure none played it more than othe other.
Mnemonic2: Jesus is coming soon. Prepare to meet the king of kings now. Practice your harp playing skills all future angels!...
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　王: king; ball (RTK)　今: now; clock (RTK)

Origin: Road . . . United States.
Mnemonic1: The road that the USA is heading down is, well... let´s just say that they´re astray...
Mnemonic2: If you go astray, just follow the rice you dropped along the road to find your way back.
Compo: 米: rice　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . astray.
Mnemonic1: Words meant to lead you astray are those of a riddle.
Mnemonic2: I led Socrates astray with my riddle. He quit philosophizing and thought only about the riddle.
Compo: 言: word; say　迷: astray

Origin: Mountain goat . . . road.
Mnemonic1: There´s a road that´s been inverted- it´s gone from horizontal to directly vertical! The only beast that could possibly climb it is a mountain goat of course.
Mnemonic2: This reminds me of a cartoon I saw once, perhaps it was with Donald Duck. he is startled and furious when he chases this mountain billygoat further and further up the mountain road, untill the angle is so steep that he finds himself inverted. And falls down, while the goat stands solidly placed inverted and laughs a goaty laughter as Donald plumments and makes that typical Donald shaped cartoon crater at the bottom.
Compo: 屰: disobey; mountain goat (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: さか, さか.さ, さか.らう

English: Go Back In Time, Go Upstream
Origin: Mountain goat . . . moon . . . road.
Mnemonic1: You decide to go salmon fishing, so you ride a mountain goat to the top of the road. Under the light of the moon, as it's illegal, you catch the salmon going upstream.
Mnemonic2: In this kanji we see a mountain goat that decided to go upstream along a road, but for some reason it will only go upstream when the full moon is up. It's actually stubborn like a mountain goat about not going upstream along the road at any other period of time. The road itself is also very confused about this.
Compo: 屰: disobey; mountain goat (RTK)　月: moon; month　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: This kanji depicts the art of modeling clay or wood into a figure of your choice. The elements for composing it are: mountain goat . . . moon . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: This guy is such a gifted sculptor. He can model a MOUNTAIN GOAT and a MOON with just SOIL mold.
Mnemonic2: A legend says that if you model a mountain goat (with tail and everything) from dirt and leave to the light of the moon on the first day of the month (#2846), the dirt will became flesh. (blackstockc).
Compo: 屰: disobey; mountain goat (RTK)　月: moon; month　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Move . . . oven fire. So as not to confuse this kanji with the general character for merit (Frame 1369), you may associate the key word with military decorations and medals of distinction, both of which it is used for.
Mnemonic1: A meritorious deed? Like moving a damsel in distress out of a fire, maybe.
Mnemonic2: Prometheus did a meritous deed for humanity by MOVING FIRE from the gods to us humans.
Compo: 動: move　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Flowers . . . heavy . . . oven fire. Do not confuse with incense (Frame 977) or perfumed (Frame 532).
Mnemonic1: Do you know how they make those FRAGRANT air fresheners? Well you take some FLOWERS, compress them with a HEAVY weight, and put them on an OVEN FIRE for a while... (cmp perfume (#493)).
Mnemonic2: The heavier the flowers the stronger their fragrance when you burn them.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　重: heavy　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Here we see a special compass used to pick out those flowers most suited for making good perfumes.
Mnemonic1: She used a perfume so strong, that you can track her by following the direction of the smell of flowers.
Mnemonic2: People always seem to overdo it with their perfume. It seems that whenever I am at school, somebody walks by with their cheap flowery perfume. If I close my eyes, I can actually use that floweriness as a compass - it tells me which direction they´re in.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　方: direction; compass (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . sun.
Mnemonic1: If you focus the suns though a magnifying glass on to the bottom of a stalk of wheat it will start to smoulder and burn like a stick of incense. The weird thing is that it burns from the bottom upwards, hanging in the air as if my magic. Try it and see!
Mnemonic2: When the sun burns the wheat a smell of incense remains in the air.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　日: day; sun
Kunyomi: か, かお.り, かお.る

Origin: Wheat . . . fist.
Mnemonic1: You spend three hours putting all of your wheat sale transaction records into Microsoft Excel, when suddenly it crashes, so you put your fist through the monitor.
Mnemonic2: A soviet-era poster for the 5-year plan shouts "Excel" and shows a fist clenching a sheaf of wheat. Wheat/Fist.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　乃: from; fist (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . excel. Compare beckon (Frame 702), to urge (Frame 300), seduce (Frame 90), and encourage (Frame 931) when choosing your connotation.
Mnemonic1: Think of the smooth talker who EXCELS at using WORDS to entice women (including married women if it makes it easier to remember).
Mnemonic2: Word and Excel somehow manage to entice people to use them, despite their plethora of bugs.
Compo: 言: word; say　秀: excel

Origin: Finger . . . mouth . . . dagger.
Mnemonic1: Wrap your FINGERS around someone´s MOUTH to keep them quiet, then put the KNIFE to their throat to ensure their cooperation. This is the best way to KIDNAP someone.
Mnemonic2: After you beckon (#650) someone by seducing them, you kidnap them and hang them upside down (the reversed positions of seduce).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　啇: the base; antique (RTK)

Origin: Excel . . . road-way.
Mnemonic1: If you excel in the Mario Kart road, your movements are saved and you can race against yourself as a transparent racer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xe8CkcrL-k4.
Mnemonic2: If you want to excel at driving in the roadway, it´s better if your windows and windshield are transparent. Picture the drivers with opaque windshields all wrecked on the side of the road.
Compo: 秀: excel　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: す.く, す.かす, す.ける

Origin: Fingers . . . turkey . . . fist.
Mnemonic1: This character is the "kei" in "keitai" (cell phone), a word you will no doubt hear often in Japan, since everyone has one. Imagine you´ve just arrived in Japan, but don´t have a cell phone yet, so instead you´re carrying around a portable turkey you can hold in your fist. To dial a number, just poke it with your fingers.
Mnemonic2: Because they have no fingers, turkeys must use their fists when dialing on a portable phone.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)　乃: from; fist (RTK)
Kunyomi: たずさ.える, たずさ.わる
Ex1English: Act in concert with, tie up with

Origin: By one's side . . . elbow . . . turkey. Its match is in frame 605.
Mnemonic1: Men walk with their elbows out from their sides in a weird turkey trot when they try to appear very MASCULINE. Think of a 70´s pimp walk.
Mnemonic2: Masculine duties are to offer your elbow to the lady by your left side and to cut the turkey on special meals.
Compo: 𠂇: side　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: This character for female forms a pair with that for male, which we will learn later (Frame 804). The elements: footprint . . . spoon . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Stop | spooning | turkeys. Spoon females.
Mnemonic2: To become feminine you must stop using a spoon to eat turkey and use a knife and fork like a proper lady.
Compo: 止: stop; footprint (RTK)　匕: spoon　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)
此: this; current; next; coming; last; past　二: two
Kunyomi: いささか, ち.と, ちっ.と
Ex2Kana: ちっともおもしろくない

Compo: 此: this; current; next; coming; last; past　木: tree; wood

Origin: Footprint . . . spoon . . . thread.
Mnemonic1: Stop sitting for so long - or else you'll get those purple threads (veins) on your legs from bad circulation. (link purple with those huge purple, bulging, crawling, worm-like varicose veins .....].
Mnemonic2: Why is your ass purple? Well, I stopped and sat for a bit on a pile of thread... (I guess it was freshly dyed).
Compo: 止: stop; footprint (RTK)　匕: spoon　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)

Origin: Hair . . . shape . . . friend.
Mnemonic1: Japanese teenage girls consider the style of the hair of the head very important. If a particular style is trendy, soon they all want their own hair in the same shape as that of their friends.
Mnemonic2: Friends influence the length and shape of each other´s hair.
Compo: 髟: long hair　友: friend
髟: long hair　此: this; current; next; coming; last; past

Origin: The lie in this character refers to falsehoods and fibs. Its elements: words . . . saw.
Mnemonic1: Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again.
Mnemonic2: Her lies are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.
Compo: 言: word; say　乍: peg holes, staple gun (RTK); saw (RTK)

Origin: Bushel basket . . . yawn.
Mnemonic1: He escaped using deceit. That is, he ran past while the guard was yawning and hid in the bushel basket.
Mnemonic2: Every day, a smuggler takes bushel baskets on donkeys across the border. But the border patrols can never arrest him for lack of evidence no matter how much they search the bushel baskets: they can´t find whatever he is smuggling. What was his deceit? He was smuggling donkeys!
Compo: 其: that, Bushel-basket (RTK)　欠: lack; yawn (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . bushel basket.
Mnemonic1: Tree + Bushel Bucket: Chess pieces carved from trees were tossed into a bushel bucket for sorting into sets.
Mnemonic2: Ever seen those huge chess games in parks? The large wooden chess pieces need to be carted in a shopping trolley.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　其: that, Bushel-basket (RTK)

Origin: Bushel basket . . . stones. The key word refers to the Japanese game played with black and white colored stones on a lined board.
Mnemonic1: Go is chess played with stones.
Mnemonic2: The ignorant gaijin put a rook on top of his opponent´s stone when playing Go, much to the consternation of the Japanese players.
Compo: 其: that, Bushel-basket (RTK)　石: stone; rock (RTK)

Origin: Bushel basket . . . equal. Note how the first stroke of equal doubles up with the sixth stroke of the bushel basket, and how the animal legs of the bushel basket are dropped to make room for the human legs of equal.
Mnemonic1: It´s a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother´s equal.
Mnemonic2: These two bushel baskets are tremendously huge. But not only they are huge, they are also perfectly equal in size.
Compo: 甘: sweet; wicker basket (RTK)　匹: small animals; equal
Kunyomi: はなは.だ, はなは.だしい

Origin: Tremendously . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: Intuition is a tremendously powerful resource of the mind.
Mnemonic2: Using Zareon´s story for the previous frame "tremendously"... The two chessplayers who are eachother´s equals are so good at chess that they don´t have to even move a muscle. Their brain power does it for them. Furthermore, they don´t even have to think, really. Their intuition takes control. This is: extreme chess.
Compo: 甚: tremendously　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Soil . . . tremendously.
Mnemonic1: Because I hid myself behind a huge dirt barrier I dug, I was able to withstand the tremendous nuclear blast.
Mnemonic2: Plain old soil can withstand tremendous amounts of pressure.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　甚: tremendously
Ex3English: Have patience, bear with; forgive, pardon

Origin: Box . . . human legs.
Mnemonic1: This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL´S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He´s probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table).
Mnemonic2: Imagine a magician doing that trick where he puts his assistant in a box and proceeds to saw her in half. Don’t the human legs sticking horizontally out of the box remind you of an equal sign?
Compo: 匚: box; hook (RTK)　儿: human legs

Origin: Box . . . ax.
Mnemonic1: Hint: Artisan/Ax Def: An artisan is a skilled manual worker; a craftsperson. Here we see his tools represented by the artisan's ax stored in his toolbox.
Mnemonic2: We here have the axe-man who´s an artisan at making sculptures with his axe... The only thing is, he never shows anyone, keeping all his sculptures inside a box down in the basement. He doesn´t want any attention.
Compo: 匚: box; hook (RTK)　斤: axe

Origin: Box . . . young.
Mnemonic1: Young kids likes to hide in cardboard boxes. (Primitive: CARDBOARD BOX, especially kids playing with them.).
Mnemonic2: Note that stroke order with box primitive is as follows: first horizontal line, then enclosed element, and then a hook (it´s incorrect in 4th edition).
Compo: 匚: box; hook (RTK)　若: young

Origin: The words of the young do not have legal validity unless backed up by "parental consent."
Mnemonic1: The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders.
Mnemonic2: Delores might say, "Yes!", but she´s way too young give any legal consent.
Compo: 言: word; say　若: young

Origin: See someone lying down in a public place with a hook in place of a hand, begging a morsel of rice or a few pence.
Mnemonic1: Lying down, Captain Hook is begging to be spared from the ticking crocodile.
Mnemonic2: Men beg lying down. Women beg as hookers.
Compo: 𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　乙: fishhook; hook
乞: beg　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: In times of drought anything at all will do. Here we see the victims begging for just a little mist for relief.
Mnemonic1: During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief.
Mnemonic2: Beggar has to drink mist because there is no water in the drought. I get this one confused with thirst 451 but try to remember that there is no water element beacuse it is a drought.
Compo: 𠦝: mist (RTK) 　乞: beg

Origin: Mist . . . umbrella . . . dry. The meaning of this key word extends beyond tree trunks to represent the main stem or line of anything from railway lines to managerial staffs. This should help distinguish it from the stories used earlier for book (Frame 224) and body (Frame 1030), both of which made use of the image of a tree trunk, as well as the kanji for trunk (Frame 194).
Mnemonic1: A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.
Mnemonic2: By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.
Compo: 𠦝: mist (RTK)　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　干: dry

Origin: Fingers . . . goods . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (#215) , maneuver (FRAME 671), winding (#1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: Using just a finger you are trying to maneuver your furniture round your room.
Mnemonic2: Luke skywalker points his fingers and uses the force to maneuver the goods through the tree branches and up over the tree.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　品: goods　木: tree; wood
Ex3English: Preserve one's chastity; adhere to one's principles

Origin: Parchment, made from animal skins, was the most common form of writing material used until the beginning of the nineteenth century. When paper took over, a method was devised to make artificial parchment from wood pulp. The fire at the left and in the "strong" position serves to remind us of the root word, "parch," since nothing dries, puckers, wrinkles, and scorches quite like fire. And here is how we put it all together. Take a sheet of paper (a "wood-good,"), wet it, and hold it over a hearth in your mind's eye. Now watch as it parches the paper, leaving it with a strange and bumpy surface resembling parchment.
Mnemonic1: Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (FRAME 215) , maneuver (#671), winding (#1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: It´s been so parched recently that your furniture suddenly catches fire.
Mnemonic2: The parchment says you need fire to make goods from trees.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　品: goods　木: tree; wood

Origin: Thread . . . goods . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: Winding thread around wooden goods (paper) to ready them for safe transport.
Mnemonic2: After stopping a bank heist, Spiderman is seen winding his webbing around the stolen goods to trap them in a tree until the police arrive to take them back.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　品: goods　木: tree; wood

Mnemonic1: Goods + wood = paper. You know how nori, ie: seaweed, comes in sheets for putting in your ramen or for your sushi? Well that's because it's water paper! Seaweed is also a sea flower of sorts, so it all just works out.
Mnemonic2: Let wooden goods = furniture. Then: Walking along the sea shore you see some washed-up furniture with water (waves) splashing against it. From a distance it looks like flowers are growing out the top, but as you get closer you see it is in fact seaweed.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　澡: wash

Origin: Mouth . . . haystack . . . clams.
Mnemonic1: History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the mouths of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting haystacks in the fields and the fisherman catching shells on the coast.
Mnemonic2: A bit nasty (but makes the whole thing much easier to remember) is to take the right side and call it a bearded clam. For erupt, you can make your own story about the mouth/opening on the left.
Compo: 口: mouth　卉: grass; haystack (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Soil . . . haystack . . . clams. In order not to confuse this kanji with that for a grave (Frame 246), something like the image of an Egyptian tomb should be adopted, with all its special connotations.
Mnemonic1: After the eruption all is a tomb. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells.
Mnemonic2: Using soil and hay to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to entomb the Pharaohs along with all of their money.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　卉: grass; haystack (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . haystack . . . clams.
Mnemonic1: Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of "indignant". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn´t seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone!
Mnemonic2: Data was aroused/indignant when he saw what the volcano had done to the farmers building their haystacks and the fishermen collecting their shells . The tragedy of it all aroused him so much he didn´t even notice he was feeling emotion.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　卉: grass; haystack (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: If you play with this primitive's form with pencil and paper, you will see that it begins with a box-like shape, and ends with the final two strokes of the halberd, a convenient combination for the tusk protruding from the mouth of an animal.
SubOrigin: Since this kanji has 4 strokes, you would expect that as a primitive it would also have 4 - but in fact it has 5 in the following two frames (the second stroke between divided into 2 strokes) and reverts to 4 again in frame 2056.
Mnemonic1: The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant´s eye. The final stroke is the tusk.
Mnemonic2: He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds.
Compo: 牙: tusk

Origin: Flowers . . . tusk.
Mnemonic1: Buds while they´re still small tend to be tusk-shaped.
Mnemonic2: Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant´s tusks keep budding into flowers.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　牙: tusk

Origin: Tusk . . . an old turkey.
Mnemonic1: Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk. This mnemonic is meant to join RtK´s keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used "elegant" here, which is not confounded so easily with graceful (#721), and accurately represents the character´s meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha´s Kanji Learner´s Dictionary).
Mnemonic2: To not confuse it with grace (#606) or graceful (#721), think of the phrase "Goodness gracious." Like: "Goodness gracious! A turkey with tusks!".
Compo: 牙: tusk　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Tusk . . . city walls.
Mnemonic1: The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks.
Mnemonic2: As everyone knows, rhinoceroses and elephants are often killed for the value of their TUSKS. Here we see a WICKED city mayor who has had countless elephants killed just to make his CITY WALLS out of TUSKS.
Compo: 牙: tusk　邑: village; city walls (阝)

Origin: Silver . . . waitress. Do not confuse this kanji's key word with before (Frame 263).
Mnemonic1: Distinguish from formerly (#501). Think of previously as "the previous customer" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the waitress gives you unwashed silverware that was previously used by the previous customer. Yuck.
Mnemonic2: For the waitress primitive, I don´t really see the receipt. So instead, I imagine a waitress holding a plate above her head, using those legs to weave through the tables.
Compo: 艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　无: choke; waitress (RTK)

Origin: Roots . . . waitress. Note that the kanji meaning of the two primitives to the right is not used here because we shall later meet a primitive meaning beforehand and want to preempt any confusion. The same holds true in the following frame.
Mnemonic1: The police tried to draw a chalk outline around the dead waitress, but it was kinda tough with all the tree roots underneath her.
Mnemonic2: If you attempted to outline the biography of most famous actresses, you´d find that they have roots working as waitresses before getting their big break.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　无: choke; waitress (RTK)

Origin: Resentment . . . waitress.
Mnemonic1: If you don´t leave some silver as a tip, you will rue the day you earned the resentment of your waitress.
Mnemonic2: The resentment of a waitress who gave up going to college to help her boyfriend (with his tuition). She rues that decision ever since she got dumped by him (just after he graduated).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　无: choke; waitress (RTK)

Origin: To avoid confusion with the image of rice seedlings to appear later, we shall take these seedlings out of their agricultural setting in the rice fields and into the frame of Brave New World surgery, where "ideas" or "values" are being implanted into brains like seedlings to insure a harmonious society. Then you need only imagine them taking root and breaking out into flower right through the tops of the skulls of people walking around on the streets.
