Mnemonic1: If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.
Mnemonic2: Crap! There are flowers in the rice field... Who let those seedlings get in there?!
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . seedling.
Mnemonic1: A sketch is a seedling (#234) of things to come. Before the assault, the sergeant draws a sketch of the attack with his fingers in the sand.
Mnemonic2: I´m bad at drawing, so when I try to sketch the kanji for cat, you can sort of recognize it, but I don´t get the curve of the "wild dogs" just right.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　苗: seedling; sapling; shoot

Origin: Knowing how much dogs love to chase cats, picture a pack of wild dogs planting "cat-seedlings," watering them, and fertilizing them until they can be harvested as a crop of cats for them to chase and torment. If you begin from the key word and think of a "crop of cats," you will not confuse this story with the apparently similar story of two frames ago.
Mnemonic1: The cat hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs.
Mnemonic2: Dawgs always wanna put their seedlings in pussies.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)
艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　明: bright; light

English: Sign, Omen; Show Signs Of, Trillion
Origin: Here we have a pictograph of the back of a turtle, the two sloping vertical strokes representing the central ridge and the four short strokes the pattern. Think of reading turtle shells as a way to foretell the future, and in particular things that portend coming evils.
SubOrigin: When this character is used as a primitive in its full form, we keep the key-word sense of a portent. When it appears to the left in its abbreviated form (namely, the left half only), we shall give it the pictographic sense of a turtle.
Mnemonic1: When your wife´s LEGs get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad portent for things to come.
Mnemonic2: A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.
Compo: 兆: sign; turtle, portent (RTK)

Origin: To give someone the "evil eye" is to stare at them, wishing them evil. The roots of the superstition are old and almost universal throughout the cultures of the world. In this kanji, too, being stared at is depicted as an eye that portends evil.
Mnemonic1: Sauron´s One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.
Mnemonic2: You lost a staring contest with a turtle because you blinked your eye before he did. (The contest wasn´t fair, because turtles have nictitating membranes, and don´t need to blink so often.) Eye comes first, because stare is most associated with eyes. And compare with challenge (#658) where this same obstreperous turtle challenges you to a finger wrestling contest. (Sibyl´s story with some notes that helped me).
Compo: 目: eye　兆: sign; turtle, portent (RTK)

Origin: When escaping from something or someone, one always feels as if one is not going fast enough, like a turtle on an expressway. (Since the turtle is on the road and not on the left, it can keep its full kanji shape as given in frame 250.)
Mnemonic1: I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to escape from prison; hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road!
Mnemonic2: A turtle version of frogger dodging cars to escape to the other side of the road…
Compo: 兆: sign; turtle, portent (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)
Kunyomi: に.げる, に.がす, のが.す, のが.れる

Origin: To associate the peach tree with the primitive for a portent, recall the famous Japanese legend of Momotarō, the Peach Boy. It begins once upon a time with a fisherman and his wife who wanted badly to have a child, but none was born to them. Then one day the old man caught a giant peach, out of which jumped a healthy young lad whom they named Peach Boy. Though the boy was destined to perform heroic deeds, his birth also portended great misfortune (how else could he become a hero?). Thus the tree that is associated with a portent of coming evil comes to be the peach tree.
Mnemonic1: The pits of a peach tree look like turtles.
Mnemonic2: King Koopa consistently captures Princess Peach. Eventually he´s going to run out of castles and just set her in a tree.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　兆: sign; turtle, portent (RTK)

Origin: Wooden leg . . . portent.
Mnemonic1: A girl with a wooden leg always wanted to play hopscotch with the other girls, but every time she tried to hop she´d lose her balance and injure another girl. That´s why the other girls make fun of her and see her presence as a portent to injury.
Mnemonic2: A turtle with a wooden leg needs to hop to get around.
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　兆: sign; turtle, portent (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . portent.
Mnemonic1: Here comes a new challenge, try to kill Bowser, the giant Turtle using jut on finger.
Mnemonic2: You are sure to take a challenge because your victory was portended. So you stand self-confident before your foe, point a finger at him and say "I will prevail, as was long portended!".
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　兆: sign; turtle, portent (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . exit.
Mnemonic1: With fingers fumbling around trying to get the key in the door so he could exit, the bungling husband woke his wife as he tried to leave for a rendezvous with his mistress.
Mnemonic2: Horror movie cliche 769: Bungling victim´s fingers fumble & bungle trying to open the exit door.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　出: exit

Origin: Flag . . . exit.
Mnemonic1: When yielding, soldiers raise the white flag before exiting from the trenches.
Mnemonic2: If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic yield to you.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　出: exit

Origin: Fingers . . . yield.
Mnemonic1: If you dig with your fingers hard enough, soil eventually yields.
Mnemonic2: When you dig, you´d better hope that whatever you´re digging into yields to your fingers. If not, you´re bound to lose some nails.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　出: exit
Ex2English: Turn up (the soil), tear up (a road)

Origin: Soil . . . yield.
Mnemonic1: (See dig (#1061)). When soil finally yielded thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a ditch.
Mnemonic2: Ditch / trench. The yielding army abandons it´s patch of soil, leaving behind a landscape of ditchs and trenches. Trench warfare.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　屈: yield

Origin: Think of the key word seal as referring to a letter you have written and are preparing to close. Instead of using the traditional wax seal, you glue a sprig of ivy on the outside. In this way the elements ivy and glue give you a curious and memorable way to seal your secret letters.
Mnemonic1: The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.
Mnemonic2: A bit of ivy glued to a letter can make a lovely SEAL when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart.
Compo: 圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . monk.
Mnemonic1: Seriously, all BAMBOO sticks look the SAME, just long CYLINDERS. Should the story be more complicated?
Mnemonic2: Fully-grown bamboo consists of a number of cylinder-like sections, all exactly the same.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　同: same; equal; monk (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . bureaucrat.
Mnemonic1: Japanese bureaucrats send all their messages through an inter-office bamboo pipe system.
Mnemonic2: The Japanese internet is a series of bamboo pipes said one ignorant bureaucrat trying to draft Internet legislation.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　官: bureaucrat

Origin: Wood . . . bureaucrat.
Mnemonic1: The maestro at home was sick of being a bureaucrat, so he got some wood and built himself a coffin and got in.
Mnemonic2: An excellent use of wood is to make coffins for bureaucrats.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　官: bureaucrat

Origin: Car . . . harm. Hint: the image of an auto going "out of control" may help keep this key word distinct from others like it, such as manipulate (Frame 864).
Mnemonic1: The roads are icy, and a whole bunch of cars have spun out of control! Luckily, it was just a couple of dents; nobody was harmed.
Mnemonic2: Control is very important! Especially when operating a car. Few people realize the harm they can cause just by losing control of their car for a second. Tremendous harm. Stay in control!
Compo: 車: car　害: harm

Origin: The key word den refers to an animal lair hollowed out in the side of a mountain. Now if we keep to the image of the monastic life as an image for same, we can picture a den of wild beasts dressed up in habits and living the common life in a mountain cavern. To bring in the element of water we need only give them a sacred "puddle" in the center of their den, the focus of all their pious attentions.
Mnemonic1: All the animals in the den share the same water.
Mnemonic2: Den and "cave" also make me think of a monk´s cell. Monks take vows of silence and fast. So a den is where you´d find nothing but water (to drink) and a monk.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　同: same; equal; monk (RTK)

Origin: Hole . . . yield.
Mnemonic1: After Osama blew a hole in NY, the counterreaction forced him to yield and retreat into caverns.
Mnemonic2: In "The Empire Strikes Back", the Milennium Falcon flies into a large hole, of what they think is a cavern, because they don´t want to yield to the forces of the Empire. Turns out it´s not a cavern at all, actually...
Compo: 穴: hole　屈: yield

Origin: Water . . . vulture . . . porter.
Mnemonic1: The vulture is on top of the porter and appears to be commiting a lewd act, so I throw water over the pair of them.
Mnemonic2: Claw marks across the porters back from engaging in lewd acts in the shower. He is tipped well for carrying the lady´s bags to her room.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　壬: porter (RTK)

Origin: A woman who is in her pregnancy is a bit like a porter, bearing her new companion wherever she goes.
Mnemonic1: A pregnant woman is a porter of her child.
Mnemonic2: The gentleman gave the woman a bit of sperm...BAM PREGNANCY!
Compo: 女: woman　壬: porter (RTK)

Origin: Woman . . . sign of the dragon. The key word is a synonym for pregnant, whose character we met earlier (Frame 546). Although the two kanji are often used together, they should be kept distinct.
Mnemonic1: A woman who is with child can't be sacrificed to the dragon; virgins only need apply.
Mnemonic2: The woman hides the dragon from poachers under her shirt, pretending she's with child. "Seen any sign of the dragon?" ask the poachers. "Nope, haven't seen him," replies the woman.
Compo: 女: woman　辰: sign of the dragon

Origin: Sign of the dragon . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: Sign of the Dragon + Mouth: Lips need chapstick during the wintertime so they don't look like the sign of the dragon who kissed you on the mouth.
Mnemonic2: As I approached her lips, I began to sense the sign of the dragon breath coming from her mouth, and I almost fainted.
Compo: 辰: sign of the dragon　口: mouth

Origin: Sign of the dragon . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: If you get too close to a fire-breathing dragon, your skin can turn red from the burn. When someone is embarrassed, it's as though they have this sign of the dragon stuck to their face.
Mnemonic2: The sign of the dragon falls off the cliff, to our great embarassment (see sign of the dragon (#2008)) We should have glued it there!
Compo: 辰: sign of the dragon　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Vase . . . meat . . . slingshot (doubled up with) snake . . . three . . . garment. The top half of this character is the old form for the kanji in frame 575.
Mnemonic1: The top 16 strokes are the chinese radical for "dragon". Joining up both meanings of the radical we can name the top part of this kanji "imperial dragon". Two-headed snakes do exist as biological curiosities, and they look a bit like a slingshot (with the heads splitting at a junction). Our imperial dragon here, the pet of a Chinese emperor, is a rare "three-headed slingshot-snake" kept in a vase and fed with meat. When the emperor attacked neighbours, his army wore the imperial dragon garment.
Mnemonic2: You attack an old dragon 龍 and take his clothes. REF: dragon (old] (#2981).
Compo: 龍: dragon; imperial　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . chihuahua.
Mnemonic1: Don´t need a silly story for this one: prostration is when a person puts themselves in a low position like a dog, as an extreme gesture of humility.
Mnemonic2: Mr T has beaten up the chihuahua, who lies prostrated in front of him. "Now," Mr T says, "I quiero some Taco Bell!".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　犬: dog (犭)
Ex3English: Turn downward, lay upside down, turn over

Compo: 口: mouth　犬: dog
口: mouth　齒: tooth
Ex4English: Mesh, engage (as of gears); bite one another

Origin: Spear . . . two balls.
Mnemonic1: Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your "spear" in the middle there.
Mnemonic2: Here we have two kings trying out for the cheer-leading squad. A spear on the floor separates their dancing areas.
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)　王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: Ball . . . plaid . . . ball.
Mnemonic1: Speckled is a pattern, like plaid, but with lots of little balls all over the place.
Mnemonic2: The sentences exchanged between the two kings got more and more heated, finally leading to a fight which left the whole area speckled with blood.
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　文: literature; plaid (RTK)　王: king; ball (RTK)

Origin: Jail cell . . . car.
Mnemonic1: Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle.
Mnemonic2: (+fuaburisu) But it´s the wrong jail cell! Your comrade is one floor above.
Compo: 非: mistake; jail cell (RTK)　車: car

Origin: Jail cell . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Saddness is like having your heart captured and jailed because of some sad or terrible event, etc. Here the sad heart waits for someone to come and un-lock their jail cell and set them free again.
Mnemonic2: Stuck in a jail cell with his heart crying out to see his family again, the prisoner has never felt so sad.
Compo: 非: mistake; jail cell (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: かな.しい, かな.しむ

Compo: 勿: not　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Keyword: Fall In Love With; Grow Senile
English: Fall In Love With; Grow Senile
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　忽: in a moment; instantly; all of a sudden; neglect; disregard

Origin: This clever little monkey has captured an entire pack of wild dogs, locked them inside a lidded crock, and wrapped the whole thing up in a silk scarf to present to the dogcatcher.
Mnemonic1: The MONKEY likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.
Mnemonic2: To catch a monkey, chase him with wild dogs into a lidded crock, then tie it with a scarf.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　袁: long kimono

Origin: A drunken sod in a tattered top hat and soiled silk scarf with a giant mouth guzzling something or other gives us a pathetic character role in which W. C. Fields might find himself right at home.
Mnemonic1: One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can´t see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it´s cool. I think it´s pathetic.
Mnemonic2: A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is pathetic-- in the original sense of the noun "pathos." The tattered tophat and scarf he wears only adds to the pathos.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　口: mouth衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Let this key word connote the decline and fall of the Roman Empire. It shows a fellow in a top hat and scarf, trying hard to look happy by putting a walking stick in his mouth sideways to twist his face into a grotesque but semi permanent smile.
Mnemonic1: If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical.
Mnemonic2: If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, allowing people to rent him and play catch with him for money!
Compo: 衣: clothes; garment (RTK)　口: mouth
Ex4English: Prosperity and decline, rise and fall

Origin: Between the top hat and the scarf you will see the character for in which is truncated at the bottom so as not to interfere with the scarf. You can think of this character forming as a pair with that of the former frame: there the in (the walking stick in the mouth) was set on its side; here it is set upright.
Mnemonic1: The guy from pathetic (#401) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.
Mnemonic2: Besides making money from acting like a dog (see decline), the pathetic man has risked his inmost internal organs by becoming a cane swallower!
Compo: 衣: clothes; garment (RTK)　口: mouth　丨: line; stick
Ex2English: Mixing of japanese and western elements

Origin: Soil . . . two mouths . . . hairpin. Hint: see spit (Frame 162). The key word carries the wide range of meanings readily associated with it: error, loss, absence, and so on.
Mnemonic1: I miss my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big cross, their mouths side by side. I stick hairpins in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. "Soil" is not drawn in its stroke order.
Mnemonic2: This kanji means miss as in "miss a (dearly departed) person", not as in "miss a target". Here the dearly departed has been buried in the ground, with her favourite hairpin in place of a gravestone, and two mourners stand around crying with open mouths.
Compo: 十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)　口: mouth　口: mouth　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Snake . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was MOURNING the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART.
Mnemonic2: You are mourning the death of a relative, and it feels as if a snake had bitten into your heart. -- "mourning feels like snake-bitten heart".
Compo: 已: oneself; snake (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: い.む, い.み, い.まわしい

Origin: The word eminent suggests a famous or well-known person. So all you need to do - given the primitives of a magic wand and a sunflower - is to think of the world's most eminent magician as one who uses a sunflower for a magic wand (like a flower-child who goes around turning the world into peace and love).
Mnemonic1: The most eminent magician is he who learned to use his magic wand early in life.
Mnemonic2: The eminent sunflower is the one that stands above the others.
Compo: 卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)　早: early; fast; sunflower (RTK)

Origin: To keep this character distinct from others of similar connotation, one need only think of the Prophet Jeremiah whose poetry gave an eminence to the state of mind we call lamentation.
Mnemonic1: When the world´s most eminent magician died, everyone´s state of mind became that of lamentation. He was buried with his famous sun-flower wand in his hand.
Mnemonic2: Data laments that he could never see his eminent father, his creator, ever again. He paints a picture of his father, that looks like a sunflower in the shape of a magic wand.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　卓: eminent

Origin: Now take the last primitive, the shellfish, and set a magic wand over it, and you have the kanji for upright. After all, the clam and the oyster are incapable of walking upright. It would take a magician with his wand to pull off such a feat - which is precisely what we have in this kanji.
Mnemonic1: A magic wand is needed to make a clam stand upright.
Mnemonic2: Just the thought of my magic wand on her clam makes my magic wand stand upright.
Compo: 卜: divination; magic wand (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . upright.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T is a terrible spy. He walks around upright. "Why should I hide?! I´ve got nothing to be ashamed of!".
Mnemonic2: NOTE: The second primitive is upright, not eminent. There is an error in the book.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　貞: upright

Origin: Old West . . . leather . . . moon.
Mnemonic1: In the old west, animal skins were made into leather and their flesh was eaten, thus using the whole animal, which viewed from the animal side could be taken as humans asserting complete hegemony over them. All your base are belong to us.
Mnemonic2: In the Old West, cowboys had hegemony OVER the Indians despite their leathercraft and ability to navigate by the moon.
Compo: 西: west (覀)　革: leather　月: moon; month

Origin: West . . . restore.
Mnemonic1: The U.S.S. Old West has capsized, and all the cowboys on board are trying to restore her upright.
Mnemonic2: Remember Oregon Trail? Remember how you had to float your wagon across rivers to get to the Old West? Well, sometimes that wagon capsizes. Once that happens you´d better quickly head to the nearest town to restore.
Compo: 西: west (覀)　復: again; restore (RTK)
Kunyomi: おお.う, くつがえ.す, くつがえ.る

Origin: Flag . . . restore.
Mnemonic1: NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on footgear, rather than actual footgear itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR FOOTGEAR and run off to RESTORE the FLAG.
Mnemonic2: You should never use a flag as a shoeshine cloth to restore your footgear.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　復: again; restore (RTK)

Origin: Flag . . . gnats (see frame 563) . . . with a belt.
Mnemonic1: These bugs BELONG TO an extremist group promoting insect independence. They are parading the FLAG of their group, the Nationalist GNATS, and wearing explosives BELTS for their planned terrorist war.
Mnemonic2: This FLAG BELONGS to the terror group called the GNATS, oftern seen wearing explosive BELTS. My opinion is they all BELONG in jail.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　丿: katakana no　虫: insect　冂: hood; belt (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . belong.
Mnemonic1: Entrust is to confer trust in someone else. My mouth belongs to you and your secret is safely entrusted with me.
Mnemonic2: If you entrust me with something, my mouth belongs to you.
Compo: 口: mouth　属: genius; belong (RTK)

Origin: The person on the left is familiar. As for the right side, we may combine the insect with a brain (observe the writing) and a belt to create the Talking Cricket who served as Pinocchio's conscience. (The belt is there because he pulls it off to give unrepentant little Pinocchio a bit of "strap" now and again.)
Mnemonic1: Mr. T accidentially stepped on Jiminy Cricket (a brainy insect, with a belt sort of sash to hold his "conscience" badge).
Mnemonic2: Mr. T accidentally steps on Jiminy Cricket. // Primitive: right side: Talking cricket = Jiminy Cricket, a brainy insect with a belt to whip little kids who misbehave.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　禺: long-tailed monkey; talking Cricket

Origin: Pinnacle . . . Talking Cricket.
Mnemonic1: If you behave badly at THE PINNACLE, JIMINY CRICKET will send you to sit in the corner.
Mnemonic2: Oh how the pious fall from their lofty pinnacles! Jiminy Cricket now deals drugs on the street corner.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　禺: long-tailed monkey; talking Cricket

Origin: Pinnacle . . . little . . . sun . . . little. Note that the form of the first element for little given here is the simpler form that has become standard in general-use characters (See Frame 110). For the time being, until typesetting fonts have made the adjustment, the official approved drawing has the drops similar to the bottom little.
Mnemonic1: There was only one chink in his plan. Even standing atop the highest pinnacle, standing above even the sun, the little man was still just as little as when he was under the sun.
Mnemonic2: Man those little chinks can do anything! They were the first to build rockets, and by launching one off the top of the highest pinnacle in China, one little chink was the first to ride above the sun, and see all the little chinks below!
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　小: little; owl (RTK)　日: day; sun　小: little; owl (RTK)

Origin: Talking Cricket . . . road.
Mnemonic1: On the road to my interview I accidentally bump into Jiminy Cricket who gives me some good advice.
Mnemonic2: I was finally able to score an interview with the wisest being around: Jiminy Cricket. However, his schedule is really packed, so they had to squeeze me in while his tour bus rode between gigs. In fact, it was really short---after a few miles I was kicked out of the bus and stranded in the middle of the interstate. But man, it was worth it!
Compo: 禺: long-tailed monkey; talking Cricket　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Talking Cricket . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: Don´t be foolish! says Jiminy Cricket as he lashes you with his belt. Follow logic, like me, not your heart.
Mnemonic2: I simply imagine Jiminy Cricket jumping all over the place, like a mad man, yelling "yeeeeehaaaaa!". Maybe he just fell in love? Mnemonic - "Jiminy Cricket has a foolish heart".
Compo: 禺: long-tailed monkey; talking Cricket　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: This character is written in the order of its elements: one . . . bend . . . sun.
Mnemonic1: A space cadet eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).
Mnemonic2: Bender lasted just one day in the space cadets.
Compo: 一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　曲: compostion, bend (RTK)　日: day; sun

Origin: Cadet . . . road.
Mnemonic1: Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.
Mnemonic2: Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) has an "encounter of the third kind" on the road. Reference to Steven Spielberg´s 1977 movie "Close Encounters of the Third Kind". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO´s while driving on the road.
Compo: 曹: official; cadet (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . cadet.
Mnemonic1: Also as part of some army survival exercise, the cadets (including Bender see frame 1172) are sent into the woods to build a vat (for collecting water for example).
Mnemonic2: Bender the Cadet (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a tree, getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey Vat 69.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　曹: official; cadet (RTK)

Origin: Imagine a compass that is disturbed every time a woman passes by, sending the needle spinning madly round and round.
Mnemonic1: Capt. Jack Sparrow´s compass gets disturbed every time a beautiful woman walks by him (just picture Keira Knightley in her sexy asian outfit as Elizabeth and the image will be fixed forever).
Mnemonic2: One way to Disturb a woman is to give her directions while she is in the middle of driving -- she just can´t take that kind of stress.
Compo: 女: woman　方: direction; compass (RTK)
Ex3Kana: すいみんをさまたげる

Origin: The character for a boy shows us a Boy Scout cleaning the dirt out of his compass - the more dirt, the better.
Mnemonic1: Little boys always head in the direction of mud and dirt.
Mnemonic2: Boys thoughts often head in dirty directions.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　方: direction; compass (RTK)

Origin: Person . . . stand . . . crown . . . compass.
Mnemonic1: In Japan, the emperor is a bystander - he stands on his crown but can´t really affect the direction of the country. (thx shimouma).
Mnemonic2: Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand... he´s asking the bystander if they know how to get to buckingham palace (!).
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)　冖: crown　方: direction; compass (RTK)
Ex3Kanji: 勉強の傍らに音楽を聞く
Ex3Kana: べんきょうのかたわらにおんがくをきく

Compo: 方: direction; compass (RTK)　冫: ice
Ex1English: On that point, in that regard
Ex2Kanji: 日本に於けるカナダ人
Ex2Kana: にほんにおけるカナダじん

Origin: Door . . . compass.
Mnemonic1: Explanation here: http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?pid=14684#p14684.
Mnemonic2: When you graduate from a school, after they gave you your tassel, they shove you to the door and give you a compass saying "Sayonara & Good Luck out there!" (ボウ).
Compo: 戸: door　方: direction; compass (RTK)

Origin: Door . . . wings.
Mnemonic1: It´s insanely hot today! I´m standing in the doorway, fanning myself with feathers.
Mnemonic2: I am a fan of the Doors but I also like the Wings. I have a fan that I take to rock concerts with the picture of each band on the sides.
Compo: 戸: door　羽: feathers; wings

Origin: Door . . . jail cell.
Mnemonic1: The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors.
Mnemonic2: An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like door at the back of his jail cell, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers "Which door?", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - "The front door !".
Compo: 戸: door　非: mistake; jail cell (RTK)

Origin: Door . . . turkey. Be sure to keep distinct from both employee (Frame 59) and use (Frame 1065).
Mnemonic1: Our company has no standards. We´ll employ any turkey who walks in the door.
Mnemonic2: Comedy. An executive is having an argument with a cocky, but skilled, employee: "Damn it, you might be good. But that don´t account for your behavior. You keep this up and I´ll fire your ass." "No, you won´t." "What damn it, I´ll fire you your ass so fast you won´t...know..."-. "And what will you do after you fire me, employ the next turkey that walks through that door?" A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. --"The Exec employs the turkey that walked through the door".
Compo: 戸: door　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Employ . . . head.
Mnemonic1: I was EMPLOYED to give HEAD...when I look back, maybe that was not a wise career move.
Mnemonic2: The people we employ are always turning their heads to look back. They don´t want to be caught playing solitare on company time.
Compo: 雇: employ; hire　頁: page; head (RTK)
尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　肖: resemblance; spark, candle (RTK)
米: rice　異: uncommon

Origin: Flag . . . water.
Mnemonic1: Animals use their urine to mark their territory. So for them, their body water works as a flag denoting their "country" (why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick).
Mnemonic2: Someone is pissing on the American flag, but since the urine is clear it looks like water.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Water . . . the invariably divided heart.
Mnemonic1: Anything full of water will invariably begin to ooze.
Mnemonic2: When you pierce a heart with a stake, it invariably oozes blood.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　必: invariably

Origin: Flag . . . baseball team.
Mnemonic1: The baseball team stick flags in their buttocks and wave them at the opposing team to put them off.
Mnemonic2: I wonder if this story will be flagged for saying i give her buttocks a score of 9.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　九: nine; baseball (RTK)
Ex2English: Rising intonation; head over heels; rising market

Origin: Hearth fire . . . door.
Mnemonic1: This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive.
Mnemonic2: -"Honey? Do we have any wood left for the hearth?" -"Aagh, just use the frickin´ door!".
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　戸: door

Origin: Hole . . . sheep . . . oven fire.
Mnemonic1: Be sure to put a hole in that ceramic sheep before you put it over the fire. Otherwise, it´ll just explode in the kiln. (If you´ve never done ceramics before, it´s important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.).
Mnemonic2: You put the sheep in the hole of the kiln and turn on the flames.
Compo: 穴: hole　羊: sheep　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Father . . . metal. Note the stroke overlap between father and metal.
Mnemonic1: Your father uses his legs to stop himself from being put in a metal cauldron.
Mnemonic2: Whilst on holiday, my father was captured by cannibals and put in a metal cauldron.
Compo: 父: father　金: gold; metal
父: father　耶: question mark
Kunyomi: じい, じじ, じじい, おやじ

Origin: Hole . . . water . . . ivy. The depression referred to here is a sunken place in the ground, rather than in one's spirits.
Mnemonic1: A depression is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow.
Mnemonic2: The depression in the ground become a trap: the hole was filled with water and covered with ivy.
Compo: 穴: hole　水: water (氵) (氺)　圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)
Kunyomi: くぼ.む, くぼ.まる, くぼ

Origin: Person . . . ivy. To distinguish from excel (Frame 980), eminent (Frame 52), esteem (Frame 196), and exquisite (Frame 130), give the key word its own unique connotation.
Mnemonic1: Mr T wants to go to an excellent school, so he enrolls in Harvard, an ivy-league school.
Mnemonic2: Bill and Ted are walking through medieval Europe when they see a humongous square jewel. "Excellent!" they both yell. But only after grabbing it do they realize it is chained to the neck of Mr. T, who grimaces angrily at them. "Bogus!" they cry, and totally run away.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)

Origin: After seeing a constant horizon of water, water everywhere for months at sea, could there be anything more delightful to the eyes than to look astern and see the ivy-clad cliffs of land on a new horizon? Of course, you'd need the eyes of a stellar telescope to recognize that the vegetation was in fact ivy, but the phrase "ivy-clad cliffs" has such a nice ring to it that we won't worry about such details.
Mnemonic1: Try to reverse Heisig´s story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. From your prison ontop the ivy clad cliff all you can see in the distant horizon is nothing but water.
Mnemonic2: From the water, I can see the ivy-clad-cliffs on the horizon.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　厂: cliff　圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)

Origin: The element for day on the left is logical enough. Next to it we see staples being held in mouth (one stroke is doubled up), indicating working in one's hobby or handicrafts at home on one's spare time. The small box at the top right is facing backwards, or more properly "inside out." Finally, we have the crotch at the bottom.
Mnemonic1: Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video´s of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch.
Mnemonic2: Tip: The complex right side of this kanji appears twice more in Heisig. He later names it "hobby". REF: shrimp (#2689), haze (#2779).
Compo: 日: day; sun　叚: False
雨: rain　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Mnemonic1: The part of the sky that is responsible for weather and rain is known as the atmosphere. It only occupies part of the sky though.
Mnemonic2: (This is atmosphere as in ambiance, mood). Rain is only part of the atmosphere for a romantic porch date. Food, music, and candles are the rest.
Compo: 雨: rain　分: part; segment

Origin: Weather/rain . . . task.
Mnemonic1: This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected.
Mnemonic2: FOG is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of FOG as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.
Compo: 雨: rain　務: task; duties

Origin: Rain . . . path.
Mnemonic1: After the rain the path was covered with dew.
Mnemonic2: Dew forms on the path least weathered.
Compo: 雨: rain　路: route, path

Origin: Think of frost as a cooperative venture, an inter-action of the malevolent forces of weather that sit around a conference table and finally decide to allow a very light amount of moisture to fall just before a short and sudden freeze.
Mnemonic1: FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.
Mnemonic2: The freezing RAIN formed FROST on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want, frost-y then think Frost Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY: FROSTY the snowman? It´s RAIN that FROSTS that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course.
Compo: 雨: rain　相: inter-

Origin: Bamboo . . . inter-.
Mnemonic1: The best kind of BOX is made from BAMBOO sticks that are INTER-laced to make it air tight. Just picture such a box and you´ve mastered this kanji.
Mnemonic2: I think of a box made of inter-locking of bamboo strips.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　相: inter-

Origin: Bamboo . . . Christmas tree . . . once upon a time.
Mnemonic1: Japanese father enrolls his student in a well-rounded school: they teach eastern traditions (the way of the bamboo), western traditions (like Christmas trees), and also teach literature (once upon a time).
Mnemonic2: Once upon a time, in order to enroll in a Christian school you had to answer a series of questions to ensure that you were really Christian. For example, the principal might show you a picture of a Christmas tree and a picture of some bamboo and ask you which one is most suitable for decoration at Christmas time.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　耒: plough; christmas tree (RTK)　昔: olden days; once upon a time (RTK)

Origin: If one is asked to think of associations for the word pierce, among the first to come to mind is that of piercing one's ears to hold earrings, a quite primitive form of self-mutilation that has survived into the 21st century. The kanji here is read, top to bottom: mama . . . oyster. All you need to do is imagine piercing an ear so that it can hold a mother-of-pearl (actually, a mama-of-pearl) you have just wrested from an oyster.
Mnemonic1: Ariel the Little Mermaid´s clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings.
Mnemonic2: The sad fate of Mama shellfish was to be captured and pierced to make an earring.
Compo: 母: mother (毋); breasts (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . pierce.
Mnemonic1: It took him awhile, but Data finally got ACCUSTOMED to his nipple/breast piercings. They were constantly rubbing up against his shirt and his heart-shaped locket. Picture Data, shirtless, squeezing his nipples in front of Picard and saying "Yes, at first they were a bit shelly, but I´ve grown quite ACCUSTOMED to them". That last bit should do it for you.
Mnemonic2: Some hardcore monks have a state of mind that has become accustomed to their self-torture through piercing themselves.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　貫: pierce
Ex1English: Get used to, become experienced in

Origin: The key word is actually a formal metaphor meaning "humble acceptance." Reading off the two primitive elements in the order of their writing, we have: nail . . . head. As in "hitting the nail on the head." Now one presumes that most people can handle metaphors, but if you were to run into a dimwit working in a hardware store who only knew the literal meaning of things, and were to ask him, in your best Japanese, to place on your head a nail, he might miss the point and cause you considerable torment.
Mnemonic1: If I put a street sign on my head what do I get ? A place on the head !
Mnemonic2: NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, The HEAD ON commercial nails it into your head......
Compo: 丁: street; nail (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)
Kunyomi: いただ.く, いただき
Ex1English: Receive humbly, be given; eat, drink

Origin: Thanksgiving . . . uncommon.
Mnemonic1: At Thanksgiving, it’s uncommon for people to accept humbly the food: most people just dig in.
Mnemonic2: You´re invited to a Thanksgiving party in Japan! Awesome! You´re so happy that your Japanese friends are trying to make you feel at home (you´ve been homesick recently). You sit down to the table, and they bring out some..uh...uncommon food. Really uncommon. Like just imagine the most uncommon Thanksgiving food ever, and that´s what you´re given (i don´t know, a frisbee or something?). Of course, you have to be Japanese and accept humbly their food.
Compo: 𢦏: thanksgiving (RTK)　異: uncommon

Origin: To the right we see a head and to the left an element that means craft. When we think of a paragraph, we immediately think of a heading device to break a text into parts. (Think of the elaborate heads often seen at the start of medieval manuscripts and the task becomes easier still.) Just where and how to do it belongs to the writer's craft. Hence, we define paragraphing as the "heading craft" to remember this character.
Mnemonic1: To write a paragraph is the craft of grouping sentences on a page.
Mnemonic2: To craft a page well, we need paragraphs.
Compo: 工: craft; construction　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: When Uncle Bob starts his comic routine of sticking spoons on his head, you know it is about that time to come up with a reason to excuse yourself.
Mnemonic1: An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head.
Mnemonic2: After spooning for hours it´s about that time he got some head. Dayum woman.
Compo: 匕: spoon　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Change . . . head. The key word has the sense of leaning on or toward someone or something.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T gave a girl some change to lean over and give him head.
Mnemonic2: Leaning over changes the position of the head…
Compo: 化: change　頁: page; head (RTK)
Kunyomi: かたむ.く, かたむ.ける, かし.げる*

Origin: This character refers to the blockheaded, persistent stubbornness of one who sticks to an idea or a plan just the way it was at the beginning, without letting anything that comes up along the way alter things in the least. The explanation makes "sense," but is hard to remember because the word "beginning "is too abstract. Back up to the image we used two frames ago - Adam and Eve in their Eden - and try again: The root of all stubbornness goes back to the beginning, with two brothers each stubbornly defending his own way of life and asking their God to bless it favorably. Abel stuck to agriculture, Cain to animal-raising. Picture these two with their giant, swelled heads, each vying for the favors of heaven, a stubborn grimace on their faces. No wonder something unfortunate happened!
Mnemonic1: A stubborn person in the beginning gets something into their head and can´t change their mind.
Mnemonic2: Picture a STUBBORN schoolboy, with his arms crossed and his book still open to the BEGINNING PAGE. Despite the teacher telling him to turn the page, he refuses and keeps his book on the BEGINNING PAGE.
Compo: 元: beginning; origin　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Part . . . head.
Mnemonic1: The PART of my HEAD where I remember the KANJI is in the kanji PARTITION.
Mnemonic2: The last time I tried to partition a hard drive under Linux, I got a severe migraine that parted my head.
Compo: 分: part; segment　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Earthworm . . . head.
Mnemonic1: Ever chopped the head off an earthworm? Notice how it will grow back immediately! Beware the killer earthworms...
Mnemonic2: When someone in the barracks tells you to come immediately, you´ll lose your head for sure トン トツ にわか.に とん.と つまず.く とみ.に ぬかずく suddenly; immediately; in a hurry.
Compo: 屯: police station; earthworm (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Sun . . . row . . . heads.
Mnemonic1: Somebody's head appears from behind the laundry in a row drying under the sun
Mnemonic2: Clouds were covering the sky for months now. Rows upon rows of people spent whole days with their heads turned upwards, waiting for sun to appear.
Compo: 日: day; sun　业: spikes　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Orders . . . head.
Mnemonic1: Two cowboys are crossing a state limit. One says to him “Did you know that in this Jurisdiction there are Orders to get your head?”, so he takes out his gun and shoots him. He claims the reward afterwards. (Thanks Fuaburisu).
Mnemonic2: Orders are given by the head person in any jurisdiction.
Compo: 令: orders　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: The image of something occurring repeatedly, over and over again, is of having one's head walked on.
Mnemonic1: I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head.
Mnemonic2: Are you familiar with the joke about the ditzy secretary who repeatedly walked back and forth forcibly over all the pages of her boss´ most important letters. When confronted she just says "Well you said they needed to be stamped before they´re mailed.".
Compo: 歩: walk　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Let your fingers do the walking as you make headway through the Yellow Pages in search of something hard to find.
Mnemonic1: Come on people, the only way to make headway in this business is to let your fingers do the walking! bust out the yellow pages and dial as many numbers as possible, surely someone is a sucker for a cold call sell.
Mnemonic2: Thing from the Addams Family has difficulties in making headway because, well, he has no head. Only walking fingers.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　歩: walk

Origin: In primitive language, this character would read stream . . . head. And that turns out to be convenient for remembering its meaning of obey. Either one obeys the person who is head of an organization or else obeys by following the stream of opinion ("current" practice, we call it). Both these senses come together in this kanji.
Mnemonic1: Obey, Obey! says the brain-washing scientist as he sends a stream of orders to fill your head.
Mnemonic2: Obey the orders streaming down from head office.
Compo: 巛: river (川); flood (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)
馬: horse　巛: river (川); flood (RTK)
Ex1English: Become familiar, grow accustomed; get (clothing) to fit

Origin: The personalism connoted by the word instruction, as opposed to "teaching" or "discipline," suits the picture here of words guiding one's progress like the gentle flowing of a stream. Even the etymology of the word instruction suggests the sense of "pouring into".
Mnemonic1: The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day.
Mnemonic2: Listen carefully to the words of instruction before you try swimming in the river.
Compo: 言: word; say　巛: river (川); flood (RTK)

Origin: Shape . . . head. This is the only time that shape is placed to the left of its relative element, the head.
Mnemonic1: Why, I OUGHT to RESHAPE your HEAD...
Mnemonic2: Since this Kanji is exceptional, the shape ought to be on the left side. Got that into your head?
Compo: 彡: hair; shape (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: As Miss Manners will be the first to tell you, out of respect, one does not look straight into the eyes of one's guests, but focus on the top button of their collar. Here, however, you are told to look above the eyes to the forehead of your guest.
Mnemonic1: Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints).
Mnemonic2: In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their foreheads together.
Compo: 客: guest; visitor　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Bundle . . . head.
Mnemonic1: When you trust in something, you've got your head 頁 all bundled 束 up (wrapped up) in it.
Mnemonic2: We found a bundle of severed heads in your room, its difficult to trust you.
Compo: 束: bundle　頁: page; head (RTK)
Kunyomi: たの.む, たの.もしい, たよ.る
Ex3English: Rely on, have confidence in, trust

Origin: Water . . . bundle . . . head.
Mnemonic1: You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids.
Mnemonic2: You can never trust the water in the rapids, it will do everything it can to pull you under. Imagine a line of natives with bundles upon their heads all fighting the rapids to cross the river.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　束: bundle　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Mountain . . . scissors.
Mnemonic1: A gorge is where God has cut into a mountain with a pair of scissors. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html.
Mnemonic2: A kid cuts a gorge into a paper mountain, with a pair of scissors.
Compo: 山: mountain　夾: scissors

Origin: Pack of wild dogs . . . scissors.
Mnemonic1: A pack of wild dogs, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by Edward Scissors Hands, who is very popular.
Mnemonic2: In a CRAMPED space, a brave man holds off PACK OF WILD DOGS with only a pair of SCISSORS.
Compo: 犬: dog (犭)　夾: scissors
Kunyomi: せま.い, せば.める, せば.まる

Origin: Fingers . . . scissors. Do not confuse with the kanji for pinch (Frame 709).
Mnemonic1: 挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip..
Mnemonic2: Fingers sandwiched between a pair of scissors. Don´t move or else!
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　夾: scissors
Ex2English: Attack on both sides, pincer movement

Origin: Two mouths . . . ceiling . . . snare . . . head.
Mnemonic1: Your chin is the part of your head under your nostrils that forms the double snare that is your jaw.
Mnemonic2: Left side is crocodile primative. crocodile´s head´s most prominent feature is his jaw.
Compo: 咢: outspokenly　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: The existential condition of anxiety that arises from the inevitable frustration of our worldly passions is contained in this character. The head is set afire, causing deep torment of spirit (and a whopper of a headache).
Mnemonic1: An anxiety feels like FIRE in the HEAD.
Mnemonic2: Many performers get "Michael Jackson anxiety" wherein they fear their head will catch on fire.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　頁: page; head (RTK)
Kunyomi: わずら.う, わずら.わす

Origin: This pictograph of two pieces of meat on a skewer, a shish kebab, will help us in the next frame.
Mnemonic1: Naka naka , "who´s there?" shish kebab .... "shish kebab who?".
Mnemonic2: This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.
Compo: 口: mouth　口: mouth　丨: line; stick

Origin: Shish kebab . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: A person who is afflicted with the vampire disease can only be killed with a sheesh-kebab through the heart.
Mnemonic2: If you are afflicted with severe heartburn, eating a spicy shish kebab will feel only slightly less painful than having it jammed straight into your heart.
Compo: 串: skewer; shish kebab (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Be sure to keep this character distinct from quick (Frame 1799) and swift (Frame 298). Picture a succession of poison darts (the sort that inflict sickness) flying out rapid-fire from a blowgun, so that "rapid-fire" can conjure up the proper image.
Mnemonic1: I picture a sick caveman, and two people rapidly blowing darts at him. One is blowing poison darts, the other is blowing antidote darts. Will the sick caveman live or die? Depends on how rapidly they fire.
Mnemonic2: If shot with a poison dart, sickness develops rapidly.
Compo: 疒: sickness　矢: arrow; dart (RTK)

Origin: Know . . . sickness.
Mnemonic1: Of course caveman is stupid. He doesn´t know anything. He´s a caveman!
Mnemonic2: This kanji shows stupidity as a "knowledge-sickness". Everybody can be stupid at times, and it usually happens because of a lack of experience. Hence the stupidity is a "knowledge sickness".
Compo: 疒: sickness　知: know

Origin: Sickness . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: Sickness-missiles are being engineered by bio-terrorists to spread epidemics all over the world. Imagine seeing footage of a place where those sickness-missiles are built : rows after rows of missiles, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different sickness such as "flu", "plague", etc.
Mnemonic2: SICKNESS / MISSILE ** Hint: True fact about biochemical warfare: in the medieval and ancient world, SICKNESS in the form of the corpses of those who had died from some EPIDEMIC or plague were often hurled at the enemy via the crude MISSILE launchers of the time. (C].
Compo: 疒: sickness　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Sickness . . . profit.
Mnemonic1: For a country full of pay-per-use public toilets, sudden diarrhea is certainly the most profitable sickness!
Mnemonic2: Caveman doesn´t have any skills, so he sells his diarrhea as chili to peasant wheat farmers for an amazing profit.
Compo: 疒: sickness　利: profiit

Origin: Sickness . . . beans.
Mnemonic1: Caveman has horrible pox. They look like edamame beans oozing bight green paste.
Mnemonic2: Pox is a sickness which symptoms include bean-shaped bumps on the skin.
Compo: 疒: sickness　豆: beans; table (RTK)

Origin: Sickness . . . piggy bank.
Mnemonic1: His sickness caused numerous carbuncles, which when emptied by the doctors also emptied his piggy bank.
Mnemonic2: The witches piggy bank was cursed with a spell causing any thief who stole it's contents to fall ill. The illness would result in the victim being covered from head to toe in a mass of carbuncles. Crime doesn't pay!
Compo: 疒: sickness　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)
疒: sickness　嵒: rock

Origin: Sickness . . . monkey . . . crotch.
Mnemonic1: The most horrific way to lose weight is from that devastating sickness that came from a monkey's crotch.
Mnemonic2: The poor monkey obviously had a sickness. He was scratching his crotch the whole time and when he started to lose weight heavily, the caretakers knew they couldn´t save him anymore.
Compo: 疒: sickness　申: honor; monkey (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Origin: Sickness . . . pelt.
Mnemonic1: I picture an exhausted sick caveman snuggling up in a comfy pelt blanket.
Mnemonic2: Your body feels tired when you have a sickness. All you want to do is wrap yourself up in a nice warm pelt and get better.
Compo: 疒: sickness　皮: skin; pelt (RTK)

English: Be Subjected To; Be Covered In
Origin: Cloak . . . pelt.
Mnemonic1: If you wear a coat of fur (pelt) you are sure to incur the wrath of animal rights extremists.
Mnemonic2: A cloak of fur (pelt) will incur the wrath of animal lovers.
Compo: 衤: cloak (RTK)　皮: skin; pelt (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . pelt.
Mnemonic1: You expose holes in a pelt by passing your fingers through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc.
Mnemonic2: Think of it in this vulgar way. You really want her to expose her “beaver” pelt, so you have to encourage her with your fingers to expose it.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　皮: skin; pelt (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . friend.
Mnemonic1: Don´t let good friends slip out between your fingers.
Mnemonic2: Imagine a cliché Hollywood situation: one person is lying on the edge of the abyss and another (presumably his friend) is hanging, only thing holding him is the grip of their hands. Then fingers slip out of the grip and he falls in said abyss.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　友: friend
Kunyomi: ぬ.く, -ぬ.く, ぬ.き, ぬ.ける, ぬ.かす, ぬ.かる

Origin: Fingers . . . empty.
Mnemonic1: With my fingers, I punch in my bank code and withdraw some money from my account. And now it´s empty again, as usual!
Mnemonic2: If you find yourself in a fight with a karate master with no weapons or martial art skills, just your empty fingers, you should withdraw because 空手 (karate="empty hand") is more powerful than 控 (="empty fingers").
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　空: empty; sky
Ex2English: Hold back, restrain oneself; wait for; deduct; note down

Origin: Fingers . . . husband.
Mnemonic1: Using his finger the husband sometimes is an erotic aid to his partner.
Mnemonic2: In Homer Simpsons´ house, the first aid kit is usually used for when he smashes his fingers trying to build something (there are countless Simpsons episodes you can draw from for this).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　夫: husband; man

Origin: Fingers . . . extremity.
Mnemonic1: I like to RUB my FINGERS over my EXTREMITIES ....like my extremity-ly long, umm, hair.... This has been edited in response to being reported ...you can change "hair" to whatever extremity-ly long body part you like.
Mnemonic2: When you´re cold, your RUB your FINGERS over your EXTREMITIES vigorously to warm up a bit. I´d still rather go in for a warm fire and some hot cocoa, though.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　末: extremity
Ex1English: Erase, strike out; deny, ignore; do away with, liquidate

Origin: Fingers . . . rocks.
Mnemonic1: A huge index finger coming down from the sky is kicking boulders of rock, clearing the land. Maybe it´s the finger of God preparing a place for his little people to live.
Mnemonic2: I imagine clearing the land in order to set up your tent after a long day of backpacking. Using your fingers, you pick up all of the rocks and get them out of the way so that you can get a comfortable night sleep. If you don´t clear the land you can just picture the rock sticking into your back as you toss and turn all night long.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　石: stone; rock (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . consider.
Mnemonic1: In Torture 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. Then you can move on to other parts (like feet, groin, head, etc. etc. ; ) ).
Mnemonic2: Aaaargh, stop! cries the victim of torture, his fingers being squeezed by the thumb screws. "I´ll consider it," the torturer says coolly, "if you tell me the names of all the agents in your organization.".
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　考: thought; consider (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . rice . . . woman.
Mnemonic1: The young taskmaster (see number (#929)) uses a tree as a watchtower to get a better view of his rice-carrying women. "I can seeeee you! One! Two! Three!".
Mnemonic2: On the top of the woodmade watchtower we look for our enemies, who will come to steal our rice and our women.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　米: rice　女: woman

Origin: Soil/ground . . . top hat . . . -times . . . nightbreak. With kanji as difficult as this one, it generally pays to toy with the various connotations of its primitives before settling on one image. Aim for as much simplicity as you can.
Mnemonic1: A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.
Mnemonic2: Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of soil for a podium, when he wore his top hat and gave the speech he had practiced many times until nightbreak. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　亠: roof; hat (RTK)　回: times　旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)

Origin: On the left we see a mound of dirt, and to the right flowers made to fit together. The two sides combine to create a great pagoda made of dirt, with flowers by the tens of thousands fitted together for the roofing of each of the layers. Be sure to put yourself in the scene and fit a few of the flowers in place yourself so that the image works its way into memory with full force.
Mnemonic1: In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner.
Mnemonic2: Pictograph-o-rama. This is a corner of a Japanese garden, with a small mound of soil on the left, and a little concrete pagoda in the front with flowers behind it. (To my eye, the fit looks a lot like a little pagoda anyway. This may or may not cause confusion for you, though...).
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　合: fit

Origin: The key word refers to boarding vessels for travel. Its elements are: finger . . . flowers . . . fit together (See frame 270).
Mnemonic1: Ok, this is a little wierd, but i took this back to the kanji for pagoda (#254). I think it helps simplify the image, and also helps anchor the pagoda kanji in memory better as an added bonus. say this aloud once, and i think it will bring out a vivid image very quickly: "Now boarding the pagoda ride. Please keep your fingers inside at all times...".
Mnemonic2: When you board the ship on the way out from Hawaii a beautiful crewmember takes her fingers and fits a lei around you ....a lei is flowers fitted together with your fingers.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　合: fit
Ex3English: Board, get on a plane, embark

Origin: House . . . head . . . dagger. Immediately we get another instance of a very odd exception. Notice how the final stroke of the head is lengthened, giving the final two strokes a chance to stretch out and make room for the dagger that fits in beneath.
Mnemonic1: The new widow sits in the house, her head in her lap (the extended stroke), her dagger in her husband.
Mnemonic2: The house´s head, her husband, was murdered with a dagger. You can still see the drops of blood above the dagger. She is now a widow.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　頁: page; head (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: The V.I.P. indicated here is an important guest making a visit. The elements are: house . . . ceiling . . . few . . . shells.
Mnemonic1: This house is reserved to V.I.P. only. If you are not one of the few with enough money to call you that way, keep out!
Mnemonic2: The V.I.P. visits your house, but your ceiling is too low for his inflated head, which he bumps and hurts. You have to give him your few shells as compensation.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　少: few　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)

Origin: Food . . . reclining . . . towel.
Mnemonic1: (decorate; ornament; adorn; embellish] We decorate a table before eating, reclining a towel over it.
Mnemonic2: Naked sushi: a lady reclining on a towel as decoration for the food laid out on her.
Compo: 食: eat; food　𠂉: man; lying down, reclining (RTK)　巾: towel

Origin: Eat . . . wrap.
Mnemonic1: My gluttony was only sated after I ate the hamburger AND the wrapper!
Mnemonic2: This guy is sated only after eating the hamburger AND its wrapping!
Compo: 食: eat; food　包: wrap

Origin: Food . . . ego.
Mnemonic1: All those starving models in Hollywood - they want to eat, but their ego (about their appearance and trim look) makes sure they grin and bear it!
Mnemonic2: He starves for FOOD but his EGO won´t let him beg.
Compo: 食: eat; food　我: ego

Origin: Food . . . wind.
Mnemonic1: The smell of cooked food wafts past you in the wind, making your stomach rumble and feeling hungry.
Mnemonic2: The wind blew away my food, so now I´m hungry.
Compo: 食: eat; food　几: table; wind (RTK)

Origin: We need to fix imagination here on two things to learn the kanji for desk: the wonderful rough wood of which it has been hewn and the wind that blows across it, sending your papers flying all over the room. These two elements, written in that order, dictate how to write the character.
Mnemonic1: My wooden desk is so messy, it looks like a strong wind blew my things all over it.
Mnemonic2: Whenever I´m alone at my computer desk, I´m always getting wood and breaking wind.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　几: table; wind (RTK)
Ex1English: Top of the desk; academic, theoretical

Origin: Picture a weather vane beneath a regal crown, spinning round and round. It is not only superfluous but makes a perfect ass out of the one who wears it.
Mnemonic1: The king´s crown was blown off by the wind. "Oh well," he said, "it´s just a superfluous symbol.".
Mnemonic2: The court jester wears a crown and is full of wind with bad jokes. He is superfluous to the King´s court. This kanji is read as "JOU" and commonly used to create the compound for jou-dan 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also jou-go 冗語 (redundancy) and jou-in 冗員 (useless workers) 員-employee (#56).
Compo: 冖: crown 　几: table; wind (RTK)

Origin: By having the crown pass from one age to the next, a people keeps itself glued to its beginnings.
Mnemonic1: Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying "i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING".
Mnemonic2: A crown, from the beginning of the new king´s life, is glued to him. He must inherit it.
Compo: 冖: crown 　元: beginning; origin

Origin: Top hat . . . villain . . . belt . . . elbow . . . turkey. This is potentially one of the most difficult characters to remember. Tackle it positively and let the image "sink in" by carrying it around with you today and calling it up in your spare moments.
Mnemonic1: I´ve finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I´m about to fight him. But what´s this? He´s suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!
Mnemonic2: The left side isn't too hard---a top-hatted villain whose villainy involves belts around elbows? Clearly he's a drug dealer. And the best way to detach yourself from the drug dealer's influence is to go cold turkey.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　凶: evil; vilain (RTK)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Part of the body . . . bound up . . . villain.
Mnemonic1: Just think of the heroine's bosom in a movie. The villain ties up the heroine (to the traintracks or the conveyor belt etc) but her bosom is the body part that is always left sticking out.
Mnemonic2: As you know, female comics villains are always binding the flesh of their bosom up in interesting ways. One has to wonder how these clothes stay on their body at all...
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　凶: evil; vilain (RTK)

Origin: State of mind . . . owl . . . villain.
Mnemonic1: When I am in trouble, my state of mind is on two sides: 1. The wise part of me (owl) 2. The villain part of me (villain) Think of the devil and the angel on your shoulders in a troubled situation.
Mnemonic2: The owl villain is the one that troubles me most of all the super-villains. He´s just so smart... you never know what he´ll do! Definitely enough to put you in a troubled state of mind.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　小: little; owl (RTK)　凶: evil; vilain (RTK)

Origin: Part of the body . . . owl . . . villain. By way of exception, the kanji for brain has no connection with the primitive for brains.
Mnemonic1: The brain is the part of the body that can give you the wisdom of the owl... or the wickedness of the villain.
Mnemonic2: The brain is the part of the body that an owl will use to defeat the villain.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　小: little; owl (RTK)　凶: evil; vilain (RTK)

Origin: Part of the body . . . storehouse.
Mnemonic1: You signed your organ donor card, right? So, when you die, your entrails and other body parts will be placed in a storehouse.
Mnemonic2: Again with the Pyramids, each Pharaoh had their entrails taken out and put into little jars that were shaped in the forms of their Gods and entombed along with the preserved body. So, the entrails are the parts of the body that are placed in the storehouse along with the Pharaoh! Damnit, why can´t they always be this easy? :(.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　蔵: storehouse

Origin: You will need to refer back to frames 13 and 14 here for the special meaning of the two primitive elements that make up this character: flesh (part of the body) and brain. What the kanji says, if you look at it, is that the part of the body that keeps the brain in working order is the stomach. To keep the elements in proper order, when you write this kanji think of the brain as being "held up" by the flesh.
Mnemonic1: The rice field is harvested once a month to get food for our stomach.
Mnemonic2: The stomach is the part of the body that digests food (which, in Japan, is mainly rice).
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)

Origin: A fire belongs IN the hearth, not OVER it. When the fire spreads to the rest of the house, we have an inflamed house. And as with any inflammation - including those that attack our bodies - the danger is always that it might spread if not checked. This is the sense behind the reduplication of element for fire, one atop the other.
Mnemonic1: To fight fire with fire would just inflame a situation.
Mnemonic2: An inflammation can often feel like FIRE upon FIRE burning.
Compo: 火: fire (灬)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: In almost every attempt to discuss an issue, the fervor of one's convictions comes to the surface and creates an inflammation of words (if you will, the "cuss" in discuss).
Mnemonic1: Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone´s words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words.
Mnemonic2: Internet discussions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!
Compo: 言: word; say　炎: inflammation

Origin: The primitives in this kanji read: water . . . inflammation. Taking inflammation in its medical sense, the first water-related inflammation that pops into mind is dehydration, the principal symptom of which is that it makes one shrivel up and look very, very thin. If that is hard to remember, try thinking it backwards: a very thin chap passes by and you imagine him suffering from (being inflamed with) dehydration (hence the element for water).
Mnemonic1: Drink water and burn twice as many calories as you eat... you´ll definitely get thin. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being burned from above and below... THAT´s what it takes to become thin.
Mnemonic2: Thin girls are twice as hot when they´re wet.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　炎: inflammation

Origin: Of all of nature's disasters, this kanji picks out two of the worst: floods and fires. To recall the disposition of the elements, think of nature's solution to nature's own problem: a great flood pouring down over a great forest fire.
Mnemonic1: What a disaster! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs.
Mnemonic2: Don´t know about Japan, but here in Australia, flooding rivers and bushfires are the most common natural disasters.
Compo: 巛: river (川); flood (RTK)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: Part of the body . . . dry.
Mnemonic1: Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).
Mnemonic2: The slaughterhouse prefers to ship dried liver to the supermarkets (can you imagine boxes soaked in blood on the truck that delivers them?). Imagine them lifting the slabs of flesh and hanging them on the clothesline to dry.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　干: dry

Origin: One is surprised, strolling through the market, to find among the meats hung out for sale a slab marked: lungs.
Mnemonic1: LUNGS are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET.
Mnemonic2: The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your LUNGS so that you can shout out at the top of your voice "IRASSHAIMASEEE" to attract customers.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　市: market; city; town

Origin: The pieces in this character should be easily recognizable: on the left, the element for part of the body, and on the right, the character for nightbreak, which we have just met. What all of this has to do with the gall bladder is not immediately clear. But all we need to do is give a slight twist to the traditional biblical advice about not letting the sun set on your anger (which ancient medicine associated with the choler or bile that the gall bladder is supposed to filter out), and change it to "not letting the night break on your anger" (or your gall) - and the work of remembering the kanji is done. And the improvement is not a bad piece of advice in its own right, since anger, like so many other things, can often be calmed by letting the sun set on it and then "sleeping it off."
Mnemonic1: The moon has a lot of gall sticking around after sunrise.
Mnemonic2: All the month long I have to start working at nightbreak. This really activates my gall bladder (=I get angry).
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　旦: dawn; nightbreak (RTK)

Origin: Dig into your flesh and pull out a lymph gland. Now give it a squeeze and watch the spring of lymph spout out of it.
Mnemonic1: A body part that acts like a spring for hormones is a gland.
Mnemonic2: When adrenaline glands release hormones, the body springs into action.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　泉: spring

Origin: Part of the body . . . wrap.
Mnemonic1: Imagine a newborn baby, fresh out of the womb, being entirely wrapped by the long piece of flesh, called a placenta, that once fed him.
Mnemonic2: Placenta is flesh/part of the body wrapped around the foetus.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　包: wrap

Origin: Flesh . . . piggy bank.
Mnemonic1: Intestines are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks. Just imagine factory workers scraping out the intestines of real piglets and packaging them up for little children.
Mnemonic2: Taking things too literally, you used a real piglet as a piggy bank. Now when you smash it open to get your coins out, you have to dig out your coins from its intestines. ew.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　昜: open; sun; piggy bank (RTK)

Origin: Part of the body . . . pedestal.
Mnemonic1: The body part feminists like to put on a pedestal is the womb, especially when they hear a man complain about some responsibility. "We give birth, so it´s your duty to do so-and-so".
Mnemonic2: If any body part deserves to be put on a pedestal, it is the womb from which new life springs forth.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　台: pedestal

Origin: Part of the body . . . need.
Mnemonic1: If you want to get closer to the actual meaning, then I think that 腰(こし) is more like the hips or the small of the back. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It´s the part of the body that needs massaging.
Mnemonic2: To the puritans reading this site - please stop reporting stories that have anything to do with sex! Although (as wrightak said) this kanji really refers to the hips, Heisig clearly chose the keyword ´loins´ because it was anatomically close enough, and the primitives lent themselves to an easy-to-remember story. Just because you´re all sexually repressed doesn´t mean other people won´t benefit from a story such as "the part of the body people need more than any other are the loins".
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　要: need

Origin: Instead of the familiar "grease" we usually associate with the elbow of someone hard at work, the kanji gives us a part of the body that has been glued to its task.
Mnemonic1: Sometimes I get carried away and do elbow curls until the point where my forearm snaps off! When that happens I simply pull out the glue and re-attach the elbow to my flesh.
Mnemonic2: Picture two Siamese twins glued together at the elbow.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Flesh . . . tree . . . umbrella . . . rice grains.
Mnemonic1: Before lacquer (#932) was made with water, it was made by draining this body part of fluid: the knee!
Mnemonic2: Back in ancient Japan, people didn´t have knee pads for things like rollerblading and such (what, come on. Ninjas on rollerblades. Ultimate 90s flashback). Instead, they would simply dip their knees in laquer, and wait until it dried (hence the flesh, and the abscence of any drops of water). Unfortunately, this meant that you would have to wait about 30 minutes after deciding to go rollerblade until you could actually do it (took some time to dry) - and removing it was a serious pain.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　木: tree; wood　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Flesh . . . missile.
Mnemonic1: Where´s my flesh missile? Between my thighs, naturally...
Mnemonic2: My thigh is the part of the body that my missile smacks against.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　殳: lance, missile (RTK)

Origin: Part of the body . . . branch.
Mnemonic1: The limbs that this kanji represents are parts of the body that are connected to the trunk, like the main branches to a tree (“arms and legs” is the second meaning of this kanji). In other words, limbs are "flesh branches".
Mnemonic2: Limbs are body parts that branch off.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　支: branch

Origin: The word trunk refers to the part of the body that is left when you have "truncated" all the limbs. I can hardly think of any reason for doing so, unless one were lumberjacking corpses and needed to have them all properly pruned and made the same so they could be floated downstream without causing a body-jam.
Mnemonic1: A trunk, a trunk // The body of a monk // The body of a monk in a trunk, a trunk.
Mnemonic2: Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. Yes, I´m appalled at how gruesome this story is too.
Compo: 月: moon; month　同: same; equal; monk (RTK)

Origin: Part of the body . . . muscles (three of which give us "triceps" or "muscles on top of muscles"). You will want to keep the kanji distinct from the one that follows by paying attention to the positioning of the elements.
Mnemonic1: What part of the body has a very, very, very powerful smell? The armpit, of course!
Mnemonic2: (no important on yomi) The part of Conan´s body that is three times more effective at defeating foes than his muscles are his stinky ARMPITs. (Note: Typically, when the flesh primitive is on the left side it refers to a body part - this helps distinguish in from threaten (#871)].
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: This kanji tells us that if you feed the flesh with too many delicious things, it soon picks up a thick layer of fat.
Mnemonic1: Every chef will tell you, fat is what make the meat taste delicious.
Mnemonic2: Fat is the most delicious part of the flesh. (Note this refers to physical fat, not the concept of obesity obese (#494)).
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　旨: delicious

Origin: Here you "savor your words" as something delicious when you describe your recent visit to a shrine or pilgrimage site.
Mnemonic1: To fat, effete Japanophiles (cheerily munching on 肉まん in the back of the tour bus) hearing the words of the tour guide "Now we will visit a shrine" elicits squeals of joy. "Oooooh, how absolutely delicious!".
Mnemonic2: You visit a shrine to say your wishes and offer delicious offering to the gods.
Compo: 言: word; say　旨: delicious
Kunyomi: もう.で, もうで, もう.でる
Ex1English: One's first visit to a temple (shrine] in the new year

Origin: If you eat too much, you may need a compass to find your way around the obese mass of flesh that piles up in the midsection. Compare this with your stories for round (Frame 44) and fat (Frame 494), similar in meaning but distinct in imagery.
Mnemonic1: Flesh in all directions = obese.
Mnemonic2: Yo momma so obese, she changed the direction of the moon.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　方: direction; compass (RTK)

Origin: Ever notice how the texture of your face and hands is affected by the wind? A day's skiing or sailing makes them rough and dry, and in need of a good soft cream to soothe the burn.
