So whenever a part of the body gets exposed to the wind, its texture is affected. (If it is any help, the Latin word hiding inside texture connotes how something is "to the touch.")
Mnemonic1: When you expose your flesh to the wind it gets textured: goosebumps!
Mnemonic2: The moon´s lack of wind preserves its texture.
Compo: 肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　几: table; wind (RTK)

Origin: Tiger . . . stomach.
Mnemonic1: Ending up in a tiger´s stomach is not good for your skin, as it´s full of stomach acids.
Mnemonic2: They say, "there's more than one way to skin a cat", but if you try to skin a tiger you might end up in its stomach.
Compo: 虍: tiger　胃: stomach

Origin: Tiger . . . think.
Mnemonic1: Real meaning: "to ponder". You have to think with prudence (ponder carefully) about approaching a tiger, as is evident from 虎.
Mnemonic2: You have to think with prudence about approaching a tiger. If not, it will eat your brains and heart. Thanks raulir.
Compo: 虍: tiger　思: think

Origin: Tiger . . . box with a one in it (or a backwards broom, if that makes it easier).

Mnemonic2: The "E" shape actually means claws here, and the real etymology is a tiger tyrannizing other animals with its claws (the etymologies actually make sense once in a blue moon!). I think of the claws here as two hooks, representing the front paws. (stroke order of that part: 二＋last of 直).
Compo: 虍: tiger　匚: box; hook (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)

Origin: Tiger . . . give.
Mnemonic1: I feel a sense of uneasiness about giving this HUGE tiger a steak.
Mnemonic2: My dear friend, a Bengali merchant, gave me a tiger as a birthday present. I felt uneasiness, knowing that I´ll have to reject it. Or was it horror?
Compo: 虍: tiger　呉: give (RTK)

Origin: Tiger . . . sow . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: There would be a lot of drama if a tiger tried to eat a sow but then the sow attacked it with a saber.
Mnemonic2: A great Indian drama acted out every year is how a poor Bengali boy fended off the tigers from his pigs using only a sabre.
Compo: 虍: tiger　豕: pig; sow (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Tigers . . . row.
Mnemonic1: In Japanese folklore there is no hell, but there is the void. There, a row of tigers waits in the blackness to devour those souls who have failed in their spiritual life.
Mnemonic2: Warning to Sigfreid and Roy: Your entertainment contract will be null and void unless you can make all the tigers stand in a row.
Compo: 虍: tiger　並: average; row (RTK)

Origin: Tiger . . . man.
Mnemonic1: Captive men are thrown to the tigers. I think you can imagine something else is done to captive women...
Mnemonic2: Tip: To avoid confusing keyword captive with captured (#1018) note that captive contains "ti" for tiger.
Compo: 虍: tiger　男: male

Origin: Chop-seal . . . man.
Mnemonic1: I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young man has to show his courage. They then receive a chopseal which is a mark of their courage.
Mnemonic2: Re: fuaburisu - The initiation rite in question is actually a reverse elbow chop to the brain, and you receive the chop seal if you have the power to withstand it. This initial imagery helps me with the altered chop seal and vertical placement.
Compo: マ: ma; chop-seal (RTK)　男: male
Ex3English: Be encouraged, be in high spirits

Origin: Water . . . courage.
Mnemonic1: The courageous man who went into the water to save a drowning victim couldn´t be seen, except by the air that bubbled up.
Mnemonic2: Bubble up the WATER and see who has the COURAGE to jump into it.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　勇: courage

Origin: Void . . . fiesta.
Mnemonic1: This is a story about the end of the universe. The universe is turning into a featureless void. There´s nothing we can do about it except for throw a fiesta and frolic a little bit before it´s all over.
Mnemonic2: Sigfreid and Roy´s contract having been voided, the tiger is free to frolic about at the fiesta.
Compo: 虚: hollow; void (RTK)　戈: pike; fiesta (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . Thanksgiving . . . row.
Mnemonic1: At the end of Thanksgiving it's tradition for everyone to stand in a row and measure their waist with a strip of thread. Whoever is the most slender wins the leftovers.
Mnemonic2: At the time of Thanksgiving, there´s a row of all sorts of food on the table, which you mustn´t eat if you want to stay as slender as a thread.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)</br𢦏: thanksgiving (RTK)　业: spikes

Origin: The key word should be taken to mean minute, detailed, or nuanced. Its primitive elements are: thread . . . doth.
Mnemonic1: THREAD, DOTH. fine THREADS DOTH make fine cloth. Think of a Shakespearean character stating this to someone else. Picture fine threads on one side of the picture and an aftershot of a fine cloth.
Mnemonic2: fine: If the thread doth fit through the eye of the needle, it is fine thread indeed.

口: mouth　尊: honor

Origin: Wooden leg . . . gigantic.

Mnemonic2: You can step a long-distance if you have gigantic wooden legs (stilts).
Compo: 足: leg; wooden leg (⻊) (RTK)　巨: giant

Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　巨: giant

Origin: The full kanji for the drum adds a branch, apparently to serve as a drumstick, to the primitive for drum.

Mnemonic2: I really hate the primitive meaning of "table" for "bean." I just use "bean." Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: "DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH".

STORY: "If a PART OF your BODY begins to SWELL/EXPAND and resembles the SHAPE of a bass DRUM, you’re either pregnant or in desperate need of a diet.".

Mnemonic2: There is a horse chestnut tree that has grown by a cliff for so long, it has deposited 10,000 horse chesnuts that lie at the bottom. Don´t worry over this one too much, you´ll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won´t forget it.

Origin: Earlier we made mention of the story of Briar Rose (or "Sleeping Beauty," as we called her in frame 165) and drew attention to the briar hedge that grew up all about her castle. But in the second part of the story, these briars blossomed into flowers. Hence her name, Briar Rose. Be careful not to confuse this character with that for thorn (Frame 446).
Mnemonic1: To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them.

Origin: Sheep . . . water . . . yawn/lack. Although this character looks rather simple, special care should be taken in learning it because of the proximity of the final two elements to the character for next, which we learned in frame 510. Note, too, that the water comes UNDER the sheep, rather than on its own to the left.
Mnemonic1: A very thirsty sheep, who always lacked water, spends his days watching his fellow sheep (in the farm next door or in another pen) and being very envious of their water.

He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team). You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...
Compo: 上: above; up　小: little; owl (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)

Compo: 孫: grandchild　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: This is not a turtle (See frame 250) but a tortoise, however you wish to picture the difference. Let the "bound up" at the to prefer to the head, and the two suns, with a long tail running through it, to the shell.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated to its bottom half, ⻲, and comes to mean eel. (If it is any help, this kanji in its full form can also be remembered through its abbreviation's primitive meaning.)
Mnemonic1: It seems bizarre, but tortoises are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.
Mnemonic2: A tortoise is prosperity bound up with a tail. They are very lucky creatures.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　日: day; sun　电: electricity, eel (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . east.
Mnemonic1: You practice your Japanese skills in a discussion thread with lots of people from the Far East (since many of the people who are interested in studying Japanese are Asian).
Mnemonic2: Spidey stays on the east side of the city to practice. The West Side is too dangerous.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　東: east

Mnemonic1: In the East, especially Japan ...there are masters of tempering metal to great strength....on the Spring of Trivia show in Japan I saw how a Japanese sword ...actually split flying bullets...all because of special Eastern tempering techniques.
Mnemonic2: Tempering should be done with the metal facing east. (If not, the metal may pick up the earth´s magnetic field).
Compo: 金: gold; metal　東: east

Origin: Metal . . . grade.
Mnemonic1: As a discriminating metalsmith, I use the highest grade metals when forging such precision devices as staple guns and missiles.
Mnemonic2: Metal has to be forged many times over in order to reach a high grade.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　段: step; grade

Origin: Metal . . . wide.
Mnemonic1: Elbonium: a new mineral found in wide caves shaped like elbows and made of metal.
Mnemonic2: A wide range of metals are classed as minerals.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　広: wide

Origin: Picture an order of monks serving as chaplains for the police force. Their special habit, made of protective metal, is distinguished by a row of copper buttons just like the "cops" they serve.
Mnemonic1: I can´t believe no one has used this one yet: Copper is metal which looks almost the same as gold. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it´s yellow and it´s shiny (atleast in some compounds)!
Mnemonic2: Copper is an excellent conductor. In other words, it´s a metal for which the voltage is the same everywhere. That´s why it´s used for wires.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　同: same; equal; monk (RTK)

Origin: Metal . . . gully.
Mnemonic1: Picture the molten lead (the heavy metal) being discreetly drained out of the factory into a gully behind.
Mnemonic2: Lead -> Dental fillings -> Metal that enters the mouth to fill a hole in a tooth.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　㕣: marsh, gully (RTK)

Origin: Pig iron refers to iron in the crude form in which it emerges from the smelting furnaces. Of all the various forms metal can take, this one shows us metal before it has been refined. Imagine two photographs labeled "before" and "after" to show the process.
Mnemonic1: Pig iron is basic/crude metal, that is, before it has been processed.
Mnemonic2: Pig-iron is crude metal (金) before (先) it is refined. If you have trouble with this character, envision a big minotaur (cow head with human legs) as a blacksmith, smelting metals and making swords for war.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　先: before; ahead

Origin: Metal . . . Mount.
Mnemonic1: Mount Fuji is completely made up of a metal known as steel.
Mnemonic2: Ancient shamans predicted a time when there would be Mounts made of metal. The steel skyscrapers of today…
Compo: 金: gold; metal　岡: mount

Origin: Mount . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: Mount everest is very sturdy, you can hit it all day with a saber and it wont even wobble.
Mnemonic2: Anything sturdy in Japan is associated with Mount Fuji. Perhaps this is because it´s symmetry is believed to make it rather sturdy itself, unlike all those crooked mountains that are around and tend to fall apart (think rock slides, avalanches, etc.). Here we see Sturdy-brand sabers with Mount Fuji engraved on the blade.
Compo: 岡: mount　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Thread . . . Mount.
Mnemonic1: A sturdy thread is equally obviously hawser (heavy rope). (see previous frame).
Mnemonic2: Spiderman saves Japan from floating away by tying Mt. Fuji to mainland Asia using a hawser made of web.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　岡: mount

Origin: Thread . . . glass canopy . . . animal horns . . . perish.
Mnemonic1: Spiderman traps The Rhino under the hood of his famous netting, where even Rhino´s horns can not break free, in fact if the netting did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even perish in there.
Mnemonic2: You use a 糸 to make a net shaped like a hood. A stray animal got caught in it by its horns and perished.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　丷: animal horns (RTK)　亡: deceased; perish

Origin: Thread . . . eels.
Mnemonic1: The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that´s left of the rope are some torn threads, and the unbound tortoise is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not "eels". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in waterfall (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as "eels". It is much better to call the right half of this character an "unbound tortoise".).
Mnemonic2: When Spiderman fights the giant tortoise, he grabs a straw rope from the edges of the sumo ring and swings it at his head. However, the tortoise quickly tucks his head back into his shell to avoid the blow (hence no head on the tortoise).
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　日: day; sun　电: electricity, eel (RTK)

Origin: Let bowl suggest a large and heavy golden bowl into which you are throwing all the books you own to mash them into pulp, for some outrageous reason you will have to think up yourself.
Mnemonic1: This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book?
Mnemonic2: If I was begging with a BOWL, I would want GOLD and BOOKS.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　本: book

Origin: Metal . . . little . . . shells. We have saved this character until no win order to draw attention to the visual difference between the owl and little. By now your eyes should be so accustomed to these apparently infinitesimal differences that the point is obvious.
Mnemonic1: The chain on this chainsaw is made of little metal shells.
Mnemonic2: A gold chain with small seashells hanging on it is in fashion these days.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　小: little; owl (RTK)　貝: shellfish; money, clam (RTK)
糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　半: half

Origin: The golden key you have been presented by the mayor gives you access to all the <i style="font-weight: bold; ">buildings in the city.
Mnemonic1: The metal thing you need in order to enter things you build is a key.
Mnemonic2: 鍵盤key (#2761) ケン, かぎ ... Parts: 金, 建 ... Story: The most important Metal in any building is the lock on the front door, and without a key you ain´t getting in. This kanji means both lock and key to most Japanese people. 錠前 is technically the word for lock but it´s not used in daily conversation. ... 熟語: ... cf: 錠前.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　建: build
金: gold; metal　丁: street; nail (RTK)

Origin: Metal . . . harden.
Mnemonic1: You weld metal in the knowledge that it will harden again.
Mnemonic2: By welding metal and then subjecting it to refrigeration, it will become very hard by the process known as annealing.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　固: harden

Origin: Metal of itself doesn't lock. It needs to be so determined by a locksmith. Now make a concrete image of that.
Mnemonic1: Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.
Mnemonic2: The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let´s try this one: My girlfriend wears a metal chastity belt with a lock but I am determined to open it! I must get inside!
Compo: 金: gold; metal　定: fix; determine

Origin: Thread . . . determine.
Mnemonic1: Even though his costume is coming apart at the seams as he chases the bad guys, Spiderman is still determined to catch them.
Mnemonic2: Spiderman´s costume has come apart at the seams and here he is, mending it in his house, determined to make it stronger than before.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　定: fix; determine
Ex1English: Come apart at the seams; unfold, bloom; break into a smile

Origin: Gold . . . orders.
Mnemonic1: Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers´ orders.
Mnemonic2: In high society, people ring a small golden bell to call their servants and give their orders.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　令: orders

Origin: This bell is made of cheap metal, and so badly made that when you ring it, it lets out a noise like the "bellowing" of juveniles who aren't getting their own way.
Mnemonic1: The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to class.
Mnemonic2: The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to COMPUTER class.
Compo: 金: gold; metal　童: juvenile; child

Origin: Begin with the double meaning of the key word pupil: "student" and the "the apple of one's eye." Now all you have to do is dwell on the phrase "juvenile of one's eye" (the meaning here) until it provides you with an image.
Mnemonic1: In Japanese comics, the eye´s of juvenilles all have enormouse pupils.
Mnemonic2: WARNING: This kanji only means the pupil of the eye. It can be confusing to use a story that has pupil meaning student in it.
Compo: 目: eye　童: juvenile; child

Origin: Think of the state of mind you were in as a child with a particularly juvenile yearning.
Mnemonic1: A paedophile´s state of mind is to yearn for juveniles.
Mnemonic2: A juvenile´s state of mind tends to go apeshit when they see something they yearn for. Usually involving jumping up and down, tantrums, and other bullshit. (Imagine giving them a big backhand across the face.).
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　童: juvenile; child
Ex2Kana: ゆうめいじんにあこがれる

Origin: State of mind . . . scenery.
Mnemonic1: My mind hankers for sunrise over the capital.
Mnemonic2: I'm in a state of mind where I hanker to see the sun over the capital for some nice scenery for a change (no more rain!)
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　景: scenery

Origin: A drop of . . . brains . . . cornucopia.
Mnemonic1: Lowly people only have a drop of brains and use nothing but 4-letter words.
Mnemonic2: A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　丿: katakana no　十: ten; cross; needle (RTK)
Kunyomi: いや.しい, いや.しむ, いや.しめる

Origin: Rock . . . lowly.
Mnemonic1: There is a grave of a lowly man with a tombstone made of a simple, small stone. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”.
Mnemonic2: A STONE makes a LOWLY TOMBSTONE.
Compo: 石: stone; rock (RTK)　卑: lowly
疒: sickness　卑: lowly

Origin: Drop of . . . brains . . . human legs . . . elbow.
Mnemonic1: 鬼(おに) is not a ghost. An ogre or a troll would be a more fitting translation. Such a thing has but a drop of brains and uses its legs and elbows as deadly weapons (a concept which should be familiar from the license (#765) to kill). I'll use "ogre" for this.
Mnemonic2: A ghost, or oni, wandering slowly on its human legs, searching for brains to eat. What looks like an elbow here is actually a pictoral representation of the forked tail protruding out of its rear.
Compo: 丿: katakana no　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　儿: human legs　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: Soil . . . ghost.
Mnemonic1: Without any weapons, our only defense was to throw clods of dirt at the advancing oni horde. (Adapted from dingomick because zombie was used as a primitive for drag+rag).
Mnemonic2: All too often I find myself vaccuming clods of dirt with my Dirt Devil.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　鬼: ghost; devil

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . ghost.
Mnemonic1: The ugly oni can´t get a date so he drinks sake by himself at the bar.
Mnemonic2: Drinking too much whisky can make you as ugly as an oni.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　鬼: ghost; devil

Origin: Rising cloud of . . . ghosts.
Mnemonic1: When you die, your SOUL either goes to the RISING CLOUDS (heaven) or to the ONI (hell, the devil).
Mnemonic2: When we die, our soul rises up in a ghostlike rising cloud of mist up to heaven (we hope) (Adapted from darg_sama,28-10-2005).
Compo: 云: say; rising cloud (RTK)　鬼: ghost; devil

Origin: Ghost . . . not yet.
Mnemonic1: Ghosts have not yet left the world, they must still have a deep fascination with their past life on Earth.
Mnemonic2: Here the "Ghostbusters" founder talks about his fascination for ghosts (picture Dan Arkroyd in the movie if that helps). He says he has a fascination for ghosts ever since he saw one as a teenager. Since then he´s been scouring all of the world, trying to capture them on tape, on video... A journalist asks "When will it end ? Aren´t you tired of chasing ghosts ?" "Oh no, not yet ! Not until I become a ghost myself anyway !".
Compo: 鬼: ghost; devil　未: not yet

Origin: Hemp . . . ghost. Take care not to confuse with the primitive of the same name we learned earlier (Frame 458).
Mnemonic1: This modern version of the witch lives in some hippie community. She smokes a lot of hemp, and spends the day talking to ghosts, which not surprisingly appears only to her.
Mnemonic2: The witch sold me some hemp that made me see ghosts don´t do drugs.
Compo: 麻: hemp　鬼: ghost; devil

Origin: Field . . . hairpin.
Mnemonic1: The girl was apprehensive about going home, having lost her precious hairpin in the paddy field. But then, it wasn't like she'd lost both, just ONE...
Mnemonic2: I ran out of Q-tips...then I noticed a hairpin lying on the counter that was about the same size as a Q-tip. I was apprehensive at first, but I thought "what the hell". Unfortunately I ended up stabbing my brain!
Compo: 田: rice field; brain (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　𧘇: clothers; scarf (RTK)

Origin: Flag . . . towel . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it.
Mnemonic2: The image that keeps coming to me is of the giant mechanical printing presses. The cloth-based material is coming off the roll like a flag and then, after printing, gets cut into sheets by saber-like cutting tools.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　巾: towel　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Fingers . . . guess.
Mnemonic1: If you mis-guess the cheese you´ll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).
Mnemonic2: Ouch! Guess how many fingers I just grated in the grater? (Edit: OR: Ouch! Guess what I just grated in the grater? -- my finger!).
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　察: police; guess (RTK)
Ex3English: Pass by each other, brush past

Origin: Hemp . . . hand.
Mnemonic1: If you grind the hemp without a stone but use your hand instead it will chafe. (Image: "Robin, why are your hands all chafed?" ´Uh... (I´ve been grinding hemp all day)´).
Mnemonic2: When the feds came to bust your little hemp grove, you jumped out the back side of the cave and tried to repel down with a hemp rope. Unfortunately, the rope chafed your hands and you fell .. ouch!
Compo: 麻: hemp　手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)

Origin: Hemp . . . stone.
Mnemonic1: If you grind the hemp you are bound to get stoned quicker.
Mnemonic2: You must GRIND the HEMP collected in the grove by your cave on solid STONE to make the best ropes.
Compo: 麻: hemp　石: stone; rock (RTK)
Ex2English: Grind, polish; study hard, brush up

Origin: You couldn't have asked for a better key word for this kanji! Just have a look at it: a perfect image of a concave lens (remembering, of course, that the kanji square off rounded things), complete with its own little "cave." Now all you have to do is learn how to write it.
Mnemonic1: The letter "U" is concavely written.
Mnemonic2: Concave has a concave shape.
Compo: 凹: concave

Origin: Maybe this helps you see how the Japanese have no trouble keeping convex distinct from concave. Note the odd feeling of the third stroke. If it doesn't feel all that strange now, by the time you are done with this book, it will. There are very few times you will have to write it.
Mnemonic1: When I get vexed, I give people the middle finger.
Mnemonic2: Convex has a convex shape.
Compo: 凸: convex

Origin: Bonsai . . . cornstalk. Use a ritualistic, religious meaning.
Mnemonic1: To join the temple, you have to dedicate yourself to raising bonsai for enlightenment, and cornstalks for sustenance.
Mnemonic2: A Japanese farmer who was growing corn tried to dedicate himself to the god of corn (in the hope it would bring better harvests). He had a little room with prayer beads, incense, etc. One day he brought an offerand that he thought would please the god of corn : a bonsai - corn (a corn plant turned into a bonsai). The god was infuriated and yelled at him "HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!". The End.
Compo: 𡗗: bonsai (RTK)　二: two　丨: line; stick

Origin: Bonsai . . . heavens.
Mnemonic1: When you play music to them, your bonsai will grow like they are in heaven.
Mnemonic2: In heaven you are surrounded by bonsai trees (full-sized ones fall through the clouds) while you play music on your harp. I always have trouble remembering that the bonsai tree is on top, so think of them growing on top of the clouds.
Compo: 𡗗: bonsai (RTK)　天: heavens; sky

Origin: Bonsai . . . rice grains.
Mnemonic1: If you look into Japanese gardens they seem so peaceful - with their small bonsais and the white stones looking like rice grains.
Mnemonic2: Simplistic and peaceful life: A bonsai to trim and enough rice to eat…
Compo: 𡗗: bonsai (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Person . . . dedicate.
Mnemonic1: The stipend is given to the student-PERSON who has come to Japan DEDICATED to study.
Mnemonic2: People who are highly dedicated to their jobs get good salaries/stipends.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　奉: dedicate

Origin: Tree . . . dedicate.
Mnemonic1: This wooden rod has one very simple dedication engraved on it: "Spare the rod, spoil the child...".
Mnemonic2: The wood from this tree is dedicated to making rods to flog naughty kids.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　奉: dedicate
手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　奉: dedicate

Origin: The key word is a suffix used to indicate "safe from" or "protected against," as in the words rustproof, waterproof, and fireproof. It is composed of: comb . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: (akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself.
Mnemonic2: I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.
Compo: 而: however; comb 　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Rain . . . two . . . row. This character will refer only to the inhabitants of the "spirit world," and not to moods or temperaments, for which we will learn another character in frame 2030.
Mnemonic1: After raining for two days in a row, you plead with the SPIRITS for some relief. (Adapted from johnskb,21-5-2006).
Mnemonic2: When it rains, two worlds come together and spirits can be seen in the forest, dancing in a row.
Compo: 雨: rain　二: two　业: spikes
Ex2English: Sending off the spirits of the dead

Origin: The sense of demand is best captured by thinking of the economic principle of "supply and demand." The primitives: rain . . . comb.
Mnemonic1: Supply and demand is a simple concept: when it rains, the demand for combs goes up to deal with wet hair.
Mnemonic2: If it´s raining combs, then the demand for them sure does drop.
Compo: 雨: rain　而: however; comb
水: water (氵) (氺)　需: demand

Origin: Person . . . demand.
Mnemonic1: No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it´s raining combs!".
Mnemonic2: One day, Mr. T started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a Confucian scholar. He was suddenly in high demand as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, "You will find happiness with a new love".
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　需: demand

Origin: Vase . . . mountain . . . comb.
Mnemonic1: Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is standing at the edge of a sheer mountain face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn´t seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly.
Mnemonic2: When you stand a comb on its edge, it looks like the mountain (#768) kanji.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　山: mountain　而: however; comb
Kunyomi: はし, は, はた, -ばた

Origin: The Roman numeral I - like that for II we met earlier in frame 379 - is only rarely used now. In the midst of all the samurai, we notice one in particular sitting on the ground with a crown on his head, indicating that he is "number I" in the current rankings.
Mnemonic1: I am ´the one´ , says the samurai with the crown around his waist and a spoon up his a***.
Mnemonic2: The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　冖: crown 　匕: spoon

Origin: Flag . . . spoon.
Mnemonic1: Red cross nuns sit in a tent under the red cross flag, spooning out food to the hungry.
Mnemonic2: A nun sits in protests under an American flag.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　匕: spoon

Origin: Water . . . nun.
Mnemonic1: TV gets weirder and weirder... Now they´re doing mud wrestling shows with nuns splashing around in the water. What will they think of next?
Mnemonic2: Water monks live in a den, but water nuns live in the MUD.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　尼: nun

Origin: Water . . . flag . . . rain.
Mnemonic1: WATER always LEAKED in the spot left by the FLAG planted in the roof everytime it RAINED. Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water.
Mnemonic2: Mark the holes where rain water can leak through with little flags.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　雨: rain
Kunyomi: も.る, も.れる, も.らす

Origin: Water . . . fingerprint.
Mnemonic1: It´s a widespread belief that they cannot find fingerprints on a body that has been deposited in the water.
Mnemonic2: It´s a widespread belief that water takes away fingerprints.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　卩: seal; stamp; (㔾) fingerprint (RTK)

Origin: The top primitive of this character is actually an old form of broom. The remaining elements are: crown . . . fruit.
Mnemonic1: People who read the glossary are mutually exclusive (exclude the top line of mutually (#757) ) from those who eat crowned fruit イ はりねずみ same kind 語彙.
Mnemonic2: I was having mutual difficulties in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the crown and I was the one picking the fruit. In order to fix the problem I checked the glossary for "mutual difficulties" but found nothing. I guess we´re going to have to mutually end our relationship.
Compo: ヨ: broom (RTK)　冖: crown 　果: fruit

Origin: The key word here refers to the adjective for an unspecified person or thing. Its elements: wicker basket . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: I had the same idea as fuabrisu. A generic person is described here as having body sort of like a tree trunk and head sort of like a wicker basket.
Mnemonic2: Two girls with a lollipop in a tree gossiping´ so-and so did this.´ ´really? so-and what did she do´ ´ o she is sooo wrong..´.
Compo: 甘: sweet; wicker basket (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Words . . . so-and-so.
Mnemonic1: I imagine a clique of catty girls conspiring against a another girl...they are exchanging lots of words, chatting about how so-and-so girl is now up to such-and-such (gasp!), and how they will spread the word about it.
Mnemonic2: You might hear the words of someone conspiring... "If you do so-and-so...".
Compo: 言: word; say　某: so-and-so

Origin: Woman . . . so-and-so.
Mnemonic1: The woman 女 hoped her friend would act as mediator to set her up with the guy she liked. She didn't mention his name, just referred to him as "A certain unnamed person -- I'll call him 'Mr. So-and-So 某' ...."
Mnemonic2: The two little gossiping girls with their lollipops are having a fight. Now an adult woman (mom or teacher) has to come between them an serve as a mediator.
Compo: 女: woman　某: so-and-so

Origin: Flag . . . altar . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: Of course it had to be the military officer´s idea to glue a national flag to the altar he´s stationed at.
Mnemonic2: Perhaps you have heard about Koizumis controversial visits at the Yasukuni war memorial shrine. It is the japanese flag waving above a small stone altar. A military officer keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground.
Compo: 尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　示: altar; show (礻)　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Military officer . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men.
Mnemonic2: This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II "comfort women" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.).
Compo: 尉: inspector; military officer (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: なぐさ.める, なぐさ.む
Ex2English: Comforting the spirits of the dead

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . each.
Mnemonic1: Imagine if at each supermarket you went to, the section for dairy products was next to the alcohol aisle. so for each wheel of cheese you decide to buy, you get an accompanying bottle of wine...perfect for a "wine & cheese" party. :).
Mnemonic2: In an attempt to increase sales of dairy products, the grocery store is giving away a free miniature whiskey bottle with each dairy product you buy.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　各: each; every

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . filial piety.
Mnemonic1: The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.
Mnemonic2: Since filial piety is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a whiskey bottle is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn´t, sink back some whiskey and it will.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　孝: filial piety
将: leader　酉: alcohol

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . saw.
Mnemonic1: Drinking alcohol that´s turned to vinegar feels like a saw going down your throat.
Mnemonic2: I spent ages sawing that whiskey bottle open, but when I got in, it had all turned to vinegar!
Compo: 酉: alcohol　乍: peg holes, staple gun (RTK); saw (RTK)
Ex2English: <ponzu> (sauce made from soy sauce and citrus juice)

Origin: This kanji is used for thick, low-grade saké made from various kinds of grains. Its primitives are: whisky bottle . . . glue.
Mnemonic1: While the keyword is "hooch", this usually means 焼酎. It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated.
Mnemonic2: This thick, illicitly-made beverage is actually just whiskey mixed with glue!
Compo: 酉: alcohol　寸: measurement; glue (RTK)

Origin: Whiskey bottle . . . ladle.
Mnemonic1: At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl.
Mnemonic2: Ever seen the anime Bartender? Bartending isn´t just about bottles of whiskey, it´s about ladling out advice.
Compo: 酉: alcohol　勺: ladle

Origin: The character we learned for fishing (Frame 184) refers to the professional, net-casting industry, while the angling of this character refers to the sport. The odd thing is that your angling rod is a golden ladle which you are using to scoop goldfish out of a river.
Mnemonic1: All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I´m a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I´m a true ANGLING professional.
Mnemonic2: Imagine an effeminate Roman 2000 years ago angling with a golden ladle instead of a rod because it matches his eyes and hair better and it impresses the boys. (Why a Roman? Because ´angling´ is just the roman-derived way to say ´fishing´ - use this to distinguish fishing from angling.).
Compo: 金: gold; metal　勺: ladle
Kunyomi: つ.る, つ.り, つ.り-

Origin: Mysterious . . . rice field.
Mnemonic1: The livestock are disappearing! I´ve placed Gandalf over the rice field to protect them.
Mnemonic2: This mysterious rice field grows not only rice, but livestock too! Picture little pigs and chickens growing right out of the ground, among the rice plants. How bizarre!
Compo: 玄: mysterious　田: rice field; brain (RTK)

Origin: Flowers . . . livestock.
Mnemonic1: One sneaky farmer wanted to amass a large collection of livestock. We all know that cows like to eat flowers, so he planted lines of flowers leading to his own fields. The livestock followed the lines, eating the flowers one by one, and amassed in his field.
Mnemonic2: Kobe beef. The Japanese amass a fortune pampering livestock feeding them flowers, offering beer, playing music and giving them massages…
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　畜: livestock
Ex1Kana: ねんりょうをたくわえる

Origin: Top hat . . . cocoon.
Mnemonic1: What could be more mysterious than a cocoon in a top hat trying to sneak in...? (Pimitive: GANDALF).
Mnemonic2: The invisible man in his top hat and cocoon of white bandages is the most mysterious man in the world.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)
目: eye　玄: mysterious
Kunyomi: くるめ.く, まぶ.しい, まばゆ.い

Compo: 口: mouth　聶: whisper
口: mouth　世: generation; world　木: tree; wood
口: mouth　兪: steal

Origin:
Learning this character will take a little doing. Before we start, it is a good idea to keep the key word distinct from melancholy (Frame 663), with which it combines to create the psychological condition of depression (a metaphor based on the hollow or sinking of the material depression we met in Frame 1421).
The picture of gloom begins with a small grove of trees, under which we see a crown made out of used tin cans. Next (the lower half of the kanji) we find a combination that appears only a few times in modern characters and only once in those treated in the volumes of Remembering the Kanji. It is composed of a shovel with a sheaf dotted with small drops on all sides. Think of it as a large scoop shovel attached to the front of a bulldozer, whose driver is singing: ♪ "Bulldozing in the sheaves, bulldozing in the sheaves..." ♪ The drops represent the chaff flying about as the sheaves are tossed about by the heavy machinery.
There is someone sitting on the ground alongside, watching as the machinery makes its way around the neighboring farmland - and it's you, wearing your tin-can crown. You feel overwhelmed by the impending doom as the invasion of agro-business draws closer and closer to the grove, the only patch of woods that remains of what once was a vast forest. The whole scene represents a re-shaping of the natural environment that brings the heavy weight of gloom down upon you.
A bit much, perhaps, but there are enough elements to allow for any number of other combinations.
Mnemonic1: The pixie, wearing a tin can crown, watches from the middle of the grove, the sparkling villain approach. She sits down in gloom wondering if she belongs amongst the trees, for she has never seen such a beautiful shape.
Mnemonic2: The context of gloom here refers to an environmental disaster that humans make. The story begins at a GROVE with TIN CANS shaped like CROWNS which are really soda cans. They belonged to workers who bulldozes (or SHOVELS) lots and lots of SHEAVES with DROPS of its pieces. Afar, a boy is SITTING while watching the workers reSHAPING the environment. His face now has a very gloomy expression.
Compo: 缶: can　木: tree; wood　木: tree; wood　冖: crown 　鬯: fragrant herbs　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

English: String (Of A Bow Or Musical Instrument)
Origin: Bow . . . mysterious.
Mnemonic1: A magic bow that only Gandalf can yield: there is no bowstring on it, and he uses his magic to fire arrows.
Mnemonic2: A bow with a mysterious invisible bowstring.
Compo: 弓: bow　玄: mysterious

Origin: Boat . . . mysterious.
Mnemonic1: The gunwale is perhaps the most mysterious part of a boat for it is neither a gun nor a whale.
Mnemonic2: Gunwale (rhymes with "tunnel") is the top edge of the side of a boat, for example the widened lip on the sides of a canoe. The mysterious origin of this part of a boat comes from the strengthened sides of warships that used artillery (it means "gun ridge").
Compo: 舟: boat　玄: mysterious
舟: boat　它: other

Origin: Cocoon . . . clothes hanger.
Mnemonic1: After the play, The Phantasm of the Opera hangs up his cape on a clothes hanger and returns to his cocoon to sleep.
Mnemonic2: You open your closet and find strange, glowing cocoons sitting on your clothes hangers... definitely a phantasm!
Compo: 幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　ヿ: enclosure; clothes hanger (RTK)

Origin: Two cocoons . . . mountain. Observe how the two vertical strokes of the mountain are extended upwards to serve as a kind of enclosure.
Mnemonic1: The villagers haven´t the faintest idea that giant coccoons resting in the mountain are soon to hatch.
Mnemonic2: Frodo and Sam fainted in the mountains and the spider wrapped them in cacoons.
Compo: 山: mountain　幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)

Origin: Cocoon . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: In its infancy, a butterfly is protected by a cocoon, as it doesn´t yet have any power of its own.
Mnemonic2: During their infancy, children are often wrapped up tight like a cocoon (i.e. in those Snugli carriers) and supported by the muscle of their parents.
Compo: 幺: short thread; cocoon (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Wheat . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: I can´t believe I brought you to the fanciest restaurant in town and you asked for turkey on wheat...how immature is that?!
Mnemonic2: Immature turkeys are stuffed with wheat to make it look bigger.
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Thread . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Hey, Spidey! Eat that turkey if you want, but make sure you eat some fibers: you want spidey threads, don´t ya?
Mnemonic2: If you want to increase your fiber intake, just leave on those threads that are used to sew up the stuffed turkey and eat them too.
Compo: 糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: In mathematics, a conjecture is a mathematical statement which has been proposed as a true statement, but which no one has yet been able to prove or disprove. Have you heard of the Finger-Turkey conjecture ? It states that if turkeys had fingers, they would be able to count. Be sure to imagine a turkey with fingers at the tip of its wings, counting from one to ten.
Mnemonic2: In the midst of conjecture on whether it was done or not, mom stuck her fingers in the turkey to check.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Soil . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: After our pre-Thanksgiving massacre, we piled high all the turkey corpses atop the soil of the farmyard.
Mnemonic2: During the Turkey Holocaust (this is what the animal kingdom calls Thanksgiving - they have really short memories and thus don´t recall that it actually happens every single year), turkeys are killed en masse, and their bodies are piled high. To keep them from tumbling down, a pile of dirt is piled high right next to them to keep them standing upright so that they will be fresh when it is time to eat them.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Why is the sweet oak so sweet? Not sure, but to me it tastes just like turkey (with gravy and cranberry sauce!) Now that is sweet.
Mnemonic2: Sweeter than Shiit~ake? Turkeys gobble Shiitake mushrooms椎茸 off the sweet oak tree. http://www.flickr.com/photos/tinyhare/13963627/.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: The spinal column has sprouted out of the flesh of your back into an umbrella that you always have with you, rain or shine. The pair of 2s on each side are the "ribs" of the umbrella. Take care to keep your image of the key word distinct from that for spine (Frame 24).
Mnemonic1: Look, says the teacher in biology class. "The spinal column holds your flesh together, just like the metal rod of this umbrella (he demonstrates this with an umbrella covered in I-Ching symbols) holds the umbrella together".
Mnemonic2: A pictograph of a spinal column. The umbrella representing the shoulder blades, the I Ching as the shoulder muscles and the part of the body as the spine itself.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　二: two　二: two　肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)
芻: grass cutting; hay　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: Do you remember that song where they say "Who let the turkeys out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble"?
Mnemonic2: (who; someone; somebody] You´re alone when, suddenly, you think you hear someone speaking. "Who´s there?", you say, but there is no answer. Then you find out it was only a turkey gobbling. You feel relieved (and ashamed to tell this story). (Based on raulir).
Compo: 言: word; say　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . turkey.
Mnemonic1: The mouth of a turkey is used solely for saying, "Gobble." Likewise, your mouth, full of turkey, is solely used to gobble it up.
Mnemonic2: Sadly my mouth gets to taste turkey solely on Christmas Day.
Compo: 口: mouth　隹: bird; turkey (RTK)

Origin: Mouth . . . bird.
Mnemonic1: A chirp is quite simply the sound that comes from the mouth of birds.
Mnemonic2: This kanji is not limited to the chirp of a bird, but stands for the sound of any kind of animal. Picture a very weird bird that can imitate with its mouth (a bird with mouth, heh) the voice of many different animals: Meeow! Woof! Mooo! Cuack!!! (Maybe the bird has Kirby powers and obtains the abilities of the animals it eats).
Compo: 口: mouth　鳥: bird
Kunyomi: な.く, な.る, な.らす

Origin: This kanji is the 12th sign of the Chinese zodiac: the sign of the hog. It is best learned by thinking of an acorn-eating hog in connection with the primitive meaning given below.
SubOrigin: The top hat represents the external shape of the acorn, and the unusual but easily written complex of strokes beneath it (which you might also see as distortions of an elbow and person) stands for the mysterious secret whereby the acorn contains the oak tree in a nutshell.
Mnemonic1: A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.
Mnemonic2: Top Hat + Elbow + Person: The sign of the hog was a very recognizable tattoo - a hog with a big grin in a top hat, sticking his elbow into the person next to him.
Compo: 亥: boar; acorn (RTK)

Origin: Acorn . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with sabres, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto acorns, and throw the acorns to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the acorn and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead.
Mnemonic2: While it´s traditional for lovers to engrave their names on a tree in many countries, in Japan, however, it was traditional for a samurai to signify his undying love for a woman by engraving the kanji of her name on an acorn with his sabre.
Compo: 亥: boar; acorn (RTK)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)
Ex1English: Cut fine; engrave, carve; (of a clock) tick away

Origin: Acorn . . . muscle.
Mnemonic1: Censure is the political equivalent of a "strongly worded letter," according to Cornell's School of Law. It is a flex of muscle by congress against the current president, but it is a very weak one. Imagine censure as congress flexing as hard as it can, only to have a little acorn-sized bump of muscle pop up suddenly.
Mnemonic2: Acorn Power is the people´s way to CENSURE a congressman you don´t agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today.
Compo: 亥: boar; acorn (RTK)　力: power; strength; muscles (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . acorn.
Mnemonic1: In the nucleus of the acorn, all the DNA is stored -- the building blocks for a new tree.
Mnemonic2: The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　亥: boar; acorn (RTK)

Origin: Skeleton . . . acorn.
Mnemonic1: The remains consisted of a skeleton which had the remains of some acorns in its stomach area. Whether it died from eating the acorns remains to be seen.
Mnemonic2: Hint: The remains of a chipmunk.
Compo: 骨: bone; skeleton (RTK)　亥: boar; acorn (RTK)
口: mouth　亥: boar; acorn (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . acorn.
Mnemonic1: I asked my teacher what this strange word meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an acorn at me!
Mnemonic2: The above-stated words are the acorn from which the following statement grows.
Compo: 言: word; say　亥: boar; acorn (RTK)

Origin: Words . . . umbrella . . . shape. The key word refers to a medical examination.
Mnemonic1: At my last check-up, the doctor said to me: "Start carrying a parasol, or you might get skin cancer. You've been tanning too much!" (Umbrella over shape = parasol].
Mnemonic2: The doctor at my checkup was expressing words of concern about my umbrella shaped gut.
Compo: 言: word; say　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: Jewel . . . umbrella . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: It's rare to see the king carrying his own parasol - typically he gets one of his attendants to do it for him (thanks to Katsuo for umbrella + shape = parasol and to Peppi for the story idea).
Mnemonic2: Tip: umbrella + shape : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it may be worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "parasol" (because it is the same shape as an umbrella). REF: rare (FRAME 1723) , check-up (#1724), measles (#2574), fallible (#2720).
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: Ceiling . . . plow . . . fishhook . . . a drop of.
Mnemonic1: Horror scene: Hanging from the ceiling, a plough and fishhook dripping with blood down onto the tiled bathroom floor.
Mnemonic2: (true stroke order] First draw T for Tile, which then becomes I. Then draw an ´L´ fish hook with a dash in the middle to make a mediocre ´e´ that few can see.//ガ wa3 와 (wa).

Origin: The sense of the key word is one of joining things together that were previously separate. Its elements: person . . . puzzle.
Mnemonic1: Mr. T furiously works a puzzle in an attempt to join Mensa, the high-IQ society.
Mnemonic2: Why do I gotta join these two puzzle pieces? I ain´t got time for joining no jigsaw-jabba! Mr. T apparently gets a severe case of crankypants when doing puzzles.
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　并: put together; puzzle (RTK)

Origin: Puzzle . . . tile.
Mnemonic1: A flower pot that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.
Mnemonic2: To solve this puzzle all you need is to put the flower pot on top of the proper tile. (cue secrets tune from Zelda).
Compo: 并: put together; puzzle (RTK)　瓦: tile

Origin: Soil . . . flag . . . puzzle.
Mnemonic1: (fence; wall; (kokuji)] A fence separates one soil from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of soils in the world have a virtual fence called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their soil with one color, their national flag as the legend and a fence on the borders... don´t you think it looks like a giant puzzle?
Mnemonic2: Why the Earth has to be fenced off and flags used to represent each "country" is a puzzle to me - we´re all just monkeys on a big rock spinning round the Sun!
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　尸: corpse; flag (RTK)　并: put together; puzzle (RTK)

Origin: <i style="font-weight: bold; ">Mochi is the glutinous rice the Japanese pound into cakes. Its primitives are: food . . . puzzle.
Mnemonic1: Call your friend and he answers the phone "Mochi, mochi!" whatever he is eating sure is making it hard to understand. I will puzzle over the content of our conversation for some time to come.
Mnemonic2: Mochi ice cream is a puzzling food, I still have no idea how they get that ice cream in there, but it sure tastes good.
Compo: 食: eat; food　并: put together; puzzle (RTK)

Origin: Food . . . ear. The sense of the key word here is that of bait or feed for animals.

Mnemonic2: Do you know Mike Tayson favorite feed? Ears! He eats ears!

Mnemonic2: Going off the idea of the right side meaning rapid growth/increase of small objects, I´ve decided to make the right side be Gremlins, those little mysterious creatures that double rapidly. Gremlins find water a little too nourishing, as it makes them instantly multiply.

Concentrate on the reasons behind the penal system ("changing people´s hearts" here), instead of the penalty itself or the punishment (revenge) aspect. It may help to note that there´s no sword, but a heart :-) (Note: 懲りる = learn from one´s bad experiences).
