Origin: Drag . . . one . . . mouth.
Mnemonic1: The empress is cruel. Normally she´ll violently pull her servants by the ear when they´ve failed to follow orders. But one time she dragged this one guy around the palace by the mouth. She must have been really angry—ever since that moment, he´s never been seen again.
Mnemonic2: The F word often comes out of the mouth of the empress.
Compo: 厂: cliff　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　口: mouth
土: ground; land; soil　后: empress; queen; after; behind; back; later

Origin: Woman . . . snake.
Mnemonic1: Cleopatra.
Mnemonic2: Be careful you don´t pick up a drag queen at a club - they might look like women, but they have a snake down there!
Compo: 女: woman　已: oneself; snake (RTK)

Origin: Woman . . . slave.
Mnemonic1: Princess Leia becomes Jabba´s slave (“princess Leia is a woman slave”).
Mnemonic2: Cinderella: A woman who was a slave who became a princess.
Compo: 女: woman　臣: subject; slave (RTK)

Origin: Pardon me if I revert to the venerable old Dr. Freud again, but his eye for symbolism is often helpful to appreciate things that more earthy imaginations once accepted more freely but that we have learned to cover over with a veneer of etiquette. For instance, the fact that things like the mouth of a cave served as natural ritual substitutes for the opening through which a woman gives birth. Hence, in order to be reborn as an adult, one may have to pass through the psychological equivalent of the womb, that is, something that bears a likeness to the opening of the woman from whom you were born.
Mnemonic1: Women share a common likeness. Their mouths are always open, whining about this and that.
Mnemonic2: From a woman´s other 口(mouth) comes a baby with a perfect likeness.
Compo: 女: woman　口: mouth

Origin: What makes a man a bridegroom is obviously a woman and her dowry, here presented as a small zoo (animals were often used for this purpose in earlier societies) and a month away from it all (the "honeymoon").
Mnemonic1: The virgin bridegroom tries to understand the new, mysterious part of his woman´s body - but with little success. It´s a zoo down there! (primitives placement: the part of the body is ´down there´ - the woman is ´left´ unsatisfied).
Mnemonic2: The only reason anyone talks about a bridegroom is if they´re about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your woman to the zoo for a month. Pretty cool honeymoon.
Compo: 女: woman　胥: together; mutual; subordinate official

Origin: Woman . . . halo.
Mnemonic1: Your daughter is a good girl......well, let´s hope so... :-).
Mnemonic2: Be careful not to think woman + angel here, which has already been seen for attractive (#430). Suggest using woman with a halo, as in an innocent girl, something that everyone sees their daughters as being.
Compo: 女: woman　良: good; halo (RTK)

Origin: The kanji in this frame demonstrates the traditional Japanese approach to marriage: it is the woman who leaves her family for another household, thus marrying into a man's family.
Mnemonic1: Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she´s married into the house than into a relationship.
Mnemonic2: Traditionally, it was the women who would marry into the households of their husband´s families.
Compo: 女: woman　家: house
Ex1English: Family a woman has married into

Origin: Wheat . . . house.
Mnemonic1: Your earnings allow you to bring home your daily bread (made of wheat, naturally).
Mnemonic2: Hmm, EARNINGS. Think of the popular saying "Bringing HOME the bacon". Here, EARNINGS is the picture "Bringing HOME the bread(WHEAT) and the bacon (PIG).
Compo: 禾: grain; wheat (RTK)　家: house

Origin: Soil . . . crown . . . sow. Compare frame 582.
Mnemonic1: There´s already King of the Hill. This is Queen of the Hillock. It´s Ms. Piggy sitting on top of a mound of soil in her crown.
Mnemonic2: The crowned sow (we met her in overpowering) is standing atop her little mound of earth - hillock - the undisputed champeen of all the pigsty.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　冖: crown 　豕: pig; sow (RTK)

Origin: Tall . . . crowned . . . sow.
Mnemonic1: In Orwell´s ´Animal Farm´ the pigs overpowered every other animals. They crownded themselves as ruler of the farm and walked tall on their rear legs, a crime strictly forbidden in the animal republic.
Mnemonic2: Ganon, the tall crowned pig, has been overpowering ther land of Hyrule for decades.
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　口: mouth　冖: crown 　豕: pig; sow (RTK)
艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　冖: crown 　豕: pig; sow (RTK)

Origin: The groundbreaking referred to here is not for the erection of new buildings but for the opening of farmlands. The elements: skunk . . . silver . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: It was the groundbreaking of the new farm, but there was an uninvited guest to the ceremony. It was a famous skunk, the one with the familiar silver stripe. The feet of the crowd rushing from the ceremony site churned up the soil very nicely. The ceremony was ruined but the groundbreaking was a great success.
Mnemonic2: I got sprayed by a skunk, so no one is helping me with the groundbreaking of my farm. On a positive note, I found silver laying all over the soil. Mine all mine!
Compo: 豸: badger; skunk　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Skunk . . . silver . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He´s a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a "heart of gold" he has a heart of silver (since he always finishes second in the game of love).
Mnemonic2: The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He´s a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a "heart of gold" he has a heart of silver.
Compo: 豸: badger; skunk　艮: northeast; silver (RTK)　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)

Origin: Skunk . . . white . . . human legs.
Mnemonic1: Anyone who watched a looney tunes cartoon know those kind of scene : pepe embraces a poor kitty mistaken for a SKUNK and the smell of pepe make the unfortunate girl loose all countenance : she turns WHITE then runs as fast as her LEGS can carry her . So much for cat s dignity and countenance.
Mnemonic2: The shocked countenance on girl's face when Pepe started to hump her white legs.
Compo: 豸: badger; skunk　白: white　儿: human legs

Origin: Sows . . . road.
Mnemonic1: In association with consummate (#540), our sow is on the road pursuing a mate.
Mnemonic2: The pig is on the road in the pursue of the turtle who is trying to escape (#283). (See story on escape (#283) & consummate (#540)).
Compo: 豕: pig; sow (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: The horns atop the sow suggest a boar at work in the background. Add the element for a road. Now create a story whose meaning is: consummate.
Mnemonic1: This is still Miss Piggy only she´s gotten horny (as she often does) and now she´s pursuing Kermit to help her consummate her desires.
Mnemonic2: In association with pursue (#539), our sow has tracked down a suitable mate, they´ve consummated their relationship, and now the little sow is all grown up into a boar with horns.
Compo: 丷: animal horns (RTK)　豕: pig; sow (RTK)　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Regiment . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: One of the members of our air force regiment has been shot down; he managed to safely eject, but his plane crashed into the ground.
Mnemonic2: The regiment led by horny Miss Piggy wearing a viking helmet accidently falls off The Pinnacle and crashes into the ground below. // old story with wrong meaning of regiment: Kermit is so frustrated with horny Miss Piggy´s regimented sex schedule, he throws her off The Pinnacle and she crashes into the ground.
Compo: 隊: regiment　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Pinnacle . . . possess . . . ground.
Mnemonic1: Any attempt to possess the pinnacle will degenerate into a land ("ground") war.
Mnemonic2: A degenerate doctor at The Pinnacle is doing illegal abortions. He´s so sick he just throws the aborted fetuses onto the ground far below. And like a possess demon, he keeps some tied to his side on a belt as trophies.
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　有: possess　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Pinnacle . . . possess . . . road.
Mnemonic1: (Image: Follow the ´Yellow-Brick Road´ to success] The pinnacle signifies your personal goal and destination. What you´re seeking to possess lies at the end of the yellow-brick road. You must follow the road to get what you want.
Mnemonic2: I fled to The Pinnacle for safety, but the demon followed me right up the road!
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　有: possess　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

English: Attach, Be Attached To, Hand Over
Origin: Pinnacle . . . adhere.
Mnemonic1: A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules.
Mnemonic2: The Pinnacle is firmly affixed to the top of the mount with bubble gum. (adhere (#1000)).
Compo: 阜: hill; pinnacle (RTK) (阝)　付: attach; adhere

Origin: Skeleton . . . possess . . . road.
Mnemonic1: A skeleton is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he´s going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still possesses.
Mnemonic2: A skeleton by the side of the road, holding a sign "Possess marrow, will travel". Yeah, it makes no sense but I don´t foget the kanji.
Compo: 骨: bone; skeleton (RTK)　有: possess　辶: walk; road; way (RTK)

Origin: Pedestal . . . heart.
Mnemonic1: While standing on the pedestal at the award ceremony, the recipient heartlessly neglected to mention the people that got him there.
Mnemonic2: Someone you put on a pedestal will NEGLECT your heart.
Compo: 台: pedestal　心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)
Kunyomi: おこた.る, なま.ける

Origin: State of mind . . . left (i.e. "sinister") . . . flesh.
Mnemonic1: When I am in a LAZY state of mind I use my left hand to play with my meat...it feels like someone else is doing it, which is good cause I´m to lazy to get a date.
Mnemonic2: When in a lazy state of mind, the things you need to do are left for next month.
Compo: 心: heart; mind (忄; ⺗)　左: left　月: moon; month

Origin: Person . . . left.
Mnemonic1: Mr T´s assistant is on his left. Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - "Stay on my left, foo!".
Mnemonic2: On your right is your "right-hand man" that you credit for all your success....on the left...... is your assistant who does all the grunt work and gets no credit for anything...
Compo: 人: human (亻); umbrella (𠆢) (RTK)　左: left

Origin: If, at some aboriginal level, Toys Я Us, then the archetypal ball must have been there at the beginning, before evolving into beach balls, ping-pong balls, rugby balls, and marbles.
Mnemonic1: The ball was the only thing that people at the beginning of time had to use as a toy. Poor cavemen.
Mnemonic2: And so it was, the ball marked the beginning of all the toys that were to come.
Compo: 王: king; ball (RTK)　元: beginning; origin
Ex1English: Play with (as with one's pen, food, etc.)

Origin: Jewel . . . two hands.
Mnemonic1: The king used both hands to tinker with himself in his spare time.
Mnemonic2: Picture the king holding a large pan in his two hands and tinkering with it, wishing he could lead the itinerant life of a tinker. As a rhyme: The king, he uses his two hands, To tinker with his pots and pans . . .
Compo: 玉: jewel; ball　廾: twenty; 2 hands
Ex1English: Play with (as with a person's feelings)

Origin: The bad feeling created by words spoken in derision often leaves a bad taste in the mouth of the one who speaks them, kind of like the foul aftertaste that follows a night before of too much of the wrong stuff - or what we call morning mouth.
Mnemonic1: When I wake up, I am always late, so I hurry to work. With a bad case of perpetual morning breath, I am the subject of derision at my office whenever I open my mouth.
Mnemonic2: If morning breath emanates from your mouth, you are subject to derision!
Compo: 口: mouth　朝: morning

Origin: The hustle and bustle of this character is depicted by a St. Bernard dog and a haystack.
Mnemonic1: Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up.
Mnemonic2: A bustle is also the name for the big wire-framed skirts that women used to wear. Here´s a St. Bernard dog jammed ass-first into the top of a haystack, looking like some kind of proper Victorian-era lady as he struggles to get out.
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　卉: grass; haystack (RTK)
Ex1English: Bustle about, exert oneself for, devote oneself to

Origin: Shredder . . . two hands.
Mnemonic1: The Bush administration taskmasters hid their abuse of power by shredding documents as fast as they could using both hands....
Mnemonic2: You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to ABUSE your plants by shredding them into wood chips.
Compo: 敝: be worn-out; Shredder (RTK)　廾: twenty; 2 hands

Origin: Shredder . . . towel.
Mnemonic1: A counterfeiter is using a shredder to shred a towel in order to print up some cash (he needs some rag paper) .
Mnemonic2: In order to create some cash, first you feed a towel through a shredder to get the raw materials. ("Paper" money isn´t plain paper; it´s mostly linen.).
Compo: 敝: be worn-out; Shredder (RTK)　巾: towel
Ex1English: Pendant paper strips in a shinto shrine, sacred staff with cut paper

Origin: Flower . . . shredder.
Mnemonic1: You cover over the shredder with flowers when the FBI comes a-knockin´.
Mnemonic2: The taskmaster arranges flowers to cover over the rags she makes us clean with.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　敝: be worn-out; Shredder (RTK)

Origin: The first companion that God made, as the Bible story goes, was Eve. Upon seeing her, Adam exclaimed, "Flesh of my flesh!" And that is precisely what this character says in so many strokes.
Mnemonic1: My companion and I are like two moons side by side.
Mnemonic2: Under the twin moons of Tatooine, Luke had no COMPANION.
Compo: 月: moon; month　月: moon; month

Origin: One often thinks of books as "good companions," but here it is the shelf we store them on that is the companion. The reasons should be obvious: it is made of the same stuff, wood, and spends a lot more time with them than we do! Here again, be careful not to let the rationality of the explanation get in the way before you turn it into a proper story.
Mnemonic1: A shelf is a wooden companion to books.
Mnemonic2: I think of an Otaku, with a wooden shelf full of anime action figure statures, who are sadly his only companions.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　朋: companion; friend

Origin: Tree . . . tome.
Mnemonic1: A palisade is a "fence of stakes especially for defense," usually the stakes are very strong, set closely together, and pointed on top. Tome can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set wooden stakes, braced by one horizontal bar.
Mnemonic2: An army of scholars build a wooden palisade to protect their precious tome of literature.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　冊: counter for books; scrapbook (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . going.
Mnemonic1: Girders are support beams that are nowadays mostly made out of steel. But in the ancient houses that are placed at the boulevard the girders will be made out of wood.
Mnemonic2: When the wooden girders start to snap, the workmen shout "Run! Let´s go!".
Compo: 木: tree; wood　行: going; journey

Origin: Here we think of plug in the sense of a cork or stopper used to seal the mouth of a bottle, water faucet, or something with liquid running out of it. Forgetting the abstract picture of the former frame, let us work with all the primitive units: tree . . . umbrella . . . ball. Imagine a tree with a faucet in the side out of which tennis balls are flowing, bouncing all over the ground by the hundreds. You fight your way up to it and shove your giant beach umbrella into the tree to plug it up.
Mnemonic1: The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. "You´ll need the whole tree to plug that gap". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they´re doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the "whole" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ).
Mnemonic2: To plug the hole, you need to use a whole piece of wood - like a cork or something.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　全: whole

Origin: Think of elucidating as presenting something in whole words, as distinct from broken fragmented sentences.
Mnemonic1: Words that tell you the results of the whole story really elucidate.
Mnemonic2: Elucidate me. Tell me, in your own words, the whole story.
Compo: 言: word; say　全: whole

Origin: House . . . celery . . . animal legs . . . soil.
Mnemonic1: The A/C wasn´t making the house cold because the filters had been blocked up with dirt.
Mnemonic2: It was so cold (#1526), the pipes blocked up with ice. After removing the ice, we insulated them with soil.
Compo: 宀: house (RTK)　共: together　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: This character refers originally to a deciduous, rough tree that grows on mountain plains. From this it gets the secondary sense of rugged or spiny. Its primitive elements: tree . . . grow late.
Mnemonic1: I learned this one from the movie Evil Dead, but when it grows late, trees change shape and become spiny creatures! Lesson: don´t go out at night.
Mnemonic2: With the safety of darkness as it grows late, spiny little insects start crawling out of the trees.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　更: grow late

Origin: Imagine a village market with stalls set up around an immense persimmon tree with watermelon-sized fruit. If it weren't for the fact that the tree is sacred to the village, people would get impatient as the persimmons fall from the tree and wreak havoc on buyers and sellers alike.
Mnemonic1: Nobody buys persimmons at the market, because there´s a tree in the middle where you can pick them for free.
Mnemonic2: The guy at the market says: I´ll give you one persimmon tree per every Simon you bring me!
Compo: 木: tree; wood　市: market; city; town

Origin: Flower . . . moon . . . quarter . . . rice grains.
Mnemonic1: According to legend, the great Ogaki wisteria tree grew and flowered from magical rice grains that were planted under the quarter moon.
Mnemonic2: The wisteria is a type of hanging vine covered with flowers. By the light of the quarter moon, the flowers look like clusters of rice grains.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　月: moon; month　关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)　水: water (氵) (氺)

Origin: Meat . . . quarter . . . team of horses.
Mnemonic1: Flesh+quarter=McDonald´s quarter pounder. Due to inflation, McDonald´s has had to start making quarter pounders out of horse meat.
Mnemonic2: Every quarter moon, the cost of a trojan horse rises one quarter by inflation.
Compo: 朕: we　馬: horse

Origin: Moon . . . quarter . . . words.
Mnemonic1: Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there.
Mnemonic2: As a prank, a guy sits with his butt flesh on the facsimile machine, inserts a quarter, and tries to fax it to his boss. However the facsimile machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his flesh, it just transmits the word "asshole". Don´t forget it´s flesh, not words, on the left side; the flesh image gets transformed into words.
Compo: 月: moon; month　关: quarter (RTK) ; golden calf (RTK)　言: word; say
Ex2English: Certified copy, transcript; copy of the domiciliary register

Origin: Barley . . . mask.
Mnemonic2: There is a certain restaurant in West-Shinjuku that serves its noodles made of BARLEY in a MASK instead of a plate. I love these theme-restaurants!
Compo: 麥: wheat　面: mask

Origin: The sense of this key word is to pull or jerk, as in opening a door or making "ramen" noodles. Its elements: fingers . . . vase.
Mnemonic1: He quickly yanked his fingers out of the vase. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the cookies...
Mnemonic2: He yanked his finger out of the vase upon discovering it had a venus fly trap in it.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　立: stand up; vase (RTK)
日: day; sun　光: ray; light

Origin: A large towel stretched overhead with only a few of the sun's rays breaking through represents a canopy over one's bed.
Mnemonic1: A canopy is a towel to block the suns rays.
Mnemonic2: From the Hitch-Hiker´s Guide to the Universe: A towel is useful, among other things, as a canopy to keep out the sun´s rays from your face while napping.
Compo: 巾: towel　日: day; sun　光: ray; light

Origin: No doubt you will find it in your heart to forgive me for forcing yet another Japanese word on you in this frame. It is not the last time it will happen in this book, but I can assure you they are used only when absolutely necessary. One rin is equal to about 1/1000 of a yen - or rather was worth that much when it still made economic sense to mint them. While inflation took its toll on this kanji as a monetary unit, it survived with the not at all surprising sense of something "very, very tiny." The kanji shows a cliff with a computer under it, apparently because it has been pushed over into the abyss by someone fed up with the thing. The total market value of one home computer that has fallen over rock and bramble for several hundred feet: about one rin!
Mnemonic1: I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it´s worth less than a rin.
Mnemonic2: A computer dropped off of a cliff would be worth about 1 RIN.
Compo: 厂: cliff　里: village; computer (RTK)

Origin: Think of the three kinds of furrows shown here in this character - a top hat's rim, a rice field's ridges, and the wrinkles that show you've been around a long time.
Mnemonic1: Using a TOP HAT to make FURROWS in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!
Mnemonic2: A mummy tries to furrow his brow but realizes that he´s got no head - just a brain with a top-hat on it. So he furrows his brain. (trigger: furrow your brain].
Compo: 亠: roof; hat (RTK)　田: rice field; brain (RTK)　久: long time

Origin: This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: bound up . . . arm.
Mnemonic1: Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! "Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!".
Mnemonic2: Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! "Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!" "You´ll never be able to use your dagger now!" (adapted from ergerg).
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)

Origin: You will have to imagine "capturing" a favorite aroma by having it gagged and bound up in a spoon.
Mnemonic1: The muchacho sits down bound up to enjoy his own aroma.
Mnemonic2: If you bind up a person and let him sit for several days, an unpleasant aroma will result.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　匕: spoon
Kunyomi: にお.う, にお.い, にお.わせる

Origin: Bound up . . . elbow. Think of this key word in the sense of something that has been nabbed or cought.
Mnemonic1: Your elbow is bound up so that your biceps will stay flexed.
Mnemonic2: My elbow was bound up in a cast, making it impossible to keep it flexed.
Compo: 勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . elbow . . . dart.
Mnemonic1: In the busy pub, one of the dart players shoved his dart into my elbow by accident when it nearly slipped out of his fingers.
Mnemonic2: Your fingers slip when someone´s elbow shoves you, causing you to drop the dart you were about to throw. But as you can see, their elbow is very small, so you decide they´re too weak to shove back.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)　矢: arrow; dart (RTK)

Origin: Fingers . . . flood . . . evening.
Mnemonic1: The old lady said that there was a flood imminent, because her fingers hurt in the evening.
Mnemonic2: The Dutch boy put his finger in the dam holding back imminent danger from flood waters until evening.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　巛: river (川); flood (RTK)　夕: evening

Origin: Sun . . . love.
Mnemonic1: The sun´s love is equivocal: it warms yet burns us.
Mnemonic2: 曖昧。 On a sunny day, a guy professes his love to a girl he admires. But she gives him the common equivocal response, "Let´s just be friends.".
Compo: 日: day; sun　愛: love; affection; favourite

Origin: The most obscure ideas are those that the sun of reason has not yet dawned on. Be sure to give the sun a professorial demeanor, complete with spectacles and a pipe.
Mnemonic1: Something that is obscure has not yet been brought before the light of day.
Mnemonic2: ´Can´t you go outside and get some sun?´ ´Not yet, I have to learn all these obscure RTK3 kanji!´.
Compo: 日: day; sun　未: not yet

Origin: Jewel . . . detain.
Mnemonic1: “The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”.
Mnemonic2: The king was detained, by men in marine blue; Must be the marines, planning a coup. (thx Katsuo/gavmck).
Compo: 玉: jewel; ball　留: detain; fasten; halt; stop

Origin: This kanji refers to one of the seven classical stones of China. Its elements: jewel . . . top hat . . . villain . . . belt . . . elbow.
Mnemonic1: Michael Jackson is the king of pop, wearing his crystal rhinestone glove (see detach (#1492).
Mnemonic2: In my story for detatch detach (#1492), the left side primitive was junkie. The top-hatted villian of society with a belt around their elbow. Here, the junkie is getting a fix of crystal meth: the jewel in the crown of today´s drugs.
Compo: 玉: jewel; ball　亠: roof; hat (RTK)　凶: evil; vilain (RTK)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: Woman . . . rapidly.
Mnemonic1: If you go through women rapidly you will be the object of envy.
Mnemonic2: Ah, puberty ... the girl that starts her journey towards womanhood the most rapidly will become the subject of envy from all her classmates.
Compo: 女: woman　疾: rapidly

Origin: It should not be hard to leep from the key word to the image of a woman who is jealous of the rock that another woman is sporting on the third finger of her left hand.
Mnemonic1: The jealous woman bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a stone.
Mnemonic2: Every woman wants a huge stone on her finger to make her friends jealous.
Compo: 女: woman　石: stone; rock (RTK)

Origin: Drawn on the walls of a complex of caves near Niaux in southern France are a number of animal likenesses dating from the Upper Paleolithic period. Among them we find pictures of deer, some of them showing men in deer masks. By comparing their drawings to real deer, Stone Age people hoped to acquire power over the animal in the hunt; and by comparing themselves to the deer, to take on that animal's characteristics. But time has locked with a "double-key" (the extra stroke through the element for key) the real secret of this art form from us, and we can only surmise such meanings. But more important than the enigmas of the troglodytic mind is the way in which caves, a double-key, and comparing gives us the kanji for deer.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated much the same as the tiger was: the lower element is dropped to leave room for a replacement. Its meaning, however, remains the same. There are a very few cases (see frame 2158) in which there is no abbreviation. When this happens, we may keep the image suggested by the above explanation: painting of a deer.
Mnemonic1: Bambi wanders into a cave and sees a side order of salad and 2 spoons...but what´s the main course?
Mnemonic2: Santa´s reindeer, Rudolf, opens a nightclub in a cave. It´s popular with all the deer and reindeer in the world. The cave speciality is a salad w/ dressing on the side. There is no other deer club that can compare. How many other deer nightclubs are there?
Compo: 广: cave (RTK)　比: compare
鹿: deer　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: Grove . . . deer.
Mnemonic1: Many deer can be found in the grove at the foot of a mountain.
Mnemonic2: Deer are well known for frolicking in groves of trees. However, they are not well known for actually watching where the heck they are bounding about. Here we have a bunch of dead deer bodies that you find at the foot of a mountain. You are trying to figure why there are so many dead deer in one spot, and then you trace a line up the mountain - leaves and such are scattered all the way up...to a grove. Looks like they hopped through some leaves to their doom.
Compo: 林: grove; forest　鹿: deer

Origin: The painting of a deer itself with its form and color is enough to fill the bill for an image of something lovely. But to give a bit of contrast, we see two mediocre drawings from a later age on two patches of ceiling above. Note that the drop in mediocre has been lengthened somewhat and the second stroke drawn down straight.
Mnemonic1: The anthropologist made an exact deer painting from the cave ceiling on the ceiling of his house. Too bad they´re both mediocre. All his wife could say was, "How...lovely.".
Mnemonic2: Lovely bambi.... pictographe : just take a look at those innocent open eyes (part 1 it´s not more far fetched than seeing mediocre in it) with thin eyebrows what a lovely deer ...(part 2).
Compo: 丽: lovely; paws　鹿: deer

Origin: Flowers . . . deer . . . one . . . tail feathers. Note the doubling up in these last two elements as in frame 2091.
Mnemonic1: Customer in restaurant asks you (waiter) what you recommend: "I recommend ze deer or ze 'eadless chicken. And I recommend you garnish it wiz some flowers." (let last six strokes = headless chicken).
Mnemonic2: It is recommended that deers stick to eating flowers. If they try to eat birds, they may end up choking on them, like this one here. Note that the head (白) is gone and the visible part of the body which is normally written with a stroke of the head must by necessity be drawn with a stroke of the tail.
Compo: 薦: recommend

Origin: Deer . . . crown (note the doubling up) . . . heart . . . walking legs. You may recall that we met the relative primitives at the bottom here before, in the kanji for melancholy (Frame 663).
Mnemonic1: The hunter experienced jubilation when the deer with melancholy walked up to him and said, "just shoot me, whats the point in running. Everyone dies someday..."
Mnemonic2: Bambi was melancholy at the death of his mother, but is now in jubilation as he´s made friends with thumper.
Compo: 慶: jubilation
白: white　儿: human legs

Ex1English: Glare at, stare hard at; keep an eye on

Compo: 臼: mortar

Origin: Water . . . weak. Do not confuse the meaning of this key word with "Drown" (Frame 763), which is closer to "founder."
Mnemonic1: Weak people placed in the water start drowning. Get some strength in those arms and learn how to swim!
Mnemonic2: Weak swimmers drowning in the water.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　弱: weak

Mnemonic1: Right part: mortar bound up over oven fire, comprising boiling cauldron. Lagoon is a shallow pond, thus easily warmed by sun, large-scale equivalent of a boiling cauldron.
Mnemonic2: I stapled both sides of some tail feathers to a waterfall towering over the lagoon to give it a more tropical feel…
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　舄: a shoe

Origin: The key word for this kanji connotes the "muddying" effect on a soft consonant brought about by vibrating the vocal chords. For example, in English a "j" is voiced while a "sh" is unvoiced. In Japanese, the し is changed to じ when it is voiced. The primitives are: water . . . eye . . . bound up . . . insect.
Mnemonic1: The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing "Help me, Help Me" under the watchful eye of the spider who´s venom is dripping like water from her fangs.
Mnemonic2: Pour water over the eyes of a bound up insect if you want to hear a pitiful buzz that is very similar to a VOICED consanant.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　勹: wrap; bound up (RTK)　虫: insect
Ex3English: Accept the bad with the good; be accepting
Ex4English: Purity and impurity; good and evil

Origin: As you pass by the muchacho taking the siesta, he cries out that he is thirsty and asks for something to drink. So you turn the water hose on him.
Mnemonic1: You awaken from your siesta because you feel extremely thirsty so you go looking for some water.
Mnemonic2: The muchacho taking his SIESTA cries out that he is THIRSTY. So you pull out a bottle of WATER and pretend you´re going to give it to him...but then you dump it all on the ground before his eyes. HAHA, sucked in muchacho!!
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　日: day; sun　匂: odour

Origin: The color of the serape or cloak of our muchacho on siesta is a dull brown, the color this kanji indicates.
Mnemonic1: Why is my package late? Imagine a UPS driver dressed in BROWN garments taking a siesta. What can BROWN do for you?
Mnemonic2: Mexicans use a cloak (pancho) for their siestas. Their color is usually brown.
Compo: 衣: clothes; garment (RTK)　日: day; sun　匂: odour

Origin: Kudzu is a word taken over from Japanese to name the crawling vines that creep up and completely take over trees. Seeing it at its worst in the Georgia countryside makes it easy to understand why it has a reputation as the "plague of the South." From there it should not be hard to arrange the primitives, flowers and siesta into a memorable image.
Mnemonic1: Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a siesta in the kudzu field. The kudzu grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the kudzu flowers mark his grave.
Mnemonic2: The muchacho takes a siesta under the flowers of the kudzu.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　日: day; sun　匂: odour

Origin: When the muchacho on siesta looks up at you and opens his mouth to talk, his voice is so hoarse that you cannot understand him.
Mnemonic1: If you have a siesta with your mouthopen, you will wake up with a hoarse voice.
Mnemonic2: After taking a siesta, you find that your mouth is hoarse (after all you ARE thirsty remember).
Compo: 口: mouth　日: day; sun　匂: odour

Origin: Imagine an audience with the emperor or the pope in which all those in attendance are sitting down, leaning against the wall, sleeping like our muchacho on siesta as the honorable host delivers his speech.
Mnemonic1: The talk was so boring the audience took a siesta.
Mnemonic2: The man talking during his siesta (in his sleep) is saying strange things and drawing an audience.
Compo: 言: word; say　日: day; sun　匂: odour

Origin: Fingers . . . siesta.
Mnemonic1: A muchacho puts up a notice that says “NO FINGER SNAPPING ALLOWED. MUCHACHOS ON SIESTA”. The muchachos are sleeping soundly, completely oblivious to the sound of dogs barking, guitar playing and even gun shots. Now imagine one tourist passing by and snapping his fingers and waking up all the muchachos at once.
Mnemonic2: Just as I was finished putting up a "no siestas" notice on my property, a muchacho gave me the finger, sat down, and promptly fell asleep.
Compo: 手: hand; fingers (扌) (RTK)　日: day; sun　匂: odour
Ex1English: Put up, hoist; display in writing, publish

Compo: 戌: sign of the dog
尢: crooked-big radical (no. 43)　丶: dot; drop

Origin: Team of horses . . . plump.
Mnemonic1: If a passenger is too plump and heavy, its too burdensome for the horse.
Mnemonic2: If your horses get so plump to be good for nothing they just become burdensome.
Compo: 馬: horse　太: plump; thick

Origin: Team of horses . . . phrase. In American slang, a pony is an underground translation of a classical text, which students who cannot manage the difficult phrases of the original language consult and pass on from one generation to the next.
Mnemonic1: The new My Little Ponies show is all about magic horses who utter cute catch phrases.
Mnemonic2: A particular My Little Pony has a string that when you pull it, it repeats the same dumb phrase like "I love you".
Compo: 馬: horse　句: phrase
Ex3English: Captured piece; means at one's disposal

Origin: Bamboo . . . team of horses.
Mnemonic1: A fervent horse doesnt need to be whipped with a bamboo stick during a race, it will go fast by itself.
Mnemonic2: A fervent history otaku rebuild the the Trojan Horse. But since he was Japanese, he used bamboo instead of normal wood.
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　馬: horse

Origin: Eyeball . . . team of horses.
Mnemonic1: In ancient Japan, the most grievous insult was to poke a rival´s horse in the eye (consider how rare an expensive a steed was in those days). It was the final step in preparation for a duel to the death.
Mnemonic2: In Japan, is is considered insulting to look at someone from atop your horse. You have to step down and face people properly.
Compo: 网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　馬: horse

Origin: The verbal abuse involved in reviling those who do not deserve it can be compared to a march of flowers in full boom having an eyeball of nastiness cast over them (literally, of course).
Mnemonic1: They gays were reviled by society, so they put flowers above their eyes and marched around.
Mnemonic2: In Northern Ireland, bitter religious groups revile their opponents by marching defiantly under their very eye, holding flowers that symbolize their beliefs.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　网: net; eye (罒) (RTK)　戍: protection; march (RTK)
Kunyomi: さげす.む, ないがし.ろ*

Origin: The only thing that distinguishes this character from that for bird is the omission of the one stroke that makes it white. Which is logical enough, when you consider that there are no crows of that color.
Mnemonic1: The book´s story is just fine, but I found a kanji dictionary explanation also interesting: As crows are all black, it´s hard to see where their eyes are (black on black), so a stroke is removed from the part in the pictograph where the eyes would be.
Mnemonic2: A crow is a bird, but not a white one. MEANING: write bird, but skip writing one in white.
Compo: 鳥: bird
甲: armor; roots (RTK)　鳥: bird

Origin: Baseball . . . bird.
Mnemonic1: Feed one pigeon and nine more birds will be swarming you immediately…
Mnemonic2: Imagine some pigeons going to see a baseball game. They would surely be the only birds there!
Compo: 九: nine; baseball (RTK)　鳥: bird

Origin: Vulture . . . husband . . . bird.
Mnemonic1: There are two types of birds often compared to husbands. Yes there are a few vultures out there, but most husbands are CHICKENS. 鶏 【にわとり】 (n) (domestic) chicken, (P) 鶏肉 【けいにく】 (n) chicken meat, (P).
Mnemonic2: The vulture´s husband is a chicken...heck...who am I to judge their interspecies love? They´re both birds so its cool.
Compo: 爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　夫: husband; man　鳥: bird

Origin: Water . . . vulture . . . husband.
Mnemonic1: The Simpsons are on vacation. Homer stops to take a leak in a mountain stream but gets snatched by an eagle. Hear his scream?
Mnemonic2: A husband who went fishing at the mountain stream to feed his family, fell in the rapids (we´ll assume this is a large mountain stream). He is saved from the waters by a great eagle. He comes back home with nothing to feed the family, his clothes still dripping wet as he tells his wife of how he was saved by a great eagle, and of course she does not believe him. The story continues in chicken (#1947).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　爪: claw; vulture (RTK)　夫: husband; man
广: cave (RTK)　鳥: bird
就: concerning　鳥: bird

Mnemonic1: The imperial seal is usually an impressive mark made with a jewel. However when the letter arrives it has been raining on it and you see that the drops of rain have been transformed into little x’s where some animal legs have run over it.
Mnemonic2: Primitives (to give correct stroke order): tool bench, towel, 4 Xs, jewel. Story: the Imperial Seal is like a kind of coat-of-arms the Emperor can stamp on stuff. Picture that coat-of-arms as depicting a big jewel (say, a diamond) with a motto on a banner above it saying 'let it be (#2074)'. (The emperor must have been a huge Beatles fan).
Compo: 璽: imperial seal

Origin: The sense of the key word is of something refreshing and invigorating. It is made up of the St. Bernard and a pair of sheaves on each side.
Mnemonic1: The St Bernard is bracing itself for an operation requiring four stitches.
Mnemonic2: St. Bernard dog had a refreshing bracing bath and now is shaking all the water out of his fur. The drops are thrown in all direction and that's why the have an x shape in the pictogram.
Compo: 大: large; St Bernard (RTK)　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)　乂: mow; sheaf, arm (RTK)
糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)
Ex1English: Spelling (as of a name); binding (as of a book)

Origin: Crotches, crotches everywhere . . . tree. Hint: think of a group of children playing an original version of "Here We Go 'Round the Mulberry Bush."
Mnemonic1: Children going around the mulberry tree singing "This is the way we wash our crotch, wash our crotch, wash our crotch...".
Mnemonic2: Imagine kids all over the top of a mulberry tree, sitting astride limbs so that their weight is on their crotches. (Mulberry trees have big sprawling limbs that run horizontally or at shallow angles making them easy to climb and sit in. I have an old mulberry in my yard, and my kids are in it constantly).
Compo: 又: again; crotch (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)　又: again; crotch (RTK)　木: tree; wood

Origin: Heavens . . . insect. Be sure to do something about the position of the two elements.
Mnemonic1: There are no insects in heaven - well, that is, except for silkworms. What, do you expect Jesus to import his fancy robes from China?
Mnemonic2: In China it was believed that the silkworms were insects sent from heaven because of the beautiful material they produced.
Compo: 天: heavens; sky　虫: insect
疋: cloth; zoo; mending (RTK)　虫: insect
解: unravel; notes; key; explanation; understanding; untie; undo; solve; answer; cancel; absolve; explain; minute　虫: insect

Origin: Insect . . . plaid.
Mnemonic1: The mosquito (an insect) knows only one sentence: Bzzzzz.
Mnemonic2: Mosquitoes are the insect who love Scots in plaid kilts because it makes for easy access to the best parts.
Compo: 虫: insect　文: literature; plaid (RTK)

Mnemonic1: The 巳nd! Thanks all.
Mnemonic2: The snake likes stealing pieces from mosaics, so if you notice your mosaic has a piece missing, that’s a sign of the snake.
Compo: 巳: sign of the snake

Origin: Insect . . . house . . . spoon.
Mnemonic1: A snake eats insects and he does that outside, while we eat another snake in the house and preferably with a spoon.
Mnemonic2: Solid Snake crawled like a bug, infiltrated my house, and took out everyone with a spoon.
Compo: 虫: insect　宀: house (RTK)　匕: spoon

Origin: Though it's a good thing that the primitive for cocoon has been radically abbreviated from this, its full form as a kanji, the story it holds is a charming one. The silkworm (insect) eats the leaves of the mulberry bush (the flowers), digests them and transforms them into thread with which it spins about itself, in mystic wisdom, its own coffin (the hood). The dividing line that separates the two elements helps the picture of the little worm cutting itself off from contact with the outside world, but as a character stroke, it is a clear exception.
Mnemonic1: This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.
Mnemonic2: The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　冂: hood; belt (RTK)　糸: thread; Spider-Man (RTK)　虫: insect

Origin: Insect . . . generation . . . tree.
Mnemonic1: A butterfly is an insect that appears after spending a generation on a tree as a cocoon.
Mnemonic2: Butterflies are insects that like to eat just the flowers but leave the leaves behind. (helps me to think of the kanji for leaves, minus the flower bit).
Compo: 虫: insect　世: generation; world　木: tree; wood

Origin: Insect . . . craft.
Mnemonic1: Little is it known that a rainbow is actually created by insects of different colours flying in formation, a craft they have perfected to create the rainbows we see today.
Mnemonic2: Rainbow is of course created by billions of colored insects (what? you really thought it was an optical illusion?). However I had problems remembering that the insect primitive goes on the left. If you have similar difficulties, try this: rainbow is an Insect-Craft. Mnemonic: I.C. Rainbow (I see rainbow).
Compo: 虫: insect　工: craft; construction

Origin: When we hear the world inlay, we usually think of setting precious stones in pieces of jewelery, but the primitive elements here suggest truth being inlaid in the soil. You might think instead of the cosmic wisdom that inlaid the truth of the universe in the stuff of the earth.
Mnemonic1: In a hole in the ground, the body of the victim was placed. And then the killer stuffed it up so that the truth would not be found out, he hoped.
Mnemonic2: I stuffed up his mouth with dirt to keep the truth from coming out.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　真: truth
Kunyomi: は.まる、は.める、うず.める、しず.める、ふさ.ぐ

Origin: Now I am going to do something unusual. The character in this frame is going to get one meaning and the primitive another, with no relation at all between the two. In time, I hope you will see how helpful this is. The kanji key word, square jewel, depicts a mammoth precious stone, several feet high, made by piling up large heaps of soil on top of one another. Not something you would want to present your betrothed on your wedding day, but a good image for remembering this rare character, used chiefly in personal names nowadays.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, we shall use this character to mean ivy, that creepy vegetation that covers the surface of the ground to form a sort of "second" ground that can get somewhat tricky to walk on without tripping.
Mnemonic1: Piling SOIL upon SOIL for aeons is how SQUARE JEWELS are formed deep in the earth.
Mnemonic2: How would you stop someone stealing your biggest square jewel? Bury it deep in the soil under ground. Then plant ivy to mark the spot.
Compo: 土: ground; land; soil　土: ground; land; soil

Origin: These are the same carp you see in Japanese "carp streamers." Only here we find a small home computer or two strung on the line by a father anxious for his son not only to have the courage and determination of a carp swimming upstream, but also the efficiency and memory of a computer. Ugh.
Mnemonic1: Japanese carp are massive fish - they are measured in ri!
Mnemonic2: The fish got carpal tunnel syndrome from the computer(I know it´s lame but it´s hard to find a good story for this).
Compo: 魚: fish　里: village; computer (RTK)

Origin: Unless you are a botanist, you are not likely to know what a Japanese Judas-tree looks like, and probably never even heard of it before, but the name is sufficiently odd to make remembering it easy. Using the primitives as our guide, we define it as a tree with ivy growing down its branches in the shape of a hangman's rope.
Mnemonic1: Simple mnemonic : "The Japanese Judas-tree is the tree on which Judas hang himself to the ivy" (Judas the traitor of the Christian bible). Just picture Judas hanging himself, using ivy as a if it was a rope.
Mnemonic2: A tree covered in poison ivy will quickly betray you, thus the name JAPANESE JUDAS-TREE.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　圭: square jewel; Ivy (RTK)

Origin: This kanji calls to mind the famous myth of the "golden bough." As you may recall, what made the sacred oak in the forest of Diana the Huntress outside of Rome "golden" were the white berries of the mistletoe that grew in the branches of the tree. When the light of the sun shone through them, they turned yellow and the branch to which they clung appeared to be made of gold. (If you don't know the story, take a break today and hunt it down in a dictionary of myth and fable. Even if you forget the kanji - which of course you won't - the story of the mistletoe and the fate it brought to Balder the Beautiful is most memorable.)
Mnemonic1: The wood from oak trees can be used to make barrels in which white wine is aged. What´s more, I love white wine with an oaky flavour...
Mnemonic2: An oak tree is white, from left to right!
Compo: 木: tree; wood　白: white

Origin: Since apricots can be eaten just as they fall from the trees, picture this mouth agape at the bottom of a tree (just as the elements have it), waiting for apricots to fall into it.
Mnemonic1: From the tree straight into the mouth is the best way to eat an APRICOT!
Mnemonic2: Imagine Totoro sleeping under his tree. As he snores a giant apricot falls nicely into his open mouth and he emits a giant burp of satisfaction. I can hear that music alreay....to - to to - to - ro...
Compo: 木: tree; wood　口: mouth

Origin: Since you probably don't know what a paulownia tree is, we shall let the key word suggest the phrase "the Little Brothers of St. Paulownia." It is a short step to associate the tree with the monks to its right. (For the curious, the name of this oriental tree really comes from a Russian princess, Anna Pavlovna.)
Mnemonic1: In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the "princess tree". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her.
Mnemonic2: Paulownia is a Japanese tree which looks same as any other tree.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　同: same; equal; monk (RTK)

Origin: The splash this kanji refers to is the dash of water against the rocks, with all the foam and spray that this creates. If you think of a splash in this sense as a wave that has run its full course and reached its extremity, namely the seashore, and if you think of it pictorially in your mind's eye, this somewhat rare (but oh so-easy-to-learn) kanji is yours for good.
Mnemonic1: The extremity of a wave of water is the splash.
Mnemonic2: A splash is WATER that has reached its EXTREMITY.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　末: extremity

Origin: You've no doubt seen cattails, those swamp reeds with a furry flower to them like the tail of a cat. This might just turn out to be a good way to get rid of a troublesome pack of wild dogs: lure them into a swamp of these reeds with the cattail flowers and then set fire to the swamp. Take care to focus on the flower rather than the "cattail" to avoid confusion with frame 259 below.
Mnemonic1: REEDS are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker.
Mnemonic2: A reed is a flower that looks like a hot dog.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　犬: dog (犭)　火: fire (灬)

Origin: People who try to sound literary often end up butchering the language. Here we see a meeting of butchers whose mouths are producing the metaphors.
Mnemonic1: Metaphorically speaking, all the equipment in your mouth is basically just a meeting of butchers, designed to pulverize whatever meat you put in there.
Mnemonic2: Metaphor: A good metaphor flows from the mouth like the meeting of flesh and saber, smoothly piercing the listener with its meaning. But a bad metaphor is like when you barely nick the flesh and only spill two drops of blood or when your saber doesn't penetrate at all but rather bends into a くく shape when you whack the flesh. (Note: This story incorporates both the traditional form of the kanji (口＋兪) and the simplified form (口＋俞)) .
Compo: 口: mouth　亼: assemble; meeting　肉: meat; flesh (RTK) (月)　巛: river (川); flood (RTK)

Origin: Associating a particularly attractive woman you know with an angel should be no problem.
Mnemonic1: The most attractive woman in the world is obviously Angelina Jolie.
Mnemonic2: The most attractive of women are said to resemble angels. Similarly, angelic women tend to be attractive.
Compo: 女: woman　喬: high; angels (RTK)

Origin: This character, a pictograph of a spoon, is easy enough to remember, provided you keep it distinct from that for seven, where the first stroke is written left to right (the opposite of here) and cuts noticeably across the second.
SubOrigin: As a primitive, this kanji can take on the additional meaning of someone sitting on the ground, of which it can also be considered a pictograph. In general, the second stroke does not cut through the first - or if it does in some fonts, only slightly.
Mnemonic1: To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k.
Mnemonic2: Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the direction of a stroke. In both ´spoon´ and ´seven´, the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in ´seven´ it is a strong line from left to right.
Compo: 匕: spoon

Origin: Pent in . . . one. The key word refers to famous sayings of famous people, and is the origin for the primitive meaning of a tongue wagging in the mouth that we learned in frame 12. The size of this kanji, a relatively rare one, is what distinguishes it from day.
Mnemonic1: Sayeth?! Who the hell says "sayeth"? Doesn´t seem quite right...just like this kanji, which is just like "day" but doesn´t seem "quite right.".
Mnemonic2: When pent up alone, one sayeth little.
Compo: 囗: box; pent in (RTK)　一: one; ceiling, floor (RTK)
Kunyomi: いわ.く、のたま.う、のたま.わく、ここに、ひらび

Origin: Elbow . . . human legs.
Mnemonic1: In some Asian kung-fu version of James Bond, the main protagonist has a “License To Kill” with his deadly elbows and human legs. His suit is always stained of red blood at the elbows and lower legs (this to help create an image that distinguish the two elements).
Mnemonic2: A midget driver trying to pass the road test to get their driver´s license. Their elbows are too short to turn the wheel and their legs are too short to reach the gas and breaks.
Compo: 允: license

Origin: The key word refers to an ancient skirt once used as part of a woman's costume. The primitives you have to work with are: outhouse . . . garment.
Mnemonic1: Compared to pants, a SKIRT is the GARMENT to be wearing when you want to use one of those Japanese toilets. It makes it so much easier: you just walk in the OUTHOUSE hike it up, and do your business.
Mnemonic2: Haven´t you ever noticed that the men / women signs on the front of outhouses are sometimes very similar? The silhouettes are usually the same, but one will decidedly be wearing a garment in the shape of a SKIRT. Also, we´ve already learned the kanji for "woman", so if the signs are only in kanji you have no right to wander in and claim ignorance, perv!
Compo: 尚: esteem; outhouse (RTK)　衣: clothes; garment (RTK)

Origin: Bamboo . . . generation.
Mnemonic1: The bamboo generation smokes bamboo grass.
Mnemonic2: “One of the most attractive aspects of bamboo is that it is a renewable resource; it takes less than a year for a stalk to reach maturity, compared to the decades for most trees, whether needle or broadleaf.” -- Mnemonic : "bamboo grass is the next bamboo generation".
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　世: generation; world

Origin: Bamboo . . . dragon. Note that the older (and still official) form of this kanji uses the old character for dragon 龍, which is good to learn and is fun to write in any case. It is made up of five primitive elements: vase . . . flesh . . . slingshot . . . fishhook (enclosure) . . . three.
Mnemonic1: The only cage that can keep a dragon is made of bamboo.
Mnemonic2: A bamboo cage won´t hold a dragon!
Compo: 竹: bamboo (⺮)　竜: dragon
Kunyomi: かご、こ.める、こも.る、こ.む

Origin: Broom . . . rice grains . . . saber.
Mnemonic1: Peel off the outside of the broom that sweeps up rice grains to reveal a saber.
Mnemonic2: A multi-purpose broom! It cleans, it sweeps (rice!), it hits! In fact, peel off the mahogany exterior to uncover a sabre! It slices, it dices, it kills!
Compo: 彔: carve (录)　刀: sword; dagger, saber (RTK) (刂)

Origin: Water . . . cadet.
Mnemonic1: Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he´s very afraid of water (Bender is a robot).
Mnemonic2: The space cadet is in training, rowing in the water (see it splash).
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　曹: official; cadet (RTK)

Origin: The two tens joined at the bottom by a short line is actually the old character for twenty, which we might as well learn since we need its primitive form. It is written the same as salad, except for the shorter final stroke.
Mnemonic1: A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty.
Mnemonic2: Ten plus ten is twenty (see generation (#28)).
Compo: 廿: twenty; 20

Origin: Bow . . . elbow.
Mnemonic1: If you pull the bow back with your elbow, you can shoot a vast distance.
Mnemonic2: The valley was so vast that if you yelled elbow! you could hear it echo bow, bow, bow.
Compo: 弓: bow　厶: myself; elbow (RTK)

Origin: The strand referred to here is the stretch of land along a beach or shoreline. Its elements are: water . . . puppet.
Mnemonic1: I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn´t upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll!
Mnemonic2: A lovely romantic walk on the strand, splashing in the water with my love doll.
Compo: 水: water (氵) (氺)　者: person; puppet (RTK)

Origin: Scissors . . . head.
Mnemonic1: Your cheeks contain your jawbones, which are known as the "scissors of the head.".
Mnemonic2: The Joker from Batman had his cheeks cut with scissors to give him that eternal smile. Now the Joker isn´t right in the head.
Compo: 夾: scissors　頁: page; head (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . spicy.
Mnemonic1: The CATALPA is the tree that bears the SPICY Indian bean (NOTE - The Catalpa is also known as the "Indian Bean" due to the bean pods that grow from it).
Mnemonic2: The caterpillar´s favorite tree is the catalpa because it tastes spicy.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　辛: spicy (RTK)

Origin: Tree . . . springtime.
Mnemonic1: The tree of spring. Fact: Camellia are highly valued in Japan and elsewhere for their very early flowering, often among the first flowers to appear in the late winter (early spring?].
Mnemonic2: Anyone who´s lived in Japan knows camellia are by far the first tree of spring to flower. And how can you miss those shockingly pink flowers!
Compo: 木: tree; wood　春: springtime

Origin: Tree . . . south.
Mnemonic1: We traveled to southern Japan just to see a camphor tree. It´s what we came for.
Mnemonic2: Trivia: Cinnamomum camphora is native to Taiwan, southern Japan, southeast China and Indochina,.
Compo: 木: tree; wood　南: south

Origin: Vase . . . cliff . . . shape.
Mnemonic1: A lad standing on the top of a cliff, looking into the far, and thinking how to shape his future.
Mnemonic2: A young lad is standing atop a cliff, looking at the writhing shape of his fallen lass below.
Compo: 立: stand up; vase (RTK)　厂: cliff　彡: hair; shape (RTK)

Origin: Flowers . . . bay.
Mnemonic1: Bulrush was the flower that you could see near almost all bays in japan before the japanese started putting concrete everywhere. Just check how many percent of Japan´s coastline that is concretised... you´ll be surprised.
Mnemonic2: The bulrush is a flower that grows around bays. http://www.meltonrossnewbarnetby.co.uk/images/bulrush.jpg.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　水: water (氵) (氺)　甫: for the first time; dog tag (RTK)

Origin: Flower . . . bird.
Mnemonic1: In the jungle there is a flowery vine called hedera rhombea that attracts humming birds by the dozens. They scoot around the flowers sucking up nectar off the vine.
Mnemonic2: Note : if you´ll remember we already have a primitive for "ivy", but it was completely made up from the "square jewel" kanji. The kanji here refers to ivy, or vine, and is used in a particular compound for "Hedera rhombea", which is a type of ivy native to Japan. This vine here produces a lot of flowers, and attracts many small birds, which is sure to cheer up even the most depressed Japanese gardener.
Compo: 艸: grass; plants; flowers (艹, 龷)　鳥: bird
